abstract: Steven Spielberg’s new film, “The BFG,” yielded disappointing results, while “The Legend of Tarzan” exceeded the predictions of analysts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s big-budget summer lineup continued to falter over the weekend, at least in North America, as two movies carrying a combined $500 million in production and global marketing costs arrived to $57.7 million in total ticket sales.

headline: New York City F.C. Exacts Revenge Over Rival Red Bulls
abstract: After a 7-0 loss to the Red Bulls at home in May, New York City F.C. regrouped for a 2-0 victory and moved into first place in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: The Major League Soccer standings, and the area’s soccer pecking order, were both transformed a bit on Sunday at Yankee Stadium when New York City F.C. crafted a convincing 2-0 victory over the rival Red Bulls, with a goal and an assist from its rookie forward Jack Harrison.

headline: Courtney Lee Isn’t Flashy, but Knicks’ Latest Piece Fits
abstract: Lee, a solid 3-point shooter and a tenacious perimeter defender, does not bring the name recognition of Dwyane Wade. But considering Wade’s asking price, Lee may be the better fit.
lead_paragraph: The best part about the Knicks’ trade for Derrick Rose and their signing of Joakim Noah was that the two required almost no introduction. Rose, a former most valuable player, and Noah, once a defensive player of the year, may not be the players they once were, but their names still carry enough cachet to excite a notoriously harsh fan base.

headline: Guo Pei: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 couture collection from designer Guo Pei.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 couture collection from designer Guo Pei.

headline: Trade and Jobs: A Note
abstract: Beware of fallacies of composition.
lead_paragraph: Given Trump’s economic policy speech – well, “policy” speech – it seems time to brush up on trade and jobs, an issue I used to write a lot about. The big story in the academia/policy space lately has been the work of Autor et al, who in two papers have estimated large losses from Chinese import penetration. I basically agree with this conclusion, at least when we’re talking about manufacturing employment. But I’m troubled by some conceptual issues, which I think are important for interpreting the results.

headline: Wilmer Flores’s Hammer Wraps Up a Demolition of the Cubs’ Rotation
abstract: Flores hit two home runs and tied a franchise record against Chicago, and the Mets chased starter Jon Lester after only four outs.
lead_paragraph: As he stood on first base after his sixth hit of the game, Wilmer Flores flashed a small grin. Mets fans showered him with chants of “Wil-mer Flo-res!” His teammate Neil Walker waved his outstretched hands up and down from the dugout, either fanning the red-hot Flores or bowing to him.

headline: Review: ‘Il Trionfo’ and ‘Pelléas’ at the Aix-en-Provence Festival
abstract: Handel’s “Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno” and Debussy’s “Pelléas et Mélisande” are featured in this French festival.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Ghosts, girls and growing up: These were the specters hanging over a weekend of opera here.

headline: Garrison Keillor Turns Out the Lights on Lake Wobegon
abstract: The creator of “A Prairie Home Companion” signed off the air for good with sentimentality, Powdermilk Biscuits and a call from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Garrison Keillor’s “A Prairie Home Companion” signed off the air for good on Saturday evening, after 42 seasons, as millions of listeners, many in their cars on a holiday weekend, tuned in via public radio.

headline: Atelier Versace: Fall 2016
abstract: The label’s fall collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s fall collection.

headline: Review: ‘Bush,’ a Biography as Scathing Indictment
abstract: If George W. Bush eventually gets a more sympathetic hearing by history, as he hopes, it will not start with Jean Edward Smith’s new book.
lead_paragraph: For George W. Bush, the summer already looks unbearable. The party he gave his life to will repudiate him by nominating a bombastic serial insulter who makes the famously brash former president look like a museum docent by comparison. And a renowned presidential biographer is weighing in with a judgment that makes Mr. Bush’s gentleman’s Cs at Yale look like the honor roll.

headline: It’s an Art Gallery. No, a Living Room. O.K., Both.
abstract: Makeshift galleries have proliferated in unconventional spaces in response to high costs and a stratified art world beholden to curators and dealers.
lead_paragraph: There was wine in plastic cups and people milling around, but the similarity to any other art gallery opening ended there.

headline: Review: Rob McClure’s ‘Smile,’ a Glass That’s Always Half Full
abstract: Mr. McClure wittily explored the meaning behind famous song lyrics and performed comedic hand puppetry, but he saved the very best for last.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical, more than most popular art forms, has always been a land of hopes, dreams and happy endings. But all too often it is also a marketplace for a synthetic cheer that feels as authentic as a tense smile pasted on the face of a grumpy official greeter.

headline: Review: ‘Tumacho,’ a Rootin’-Tootin’ Musical, Keeps Its Poker Face
abstract: This absurdist spoof explores notions of masculinity in a Wild West saloon, without its cast’s cracking up. The audience needn’t worry about the same.
lead_paragraph: As the setting is a saloon in the wildest of Wests, it seems right fittin’ that every blessed member of the cast of “Tumacho,” which opened last week in a sweet tequila haze at the Wild Project in the East Village, is terrific at keeping a poker face. And, man, it can’t be easy.

headline: Black Man’s Fatal Encounter With Police Splits Mississippi City Known for Harmony
abstract: After Antwun Shumpert was fatally shot by a police officer last month, Tupelo, Miss., has been thrust into a national debate.
lead_paragraph: TUPELO, Miss. — The blue lights flashed in the rearview mirror of the Ford Focus. The man behind the wheel, a 37-year-old African-American, pulled over, opened the door and sprinted into the Mississippi night.

headline: Elie Wiesel Is Recalled at Funeral for a Legacy Beyond His Moral Voice
abstract: A small gathering of relatives and friends attended a funeral in Manhattan for Mr. Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and writer who died on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The funeral for Elie Wiesel was a gathering of his family and close friends, held on Sunday at a synagogue on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But outside on East 62nd Street stood people, some in tears, who had never met the man who survived the Holocaust to become a clarion voice for those victims who did not.

headline: Emirates Warn Against Traditional Clothing Abroad After Man Is Mistaken for Terrorist in Ohio
abstract: A businessman from Abu Dhabi was confronted by armed officers after a hotel clerk said she had overheard him pledging allegiance to ISIS, but the police later apologized.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates warned its citizens on Sunday to avoid wearing traditional clothing when traveling abroad, apparently in response to an episode in Ohio last week in which a businessman from Abu Dhabi, dressed in robes and a head scarf, was confronted by the police at gunpoint because a hotel clerk thought he might be a terrorist.

headline: As ISIS Loses Land, It Gains Ground in Overseas Terror
abstract: The Islamic State, the only terrorist group to actually create a state with borders, is becoming a larger, more sophisticated version of its stateless rival, Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In just the past few days, the Islamic State’s evolving brand of terrorism has revealed its deadly, shifting faces.

headline: Helpful Theorem
abstract: The return of the husband-and-wife team of Jill Denny and Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy birthday, U.S.A.! We have a crossword puzzle by the husband-and-wife team of Jill Denny and Jeff Chen to start off our solving week, and the theme is very clever. It involves a bit of math, though, so get into a division state of mind.

headline: In China, the ‘Noisiest Park in the World’ Tries to Tone Down Rowdy Retirees
abstract: It gets raucous in People’s Park, where older performers jostle for space, audiences and exercise, and some city residents have had enough of the din.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — As the Happy Runxin and Glad Tidings performing troupes squared off in the Chengdu People’s Park on a recent morning, the newly installed noise monitors flashed to life, their red digits registering each potential transgression by the park’s famously boisterous amateur dancers and musicians.

headline: Poland’s Conservative Government Puts Curbs on State TV News
abstract: The right-wing Law and Justice Party’s effort to impose its nationalist message on the state broadcaster has prompted wide concern about press freedom.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Poland — The ax fell for Piotr Maslak just 12 days into the new year, when his new boss at Poland’s state television told him that there was no way to work together anymore, citing “different perspectives.” Mr. Maslak, 40, agreed, and now says he is “proud of being the first” to be sent packing under the conservative government that took power seven months ago.

headline: Obama Will Need His Oratory Powers to Sell Globalization
abstract: At a time when Donald J. Trump and the pro-“Brexit” crowd are preaching nativism and nationalism, the president undertakes the delicate task of arguing the opposite.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama travels to North Carolina and Europe this week, he will press an argument that could define foreign policy in the last six months of his presidency: that Americans and Europeans must not forsake their open, interconnected societies for the nativism and nationalism preached by Donald J. Trump or Britain’s Brexiteers.

headline: Man Injured in Central Park Explosion
abstract: A young man’s leg was severely wounded after he stepped on what investigators believe was part of a homemade firework that had been left behind, the police said.
lead_paragraph: With a bright sun and an easy breeze, the morning had the makings of a perfect Sunday in Central Park for strolling visitors.

headline: Why Tech Support Is (Purposely) Unbearable
abstract: Worse, just as you suspected, companies know the torture they are putting you through, with cable and mobile service providers the most egregious offenders.
lead_paragraph: You may consider yourself even-keeled, the kind of person who is unflappable when those around you are losing their cool. But all that goes out the window when you call tech support. Then you fume. Your face turns red. You shout things into the phone that would appall your mother.

headline: Amazon Is Quietly Eliminating List Prices
abstract: As retailers face consumer lawsuits over discounts, Amazon is changing the way it presents bargains to customers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a major shift for online commerce, Amazon is quietly changing how it entices people to buy.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Upsets Londoners Who Find Harmony in a Cultural Cacophony
abstract: London, where 100 languages are spoken and three million residents come from other countries, can feel like a world apart. The referendum provided the latest reminder.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a few days after Britain had startled itself and much of the world by electing to leave the European Union in the “Brexit” referendum, and Narrinder Bahia and Arvin Singh were sitting on the grass in Hyde Park, trying to take in what had happened.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 4
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, which will be held Tuesday as the markets will be closed Monday for Independence Day. The regular four-week bill auction also will be held Tuesday.

headline: The Language of Potholes in the Spring
abstract: A poem about the inevitable cavities, Sizes A, B and C to street workers, that appear after the ice melts and the weather warms.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: At Wimbledon, a Rare Sunday for Play Brings Out the Adventure in One Fan
abstract: An avid tennis fan from New York makes a whirlwind trip to Wimbledon just for the day.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For only the fourth time in 130 Wimbledons, there was play on the first Sunday.

headline: White House Prohibits Cabinet From Addressing Democratic Convention
abstract: The new policy is intended to avoid the appearance that the administration is being consumed by the campaign as officials walk a fine political, and sometimes legal, line.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has forbidden members of President Obama’s cabinet to address the Democratic National Convention this month, a stark break from past policy that is intended to avoid the appearance that the administration’s final months are being consumed by the politics of Hillary Clinton’s campaign.

headline: Iceland’s Run in Euro 2016 Ends With Frenetic First Half for France
abstract: France defeated Iceland, 5-2, after scoring four goals before halftime in a European Championships quarterfinal. It will face Germany in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — For the last three weeks, Iceland’s men’s soccer team played with will and whimsy and wonder, the tiniest among the minnows at this European Championships stunning the soccer world as it wrote a fairy tale that kept getting better. But then, on Sunday, France needed little more than 20 minutes to suddenly, and sharply, scrawl down the harshest of endings.

headline: Novak Djokovic’s Early Exit Makes Wimbledon Anyone’s Title
abstract: The defeat of the top-ranked Djokovic opens the competition to anyone from home favorite Andy Murray to American Sam Querrey, who beat Djokovic on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Sunday was an unusual day for Wimbledon to be open for business, which seemed just right considering that this Grand Slam tournament is no longer business as usual with Novak Djokovic out of contention.

headline: After Slaughter, Bangladesh Reels at Revelations About Attackers
abstract: The men tied to the bloody restaurant siege in Dhaka, all in their late teens and early 20s, were products of Bangladesh’s elite.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s capital city reeled in shock on Sunday as clues began to flood social media about the privileged backgrounds of the half-dozen attackers believed to have butchered 20 patrons of a restaurant during a bloody siege here late last week.

headline: Sheryl Swoopes Out as Women’s Coach at Loyola University Chicago
abstract: The departure of Swoopes, a three-time W.N.B.A. most valuable player, follows accusations that she had mistreated her players at Loyola University Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Swoopes, one of the most celebrated and accomplished players in women’s basketball history, is no longer the head coach at Loyola University Chicago, Athletic Director Steve Watson announced on Sunday. The announcement came three months after the university revealed an investigation into accusations that Swoopes mistreated players during her three seasons leading the Ramblers’ women’s team.

headline: Donald Trump’s Star of David Tweet Came From a Fringe Website, a Report Says
abstract: A post by Mr. Trump involving Star of David imagery and Hillary Clinton was traced to a message board known for anti-Semitism and white supremacy.
lead_paragraph: The Star of David imagery used in a Twitter post by Donald J. Trump this weekend had previously appeared on a message board known for anti-Semitism and white supremacy, as well as on a Twitter account with a history of racially charged comments, according to a report.

headline: Mark Teixeira Hits 400th Home Run as Power Hitting Pushes Yankees Past Padres
abstract: Teixeira scored his milestone 400th home run in the eighth inning on Sunday, then hit another in the ninth to score Brett Gardner.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In a season filled with frustration for the Yankees, nobody has been more agitated than Mark Teixeira. First he hurt his neck, then he hurt his knee. And if his body did not ache all the time, his bat certainly did, as he went more than two months without a home run.

headline: Investors Watch Bank of England for Brexit Plan as U.S. Releases Jobs Report
abstract: The bank is expected to take near-term action to ease the stress of Britain’s exit from the European Union. And American analysts are hoping for a bounce in hiring numbers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the week ahead.

headline: Doc Gooden and Darryl Strawberry on Their Intertwined Roads to Recovery
abstract: “Doc & Darryl” is a documentary about two former Mets whose talents were briefly realized before their careers were derailed by drug suspensions, arrests and jail time.
lead_paragraph: In the new ESPN “30 for 30” documentary, “Doc & Darryl,” Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry face each other in a diner in Maspeth, N.Y. — former Mets who are not close friends but were brought together by filmmakers hoping to ignite a conversation between the two recovering addicts.

headline: Olympics Ease an Ad Blackout, and Brands Flood the Field
abstract: A move to improve relations with athletes by giving their sponsors more leeway may not sit well with companies that pay millions for official status.
lead_paragraph: Some called it a gag rule impinging on freedom of speech. Others bristled at the requirement to abandon longtime sponsors at the very moment they would be entering the international spotlight.

headline: New Jersey Savors Reprieve From Gas-Tax Increase, but Halt in Roadwork Looms
abstract: A disagreement between Gov. Chris Christie and state lawmakers delayed a rise of 23 cents a gallon, forcing the state to plan a shutdown of nonessential road projects.
lead_paragraph: SEA BRIGHT, N.J. — Amid a sea of beach umbrellas in this Jersey Shore town, Rob Sutton was smiling about more than the sun and sand.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, July 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “ISIS says, ‘We kill Shiites,’ but I lost my dearest friends to me in this explosion, and they were Sunnis.”

headline: How Anti-Growth Sentiment, Reflected in Zoning Laws, Thwarts Equality
abstract: A growing body of economic literature suggests that efforts in America aimed at things like “maintaining neighborhood character” contribute to segregation and lead to stagnation.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — The small city of Boulder, home to the University of Colorado’s flagship campus, has a booming local economy and a pleasantly compact downtown with mountain views. Not surprisingly, a lot of people want to move here.

headline: Consummate Hitter Ichiro Suzuki Comes in Contact With an Irrefutable Number
abstract: Miami’s Suzuki, 42, after eclipsing a quasi-milestone that raised the ire of Pete Rose, now sets his sights on 3,000 hits in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Sitting at his locker in the visitors’ clubhouse at Turner Field, filing his fingernails in preparation for his 2,424th game in the majors, Ichiro Suzuki was the portrait of calm.

headline: A Brooklyn Neighborhood Where Airbnb Is Being Put to the Test
abstract: A new study contends that New York City rents have risen fastest in gentrifying areas like Bedford-Stuyvesant, where Airbnb is the most widespread.
lead_paragraph: Bedford-Stuyvesant, a historically African-American neighborhood in Brooklyn, has become one of the latest battlegrounds in the war between New York City and Airbnb.

headline: As Self-Driving Cars Hit the Road, Innovation Is Outpacing Insurance
abstract: The recent death involving Tesla’s Autopilot feature underscored the technology’s risks. But the advances have gotten ahead of insurers’ ability to factor self-driving systems into their policies.
lead_paragraph: Advances in self-driving car technology have gotten ahead of insurers’ ability to factor the systems into auto premiums.

headline: A Long Swim to Rio
abstract: The United States’ top swimmers spent the last week at the Olympic trials in Omaha, all fighting for berths in the Rio de Janeiro Games.
lead_paragraph: The United States’ top swimmers spent the last week at the Olympic trials in Omaha, all fighting for berths in the Rio de Janeiro Games.

headline: Michael Phelps Heads to Fifth Games Saturated With Wisdom
abstract: Once a wide-eyed kid and now a waterlogged veteran, Phelps was eager to provide guidance to a young team of Americans, the majority of whom were first-time Olympians.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Of all Michael Phelps’s feats, this one may be the most remarkable: He has been to four Olympics without once having to perform a skit in front of the other American swimmers.

headline: Drone Strike Statistics Answer Few Questions, and Raise Many
abstract: The Obama administration’s release of the civilian death toll from targeted drone attacks revealed an uncertainty about whom it had killed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The promise of the armed drone has always been precision: The United States could kill just the small number of dangerous terrorists it wanted to kill, leaving nearby civilians unharmed.

headline: A Beach Club in Queens Where Every Summer Is the Same
abstract: The Silver Gull Beach Club is part of a disappearing world of private waterfront clubs in New York City.
lead_paragraph: “Changes? This place never changes,” Dave Gelfman, 101, said as he leaned back in his beach chair at his regular spot at the Silver Gull Beach Club and pressed his feet on the warm concrete deck.

headline: Dhaka Victims Were a Diverse Group of Global Citizens
abstract: Among the 20 victims were Italian entrepreneurs, Japanese engineers, students from America and a Bangladeshi activist. Here is what we know about them.
lead_paragraph: The attack on Holey Artisan Bakery in Dhaka, Bangladesh, killed 20 restaurant patrons who were thriving in an interconnected world. Nine of the victims were Italian, most of whom worked in the apparel trade. Seven were Japanese experts in Dhaka to help improve the city’s chronic traffic congestion. Three were students at American universities who had gone to high school together in Dhaka, and one was a Bangladeshi woman who worked for nonprofit groups and was passionate about the arts. Two police officers who responded to the attack were also killed.

headline: Donald Jelinek, Lawyer for Attica Prisoners, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Jelinek also represented civil rights workers in the South and Native Americans who seized Alcatraz Island to air their grievances against the government.
lead_paragraph: Donald Jelinek, who quit a Wall Street law firm to defend civil rights workers in the South and later inmates accused in the Attica prison revolt and Indians who seized Alcatraz Island to dramatize their grievances against the government, died on June 24 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Justin Gatlin Zips to His Third Olympics in Winning the 100 Meters
abstract: Gatlin’s time, 9.80 seconds, was the fastest in the world this year.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Justin Gatlin pointed his left index finger into the sky as he surged across the finish line late Sunday afternoon to secure a first-place finish in the men’s 100-meter race at the United States track and field trials.

headline: A Space Pioneer, 79, Is Ready to Track Juno for NASA
abstract: Susan G. Finley, whose career with NASA spans more than five decades, will monitor signals from the explorer Juno on the Fourth of July, when it is expected to reach Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: Susan G. Finley began working on rockets before NASA existed.

headline: Suicide Bomber Attacks Near U.S. Consulate in Jidda, Saudi Arabia
abstract: The early-morning blast, near a hospital across from the consulate, injured two people, according to the Saudi state news agency.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber blew himself up near the American consulate in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, early Monday morning, injuring two people, the Saudi government said in a statement to its official news agency.

headline: Corrections: July 4, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, July 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Take your pick of three options to watch Fourth of July fireworks on the small screen. And “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” comes to iTunes.
lead_paragraph: With three options to watch Fourth of July fireworks from home, you shouldn’t be left wanting. And the portentously titled “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” makes its way to iTunes.

headline: Vashti Cunningham, Daughter of an N.F.L. Improvisor, Is Raising the Bar
abstract: The 18-year-old Cunningham, the offspring of the former N.F.L. quarterback Randall Cunningham, will compete at the Rio Olympics in the high jump.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Randall Cunningham, the former cutting-edge N.F.L. quarterback, is now a soft-spoken minister and the coach of a high-jumping prodigy, who happens to be his daughter, Vashti Cunningham. On Sunday, she qualified for the Rio Olympics a month after graduating from high school.

headline: Dear Muslim Americans:
abstract: A reader denounces Donald Trump and offers hospitality.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: High Vaccine Prices
abstract: Doctors Without Borders writes that “vaccines are useless if they sit on shelves priced out of the reach of the children who need them most.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eliminate Aid for For-Profit Colleges
abstract: A reader says the “best way to protect students from bad and predatory colleges” is to give financial aid only for public and nonprofit colleges.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Giving Clinton Her Due
abstract: Of the two flawed presidential candidates, one is clearly out-campaigning the other.
lead_paragraph: It is easy in an election cycle that has seen the improbable rise of the preposterous presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump to center all discussion about the race on him: how poorly he’s doing, how outrageous this week’s comments were, how damning a new investigative report into his past has proved.

headline: Trump, Trade and Workers
abstract: Bashing China doesn’t make you labor’s friend.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump gave a speech on economic policy last week. Just about every factual assertion he made was wrong, but I’m not going to do a line-by-line critique. What I want to do, instead, is talk about the general thrust: the candidate’s claim to be on the side of American workers.

headline: National Monuments Tell America’s Story
abstract: Readers call for more designations by President Obama, and applaud his naming of Stonewall.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Flag on Iwo Jima
abstract: A reader writes that the discovery that a Marine in the famous photo was misidentified may be beside the point.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Exodus in Our Own Backyard
abstract: President Obama has spoken with sympathy of the families and young children fleeing violence in Central America. But he has done too little.
lead_paragraph: The United States often faces global crises that force it to balance incompatible interests. But there is one test, close to home, whose answers are straightforward.

headline: Did a Fear of Slave Revolts Drive American Independence?
abstract: To the founders, separation from Britain was about racial fear and exclusion as much as it was about inalienable rights.
lead_paragraph: Binghamton, N.Y. — FOR more than two centuries, we have been reading the Declaration of Independence wrong. Or rather, we’ve been celebrating the Declaration as people in the 19th and 20th centuries have told us we should, but not the Declaration as Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin and John Adams wrote it. To them, separation from Britain was as much, if not more, about racial fear and exclusion as it was about inalienable rights.

headline: The Salmon’s Swim for Survival
abstract: The best option for the fish would be to breach, bypass or remove one or more of the four big dams on the Lower Snake River.
lead_paragraph: There are two recent pieces of welcome news affecting the Pacific Northwest’s beleaguered salmon populations — battered by dams, habitat loss, timid government agencies and global warming.

headline: Freedom, Fireworks and Brexit
abstract: On this Fourth of July, perhaps Americans should proclaim another break with Britain, this time with its misguided vote to turn back the clock.
lead_paragraph: This year, the commemoration of the break with the British Empire on the Fourth of July is particularly rich in material for mulling the state of democracy and trans-Atlantic relations.

headline: Fire, Not Fireworks
abstract: With drought and wildfires ravaging parts of the West, there will be no fireworks in our California backyard to celebrate the nation’s birth.
lead_paragraph: Santa Barbara, Calif. — RECENTLY, after a wildfire had ravaged the canyons a few miles away, the kids and I were eating dinner. Suddenly, we heard the pop of firecrackers igniting over the dry fields behind us. The boys jumped; the dogs howled, and soon a wailing police car whizzed by. We held our breath and waited for the proverbial five-bell alarm.

headline: There Is No Scientific Method
abstract: Why are the results of science considered more reliable than those from other forms of human inquiry, like poetry or philosophy?
lead_paragraph: The author has appended a response to reader comments at the bottom of this article.

headline: Suicide Bombings Hit 3 Cities in Saudi Arabia, One Near a Holy Site
abstract: The explosions, including near the Prophet’s Mosque in Medina, followed a bloody week of Islamic State attacks in other countries during Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Bombings rocked three cities across Saudi Arabia on Monday, including near the Prophet’s Mosque in the holy city of Medina, raising the specter of increasingly coordinated attacks by militants seeking to destabilize the monarchy.

headline: Midea of China Moves a Step Closer to Takeover of Kuka of Germany
abstract: A purchase of a one-quarter stake in the German robotics company makes Midea the largest Kuka shareholder as it seeks all of the company.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese appliance maker has struck a $1.3 billion deal that brings it closer to taking over a German robotics company, a proposed transaction that has stirred concerns in Germany about Chinese purchases of the country’s industrial skills.

headline: Proud to Live in a Town Called Dildo
abstract: Residents of Dildo, Newfoundland, are eager to dispel misguided notions about where their town got its name.
lead_paragraph: An hour’s drive from the town of Come By Chance, past Spread Eagle Island, there is a large green traffic sign that often functions as its very own destination: “Dildo,” the sign proclaims, with an arrow pointing straight ahead.

headline: In Dissents, Sonia Sotomayor Takes On the Criminal Justice System
abstract: Justice Sotomayor’s dissents this term came mostly in criminal cases, and were informed as much by events in Ferguson, Mo., in 2014 as by those in Philadelphia in 1787.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court term had barely gotten underway in early November when Justice Sonia Sotomayor issued her first dissent. A police officer’s “rogue conduct,” she wrote, had left a man dead thanks to a “‘shoot first, think later’ approach to policing.”

headline: Tammany Hall’s Auditorium, Where Politics Once Took Center Stage, Will Be Demolished
abstract: The auditorium will not be preserved as part of a conversion of the Manhattan building from an Off Broadway theater to a six-story office space.
lead_paragraph: Independence Day 1929 was a great one for Tammany Hall.

headline: Benjamin Netanyahu Traces Path to Power Back to Entebbe, and Lost Brother
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke at an airport in Uganda 40 years after a daring raid there killed his brother and propelled him into politics.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Whenever he is facing a critical decision, whether for his country’s military or his own personal life, there is one person Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel says he routinely consults: his dead brother.

headline: Fashion Cheers the Reopening of the Paris Ritz
abstract: After four years, Anna Wintour, Amanda Harlech and company can return to their second home.
lead_paragraph: This may be a Paris couture season marked by external unease — by Brexit shock waves, anticipation of upheaval at two haute maisons, continued terrorism fears — but it is also one framed by a certain kind of insider celebration.

headline: The House That Love Built — Before It Was Gone
abstract: For Monica Vitti, Eileen Gray and Frank Lloyd Wright, their homes were the culmination of passionate affairs. And the places they ended.
lead_paragraph: For Monica Vitti, Eileen Gray and Frank Lloyd Wright, their homes were the culmination of passionate affairs. And the places they ended.

headline: In New Zealand, Centuries of Smoke
abstract: There’s always steam rising from White Island, a marine volcano off the country’s North Island. Just check a Maori legend or a day-old Instagram post.
lead_paragraph: WHITE ISLAND, New Zealand — A foul smell hangs in the air over White Island, a marine volcano in New Zealand’s Bay of Plenty, and steam hisses from rocks stained bright yellow from centuries of sulfur exposure. In a country that revels in its association with the “Lord of the Rings” movies, J. R. R. Tolkien’s orcs and elves wouldn’t appear out of place here.

headline: Nigel Farage, Who Spurred ‘Brexit,’ Resigns as Head of U.K. Independence Party
abstract: Mr. Farage, the politician who probably did more than any other to force the referendum on British membership in the European Union, resigned on Monday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He spent nearly 20 years pushing for Britain to leave the European Union, and having succeeded in his aim, he is now taking his leave.

headline: Horror and Sorrow in Dhaka
abstract: A terrorist attack on a café has struck a blow against Bangladesh’s very idea of itself.
lead_paragraph: When I was last in Dhaka, I used to take my son out in the car every afternoon. “Let’s go to Holey!” He would cry out from the back seat.

headline: Schiaparelli: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall Couture Collection of Schiaparelli.
lead_paragraph: Fall Couture Collection of Schiaparelli.

headline: Ling Jihua, Ex-Presidential Aide in China, Gets Life Sentence for Corruption
abstract: Mr. Ling joins two other notable senior party officials in receiving a lifetime prison sentence for graft.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have sentenced Ling Jihua, the top aide of a former president and Communist Party chief, to life in prison for corruption, according to the state news media.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservative Mudslinging, and George Osborne Calls for Tax Cuts
abstract: Michael Gove was criticized as having an “emotional need to gossip,” and Mr. Osborne said that he wanted to reduce Britain’s corporate tax to 15 percent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A lawsuit could threaten “Brexit.” George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, wants to cut taxes to bolster the economy. And contenders to replace David Cameron as Conservative Party leader (and therefore prime minister) are throwing dirt before the first round of voting.

headline: Iris Van Herpen: Fall 2016
abstract: The fall 2016 couture collection from designer Iris Van Herpen.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2016 couture collection from designer Iris Van Herpen.

headline: Not Forgotten: The Fourth, a Star-Spangled Birthday
abstract: We culled our archives for people born on the Fourth of July to explore what, if anything, they had in common.
lead_paragraph: We culled our archives for people born on the Fourth of July to explore what, if anything, they had in common.

headline: After Brexit, Can Germany Lead Europe Alone?
abstract: The British exit from the E.U. has put Angela Merkel and her colleagues in a tough position amid nationalistic shifts on the Continent.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Whether Britain’s decision to leave the European Union turns out to be a disaster or just a bump in the road for Europe on its path to unification, one consequence is already abundantly, disturbingly clear: Brexit will cement Germany’s role as the Continent’s leader — a role that neither Germany nor anybody else is entirely comfortable with.

headline: British Court Convicts Former Barclays Employees Over Libor Rigging
abstract: The trial followed a half-decade investigation that has led to billions of dollars in fines, and it has rocked the reputations of some of the world’s biggest banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British jury has convicted three former employees of Barclays of plotting to improve the bank’s trading results by “dishonestly rigging” an important benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: Australian Candidates Woo Allies as Election Deadlock Continues
abstract: Neither the governing Liberal National coalition nor the Labor Party won enough seats outright to form a government.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The two men seeking to emerge as Australia’s prime minister after national elections on Saturday, Malcolm Turnbull and Bill Shorten, have begun a delicate courtship of a handful of lawmakers who are likely to hold the balance of power in the next Parliament.

headline: Israelis’ Favorite Thing About Donald Trump? His Style (to Put It Bluntly)
abstract: While Israelis have mixed views of Mr. Trump’s policy proposals, they admiringly describe him as “dugri,” a slang Hebrew term derived from the Arabic for “straight ahead.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Donald J. Trump has been called a lot of things by a lot of people around the world. In Israel, where his comments about remaining “neutral” in peace negotiations raised hackles but his condemnation of “radical Islam” wins plaudits, the word that keeps coming up is “dugri.”

headline: Malaysia Links Nightclub Attack to Islamic State
abstract: The episode, which wounded eight people in Puchong, was thought to have been the first assault in Malaysia tied to the militant group.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A grenade attack at a nightclub in Malaysia last week was the work of the Islamic State, and two men who received instructions from a fighter for the group have been arrested, the Malaysian authorities said on Monday.

headline: Partying on Both Sides of the Champs-Élysées
abstract: Miu Miu set up a supper club and amfAR raised money for AIDS research as the couture season kicked off.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The couture season began with a coup. Coupe de Champagne, that is.

headline: 1966: Brick Narrowly Misses Queen
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: During her visit in Belfast in July 1966, the Queen Elizabeth II narrowly escapes a falling brick.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in July 1966. British Pathé.

headline: Chaotic Building Spree Dismays Some in Seaside Georgian City
abstract: A former president’s determination to give Georgia a more contemporary look has left Batumi’s skyline a bizarre mash-up of architectural styles.
lead_paragraph: BATUMI, Georgia — Once a staid seaside resort in the Soviet Union, this frontier city has undergone an extreme face-lift, the legacy of former President Mikheil Saakashvili’s determination to give Georgia a more contemporary, jazzier look.

headline: Off-Duty Officer Fatally Shoots Man in Brooklyn Traffic Dispute
abstract: The authorities were still trying to determine what prompted the killing, which happened early on Monday in the Cypress Hills neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: An off-duty New York City police officer who had just finished his shift shot and killed a man during a traffic dispute early on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: What to Expect During Juno’s Mission to Jupiter
abstract: The NASA spacecraft will orbit the gas giant 37 times in 20 months, with the hopes it will collect data and images that offer clues to the origins of our solar system.
lead_paragraph: With the exception of the sun, Jupiter is bigger than everything in the solar system put together. But little is known about the interior beneath its colorful cloud stripes.

headline: Christian Dior: Fall 2016
abstract: Looks from the Dior Collection
lead_paragraph: Looks from the Dior Collection

headline: Paris Couture Week: Guo Pei — and a Miu Miu Party
abstract: A photo diary of the collections presented on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the collections presented on Sunday.

headline: London Stock Exchange Shareholders Approve Deutsche Börse Merger
abstract: Support for the deal came after Britain voted last month to leave the European Union, a move that led to questions about whether the agreement could be completed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shareholders in the London Stock Exchange Group approved on Monday plans to merge with Deutsche Börse in an all-stock deal that the stock exchange operators hope will create a European champion in the industry.

headline: Branding Day, Fading Elsewhere, Still a Ritual on Colorado Ranch
abstract: Technology has changed much in the West. But on Bill Gray’s ranch in Colorado, they’re preserving the roping and riding skills that make a cowboy a cowboy.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Time has changed much in the American West. On some ranches, cowboys round up cattle on four-wheelers and track livestock with drones. While technology is easing tasks, though, some think it is also threatening the skills that make a cowboy a cowboy: roping, riding and a near-religious devotion to hard work.

headline: Recipes, Fireworks, Songs
abstract: Reflect on a Fourth of July speech by Frederick Douglass, then get cooking.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Democratic and Republican Conventions Lure and Repel Visitors to Host Cities
abstract: Travelers should expect convenient lodging, transportation and other needs to be difficult to obtain in Cleveland and Philadelphia later this month.
lead_paragraph: With tens of thousands of out-of-towners expected to descend on Philadelphia and Cleveland this month for the political conventions, most other travelers may want to stay away. But whether for business meetings, personal visits or other reasons, many others will not be able to avoid traveling to those cities.

headline: What Poison Ivy Has Against Us
abstract: Most people know, and fear, the distinctive three-leaf pattern in the wild. Do other animals have to avoid it, too?
lead_paragraph: Q. Are any animals besides humans affected by poison ivy?

headline: Rabies Test Strips Are Found to Be Unsatisfactory
abstract: Diagnostic strips made by six companies “cannot be recommended” because of high false-negative rates, according to scientists in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Rabies  kills about 60,000 people a year, many of them children in Africa and Asia. Rapid tests for the infection are badly needed in poor countries.

headline: Garth Brooks Is Returning to New York to ‘Shake Things Up’
abstract: Mr. Brooks, the top-selling solo artist in United States history, will come back to the city after nearly 20 years to perform at Yankee Stadium this weekend.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Garth Brooks’s last show in New York City, The New York Times described him as “Garth Brooks, a country music superstar whose style is about as foreign to New York City as Lou Reed’s is to Oklahoma, Mr. Brooks’s home state,” and warned of “hard-nosed New Yorkers” who might “shudder at the thought of hearing country music.”

headline: After Attacks, Lebanese Christian Town Casts Wary Eye on Syrian Refugees
abstract: A wave of deadly suicide bombings in the quiet town of Al Qaa has strained a tenuous coexistence between residents and newcomers fleeing Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: AL QAA, Lebanon — The mourners packed the vast hall behind the Mar Elias Church and crowded around five white coffins, some clutching flowers or photographs of the dead. A marching band struck up a dirge, and relatives of the deceased raised their arms, wailing and swaying with the rhythm.

headline: 1916: Russians Take 2,700 Prisoners
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In July 1916, the Russians take 2,700 prisoners in the Baranovitchi region.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The most encouraging news continues to arrive from Petrograd. Latest despatches indicate that the Austro-German counter-offensive between the Stokhod and the Styr has been broken, while the Tsar’s troops, having inflicted enormous losses upon the enemy, are again attacking with energy. Several days ago the Herald forecast heavy fighting in the region of Baranovitchi, and an important Russian victory in this sector, with the capture of nearly 3,000 officers and men, eleven guns and many machine-guns, is now officially announced. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 5, 1916

headline: Donald Trump Meets With Senator Joni Ernst, a Possible Running Mate
abstract: Ms. Ernst, of Iowa, served in the Army in Iraq and could help the presumptive Republican nominee attract women and ease concern about his lack of military experience.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump met in New Jersey on Monday with Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, as he screens potential running mates in a series of meetings.

headline: Kevin Durant to Join the Golden State Warriors
abstract: Durant, one of the highest-caliber players to ever enter the free agent market, chose to leave for Golden State after playing almost his entire career in Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: The biggest question of the N.B.A. off-season was answered Monday when Kevin Durant, one of the best players ever to hit unrestricted free agency in any sport, agreed to join the Golden State Warriors.

headline: America!
abstract: Some patriotic number teasers to enliven your Fourth of July.
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Daniel Finkel of Math for Love, the Seattle-based team out to transform math education through games and teacher workshops. With the Brexit campaign making headlines, the words “Independence Day” have never felt more loaded. Here are a pair of July 4 puzzles to celebrate American Independence.

headline: David Hockney Takes a Fresh Look at Portraiture
abstract: His new exhibition in London features rainbow-hued canvases that are less a study in psychology than in body language, gesture and idiosyncrasy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He may be turning 79 this month, but David Hockney shouldn’t be mistaken for an aging technophobe. His last major British show, an exhibition of landscapes at the Royal Academy of Arts in 2012, included a gallery of works that had been composed on an iPad, then printed out in extra-large format.

headline: Consciousness: The Mind Messing With the Mind
abstract: Science is struggling to figure out if we, or even a thermostat, truly possess matter beyond the physical.
lead_paragraph: A paper in The British Medical Journal in December reported that cognitive behavioral therapy — a means of coaxing people into changing the way they think — is as effective as Prozac or Zoloft in treating major depression.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Hannibal’ and ‘Star Trek’ Films
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Drake’s ‘Views’ Rules the Music Chart for Ninth Week
abstract: The streak is the longest since Adele’s “21” notched 10 straight weeks at the beginning of 2012.
lead_paragraph: Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake, Drake.

headline: ISIS Bombing in Baghdad Casts Doubt on Iraqi Leader’s Ability to Unite
abstract: After at least 155 people were killed in a car bombing in Baghdad, Iraq’s leader tried to assuage the public’s anger and grief by speeding the executions of militants.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As grief-stricken Iraqis held a candlelight vigil Sunday night at the site of a car bombing that killed more than 150 people, workers often using the flashlights from their cellphones were still pulling bodies from the rubble.

headline: Poaching Leaves Elephant Daughters in Charge
abstract: As illegal hunting thins out the ranks of matriarchs, their daughters are taking over as leaders of their social groups.
lead_paragraph: SAMBURU NATIONAL RESERVE, Kenya — The Land Cruiser bumped and rattled over the lush, tawny savanna dotted with acacia trees.

headline: Trump’s Rise Inspires a Rush to Publish (and Exhume) Books About Him
abstract: Every election brings a wave of political books, but this year is already exceptional in terms of how many have Donald Trump as the central character.
lead_paragraph: On his bedroom wall, the New Yorker writer Mark Singer has a framed, handwritten note from Donald J. Trump. “Mark, you are a total loser! And your book (and writings) sucks!” the note says.

headline: South Korea Targets Executives, Pressed by an Angry Public
abstract: Long seen as lenient on businesses, South Korea is increasingly seeking to prosecute company officials to address public anger over corporate misbehavior.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Looking for answers after the deaths of scores of children and pregnant women from a mysterious lung ailment, a group of families in South Korea began to focus on a potential cause: a cleaner called Oxy.

headline: Chris Evans to Step Down as ‘Top Gear’ Presenter
abstract: The popular BBC entertainment show, which features cars and testosterone-fueled antics, has suffered from sagging ratings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The presenter Chris Evans announced on Monday that he was stepping down from “Top Gear,” the popular BBC entertainment show whose mix of cars and testosterone-fueled antics had attracted a global following.

headline: From Vetements to Versace, Couture Without Borders
abstract: Opening the season by opening up fashion’s most elite art to a host of new influences and actors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Walls, metaphorical and literal, may be the political buzzwords of the moment as a tide of xenophobia sweeps Europe and the United States, but in Paris, as the couture shows began, inclusion was the message.

headline: Donald Trump Finds Himself Playing Catch-Up in All-Important Ohio
abstract: As Republicans head to Cleveland to nominate Mr. Trump in two weeks, a vortex of headwinds are rising against him in the crucial battleground state.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Since the Republican Party’s 19th-century founding, not one of its nominees has won the White House without carrying Ohio, a most diverse and perennially hard-fought state.

headline: Hiding From Windows 10
abstract: Sharing your location with your apps and operating system has its advantages. But if you’d rather not, you can disable the function.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I stop Windows 10 from using my laptop’s location?

headline: When the Cost of a Medical Emergency Adds Up
abstract: Consumers Union and a doctor discuss the privatization of these services.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New Payday Options for Making Ends Meet
abstract: Employers and start-ups are testing ways to give employees faster access to their wages.
lead_paragraph: For decades, most American companies have paid their workers once every week or two, minimizing the administrative costs of frequent paydays and maximizing the interest the companies earn by keeping the money in the bank.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Viceland’s latest documentary series, “Black Market,” has its premiere. And on Hulu, “The Mindy Project” wraps up its fourth season.
lead_paragraph: Viceland makes its latest foray into daring documentaries with “Black Market,” a project by the “Wire” actor Michael K. Williams. Online, the third and final season of “Hannibal” is ready for your binge-watching pleasure on Amazon, and “The Mindy Project” wraps up its fourth season on Hulu.

headline: In His New Novel, Ben Winters Dares to Mix Slavery and Sci-Fi
abstract: “Underground Airlines,” which has a white author and a black narrator, lands in a thicket of fictional works about slavery and its lingering legacy in America.
lead_paragraph: In Ben H. Winters’s chilling new thriller, “Underground Airlines,” a bounty hunter named Victor tracks fugitives for the United States Marshals Service. But his mission, like his past, is complicated: The people he’s chasing are escaped slaves. Their main crime is rejecting a life of forced servitude. And Victor himself was once one of them.

headline: Dominika Cibulkova Advances at Wimbledon, Meaning Her Wedding May Have to Wait
abstract: Cibulkova, the No. 19 seed, posted a 6-3, 5-7, 9-7 victory over No. 3 Agnieszka Radwanska, complicating Cibulkova’s plans to be married Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Dominika Cibulkova is supposed to get married on Saturday.

headline: Donald Trump’s Potential Running Mates: Pros and Cons
abstract: The presumptive Republican presidential nominee’s team has already begun vetting Chris Christie, Joni Ernst, Newt Gingrich and Mike Pence.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump plans to announce his running mate before the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this month, and has started an “Apprentice”-style search — meeting with possible candidates one by one and then posting on Twitter about it. (On Monday, he even praised on Twitter Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, a long-shot running mate whom some Republicans nonetheless like because of his military service.)

headline: Turkish Leader Erdogan Making New Enemies and Frustrating Old Friends
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan long professed a foreign policy of “zero problems with neighbors” but now seems mired in disputes with just about everybody.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, strode onto a stage a month ago looking down upon a sea of a million fans waving red Turkish flags. They were celebrating the 15th-century conquest of Istanbul by the Ottoman sultan Mehmed II, the golden moment of Turkey’s Muslim ancestors triumphing over the Christian West.

headline: Standard Life Fund Halts Withdrawals After ‘Brexit’ Vote
abstract: The decision by the insurer’s mutual fund was a response to panicked investors looking to pull their assets following the referendum last month.
lead_paragraph: A British mutual fund with large investments in London commercial real estate said on Monday that it had suspended requests from investors wanting to exit the $3 billion fund.

headline: Bombings Rock Saudi Arabia
abstract: Bombings hit three cities across Saudi Arabia on Monday, including near the Prophet's Mosque in the holy city of Medina.
lead_paragraph: Bombings hit three cities across Saudi Arabia on Monday, including near the Prophet's Mosque in the holy city of Medina.

headline: Review: In Viceland’s ‘Black Market,’ Michael K. Williams Delves Into Illicit Sales
abstract: This six-part series, thin on hard reporting, starts with carjacking in Newark and abalone poaching off South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The host of the new Viceland series “Black Market” is the actor Michael K. Williams, but you can call him Omar. Mr. Williams’s stature as a portrayer of charismatic criminals — Omar Little in “The Wire,” Chalky White in “Boardwalk Empire” — is meant to give “Black Market” a credibility it can’t obtain from exhaustive reporting or balanced testimony, neither of which gets much attention in the land of Vice Media.

headline: Britain’s Role in Iraq War: What to Expect From Chilcot Report
abstract: The seven-year investigation by the Iraq Inquiry Committee, known as the Chilcot inquiry, lasted longer than British combat operations in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — (Editors’ note: Read our latest article  about the release of the Chilcot report here.)

headline: Review: ‘Invincible Summer’ Focuses on Friendships Built to Survive Crises
abstract: Alice Adams’s debut novel has a pokey start, but as its individual stories kick in, its grip tightens considerably.
lead_paragraph: There’s a long list of reasons that Alice Adams’s debut novel, “Invincible Summer,” shouldn’t work. But it clicks anyhow. Ms. Adams has managed to combine a hoary premise, a familiar plot, readable to iffy prose and pigeonhole-ready characters and spin their story into a heart tugger with seemingly honest appeal. This amazing feat doesn’t rival those of the Large Hadron Collider, which plays a cameo role in “Invincible Summer.” But it’s close.

headline: Learning From Healthy Bears (You Mean We Should Hibernate?)
abstract: Studies of bears’ long, deep sleep are giving scientists clues to fighting obesity, diabetes, heart disease and other ailments.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Gain a few hundred pounds and lie around in bed for months, and you are likely to develop a host of ailments, from diabetes and heart failure to muscle loss, osteoporosis and bedsores.

headline: Michel Rocard, Former Prime Minister of France, Dies at 85
abstract: The politician was known for his efforts as a pragmatic reformer of the Socialist Party and for his struggles with President François Mitterrand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Michel Rocard, a former French prime minister who embodied a pragmatic, market-friendly element in the Socialist Party, but whose reformist zeal encountered powerful countercurrents on the left, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 85.

headline: Runner Boris Berian Goes From McDonald’s Employee to a Symbol of Athletes’ Rights
abstract: An 800-meter runner, Berian found himself embroiled in a legal battle with the athletic-apparel behemoth Nike when he attempted to change sponsors.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Boris Berian did not take any recommended route to becoming a champion 800-meter runner and an advocate for athletes’ rights by standing up to Nike.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Fall 2016
abstract: Their latest Couture Collection.
lead_paragraph: Their latest Couture Collection.

headline: Tesla and Google Take Different Roads to Self-Driving Car
abstract: Two self-driving car pioneers have distinct views of the role of the person behind the wheel.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In Silicon Valley, where companies big and small are at work on self-driving cars, there have been a variety of approaches, and even some false starts.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Campaign Calls Donald Trump’s Star of David Tweet Anti-Semitic
abstract: Mr. Trump took the unusual step of deleting the Twitter post, though the episode was seen by some as an example of his pattern of racially charged remarks.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign said on Monday that an image posted by Donald J. Trump on Twitter over the weekend that showed a photo of Mrs. Clinton against a backdrop of $100 bills and a Star of David was “blatantly anti-Semitic.”

headline: Savoring the Spectrum of American Ballet Theater’s Rich Season
abstract: This year, the company’s pictorial aspect felt stronger than ever, with choreography that made the stage pictures come to life.
lead_paragraph: Scenery, costumes, music, choreography, dancers: American Ballet Theater’s eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House is this country’s peak annual demonstration of ballet as a composite art. It’s what many people think of as Diaghilev’s formula for ballet theater, with a strong emphasis on a varied color palette.

headline: Prince Websites Compiled in Online Museum
abstract: This archive features 16 websites that the singer, who died in April, had spanning two decades.
lead_paragraph: An online archive of 16 of Prince’s official websites spanning the last two decades was unveiled on Monday, nearly 11 weeks after the music icon was found dead at his Paisley Park estate outside of Minneapolis from an accidental overdose of a powerful painkiller.

headline: California Drug Price Plan Is Criticized by Patient Advocates
abstract: A California initiative meant to lower skyrocketing prescription drug prices faces opposition from not only drug makers but also some patient advocacy groups.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A state ballot initiative meant to lower prescription drug prices for California faces an expected opponent: the pharmaceutical industry, which has spent almost $70 million to defeat it.

headline: After Djokovic Upset, Sam Querrey Wins Again at Wimbledon
abstract: Querrey, the 28-year-old American, advanced to his first Grand Slam quarterfinal in singles.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — After the tennis upset of the year, there was no Manic Monday letdown for Sam Querrey.

headline: No Corrections: July 5, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, July 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Bird Song, Sirens and Saxophones for a Stroll Between Museums
abstract: “Soundwalk 9:09,” composed by John Luther Adams, uses sounds recorded near the Metropolitan Museum. It’s for people to listen to as they walk from the Met to the Met Breuer.
lead_paragraph: It was with some trepidation that I set out last week to try “Soundwalk 9:09,” a piece the Metropolitan Museum of Art commissioned from John Luther Adams, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer. Composed of sounds recorded in the area, the work is intended for people to listen to on their smartphones as they make the eight-block walk between the museum’s mother ship, on Fifth Avenue, and its new outpost, the Met Breuer, in the old Whitney building on Madison Avenue.

headline: One Robber’s 3 Life Sentences: ’90s Legacy Fills Prisons Today
abstract: The era’s zero tolerance of drug users helped lead to a life term for Lenny Singleton, one of tens of thousands of such inmates across the country.
lead_paragraph: BURKEVILLE, Va. — Lenny Singleton is the first to admit that he deserved an extended stay behind bars. To fuel his crack habit back in 1995, he walked into 13 stores over eight days and either distracted a clerk or pretended to have a concealed gun before stealing from the cash register. One time, he was armed with a knife with a six-inch blade that he had brought from his kitchen.

headline: Quiet Fixer in Donald Trump’s Campaign: His Son-in-Law, Jared Kushner
abstract: Mr. Trump has long preferred the advice of family over political operatives, and Mr. Kushner is seen as a de facto campaign manager.
lead_paragraph: International diplomacy is a world of careful rituals, hierarchy and credentials. But when the Israeli ambassador to the United States, Ron Dermer, wanted to communicate with Donald J. Trump, he ended up on two occasions in the Manhattan office of a young man with no government experience, no political background and no official title in the Trump campaign: Jared Kushner.

headline: San Francisco Considers Tax on Tech Companies to Pay for Boom’s Downside
abstract: As officials struggle to balance the city budget, activists and some lawmakers want the sector to help pay for programs for the homeless and for affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Maria Poblet, who leads an organization that assists Latino families facing eviction in San Francisco, says she appreciates the philanthropy that the city’s technology companies do in far-flung places to address global poverty and the environment. But what she really wants to see them do is pay more taxes to help with homelessness and lower-cost housing in San Francisco.

headline: White Sox Defeat Yankees as C. C. Sabathia Has Another Rocky Start
abstract: Sabathia gave up five runs on eight hits over six innings as his E.R.A. rose from 2.20 two weeks ago to 3.48 after Monday’s loss, his third straight poor start.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Just as the Yankees took care of one troubled member of their rotation Monday by sending Nathan Eovaldi to the bullpen, another gave them cause for concern.

headline: Struggles in a Steel Town Highlighted by Donald Trump
abstract: In Monessen, Pa., even a campaign stop by Donald J. Trump can’t seem to unite the city’s leaders on how to move on from a steel mill’s closing — 30 years later.
lead_paragraph: MONESSEN, Pa. — Thirty years have passed, almost to the day, since the last blasts of the steel furnaces that were the reason for this city’s existence. The steel mill is gone — used to film “RoboCop,” then demolished. Most of the people are gone, too, and those who remain are struggling to find a new purpose for this place.

headline: A New Friend on the Subway
abstract: After comparing notes on the city’s difficulties, a resident and a foreign visitor parted with a big hug.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Reading List of Tell-Alls, Strategic Plans and Cautionary Tales in Finance
abstract: Books to get you caught up on influential deal makers, activist shareholders, the failings of the modern economy and the habits of highly successful people.
lead_paragraph: With the summer upon us and the so-called Brexit vote behind us, perhaps you might have some time to read one of the terrific books published recently that touch on big themes in business, finance and technology. I’ve been plowing through stacks of them to make your life simpler. Here are some of my favorites.

headline: At Nathan’s Hot Dog Contest, 15 Women Challenge the Gluttony Ceiling
abstract: Before the first man takes a bite at the annual Coney Island contest, female noshers dig in, including a taxidermist, a fashion model and a truck driver.
lead_paragraph: The contestants rolled up their sleeves and took to their plates of hot dogs on the stage, lining up their cups of water in a strategic array, as thousands of perspired onlookers watched with anticipation.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, July 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Crack cocaine scared the hell out of a lot of people. It’s disappointing there wasn’t more consideration as to why this man did this. Do we really want to keep him in jail for the rest of his life?”

headline: Young Performers Look to Apps for Stardom
abstract: YouNow, a live-streaming app that allows users to perform and interact with fans, has helped singers like Hailey Knox break into the industry.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At VidCon, a sprawling conference here for the young stars of online video, success has a particular sound: a sudden, earsplitting shriek, signaling that a legion of tween-age fans have spotted one of their idols and are making a frantic selfie run.

headline: Durant to Warriors: For a Title, N.B.A. Stars Are Now Willing to Align
abstract: For Durant the jump is as much about the talent-laden roster he is joining, and the chance it gives him to win his first N.B.A. title, as it is anything else.
lead_paragraph: Jerry West and the fraternity of California N.B.A. championship ring bearers — Bay Area chapter — win again.

headline: Adding Classes and Content, Resurgent Libraries Turn a Whisper Into a Roar
abstract: Coding class? Zumba? No longer just repositories for books, New York’s public libraries have reinvented themselves as one-stop community centers that aim to offer something for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Carter’s summer hideaway is not in the Hamptons, the Catskills or on the Jersey Shore. It does not require a car ride or a small fortune to keep up.

headline: Mets Rally From 6-0 Deficit After Matt Harvey Struggles
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes’s two-run double in the eighth broke a tie after Matt Harvey gave up six runs (five earned) and 11 hits in three and two-thirds innings.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey presented himself in a fresh, new light when he took the mound Monday, wearing crisp white cleats to match his uniform. Harvey needed a clean slate after losing 10 games, after having never lost more than eight in a season.

headline: Jacoby Ellsbury’s Bat: Effective at Finding the Ball, but Also the Glove
abstract: Ellsbury, the Yankees’ leadoff hitter, tied the single-season record for reaching first on catcher’s interference, an achievement he attributes to his opponents, not himself.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the Yankees’ Jacoby Ellsbury swung and lofted an easy fly ball to Chicago White Sox right fielder Jason Coats on Monday, it looked as innocuous and forgettable as countless other routine plays during a baseball season.

headline: Brandon Jennings Agrees to Join Knicks
abstract: Jennings, formerly of the Orlando Magic, will sign a one-year deal to back up the newly acquired Derrick Rose at point guard.
lead_paragraph: Point guard Brandon Jennings said he had agreed to join the Knicks, where he will back up the newly acquired Derrick Rose.

headline: Devouring 1,000 Mosquitoes an Hour, Bats Are Now Welcome Guests as Zika Fears Rise
abstract: Concerns that the Zika and West Nile viruses could be spread by local mosquitoes have prompted a Long Island town to build bat houses.
lead_paragraph: NORTH HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — As mosquito season heats up, bringing with it the threat of the West Nile and Zika viruses, one Long Island town is taking an unorthodox approach: bats.

headline: Pirate’s Guide
abstract: Jules Markey uncovers something important.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I will admit that today’s theme made me snort a bit. International Talk Like a Pirate Day is not until Sept. 19 this year, but Jules Markey is giving us a head start in the search for the buried treasure.

headline: First Day on New York’s Streets for Just-Graduated Police Officers
abstract: The officers on duty for a Fourth of July fireworks show were among the 1,257 graduates of the Police Academy who began their first detail on the holiday.
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening, a class of new police officers was stationed at 23rd Street and First Avenue in Manhattan, as revelers, clad in red, white and blue, streamed toward the East River before the Fourth of July fireworks show.

headline: Abbas Kiarostami, Acclaimed Iranian Filmmaker, Dies at 76
abstract: Associated with the Iranian New Wave of the late 1960s, Mr. Kiarostami was known for his parablelike dramas of ordinary people.
lead_paragraph: Abbas Kiarostami, often hailed as Iran’s greatest filmmaker, whose searching, parable-like dramas of ordinary people and their problems reflected a poetic vision and a philosophical turn of mind, died on Monday in Paris. He was 76.

headline: Robin Hardy, Who Set ‘The Wicker Man’ Cult Alight, Dies at 86
abstract: Sex and human sacrifice are the core of a pagan society in Scotland in “The Wicker Man,” Mr. Hardy’s best-known film.
lead_paragraph: Robin Hardy, the director of the horror film “The Wicker Man,” which failed at the box office when it was released in 1973 but went on to attract a large cult following, died on Friday. He was 86.

headline: Noel Neill, the Lois Lane to George Reeves’s ‘Superman,’ Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Neill had roles in movies including “The Blue Dahlia,” “The Sky Dragon,” “Henry Aldrich’s Little Secret,” and “Junior Prom,” among many others.
lead_paragraph: Noel Neill, the petite film and television actress who played Lois Lane in 1940s “Superman” movie serials and on television in the 1950s, died on Sunday at her home in Tucson. She was 95.

headline: Brewers Shut Down Nationals, Ending a Skid
abstract: The Brewers ended a four-game losing streak behind starter Max Scherzer who gave up a run and four hits in six innings.
lead_paragraph: Junior Guerra outdueled Max Scherzer, and Martin Maldonado homered as the visiting Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Washington Nationals, 1-0, on Monday, ending a four-game losing streak.

headline: NASA’s Juno Spacecraft Enters Into Orbit Around Jupiter
abstract: A signal from the spacecraft Monday night confirmed that it had arrived at the planet, on a mission NASA hopes will yield clues about the origins of our solar system.
lead_paragraph: Ducking through intense belts of violent radiation as it skimmed over the clouds of Jupiter at 130,000 miles per hour, NASA’s Juno spacecraft on Monday clinched its spot around the solar system’s largest planet.

headline: How to Sell Kids on Vegetables
abstract: The same marketing ploys used to sell junk food also work at the salad bar, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: The same marketing techniques used to convince children to eat junk food are highly effective in promoting fruits and vegetables, a new study has found.

headline: Is Sushi ‘Healthy’? What About Granola? Where Americans and Nutritionists Disagree
abstract: We surveyed Americans and a panel of nutrition experts about which foods they thought were good or bad for you.
lead_paragraph: We surveyed Americans and a panel of nutrition experts about which foods they thought were good or bad for you.

headline: Email by Ed Day, former C.E.O. of Mississippi Power, to top company officials, Aug. 8, 2012
abstract: Selected documents from the Kemper Coal Files.
lead_paragraph: Selected documents from the Kemper Coal Files.

headline: The Urgency in Fighting Childhood Obesity
abstract: Overweight children are likely to become overweight adults – unless they adopt healthier patterns of eating and exercise.
lead_paragraph: Life-threatening ailments like heart disease, cancer, stroke and Type 2 diabetes most often afflict adults. But they are often consequences of childhood obesity.

headline: With Hippotherapy, the Horse Provides the Therapy
abstract: For people with cerebral palsy and other disorders, holding the body upright while riding can improve muscle tone — and it’s fun.
lead_paragraph: Three-year-old Jack Foster sat on his mother’s lap as she wrapped a towel carefully around his neck.

headline: Greg Zoll, independent monitor for the Mississippi Public Service Commission, April 15, 2014
abstract: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.
lead_paragraph: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.

headline: Sierra Club testimony to the Mississippi Public Service Commission, March 14, 2014
abstract: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.
lead_paragraph: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.

headline: Email by Brett Wingo to the Southern official Helen R. Nalley on June 10, 2014
abstract: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.
lead_paragraph: Selected documents from The Kemper Coal Files.

headline: Sleep Problems Tied to Diabetes in Men
abstract: Men who do not get enough sleep — or get too much — may have an increased risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Men who do not get enough sleep — or get too much — may have an increased risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study suggests.

headline: Short Answers to Hard Questions About Clean Coal Technology
abstract: A primer on carbon capture and storage, and why it has an uncertain future as a force for fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: A primer on carbon capture and storage, and why it has an uncertain future as a force for fighting climate change.

headline: Piles of Dirty Secrets Behind a Model ‘Clean Coal’ Project
abstract: A Mississippi project, a centerpiece of President Obama’s climate plan, has been plagued by problems that managers tried to conceal, and by cost overruns and questions of who will pay.
lead_paragraph: DE KALB, Miss. — The fortress of steel and concrete towering above the pine forest here is a first-of-its-kind power plant that was supposed to prove that “clean coal” was not an oxymoron — that it was possible to produce electricity from coal in a way that emits far less pollution, and to turn a profit while doing so.

headline: Public Burials in New York
abstract: An advocate writes that “agreeing to a public burial should not mean that anything can happen in transit.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On Mentoring Women
abstract: A reader writes that women should not forget that men as well as women can be good mentors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Job for the U.S.: Safe Harbor for Refugees
abstract: The Unitarian Universalist Service Committee and Catholic Relief Services provide perspectives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nuclear Power, to Tide Us Over
abstract: Readers see the coming of a lower carbon footprint, or not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Internships Are Not a Privilege
abstract: The unpaid internship system advantages those with networks and financial means while others wait at opportunity’s door. Proposals would change that.
lead_paragraph: TALENT is equally distributed, but opportunity is not. And while many Americans believe fervently and faithfully in expanding opportunity, America’s internship-industrial complex does just the opposite.

headline: Choosing Leaders: Clueless or Crazy
abstract: British political party members and Republican presidential primary voters have all faced dilemmas.
lead_paragraph: These days, if you want to elect a leader, you generally have two choices: a sensible, establishment figure who is completely out of touch, or a populist outsider who is incompetent, crazy or both.

headline: Don’t Let Iran’s Progress on the Nuclear Deal Go to Waste
abstract: It’s important that Iran benefit from meeting its commitments, though there can be no complacency.
lead_paragraph: One year later, the nuclear deal between Iran and the major powers is working. It has substantially restricted Iran’s ability to produce fissile material, the key ingredient for a nuclear bomb, and in that way has made the world safer.

headline: College Kids, With Kids
abstract: Far too many student-parents drop out, cutting them off from good jobs.
lead_paragraph: IN the last year or so, dozens of employers — from the Navy to Goldman Sachs — have begun offering or expanding benefits like paid family leave and job-sharing that enable parents to better balance work with family life. Slowly, America’s famously family-unfriendly workplace might finally be improving. But the only employees who really stand to benefit are white-collar ones. Since the 1960s, paid parental leave increased nearly five times for workers with a college degree, but it has only doubled for those with just a high school degree.

headline: The Struggle to Vote in Kansas
abstract: It is shocking that thousands of qualified Kansans still have no certainty that they will be allowed into the voting booth.
lead_paragraph: The right to vote is turning into a tooth-and-claw saga in Kansas, thanks to right-wing ideologues’ determination to force new voters to produce a passport, a birth certificate or naturalization papers as proof of citizenship.

headline: Who Gets the Subsidized Apartments?
abstract: A special provision for artists means fewer low-income families are served, and it also, a study suggests, contributes to racial segregation.
lead_paragraph: Federally financed affordable housing developments do not typically include yoga studios or rooftop clubs with spectacular skyline views.
