lead_paragraph: The monologuist Mike Daisey was sitting on a bench in Brooklyn’s Carroll Park, nursing a cup of coffee and talking about his new show, “The Trump Card,” a critically comedic probe of what makes the presumptive Republican presidential nominee tick. Suddenly a man sitting alone nearby broke out in a noisy, mostly on-key rendition of “God Bless America.” Mr. Daisey stopped midsentence and looked over.

headline: Shura’s ‘Nothing’s Real’ Channels the 1980s
abstract: This pop singer creates lovestruck, self-doubting narrators on this album, which is her first.
lead_paragraph: The young English singer Shura is fluent in the sound of mid-to-late 1980s dance-pop and freestyle: really, almost born to it. This is the area of early Madonna and Janet Jackson, Debbie Gibson and Debbie Deb, and it comes out fully embodied and elegantly modernized on “Nothing’s Real,” her first album.

headline: A Feel-Good Lip Balm Created in Her Dorm
abstract: Zoe Mesnik-Greene, 23, is the founder of Lasting Smiles, an eco-friendly lip balm that raises money for children with cleft lips and palates.
lead_paragraph: Name Zoe Mesnik-Greene

headline: In Africa, Benjamin Netanyahu Looks for Friends, and U.N. Votes, for Israel
abstract: The Israeli prime minister is on a four-country tour, hoping to rebuild economic and strategic ties on a continent where his nation was once a major presence.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, cruised around the capital of Kenya with an entourage of dozens of Israeli executives, hoping to sell Africa everything from Israeli-made plastic wrap, sprinklers and irrigation pipes to software, CCTV cameras and military equipment. Even cantaloupe seeds.

headline: Times Insider Book Club: Charles Duhigg
abstract: At noon on Wednesday, July 20, Charles Duhigg, a New York Times reporter and the author of “Smarter Faster Better,” was on hand to answer readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: At noon on Wednesday, July 20, Charles Duhigg, a New York Times reporter and the author of “Smarter Faster Better,” was on hand to answer readers’ questions.

headline: The Big News About What We Already Knew
abstract: A British report on Iraq and an F.B.I. report on emails unsurprisingly offer no surprise.
lead_paragraph: Now is the summer of unrevealing revelations.

headline: Up North, Pup Makes Freshly Mutating Punk
abstract: This Toronto band’s second full-length album, “The Dream Is Over,” applies its raucous energy to the frontman Stefan Babcock’s vivid storytelling.
lead_paragraph: It may not be evident from a distance, but punk is constantly mutating from within. At its best, the genre puts up a shambolic edifice that can obscure real rumbles of change — so long as the attitude is intact, the component parts can shift endlessly.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, Iraq Inquiry: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In Atlantic City, Hillary Clinton Uses a Donald Trump Failure as Backdrop
abstract: A shuttered casino was a not-so-subtle part of a candidate’s continued efforts to tweak her Republican opponent.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — In this fading hub of spinning fortunes and Northeastern excess, Hillary Clinton found little occasion for subtlety.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Andrew Caspersen Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in $40 Million Fraud
abstract: The former Wall Street executive, whose lawyer said had a gambling addiction, admitted to defrauding friends, relatives and a billionaire’s foundation.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Caspersen, a former Wall Street executive and scion of a wealthy family, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to federal charges that he defrauded friends, relatives and a hedge fund billionaire’s foundation of nearly $40 million.

headline: Attorney General Accepts Recommendation Not to Charge Hillary Clinton
abstract: The statement by Loretta Lynch ends the investigation into Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private email server while secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The investigation into Hillary Clinton’s email server is over, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said on Wednesday.

headline: Let’s Put More New York in New York Fashion Week: Men
abstract: The men’s wear shows return to Manhattan, this time without the local favorites Duckie Brown and Public School.
lead_paragraph: Is it a sprint to the finish or a long slog home? This question about the sustainability of the still-young New York Fashion Week: Men’s has echoed throughout social media and the style blogs lately, casting doubt on the viability of a cycle that resumes Monday morning with a Perry Ellis show.

headline: Jared Kushner Defends Donald Trump, His Father-in-Law, on Bias Charge
abstract: The publisher of The New York Observer wrote in an op-ed that Mr. Trump was not an anti-Semite or a racist, but that his campaign could be “careless” on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: “My father-in-law is not an anti-Semite.”

headline: Mets Place Matt Harvey on Disabled List
abstract: Harvey, who was once the ace of the staff but who has struggled to pitch effectively for much of the season, is experiencing discomfort in his right shoulder and will visit a specialist on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey, who was once the ace of the Mets’ starting rotation but who has repeatedly struggled this season, was placed on the disabled list on Wednesday with discomfort in his throwing shoulder and will visit a vascular surgeon.

headline: Cambodian Leader’s Family Is Profiting From His Position, Report Says
abstract: Relatives of Hun Sen have acquired shares in companies in nearly every sector of the economy, the human rights group Global Witness says.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Relatives of Cambodia’s prime minister, Hun Sen, are amassing personal fortunes through the family’s political influence and have acquired shares in companies in nearly every sector of the economy, according to a report released on Thursday by the human rights group Global Witness.

headline: How Did Denard Robinson of the Jaguars End Up Fast Asleep in a Partly Submerged Car?
abstract: The N.F.L. running back and a passenger were found “passed out” in an Impala that was touching the bottom of a pond early Sunday in Jacksonville.
lead_paragraph: When the police in Florida found Denard Robinson, an N.F.L. running back for the Jacksonville Jaguars, asleep in his car on Sunday morning, the vehicle was in a strange place.

headline: Fly Detroit to San Francisco, for Just $20,000
abstract: Technical problems led to a temporary overpricing of tickets in about 150 of Delta’s 40,000 markets.
lead_paragraph: AIRLINE websites occasionally publish absurdly low airfares by mistake, causing a stampede of consumers seeking to book bargain tickets.

headline: Time to Get Fit, for Lingerie
abstract: Leather bits from Zana Bayne, sleek jelly flip-flops by Jason Wu, and sales galore.
lead_paragraph: There’s no time like summer to get fit — for lingerie, that is. On Friday, the e-tailer True&Company is pitching a try-on tent at the Williamsburg boutique Concrete & Water, where “fit therapists” will give customers a quiz to figure out what style — an unlined balconette ($64), say, or a bralette with strappy cutout details ($68) — works best for their shape. At 485 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn; R.S.V.P. at trueandco.com/tryontent.

headline: Donald Trump Steps Up Fund-Raising for His Campaign to $26 Million in June
abstract: His campaign cash still lags far behind that of his presidential rival, Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, said on Wednesday that he had raised $26 million for his campaign in June, a substantial improvement from his paltry May total but one that still leaves him far behind his rival, Hillary Clinton.

headline: The ‘Kidbutz’ of Topanga Canyon
abstract: In an upscale twist on a hippie commune, a group of California parents are raising their children together in a $2 million home.
lead_paragraph: TOPANGA, Calif. — In a four-bedroom, 3,400-square-foot house with three and a half baths and a two-car garage in this hilly Los Angeles County enclave, Aleksandra Evanguelidi, 41, sleeps in the master bedroom; in the room next door is her daughter, Juno, 6, who shares it with Claire, also 6. Across the hall is an under-the-sea-theme loft. Eli, age 4, sleeps there. His mother, Ashley Welch, 24, has the room across the hall, which doesn’t have a bathroom of its own but does have a private balcony. And in the room next door, is Justin Balthrop, 37, Claire’s father.

headline: Isenheim Altarpiece: A Portrait of Agony; a Message of Hope
abstract: The Isenheim Altarpiece’s painted panels are at once gruesome and hopeful. Learn about some of its key and surprising features.
lead_paragraph: Above, explore each numbered annotation to read more about some key and surprising features of the Isenheim Altarpiece, which the writer Francine Prose recently traveled to see.

headline: Alton Sterling and When Black Lives Stop Mattering
abstract: Tiny cameras allow us to bear witness to injustice. What does that change?
lead_paragraph: OVER the past several years, we have borne witness to grainy videos of what “protect and serve” looks like for black lives — Tamir Rice, Walter Scott, Eric Garner, Kajieme Powell, to name a few. I don’t think any of us could have imagined how tiny cameras would allow us to see, time and again, injustices perpetrated, mostly against black people, by police officers. I don’t think we could have imagined that video of police brutality would not translate into justice, and I don’t think we could have imagined how easy it is to see too much, to become numb. And now, here we are.

headline: Agency Clears Mayor de Blasio and Nonprofit of Campaign Finance Violations
abstract: But the New York City Campaign Finance Board did criticize the now-defunct group, Campaign for One New York, which had used unlimited donations to advance the mayor’s political agenda.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Campaign Finance Board on Wednesday issued a blunt critique of a nonprofit closely linked to Mayor Bill de Blasio that has used unlimited donations to advance his political agenda, denouncing the group’s behavior while clearing it and the mayor of any campaign finance violations.

headline: Hillary Clinton: Ma’am Survivor
abstract: You have to accept the swirl of madness with the political mastery, the constant flirtation with self-destruction.
lead_paragraph: The Clintons — both Hillary and Bill — are very smart, but also quite reckless. They play too close to the edge and sometimes go over. They parse words to parry attacks. They possess a sort of preternatural political ability, but also a political paranoia.

headline: Gender-Segregated Swimming Cut Back at 2 Public Pools Near Brooklyn Hasidic Areas
abstract: Swimming hours scheduled to be women-only were popular among the area’s Hasidim, but critics said the segregation infringed upon the separation of church and state.
lead_paragraph: New York City will continue to allow gender-restricted hours at two public pools located near Hasidic enclaves in Brooklyn, but agreed to reduce the pools’ segregated hours as part of an exemption to gender discrimination laws granted by the city’s Human Rights Commission.

headline: Care by Private Doctors Among Big Changes Urged for V.A. Health System
abstract: A commission created to try to fix Veterans Administration health care after a scandal proposes a network of V.A., military and private doctors to treat veterans.
lead_paragraph: Two years after a Department of Veterans Affairs scandal involving long wait times at veterans hospitals, an official report has found that the veterans’ health care system suffers from “profound deficiencies” despite billions of dollars spent in recent years to overhaul it. The report says that the hospital system needs sweeping changes, including a program that would pay for all veterans to see private doctors.

headline: A Flawed Approach to Labeling Genetically Modified Food
abstract: A proposed law would make it unnecessarily difficult to check a label, by requiring the scanning of electronic codes in the store.
lead_paragraph: The Senate is expected to vote as early as Thursday on a bill that would require businesses to label genetically modified foods. Unfortunately, it would allow companies to use confusing electronic codes for scanning instead of simple, clear labels.

headline: G.M.O. Labeling Bill Clears First Hurdle in Senate
abstract: The bill would set a national standard for labeling G.M.O. foods, though critics say the system would not be tough enough.
lead_paragraph: A federal bill that would require labeling of foods made with genetically engineered ingredients passed a major hurdle in the Senate on Wednesday, significantly raising the odds that a national standard for labeling will put an end to a fight that has roiled the food industry for years.

headline: Disappearance of ex-Guantánamo Bay Prisoner Raises Alarms
abstract: Suggestions that a former detainee sent to Uruguay may have crossed the border into Brazil have prompted concerns on releasing detainees to other countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disappearance of a former Guantánamo Bay prisoner who was transferred to Uruguay is sharpening debate here over the wartime prison, even as a House committee prepares to hold an oversight hearing on Thursday about the Obama administration’s policy on releasing detainees to other countries.

headline: Ramadan for Muslim Inmates: Mixing Religious Duty With Prison’s Limits
abstract: At Sing Sing Correctional Facility in New York, the rigorous demands of the Islamic holy month require complicated changes to a rigid schedule.
lead_paragraph: OSSINING, N.Y. — As they heard the beginning of the 8:30 p.m. call to prayer on Tuesday, the Muslim men took their first sips of water of the day, breaking the Ramadan fast for the last time this year.

headline: Stanley Gault, Who Led Rubbermaid and Goodyear, Dies at 90
abstract: After a long career at General Electric, Stanley C. Gault led turnarounds at Rubbermaid and Goodyear.
lead_paragraph: Stanley C. Gault, a tough, sales-minded executive who helped revive two emblematic Ohio companies, Rubbermaid and Goodyear, after working for three decades at General Electric, died on June 29 in Cleveland. He was 90.

headline: House Republicans Back Away From Gun Vote After Conservatives Rebel
abstract: A bill promoted by House Republican leaders that would aim to block buyers with links to terrorism had already faced broad opposition from Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders on Wednesday backed away from plans to vote on a gun measure that already faced broad Democratic opposition after their own conservative members said they would also reject it.

headline: U.S. Safety Agency Investigates Another Tesla Crash Involving Autopilot
abstract: As safety officials opened an inquiry into a Pennsylvania accident, a witness to the fatal Florida Tesla crash described a car that did not slow down even after impact.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top auto safety regulator said on Wednesday that it had begun an investigation of a second crash involving a Tesla Motors car equipped with Autopilot technology, a system designed to let vehicles drive themselves for brief periods.

headline: List of New Jersey Transportation Department Projects Shutting Down
abstract: The New Jersey Department of Transportation has released a list of projects that will be halted, after Gov. Chris Christie declared a state of emergency and said nonessential transportation projects would be suspended to conserve the money left in the state’s nearly depleted transportation trust fund.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Department of Transportation has released a list of projects that will be halted, after Gov. Chris Christie declared a state of emergency and said nonessential transportation projects would be suspended to conserve the money left in the state’s nearly depleted transportation trust fund.

headline: List of N.J. Transit Projects Shutting Down
abstract: Many mass transit projects will be affected by Gov. Chris Christie's decision to shut down nonessential transportation projects. Mr. Christie ordered the shutdown to conserve the money left in the state’s nearly depleted transportation trust fund.
lead_paragraph: Many mass transit projects will be affected by Gov. Chris Christie's decision to shut down nonessential transportation projects. Mr. Christie ordered the shutdown to conserve the money left in the state’s nearly depleted transportation trust fund.

headline: A Wrongful Conviction
abstract: Amy Albritton received this letter informing her that she was prosecuted for a criminal drug offense in error years after she had spent weeks in jail and lost her job and her home.
lead_paragraph: Amy Albritton received this letter informing her that she was prosecuted for a criminal drug offense in error years after she had spent weeks in jail and lost her job and her home.

headline: New Jersey to Shut Down Hundreds of Transportation Projects
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie ordered the work stoppage, which affects projects across the state, after lawmakers failed to agree on a gas-tax increase.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of projects to replace bridges, resurface roads and renovate transit stations across New Jersey will grind to a halt by Friday night, after state lawmakers failed to reach a deal last week on raising the gas tax.

headline: F.B.I. Chief to Explain Recommendation on Hillary Clinton Before Congress
abstract: Republicans on Capitol Hill moved to stretch out Mrs. Clinton’s email travails after what many in the party viewed as a lackluster response from Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, will testify before Congress on Thursday to explain his decision to recommend no criminal charges against Hillary Clinton, but the appearance will be only the beginning of the tests Republicans plan as they maneuver to capitalize on Mr. Comey’s rebuke of the presumptive Democratic nominee and her handling of classified emails.

headline: Indians Hoping to Follow Cavaliers’ Parade Path in Cleveland
abstract: Manager Terry Francona’s team is 51-33 and leading the American League Central after a recent 14-game winning streak, and would like nothing more than to emulate the Cavaliers as champions.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The best place to watch a celebration 52 years in the making was from atop the ballpark of the Cleveland Indians. That was where Chris Antonetti, president of the Indians’ baseball operations, watched the Cavaliers start their motorcade through downtown after winning the N.B.A. title last month. For almost an hour, Antonetti, Manager Terry Francona and others in the front office watched the cars wind from a plaza next door, up to Ontario Street, down to Carnegie Avenue, over to East Ninth Street, and into history.

headline: How Gretchen Carlson Took On the Chief of Fox News
abstract: Gretchen Carlson, who has not shied away from discussing sexual harassment, is suing Roger Ailes over his alleged conduct toward her.
lead_paragraph: On June 21, Gretchen Carlson devoted the closing minutes of her afternoon Fox News show, “The Real Story with Gretchen Carlson,” to discussion of a milestone: She turned 50 that day.

headline: Robert Nye, Novelist Who Imagined Falstaff’s Memoirs, Dies at 77
abstract: The rollicking writer also wrote poetry and children’s books.
lead_paragraph: Robert Nye, a poet and novelist who found rich material in the legends of ancient England and Wales, and who invented a rollicking afterlife for one of Shakespeare’s most enduring characters in his acclaimed novel “Falstaff,” died on Saturday in Cork, Ireland. He was 77.

headline: Portugal Beats Wales at Euro 2016 and Gets Another Shot at Glory
abstract: Portugal, led by Ronaldo, advanced to the final of the European Championships, where it will play the winner of the France-Germany game on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — The ball soared in front of the goal and Cristiano Ronaldo jumped, his body hanging in the air for what felt like one beat, two beats, three beats, four. His chest was pitched. His back was arched. His eyes were forward, locked on the target.

headline: In a Defiant, Angry Speech, Donald Trump Defends Image Seen as Anti-Semitic
abstract: The presumptive Republican presidential candidate, reviving recent controversies in his campaign, also reaffirmed his praise of Saddam Hussein.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday offered a defiant defense of his campaign’s decision to publish an image widely viewed as anti-Semitic — saying he regretted deleting it — and vigorously reaffirmed his praise of Saddam Hussein, the murderous Iraqi dictator.

headline: Email Case May Complicate Clinton Aides’ Pursuit of Security Clearance
abstract: Fallout from the F.B.I. inquiry is likely to affect several State Department advisers who facilitated the former secretary’s reliance on a private server.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Questions raised by the F.B.I. about the State Department’s handling of Hillary Clinton’s emails have cast a cloud of doubt over the political futures of a number of her top advisers, including some expected to hold high-level jobs in her administration if she is elected president.

headline: Irving Gottesman, Pioneering Psychologist on Schizophrenia, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Gottesman was perhaps best known for a study of twins that found a genetic link to mental illness, changing how people thought about its origins.
lead_paragraph: Irving Gottesman, a pioneer in the field of behavioral genetics whose work on the role of heredity in schizophrenia helped transform the way people thought about the origins of serious mental illness, died on June 29 at his home in Edina, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis. He was 85.

headline: Samsung Profit Rises on New Smartphone Screen Technology
abstract: The South Korean technology conglomerate posted its best quarterly profit figure in two years as its phones held their own against Apple.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Six months after it warned that 2016 would be a tough year, Samsung Electronics is showing that new technology and new phones are beginning to pay off.

headline: Inspired by the Shouting, Roger Federer Roars Back at Wimbledon
abstract: Down two sets, Federer barked and grunted his way to a victory over Marin Cilic.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The eldest set of Federer twins, 6-year-old Myla and Charlene, were on the grounds Wednesday but not in the stands on Centre Court, where their father was playing five sets in the sunshine.

headline: Nonprofit Linked to de Blasio Seeks to Deflect Ethics Panel’s Subpoena
abstract: A New York State Supreme Court justice heard arguments from the group and the commission investigating whether it engaged in lobbying without registering as a lobbyist.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Mayor Bill de Blasio’s political nonprofit group sought to convince a judge here on Wednesday that it should not be compelled to respond to a subpoena from a state ethics panel.

headline: Baldev Duggal, Film Processing Innovator, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Duggal turned a $200 grubstake into Duggal Visual Solutions, and helped transform the area around the Flatiron Building into a center of fashion and photography.
lead_paragraph: Baldev Duggal, who immigrated from India as a teenage amateur photographer and became a patriarch of the film processing industry, as well as an impetus for reviving the Flatiron district in Manhattan and the Brooklyn Navy Yard, died on June 29 at his vacation home in Truro, Mass. He was 78.

headline: Italy’s Plan for Banks Could Roil Europe
abstract: The Italian government wants to spend $45 billion to prop up banks laden with bad loans. That could increase the strain caused by “Brexit.”
lead_paragraph: Even as Europe grapples with repercussions of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, a dispute over tens of billions of dollars is also threatening to roil the region’s $16 trillion economy.

headline: Border Stops
abstract: Joel Elkins makes his debut, ably assisted by Andrea Carla Michaels.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Virtual high five me! I got this rebus right off the bat. Rebus elements have always been my solving Achilles’ heel, but today’s puzzle, a debut by Joel Elkins and a rebus debut for Andrea Carla Michaels, is a perfect example of the Wordplay philosophy, “Solve more puzzles to become a better solver.” Sooner or later, something will click in your brain and whatever was holding you back will give way to a higher level of solving.

headline: Stories Differ on Clinton Emails
abstract: James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., and Hillary Clinton gave significantly differing accounts of her email use as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., and Hillary Clinton gave significantly differing accounts of her email use as secretary of state.

headline: On a Team That Values Versatility, Adam Warren Is Finding His Place
abstract: Warren, who was traded to the Cubs from the Yankees, started his first game of the season on Wednesday. The pitcher has adapted to a shifting role with Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Adam Warren is a perpetually patient man. So when Zack Cozart, the first batter Warren faced on Wednesday, smacked a full-count fastball over the ivy-covered wall in left field, Warren could only smile about it.

headline: C.D. Brooks Is Dead at 85; Preached Seventh-Day Adventist Message
abstract: For six decades, Mr. Brooks used the “Breath of Life” to help convert tens of thousands and establish 15 congregations in cities across the country.
lead_paragraph: C. D. Brooks, a leading Seventh-day Adventist evangelist who delivered the church’s message to millions as the founding speaker of the Breath of Life media ministry, died on June 5 in Laurel, Md. He was 85.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like the airport shuttle from hell.”

headline: Knicks Drawing on Top Spanish League to Stock Bench
abstract: Center Guillermo Hernangomez and forward Mindaugas Kuzminskas, veterans of the league where Kristaps Porzingis played, both reached deals to join him in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks have been busy this summer remaking their roster. Some of it might even look familiar — at least to fans of the Spanish A.C.B. League.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Netflix releases its latest original movie, “Brahman Naman.” And watch the Backstreet Boys sing their 1990s earworms in “Greatest Hits” on ABC.
lead_paragraph: Netflix releases its latest original movie, the Indian coming-of-age comedy “Brahman Naman.” And watch the Backstreet Boys, Jewel and other musicians sing the earworms of the 1990s in a new episode of “Greatest Hits” on ABC.

headline: House G.O.P. Returns Focus to Obamacare’s Spending Authority
abstract: A Republican report concluded that the administration continued funding for a program central to the health insurance law without congressional approval.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration knowingly spent billions in health care dollars without proper congressional authority and went to “great lengths” to impede congressional scrutiny of the money, Republicans on two major House committees said in a report that will be made public on Thursday.

headline: China Violated Rights of Detained American, U.N. Panel Says
abstract: A rights advocacy group highlighted that view as it sought to put more pressure on China during a visit by the United Nations leader in Beijing this week.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A United Nations committee has said that China has violated international human rights law by detaining without proper cause an American citizen, Phan Phan-Gillis, and has called for her immediate release.

headline: In Shadow of ‘Brexit,’ NATO Will Sound Message of Unity Against Russia
abstract: The multinational group is poised to agree to add four battalions along the eastern front in answer to an increasingly aggressive Russian leadership.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Polish leaders have waited for years for a NATO summit meeting that would recognize what, to them, is a self-evident reality: that the proper way to respond to an increasingly pugnacious Russia is to plant more alliance troops and weaponry along the eastern front.

headline: British Politics Gives a Sense of Government by Old School Chums
abstract: It’s hard not to conclude that Britain’s path into crisis has largely been determined by an elite clique of people plotting with and scheming against one another.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was only a column in The Daily Mail, but in its way, it told you everything you need to know about politics in Britain these days.

headline: Corrections: July 7, 2016
abstract: Corrections Appearing in Print on Thursday, July 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: After Philando Castile’s Killing, Obama Calls Police Shootings ‘an American Issue’
abstract: The president, reacting to a grisly video that showed Mr. Castile being shot by the police in Minnesota, asked the nation to confront racial disparities in law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — President Obama, reacting with the same horror as many Americans to a grisly video of a bloody, dying man in Minnesota who was shot by the police, begged the nation to confront the racial disparities in law enforcement while acknowledging the dangers that officers face.

headline: The E.P.A.’s Civil Rights Problem
abstract: Complaints about facilities in minority areas take much too long to investigate, and the agency has never made a formal finding of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: An oil refinery in a predominantly African-American neighborhood in Beaumont, Tex. A hazardous waste disposal site in Chaves County, N.M., a largely low-income, largely Hispanic area. Two power plants in Pittsburg, Calif., where most of the residents are from minority communities.

headline: The Not-So-Liberal Roberts Court
abstract: It’s worth remembering that today’s conservative justices are a good deal more conservative than the liberal justices are liberal.
lead_paragraph: The takeaway from the term that ended last week seems to be that by the time the Supreme Court, short-handed and stumbling in the wake of Justice Antonin Scalia’s death, finally got its act together at the end of June, it had — lo and behold — turned liberal.

headline: Hillary, Beyond Email
abstract: It’s a good time for Clinton to make changes so she doesn’t win simply by default.
lead_paragraph: Chances are, Hillary Clinton did not grow up dreaming that someday she’d be a woman of whom it could be said that “no reasonable prosecutor” would indict her.

headline: A 16-Year-Old Needs a License. Shouldn’t a Self-Driving Car?
abstract: After a fatal crash of a self-driving Tesla, we need to take a harder look at autopilot technology.
lead_paragraph: IN the United States, a person cannot legally drive until he or she has passed a licensing test. Shouldn’t self-driving vehicles have to pass a test as well?

headline: Heal the V.A. (But First, Do No Harm)
abstract: A commission has recommended a complex public-private partnership to help the department deliver medical care; it should proceed cautiously.
lead_paragraph: Two years after a scandal engulfed the nation’s veterans hospitals, with reports of long waiting lists, cooked appointment books and patients dying while they waited for care, a commission created by Congress has delivered a plan to transform the Veterans Affairs Department over the next 20 years.

headline: Clean Coal, or a Dirty Shame?
abstract: Given the major problems at a plant using carbon capture technology, is the approach economically feasible and environmentally necessary?

headline: How Photography Helped Build the Statue of Liberty
abstract: Famed for his Statue of Liberty, Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was keenly aware of the power of photography to raise awareness – and funds – for his utopian project.
lead_paragraph: Famed for his Statue of Liberty, Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was keenly aware of the power of photography to raise awareness – and funds – for his utopian project.

headline: Danone of France to Buy WhiteWave in $10 Billion Deal to Bolster U.S. Portfolio
abstract: The agreement values WhiteWave at $12.5 billion and would increase Danone’s offerings of organic products and plant-based alternatives to milk and yogurt.
lead_paragraph: Danone, the French company that sells Stonyfield yogurt and Evian water, said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy the WhiteWave Foods Company — maker of Horizon Organic dairy products and Earthbound Farm salad greens, among other brands — for about $10 billion in cash.

headline: How Falling Behind the Joneses Fueled the Rise of Trump
abstract: His supporters have taken a look around the neighborhood and they do not like what they see.
lead_paragraph: In his 1847 pamphlet, “Wage Labour and Capital,” Karl Marx made a point that turns out to be relevant to the Trump phenomenon and the 2016 presidential campaign:

headline: Targeting Apartments in Astoria, Queens
abstract: Emma Petkofsky and Michael Maisch wanted a two-bedroom in Astoria, Queens.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2014, when Emma Petkofsky arrived for graduate school at New York University, she heard about two roommates who needed a third in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Climate Change Claims a Lake, and an Identity
abstract: An indigenous group that survived Spanish and Inca conquest cannot handle the abrupt upheaval of global warming. Lake Poopó was more than their livelihood: It was their identity.
lead_paragraph: An indigenous group that survived Spanish and Inca conquest cannot handle the abrupt upheaval of global warming. Lake Poopó was more than their livelihood: It was their identity.

headline: ‘Time in the Box’: Young Rikers Inmates, Still in Isolation
abstract: New York City is struggling to end solitary confinement at its jails for people under 22. Here are interviews with several young men who as of a few weeks ago were in segregation at Rikers Island.
lead_paragraph: At the time, it was a momentous announcement: New York City officials said they would eliminate solitary confinement at Rikers Island for all inmates under age 22.

headline: Bulgarians Hope Che Guevara and Brigitte Bardot Can Save Their Village
abstract: Two artists want their murals of famous people — alongside portraits of residents — to help start a revival in Staro Zhelezare, population 400.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a natural pairing,” Stefana Gospodinova, a 64-year-old resident of Staro Zhelezare, a remote Bulgarian village, said of herself and Brigitte Bardot, the French femme fatale. “I am mistaken for her all the time.”

headline: The Documents Filed
abstract: After Amy Albritton was arrested, Officers David Helms and Duc Nguyen submitted an incident report and a subsequent laboratory evidence form to the Houston Police Department.
lead_paragraph: After Amy Albritton was arrested, Officers David Helms and Duc Nguyen submitted an incident report and a subsequent laboratory evidence form to the Houston Police Department.

headline: How Photography Helped Build the Statue of Liberty
abstract: Famed for his Statue of Liberty, Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was keenly aware of the power of photography to raise awareness — and funds — for his utopian project.
lead_paragraph: Photography was still in its early years when the 20-year-old Alsatian-born Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi traveled to Egypt with a box camera. He returned with calotypes and, more important, a fascination with the monumental architecture of antiquity — undoubtedly planting the seeds for the gigantism of his own designs for the Statue of Liberty. Although he soon sidelined photography in favor of painting and sculpture, it’s a medium whose visionary possibilities he recognized in the the early stages of its development.

headline: How a $2 Roadside Drug Test Sends Innocent People to Jail
abstract: Widespread evidence shows that these tests routinely produce false positives. Why are police departments and prosecutors across the country still using them?
lead_paragraph: Amy Albritton can’t remember if her boyfriend signaled when he changed lanes late that August afternoon in 2010. But suddenly the lights on the Houston Police patrol car were flashing behind them, and Anthony Wilson was navigating Albritton’s white Chrysler Concorde to a stop in a strip-mall parking lot. It was an especially unwelcome hassle. Wilson was in Houston to see about an oil-rig job; Albritton, volunteering her car, had come along for what she imagined would be a vacation of sorts. She managed an apartment complex back in Monroe, La., and the younger of her two sons — Landon, 16, who had been disabled from birth by cerebral palsy — was with his father for the week. After five hours of driving through the monotony of flat woodland, the couple had checked into a motel, carted their luggage to the room and returned to the car, too hungry to rest but too drained to seek out anything more than fast food. Now two officers stepped out of their patrol car and approached.

headline: Kerri Walsh Jennings Seeks Olympic Success With a New Partner
abstract: Kerri Walsh Jennings, seeking her fourth gold medal, is teamed with April Ross, a silver medalist in 2012, whose style differs from that of her predecessor.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — Plans for winning a gold medal at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro were laid before medals were awarded at the last Olympics.

headline: Bombing at Bangladesh’s Largest Eid Gathering Kills at Least 3
abstract: The Islamic State had warned that more violence would follow the militants’ bloody siege in Dhaka, the capital, last week.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A bombing at Bangladesh’s largest gathering for the Eid al-Fitr holiday killed two police officers and a civilian on Thursday, police officials said, a day after the Islamic State warned that more attacks would follow the militants’ bloody siege in the capital last week.

headline: Should We Still Listen to Prozac? Peter D. Kramer Jumps Back Into the Antidepressant Debate
abstract: Do antidepressants work? More often than not, argues the author of “Listening to Prozac.”
lead_paragraph: ORDINARILY WELLThe Case for AntidepressantsBy Peter D. Kramer310 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

headline: The Curtain Falls on Valentino’s Double Act
abstract: Valentino’s longtime designer duo of Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli is no more. A day after unveiling their new couture collection, Ms. Chiuri on Wednesday announced her departure.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris couture shows concluded Wednesday night with, well, a conclusion: the final Valentino show designed by the longtime team of Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli, the pair who had proved to the world that fashion fairy tales were possible, and that a brand intimately associated with a single founder could have a well-written transition and a happy second act in the hands of others.

headline: Minnesota, Baton Rouge, Euro 2016: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Amid Political Uncertainty, Australia Faces Ratings Downgrade
abstract: Standard & Poor’s warned that it could lower Australia’s gilt-edged triple-A credit rating in the next two years in light of an inconclusive election.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Even as global economic worries move investors to pour their money into seemingly stable Australia, political deadlock is jeopardizing the country’s long-held image as a financial haven.

headline: Where to Go in Toronto
abstract: The turbocharged growth of Toronto’s downtown long bypassed Corktown, but now the scruffy historic patch is attracting attention.
lead_paragraph: Lower rents and uncommon architectural stock are drawing entrepreneurs to Corktown, on downtown Toronto’s eastern fringes. For years, the turbocharged growth of the city’s downtown bypassed the area. Empty storefronts outnumbered its well-preserved 19th-century rowhouses, the remnants of working class Irish-Catholic immigrants who provided Corktown’s name. Public housing in the neighborhood’s Regent Park also seemed to inhibit newcomers. But as condos sprout on Corktown’s edges, small businesses are setting up along the main roads, King and Queen Streets. Corktown remains one of downtown’s quieter quarters, but the buzz around this historic patch keeps growing.

headline: Sand Sculptures Making a Splash at Beach Weddings
abstract: Some couples are spending up to $3,000, or more, for a memory of their day, even if it doesn’t last from here to eternity.
lead_paragraph: When Anthony Rossomando told his mother about the sand sculpture he and his fiancée, Stephanie Angelone, were having made for their beach wedding at the Casa Marina, a Waldorf Astoria resort in Key West, Fla., Mr. Rossomando recalled his mother saying, “How nice.”

headline: London, South of the River (Before ‘Brexit’)
abstract: A return visit to the south side of the Thames finds a rich multicultural milieu that the author hopes won’t change after the ‘Brexit’ vote.
lead_paragraph: When I was an undergraduate a few decades ago, I spent a semester at Goldsmiths College (now officially Goldsmiths, University of London), in New Cross, in southeast London. Ever since, I’d wanted to go back and see the small campus, with its cluster of midcentury dorms and surrounding streets of general decrepitude: sagging rowhouses; low-end shops; pubs and the occasional greasy spoon. At the time, Goldsmiths was the only study-in-London program I could find that allowed one-semester students like me to live and study amid our British counterparts, rather than in an Americans-only bubble.

headline: Burma Noodle Bar
abstract: A brief and possibly ephemeral Burmese menu at the Industry City Food Hall in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A brief and possibly ephemeral Burmese menu at the Industry City Food Hall in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Burmese Bites
abstract: Behind the New York Hall of Science in Queens, a tent dedicated to Burmese palata.
lead_paragraph: Behind the New York Hall of Science in Queens, a tent dedicated to Burmese palata.

headline: Burmese Food in New York: Hard to Find but Easy to Love
abstract: The search ends at two shoe box restaurants, Burmese Bites in Queens and Burma Noodle Bar in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, the only place to find Myo Lin Thway’s palata was the once-a-year Myanmar Baptist Church Fun Fair in Queens.

headline: New York Today: The Heat Is Here
abstract: Thursday: Hot weather on tap, Brooklyn Lobster Fest and a trip to the North Pole.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:58 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: Italy’s Plan for Banks Is Dividing Europe
abstract: More British Property Funds Halt Withdrawals | Wall Street Scion Pleads Guilty to Charges in $40 Million Fraud
lead_paragraph: ITALY’S PLAN FOR BANKS IS DIVIDING EUROPE The Italian government needs to spend an estimated $45 billion to shore up its banks, which are burdened with bad loans. But fears that European authorities will bar the government from providing this support is adding to turbulence in the aftermath of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, Peter Eavis reports in DealBook. And the situation could keep investors on edge through the summer.

headline: Democrats Plan Early Attacks Tying G.O.P. Candidates to Trump
abstract: Aiming to exploit Donald J. Trump’s unpopularity, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee will spend over $1 million on ads casting the G.O.P. as wholly defined by him.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats are poised to mount a major offensive tying Republicans on the ballot to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign. Aiming to exploit Mr. Trump’s drastic unpopularity with swing voters, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee will spend over $1 million on advertisements casting the Republican Party as wholly defined by Mr. Trump.

headline: Does NATO Still Exist?
abstract: The Atlantic alliance seems to have forgotten its purpose.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Treaties are made to turn a will into an obligation. But what happens when this will changes? British voters have just given one example — however ill-informed — by dismissing the idea that European Union treaties deliver value to their country. Discomforting as it may be, there’s reason to take a critical look at an even older accord that binds the nations of the West: the NATO treaty.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Quest of Dungeon Master Dad
abstract: Five-year-olds don’t need guidebooks to imagine an epic brawl with an owlbear.
lead_paragraph: Paul writes: I have a dispute with my son’s friend’s parents. They feel that Dungeons & Dragons is inappropriate for 5-year-olds. I think the imaginative play is good for our boys, but the other parents believe that the game will make their child an outcast. Help these parents see reason and allow their child to play a game of D.&D.

headline: Peacemaking Goes Awry as Donald Trump Lashes Out at G.O.P. Senators
abstract: Mr. Trump was in Washington for meetings with congressional members, including one with Ted Cruz, the Texas senator who came closest to toppling him this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A peacemaking summit meeting between Republican lawmakers and their renegade presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, descended on Thursday into an extraordinary series of acrid exchanges, punctuated by Mr. Trump’s threatening one Republican senator and deriding another as a “loser.”

headline: Cynthia Ozick: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Critics, Monsters, Fanatics, and Other Literary Essays” leans to “Nabokov rather than Hemingway. If less is more, it is nevertheless also loss.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Critics, Monsters, Fanatics, and Other Literary Essays” leans to “Nabokov rather than Hemingway. If less is more, it is nevertheless also loss.”

headline: The Perfect Imperfections of Blueberry Pie
abstract: Solving the mysteries of a dessert that’s worth getting just right.
lead_paragraph: “You’re never going to get a perfect blueberry pie,” said Miriam Foster, cheerfully. “That’s the whole point of blueberry pie!” Foster is a baker who, with her husband, Grayson Murphy, runs the Orient Country Store on the East End of Long Island. Her pies are perfect. I was in line there once, and a tween pointed to one on the countertop. “That is like the Beyoncé of pastries,” she said. “There is literally nothing wrong with it.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Set to Embrace Clinton, but Does He Deserve a Prime-Time Speech?
abstract: A weekly politics chat also looks at Hillary Clinton’s email fiasco, Donald Trump’s troubles and vice-presidential possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshot’s elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor based in New York, discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

headline: Peter Doig Says He Didn’t Paint This. Now He Has to Prove It.
abstract: A former corrections officer who said he knew Mr. Doig filed the lawsuit, saying the painter’s denials blew up a plan to sell the work for millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: O.K., Peter Doig may have tried LSD a few times when he was growing up in Canada during the 1970s. But he still knows, he said, when a painting is or isn’t his.

headline: Shock and Denial in Bangladesh
abstract: The government has focused on squashing the opposition instead of confronting the threat from jihadists.
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh is still in shock and mourning after the brutal terrorist attack in the country’s capital, Dhaka, last Friday when five or more young jihadists burst into a restaurant and tortured and killed at least 20 people, mostly foreigners. On Thursday, a bombing at a prayer ground where tens of thousands of people gathered for Eid al-Fitr, the holiday that concludes the holy month of Ramadan, killed two police officers and a civilian.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservatives Decide a Woman Should Lead Britain
abstract: Tory lawmakers have chosen Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom as finalists who will go before the party’s rank-and-file members to become its next leader, as well as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Conservative lawmakers have ensured Britain’s next prime minister will be a woman, choosing Theresa May, the home secretary, and Andrea Leadsom, an energy minister, as finalists in their party’s leadership contest.

headline: Ralph Lauren’s Turnaround Plan Has Parallels of Ford Motor’s Road Map
abstract: The fashion company, under a new chief, is starting from a stronger position than Ford had in 2006, when it started its renaissance.
lead_paragraph: When the Ralph Lauren Corporation recently unveiled a turnaround plan, calling it “The Way Forward,” it unwittingly invoked another all-American icon fallen on hard times: Ford Motor, whose “Way Forward” plan in 2006 saved the automaker from bankruptcy.

headline: A Foot in the Door (or Something Like That), and We’re Off
abstract: The New York Times’s new public editor introduces herself to readers.
lead_paragraph: The first day in a new job is never easy. I got my heel stuck in the gap between the elevator and the floor and thought it was over before I reached my office.

headline: China to Pillory, or Praise, Cities Based on Water Pollution
abstract: The Ministry of Environmental Protection has said it plans to monitor supplies in 338 cities and each month name the 10 best and 10 worst.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese environmental officials are increasingly turning to naming and shaming cities that fail to bring down pollution levels.

headline: Video Review: The New Audi Q7 Drops to Fighting Weight
abstract: The big three-row Audi S.U.V. that has been produced for over a decade returns for 2017 lighter and stuffed with family-friendly technology.
lead_paragraph: WHETHER it’s for a coming high school reunion or making those favorite jeans tolerable again, nearly all of us wouldn’t mind dropping some weight. The same goes for cars. Lighter vehicles are quicker, and they chug less fuel.

headline: Not Forgotten: Arthur Conan Doyle, the Spiritualist Behind the Rational Sherlock Holmes
abstract: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, remembered for creating the staunchly rational Sherlock Holmes, was also a devoted spiritualist.
lead_paragraph: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, remembered for creating the staunchly rational Sherlock Holmes, was also a devoted spiritualist.

headline: No Sympathy About Cockroaches
abstract: Recalling a building superintendent’s snappy comeback to a tenant who made a complaint about vermin in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In Case You Missed It: June's Top Real Estate Stories
abstract: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

headline: Why Dieters Flock to Instagram
abstract: Instagram may have success as a dieting platform because it lets people have the level of connection — or privacy — they crave, a researcher says.
lead_paragraph: On Instagram, devotees of a diet called the Whole30 have shared more than a million colorful photos of gluten-free, sugar-free, alcohol-free and dairy-free meals, and the occasional image of people showing off their bodies after 30 days of diet restrictions.

headline: Amazon’s Audible Goes Long on Short-Form Audio
abstract: The audiobook and spoken-word company is selling access to an extensive library of short-form audio, including original programs, for $4.95 per month.
lead_paragraph: Amazon hopes to persuade people to pay for something they have traditionally enjoyed free: short-form audio.

headline: Review: ‘The Night Of’ Takes a Cab Ride to Hell
abstract: HBO’s limited series is a detailed procedural, but one in the spirit of true-crime stories like “Serial,” about the challenge of serving justice.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, there was the procedural. “Dragnet,” “Law & Order” and the like set the template for television crime stories that took viewers briskly though the process by which bad guys get caught.

headline: 1931 | Advertisement of a Death Foretold
abstract: The Times receives thousands of death notices annually. At least one came directly from the decedent.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, reflects on an unusual death notice.

headline: Makers of Self-Driving Cars Ask What to Do With Human Nature
abstract: The difficulty of getting drivers to take control of automated cars when necessary has prompted many automakers to take people out of the equation.
lead_paragraph: EVEN before Tesla revealed that a fatal accident had occurred while one of its cars was in semiautonomous driving mode, a debate was well underway between researchers and engineers: Is it possible to get a driver to safely take back control of a car once the vehicle has started driving itself?

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Cough That Won’t Stop
abstract: A 43-year-old man starts to cough every time he takes a deep breath. Can you figure out why?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: A 43-year-old man starts to cough every time he takes a deep breath. Can you help him figure out why?

headline: F.B.I. Director James Comey Testifies Before Congress
abstract: The F.B.I. Director, James Comey, will testify before Congress on Thursday before the House Oversight Committee. He is expected to be questioned about his recommendation on Tuesday that Hillary Clinton face no criminal charges for her handling of email while secretary of state.

headline: Serena Williams Reaches Wimbledon Final, but Venus Williams Falls
abstract: Angelique Kerber beat Venus Williams, 6-4, 6-4, and Serena Williams beat Elena Vesnina, 6-2, 6-0, setting up Saturday’s final.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It had been nearly six years since Venus Williams had been in a moment like this: Years of figuring out how to play with Sjogren’s syndrome, an autoimmune disease. Years of battling back to the top 10 after being outside the top 100. Years of enduring early-round losses at Grand Slam tournaments.

headline: Denmark’s Tougher Citizenship Test Stumps Even Its Natives
abstract: The government, which has been tightening rules on immigration, has made little effort to hide the goal of the exam: to make it significantly harder to become Danish.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Which Danish restaurant gained a third Michelin star in February 2016?

headline: Bode Men’s Wear, Cut From Vintage Cloth
abstract: The designer Emily Adams Bode asked four friends, and not necessarily models, to try on her garments.
lead_paragraph: The designer Emily Adams Bode asked four friends, and not necessarily models, to try on her garments.

headline: Brand to Know: A Men’s Wear Line Made From Vintage Quilts
abstract: The pants and button-downs by Emily Adams Bode began as bedspreads — or grain sacks or uncut dish towels.
lead_paragraph: The designer Emily Adams Bode has been accumulating fabric since childhood; she inherited some from her grandmother, and picked up other pieces while antiquing with her mom. Eventually, she began to frequent estate sales and trade shows herself, and buying surplus that vintage stores couldn’t sell. Now 27, Bode’s Lower East Side workroom is filled with everything from 19th- and 20th-century quilts (including several Victorian ones with intricate threading) to handwoven African textiles, from old stock from dish towel companies to grain sacks, and abstract floral fabrics that she created with a couple in India. Nearby stands a jam-packed rack of pants, shirts and jackets that a local tailor cut from these unexpected fabrics.

headline: Danone Expands With WhiteWave Deal, but at a High Cost
abstract: The French dairy company can get away with it because expanding outside of Europe looks attractive, and debt comes cheap.
lead_paragraph: Danone’s purchase of the WhiteWave Foods Company, a soy and almond milk maker based in the United States, is an expensive way of buying growth. The French dairy company can get away with it because expanding outside of Europe looks attractive, and debt comes cheap.

headline: Edie Campbell and Christabel MacGreevy’s Patches — and the Clothes to Wear Them on
abstract: The model and illustrator, longtime friends, will launch an 85-piece limited edition collection at Dover Street Market in London this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The model and illustrator, longtime friends, will launch an 85-piece limited edition collection at Dover Street Market in London this weekend.

headline: Playful Patches (and Vintage Clothing) Created by Friends
abstract: The model Edie Campbell and the illustrator Christabel MacGreevy have started a company of iron-ons — and now, the clothes to wear them on.
lead_paragraph: “Patches have always been symbols of identity,” says the illustrator Christabel MacGreevy. “They’re a way of marking allegiance and signing up to something, whether it’s your school, the band you like or a 1970s motorcycle gang.” MacGreevy, 25, is herself outfitted in patches on a recent morning in London: her black jeans are worn with a baseball vest that has the word ‘chic’ stitched onto the front. She is discussing the ethos behind Itchy Scratchy Patchy, the playful line of decorative patches — and now clothing — that she co-founded with her lifelong friend, the British model Edie Campbell, a year ago. Decorated with brightly stitched marigolds, toadstools, centipedes and sumo wrestlers, her leather biker jacket, which is nonchalantly slung over the back of a chair, is a vivid scrapbook of the brand’s embroidered iron-ons, which have become popular with Courtney Love and Gigi Hadid.

headline: ‘Brexit’ and Russia Loom Over Obama’s Final NATO Summit Meeting
abstract: The meeting will take place amid tumult including Russian aggression in Eastern Europe and disarray since Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama arrived here early on Friday morning to attend a NATO summit meeting that is unfolding against a tumultuous backdrop of renewed Russian aggression in Eastern Europe, a migrant crisis and terrorism fears on the Continent’s southern rim and internal disarray in the wake of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.

headline: Ford Explorers Under Scrutiny for Exhaust Fumes Inside Vehicle
abstract: The company and its dealers have tried to solve the problem in the past, but only if owners complained.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are investigating whether more than 600,000 Ford Explorers, in model years 2011 to 2015, should be recalled because exhaust fumes can enter the passenger compartment.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret Life of Pets’ Amuses, but Misses Opportunities
abstract: This film is clearly the work of dog people, and traffics — like nearly every other movie in its genre — in some tired anti-feline stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: First things first: “The Secret Life of Pets” is preceded by a short film starring the Minions, in which those irrepressible yellow gelcaps take up landscaping so they can purchase a blender. You may regard this extra little cartoon as a bonus or a tax, depending on your level of Minion tolerance. Mine reached its end around 90 seconds before the movie did. But in any case, Illumination Entertainment and Universal Pictures are determined to keep selling toys and Halloween costumes, and it’s pointless to protest the merchandising of manufactured cuteness.

headline: The ‘Intentional Summer’ Challenge: Go on a Quest
abstract: Find a hike with a treasure hunt, choose an unusual side trip on a vacation or set out to find something specific.
lead_paragraph: Challenge No. 3: Plan a quest — find a hike with a treasure hunt, choose an unusual side trip on a vacation or set out to find something specific.

headline: Apple’s iOS 10 Is Available for Beta Testers Who Want a Head Start
abstract: Early adopters can try the new messaging app and improved photo software, and they can help the tech giant fix problems before the full release in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Apple on Thursday released an early version of its next mobile operating system, which will deliver some of the most substantial changes to iPhones and iPads in years.

headline: Climate Refugees: Bolivia
abstract: The disappearance of Lake Poopó has not only destroyed the livelihoods of hundreds of fishing families, but also added to a new category of climate refugees.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance of Lake Poopó has not only destroyed the livelihoods of hundreds of fishing families, but also added to a new category of climate refugees.

headline: 1966: Sacrifices for Common Market
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: French Prime Minister Pompidou reminds British leaders of France’s sacrifices for the Common market in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Georges Pompidou of France visited 10 Downing Street in London in July 1966. British Pathé.

headline: Former Barclays Traders Sentenced in Libor-Rigging Case
abstract: Four men were sentenced to as long as six and a half years in prison by a London judge for conspiring to manipulate the benchmark interest rate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Four former Barclays employees were sentenced to prison terms on Thursday – the longest of which was six and a half years – after three of the traders were convicted last week of plotting to manipulate the benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: Exquisitely Patterned Plates
abstract: Exuberant motifs inspired by Indonesian batiks, French toiles or Turkish tiles upend the boring white.
lead_paragraph: Exuberant motifs inspired by Indonesian batiks, French toiles or Turkish tiles upend the boring white.

headline: Deadly Police Shooting in Minnesota
abstract: Philando Castile was shot and killed by a police officer during a traffic stop in a suburb of St. Paul. A passenger documented the aftermath in a live video stream.
lead_paragraph: Philando Castile was shot and killed by a police officer during a traffic stop in a suburb of St. Paul. A passenger documented the aftermath in a live video stream.

headline: Olympic Hurdler Isn’t Letting Disease Stand in His Way
abstract: Aries Merritt, an Olympic gold medalist in the 110-meter hurdles in 2012 and a kidney transplant recipient in 2015, is trying to qualify for the team again, beginning Friday.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — At the 2012 London Olympics, Aries Merritt of the United States won a gold medal in the 110-meter hurdles. Several weeks later, he shattered the world record in 12.80 seconds, his braids gathered in a ponytail, his left leg jabbing over each hurdle like a celebratory finger.

headline: The Great New York Whale Census
abstract: A new survey is aiming to find out why so many whales are passing through New York’s waters, and determining how close they venture to crowded shipping lanes.
lead_paragraph: If your knowledge of New York’s wildlife is limited to pigeons and squirrels, Howard Rosenbaum, the director of the Ocean Giants program at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, Brooklyn, has some surprising news. “In less distance out to sea than the average New Yorker’s commute home,” he said, “there is likely a whale singing at this very moment.”

headline: 1891: Mapping Columbus’s Arrival
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In July 1891, an expedition ascertains that Christopher Columbus landed on Watling Island.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An expedition which was recently sent out from Chicago has ascertained that Columbus landed on Watling Island, and has accordingly erected a monument in his honor on the exact spot where his feet first pressed the soil. Nothing is easier than to find out upon what island Columbus first landed. You write the names of the three islands which claim this honor on separate slips of paper, and, after putting them in a hat, draw out the correct name. This is doubtless the course which was pursued by the members of the Chicago expedition; but why they should have troubled themselves about Columbus and his discoveries is not so clear. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 8, 1891

headline: Jazz Pianist Joey Alexander Turns 13 and Debuts New Song ‘City Lights’
abstract: The Latin-tinged track — an original composition that aims to capture the energy of New York City — will appear on his second album, due in September.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago the jazz pianist Joey Alexander turned 13. Given the unusual arc of his young career, it shouldn’t be a surprise that he celebrated onstage with his trio, at the Freihofer’s Saratoga Jazz Festival. After the performance, he was presented with a cake in the shape of a grand piano, and thousands in the crowd sang “Happy Birthday,” basking in a moment that Joey himself seemed to take in stride.

headline: The Photographer Capturing Downtown New York’s Single-Story Buildings — Before They’re Gone
abstract: Adam Friedberg, a 25-year resident of the East Village, has pledged to photograph every one-level building, or “low rider,” remaining in his community.
lead_paragraph: Adam Friedberg, a 25-year resident of the East Village, has pledged to photograph every one-level building, or “low rider,” remaining in his community.

headline: Daily Report: Where Are the Futurists?
abstract: Farhad Manjoo argues that Alvin Toffler’s forecast of “future shock” has largely come to pass, and what we’ve ended up with is future blindness.
lead_paragraph: Futurists once had a future. Now, not so much — and that’s a shame.

headline: The Deadliest Guns Need the Most Control
abstract: We won’t reduce gun violence until we recognize that some guns are more dangerous than others.
lead_paragraph: If the National Rifle Association’s Nov. 8 doomsday scenario of a Clinton victory proves true, there will be a serious gun-control bill sitting on President Hillary Clinton’s Oval Office desk before 2017 is over. The question then is: What would be the most effective way to reduce gun violence through new regulations or laws?

headline: Jon Jones’s Removal From Card Hits U.F.C. 200 Hard
abstract: The announcement late Wednesday that Jones had potentially failed a drug test and was off the card for U.F.C. 200 on Saturday was a major blow.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship was not in a great position to suffer a setback just before its biggest weekend of fighting ever. So the announcement late Wednesday that Jon Jones had potentially failed a drug test and was off the card for U.F.C. 200 on Saturday was a major blow.

headline: Race for Britain’s Prime Minister Down to Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom
abstract: Ms. May, the home secretary, or Ms. Leadsom, an energy minister, will become the first woman to lead Britain since Margaret Thatcher resigned in 1990.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One way or another, Britain will have its second female prime minister.

headline: Android Security When You Need It
abstract: The current version of Google’s operating system, Android 6.0, offers several ways to unlock your device’s screen — with or without your direct input.
lead_paragraph: Q. I forgot my Android tablet at work one night and used the Android Device Manager to remotely lock it from home. I got the tablet the next day, but now it requests the password every time I want to use it. Except for the odd occasion when I bring it to the office, I mostly use it at home and don’t need the password, so how can I remove the requirement?

headline: Your Awkward Family Travel Photos
abstract: We partnered with AwkwardFamilyPhotos.com and asked our readers to send us their uncomfortable vacation photos. These are some of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: We partnered with AwkwardFamilyPhotos.com and asked our readers to send us their uncomfortable vacation photos. These are some of our favorites.

headline: Why Do More Black Women Die of Breast Cancer? A Study Aims to Find Out
abstract: Scientist will investigate whether genetic and biological factors, not just lifestyle factors, influence racial disparities.
lead_paragraph: Black women are at a greater risk of dying of breast cancer and of suffering from aggressive subtypes of the disease. Recent advances in survival rates among women of other races haven’t applied to them, and scientists aim to better understand why through a large study.

headline: Baton Rouge Is Passionate, and Peaceful, After Shooting of Alton Sterling
abstract: As a crowd thinned from Wednesday night to Thursday morning outside the store where Mr. Sterling was killed by officers, there was almost no visible police presence.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — The protest of the fatal police shooting of a CD vendor here in Louisiana’s capital had many of the trappings of similar flare-ups around the country: blaring music, young men with faces obscured by bandannas, and obscene and brutal sentiments directed toward the local police department, on angry tongues and homemade placards.

headline: Asset Manager Extends Stay of Withdrawals in British Funds
abstract: Aberdeen Asset Management said that a temporary bar on redemptions in its British real estate funds would remain in place until noon on Monday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Aberdeen Asset Management said on Thursday that it would extend a temporary bar on redemptions in its British property funds through Monday.

headline: Europe Turns Inward, Just as Challenges on Its Borders Mount
abstract: If Middle Eastern countries fear infection from Syria’s civil war, so do many European countries fear infection by the British vote to leave their union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is hard, if not impossible, to recall a time when Europe’s view across the Mediterranean has been so clouded by conflagration in what seems a redrawn crescent of crisis from North Africa to Turkey.

headline: Germany Passes ‘No Means No’ Law After Cologne Attacks
abstract: The legislation would make it possible to prosecute in cases where victims made clear they did not want to engage in sexual activity, even if they did not cry out for help.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German lawmakers unanimously approved legislation on Thursday that would make it easier to prosecute suspects of sexual violence and that defines rape as the violation of a woman’s will under the principle of “no means no.”

headline: The Story After ‘Chariots of Fire’
abstract: “The Last Race’’ recounts the last years of Eric Liddell, a British Olympic runner who died in a Japanese labor camp in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Thirty-five years ago, a low-budget film from Britain about two runners who represented the country in the 1924 Olympics became a worldwide hit and went on to win four Academy Awards, including best picture.

headline: How Wall Street Bro Talk Keeps Women Down
abstract: Objectifying women was the rite of passage through which I entered the world of men.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a 27-year-old bond trader at Bank of America, I went to dinner with a managing director and a high-profile client, both men, at a Brazilian all-you-can-eat meat restaurant in Manhattan. The waitress came by to see if we wanted another round of drinks. When she was out of earshot, the client said, “I’d like to bend her over the table, give her some meat.” They laughed. I forced a smile. On the way home, I fumed. I was troubled by the comment, and disgusted by the man who said it. But I was angry with myself. Why hadn’t I said anything?

headline: From Dante to ‘Walking Dead,’ He’s a Master of Immersive Theater
abstract: The director and designer Michael Counts prepares his new show, “Paradiso: Chapter 1,” a suspense thriller that is also a game.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long drab hallway, on an upper floor of an office building in Koreatown, the director and designer Michael Counts was making a warren of escape rooms. The space was a gut job, and after a month of toil it was mostly unfinished wood and sawdust-coated surfaces, with a couple of gleaming exceptions. If you looked closely, you could see it was a set, fitted snugly inside the exterior walls.

headline: Would Donald Trump Quit if He Wins the Election? He Doesn’t Rule It Out
abstract: Some in political circles still feel Mr. Trump could decline to be president if elected. “I’ll let you know how I feel about it after it happens,” he told us.
lead_paragraph: The traditional goal of a presidential nominee is to win the presidency and then serve as president.

headline: Etna Fumes and Spews, but the Winemaking Goes On
abstract: The existential threat is ever-present, yet the promise proves too tough to resist.
lead_paragraph: RANDAZZO, Sicily — Chiara Vigo was just a young girl at the time, but the eruption of Mount Etna in 1981 is burned into her memory.

headline: Good, Bad, and Mad: The News with Andrew Rosenthal
abstract: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on wasteful investigations, police shootings and polls that show diminishing support for Donald Trump among women voters.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on wasteful investigations, police shootings and polls that show diminishing support for Donald Trump among women voters.

headline: Dresses Our Brides Have Worn
abstract: A selection of wedding-day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.
lead_paragraph: A selection of wedding-day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.

headline: My Stepmother Calls Herself Mom but Doesn’t Act Like One. What to Do?
abstract: Also, competitive tipping, roommate troubles and houseguest etiquette on vacation.
lead_paragraph: My father’s wife of 13 years, who has no children, has started calling herself our mom on Facebook. My sisters and I never lived with her and don’t relate to her or our father well because of their alcoholism. She posts corny images of kittens with quotes like, “My daughters are my whole world!” But she barely telephones to ask how we are. We call her “Mom,” not to hurt her feelings. But it feels unjust to our real mother, who raised us alone after our father abandoned us in our harrowing teen years. We have somewhat repaired our relationship with him and want to keep the peace. Is there a kind way to communicate our discomfort?

headline: Dwyane Wade’s Game Plan Includes Fashion Design
abstract: The 12-time N.B.A. All-Star is slowly building a label of his own.
lead_paragraph: He’s a 12-time National Basketball Association All-Star, with three championship rings and one eye on a future in fashion. Dwyane Wade has a line of watches, socks and underwear to his name so far. The 34-year-old guard, who will be returning to Chicago, his home city, as a member of the Bulls after 13 seasons with the Miami Heat, recently released his eighth collection of neckties with the Tie Bar, a Chicago-based brand. But his fashion plans go far beyond that.

headline: Alasdair McLellan Photographs a Famous London Skateboard Gang
abstract: For a new show opening this week at the ICA, the photographer turns his lens on London’s Palace Wayward Boys Choir.
lead_paragraph: For a new show opening this week at the ICA, the photographer turns his lens on London’s Palace Wayward Boys Choir.

headline: Capturing London’s Homegrown Skateboarding Brand, in Pictures
abstract: A new exhibition honors the influence of the South London group the Palace Wayward Boys Choir.
lead_paragraph: The Palace Wayward Boys Choir doesn’t sing — and their titular palace is a rental house near London’s Waterloo station. Instead, the boys make up a London skateboard gang — and have gone from shooting shaky videos to lending their name to the city’s lines-around-the-block cult fashion label, Palace.

headline: How to Fix Wall Street’s Flawed System of Compensation
abstract: Partners should shoulder more liability and be held accountable when their banks take big risks with other people’s money, an academic says.
lead_paragraph: When a professor emeritus at the London School of Economics, who also spent many years as an adviser at the Bank of England, publicly endorses a much-needed – but generally overlooked – overhaul of Wall Street, that is an occasion for celebration.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: The News With Andrew Rosenthal
abstract: The opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on wasteful investigations, police shootings and polls that show diminishing support for Donald Trump among women.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into working and thinking at The New York Times. Today, Andrew Rosenthal, an opinion columnist with The Times, responds to recent news: the good, the bad and the most maddening.

headline: Rise in Health Premiums
abstract: A reader writes of Obamacare, “I’d rather pay more than have no insurance.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Plan to Curb Tax-Inversion Deals Could Go Too Far
abstract: The Treasury Department wants to curb a practice called earnings stripping, but its efforts could hurt normal funding practices.
lead_paragraph: There’s a harmful flip side to the push against tax-inversion deals in the United States. The Treasury Department’s latest plan to curb tax-motivated overseas mergers takes aim at inter-company loans. It is a good idea to curb this so-called earnings stripping. The proposed rule is broad, however, and could hurt normal funding practices.

headline: Humane Treatment of Workers in Poultry Plants
abstract: An Oxfam executive hails Perdue’s efforts to improve chickens’ lives, but asks, “What about the workers in its plants,” often denied bathroom breaks?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Progress on Gay Rights
abstract: A gay activist hopes that the appointment of an independent expert to fight discrimination will be a harbinger of advances to come.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Racist’ Killing of Nigerian Asylum Seeker Stuns and Saddens Italy
abstract: The victim and his wife, who were assaulted by a man hurling racist abuse, had fled to Italy to escape the extremist group Boko Haram, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An Italian man who the authorities say hurled racist abuse at a Nigerian couple and beat the husband when he came to his wife’s defense was charged on Thursday with manslaughter, after the husband died from his injuries.

headline: Runners on Film: Alexi Pappas Makes More Movies
abstract: Elite distance runner Alexi Pappas has created a series of short films musing about the lives of elite runners.
lead_paragraph: Alexi Pappas is a renaissance runner. She writes poems. She makes and stars in movies. She tweets. Even her signature bun has its own Twitter account.

headline: Narcissist Donald Trump
abstract: A reader writes that the presidential candidate can’t see past his own views.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Who Benefits From the Income Tax Credit?
abstract: Readers take issue with the notion that expanding the earned-income tax credit program is better than raising the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
