headline: Speed Up, Slowpoke, or Get a Ticket
abstract: Laws targeting slow drivers in the left lane are being introduced in more states with the goal of reducing congestion and accidents.
lead_paragraph: Slowpokes, beware: More states are cracking down on drivers who dawdle in the left lane.

headline: 500-Million-Year-Old Worm Was an Undersea Architect
abstract: What scientists originally thought was ancient seaweed turned out to be tubelike shelters built by ancient sea worms.
lead_paragraph: Some 500 million years ago the ocean floor was covered in apartment complexes built by prehistoric worms.

headline: Magnificent Obsession Morphs Into a Stained-Glass Museum
abstract: A real estate magnate has invested millions of dollars in stained-glass windows, mosaics and clocks that will be in a new museum in Evanston, Ill.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Passageways lined in stained glass snake through a museum in progress on a quiet side street here, and workers are filling the galleries with iridescent mosaics, opalescent glass vases and ornate clocks that contain tiny mechanical birds and acrobats. The collections on view represent a fraction of the holdings of Cameel Halim, a real estate magnate in the Chicago area, and his Halim Museum of Time and Glass, which is scheduled to open early next year.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Expected to Endorse Hillary Clinton Next Week
abstract: The senator and candidate are expected to appear together in New Hampshire on Tuesday, said three Democrats involved in the planning.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of private preparations, Senator Bernie Sanders is expected to endorse Hillary Clinton on Tuesday at a campaign event in New Hampshire, according to three Democrats who have been involved in the planning.

headline: F.B.I. Director Testifies on Clinton Emails to Withering Criticism From G.O.P.
abstract: Republican lawmakers on Thursday used blunt testimony from the director, James B. Comey, to try to build a case that Hillary Clinton repeatedly lied to the public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey Jr., defended himself Thursday against an onslaught of Republican criticism for ending the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails, but he also provided new details that could prove damaging to her just weeks before she is to be named the Democrats’ presidential nominee.

headline: 36 Hours in Helsinki, Finland
abstract: Every corner of this cool Nordic city is heating up, with a renewed waterfront, renovated museums and revived industrial spaces.
lead_paragraph: Every corner of this cool Nordic city is heating up, with a renewed waterfront, renovated museums and revived industrial spaces.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino, Maison Margiela, Jean Paul Gaultier and Viktor & Rolf
abstract: A photo diary of the fall 2016 couture shows that were presented in Paris on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall 2016 couture shows that were presented in Paris on Wednesday.

headline: Met Opera’s New Concertmaster: The Canadian Violinist Nikki Chooi
abstract: The 27-year-old has a one-year contract and will join the opera orchestra’s other concertmaster, David Chan.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera announced Thursday that its next concertmaster would be the young Canadian violinist Nikki Chooi, who has appeared with orchestras around the world and played last season with the eclectic, genre-bending string trio Time for Three.

headline: Kevin Turner, Microsoft Executive, to Join Citadel Securities
abstract: Mr. Turner, Microsoft’s chief operating officer, is the latest in a spate of technology executives to join a financial firm.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A top Microsoft executive, Kevin Turner, is leaving the company to join Citadel Securities as its new chief executive, continuing a wave of executive departures of technology industry leaders to financial firms.

headline: Fight Over Emails Yields New Details on Role of Outside ‘Agents’ for de Blasio
abstract: Lawyers for a nonprofit aligned with Mayor Bill de Blasio continue trying to keep secret email chains between the group and aides, but documents unsealed this week hint at what those messages show.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — After the rocky conclusion to his first year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio sought counsel at the start of 2015 from his most trusted advisers.

headline: Subpoena for Information From a de Blasio-Connected Nonprofit
abstract: The Campaign for One New York, the nonprofit arm of Mayor Bill de Blasio, has refused to comply with a subpoena, filed on April 22, by a state ethics panel that is investigating whether the mayor’s group engaged in unregistered lobbying. The two are fighting over the matter in court in Albany.
lead_paragraph: The Campaign for One New York, the nonprofit arm of Mayor Bill de Blasio, has refused to comply with a subpoena, filed on April 22, by a state ethics panel that is investigating whether the mayor’s group engaged in unregistered lobbying. The two are fighting over the matter in court in Albany.

headline: Eight U.S. Airlines Win Tentative Approval to Fly to Havana
abstract: American Airlines, Alaska Airlines and Delta Air Lines are among those that received preliminary approval for flights that could begin in September.
lead_paragraph: A fiercely contested battle among United States airlines to be the first to schedule flights to Havana, Cuba’s capital, in more than 50 years is coming to a close.

headline: A Biological Surprise Attack Slows Gypsy Moth Invasion
abstract: This year’s big outbreak of invasive gypsy moth caterpillars has been slightly blunted by an Asian fungus with a mysterious origin story.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a tale from the annals of globalizing insect problems and solutions.

headline: For Men, Summer Poses the Greatest Fashion Challenge
abstract: A garment-by-garment guide on how to go from stylish urbanite to stylish beachgoer.
lead_paragraph: A garment-by-garment guide on how to go from stylish urbanite to stylish beachgoer.

headline: Nicholas Kristof: Ethics and Tiananmen Square
abstract: In 1989, Nicholas Kristof and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, were asked by a 19-year-old protester to help him flee China — a request that pitted professional obligations against what they thought was the right thing to do.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Nicholas Kristof and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, were asked by a 19-year-old protester to help him flee China — a request that pitted professional obligations against what they thought was the right thing to do.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Captain Fantastic’
abstract: The writer and director Matt Ross narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Matt Ross narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Real Estate for the 1 Percent, With Art for the Masses
abstract: New York’s high-end developers are spending money on public works by artists like Yayoi Kusama and Anish Kapoor.
lead_paragraph: THE sculptor Richard Serra, a stickler about the differences between art and architecture, once described most public sculpture in urban architectural settings as “displaced, homeless, overblown objects that say, ‘We represent modern art.’”

headline: Matt Ross Narrates a Scene From ‘Captain Fantastic’
abstract: The writer and director discusses a scene from his film featuring Viggo Mortensen.
lead_paragraph: Parents raise their kids off the grid in the drama “Captain Fantastic,” featuring Viggo Mortensen and written and directed by Matt Ross. In this scene, the family members hasve left their home in the woods to take a trip. Their transportation is somewhere between a school bus and a mobile home with the father at the wheel. They are stopped by a police officer for a broken taillight.

headline: Review: Barbara Carroll Sustains a Profound Jazz Symbiosis
abstract: Ms. Carroll, called the first lady of jazz piano, balances playful invention with order, abetted by her musical union with the bassist Jay Leonhart.
lead_paragraph: Jazz may not be the ideal forum for conveying a lifetime’s accumulated wisdom. But for Barbara Carroll, nicknamed the first lady of jazz piano, it is a kind of philosophical scripture that balances improvisation and playful invention with a classical sense of order. Her collaboration with her longtime bassist, Jay Leonhart, is a musical friendship that grows deeper and more touching as each year passes.

headline: Dolan Family Repurchases Newsday
abstract: Only two weeks after handing the paper to Altice in a deal for Cablevision, Newsday is again part of the Dolan family holdings.
lead_paragraph: Newsday barely had time to get used to a new owner.

headline: Baryshnikov Center to Welcome Somi, Musicians of Rajasthan and Liz Gerring Dance
abstract: This Manhattan center’s fall season will also include a theremin virtuoso with American Contemporary Music Ensemble and dance by Rachid Ouramdane.
lead_paragraph: A German-born theremin virtuoso, a group of musicians from Rajasthan, India, and the United States premiere of a work by the French choreographer Rachid Ouramdane will be among the highlights of the Baryshnikov Arts Center’s fall season, the center announced on Thursday.

headline: Gut Bacteria Are Different in People With Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
abstract: People with chronic fatigue syndrome have a unique bacterial blueprint in their guts and blood, suggesting that the condition has a physical cause and is not psychological.
lead_paragraph: A new study has identified a bacterial blueprint for chronic fatigue syndrome, offering further evidence that it is a physical disease with biological causes and not a psychological condition.

headline: Review: Five Contemporary Ballets, Zero Female Choreographers
abstract: On Wednesday, this Gauthier Dance, the resident dance company at Theaterhaus Stuttgart, returned by popular demand to Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — Gauthier Dance was a hit last summer with audiences here at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival. On Wednesday, this German group, the resident dance company at Theaterhaus Stuttgart, returned by popular demand.

headline: Latest of Obama’s Safety Rules on Arctic Drilling Are Released
abstract: The rules fell short of many environmentalists’ demands to cut off such drilling entirely, but oil companies complained that they would stymie exploration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced new safety and environmental regulations on Thursday to control offshore drilling in the Arctic Ocean off the Alaskan coast.

headline: Mark Cavendish Makes It Three Tour Stage Wins, and It’s Early
abstract: Cavendish won Stage 6 of this year’s Tour de France, and his 29th over all, on Thursday, before the race moved into the Pyrenees.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUBAN, France — The minds of many people at the Tour de France were elsewhere Thursday. Their focus was on the European Championships semifinal soccer match between France and Germany in Marseille scheduled for Thursday evening.

headline: Tokyo’s Underground Shopping Paradise
abstract: Somehow, Hiroshi Fujiwara has created a lovely shopping experience deep within the Ginza district.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It has been three decades since Hiroshi Fujiwara, universally referred to here as the godfather of streetwear, started writing a column in the indie magazine Takarajima. Fujiwara’s “Last Orgy” bulletins brought readers monthly news flashes about the hottest rappers, the latest 12-inch vinyl, photographers, D.J.s, skateboarders, sneakers, break dancers and American heritage brands.

headline: Brooklyn Judge Overturns Man’s Conviction in 2005 Double Murder
abstract: Justice Matthew J. D’Emic threw out the guilty verdict against Wayne Martin after prosecutors said exculpatory evidence in the case had been withheld.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Thursday threw out the murder conviction of a Brooklyn man serving a life sentence for the killing of two people in 2005 after prosecutors said exculpatory evidence in the case had been withheld.

headline: Review: Is the Indian Point Nuclear Plant Safe? Nobody Knows
abstract: The documentary “Indian Point,” directed by Ivy Meeropol, focuses on complaints about the safety of this power plant, about 45 miles from Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: “The awful thing about life is this: Everyone has their reasons.” That perceptive and frustrating quotation (from the 1939 film “The Rules of the Game”) came to mind often during “Indian Point,” a low-key look at a high-tension topic.

headline: Review: Fraternal Dysfunction in the Old South in ‘Men Go to Battle’
abstract: This film, which takes place during the early years of the Civil War, pushes back against the rigid formality of the period genre.
lead_paragraph: An admirable attempt to expand the aesthetic parameters of the American period film, “Men Go to Battle,” directed by Zachary Treitz from a script by Mr. Treitz and Kate Lyn Sheil, who is also a co-star and co-producer of the movie, is set in Kentucky during the early years of the Civil War.

headline: Two Convicted of Conspiring to Leak Vatican Secrets in ‘Vatileaks 2’
abstract: A Vatican court found two former members of a papal oversight commission guilty, but said it could not try two journalists.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A Vatican court on Thursday found two former members of a papal oversight commission guilty of having conspired to leak confidential information and documents to the press. But as the trial known as “Vatileaks 2” came to a close, the tribunal declared that it did not have the jurisdiction to try two journalists charged with disseminating that information via separate books.

headline: France Beats Germany to Reach Euro 2016 Final
abstract: Antoine Griezmann scored twice and France moved a step closer to winning another major soccer championship on home soil with its victory over Germany.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — They sang.

headline: Iraq Report Prompts More Defensiveness Than Regret From Tony Blair
abstract: An exhaustive study of how Britain went to war in 2003 led to soul searching by the former prime minister, but no acknowledgment that he got it wrong.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — His voice sometimes close to cracking, his expression strained and grim, former Prime Minister Tony Blair spent much of the past two days responding to the damning judgment of an inquiry into how he led Britain into the Iraq war, engaging in an extraordinary public mix of soul searching, regret and defensiveness.

headline: Review: ‘The Debt’ in This Barney Elliott Film Is a Commodity
abstract: Peru’s agricultural landscape is the setting for this film about corporate greed and the persistence of native farmers.
lead_paragraph: Toggling between the breathtaking Peruvian highlands and the busy clamor of Lima, “The Debt” places three very different lives on a collision course freighted with moral and financial complexity.

headline: Peter Powers, Mayor Giuliani’s Steady Right Hand, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Powers was a high school friend whom Rudolph W. Giuliani recruited to impose order on his chaotic novice mayoral campaign and later installed as his even-tempered alter ego in City Hall.
lead_paragraph: Peter J. Powers, a high school friend whom Rudolph W. Giuliani recruited to impose order on his chaotic novice mayoral campaign and later installed as his even-tempered alter ego to manage New York City’s government, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 72.

headline: Email Issue Only Hardens Political Views in Philadelphia Suburbs
abstract: While a parade of Republicans said this week they could not vote for Donald J. Trump, many also said the same about Hillary Clinton after the F.B.I.’s rebuke.
lead_paragraph: MEDIA, Pa. — There is potential good news for Hillary Clinton in the politically crucial Philadelphia suburbs: A parade of Republicans said in interviews this week they could not vote for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Paul Hornung Sues the Helmet Maker Riddell Over Concussions
abstract: Hornung claims Riddell should have warned players that its helmets, while helping to prevent skull fractures, provided no protection against brain trauma.
lead_paragraph: Paul Hornung, the Hall of Fame running back with the Green Bay Packers, has sued Riddell, asserting that the company knew of the dangers of brain trauma more than 50 years ago but failed to warn him and other players that their helmets would do nothing to prevent concussions.

headline: Tokyo Right Now
abstract: Numerous young men of Tokyo have adopted styles that contrast markedly with those of their elders.
lead_paragraph: Numerous young men of Tokyo have adopted styles that contrast markedly with those of their elders.

headline: Review: ‘Cold War 2,’ a Brisk Exercise in Hong Kong Suspense
abstract: This action film by Longman Leung and Sunny Luk follows the 2012 crime film “Cold War,” a tense, engaging cop thriller.
lead_paragraph: A hit in Hong Kong, the 2012 crime film “Cold War” went straight to video in the United States — too bad because it’s a tense, engaging thriller that deftly plays with a template partially established by “Infernal Affairs,” an influential genre exercise that appeared in 2002.

headline: The Trusted Grown-Ups Who Steal Millions From Youth Sports
abstract: Prosecutors in several states say embezzlement investigations involving youth sports have become common.
lead_paragraph: WHITEHALL TOWNSHIP, Pa. — With downcast eyes and a microphone clenched in one fist, Brian Farley stood uneasily before nearly 400 children from the Tri-Boro Youth Soccer Club in eastern Pennsylvania.

headline: Review: ‘Cell’ Offers Zombified Victims and an Unfocused Narrative
abstract: This film, dated, despondent and pretty much a disaster, plays like a series of nods to other science fiction-horror hybrids.
lead_paragraph: Dated, despondent and pretty much a disaster, “Cell” plays like a series of nods to other science fiction-horror hybrids, notably “The Matrix” (1999) and Philip Kaufman’s 1978 remake of “Invasion of the Body Snatchers.” This isn’t so much a criticism of the movie’s source material — Stephen King’s paranoid and prophetic 2006 novel with the same title — as of a bare-bones screenplay (by Mr. King and Adam Alleca) that’s wholly unable to deliver even a smidgen of nuance or depth.

headline: Paul Hornung vs. Riddell Complaint
abstract: In his complaint filed in state court in Illinois, Hornung claims that Riddell should have warned players that its plastic helmets, while helping prevent skull fractures, “provided no protection” against brain trauma, including concussions.
lead_paragraph: In his complaint filed in state court in Illinois, Hornung claims that Riddell should have warned players that its plastic helmets, while helping prevent skull fractures, “provided no protection” against brain trauma, including concussions.

headline: Review: About Norman Lear, Who Gave Us Archie Bunker
abstract: The documentary “Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You” is a portrait of the 1970s TV hitmaker who broke ground with issue-oriented humor.
lead_paragraph: There are lessons to be gleaned about creativity and longevity from “Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You,” Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady’s assured documentary portrait of that influential television producer. Mr. Lear, now almost 94, is a master of topical humor who largely defined prime-time comedy in the 1970s, having led at one point six of the top 10 shows in the Nielsen ratings. “All in the Family” (1971-79) may well be his masterpiece; Archie Bunker’s armchair is enshrined in the Smithsonian.

headline: A Planet Where Sunsets Are 3 Times as Nice
abstract: Astronomers have discovered HD 131399Ab, a gas giant in a system with three stars some 320 light years away.
lead_paragraph: Tatooine, the desert home world of Luke and Anakin Skywalker in Star Wars, is iconic in part because it orbited two stars, making for some scenic double sunsets.

headline: Review: Homeless Teenagers, Strutting and Seething in ‘Runaways’
abstract: This teeming revival of Elizabeth Swados’s 1978 musical melds a pack of 25 young actors into one vital, desperate voice.
lead_paragraph: They’re tearing up the air at New York City Center, where a pulsing reincarnation of Elizabeth Swados’s “Runaways” is testifying to the atomic power of adolescent angst. This blast of undiluted teen spirit, which opened Wednesday night as the first offering in the Encores! Off-Center summer season, is guaranteed to leave you feeling windblown, hyped up and ready to race through the most torpid summer night.

headline: Review: ‘Our Little Sister,’ or What We Found at Dad’s Funeral
abstract: With brilliant narrative stealth, Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film watches as three single women welcome their long-lost teenage half sister into their lives.
lead_paragraph: “Our Little Sister” begins with a couple waking up in bed. After some morning conversation, the woman dresses and leaves, and as she walks home, the soundtrack swells with string-heavy, melodramatic music. The lushness of the sound seems at odds with the plainness of the images, and this discrepancy establishes a tone that will last through the rest of this delicate and satisfying film. Characters may refrain from expressing the strong emotions that flow beneath the surface of their daily lives, but every so often the music (composed by Yoko Kanno) will remind us of the existence of those feelings.

headline: Review: ‘Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,’ Antics to Not Love nor Cherish
abstract: This aggressively stupid movie has nothing going for it other than some wasted talent.
lead_paragraph: Two idiots need dates; they get them.

headline: Review: ‘Fathers and Daughters,’ a Sappy Tale Unredeemed by Star Power
abstract: Blunt dialogue and infuriatingly coy storytelling pervade this weepy melodrama starring Amanda Seyfried and Russell Crowe.
lead_paragraph: Has any recent film threatened to drown more big-name talent in scented soap suds than Gabriele Muccino’s weepy melodrama “Fathers and Daughters”? Mr. Muccino, an Italian director best known for the Will Smith vehicles “The Pursuit of Happyness” and “Seven Pounds,” doesn’t shy away from the kind of wholesale sentimentality that feels like a hangover from the 1980s.

headline: Review: ‘Zero Days’ Examines Cyberwarfare’s Potential Online Apocalypse
abstract: This Alex Gibney documentary describes the origin of Stuxnet, malware devised by Israel and the United States with grave implications for the future.
lead_paragraph: Technology: With every seemingly miraculous advance comes the potential for its catastrophic misuse. If you’re inclined toward paranoia, Alex Gibney’s sobering documentary “Zero Days,” about the spread of malware, exposes a whole arena of potential terror and calamitous destruction surrounded in secrecy.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from critics for The Times.
lead_paragraph: James Cohan Gallery533 West 26th Street, ChelseaThrough July 29

headline: Bill Cosby’s Challenge to Criminal Case Fails
abstract: A Pennsylvania judge ruled that Mr. Cosby had not been entitled to confront his accuser in a preliminary court hearing this spring.
lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — In a setback to Bill Cosby, a Pennsylvania judge ruled here Thursday that the entertainer had not been entitled to confront and cross-examine his accuser in a preliminary court hearing this spring, at which evidence in the case was ruled sufficient to proceed to trial.

headline: Matt Harvey Considering Season-Ending Surgery
abstract: Harvey has symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome, a condition in which nerves or blood vessels are compressed between the neck and upper torso.
lead_paragraph: Despite Matt Harvey’s prolonged struggles this season, Mets Manager Terry Collins and the team’s pitching coach, Dan Warthen, thought the club’s former ace had turned a corner during his rain-shortened start on June 28 against the Washington Nationals. He had pitched less than four innings, but Collins liked the rhythm Harvey had displayed on the mound, and his command of his breaking pitches. Optimism reigned.

headline: Review: Viggo Mortensen Captivates in ‘Captain Fantastic’
abstract: Mr. Mortensen is just one of the reasons to see this film about a family forced to leave their home in the woods and become reacquainted with society.
lead_paragraph: A story of love and extremes, the pleasurably freewheeling “Captain Fantastic” centers on a family that has found its bliss in splendid, unplugged isolation. Somewhere in deepest Oregon, amid the tall pines and soaring mountains, young and old hunt and holler and drop lines from Noam Chomsky. The clan’s father isn’t a superhero, but because he’s played by Viggo Mortensen he’s the next best thing. Mr. Mortensen, whose intensity has the sting of possession, has a way of making you believe his characters can do whatever they set their minds to: fly, leap over buildings, save the world.

headline: Trekkies, Set Phasers to Fun for a Trip to Starfleet Academy
abstract: “Star Trek: The Starfleet Academy Experience,” at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, lets you be an academy cadet in the 26th century.
lead_paragraph: STARDATE: July 9, 2016. The Starfleet Academy has established a base in a 12,000-square-foot tent just north of the aircraft carrier Intrepid on Pier 86. Your mission: to boldly go and discover your role in future starship missions. Cosplay not required.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, July 9 Through July 17
abstract: The rock band Jane’s Addiction will perform with Dinosaur Jr. on July 17 in Port Chester, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Julie Klausner’s Comic Success With ‘Difficult People’
abstract: Ms. Klausner, who had pursued several outlets for her comedy writing, has gained traction with “Difficult People,” starting its second season on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: One morning in June, Julie Klausner greeted the day by telling her Twitter followers that she had the kind of swagger that comes from “wearing a bathing suit as clothes.” Then she wondered about her word choice: “Can I say swagger if I mean rock bottom?” she wrote.

headline: Dennis Oppenheim, a Sculptor Who Moved Heaven and Earth
abstract: An exhibition at the Storm King Art Center is a mini-retrospective of Mr. Oppenheim’s prolific career.
lead_paragraph: From his Minimalist earthworks created in remote places in the 1960s to Pop-Surrealist public sculptures for urban settings in the 1990s and 2000s, Dennis Oppenheim was dedicated to the proposition that art should be open to the world rather than cloistered in galleries and museums. So it is appropriate that he should be this year’s featured artist at the Storm King Art Center in the Hudson Valley, where sculptures by Alexander Calder, Sol LeWitt, Louise Nevelson, Alice Aycock and scores of other artists dot the beautiful, 500-acre landscape of hills, fields and forest.

headline: Critics of Police Welcome Facebook Live and Other Tools to Stream Video
abstract: After killings of black men by the police this week, scores of African-Americans declared on social media that they would equip themselves with tools to stream video live.
lead_paragraph: After back-to-back killings of black men by police officers this week, scores of African-Americans declared on social media that they would be equipping themselves with a powerful tool: Facebook Live.

headline: Philadelphia Offers a Full-Fledged Summer of African Art
abstract: “Creative Africa,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and “Nari Ward: Sun Splashed,” at the Barnes Foundation, bring us into a present that pushes toward the future.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — People talk about Africa as if it were a unitary thing, one culture, one mind, which it’s not. That’s my only problem with “Creative Africa,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and my complaint stops with the title. The project itself, a set of five small, tight, concurrent exhibitions of African material, is richly textured, and in one case sensational.

headline: Hamilton and Burr Square Off Again, This Time on a Museum Stage
abstract: To commemorate the Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr duel, the New-York Historical Society presents a tour and a re-enactment intended to help museumgoers reflect on both history and moral issues.
lead_paragraph: Much of this year’s hoopla about Alexander Hamilton has focused on how he lived. But on Sunday, the New-York Historical Society will have young visitors investigate a more sobering topic: how he died.

headline: Review: ‘The Hatred of Poetry’: Let’s Count the Ways
abstract: Could it be that readers expect too much of poetry? The novelist and poet Ben Lerner explains.
lead_paragraph: In “Mean Free Path,” a collection of poetry published in 2010, Ben Lerner kicked off a stanza like this: “There must be an easier way to do this/I mean without writing.”

headline: Fendi: Fall 2016
abstract: The Couture Collection.
lead_paragraph: The Couture Collection.

headline: Warhol Museum Director to Join Sotheby’s New Fine Art Division
abstract: Eric Shiner, the director of the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, is joining a Sotheby’s unit as a senior vice president.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol famously said, “Being good in business is the most fascinating kind of art.”

headline: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, NATO: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Beyoncé, Prompted by Shootings, Finds a More Forceful Voice
abstract: This singer wrote on her website of the need for greater respect regarding black lives after the police fatally shot two more men in recent days.
lead_paragraph: A more politically engaged Beyoncé has been brewing for some time now.

headline: A Killing. A Pointed Gun. And Two Black Lives, Witnessing.
abstract: A live stream on Facebook takes us into a car where a fatal police shooting occurred, emphasizing the gulf between virtual and physical presence.
lead_paragraph: “Stay with me.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Deutsche Bank Pulls Back from Deals in Coal Mining Sector
abstract: Investment bankers leave as Deutsche joins other banks in cutting financing to a beaten-down industry that has attracted environmentalists’ scorn.
lead_paragraph: Pressured by environmentalists and worried about big losses from a troubled industry, many large banks and other lenders have made a hasty retreat from coal mining in recent years.

headline: This Week’s Movies | July 8, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,” “The Secret Life of Pets” and “Our Little Sister.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,” “The Secret Life of Pets” and “Our Little Sister.”

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Couture Week
abstract: Valentino's designer shakeup, a collaborative Vetements show, an appearance from Celine Dion — and so much more.
lead_paragraph: Valentino's designer shakeup, a collaborative Vetements show, an appearance from Celine Dion — and so much more.

headline: ‘La Chienne’ and ‘A Married Woman’: The Better Half, in Dark Strokes
abstract: New releases on discs of movies from Jean Renoir and Jean-Luc Godard reflect in different ways on their spouses at the time of filming.
lead_paragraph: French cinema in the 20th century is distinguished by two incomparable runs — the 14 early sound films that Jean Renoir made in the 1930s and the 15 consecutive features made by Jean-Luc Godard some 30 years later. The two periods are represented by two new releases, Renoir’s “La Chienne” (Criterion) and Mr. Godard’s “A Married Woman” (Cohen Media).

headline: For Fourth Time, Baltimore Opens a Trial in the Death of Freddie Gray
abstract: After two acquittals and a hung jury in trials against other officers, prosecutors turn their attention to Lt. Brian Rice, the highest-ranking officer at the arrest.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Two officers have been acquitted. Another had a deadlocked jury. And on Thursday, prosecutors in a courtroom here began their fourth attempt to convict a police officer in the fatal arrest of Freddie Gray, the black man who died of a spinal cord injury he suffered while in police custody last year.

headline: Growing Unease as British Mutual Funds Block the Exit Doors
abstract: The refusal of six asset management firms to allow investor withdrawals is creating a nightmare situation for global markets.
lead_paragraph: As one British mutual fund after another bars its doors to fleeing investors, traders and regulators alike are asking the same question: What does it mean for nervous global markets?

headline: Theater Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Deal-Scouting Firm Scores Again With Danone-WhiteWave Deal
abstract: Hudson Executive Capital, an activist investment firm with a collaborative strategy, will profit handsomely from a deal it promoted.
lead_paragraph: An investment banker’s job is to identify companies that have a strong potential to be bought or sold in the near future, and get in on the ground floor of the action.

headline: Study Supports Suspicion That Police Are More Likely to Use Force on Blacks
abstract: A report by the Center for Policing Equity comes at a time of increased tension over shooting episodes.
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of interactions between police officers and civilians end routinely, with no one injured, no one aggrieved and no one making the headlines. But when force is used, a new study has found, the race of the person being stopped by officers is significant.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Loses Air-Conditioning and Will Close for Weekend
abstract: The museum said events are being rescheduled and that its “sensitive materials are being moved to climate controlled spaces.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking to escape the heat this weekend, don’t seek refuge at the Brooklyn Museum — it will be closed because of an air-conditioning outage and will reopen on Wednesday. According to a spokeswoman, “A transformer malfunctioned and destroyed cables leading to” the air conditioning.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Players Renew Their Fight for Equal Pay
abstract: With the Rio Olympics fast approaching, the team is turning to the court of public opinion to press its case.
lead_paragraph: Beaten in federal court and rebuffed at the negotiating table, the United States women’s national soccer team is taking its fight for equal pay back to friendlier turf: the court of public opinion.

headline: Michael Brown’s Mom, on Alton Sterling and Philando Castile
abstract: When their children are killed, mothers are expected to keep the peace and to work for change. But nothing changes.
lead_paragraph: St. Louis — I CRIED on Wednesday as I watched, like much of the country, the horrifying video images from Baton Rouge, La., showing a black man being shot to death, in the back and chest, after being wrestled into submission by two white police officers. On Thursday, I woke up to the news of a black man in Minnesota, shot by the police during a traffic stop. I am devastated and infuriated.

headline: Suicide Rate Among Veterans Has Risen Sharply Since 2001
abstract: The V.A. released key findings of a recently completed study examining the death records of more than 55 million veterans from 1979 to 2014 from every state.
lead_paragraph: The suicide rate among veterans has surged 35 percent since 2001, driven in part by sharp increases among those who have served since 2001, according to the largest study of such suicides. Of particular concern is the suicide rate among women, which has increased 85 percent in that time.

headline: Transfer Policy Questioned After Former Guantánamo Bay Detainee Goes Missing
abstract: A House committee grills Obama administration officials when Uruguay loses track of a Syrian who had been resettled there after his release from prison at the U.S. naval base in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican lawmakers on Thursday sharply questioned two Obama administration officials who negotiate the transfer of Guantánamo Bay detainees, charging that the government had resettled some prisoners in countries incapable of keeping an eye on them.

headline: A Discussion About the Minnesota Video
abstract: Marc Lacey, a deputy national editor at The Times, and the critic at large Wesley Morris talk about the aftermath of the fatal shooting by a police officer in a St. Paul suburb that was caught on Facebook Live.
lead_paragraph: Marc Lacey, a deputy national editor at The Times, and the critic at large Wesley Morris talk about the aftermath of the fatal shooting by a police officer in a St. Paul suburb that was caught on Facebook Live.

headline: Comedy Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Inspired by ‘Princess Ida’
abstract: At intermission during the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta about a feminist movement, a woman insisted on using the typically shorter line for the men’s room.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Eduardo Cunha, Who Helped Oust Dilma Rousseff, Resigns Brazil House Post
abstract: Mr. Cunha, the speaker of the lower house, stepped down as indignation mounted over his quest to remain in power while facing bribery charges.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The conservative lawmaker who orchestrated the ouster of Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, resigned as the speaker of the lower house of Congress on Thursday as indignation mounted over his quest to remain in power while facing charges of taking as much as $40 million in bribes.

headline: U.F.C. vs. Boxing: Gloves-On, Gloves-Off-Again Rivalry Dates to 1800s
abstract: U.F.C. 200 is a milestone event for mixed martial arts, which considers itself a rising contender to boxing. The event comes 127 years after a fight that signaled the rise of modern boxing.
lead_paragraph: It is a grand moment for a youthful sport: The Ultimate Fighting Championship, a principal organizer and promoter of mixed martial arts matches, started three nights of shows on Thursday to celebrate its 200th pay-per-view event (which will actually come later, because two numbered fights have been canceled, but never mind: The event is called U.F.C. 200).

headline: Juno Halts Cancer Trial Using Gene-Altered Cells After 3 Deaths
abstract: The study was testing the use of genetically engineered cells as a treatment for cancer, which had shown promising earlier results.
lead_paragraph: Three patients in a study testing the use of genetically engineered cells as a treatment for cancer have died from swelling in the brain, dealing a setback to one of the most exciting pursuits in oncology.

headline: Delayed Care Faulted in Immigrants’ Deaths at Detention Centers
abstract: Poor medical care and delayed emergency treatments are blamed for at least seven immigrants’ deaths in detention centers.
lead_paragraph: Deficient medical care contributed to at least seven immigrants’ deaths in federal detention, according to a report published on Thursday by Human Rights Watch, an advocacy group.

headline: Movie Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: Death in Black and White
abstract: In a week full of killings, racial justice feels elusive.
lead_paragraph: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Congressional Study Faults Highway Agency Over Testing of Guardrails
abstract: The report responded to concerns about a widely used guardrail system involved in lawsuits over injuries to drivers and passengers.
lead_paragraph: A congressional watchdog on Thursday accused federal highway officials of poor oversight of the safety testing of guardrails and other roadside equipment, in a report based on a yearlong investigation.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Serena Williams-Angelique Kerber Final Is Grand Slam Rematch
abstract: Williams, who is seeking to tie Steffi Graf’s Open-era record of 22 Grand Slam singles title, lost to Kerber in this year’s Australian Open final.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It did not take long in the least, and as soon as Serena Williams had thrashed Elena Vesnina, 6-2, 6-0, in well under an hour, it was clear that the Wimbledon final on Saturday was going to be a rematch.

headline: Next Up for Donald Trump’s Running-Mate Tryouts: Chris Christie
abstract: The New Jersey governor will join the presumptive Republican presidential nominee for two campaign events in South Florida.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Donald J. Trump will continue the public tryouts for potential running mates on Friday, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey joins him for two events in South Florida, according to a spokeswoman for Mr. Trump.

headline: Iraq War Lies, 13 Years Later
abstract: An official British report has reminded both Britons and Americans how lies and ideology can lead nations into war.
lead_paragraph: It seems a long time ago, and in a world far, far away, that George W. Bush, Dick Cheney and Donald Rumsfeld, enthusiastically supported by Tony Blair, went to war with Iraq. Thirteen years later, after voluminous studies and books and wave upon wave of terrible consequences, it would seem there is no doubt that these leaders created a false case for invading Iraq and then utterly mismanaged the occupation.

headline: When Will the Killing Stop?
abstract: The latest fatal shootings of black men by the police underline an urgent need for changes in attitude and oversight of departments across the country.
lead_paragraph: Updated: July 8, 2016

headline: Christie’s Phone, a Missing Piece in the Bridge Case, Is Found
abstract: A federal judge quashed the efforts of lawyers for the defendants to obtain the phone, which they believe might contain clues about the involvement of others in the scheme.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — After weeks of shrugs and head-scratching, one of the more perplexing mysteries of the investigation into the infamous traffic jam at the George Washington Bridge has been solved: Gov. Chris Christie’s lawyer has the governor’s cellphone.

headline: Classical Music Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Gretchen Carlson Suit Against Fox News Head Forces Network to Face Changing Mores
abstract: Facing a gender discrimination suit against its chairman, Fox is being swept by societal forces that are defying old behaviors long abetted by silence.
lead_paragraph: At a time of fast-moving social change, Fox News can at times be viewed as a port in a storm for traditionalists who pine for the way we were — for the days when there was no gay marriage; no terms like “gender fluidity”; no doubt about the roles men and women were supposed to play and certainly no talk about the liberties men might take with female subordinates behind closed doors.

headline: After Poised Live-Streaming, Tears and Fury Find Diamond Reynolds
abstract: Ms. Reynolds has emerged as an influential witness in the latest shooting of an African-American at the hands of a police officer.
lead_paragraph: Diamond Reynolds was cool and composed as an anchorwoman on Wednesday night, her voice strong as she narrated the horrific scene around her into her phone that was streaming live on Facebook.

headline: Dozens Killed in Suicide Attack on Shiite Shrine North of Baghdad
abstract: Three suicide bombers disguised in military uniforms infiltrated a mausoleum, the Iraqi authorities said, killing at least 36 people and wounding 40.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militants fired mortars on a Shiite shrine north of Baghdad late on Thursday, and in the confusion that followed, three suicide bombers in military uniforms infiltrated the compound and blew themselves up, the Iraqi authorities said.

headline: Dispute as Westchester Housing Pact Nears End: Did the County Honor It?
abstract: A federal monitor overseeing a desegregation agreement requiring Westchester County to build 750 units of affordable housing wants outside analysis.
lead_paragraph: Westchester County has spent seven years putting into place a far-reaching affordable housing agreement that promised to remake one of the wealthiest suburbs in the nation.

headline: Protests Break Out After Shootings
abstract: After the fatal shooting of a black man by a police officer in Minnesota, protesters gathered on the streets of New York City. That death came in the same week as a similar shooting in Baton Rouge, La.
lead_paragraph: After the fatal shooting of a black man by a police officer in Minnesota, protesters gathered on the streets of New York City. That death came in the same week as a similar shooting in Baton Rouge, La.

headline: Yankees Hold Off Indians to Get Critical Stretch Off to Good Start
abstract: Three sixth-inning runs put the Yankees ahead, 5-2, and their bullpen helped seal the victory in the first game of what could be a season-defining, 14-game stretch.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — To understand the desperate straits the Yankees are in, consider the sudden and rare scent of meritocracy that has permeated the lineup card.

headline: Public Colleges Chase Out-of-State Students, and Tuition
abstract: Since the 2008 recession, states have reduced spending on public higher education by 17 percent, creating questions of affordability and access.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Over three generations, the Michael family forged a deep bond with the University of California, dating back nearly 50 years to when Jay Dee Michael Sr. was the university system’s vice president and chief lobbyist.

abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: Jews With Special Needs Prepare for a Rite of Passage
abstract: Now in their 20s and 30s, four young adults who all have cognitive disabilities will have their bar and bat mitzvahs, ceremonies that once seemed impossible for them.
lead_paragraph: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y. — The students and tutors gathered around the table ready for the task at hand: 40 cheese and 40 bologna sandwiches, the meat and cheese separated to follow kosher rules.

headline: Kevin Durant, Whether Hero or Villain, Defends His Move to the Warriors
abstract: The newly minted Golden State Warrior said he was not seeking an easier path to a championship by leaving the Thunder. “Hopefully everybody understands,” he said.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Kevin Durant did not dress the part of the villain. He wore a blue suit set off by a white button-down shirt and scuff-free white sneakers to his first news conference since joining the Golden State Warriors in a free-agent signing that sent shock waves through the N.B.A.

headline: Communities Work to Avoid Provocations in Response to Shootings
abstract: As high-profile police shootings of black men, like those this week, continue, communities are veering from the tight-lipped and sometimes antagonistic reactions of the past.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — When a young black man, Michael Brown, was shot to death by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., in 2014, the outrage over the official response fused with the anger over the act itself.

headline: Jazz Listings for July 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: De Blasio Has a Chance to Run a Better Campaign, Not Just a Richer One
abstract: A board ruled in favor of the mayor, saying advocacy groups’ spending would not affect his re-election budget. But it also advised changes to campaign finance law.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio came to office in 2014 with the best financial hand dealt to a New York mayor in at least a century, and probably longer, thanks to booms on Wall Street, in real estate prices, in midlevel job growth, in tourism, in population growth and in public safety. This has made everything easier, if not easy; abundance can cause headaches, but it is preferable to scarcity.

abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Suit Accuses New York Police of Violating Citizens’ Right to Film
abstract: The federal lawsuit, which calls the interference unconstitutional, was filed by an activist who was arrested while recording the police on the sidewalk.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department violates the First Amendment by interfering with people who try to film officer activity, according to a lawsuit filed by an activist who was arrested while recording the police on the sidewalk.

headline: Civil War Battle
abstract: A Friday themeless by Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — We last saw Barry Silk in December of 2015 and he’s back again with a 72-worder to start our solving weekend.

headline: John McMartin, Versatile Mainstay on Broadway and TV, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. McMartin starred in “Sweet Charity” on stage and screen and was a favorite of Bob Fosse, Harold Prince and Stephen Sondheim.
lead_paragraph: John McMartin, one of the most recognizable actors on Broadway and television, who played a meek tax accountant in the musical “Sweet Charity” on both stage and screen and had a starring role in the Stephen Sondheim musical “Follies,” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Latino Gang Members Charged With Firebomb Attack on Blacks
abstract: A federal indictment charged seven in a 2014 attack at a housing complex in East Los Angeles in what was called an effort to drive out African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Seven members of a Latino street gang were charged with firebombing a public housing complex in East Los Angeles with the goal of driving black residents out of the neighborhood, a federal indictment says.

headline: Don Friedman, Versatile Jazz Pianist, Dies at 81
abstract: Over a six-decade career, Mr. Friedman worked with the likes of Clark Terry, Ornette Coleman, Booker Little and Herbie Mann.
lead_paragraph: Don Friedman, a versatile pianist who moved easily between the modern-jazz mainstream and the more volatile jazz avant-garde, died on June 30 at his home in the Bronx. He was 81.

headline: South Korea and U.S. Agree to Deploy Missile Defense System
abstract: The announcement came despite strong protests from China, which sees the plan as a threat to its own security.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea and the United States announced on Friday that they have decided to deploy an advanced American missile defense system in the South, despite strong protests from China, which sees it as a threat to its own security.

headline: Snipers Kill 5 Dallas Officers at Protest Against Police Shootings
abstract: Six other officers were also shot during a demonstration protesting the shootings in Minnesota and Louisiana this week, the police chief said.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Five Dallas police officers were killed and six others were wounded by snipers on Thursday night during a demonstration protesting shootings by officers in Minnesota and Louisiana this week, the Dallas police said.

headline: The Mets, With a Suddenly Booming Offense, Outlast the Nationals
abstract: The two teams combined for eight home runs on Thursday night, a single-game record at Citi Field. But it was the home team that emerged with a 9-7 victory.
lead_paragraph: On a day when Manager Terry Collins saw the Mets’ pitching depth depleted, he found a sliver of solace in the way that Wilmer Flores continued his hitting surge in Thursday night’s game at Citi Field against the Washington Nationals.

headline: Home Run Derby Lineup Announced
abstract: Mark Trumbo, who was leading the majors with 26 home runs through Wednesday, highlights the eight-player bracket for Monday’s Home Run Derby in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: Mark Trumbo, who was leading the majors with 26 home runs through Wednesday, highlights the eight-player bracket for Monday’s Home Run Derby in San Diego.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It was enough to make you cry, seeing the fish swimming dizzy or dead. But that was just the start. The flamingos are dead, the ducks are gone, everything else.”

headline: Dallas Police Officers Killed at Protest
abstract: Sniper fire targeted police officers in a demonstration in the city’s downtown area that until then had been peaceful.
lead_paragraph: Sniper fire targeted police officers in a demonstration in the city’s downtown area that until then had been peaceful.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Take a vacation with Woody Allen’s “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” or plunge into François Ozon’s “Swimming Pool.” And Jaycee Dugard talks about life after captivity, on “20/20.”
lead_paragraph: Heat getting to you? Take a European vacation with Woody Allen’s “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” or plunge into François Ozon’s “Swimming Pool.” Meanwhile, on “20/20,” Jaycee Dugard, who was abducted when she was 11, talks about life after captivity. And Amber Rose unleashes her attitude on VH1.

abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers around the world.

abstract: Dior’s chief executive talks about the appointment of the first woman to be artistic director of the label.
lead_paragraph: “I had it in mind that a woman designer might be interesting for a while now.”

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, July 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: The Week in Pictures: July 8, 2016
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: Taiwan Train Explosion Wasn’t Organized Terrorism, Government Says
abstract: At least 25 people were injured in the blast, which Taiwan’s premier said was most likely the work of “an individual person.” A news agency said a suspect had been identified.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The authorities in Taiwan said on Friday that they had ruled out organized terrorism in a bombing on a commuter train that left at least 25 people wounded.

headline: What to Know About Dior’s New Artistic Director, Maria Grazia Chiuri
abstract: The house (finally) announced today that the Italian co-designer of Valentino would succeed Raf Simons — making her the first woman ever to hold the job.
lead_paragraph: Today, Christian Dior officially named Maria Grazia Chiuri as its new artistic director, filling the position that Raf Simons vacated in October 2015 — and making her the first woman to hold the job in the house’s history. Here’s what to know about the Italian designer, who will present her first collection this September.

headline: Elizabeth Holmes of Theranos Is Barred From Running Lab for 2 Years
abstract: Regulators also revoked the operating license of a Theranos lab and levied a fine. The sanctions were a major setback for the blood-testing start-up.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have barred Elizabeth Holmes, chief executive of Theranos, from owning or operating a medical laboratory for at least two years, raising new questions about the future of the embattled blood-testing start-up and its founder, once a Silicon Valley phenomenon.

headline: The Purge of Ohio’s Infrequent Voters
abstract: In the largest counties, a survey found that voters in Democratic neighborhoods were removed from the rolls much more than those in Republican areas.
lead_paragraph: Should voting sporadically in past elections be grounds to remove a voter from the election rolls?

headline: The Political Orphans
abstract: Independents, now a plurality of American voters, have no convention to call their own. So I went online looking for a party hookup.
lead_paragraph: In barely two weeks, Republicans will converge in Cleveland for the Trumpocalypse, a fact-free and hate-filled gathering likely to be as scary as it will be entertaining. A week later the Democrats will assemble in Philadelphia in a focus-group-tested pander fest, as tightly scripted as the visualize-world-peace answers at a Miss Universe contest.

headline: All the Nominee’s Enablers
abstract: The G.O.P. establishment, and the people behind it, will accept a lot as long as the rich ultimately benefit.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House, sort of laid out both a health care plan and a tax plan. I say sort of, because there weren’t enough details in either case to do any kind of quantitative analysis. But it was clear that Mr. Ryan’s latest proposals had the same general shape as every other proposal he’s released: huge tax cuts for the wealthy combined with savage but smaller cuts in aid to the poor, and the claim that all of this would somehow reduce the budget deficit thanks to unspecified additional measures.

headline: The Power of Altruism
abstract: We inherently desire to do good, but society’s assumptions of selfishness affect our behavior.
lead_paragraph: Western society is built on the assumption that people are fundamentally selfish. Machiavelli and Hobbes gave us influential philosophies built on human selfishness. Sigmund Freud gave us a psychology of selfishness. Children, he wrote, “are completely egoistic; they feel their needs intensely and strive ruthlessly to satisfy them.”

headline: Train Teachers Like Doctors
abstract: Yearlong residencies would improve long-term outcomes, for everyone in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: AMERICA is facing a wave of teacher shortages that threatens our ability to deliver on the promise of quality education. Baby boomer retirements and high rates of teacher turnover, coupled with steep drops in enrollment in teacher-preparation programs, have contributed to this growing crisis. Some states, like California, now have shortages in nearly every subject area, affecting students across the state.

headline: More Than a Cult Designer: Hiroki Nakamura Goes Big
abstract: Word of mouth and a celebrity clientele made Visvim an insider’s favorite. Now it has shaken off its obscurity and is in stores all over the world.
lead_paragraph: The moment was primed for kitsch or magic; it could have gone either way. On a warm summer morning in Florence, Italy — the air narcotic with the scent of blooming camellia — guests of the men’s wear trade fair Pitti Uomo made their way through tunnels of clipped greenery at the Renaissance Boboli Gardens to a fashion show mounted by the Japanese designer Hiroki Nakamura.

headline: Police Shootings Highlight Unease Among Black Gun Owners
abstract: Issues of race, policing and gun rights have turned into a volatile mix after officer-involved shootings of black men and the killing and wounding of officers by snipers at a protest.
lead_paragraph: It is legal to carry a firearm openly in Texas, and Yafeuh Balogun often keeps a 12-gauge Mossberg 500 slung over his shoulder. He patrols his Dallas neighborhood and promotes the benefits of legal gun ownership to people who, like himself, are black.

headline: How the Attack on the Dallas Police Unfolded
abstract: Five officers were killed and seven others were shot during a protest in downtown Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Five officers were killed and seven others were shot during a protest in downtown Dallas.

headline: You’re Taking That With You, Right?
abstract: Buyers are often faced with items the sellers forgot to take with them or quite deliberately left behind.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when Lee Silber wanted to downsize from a house in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, she found a five-room co-op right in the neighborhood, made an offer and went into contract.

headline: A Fire Monkey Can Usher In Chaos. So Can 600 or So Macaques.
abstract: This is a rare Year of the Fire Monkey, an occasion often associated with chaos. Just ask a village in China that’s been overrun by little, loud primates.
lead_paragraph: What do Julius Caesar, Miley Cyrus and a village in Sichuan Province, China, have in common?

headline: After a Suicide, a Security Guard for the Heart
abstract: A shocking discovery following the loss of a sister becomes an unlikely source of solace.
lead_paragraph: After my little sister died, I threw on the mantle of detective, signing up with an online dating service so I could read the profile she had posted. But all I learned is that we shared the same favorite flavor of ice cream.

headline: The UConn Legend Breanna Stewart Adjusts to Life in the W.N.B.A.
abstract: Stewart, a four-time national champion, is learning to deal with losing and the pressure of high expectations in a league that can use a breakout star.
lead_paragraph: Breanna Stewart sat in the visitors’ locker room at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night in an unfamiliar position.

headline: Jobs Roar Back With Gain of 287,000 in June, Easing Worry
abstract: After a grim employment report in May, the economy showed new life, tamping down some concerns about an economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Quashing worries that job growth is flagging, the government on Friday reported that employers increased payrolls by 287,000 in June, an arresting surge that could reframe the economic debate just weeks before Republicans and Democrats gather for their conventions.

headline: A Joyful Effort
abstract: Marissa Dutton and Ethan Nichtern were married June 18 in High Falls, N.Y. Their kismet meeting led them to a love enhanced by their dedication to meditation and Buddhism.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Dutton and Ethan Nichtern were married June 18 in High Falls, N.Y. Their kismet meeting led them to a love enhanced by their dedication to meditation and Buddhism.

headline: Practicing the Perfections of Meditation, and Love
abstract: An expert on meditation and a New York agent join up for a romantic comedy that continues on past the closing credits.
lead_paragraph: The problem with Hollywood’s romantic comedies, Ethan Nichtern explained during a talk in Manhattan on meditation and desire, is that they end just as the relationship is really getting started.

headline: Fendi’s Dolce Vita
abstract: The brand’s 90th anniversary couture show was held on the waters of the Trevi Fountain, and replete with myths and legends.
lead_paragraph: ROME — It’s hard to hold a newsworthy fashion show these days. Collections have been shown, after all, on the Great Wall of China, on a 9/11 anniversary and in Blenheim Palace in England. Yet Thursday evening in Rome, Fendi managed to add to the canon.

headline: Typhoon Nepartak Heads for China After Killing 2 in Taiwan
abstract: The storm hit Taiwan as a Category 4 typhoon, the second-most powerful category, with wind gusts reaching 140 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A powerful typhoon killed at least two people and injured 72 others on Friday as it crossed Taiwan on its way toward the Chinese mainland, the authorities said.

headline: A Novel Follows Gen-Xers Through Their Boom-or-Bust Post-College Lives
abstract: Gen X friends face success and regret in the decades after college.
lead_paragraph: INVINCIBLE SUMMERBy Alice Adams308 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

headline: Dallas, Donald Trump, Euro 2016: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stories Exploring the Misguided, the Unrequited and the Mortified
abstract: All of the stories in this stark and cutting collection grapple with our failure to communicate.
lead_paragraph: YOU ARE HAVING A GOOD TIMEStoriesBy Amie Barrodale191 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Paper, $14.

headline: Stench Soup and Stink Bombs: Mary Roach on the Soldier’s Life
abstract: Mary Roach turns her not-for-the-squeamish gaze onto the soldier’s life.
lead_paragraph: GRUNTThe Curious Science of Humans at WarBy Mary Roach285 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

headline: Dallas Shootings Were ‘Vicious’ and ‘Despicable,’ Obama Says
abstract: The president cautioned that a lot about the attack was still not known, but said there was “no possible justification” for such violence against law enforcement officers.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama on Friday deplored the shooting deaths of five police officers in Dallas, saying there was “no possible justification” for such a “vicious, calculated and despicable attack on law enforcement.”

headline: Five Dallas Officers Were Killed as Payback, Police Chief Says
abstract: The shooting rampage committed by Micah Johnson, 25, was described as the kind of retaliatory violence that people have feared for the last two years.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The heavily armed sniper who gunned down police officers in downtown Dallas, leaving five of them dead, specifically set out to kill as many white officers as he could, officials said Friday. He was a military veteran who had served in Afghanistan, and he kept an arsenal in his home that included bomb-making materials.

headline: How to Plan Your Family’s Vacation
abstract: To get the most out of a family trip, involve everyone in the planning, build in downtime, and find creative excursions.
lead_paragraph: Family vacations should be about creating a lifetime of memories, spending time with your loved ones and, most important, having fun. More often than not, however, they end up being just the opposite, according to Kay Merrill, a family travel specialist and the owner of Are We There Yet? Family Adventures, a travel consultancy in Larkspur, Calif.

headline: For Hotel Spas and Excursions, Moonlight Feels Right
abstract: Resorts and hotels are now offering nighttime programs, including horseback rides, massages by candlelight and painting under the stars.
lead_paragraph: While hotels have long offered daytime activities to introduce guests to local experiences, a number of properties are now staying up much later.

headline: A Charleston Restaurant Twisting Lowcountry Classics
abstract: The Watch features a menu that blends Lowcountry fare and international dishes.
lead_paragraph: Hearing the words “hotel” and “restaurant” in succession can often be a red flag for a discriminating diner. It’s even worse if “view” is tagged on — the eye-pleasing sights from high above somehow always outshine what emerges from the kitchen. So while I rode the elevator up to the seventh floor to dine at the Watch Rooftop Kitchen & Spirits — the highest restaurant in Charleston, in the recently refurbished hotel the Restoration — my gut felt skeptical.

headline: In Fashionable Milan, a Hotel Dressed in (What Else?) Black.
abstract: The LaGare Milano caters to the fashion world when it comes to the favored color, a slimming black. But the luxe hotel is also reasonably priced.
lead_paragraph: From $190.

headline: The Secret Superpower of a Shared-Custody Kid
abstract: Growing up across two households with two distinct sets of customs has made me observant and adaptive: I’m bilingual, in a sense.
lead_paragraph: At 5:25 p.m., my mother pulled into our driveway. I saw my dad’s Cadillac waiting for us and glanced at Mom, whose broad smile instantly flattened. At 10 years old, I could already read her thoughts: Pickup time was 5:30, and she wasn’t willing to suffer accusations of tardiness, just because he was Mr. Punctuality.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Horse Therapy, Sunscreen and Life-Changing Handcycling

Biden Jr. had been going to hit the presidential campaign trail on Friday for Hillary Clinton, but after a shooting in Dallas during protests left five police offers dead, the campaign appearance was postponed. headline: Two Books Recount How Our Postal System Created a Communications Revolution
abstract: Two histories of the Postal Service, once a mainstay of communication, now a system under threat.
lead_paragraph: In 1831 Alexis de Tocqueville celebrated the American postal system as a marvel of its day — a “great link between minds.” According to Devin Leonard, it may soon vanish. Drenched in red ink, the United States Postal Service has shut offices, reduced opening hours, closed processing plants and slashed its work force. While Leonard’s diagnosis of the United States mail as a “dying institution” may be premature (the Postal Service is still America’s largest civilian employer after Walmart), the system is clearly in crisis.

headline: Fall in Fear, Rise in Interest

lead_paragraph: Between the 10 hours of “Making a Murderer,” renewed interest in the O.J. Simpson trial and the infinite number of “Law & Order” episodes currently playing somewhere, it seems that our appetite for stories of, well, law and order is bottomless.

headline: How to Toss a Pizza
abstract: Practice with faux dough. Avoid catching in the center.
lead_paragraph: “Take off any jewelry or watches,” says Tony Gemignani, an eight-time winner of the world championship in pizza-­dough acrobatics and owner of 16 pizzerias in California and Las Vegas. To avoid snags, your hands should be unadorned, with fingernails cut short. Roll or stretch a softball-­size ball of dough (11 to 14 ounces) into a 10-­inch circle. Drape it over your hands, and bring them up to your chest like a boxer. Your dominant hand should be palm up, the other in an upward-­facing fist. If you’re right handed, you’ll be rotating the dough in a clockwise spin (counterclockwise for lefties). To wind up for the toss, wheel your palm in the opposite direction of your eventual throw. Unwind, simultaneously pushing up and rotating your palm until the back of your wrist faces you. Release the dough just above your head, and catch it again at your upper chest atop the knuckles of both fists. Repeat. Try not to catch the dough right in the center, which can weaken the middle, resulting in what Gemignani calls “droopy” pizza slices. Always practice over a clean countertop so you can salvage fumbled catches.

headline: Getting Past the First Cut With a Résumé That Grabs Digital Eyes
abstract: Employers increasingly rely on computerized systems to narrow down job candidates, so experts recommend using keywords and simple structures in résumés.
lead_paragraph: I’m currently underemployed and looking for a new job. I’ve been applying for multiple positions per day via online job boards. Most of the time I don’t hear back — good or bad — from the companies I’m applying to, even though I know I’m more than qualified.

headline: The 6.26.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE ETHICIST

headline: Three Picture Books About Family Trips, in Time for Summer Travel
abstract: Three picture books approach family trips with humor and imagination.
lead_paragraph: I come from a people pathologically afraid of being lost. One missed exit off the Garden State Parkway and you’d swear my mom saw the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse filling her rearview mirror. It’s a lineage that inspired neither breeziness nor wanderlust, and very likely explains why we all still live within spitting distance. Now that you’re clear on my formative potholes, let’s hit the road already. Because school is history. Summer without child care has washed ashore. And like salmon swimming upstream to die (I mean spawn), it’s time for us to visit Grandma. Again. And again. And again.

headline: Plans Change for Trump and Clinton as Shootings Hang Over Trail
abstract: After a shooting in Dallas left five police officers dead, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton canceled campaign appearance on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Amid renewed racial tensions after a deadly, and apparently unprovoked, shooting of a black man in Minnesota and another in Louisiana, events capped by an attack of police officers in Dallas during protests, the focus of the presidential race was to move to Florida and Pennsylvania. Instead, on Friday, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton canceled campaign appearance after the ambush in Dallas.

headline: The Only Piano I Could Afford
abstract: Musical instruments, like marriages, can’t always be repaired.
lead_paragraph: My first home after moving to Mississippi had a bubble on the ceiling from when Hurricane Katrina punched it hard on the roof. It was cheap, but drafty. The doors didn’t keep out the insects, which local residents insisted were water bugs or palmetto bugs, anything but roaches. My first wife, Candace, and I soon found a new rental apartment. It was brick with a wide front door and a big living room. Most important, it had space for a piano.

headline: A Medical Mystery of the Best Kind: Major Diseases Are in Decline

lead_paragraph: Something strange is going on in medicine. Major diseases, like colon cancer, dementia and heart disease, are waning in wealthy countries, and improved diagnosis and treatment cannot fully explain it.

lead_paragraph: Social-issue documentaries are the white knights of cinema — vanquishing dragons, tilting at windmills — but they are not intended as agents of diplomacy. Right is right, wrong is wrong. Take no prisoners. Divide and conquer.

When he returned to Mississippi after serving 10 years as an Army Ranger, he found Tibbehah County infested with strip joints and meth labs, bogus preachers and vicious bikers, crooked politicians and marauding gangsters. Now, in THE INNOCENTS (Putnam, $27), the sixth book in this series, Quinn has been voted out as sheriff, but he’s still trying to make things right.

The attack came during a peaceful demonstration against the widely publicized police shootings of black men in Louisiana and Minnesota earlier in the week.

lead_paragraph: CALGARY, Canada — Officially, Naheed Nenshi, the mayor of this oil-fueled city, is meant to be addressed as Your Worship, a stuffy, colonial-era honorific that has somehow managed to survive Canada’s transformation into a modern, multicultural nation. “It’s weird,” Mr. Nenshi, a rotund, curly-haired 44-year-old, said one recent afternoon as he sat behind the large wooden desk that dominates his office.

headline: Widespread Flooding in China Kills Over 160, Providing a Test for Leaders
abstract: The country’s flood defenses have faltered in the past, but Prime Minister Li Keqiang has said that the government is better prepared this year.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Torrential rains and floods across the southern half of China have besieged cities and towns for days. More than 160 people had died by Friday in drownings and landslides and as buildings collapsed, including 35 people buried by a landslide in the far west. Nearly two million people have been moved to safer ground while swollen rivers and lakes strain dikes and dams.

headline: Collecting Street Art: Have Room on Your Wall for a Wall?

lead_paragraph: IN what was billed as a monthlong residency in New York City, the British street artist Banksy worked at night putting stencils on walls around the city. In the morning, he posted images online that sent fans hunting to find them before they were painted over.

lead_paragraph: At the corner of Jersey and Crosby Streets in SoHo, during one of those New York City days when it suddenly feels way too hot, the sun was blazing down and a tang of urine wafted up.

headline: For Effective Brain Fitness, Do More Than Play Simple Games
abstract: The theory of a more holistic approach is that the brain thrives on continuous stimulation, which can include exercising, laughing and socializing.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a “brain fitness” course was introduced at her retirement community, Connie Cole was eager to sign up. After joining, she learned how to use an Apple iPad and work more complex tasks verbally and on paper.

headline: Aubrey Plaza on Life After ‘Parks and Recreation’

In “Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,” Aubrey Plaza and Anna Kendrick play hard-partying besties who clean up their acts to fulfill the ad requirements of hellion brothers ordered to bring nice girls to their sister’s Hawaiian nuptials. But no sooner have they landed in Oahu than buyers’ remorse sets in.

lead_paragraph: On a frigid night in December, the members of the Caribbean-inflected New York band the Frightnrs sat around talking tattoos. The group’s singer, Dan Klein, had been adding ink at an unusually accelerated pace.

lead_paragraph: Most choreographers celebrating a 50th anniversary season revisit the past, but when it came time for her turn last fall, Twyla Tharp, with typical daring, created two new dances. This summer, however, she’s looking back — to a point.

headline: Doping Watchdog Answers Questions From United States Senate
abstract: The global regulator of doping in sports answered a Senate committee’s inquiry this week, seeking to assure lawmakers that taxpayer money was well spent.
lead_paragraph: The global regulator of doping in sports, responding to questions about why it did not respond more aggressively to whistle-blowers’ accusations of a government-run doping program in Russia, has told United States lawmakers that it did not have the authority to investigate such claims.

headline: Dada Was Born 100 Years Ago. So What?
abstract: New York Times critics explore the impact and history of the provocative cultural movement, which reveled in anti-art, in dance, music and visual arts.
lead_paragraph: On July 14, 1916, the poet Hugo Ball proclaimed the manifesto for a new movement. Its name: Dada. Its aim: to “get rid of everything that smacks of journalism, worms, everything nice and right, blinkered, moralistic, europeanised, enervated.” This aim could be achieved simply by saying: “Dada.”

headline: In China, Relatives Await Word on Detained Rights Lawyers After a Year
abstract: About 250 human rights lawyers and activists were detained last year, and this week loved ones of those still in custody began to speak out more vocally.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — You Minglei, a legal assistant to a human rights lawyer in Fuzhou, in southern China, was waiting on Friday for his wife, Zhao Wei, to come home. The police had released Ms. Zhao on bail on Thursday after nearly a year in jail and just two days before the anniversary of mass detentions of rights lawyers and activists in China that have drawn criticism from around the world and that are known as “709” for July 9, the day it began last year.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Jay McInerney
