lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer Jay McInerney, who shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The nature writer Terry Tempest Williams enters the monthly travel list with her look at America’s national parks, “The Hour of Land,” new at No.3.
lead_paragraph: Energy Explorer: The nature writer and environmental activist Terry Tempest Williams enters the monthly travel list (available online) with her look at America’s national parks, “The Hour of Land,” new at No. 3. One bright thread running through the book is Williams’s relationship with her father, John Tempest, a stoical, Teddy Roosevelt-style outdoorsman who shares his daughter’s love of wild places even as he revels in the company he founded to lay pipes for natural gas. “I’m proud of what we’ve done,” he tells her. “Not many men can say they’ve walked most of the major gas lines that fueled the American West’s development like I have.”

headline: A More Personal Hillary Clinton Tries to Erase a Trust Deficit
abstract: Mrs. Clinton has slowly owned up to the trustworthiness problem. But it will take more than acknowledgment to fix the issue.
lead_paragraph: For most of her presidential campaign, whenever Hillary Clinton has been confronted with polls showing that a majority of voters do not trust her, she has attributed the problem to decades of wild Republican attacks and right-wing conspiracy theories.

headline: ‘Death & Harry Houdini’ Makes Art Out of Magic and Mayhem
abstract: A look at poster art for the music-and-magic show at the House Theater of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “Death & Harry Houdini” is a biographical show about the famed death-defying magician, featuring live magic and vaudeville-style music. It was the first production at House Theater in Chicago in 2001, and has been revived a few times since. Its most recent incarnation, which started performances in May, features an eye-catching poster with the title rendered in stylized oversized lettering. Houdini’s face, partially covered by a gas mask, peers out with an ominous intensity. The poster’s hues — red, a dark brown-black and a bluish aqua — lend it a dangerous Steampunk-like quality.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Strike Different Tones After Dallas Shooting
abstract: The killing of five police officers in Dallas altered the contours of the campaign, with Mr. Trump calling the events in Texas “an attack on our country.”
lead_paragraph: The ambush that left five police officers dead at a protest in Dallas on Thursday has altered the contours of the presidential campaign, with Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump canceling political events on Friday and striking different tones about the killings.

headline: Chaos After the Gunshots in Dallas
abstract: Five Dallas police officers were killed and seven others were wounded, along with two civilians, in a sniper attack during a demonstration on Thursday night against police shootings in Minnesota and Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Five Dallas police officers were killed and seven others were wounded, along with two civilians, in a sniper attack during a demonstration on Thursday night against police shootings in Minnesota and Louisiana.

headline: 1891: Kaiser William in London
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune archives: A cricket match enlivens a visit by Kaiser William to England in 1891.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — All was bustle at Windsor Castle this morning [July 8], attendant upon the packing of the trunks and the removal of the impedimenta of the German Emperor and Empress to London. During the forenoon, the German Emperor, attended by one of his suite and General McNeil, rode from the Castle on horseback to Cumberland Lodge, and returned to the Palace to luncheon. The Queen took tea at Frogmore, on her way to the garden party given at Cumberland Lodge this afternoon by Prince and Princess Christian of Schleswig-Holstein to celebrate their silver wedding. The day’s proceedings included a cricket match between a team selected by Prince Victor Christian against a team of officers of the Household Brigade, the match being played on the ground in front of the Lodge. The band of the Scots Guards and the pipers of the regiment were in attendance, and enlivened the afternoon’s proceedings. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 9, 1891

headline: Seasons at the Plate That Came Out of Left Field
abstract: Few fans could have predicted the terrific seasons these five players are enjoying entering the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: Once the baseball season reaches its halfway point, the league leaders start to take on a familiar look. The patient hitters are drawing the most walks, the home run hitters are hitting homers and the doublers are doubling.

Trump) and a new episode of Jimmy Fallon’s “Tonight” show.

headline: Investors Get Stung Twice by Executives’ Lavish Pay Packages

lead_paragraph: It’s a frustrating fact of life for many mutual fund investors: Even if they’re distressed by outsize executive compensation at public companies whose shares they indirectly own, chances are good that the votes cast by their investment managers actually encourage delusional pay.

lead_paragraph: Everyone at the market in New York has summer squash now, and most vegetable gardens are brimming with it. From my perspective — which is, admittedly, somewhat fanatic — what you want when it comes to summer squash are specimens that are neither too big nor too small.

lead_paragraph: Helen Gurley Brown’s turreted quadruplex atop the exclusive Beresford co-op at 211 Central Park West, where she lived for four decades until her death in 2012 and which was bedecked in midcentury glamour, has finally sold. At $19,380,000, it was the second most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

headline: What I Love | Ellen Freudenheim

headline: A Central Conflict of 21st-Century Politics: Who Belongs?
abstract: Michael Ignatieff, a former party leader in Canada, describes tensions between those who see immigration as a universal right, and those who regard it as a limited gift.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trend emerged into public consciousness last year with the rise of far-right politics in Europe. It spread with Donald J. Trump’s successful campaign to become the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in the United States. And its consequences became unmistakable with Britain’s vote last month to exit the European Union.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘You’ll Grow Out of It’
abstract: This week, Jessi Klein discusses her new essay collection; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Antonio García Martinez talks about “Chaos Monkeys”; and Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jessi Klein discusses her new essay collection; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Antonio García Martinez talks about “Chaos Monkeys”; and Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Factional Fighting Breaks Out in South Sudan’s Capital
abstract: Gunfire broke out for a second straight day on Friday, threatening a truce just days before the country’s independence anniversary.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Gunfire again echoed across South Sudan’s capital on Friday, a day after fighting among military factions there left at least five dead, in a new outbreak of violence that has threatened an already-tense stalemate just days before the country is to celebrate its fifth independence day.

headline: The Playlist: Jay Z Responds to Police Shootings With ‘Spiritual’
abstract: Hear the tracks (and watch the videos) that caught our pop critics’ attention, from Francis and the Lights’s “Friends” to Kenny Garrett’s “Backyard Groove.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, The New York Times pop critics weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: 1916: Russia and Japan Sign Pact
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: Russia and Japan sign a pact to ensure “equilibrium” in the Far East in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Discussing the effects of the treaty between Russia and Japan, guaranteeing the mutual protection of their interests in the Far East, the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued the following communiqué in Tokio: The object of the new arrangement is to conform clearly with other international treaties and to assure the equilibrium of affairs in the Far East. The text, which is brief, but of considerable importance, proves the firm determination of the two Powers to maintain relations of mutual confidence and to co-ordinate their efforts for the defence of their rights and legitimate interests. It does not in any way threaten the situation of any other Power having equally-pacific designs, and it is in complete harmony with the Anglo-Japanese Alliance, of which it augments the force and is a corollary. Frequent allusions from an unauthorized source have intimated that the document will have an important influence on the future attitude of Japan toward China. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 9, 1916

headline: Was Mary Todd Lincoln Driven ‘Mad’ by a Vitamin Deficiency?
abstract: A doctor suggests a new explanation for the many odd behaviors of first lady Mary Todd Lincoln: A vitamin deficiency that affected her mind.
lead_paragraph: Could pernicious anemia, a disease caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency, have explained the many strange behaviors of Mary Todd Lincoln?

headline: British Art Fairs: One Country, but Worlds Apart
abstract: As local fairs in the countryside struggle, an international clientele is likely to help the London art market weather the uncertainty over Brexit.
lead_paragraph: A chipped china saucer. A toy cow. A terra-cotta flowerpot. A dog-eared “Peter Rabbit” book. Half a tin of white emulsion paint. A thimble.

headline: Helen Gurley Brown’s penthouse at the Beresford has sold.
abstract: The turreted quadriplex was bedecked in midcentury glamour with bold hues of pink and red.
lead_paragraph: The turreted quadriplex was bedecked in midcentury glamour with bold hues of pink and red.

headline: Milos Raonic and Andy Murray Reach Wimbledon Final
abstract: Raonic defeated Roger Federer in five sets on Friday to reach his first Grand Slam final; Murray beat Tomas Berdych in three sets.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer had been carefully calibrating expectations — for himself, for the news media, for the fans — before Wimbledon began.

headline: Ellen Freudenheim, Abroad in Brooklyn
abstract: Ellen Freudenheim has written her fourth guidebook to her home borough, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Freudenheim, an author and activist, had visited Brooklyn only twice before she started house hunting in Park Slope in 1983. She was pregnant with her first child and living in a small Greenwich Village apartment.

headline: What Allison Janney Can’t Travel Without
abstract: When the actress Allison Janney takes a trip, a Chanel handbag, hand cream and an extra pair of socks go with her.
lead_paragraph: With seven Emmy Awards to her credit, the actress Allison Janney is best known for her roles on “The West Wing” and “Masters of Sex” and her current turn as a recovering alcoholic with a dark sense of humor on the CBS comedy series “Mom.” She’s also starring, with Ellen Page, in the film “Tallulah,” to be released on July 29.

headline: Model’s Eye View: Couture Week With Jing Wen
abstract: From the winged eyeliner at Christian Dior to a life-size Karl Lagerfeld cutout, the model and photographer shares a diary of her time in Paris exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: From the winged eyeliner at Christian Dior to a life-size Karl Lagerfeld cutout, the model and photographer shares a diary of her time in Paris exclusively with T.

headline: The Horror in Dallas, a Country Drowning in Grief
abstract: After the killing of five officers, the police and civilians now plead for an end to violence and divisiveness.
lead_paragraph: Instantly, shockingly, the murder of five police officers on duty at a peaceful protest in Dallas has compounded the nation’s continuing  agony. The devastating attack wounded seven other officers and two civilians. In mere hours, the carnage left the country with a wrenching shift: from grieving the latest black victims of police shootings in Minnesota and Louisiana to grieving for the police officers slain so viciously in Dallas.

headline: 5 Slain Dallas Officers Served Overseas and at Home
abstract: The dead officers included at least two military veterans and one who was awarded a title of ‘Cops’ Cop.’
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — On Thursday night, around the time the gunfire started, Kristy Villasenor, the wife of a Dallas police officer, posted a picture of herself and her toddler daughter on Facebook from a Texas Rangers baseball game at Globe Life Park in Arlington.

headline: Grace Gummer on ‘Mr. Robot’ and Being Meryl Streep’s Daughter
abstract: The 30-year-old actress plays an F.B.I. investigator on the cyberthriller that starts its second season next week.
lead_paragraph: The weight of a gun in her hand was unsettling. “It’s a very loaded feeling in every sense,” Grace Gummer said. “It makes you stand a little straighter, walk a little taller. It makes you feel important. But at the same time, it’s terrifying.”

headline: Part Plumber, Part Ringmaster
abstract: Jimmy Hoehlein, a fish guy (more formally known as an aquarium service technician), paid a visit to tanks in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Hoehlein, a fish guy (more formally known as an aquarium service technician), paid a visit to tanks in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village.

headline: Gods of a Fish-Eat-Fish World
abstract: An aquarium service technician is part plumber, part veterinarian, and part ringmaster of a world where things aren’t meant to live in harmony.
lead_paragraph: Felix the Fish Guy’s Fourth of July plans were dashed by a middle-of-the-night phone call from a frantic client.

headline: What You Should Watch This Weekend: ‘The Night Of’ and ‘The Circus’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our upcoming website.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘You’ll Grow Out of It’
abstract: Jessi Klein talks about her new book of essays, and Antonio García Martinez discusses “Chaos Monkeys.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Date-Stuffed Parathas
abstract: For a summery twist on this buttery flatbread, stuff it with dates and grill it.
lead_paragraph: For a summery twist on this buttery flatbread, stuff it with dates and grill it.

headline: Paratha That’s Easy, Versatile and Burnished With Butter
abstract: These Indian flatbreads are a cinch to make and at their most ethereal when eaten fresh and warm.
lead_paragraph: I’m not in the habit of baking my own bread. The crackling loaves that I can pick up at the shop around the corner surpass anything I make at home.

headline: Shootings Further Divide a Nation Torn Over Race
abstract: This week’s convulsive events have prompted anguished pleas for unity and echoes of the protests and divisions of the late 1960s and early ’70s.
lead_paragraph: First came the cellphone video of an African-American man being fatally shot by a Louisiana police officer, and the astonishing live feed of a Minnesota woman narrating the police killing of her African-American boyfriend during a traffic stop. Then came the horrific live television coverage of police officers being gunned down by a sniper at a march protesting the police shootings.

headline: Obama Rebukes Poland’s Right-Wing Government
abstract: President Obama expressed concern over the Polish government’s constitutional crisis as a NATO summit meeting began in Warsaw.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama chided Poland’s new right-wing leaders on Friday over moves that have effectively hobbled the country’s top constitutional court, the chief check on the government’s power, and urged them to do more to nurture democratic values and institutions.

headline: In This Heat, Happiness Is Just a Sprinkler Away
abstract: New York City’s play sprinklers have one thing in common: As soon as it’s hot, they become magnets for children (and some adults).
lead_paragraph: They range from simple spigots in the corner of a Bronx housing project to elaborate water-drenched playgrounds with river views in Brooklyn. But wherever they are, New York City’s play sprinklers have one thing in common: As soon as it is hot, they are thronged with children (and some adults) who know that in July, bliss is whatever cools you down.

headline: On Dallas Streets, Fearful Bystanders and Chilling Historical Echoes
abstract: In a nightmarish week, Dallas was thrust into the heat of the moment on Thursday when a peaceful march quickly turned violent.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The hundreds of demonstrators were in the middle of a call and response: “Hands Up! Don’t Shoot!” Some held their hands up in solidarity, some held up colorful posters, some held children’s hands, others walked casually as if on a stroll. It was late twilight, the sky a cobalt blue and the overnight lights on in the downtown buildings.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Mets’ Matt Harvey Chooses Season-Ending Surgery
abstract: Harvey, who is 4-10 with a 4.86 E.R.A., will have an operation to alleviate thoracic outlet syndrome, his agent, Scott Boras, said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Mets were counting on Matt Harvey this season, hoping he would build off his strong comeback in 2015 and help lead the team back to the postseason for the second year in a row.

headline: Divided by Race, United by Pain
abstract: Don’t forget that the protesters were peaceful. Don’t forget that the police were protecting them.

headline: Economic Uncertainty Remains Even After ‘Brexit’
abstract: That Britain would somehow reject the rational choice seems to have never occurred to investors worldwide, and now we see the consequences.
lead_paragraph: It does not seem quite fair: The scattered remains of the prior financial crisis are still hanging around, and yet there are already stirrings of another.

headline: After Dallas Killings, New York Police Dept. Steps Up Precautions
abstract: The agency directed officers to patrol in pairs, and the presence of the police outside some precinct station houses may also be increased.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting of five police officers at a protest in Dallas, with its unsettling echoes of the murder of two officers in Brooklyn, reverberated through New York City on Friday as officials stepped up security precautions.

headline: Ashland Comes to Brooklyn
abstract: The transformation of the Brooklyn Cultural District continues with the opening of the Ashland, a new residential rental tower.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of the Brooklyn Cultural District continues this summer with the opening of the Ashland, a residential rental tower at the nexus of Fort Greene, Downtown Brooklyn and the numerous arts organizations that are anchored by the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: The Revolution: A ‘Purple Rain’ Reunion in Prince’s Honor
abstract: The band members on the “Purple Rain” album will take part, as will others who played with Prince early in his career, in two shows in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: The Revolution, the group Prince founded as his backing band in 1979, has made good on the promise of a reunion, made soon after the musician’s death on April 21. On Wednesday, the bassist Mark Brown (known professionally as BrownMark) announced on Facebook that the group would play on Sept. 2 and Sept. 3 at the First Avenue club in Minneapolis, the setting for the concert sequences in the film “Purple Rain,” starring Prince, and a central point for mourners after the singer’s unexpected death at 57.

headline: The Greenest Building in the South Bronx
abstract: Work is nearly finished on the Bronx River House, an ecologically sensitive building for the Bronx River Alliance and community groups.
lead_paragraph: Near the elevated 6 train, past graffitied buildings and auto body shops, just off the trash-strewn Sheridan Expressway, a narrow, hidden river flows. And on its banks the greenest and most cutting-edge building in the South Bronx is rising.

headline: Lawsuit Aims at Jeffrey Katzenberg and His Dual-Class Shares
abstract: He owns 11.5 percent of DreamWorks Animation but has 60 percent of the shareholder vote, which gives him control in a sale to NBCUniversal.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chief executive and controlling shareholder of DreamWorks Animation, cut himself a nice side deal at the expense of DreamWorks shareholders, according to a recent lawsuit filed in Delaware Chancery Court over the company’s $3.8 billion sale to Comcast’s NBCUniversal.

headline: How Trump Can Save the G.O.P.
abstract: Conservatives should thank him for exposing the party’s real problems.
lead_paragraph: AS the Republican National Convention nears, there is growing talk of a palace — or party — coup to wrest the nomination from Donald J. Trump, or at least stage a public protest against him.

headline: Four Seasons, Lunch Spot for Manhattan’s Prime Movers, Moves On
abstract: The restaurant, which redefined American dining and gave birth to the power lunch, is leaving the space it has occupied since 1959.
lead_paragraph: In New York, a restaurant that lasts 10 years is old. Most fail to make it to their first birthday. When the Seagram Building turns the lights out on the Four Seasons restaurant next week, it will end a run that began in 1959. Eisenhower was president, the Edsel was still new and television viewers tuned in, for the first time, to “Bonanza” and “The Twilight Zone.” It was a very long time ago.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

headline: Steve Cummings Produces Fourth Tour de France Stage Win for His Small Team
abstract: Cummings posted the fourth win by a rider on Dimension Data, an African registered team with a budget far smaller than its rivals.
lead_paragraph: BAGNÈRES-DE-BIGORRE, France — Britain may have voted to leave Europe, but it is dominating the Tour de France.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 9 Through July 17
abstract: Jorge Celedón will perform with Grupo Niche on July 22 at Prudential Hall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Secret to Swordfish Speed Is Found: Grease
abstract: Scientists have discovered an oil-producing gland that lubricates the fish’s head and helps it achieve impressive speeds.
lead_paragraph: Swordfish are among the fastest fish in the ocean, and now scientists may have found at least one reason: The fish secrete a performance-enhancing grease.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Cough That Won’t Stop Solved!
abstract: A healthy middle-aged man can’t stop coughing. Our readers helped solve the mystery.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we asked Well readers to unravel the case of a middle-aged man who had a cough for over a year. He was just about to give up on finding a cause or cure when he started coughing up blood. A CT scan done at that point revealed a strange hole near the base of the right lung. Your challenge was to figure out what was going on.

headline: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life.
abstract: Andes Bureau Chief Nicholas Casey and staff photographer Joshua Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their story about a vanished lake.
lead_paragraph: Andes Bureau Chief Nicholas Casey and staff photographer Joshua Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their story about a vanished lake.

headline: Review: Dance That Reaches for the Stars, With Help From Technology
abstract: Dusan Tynek Dance Theater performed the premiere of “Tethered Light” at New York Live Arts on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Dusan Tynek’s new dance, tiny white lights seem to float in the darkness like fireflies or distant stars. It’s an image that shimmers with the promise of wonder or even sublimity. And yet, as the sources of illumination turn out to be no more than LEDs strapped to shins and forearms of dancers, the shimmer fades. The title of the work, “Tethered Light,” comes to feel disappointingly accurate.

headline: The Agony of the Digital Tease
abstract: They communicate with breadcrumbs, sporadic noncommittal messages that are just enough to keep you wondering but not enough to seal the deal.
lead_paragraph: There was the breadcrumb dropped on Valentine’s Day, by the ex-girlfriend of my friend. The two women hadn’t spoken in months, after a prolonged breakup, and the ex was now seeing somebody new.

headline: Gretchen Carlson Suit Aims at Retaliation Over Discrimination
abstract: The suit is following a trend so pronounced that it has sometimes displaced attempts to remedy the discriminatory treatment itself.
lead_paragraph: In the complaint that Gretchen Carlson, the former Fox News anchor, filed this week against Roger Ailes, the network’s chairman, one thing stands out above all: the overtness of the sexual harassment that Ms. Carlson says she endured.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, July 9 Through July 17
abstract: “Ain’t Misbehavin’,” a musical revue by Murray Horwitz and Richard Maltby Jr., is running through July 16 at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘This Has Pushed a Button’: Killings in Kenya Ignite National Outcry
abstract: The case of a lawyer, his last known client and a taxi driver, all last seen in police custody but later found dead in a river, has exploded like few others in Kenya.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The bodies were found in horrible shape.

abstract: A reader writes that most “prefer the dignity of a living wage over the government’s beneficence.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
abstract: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
lead_paragraph: There used to be a lake in Bolivia. Lake Poopó. Then it disappeared — along with most of the villagers who depended on the lake, for generations.

headline: Migration to Greece by the Aegean Sea Has Plummeted, U.N. Says
abstract: The figures suggest that a deal brokered by the European Union with Turkey has worked, although human rights groups have raised concerns.
lead_paragraph: The number of migrants risking the perilous voyage from Turkey to Greece via the Aegean Sea has plummeted, according to new figures released by the United Nations, a sign that a deal brokered by the European Union in March to ease the migration crisis has shown some success.

headline: Fendi’s Fall 2016 Couture Show in Rome
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld and Silvia Venturini Fendi presented a fur-focused show on top of the Trevi Fountain.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld and Silvia Venturini Fendi presented a fur-focused show on top of the Trevi Fountain.

headline: On the No-Fly List? No Gun
abstract: Senators Susan Collins and Heidi Heitkamp discuss their bipartisan legislation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fendi’s Fairytale Show at Rome’s Trevi Fountain
abstract: For its fall couture collection, titled “Legends and Fairytales,” the house suspended plexiglass panels over the famous Roman fountain.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 17th century, Louis XIV was obsessed with fountains: he installed 50 at Versailles, with 620 jets spewing more water per day than the entire city of Paris consumed. Such was the outlay that, as the king promenaded, the fountains behind would be switched off to enable those ahead to be fully fed, a logistical nightmare handled by a team of fountaineers specifically devoted to the task.

headline: 4 Young Chess Masters Tackle a Persistent Puzzle: The Gender Gap
abstract: It is one of the vexing questions in the game: Why are boys and men so much more prominent than their female counterparts?
lead_paragraph: Fourteen of the nation’s top young chess masters came to New York this week for an elite clinic at the Marshall Chess Club. Four of them were girls. For proponents of gender parity in chess, this was progress.

headline: NATO Unity, Tested by Russia, Shows Some Cracks
abstract: At a summit meeting of the Atlantic alliance, the first after Britain’s vote to withdraw from the European Union, leaders brought differing agendas for dealing with Moscow.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama and European leaders tried to project a united front at a NATO summit meeting on Friday, with Mr. Obama dismissing as “hyperbole” any fear that Britain’s vote to leave the European Union would unravel the broader trans-Atlantic security alliance.

headline: Police and Race: A National Tragedy
abstract: Readers respond to the racially motivated killings of recent days.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Paradox of Disclosure
abstract: Revealing your bias often makes others more likely to take your advice.
lead_paragraph: A POPULAR remedy for a conflict of interest is disclosure — informing the buyer (or the patient, etc.) of the potential bias of the seller (or the doctor, etc.). Disclosure is supposed to act as a warning, alerting consumers to their adviser’s stake in the matter so they can process the advice accordingly.

headline: Artists Begin Building Trump’s Border Wall, Sending Mexico the Bill
abstract: The structure, in the California desert, stands 20 yards from the actual United States-Mexico border.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Donald J. Trump announced his plans to build a wall at the border, pundits and voters have been debating how it would work. Now a pair of artists have offered an example: They have built a wall — or the start of one, anyway — near the edge of Jacumba Hot Springs, Calif., a border town about 70 miles southeast of San Diego.

headline: Watergate Hotel Is Back and Banking on History, Glamorous or Scandalous
abstract: The hotel has been reopened on a bet that a $125 million renovation to restore its midcentury roots — and its distinctive history — can inspire a renaissance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Depending on how you look at it, fate has been either cruel or kind to the Watergate Hotel.

headline: Investors Doubt Proposed Deals by Aetna and Anthem
abstract: If stock prices are an indicator, Aetna’s plan to buy the insurer Humana and Anthem’s bid for Cigna are unlikely to come to fruition.
lead_paragraph: Two American health care megadeals have been given grim diagnoses. Aetna’s $34 billion plan to buy rival Humana and Anthem’s $44 billion acquisition of Cigna are risky propositions to shrink the industry to three big insurers from five. Their stock prices now suggest zero chance either deal will succeed. If investors are correct, the companies will return to independence worse than when they started.

headline: ‘Squidbillies’ Is Still Blazing a Caustic, Backwoods Trail
abstract: The Adult Swim series returns for a 10th season, and lipstick will never be the same, while “Duck Dynasty,” on A&E, lacks spontaneity.
lead_paragraph: A series can have a long television tenure by gently subverting backwoods stereotypes: Witness the return this week of A&E’s “Duck Dynasty” for what seems like its zillionth season. But a series can also have a long television tenure by taking backwoods stereotypes and turning them into a cudgel with which to pound maniacally on all manner of topical subjects. Yes, the squids are back.

headline: Review: On Hot Summer Days, Sandwiches Provide the Shade
abstract: Suzanne’s Table and Plum Plums Cheese offer slices of bread with everything imaginable in between.
lead_paragraph: It’s hot out there, and when temperatures soar, we like a sandwich swaddled in crisp paper or tin foil — no muss, no fuss — with a few extra napkins. Two relatively new spots, both sticklers for quality, give you exactly what you want: honest sandwiches with a bit of pizazz. In the classic children’s book “Bread and Jam for Frances,” an intransigent little badger refuses to eat anything but bread and jam — until, of course, she sees what is possible, and at last relishes a lobster-salad sandwich on thin slices of white bread. A good sandwich always has a happy ending.

headline: Cartoon of Obama Is Condemned as Anti-Semitic in Spain
abstract: As part of a protest against President Obama’s visit to Spain, the United Left posted a drawing of him hugging a caricature of Jewish man and slipping him money.
lead_paragraph: Jewish associations in Spain and the Israeli Embassy in Madrid condemned a cartoon used by a Spanish far-left political party to protest President Obama’s planned visit, saying on Friday that the cartoon was anti-Semitic.

headline: Theranos Sanctions Letter
abstract: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services is imposing penalties and sanctions on Theranos. They include revoking the license of its flagship laboratory in Newark, Calif., and prohibiting it from taking Medicare and Medicaid payments for its services.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services is imposing penalties and sanctions on Theranos. They include revoking the license of its flagship laboratory in Newark, Calif., and prohibiting it from taking Medicare and Medicaid payments for its services.

headline: Street Style: Haute Couture in Paris
abstract: Haute couture brings the last of the fashion shows in Europe until September, and the fashion crowds come out to see the finery.
lead_paragraph: Haute couture brings the last of the fashion shows in Europe until September, and the fashion crowds come out to see the finery.

headline: Review: A Sushi Spot, Ajihei in Princeton, Diversifies Its Menu
abstract: A Japanese restaurant known for its simple presentations of sashimi and sushi now focuses more on cooked dishes, especially ramen.
lead_paragraph: In the days before “Iron Chef,” there was “Ajihei the Cook,” a 1970s Japanese comic about a young chef who faced battles of the knife and the noodle in his quest to become the best.

headline: Review: Mourning in Tap Shoes at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: “And Still You Must Swing,” by Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, Derick K. Grant and Jason Samuels Smith, takes on a different kind of fervor after the recent shootings.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards paced restlessly, rubbing her palms together. The jazz trio had stopped playing. She seemed uncertain of her next move.

headline: Review: In ‘La Bohème,’ Young Singers Embrace the Roles of Puccini’s Free Spirits
abstract: This simple but touching production showcases fledgling performers who were coached through a Martina Arroyo Foundation program.
lead_paragraph: Four young men share a garret in Paris: a struggling writer who fancies himself a poet; a frustrated artist who humbles himself painting lame murals in a remote tavern; a sort of cafe philosopher with scant employment options; and a versatile musician who manages to pick up a gig now and then, including a strange one from an eccentric nobleman.

headline: Review: The Grey Lady Opens in Montauk
abstract: The latest branch in a small upscale chain of New England-style restaurants adapts to local flair, and even serves lionfish.
lead_paragraph: The term “Gray Lady” is not just a nickname for this publication. It’s also used, often with the alternative spelling of “grey,” to describe the island of Nantucket when shrouded in fog. This salt-and-sea image — rather than the ink-stained one — is the concept behind a small upscale chain of New England-style restaurants, which serve straightforward seafood dishes in casually stylish settings. Grey Lady locations, however, are anything but casual. With outposts in Aspen, Nantucket, Manhattan, and now Montauk, this is a Lady with expensive taste in real estate.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jazmine Hughes, Lynda Richardson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: How New York Artists Interpret Greek Words
abstract: Works on view in a new show at Mykonos’s Dio Horia space are paired with Greek vocabulary, from “empathy” to “eroticism.”
lead_paragraph: Works on view in a new show at Mykonos’s Dio Horia space are paired with Greek vocabulary, from “empathy” to “eroticism.”

headline: How the Police See Us, and How They Train Us to See Them
abstract: Black Americans as threat and threatened.
lead_paragraph: The first image you see when you play the video is the face of a black woman. She is sitting in the passenger seat of a vehicle. Then the camera turns to a black male in the driver’s seat, leaned over, eyes half-closed, T-shirt slick with blood.

headline: Review: Miro Kitchen in Fairfield Gives Homey Dishes an Asian Jolt
abstract: A self-taught chef turns conventional fare into exuberantly creative cookery.
lead_paragraph: Whether we realize it or not, most of us patronize Asian restaurants where the cuisine has been tamed — made blander and more familiar — to suit American palates.

headline: The Greek Island That’s Becoming an Unexpected Art Destination
abstract: A group show of New York-based artists on view this summer on Mykonos marks an ambitious moment for what’s long been considered an opulent party town.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, some of the most influential young artists in New York — among them Jeff Koons, Ashley Bickerton, Haim Steinbach, Peter Halley and Meyer Vaisman — flew to Athens for the opening of the Deste Foundation for Contemporary Art’s seminal show “Cultural Geometry.” That exhibition was something of a flash point: as its curator Jeffrey Deitch recalls, it brought the international art community to Greece en masse, in what was, for many, their inaugural visit to the country. Now, just shy of 30 years later, a group of American artists is again descending on Greece. This time, though, it’s happening on the island of Mykonos, for a group show, “Greek Gotham,” at Marina Vranopoulou’s year-old space, Dio Horia. Opening July 29, and spread over 4,000 square feet, the show will bring together 16 of New York’s most of-the-moment artists — among them Nina Chanel Abney, KAWS and Erik Parker. It was conceived by the New York-based art consultant Maria Brito, who is taking on the role of curator for the first time.

headline: Me and Barbra, and a Mall-Full of Goodies
abstract: In the play “Buyer & Cellar” at Penguin Rep, an underemployed actor becomes caretaker of Barbra Streisand’s personal shopping center.
lead_paragraph: “The idea was too much fun to let go.” This is how, in his program note, Jonathan Tolins explains how he came to write “Buyer & Cellar,” the one-man show at Penguin Rep in Stony Point through July 24.

headline: Flu Vaccine in Pregnancy Offers Brief Protection of Babies
abstract: Flu shots in pregnant women protect their unborn children, but only for a matter of weeks.
lead_paragraph: Unborn babies are temporarily protected by their mother’s flu shot, but that immunity fades within weeks after birth, a new study found.

headline: Haute Couture Brings Out the Fashion Crowd in Paris
abstract: We captured head-turning street style during the recent shows — the last in Europe until September.
lead_paragraph: At the last of the shows in Europe until September, the fashion crowd comes out to see the finery.

headline: Familiar Pianist at Caramoor, and Beethoven’s Gravitational Pull
abstract: Jonathan Biss, the artist in residence at the center, feels the force of the legendary composer’s personality.
lead_paragraph: As an 18-year-old student at the Curtis Institute of Music, Jonathan Biss had little professional experience when he took part in the rising-star residency for instrumentalists at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah in 1998. But those who recall the tall, dark pianist during his residency say he radiated self-assurance beyond his years.

headline: Review: Lady Liberty Steps Off Her Pedestal to Sing
abstract: “Liberty: A Monumental New Musical,” by Dana Leslie Goldstein and Jon Goldstein, brings historical figures and one statue to life at 42West.
lead_paragraph: She’s poised, idealistic, determined. But many Americans think she’s just a useless foreigner.

headline: Man Survives Terrorist Attack in Bangladesh, but Is in Custody as a Suspect
abstract: Tahmid Khan, a college student, was wrongly suspected of being in league with the militants, his family and friends say. They now fear for his safety.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — When he was released with seven other hostages after a harrowing night of terrorist violence last Saturday, Tahmid Hasib Khan expected to be greeted with welcoming arms. Instead, Mr. Khan, a 22-year-old University of Toronto student, was grabbed by the Bangladeshi police, beaten and taken into custody. He has not been seen since.

headline: Review: ‘Struck’ at the New Jersey Repertory Company
abstract: Sandy Rustin’s play, having its world premiere in Long Branch, is a comedy that wrestles with chance and coincidence.
lead_paragraph: You can’t charm me into liking a play.

headline: The Dallas Gunman: What We Know
abstract: Micah Johnson, the gunman who carried out Thursday night’s attack in Dallas, leaving five police officers dead and seven wounded, was a military veteran who appears to have identified with black power groups.
lead_paragraph: Micah Johnson, the gunman who carried out Thursday night’s attack in Dallas, leaving five police officers dead and seven wounded, was a military veteran who appears to have identified with black power groups.

headline: Tracing the Origins of a Revolutionary War Spy Ring on Long Island
abstract: A new television show, “Turn: Washington’s Spies,” has led to an influx of tourists interested in espionage efforts under General George Washington.
lead_paragraph: When Linda Carlson recently flew from Orlando, Fla., to visit her daughter and five grandchildren in Patchogue on Long Island, she added an unusual item to the family itinerary: touring the sites she had seen on “Turn: Washington’s Spies,” a television series on AMC about local espionage efforts during the Revolutionary War.

headline: Rats on Main Street? Don’t Scream, They’re Art
abstract: The artist Kim Jones feels a connection to the wily rodents, and that explains why Ridgefield is teeming with rubber creatures.
lead_paragraph: A pre-turncoat Benedict Arnold had two horses shot from under him in the Battle of Ridgefield, which was actually one fierce clash and several skirmishes in 1777 that left around 100 dead.

headline: Black Caucus Demands Congress Hold Gun Vote After Shootings
abstract: Representative John Lewis, who led the House floor sit-in after the Orlando nightclub shootings, said Friday, “There’s no room in our society for violence.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders on Friday voiced dismay and outrage over the killings of police officers in Dallas and called on the American people to unify, and members of the Congressional Black Caucus, while echoing the grief and calls for healing, also demanded that Republicans allow votes to tighten the nation’s gun laws.

headline: Michael Hubbard, Former Alabama Speaker, Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: The Republican often described as the most powerful politician in the state, was convicted last month on 12 counts of corruption.
lead_paragraph: Michael G. Hubbard, the former speaker of the Alabama House of Representatives who was convicted in a state trial  last month on 12 counts of corruption, was sentenced on Friday to four years in prison plus probation and $210,000 in fines.

headline: Suspect in Dallas Attack Had Interest in Black Power Groups
abstract: Micah Johnson served in the Army and maintained a Facebook page that paid homage to black pride.
lead_paragraph: The man who the Dallas police say killed five officers in a barrage of bullets on Thursday was a troubled Army reservist who left Afghanistan under a cloud of sexual harassment charges made by a fellow soldier who sought an order of protection against him and said he needed mental health counseling.

headline: A Highway’s Starting Line, and a Flemish Firehouse
abstract: In F.Y.I., Michael Pollak explains why if you want to go from sea to shining sea, you start at 42nd Street.
lead_paragraph: Q. For some years, a seemingly official Department of Transportation street sign reading “Lincoln Highway” stood affixed to a lamppost on a corner of 42nd Street and Broadway, near the Zipper on 1 Times Square. No explanation of why 42nd Street should be known as the Lincoln Highway. Then, just as mysteriously, it was gone. Was it street art? A prank? A change of mind by the city? Please help.

headline: A Theranos Timeline
abstract: A start-up once promised to upend the medical testing business. Now, it is subject to regulatory and criminal review.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Holmes dropped out of Stanford to start Theranos in 2003, when she was 19. The company rose to prominence on the promise that it could detect health ailments at a low cost by testing blood drawn by the mere prick of a finger. Until a few years ago, the company had kept a relatively low profile. Here is a look at some milestones in the company’s development:

headline: Dallas, Roger Federer, Hillary Clinton: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Diamondback Terrapins Thrive Where Others Can’t
abstract: The turtle, named for the pattern on its back, is rarely as abundant as it is in Jamaica Bay — where it does well in the demanding habit of the estuary.
lead_paragraph: The angular, concentric rings on a diamondback terrapin’s carapace form the bold pattern that lends this turtle its wonderful name. Terrapins were more abundant in preindustrial New York City, but like striped bass, oysters and lavish beds of salt marsh cordgrass, they still survive in the estuaries where they evolved. Estuaries are difficult habitats for plants and animals as they are constantly in flux. Inundated with salt water daily, they provide a rich, virtually unending supply of nutrients to those species adapted to rapid change.

headline: Jay Z and Beyoncé: Activism Gone Vocal
abstract: Once chastised by Harry Belafonte for not being socially responsible, music’s power couple now raise concerns about police brutality in their songs.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the singer, actor and civil rights leader Harry Belafonte indicted, among others, Jay Z and Beyoncé as being part of a generation of black artists who have “turned their back on social responsibility.” It was a rare public upbraiding for a couple who had so effectively shifted American pop culture, but whose work for social change was primarily rooted in what they accomplished on record, not off.

headline: The Erie Canal: A Marvel, Every Inch of the Way
abstract: In “Heaven’s Ditch: God, Gold and Murder on the Erie Canal,” Jack Kelly recounts the construction of the Erie Canal, a 360-mile waterway built entirely by hand and largely through wilderness.
lead_paragraph: The Erie Canal, New York City’s visionary lifeline to the Midwest, moved earth and heaven as well as cargo. It was, Jack Kelly writes, “itself the product of inspiration, its construction an act of faith,” which may explain why it also stoked the religious and political furor that engulfed the State of New York two centuries ago.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: After Life: Keila, Tracy, Carol and Evelyn
abstract: Sara Bennett, a public defender turned photographer, followed four women as they transitioned from long prison sentences to life in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Sara Bennett, a public defender turned photographer, followed four women as they transitioned from long prison sentences to life in New York City.

headline: How the Dallas Shooting Unfolded
abstract: The attack was the deadliest against law enforcement officers in the United States since Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: The attack was the deadliest against law enforcement officers in the United States since Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Kevin Durant Reboots, Goes Digital
abstract: The superstar’s move to Golden State is another sign of Silicon Valley cultural hegemony.
lead_paragraph: There was a technical glitch. The Golden State Warriors, breakers of unbreakable records, failed to finish the season as repeat N.B.A. champions. Silicon Valley’s hometown team lost to some guys from the Rust Belt. So this week the Warriors upgraded their operating system. An already-extraordinary lineup that included the league’s two-time reigning M.V.P., Steph Curry, added the Oklahoma City Thunder’s Kevin Durant, the best scorer of his generation and the last M.V.P. before Curry.

headline: How Newfound Freedom Feels
abstract: Sara Bennett quit the law to become a photographer and learned how little she knew about the lives of prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Before she became a photographer, Sara Bennett was a public defender, so she thought she knew something about life in prison. But as she followed four women in their transition back to freedom in New York City, she realized she had a lot to learn. The women were all convicted of murder and served between 17 and 35 years, mainly at Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester County. “I didn’t know that if a loved one dies, you’re allowed to go to the funeral but you’re shackled,” Ms. Bennett said. “I didn’t know what it meant to be ill and grow old in prison.”

headline: The Neighborhood Apothecary
abstract: C.O. Bigelow, a small drugstore in the West Village in Manhattan, opened in 1838 and is said to have been favored by Mark Twain and Thomas Edison.
lead_paragraph: C.O. Bigelow, a small drugstore in the West Village in Manhattan, opened in 1838 and is said to have been favored by Mark Twain and Thomas Edison.

headline: Bustling Village Apothecary, Unchained by Time
abstract: C.O. Bigelow has a loyal following in the West Village in Manhattan and is considered by some to be the oldest pharmacy in the United States, opening in 1838.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday afternoon at the West Village apothecary C.O. Bigelow, Ronald Freyberger stood at the rear counter and updated a manager, Joseph Campanile, about the splint on his right hand. “The doctors still aren’t sure what the issue is, but either way, I still need to keep wearing this thing,” he said. Mr. Campanile asked about Mr. Freyberger’s health and how he was feeling that day. ( “All things considered,” he said, “pretty good.”)

headline: How Raven McRae, a Broadway Dancer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. McRae, 22, commutes by ferry from Staten Island for the matinee and evening performances of “Paramour,” a Cirque du Soleil musical.
lead_paragraph: Raven McRae, a 22-year-old dancer who was trained as an actress at LaGuardia High School, is the only native New Yorker in the cast of “Paramour,” a Cirque du Soleil musical currently on Broadway. Ms. McRae, who spent much of her childhood on Staten Island, lives there with her mother in an apartment in St. George. On Sundays, she commutes by ferry to Manhattan for two performances. Ms. McRae made her Broadway debut as a dancer two years ago in “Motown: The Musical.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Rejects F.B.I. Claim That She Was ‘Careless’ With Emails
abstract: In interviews on CNN and MSNBC, Mrs. Clinton tried to put the controversy surrounding her use of a private email server at the State Department to rest.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton on Friday rejected the F.B.I.’s assertion that she had been “extremely careless” with classified material as secretary of state, offering her first public comments on the matter since the Justice Department closed its inquiry without bringing charges against her this week.

headline: ‘Bomb Robot’ Takes Down Dallas Gunman, but Raises Enforcement Questions
abstract: Did the use of a bomb disposal robot by the Dallas police to carry and detonate an explosive device blur the line between policing and warfare?
lead_paragraph: The Dallas police ended a standoff with the gunman suspected of killing five officers with a tactic that by all accounts appears to be unprecedented: It blew him up using a robot.

headline: Harlem, Through Your Lens
abstract: Readers shared their photos to show what Harlem means to them.
lead_paragraph: Readers shared their photos to show what Harlem means to them.

headline: City Hall Tightens Control of Deed Changes After Nursing Home Deal
abstract: After the sale of a Manhattan property to condominium developers, the mayor’s office announced it would overhaul its policy for altering deed restrictions.
lead_paragraph: With several investigations into the deed modification and sale of a Manhattan nursing home still active, the de Blasio administration on Friday announced a new policy to overhaul its procedure for removing or amending deed restrictions.

headline: 10 More States Sue U.S. Over Transgender Policy for Schools
abstract: The lawsuit is similar to one filed after the administration directed public schools to let students use the bathroom matching their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Ten more states sued the federal government on Friday over a directive to public schools on bathroom use by transgender students, adding their objections to those of 11 states that brought a lawsuit soon after the directive was released in May.

headline: A Week From Hell
abstract: We as a society will not extinguish violence quickly, but individuals can make a start today.
lead_paragraph: Last week was yet another week that tore at the very fiber of our nation.

headline: After a Professor Is Cleared of Sexual Harassment, Critics Fear ‘Cultural Silence’ at Yale
abstract: After a professor was cleared of sexual misconduct by university personnel, faculty members and students wondered whether the review process had been fair.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas Pogge came to Yale University in 2008, his hiring was heralded as a major boon to its philosophy department, which had been struggling in recent years. Professor Pogge, a renowned German-born scholar of moral philosophy and international affairs, brought to Yale impressive academic credentials, and a dose of star power.

headline: The Baseball Gods Clobber the Mets
abstract: On a day when Terry Collins said that Noah Syndergaard would definitely pitch in the All-Star Game, the Mets pitcher left the game early with arm fatigue.
lead_paragraph: Before batting practice Friday, the Washington Nationals and Stephen Strasburg decided to rule Strasburg out of Tuesday’s All-Star Game. Strasburg is undefeated and was healthy enough to face the Mets on Friday night. But he recently spent time on the disabled list with a back injury, so caution prevailed over sentiment.

headline: A Different Look for the Men’s Final
abstract: For the first time in a major final, Murray will face someone other than Roger Federer or Novak Djokovic.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Andy Murray has certainly had his major moments, none better than becoming the first British man to win Wimbledon in 77 years.

headline: Alison Bernstein, Educator and Ford Foundation Executive, Dies at 69
abstract: At the Ford Foundation, Ms. Bernstein allocated tens of millions of dollars to programs for the arts and education at all levels.
lead_paragraph: Alison Bernstein, who expanded opportunities for learning and tackled challenging social problems as an educator and as an official of the Ford Foundation, died on June 30 at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 69.

headline: Knicks’ Free-Agent Hires Add Needed Depth and Homegrown Passion
abstract: The Knicks introduced their three major free-agent signings from this month, guards Brandon Jennings and Courtney Lee and center Joakim Noah, a New York native who grew up a die-hard fan.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When Phil Jackson met with Carmelo Anthony shortly after the end of the regular season, he asked his aging star a question that would set the tone for the coming summer.

headline: Dallas Police Chief David Brown, a Reformer, Becomes Face of Nation’s Shock
abstract: As Chief Brown sorted through a jumble of reports, some of them wrong, publicly narrating the standoff between his officers and the gunman, he also offered simple, emotional words.
lead_paragraph: After the killings in Dallas, David O. Brown, the city’s police chief, became the face of the nation’s shock.

headline: Live Footage of Shootings Forces Facebook to Confront New Role
abstract: After the death of Philando Castile and sniper fire in Dallas were streamed on Facebook, the company faces questions about how to handle graphic content.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Late Thursday evening, when sniper fire rang out across downtown Dallas, a bystander, Michael Kevin Bautista, used his smartphone to stream the events in real time on Facebook Live. Within the hour, CNN was rebroadcasting the footage.

headline: Obama’s Delicate Balance on Issue of Race and Policing
abstract: The president delivered a call for racial justice after two black men were killed by the police, only to face the cameras hours later to denounce the killings of five officers.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — As Air Force One headed for Europe on Thursday afternoon, President Obama holed up in the plane’s office editing a Facebook post meant to express his anguish at two deadly shootings by police officers. Given what had happened, he told his aides, he didn’t think it was enough.

headline: On The Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a co-ops on the Upper East Side and in Chelsea, and a Greenpoint two-family.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a co-ops on the Upper East Side and in Chelsea, and a Greenpoint two-family.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in Chelsea and in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Rowayton, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Westchester Must Hire Consultant for Fair-Housing Study, Judge Rules
abstract: Following disputes over zoning, a federal judge called the county’s efforts to analyze barriers to fair housing a “failed process.”
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ruled that Westchester County must hire a consultant to study barriers to fair housing in communities across one of the richest suburbs in the country.

headline: From All Angles, Eagle Eyes Are Fixing on the All-Star Game
abstract: With home-field advantage in the World Series at stake, the teams’ vigilant replay monitors will endeavor to make sure that close calls go their way.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — If anybody appreciates the value of video replay, it is Yankees second baseman Starlin Castro. Two calls involving Castro on Thursday night — his slide into home plate with the go-ahead run and a madcap groundout for the final out — were reversed in his favor as the Yankees hung on to beat Cleveland, 5-4.

headline: My Protests and Prayers in Dallas
abstract: “Enough is enough,” we chanted. But then five more people were killed.
lead_paragraph: Dallas — On Friday, the city of Dallas was in mourning, and so was I.

headline: It May Cause Sparks to Fly
abstract: A Saturday puzzle by Josh Knapp.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Josh Knapp is primarily a late-week constructor, and he’s back today with a crunchy, lively Saturday puzzle.

headline: Bad Guys Win if the Police Reject Protests
abstract: If a police department has built mutual respect with the community, a fanatic’s attack shouldn’t shake it.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY night in Dallas, a calm and peaceful protest was shattered by a brutal precision attack against officers at the scene. Just moments before, some of those same officers had been amiably chatting with young families and others in the diverse group of demonstrators.

headline: Bartolo Colon Heads to Fourth All-Star Game as Madison Bumgarner’s Replacement
abstract: With Bumgarner scheduled to pitch Sunday, National League Manager Terry Collins turned to one of his own, the Mets’ 19-year veteran Colon, who said the honor “means a lot.”
lead_paragraph: Bartolo Colon was selected by Terry Collins, the National League’s manager in Tuesday’s All-Star Game, to replace Madison Bumgarner on the roster. Bumgarner was to pitch for the San Francisco Giants on Sunday.

headline: New York Senate to Hold Hearings on Hoosick Falls’s Tainted Water
abstract: The hearings would take place in August to address the water supply in the upstate village, where municipal wells are polluted with the toxic chemical PFOA.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Amid rising pressure to investigate the causes and consequences of one of the state’s worst recent environmental crises, the New York Senate announced on Friday that it would hold hearings next month on the polluted water in Hoosick Falls.

headline: Long Lines at Airports? You Ain’t Seen Nothing Yet
abstract: Security delays are only the most visible sign of the budgetary con game that is hobbling the federal government
lead_paragraph: WE’VE all seen the long summer lines at airport security checkpoints full of angry travelers. But many of us haven’t heard the real reason: funding for the Transportation Security Administration has been sliced by 8.5 percent over the past five years, leading to a 5.5 percent drop in the number of screeners. At the same time, the number of travelers has increased by more than 15 percent.

headline: How Mrs. Clinton Would Pay Tuition Bills
abstract: Her new college plan is a good outline but not a full solution.
lead_paragraph: The cost of college is choking off opportunity in the United States, preventing some young people from getting an education and leaving others struggling to pay off their debt. Eager to woo young voters who cheered the proposal by Bernie Sanders for tuition-free public colleges, Hillary Clinton unveiled a similar initiative this week.

headline: Giving the Economy the Help It Needs
abstract: This election season, people will have a chance to choose leaders who recognize that aggressive fiscal policy can help ensure a full recovery.
lead_paragraph: Solid job growth in June, reported on Friday, provided welcome proof that the alarming performance in May was a fluke. But one month of solid growth is not good enough.

headline: Roger Ailes, Arguing Gretchen Carlson Breached Contract, Presses for Arbitration
abstract: The Fox News chairman’s legal team says the former anchor’s contract included a confidentiality agreement.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Fox News chairman Roger Ailes filed a motion on Friday arguing that the sexual harassment lawsuit filed against him by a former anchor, Gretchen Carlson, should be moved from a New Jersey Superior Court into federal court and submitted for arbitration.

headline: Indians Knock the Shine Off a Promising Yankees Rookie
abstract: Starter Chad Green, vying to join the Yankees’ rotation, followed up a solid start in San Diego by giving up three home runs in the first inning as Cleveland won in a rout.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The memory of the rookie Chad Green’s impressive start in San Diego on Sunday did not last long. The first batter Green faced on Friday, Carlos Santana, hit a home run to right field. So did the next batter, Jason Kipnis. A few hitters later, Lonnie Chisenhall belted yet another.

headline: Shooting Protest in New York
abstract: About 250 demonstrators gathered for a rally at Union Square in Manhattan on Friday night. A smaller group marched through the East Village and Chelsea, then to Grand Central Terminal and Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: About 250 demonstrators gathered for a rally at Union Square in Manhattan on Friday night. A smaller group marched through the East Village and Chelsea, then to Grand Central Terminal and Columbus Circle.

headline: Abdul Sattar Edhi, Pakistan’s ‘Father Teresa,’ Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Edhi set up a foundation that runs nursing homes, orphanages, soup kitchens and family planning centers — all free of charge — as well as Pakistan’s largest ambulance service.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Abdul Sattar Edhi, the Pakistani philanthropist whose name became synonymous with charitable causes and who achieved an almost saintly status in Pakistan, died on Friday in the southern port city of Karachi. He was 88.

headline: The Mets Lose Noah Syndergaard, Yoenis Cespedes and the Game
abstract: Two of the Mets’ key players left the game with injuries as the Nationals won at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard’s first pitch Friday against the Washington Nationals was a 99-mile-per-hour fastball, typical for the Mets’ fireballing right-hander. But by the fifth inning, Syndergaard’s velocity had dropped to 91 m.p.h., and his concerned teammates watched an unnerving scene unfold.

headline: Larry Brown, 75, Is Stepping Down at S.M.U.
abstract: Brown ends a four-year run during which the Mustangs made the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1993 and then were barred from postseason play last season.
lead_paragraph: Larry Brown is leaving Southern Methodist after turning down a contract extension, ending a four-year run during which the Mustangs made the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1993 and then were barred from postseason play last season.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 9, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “There are no words to describe the atrocity that occurred to our city. All I know is that this must stop, this divisiveness between our police and our citizens.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Angelina Jolie Pitt dares you to watch her and her husband, Brad Pitt, as they watch others in “By the Sea.” And Johnny Depp impersonates a crime boss.
lead_paragraph: Angelina Jolie Pitt dares you to watch her and her husband, Brad Pitt, as they watch others in “By the Sea,” her voyeuristic take on the classic art house film. Catch up on “Mr. Robot” before the new season begins on Wednesday. And Johnny Depp does his best Whitey Bulger impersonation in “Black Mass.”

headline: Corrections: July 9, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, July 9, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: ‘I’m Tired of Having to Argue My Humanity to You’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate the shootings in Dallas, Minnesota and Louisiana, as well as Hillary Clinton’s emails and Kevin Durant’s loyalty.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Dick Morris Takes Aim at Hillary Clinton From a Tabloid Perch
abstract: Dick Morris was close with the Clintons before that toe-sucking scandal in ’96. Now he’s working for the media company that brought him down.
lead_paragraph: There are so many ways a supermarket tabloid could trumpet this.

headline: Audra McDonald and Zachary Quinto on Public, and Private, Drama
abstract: The actors discuss the childhood difficulties that drew them to the craft, their shared commitment to young people at risk, and more.
lead_paragraph: “Not to be dramatic,” said Audra McDonald, fluttering her hands around her face in a comic pantomime of theatricality, “But it is our work.” She had just tracked whether a tornado watch that was in effect in New York City posed any threat to her teenage daughter, enrolled in a summer program in Connecticut.

headline: 88 Keys to Her Future
abstract: A Chinese couple push their daughter to study piano with the aim of giving her financial security and a safe career.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese couple push their daughter to study piano with the aim of giving her financial security and a safe career.

headline: Steinway’s Grand Ambitions for Its Pianos in China
abstract: To breathe new life into its sales, the celebrated piano maker is promoting its instruments to China’s growing middle class both as a status symbol and an investment.
lead_paragraph: NINGBO, China — Dozens of girls in tiaras and boys in tuxedos who dreamed of becoming China’s next musical sensation stared at the beast onstage. At nine feet long and nearly 1,000 pounds, with a steely black sheen and a price of more than $200,000, the Steinway & Sons D-274 concert grand piano seemed designed to intimidate.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the streets of Baton Rouge to the island nation of Kiribati.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the streets of Baton Rouge to the island nation of Kiribati.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: America Can Fix Its Student Loan Crisis. Just Ask Australia.
abstract: Other countries offer plans that give students more time to repay loans or that make provisions for fluctuating earnings, so fewer borrowers default.
lead_paragraph: Americans owe $1.3 trillion in student loans. More than seven million borrowers are in default, and millions more are behind on their payments.

headline: Sydney H. Schanberg Dies at 82; Times Reporter Chronicled Khmer Rouge Terror
abstract: Mr. Schanberg won a Pulitzer Prize for covering the fall of the Lon Nol regime to the Khmer Rouge in 1970s Cambodia. His account of a colleague’s survival during the genocide of millions inspired the film “The Killing Fields.”
lead_paragraph: Sydney H. Schanberg, a correspondent for The New York Times who won a Pulitzer Prize for covering Cambodia’s fall to the Khmer Rouge in 1975 and inspired the film “The Killing Fields” with the story of his Cambodian colleague’s survival during the genocide of millions, died on Saturday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Snapchat Old Hat? Oh, and Theranos
abstract: This week, the two entertain doubts on the future of Theranos, and on the suspiciously public canoodling of Taylor Swift and Tom Hiddleston.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Sydney H. Schanberg’s Pulitzer-Winning Coverage of Cambodia’s Fall
abstract: Mr. Schanberg shared his Pulitzer prize with Dith Pran, his assistant.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Schanberg shared his Pulitzer prize with Dith Pran, his assistant.

headline: Micah Johnson, Gunman in Dallas, Honed Military Skills to a Deadly Conclusion
abstract: Mr. Johnson, who killed five police officers, wrote about a combat tactic known as “shoot and move” and rehearsed in his backyard, officials said.
lead_paragraph: GARLAND, Tex. — There was a time when he was known as a well-mannered young man — a regular at his church and a pleasant presence on a tree-lined, suburban, multicultural street in a neighborhood called Camelot. He grew up to serve his country in Afghanistan.

headline: Plan to Remodel? Get Everything in Writing.
abstract: The importance of a contract; co-op rules for renting; and uncovering bedbug history.
lead_paragraph: We are planning to have the kitchen and bathroom of our condo renovated this summer and have found a contractor we would like to hire. But the only “contract” from the contractor consisted of some language about payment at the end of his estimate. I would like to draw up a formal contract to protect our down payment, the building and us. I could cobble together something from online sample forms, but I wonder if it is necessary to engage a lawyer. I would rather not invest the time and money, and potentially alienate our contractor from the beginning, but I want to be protected.

headline: Serena Williams Wins Wimbledon, Tying Record for Grand Slam Singles Titles
abstract: Williams not only matched Steffi Graf’s number of major championships, but also avenged a loss to Angelique Kerber at the Australian Open final this year.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — On the first point of the women’s final at Wimbledon on Saturday, Angelique Kerber ended a rally with a forehand winner down the line.

headline: Iran, Once Quiet About Its Casualties in Syria and Iraq, Now Glorifies Them
abstract: The reason for the change, analysts say, is not rooted in newfound dedication to transparency, but in a desire to sustain Iranian support for Syria’s government.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The first news report, to a nation usually kept in the dark about military matters, was shocking: 13 Iranian soldiers, all with links to the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, had been killed in an ambush near the Syrian city of Aleppo. What followed this spring may have been even more surprising. Details about the soldiers appeared extensively in the Iranian news media, which not only gave the names of the dead but lionized them with sweeping life stories. Poster-size portraits were plastered all over their hometowns.

headline: Childless Women to Marketers: We Buy Things Too
abstract: Some women without children, a growing demographic in the United States, are pressing for marketing campaigns that don’t treat them like mothers.
lead_paragraph: Even as advertisers are embracing new configurations of families — two dads, say, or grandparents raising grandchildren — there’s one group that feels left out.

headline: Where U.N. Once Deliberated, Sage Counsel From Elmo and Grover
abstract: Hain Celestial Group occupies space in Lake Success, N.Y., that once housed Sperry Gyroscope Company and the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: General Assembly and gyroscopes

headline: At the Grand Canyon, a Mechanic’s Love Affair With Locomotives
abstract: Eric Hadder turned a childhood fascination with trains into a career maintaining a vegetable-oil-powered steam engine for the Grand Canyon Railway.
lead_paragraph: Eric Hadder, 43, is chief mechanical officer at the Grand Canyon Railway in Williams, Ariz.

headline: Contest for British Premier Flares Over Claims on Motherhood
abstract: One contender seemed to suggest in a newspaper interview that being a mother would make her a better leader than her rival, who does not have children.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A dispute erupted Saturday in the contest between the two women vying to become Britain’s next prime minister after one of them seemed to suggest in a newspaper interview that being a mother would make her a better leader than her rival, who does not have children.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer us a tough acrostic this weekend.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Wow, this was a tough one for me. It just goes to show you how important it is to develop a broad solving wheelhouse. I am not a learned person when it comes to baseball, and it showed in my solve. My only gimmes were HIGH FIVES, RETRIEVER and FOMENT, which is a great word.

headline: Redfin Shies Away From the Typical Start-Up’s Gig Economy
abstract: Redfin, a Seattle company that considers itself a real estate and tech company, has challenged the conventions of both by hiring full-time agents.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Glenn Kelman became the chief executive of his online real estate start-up, he defied the tech industry’s conventional wisdom about how to grow.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo, Quiet Superstar, Can Win Portugal’s Heart With Euros Title
abstract: Ronaldo has had years of success at Real Madrid but still seeks his first major title for Portugal, which faces France in the European Championships final on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cristiano Ronaldo spends a lot of time alone. Alone on the wing, alone in his kitchen, alone in his thoughts, where, by his own admission, much of his focus is on whether he will again win the Ballon d’Or award — the world player-of-the-year honor, which, of course, is for a single, solitary superstar.

headline: In Week of Emotional Swings, Police Face a Dual Role: Villain and Victim
abstract: After the killing of five of their colleagues in Dallas amid protests over the latest fatal police shootings caught on video, officers in New York and elsewhere reflected on what their job is like now.
lead_paragraph: Police barricades wrapped around the headquarters at One Police Plaza and other department buildings in New York. Many cities issued new marching orders: no solo patrols. No officers should be alone.

headline: Dozens Reported Dead in South Sudan Capital After Rival Forces Battle
abstract: Heavy exchanges of gunfire rolled across neighborhoods of Juba, with unconfirmed reports that up to 150 people were killed.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Fighting between competing factions of South Sudan’s government in its capital left the world’s youngest country teetering on Saturday, the fifth anniversary of its independence. The government reported dozens of casualties, and there were unconfirmed reports that up to 150 people had been killed.

headline: Women Carry Golf’s Torch Where Men Are Reluctant to Go
