abstract: Many female golfers are enthusiastic about the chance to play at the Olympics, an opportunity met with a yawn by the men.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — On the way to claim her luggage at San Jose International Airport, Gerina Piller passed signs welcoming the gymnasts vying for spots last week on the team that will compete for the United States at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Piller has her sights set on becoming an Olympian by weekend’s end, though she was not in town for the gymnastics trials.

headline: Obama on Dallas: No Reprise of ’60s Racial Strife
abstract: “When we start suggesting that somehow there is this enormous polarization and we’re back to the situation in the 1960s — that’s just not true,” President Obama said.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama expressed optimism on Saturday that the killings of young black men and white police officers this week have not left the United States as racially divided as it was during the strife and riots that racked the country in the 1960s.

headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Struggle to Be Unifying Voice for Nation
abstract: The violence of the past week cried out more for a unifying candidate and revealed how hard it is for Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton to become that person.
lead_paragraph: No moment in the 2016 presidential campaign has cried out more for a unifying candidate than the police shootings of two black men last week and the ensuing national uproar, followed by the shocking sniper ambush that killed five police officers in Dallas.

headline: Deep-Pocketed N.B.A. Has Short Arms When Offering a Hand Up
abstract: A financial windfall has enriched even the most middling of N.B.A. players while those in the N.B.A. Development League play for paltry sums.
lead_paragraph: Now that some of the N.B.A.’s middling (or worse) players are among the richest athletes in professional team sports, the league should summon its inner Bernie Sanders and spare some comparative loose change for its most impoverished.

headline: A Struggle for Common Ground, Amid Fears of a National Fracture
abstract: People in interviews across the United States said the nation increasingly felt mired in bloodshed and blame, and was fracturing along racial and ideological lines.
lead_paragraph: Long after her two sons were in bed, Shanel Berry kept vigil in front of the television at her home in Waterloo, Iowa, watching the week’s horror unfurl and obsessing over a single question: Was the gunman who killed five Dallas police officers black?

headline: Kevin Durant Was N.B.A.’s Ultimate Prize, With Participation Trophies Galore
abstract: The Golden State Warriors won free agency by signing the coveted Kevin Durant, while the Nets, Knicks and Bulls were forced to take risks.
lead_paragraph: In the first week of the N.B.A.’s annual free-agent spending spree, billions of dollars were committed to dozens of players. The players themselves announced some deals, and others were leaked to the news media, but because of the unique nature of business in the N.B.A., nothing could be completed or confirmed by teams until seven days into the process. Now that the dust has settled, some teams have gotten stronger, some took serious risks and yet others left fans scratching their heads.

headline: Steven Wright Snagged an All-Star Spot by a Fingertip
abstract: Once a middling pitching prospect for the Indians, Wright reinvented himself as a knuckleballer who made his first All-Star team with the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox were stumbling in the summer of 2012, on their way to a last-place finish in the American League East. While contenders acted boldly before the trading deadline, snagging Zack Greinke, Hunter Pence, Hanley Ramirez, Ichiro Suzuki and other stars, the Red Sox made a more subtle transaction: They shipped a fading first-base prospect, Lars Anderson, to the Cleveland Indians for a Class AAA knuckleballer named Steven Wright.

headline: Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Trump, or None of the Above
abstract: In this year of political animosity, more voters say they are undecided because they dislike both candidates.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Hillary Clinton is ahead of Donald Trump by an average of five percentage points nationally, recent polls suggest. But both campaigns — just like all campaigns in earlier years — are hoping and praying that “independent” and “undecided” voters (who aren’t necessarily the same) can be persuaded to swing their way.

headline: Can Sanctions Make North Korea Budge?
abstract: Enforcement is crucial; so is a strategy beyond punishment.
lead_paragraph: The new American sanctions on North Korea are hardly surprising, since the regime brutally controls 25 million people, has an aggressive nuclear program and is improving its ability to launch missiles that could one day hit the United States. The question is: Are these sanctions connected to a strategy beyond punishment?

headline: Solving All the Wrong Problems
abstract: Do we really need an app that lets us brew our coffee from anywhere?
lead_paragraph: Every day, innovative companies promise to make the world a better place. Are they succeeding?

headline: Want to Attract More Readers? Try Listening to Them
abstract: Journalists traditionally liked to have an arm’s-length relationship with readers. But that’s no longer good for business. Or for journalism.
lead_paragraph: MOST journalists I’ve worked with have a reflexive aversion to interacting with readers. They subscribe to the view that editors and reporters have the most cultivated sense of which stories are most important, and which subjects most worthy of attention. Expecting them to consider the opinions of readers when making such journalistic decisions would be akin to asking an artist to produce a masterwork to accommodate the taste of a benefactor.

headline: How to Get Paid to Do Nothing
abstract: If the rat race is getting too much, then consider a career in “queuing.”
lead_paragraph: London — ITALIAN bureaucracy is legendary for a reason. Italians spend so much of their lives waiting in line — an estimated 400 hours a year per person — that some are now willing to pay freelancers to wait on their behalf. The rich can pay a “codista,” a neologism for a trained line sitter, to maunder at the post office or bank while they get on with something more important.

headline: Is the Islamic State Unstoppable?
abstract: Attacks in Iraq, Turkey and Bangladesh show that the group’s tactics may change but its goals remain the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — BEFORE Fayad Tayih abandoned the Islamic State earlier this month, he detected a striking trend: More people inside the self-declared caliphate were signing up to become suicide bombers. Mr. Tayih had been working in an administrative job for the jihadist group in Deir al-Zour, in eastern Syria, at the time. “Those who were working with me noticed the same thing,” he told me over Wickr, an encrypted messaging app.

headline: Why the E.U. Had It Coming
abstract: Frustration with the European Union has been building for decades.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — I WAS not surprised by the Brexit vote. Only by those who were surprised. Hadn’t the opinion polls showed the two sides neck and neck for weeks? Haven’t the British been talking about this for decades?

headline: The Clinton Contamination
abstract: They were careless people, Bill and Hillary, they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT says a lot about our relationship with Hillary Clinton that she seems well on her way to becoming Madam President because she’s not getting indicted.

headline: Are We Unraveling?
abstract: Echoes of the late 1960s and the 1970s in the latest spasm of violence.
lead_paragraph: THE center is not holding.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Worst Ally
abstract: The only president he’ll have more trouble working with than Hillary Clinton is Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: WHATEVER drama plays out when Republicans meet in Cleveland next week to nominate their party’s presidential candidate, the most consequential story line might well be the nationally televised debut of the awkward political partnership between Donald J. Trump, the presumptive nominee, and House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, the highest-ranking elected Republican and thus chairman of the convention. But it offers just a sample of the spectacles sure to ensue between them should Mr. Trump become president.

headline: The Secret Rules of the Drone War
abstract: Without more detailed information, it is impossible to know whether the Obama administration is following its own rules.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, the Obama administration revealed its estimate of the number of civilians killed since 2009 in counterterrorism airstrikes outside of Iraq, Afghanistan and Syria. In a three-page report that offered little insight into the government’s secretive drone campaign, officials said they had concluded that between 64 and 116 civilians died in 473 strikes.

headline: Silicon Valley-Driven Hype for Self-Driving Cars
abstract: The excitement over autonomous driving ignores the many potholes along the way.
lead_paragraph: BECAUSE of reports that he may have been watching a Harry Potter movie at the time, Joshua Brown, the Tesla owner killed in the self-driving car industry’s first known fatal accident, has come to be regarded as a reckless contributor to his own sad fate.

headline: Get the Epidural
abstract: “Natural” sounds so relaxing. So earth goddess. But how often do people really want women to do anything “natural”?
lead_paragraph: I AM seven months pregnant and standing in line at a grocery store in Brooklyn, minding my own business (as much as anyone pregnant can mind her own business, because people constantly feel as if they have the right to talk to pregnant women about their pregnancy). A woman in front of me turns around. She’s a little younger than me. She does not appear pregnant. She is not with kids. Maybe she has kids at home. It doesn’t really matter.

headline: If a Carrot for Jordan Works, Syrian Refugees Will Stay Put
abstract: Jordan agreed to take in thousands of Syrian refugees in return for giant interest-free loans from the World Bank. But is it robbing Peter to pay Paul?
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — On a busy thoroughfare in Amman, Jordan’s capital, a coffee seller named Mohammed Al Mulki no longer shivers when he sees a police car pull up. At a nearby sweet shop, the counterman, Zuheir Taleb, no longer slips out of the back when a uniformed official walks in.

headline: Protectionism: A Fleeting Promise
abstract: Readers respond to “A More Efficient World That People May Not Want” (July 1).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paying Lawyers to Learn
abstract: Readers respond to “Time Doesn’t Heal Wounds of Bad Loans” (June 17).

headline: Message in a Buyback
abstract: Readers respond to “Buyback Surge May Signal Danger, Not Growth” (June 26).

headline: Academia’s Tilt to the Left
abstract: Why do professors, especially in New England, tend to be liberal? Does it affect their teaching? As one reader asks, is there a “left-wing geology”?
lead_paragraph: Why do professors, especially in New England, tend to be liberal? Does it affect their teaching?

headline: Hillary Clinton Emphasizes Her Time on the World Stage
abstract: Foreign policy experience provides stark contrasts with Donald J. Trump, and Mrs. Clinton’s campaign believes two new ads stressing that point will sting.
lead_paragraph: After opening her general election advertising campaign focusing on her record of working with families and children, Hillary Clinton has pivoted to foreign policy, releasing two new ads criticizing Donald J. Trump’s lack of experience.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Learns Patience, the Power Hitter’s Virtue
abstract: Cespedes and other hitters who occupy the middle of major-league lineups have seen their home run totals rise as they draw more walks.
lead_paragraph: Yoenis Cespedes will always be remembered in Mets lore for the torrid hitting and powerful bat that carried the team to a National League East title in the second half of last season. He finished the year with a .291 batting average, .870 on-base-plus-slugging percentage and 35 home runs, 17 of them coming over the final two months with the Mets.

headline: Public Schools? To Kansas Conservatives, They’re ‘Government Schools’
abstract: Even some Republicans are worried that the use of the term portends less support for public education.
lead_paragraph: LEAWOOD, Kansas — Erica Massman, a moderate Kansas Republican, refers to the building where her daughter attends fourth grade as a public school.

headline: Indian Forces Kill 10 During Kashmir Protests Over Separatist’s Death
abstract: Protesters attacked more than 70 government offices and police posts in parts of Kashmir, including Srinagar, the main city, setting fire to some structures.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian police officers killed at least 10 people on Saturday when they fired on protesters in Kashmir, where thousands defied a curfew to attend a prayer service for a top separatist militant killed by Indian forces a day earlier.

headline: Carl Haas, Builder of a Formidable IndyCar Racing Team, Dies at 87
abstract: After a driving career in the 1950s, Mr. Haas worked with Paul Newman to operate a racing team that won more than 100 IndyCar races.
lead_paragraph: Carl Haas, an auto racing entrepreneur best known for his ownership, with the actor Paul Newman, of a racing team that won more than 100 IndyCar races, died on June 29 at his home near Chicago.

headline: Americans Gather at Vigils and Protests
abstract: In the aftermath of shootings in Minnesota, Louisiana and Texas, people across the country gathered to remember victims as well as protest police shootings.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of shootings in Minnesota, Louisiana and Texas, people across the country gathered to remember victims as well as protest police shootings.

headline: Driven by Data, Pros and Joes Alike Vie for Cycling Crowns
abstract: A social media site that started out catering to weekend warriors now counts some of the top professional riders among its users.
lead_paragraph: L’ISLE JOURDAIN, France — The Tour de France pours out pages of standings every day. Not just the daily and overall rankings, but also a variety of secondary competitions for skills like climbing and sprinting.

headline: Obama Tells NATO That ‘Europe Can Count On’ the U.S.
abstract: The president assured alliance partners that threats from terrorism and an aggressive Russia would not deter the United States.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama, acknowledging that the trans-Atlantic alliance faces an unprecedented array of threats from terrorism, migrant flows and an aggressive Russia, said on Saturday that “in good times and in bad, Europe can count on the United States — always.”

headline: Lenny Dykstra Crawls from a Hole He Joyfully Dug for Himself
abstract: The former Met’s new autobiography is a swaggering salute to a steroid-fueled career of exceptional excess.
lead_paragraph: In his new autobiography, “House of Nails: A Memoir of Life on the Edge,” Lenny Dykstra emerges as a figure of enormous braggadocio who moves swiftly from roguish to Trumpian. He can hardly stop admiring his hitting skills, his houses, his private jets, his magazine for wealthy athletes and his epiphany that steroids would help sate his craving to make millions of dollars after the Mets traded him to the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Chris Froome Grabs Tour de France Lead With a Wobbly, High-Speed Descent
abstract: The defending champion combined his climbing and descent skills to win the race’s eighth stage and acquire the leader’s yellow jersey.
lead_paragraph: BAGNÈRES de LUCHON, France — Chris Froome, the defending Tour de France champion, is known for his ability to climb mountains swiftly and race against the stopwatch in time trials with similar speed.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Anti-Abortion Group Presses Ahead Despite Recent Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: Although Texas’ abortion clinic restrictions were overturned, the leaders of the National Right to Life Committee are redoubling their efforts on the “humanity of the unborn child.”
lead_paragraph: HERNDON, Va. — Stung by the recent Supreme Court decision that overturned Texas abortion clinic restrictions, leaders of the country’s largest anti-abortion group are redoubling their efforts for restrictions on abortion that they claim will prevent fetal pain and that they believe can fare well in the public eye and, they hope, in the courts.

headline: Serena Williams Digs Deep to Win Way More Than Just One More
abstract: In 2012, Williams was trying to win just one more major title. In a stunning late-career resurgence, she has won nine majors since.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Back at Wimbledon in 2012, Serena Williams and her new, not yet official coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, had a discussion at the All England Club.

headline: Bernie Sanders Allies Lose a Fight Over Democrats’ Stance on Trade
abstract: The party’s platform committee rejected a push to oppose a congressional vote on the Trans-Pacific Partnership deal, which President Obama supports.
lead_paragraph: Amid boos from the sidelines, allies of Hillary Clinton and President Obama on Saturday beat back an effort by the Bernie Sanders campaign to have the Democratic Party officially oppose a congressional vote on the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.

headline: Minnesota Officer Was ‘Reacting to the Presence of a Gun,’ Lawyer Says
abstract: The comments from the lawyer provided the fullest accounting yet of Officer Jeronimo Yanez’s version of the death of Philando Castile.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANTHONY, Minn. — A lawyer for the suburban police officer who fatally shot a black man during a traffic stop said on Saturday that the race of the driver, Philando Castile, played no role in how his client responded, and that the officer “was reacting to the presence of a gun” when he opened fire.

headline: Teenagers in Japan Can Finally Vote. But Will They?
abstract: In a nation whose politics are dominated by older voters, apathy threatens to dilute the power of newly enfranchised 18- and 19-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Mena Hakamada, an 18-year-old college freshman, knows how important it is to vote.

headline: Major League Baseball Continues to Churn Out Statistics That Delight
abstract: As the All-Star Break approaches, a look at the strange and surprising statistics so far in baseball.
lead_paragraph: April 4-6, Colorado at Arizona; April 8 and April 10, Colorado vs. San Diego

headline: Black Lives Matter Was Gaining Ground. Then a Sniper Opened Fire.
abstract: The group faces perhaps the biggest crisis in its short history, as it scrambles to distance itself from the Dallas gunman and tries to rebut a chorus of detractors.
lead_paragraph: It felt like a watershed moment for a scattered and still-young civil rights movement.

headline: In the Turmoil Over Race and Policing, Children Pay a Steep Emotional Price
abstract: Young people are reeling from their losses and harboring pent-up depression that often comes pouring out in panic attacks and breakdowns, relatives say.
lead_paragraph: In the past week alone, there was the 4-year-old girl in Falcon Heights, Minn., who was captured on video consoling her mother after they watched a police officer shoot the mother’s boyfriend through the window of a car. And there was the 15-year-old boy in Baton Rouge, La., who sobbed uncontrollably in front of television cameras after the similar shooting death of his father.

headline: Double Quote
abstract: Patrick Berry makes our eyes cross.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — No, you’re not seeing things. O.K., maybe you are. Patrick Berry is back, and he is giving everyone a case of double vision.

headline: Inside China’s Secret 23-Day Detention of a Foreign Nonprofit Chief
abstract: The group that Peter Dahlin, a Swede, helped found is the type of organization that President Xi Jinping has said is undermining the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: CHIANG MAI, Thailand — On the 10th day of Peter Dahlin’s captivity in a secret Beijing jail, Chinese state security officers sprang one of their big surprises — something he found even more astonishing than hearing a colleague being beaten in a room above his cell.

headline: Marie Colvin Wrongful-Death Complaint
abstract: This wrongful death lawsuit was filed on behalf of the journalist Marie Colvin’s sister, Cathleen Colvin, and other surviving family members. The suit claims that Ms. Colvin, who was was killed on February 22, 2012, was intentionally targeted by Syrian forces.
lead_paragraph: This wrongful death lawsuit was filed on behalf of the journalist Marie Colvin’s sister, Cathleen Colvin, and other surviving family members. The suit claims that Ms. Colvin, who was was killed on February 22, 2012, was intentionally targeted by Syrian forces.

headline: Family of Marie Colvin, Slain U.S. Journalist, Sues Syria
abstract: The complaint contends that Syrian officials worked in concert to locate, track and target journalists like Ms. Colvin, who was killed in an artillery strike in 2012.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Relatives of Marie Colvin, a veteran American war reporter who died more than four years ago in an artillery barrage in Syria, have filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the Syrian government, accusing it of targeting and killing her as part of a systematic strategy to silence civilian journalists and activists covering the war.

headline: Wimbledon Brings a New, Inclusive Tradition to Its Exclusive Grass
abstract: Wimbledon had been reluctant to include wheelchair tennis singles because the soft, slick grass was considered prohibitive to play. For the players, the unknowns proved challenging, but worth it.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon, a place of hallowed tradition that dates to 1877, was this year both a straggler and a pioneer, introducing into the tournament wheelchair singles matches, a format that has been a fully fledged Paralympic sport since 1992 but had never before been played on grass.

headline: Raid on Indonesian Food Stall Prompts Fears of Fundamentalism
abstract: While the case has become a symbol of what some see as “creeping Islamization,” others insisted that the country was not becoming more religious.
lead_paragraph: SERANG, Indonesia — Lying on the floor against a gym bag full of clothes in a two-room shack in the West Java town of Serang, Saeni tried to explain how her life had been turned upside down, but she fainted before she could finish.

headline: Review: Garth Brooks Brings Rousing Anthems and Ballads to Yankee Stadium
abstract: Mr. Brooks, the signature country star of the 1990s who has come out of semiretirement, played for more than an hour and a half, including with his wife, Trisha Yearwood.
lead_paragraph: “The cameras are over,” Garth Brooks said late Friday night, speaking conspiratorially to the tens of thousands of people who had come to Yankee Stadium to see him. “Now it’s just you and me.”

headline: U.S. Women Win Olympic Warm-Up Against Backdrop of Wage Dispute
abstract: The friendly was the final match for the Americans before Coach Jill Ellis releases her roster for the Summer Games in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The United States women’s soccer team edged lightly regarded South Africa, 1-0, on Saturday thanks to a first-half goal from Crystal Dunn. Despite the closer-than-expected score before a small crowd at Soldier Field, the Americans were never in danger as goalkeeper Hope Solo collected her 100th career shutout with the national team.

headline: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Returns Home After Heart Surgery in London
abstract: The convalescence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has done nothing to soften the political opposition he faces over the so-called Panama Papers.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif returned to Pakistan on Saturday after an absence of more than a month because of heart surgery in London, but his health problems have not softened the political opposition he faces.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, July 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Growing up, I hated the police. They abused me for no reason. It’s just because I was in the neighborhood and a person of color.”

headline: 2 Are Killed by Bulls in Spain
abstract: A professional matador was killed in the ring in front of spectators, and another man died in a local bull run. Two other men were gored at a popular festival in Pamplona.
lead_paragraph: A professional bullfighter was gored to death and a man was killed in a bull run in Spain on Saturday, while 13 other people were injured at the world-famous running of the bulls in Pamplona, according to news reports and a government website.

headline: Yankees Take Advantage of a Reprieve Against the Indians
abstract: A bizarre play on the basepaths short-circuited a Cleveland rally in the ninth, and the Yankees pulled out a win in extra innings.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Yankees required more than four hours, 16 players, a bizarre play on the basepaths, an exquisitely timed substitution and a handful of nerve-racking escapes on Saturday to come away with a 7-6, 11-inning victory over the Cleveland Indians that left their clubhouse both drained and buoyant.

headline: After ‘Brexit’ Vote, Immigrants Feel a Town Turn Against Them
abstract: Long-simmering anger in Boston, England, has become more explicit and worrisome, including a leaflet asking, “Did you pack your bags yet?”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, England — A few days after Britain voted to leave the European Union, Monika Baginski was in a supermarket, chatting with a friend on the phone in her native Polish, when a man followed her down the aisle. “You foreigner,” Ms. Baginski recalled him saying. “You’ll be out soon.”

headline: Congress’s Look-Good Season: Republicans Pursue Bills to Show Voters
abstract: Party leaders have been eagerly arming members with legislative accomplishments to use in their re-election campaigns back home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Senator Patrick J. Toomey of Pennsylvania, it was a measure to block federal funding to so-called sanctuary cities for immigrants.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2 Finale: I Believe You
abstract: Would you accept Claire’s explanation about time travel and 18th-century Highlander love interests?
lead_paragraph: “Dragonfly in Amber” makes clear that the failings of the second season are undeniable. The first season of “Outlander” deftly melded historical drama, fantasy and romance. It worked because the focus was on Claire and Jamie’s relationship. But this season widened its perspective. The show opened up its world, pushed its visual boundaries and incorporated an even more sprawling cast. But the writing has shortchanged important relationships at nearly every turn in favor of intrigue and political maneuverings.

headline: Justin Gatlin Wins 200-Meter Final at the United States Olympic Trials
abstract: Gatlin finished in 19.75 seconds to qualify for the Rio Games, while Bernard Lagat, 41, claimed the 5,000-meter race and was headed to his fifth Olympics.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Aries Merritt, the 2012 Olympic champion and world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles, who received a transplanted kidney from his sister in September, will not get a chance to defend his gold medal next month at the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Daniel Murphy Hammers the Mets, Who Again Struggle at the Plate
abstract: Murphy, who left the Mets in the off-season, hit a home run and had four R.B.I. in the Nationals’ 6-1 victory on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Murphy loved his time with the Mets. He was drafted by the organization in 2006 and developed into a productive hitter. But even after his spectacular hitting in the 2015 playoffs, the Mets declined to keep him. Questions swirled about his inconsistent defense, his cost and his ability to sustain his improved hitting.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of July 5
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton campaigned in North Carolina, Ohio and New Jersey this week in the shadow of violent events in the country.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton campaigned in North Carolina, Ohio and New Jersey this week in the shadow of violent events in the country.

headline: A Secret Detention in China
abstract: Peter Dahlin, a Swede, was detained by the Chinese authorities and forced to perform a prepared confession on national television. After 23 days of interrogation, he was deported.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dahlin, a Swede, was detained by the Chinese authorities and forced to perform a prepared confession on national television. After 23 days of interrogation, he was deported.

headline: Serbia and Croatia Qualify in Olympic Basketball; One Spot Remains
abstract: The Serbs routed Puerto Rico and the Croats edged Italy in overtime to make the field in Rio de Janeiro. France and Canada will meet in Manila on Sunday, with the winner advancing to Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Serbia and Croatia are headed for Brazil, while France or Canada will claim the final spot in Olympic basketball.

lead_paragraph: Hamsika Chandrasekar and Ramkumar Viswanathan Venkateswaran are to be married on July 10 in Houston. Pandit O. V. Ranganathan is to perform the ceremony at VPSS Haveli, a wedding hall.

lead_paragraph: Lauren Nicole Westbrook and Brian Lee McIntosh were married July 9. The Rev. Jason S. McElwee, an Assemblies of God minister, performed the ceremony at Graham Memorial Chapel, at Washington University in St. Louis. The Rev. Rick Potts, a Roman Catholic priest, gave a blessing.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: In “The Night Of,” a Muslim college student drives a cab to hell. And “Ten” is available to stream in tribute to Abbas Kiarostami, who died on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In “The Night Of,” a Muslim student takes a cab ride to hell and ends up charged with murder. “The Circus: Inside the Greatest Political Show on Earth” returns to parse the presidential race. And “Ten” is available to stream in tribute to the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, who died on Monday.

headline: DeRay Mckesson, Arrested While Protesting in Baton Rouge, Is Released
abstract: Mr. Mckesson, a Black Lives Matter activist, was marching with a group in Louisiana when police officers arrested him and accused him of blocking the road. He was released on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: DeRay Mckesson, one of the best known voices for the Black Lives Matter movement, was among hundreds of people arrested at weekend demonstrations across the country. He spent 16 hours in a Baton Rouge jail cell until he was released Sunday afternoon, vowing to continue demonstrating because he was convinced that the authorities want activists to be “too afraid to protest.”

headline: Story of Philistines Could Be Reshaped by Ancient Cemetery
abstract: Archaeologists in Ashkelon, Israel, said they had found a burial site that could help reveal the origin and lifestyle of a civilization whose history has been written by its enemies.
lead_paragraph: After more than 30 years of excavating the remains of a Philistine city, a team of archaeologists says it believes it has found a cemetery belonging to the ancient people on the outskirts of Ashkelon in Israel.

headline: Malcolm Turnbull Claims Victory in Australia Election After Rival Concedes
abstract: The electoral commission has forecast that Mr. Turnbull’s Liberal Party-led coalition could win a combined 76 seats, which would give it an absolute majority.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — More than a week after one of the closest and longest Australian national elections in half a century, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull declared victory on Sunday after the leader of the opposition Labor Party conceded defeat.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Final Bows in ‘Hamilton’ on Broadway
abstract: Mr. Miranda, who played the title character in the musical, shared his moment with other departing cast members, including Phillipa Soo and Leslie Odom Jr.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s final bows for his farewell performance in “Hamilton” on Saturday night seemed routine, if overly humble for the departure of the show’s star and mastermind. He even shared his bows with the other cast members also exiting the show, including Phillipa Soo and the Tony winner Leslie Odom Jr.

headline: Police and Protesters Clash in Minnesota Capital
abstract: Demonstrations in St. Paul and across the country continued after a series of fatal police shootings of black men.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Police officers in riot gear clashed with protesters who blocked a major highway here for hours on Saturday night, marking a tense turn for the demonstrations that have continued almost nonstop since a black man, Philando Castile, was fatally shot by a suburban police officer during a traffic stop on Wednesday.

headline: Dallas, Euro 2016, Wimbledon: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Donald Trump Keeps Distance in G.O.P. Platform Fight on Gay Rights
abstract: A contentious debate between conservatives and moderates has left Mr. Trump mainly on the sidelines, but offering assurances to both sides.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Same-sex marriage and transgender rights are emerging as points of serious strain between social conservatives and moderates who are trying to shape the Republican platform, reviving a festering cultural dispute as thousands of party activists and delegates prepare for their convention.

headline: Cambodian Opposition Figure’s Killing Recalls Darker Times
abstract: Kem Ley, a prominent commentator who recently helped found a political party, was gunned down Sunday at a gas station in the capital.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — A prominent Cambodian political commentator who had recently helped found a new independent political party was gunned down at a gas station in central Phnom Penh on Sunday morning in what analysts called a major setback for democracy and freedom of expression in the country.

headline: Juba Gripped by Renewed Violence as Factions Clash in South Sudan
abstract: Armed battles and waves of gunfire spread across the capital a day after the fifth anniversary of the nation’s independence.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Armed clashes between two factions and waves of heavy gunfire spread across South Sudan’s capital on Sunday, a day after the nation’s fifth anniversary of its independence.

headline: Marie Colvin Wrongful-Death Complaint
abstract: This wrongful death lawsuit was filed on behalf of the journalist Marie Colvin’s sister, Cathleen Colvin, and other surviving family members. The suit claims that Ms. Colvin, who was was killed on February 22, 2012, was intentionally targeted by Syrian forces.
lead_paragraph: This wrongful death lawsuit was filed on behalf of the journalist Marie Colvin’s sister, Cathleen Colvin, and other surviving family members. The suit claims that Ms. Colvin, who was was killed on February 22, 2012, was intentionally targeted by Syrian forces.

headline: Philippines v. China: Q. and A. on South China Sea Case
abstract: An international tribunal released a landmark decision on Beijing’s claim to sovereignty over 90 percent of the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: An international tribunal in The Hague released a landmark decision on Tuesday in a dispute between China and the Philippines over  the South China Sea. Here are answers to six questions about the case.

headline: President Obama Urges Mutual Respect From Protesters and Police
abstract: Mr. Obama implored both sides to avoid inflammatory words and actions as protests against police shootings ramped up across the country over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — President Obama on Sunday urged those protesting the recent shootings of black men by police officers to avoid inflammatory words and actions, which he said would worsen tensions and set back their cause.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make some blueberry pie tonight, then have it with a cup of coffee in the morning.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Japan Vote Strengthens Shinzo Abe’s Goal to Change Constitution
abstract: Whether Prime Minister Abe will be able to pursue his ambition of overturning the clause that calls for the complete renunciation of war remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Voters helped Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan move closer on Sunday to securing the lawmaker support he needs to revise a pacifist Constitution that has been in place since American occupiers created it in 1947.

headline: After 31 Lonely Years, a Sculpture in East Harlem Will Have Company
abstract: “Growth,” a metal work by Jorge Luis Rodriguez, has been alone in Harlem Art Park since it was installed in 1985. Now, more artists are bringing their work to the space.
lead_paragraph: It took three decades, but Jorge Luis Rodriguez is finally savoring the full flowering of a seed he planted in an East Harlem park.

headline: In U.S. Presidential Election, the Young and the Old Are Crucial
abstract: Can Hillary Clinton foster the enthusiasm that President Obama did with young voters? And can Donald J. Trump convince older voters that he’s not a big risk?
lead_paragraph: Years ago, the conservative activist Grover Norquist was the guest speaker in a class I teach at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Andy Murray Beats Milos Raonic to Win Second Wimbledon Title
abstract: Murray, who was runner-up at the year’s first two majors, delighted the home crowd by capturing his third Grand Slam championship.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A three-year drought can surely not generate the same sort of anxiety as a 77-year drought.

headline: Egyptian Minister Visits Israel in Push for Peace With Palestinians
abstract: In the first such high-level visit in nearly a decade, Sameh Shoukry, Egypt’s foreign minister, arrived in Israel to help rejuvenate the moribund peace process.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Egypt’s foreign minister arrived in Israel on Sunday — the first such high-level visit in nearly a decade — saying that he had come to promote the “vision” of his boss, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, to help rejuvenate the moribund peace process between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

headline: Charging Document for DeRay McKesson
abstract: DeRay McKesson, a national voice for the Black Lives Matter movement, was among scores of people arrested at demonstrations across the country late Saturday, as protesters expressed anger over the shootings of two black men by police officers last week. Mr. McKesson was taken into custody during a march in Baton Rouge, La.
lead_paragraph: DeRay McKesson, a national voice for the Black Lives Matter movement, was among scores of people arrested at demonstrations across the country late Saturday, as protesters expressed anger over the shootings of two black men by police officers last week. Mr. McKesson was taken into custody during a march in Baton Rouge, La.

headline: Dallas Gunman Had Plans for Wider Attack, Police Say
abstract: Micah Johnson had practiced explosive detonations, the city’s police chief said, providing new details of how Mr. Johnson sang, laughed and taunted officers during negotiations.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The gunman who killed five police officers in Dallas had enough bomb-making materials in his home to lead the authorities to believe he was planning a larger attack, the city’s police chief said on Sunday. He provided new details of how, during two hours of negotiations, the gunman sang, laughed and asked how many officers he had killed before he was killed by a bomb-equipped robot.

headline: Our ‘Ghostbusters’ Review: Girls Rule. Women Are Funny. Get Over It.
abstract: This redo lets women, especially Kate McKinnon, be as simply and uncomplicatedly funny as men, and still leaves room for Chris Hemsworth.
lead_paragraph: Sliding into theaters on a river of slime and an endless supply of good vibes, the new, cheerfully silly “Ghostbusters” is that rarest of big-studio offerings — a movie that is a lot of enjoyable, disposable fun. And enjoy it while you can because this doesn’t happen often, even in summer, which is supposed to be our season of collective moviegoing happiness. The season when everyone jumps onboard (whee!) and agrees that, yes, this great goof is exactly what you were thinking when you wondered why they didn’t make summer movies like they used to.

headline: Charging Document for DeRay McKesson
abstract: DeRay McKesson, a national voice for the Black Lives Matter movement, was among scores of people arrested at demonstrations across the country late Saturday, as protesters expressed anger over the shootings of two black men by police officers last week. He was arrested in Baton Rouge, La.
lead_paragraph: DeRay McKesson, a national voice for the Black Lives Matter movement, was among scores of people arrested at demonstrations across the country late Saturday, as protesters expressed anger over the shootings of two black men by police officers last week. He was arrested in Baton Rouge, La.

headline: ‘The Secret Life of Pets’ Shows Bark, Topping Box Office
abstract: The film took in about $103.2 million over the weekend at North American theaters, the largest opening total this year for an original movie.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Few summer movies had as much riding on them as “The Secret Life of Pets.” NBCUniversal started work on a related theme park ride before selling a single ticket. “If the film doesn’t do as well as I think, it will be painful,” the company’s chief executive, Steve Burke, acknowledged last month.

headline: Artistic Director Moves from Abrons to Skirball Center
abstract: Jay Wegman, artistic director of Abrons Arts Center, will leave to join N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts as its senior director.
lead_paragraph: Jay Wegman, artistic director of Abrons Arts Center, will leave his post there and join N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts as its senior director on Aug. 1.

headline: A Word With: Javier Muñoz, the New Hamilton on Broadway
abstract: On Monday, Mr. Muñoz replaces Lin-Manuel Miranda, and steps into the title role of “Hamilton.”
lead_paragraph: There is a new Hamilton in “Hamilton,” although President Obama and Beyoncé have seen him already.

headline: Yemeni Guantánamo Prisoner Is Transferred to Italy After 14 Years
abstract: The latest transfer from the military prison came at a time of heightened scrutiny after a former prisoner there disappeared after being resettled in Uruguay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Sunday announced that it had transferred a Yemeni detainee to Italy. The United States military had held the man in indefinite wartime detention without trial at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for 14 and a half years.

headline: Chris Froome Maintains Lead at Tour de France During a Brutal Ninth Stage
abstract: Faced with steep climbs and weather that ranged from searing heat to hail and lightning, Froome finished with a 16-second advantage but could not shake his rivals.
lead_paragraph: ARCALIS, Andorra — While locusts were left out of the mix, Sunday’s taxing mountain stage of the Tour de France was made even more difficult by a variety of other plagues, including searing heat, pounding rain, hail and lightning.

headline: Turnbull Claims Victory in Australia
abstract: Ending Australia’s unusually close and long election, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull declared victory on Sunday after the leader of the opposition Labor Party, Bill Shorten, conceded.
lead_paragraph: Ending Australia’s unusually close and long election, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull declared victory on Sunday after the leader of the opposition Labor Party, Bill Shorten, conceded.

headline: On a Somber Sunday, ‘One Nation Under God Examines Its Soul’
abstract: Church leaders addressed the aftershocks of a week of gun violence as they tried to comfort worshipers in New York, Texas, Louisiana, Minnesota and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Fearful that the nation is locked in a spiral of violence and discord, many Americans took what refuge they could in church on Sunday. In tiny storefronts and suburban megachurches, worshipers mourned the deaths of five Dallas police officers at the hands of an African-American sniper who was aiming to kill white officers at a demonstration against police violence. They also grieved for two African-American men killed in shootings by the police in Baton Rouge, La., and Minnesota.

headline: Fatal Tesla Crash Draws In Transportation Safety Board
abstract: In addition to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the N.T.S.B. will investigate a Florida crash involving a Tesla operating in Autopilot mode.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A second federal agency is investigating a fatal May 7 crash in Florida involving a Tesla automobile operating in Autopilot mode that failed to stop when a tractor-trailer turned in front of it.

headline: Heng on ISIS’s Growth in Asia
abstract: The appeal of the Islamic State terror group has been gradually growing in the region.
lead_paragraph: The appeal of the Islamic State terror group has been gradually growing in the region.

headline: In India, a Spirited Defense of Writers
abstract: A judge’s words about freedom of expression belong at the top of Prime Minister Modi’s reading list.
lead_paragraph: The Madras High Court in Chennai, India, delivered a decision on Tuesday that was remarkable for its eloquence on the right to freedom of expression, on the centrality of this right to India’s democracy and on the state’s duty to protect it.

headline: Forget Beanbag Chairs. Amazon Is Giving Its Workers Treehouses.
abstract: Amazon is building a complex at its Seattle headquarters where employees can sit by a creek, walk on suspension bridges and brainstorm in the boughs.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Just off a remote stretch of road here, near wineries, horse stables and farms, Amazon is secretly growing something, but it’s not what Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, calls the “tiny seeds” that could become the company’s next big businesses.

headline: Among the Little Englanders
abstract: A visit to the seaside towns that voted to take Britain out of the European Union.
lead_paragraph: CLACTON-ON-SEA, Britain — Meet some of the men and women who sank Europe. They are playing a game called the Claw on Clacton Pier. They put a coin into the machine and try to grab one of the brightly colored, rather menacing puppets at the bottom. Their children look on, anxiously.

headline: Forthcoming Article
abstract: This article was published prematurely.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof’s column was published prematurely on this URL. It will be published in the coming days.

headline: Hillary Clinton, as Seen Through a Chinese Prism
abstract: Opinions on the American presidential candidate veer from admiration, mostly among women and civil libertarians, to distaste, mostly among male policy makers.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Hillary Clinton is blunt, negative on China, friendly toward homosexuals, and female — all reasons some Chinese give for not wanting to see her as the next president of the United States.

headline: Mets Stagger Into All-Star Break With Another Loss to the Nationals
abstract: Jose Reyes hit two homers, but the Mets could not take advantage of Washington starter Gio Gonzalez’s wildness and are now six games behind their rivals.
lead_paragraph: Asked about the Mets’ season during yet another injury-filled weekend, Manager Terry Collins paused to think. How best to describe the first half of a season in which initially high expectations had been lowered by struggles and aches?

headline: A New Disney Princesa Carries Responsibilities Beyond Her Kingdom
abstract: Disney has created its first Latina princess, Elena, who will have her debut on the Disney Channel this month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “It was finally my time.”

headline: Obama on ‘Brooding’ Over the Interminable Wars of His Presidency
abstract: “What I’ve been trying to do is to create an architecture, a structure,” for an American approach to military operations, the president said, “and it’s not there yet.”
lead_paragraph: ROTA, Spain — For President Obama, war is never far from his thoughts. On Sunday afternoon, he flew to this sprawling naval air station near the mouth of the Mediterranean to tour the Ross, one of four guided-missile destroyers that patrol from the Baltic to the Black Sea, potent symbols of America’s military presence in Europe.

headline: Review: In ‘Hot Milk,’ by Deborah Levy, a Broken Life and a Frayed Maternal Bond
abstract: Ms. Levy has set a seemingly simple story against a backdrop thrumming with low-key menace and sly, dry humor, sometimes in the same paragraph.
lead_paragraph: Restless, listless, sleepless and penniless, Sofia Papastergiadis, the heroine of Deborah Levy’s gorgeous new novel, “Hot Milk,” feels about as miserable and alarmed as it is possible to feel. We meet her just after she drops her laptop on the floor, shattering both the screen and the illusion of well-being.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 11
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Honoring García Lorca’s Genius: A Bout Over a $22 Million Archive
abstract: An arts center first conceived in 2004 sits empty in Granada, Spain, while Federico García Lorca’s family members fight for control.
lead_paragraph: GRANADA, Spain — The legacy of Federico García Lorca’s hostilities with government lives on these days through his family, whose members are tangling with officials over control of a new $25 million center built to honor García Lorca, the playwright and poet who was executed by firing squad during the Spanish Civil War.

headline: At Euro 2016 Final, Portugal Loses Ronaldo but Defeats France
abstract: Cristiano Ronaldo was taken off on a stretcher in the first half with a knee injury, but Éder supplied the victory with a goal in the 109th minute.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — Cristiano Ronaldo was crying, his chest heaving, his knee throbbing, his heart aching like never before. Ronaldo, prone on the turf, sat up slowly and did what he surely never imagined having to do in a game like this: He wrapped his captain’s armband around a teammate as his eyes clouded over. Then he lay back, shimmied onto a stretcher and was carried to the locker room.

headline: Review: Marisa Tomei, in Extremis, in ‘The Rose Tattoo’
abstract: At the Williamstown Theater Festival, one of Tennessee Williams’s less deluded heroines.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Marisa Tomei, who stars in the Williamstown Theater Festival’s buoyant new production of Tennessee Williams’s “The Rose Tattoo,” may at first blush appear to be literally a few sizes too small for the feisty, fiery central role of Serafina Delle Rose.

headline: Review: ‘The White House: Inside Story’ on PBS
abstract: This documentary looks at the history of the White House, its symbolism and the burdens of living and working there.
lead_paragraph: For a reflective pause in the storm that is the 2016 presidential election, see “The White House: Inside Story,” Tuesday night on PBS.

headline: Iranian Lawmakers’ Car Ambushed by Gunmen in Kurdish Region
abstract: The two men were wounded, and the vehicle’s driver and a veterinarian traveling with them were killed, in an attack near Dalahu on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Gunmen ambushed a car carrying a lawmaker and a local governor on Sunday in Iran’s restive Kurdish region, state news media reported. Both men were wounded, and the driver and a veterinarian traveling with them were killed.

headline: For Black Lives Matter, Classical Music Steps In
abstract: “Sing Her Name,” a benefit concert set for Wednesday in New York, has become tragically timely.
lead_paragraph: After last week’s shootings, an orchestral concert to benefit the Black Lives Matter movement, scheduled for Wednesday night at Cooper Union, has become tragically timely.

headline: Review: The Skivvies Rock Their Socks Off (and Other Clothes, Too)
abstract: The Skivvies stripped down to their underwear and wielded instruments as if they were toys, treating the stage like a glorified sandbox for grown-up children.
lead_paragraph: Indie rock, alt-cabaret, new burlesque: Whatever you call it, the jolly musical comedy of the Skivvies, a troupe of entertainers who perform in their underwear, joyfully rocked the house at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Saturday evening. Like Joe Iconis and Family, who also regularly play the club, the Skivvies are devoted to the concept of strength in numbers and an artistic community in which everyone is more or less equal, and show business is communal play. Watching them, I was reminded of the Tubes, the traveling rock circus that had its moment in the sun in the late 1970s and early ’80s.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, No Fan of Donald Trump, Critiques Latest Term
abstract: Justice Ginsburg took stock of a tumultuous term for the Supreme Court after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia and gave her thoughts about a Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unless they have a book to sell, Supreme Court justices rarely give interviews. Even then, they diligently avoid political topics. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg takes a different approach.

headline: Pizazz
abstract: Freddie Cheng starts off our solving week with pizazz.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — WOW! We start off our solving week with a 76-worder by Freddie Cheng. I mention the word count because the majority of Monday puzzles utilize the 78-word maximum for an early-week 15 x 15 grid. Going just a tad lighter with the black squares enables Mr. Cheng to include some longer nontheme entries, which lent this solve a nice, spacious feeling.

headline: Jacoby Ellsbury Turns Ire Into Fire as Yankees Defeat Indians Again
abstract: Miffed over a strike call that he thought should have resulted in a walk, Ellsbury hit the next pitch for a three-run homer that helped the Yankees claw back to .500.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Jacoby Ellsbury saw Carlos Carrasco’s 3-1 pitch arrive off the outside edge of home plate, he placed his bat on the ground, unstrapped his shin guard and prepared to head to first base.

headline: Americans Gather at Demonstrations, Churches and Memorials
abstract: In the aftermath of shootings in Minnesota, Louisiana and Texas, people across the country mourned the victims and protested their deaths.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of shootings in Minnesota, Louisiana and Texas, people across the country mourned the victims and protested their deaths.

headline: Another Meeting on Trans-Atlantic Trade, and China to Report Its G.D.P.
abstract: The United States and the European Union have struggled to reach an agreement in agriculture and financial services. And China’s gross domestic product has probably continued to slow.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the week ahead.

headline: Videos With an Automatic Assist
abstract: Automatically generated videos are appearing in growing numbers on news companies’ websites and social pages, but they’re not always easy to spot. Here are a few examples.
lead_paragraph: Automatically generated videos are appearing in growing numbers on news companies’ websites and social pages, but they’re not always easy to spot. Here are a few examples.

headline: Shakespeare at Night in the Park
abstract: A poetic tribute to a recent evening watching “The Taming of the Shrew” at the Delacorte Theater (the audience included a raccoon).
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Berlin Protests in Support of Squatters Turn Violent
abstract: A demonstration on Saturday swelled to 3,500 people, and some threw rocks and bottles at police officers, who responded with tear gas and billy clubs.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A simmering dispute between leftist squatters and the authorities in Berlin erupted overnight into what the police on Sunday called “the most aggressive and most violent protest in the past five years.”

headline: Review: A Harrowing Puppet Show, ‘Demolishing Everything With Amazing Speed’
abstract: The series of short plays, written in 1917, have a macabre tone, unfolding as a bright catalog of carnage and vivisection.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — The timing could not have been worse — or more perfect. A series of short plays written nearly a century ago acquired an icy and unexpected urgency when they received their belated world premiere last week. And an audience was frozen into the kind of stillness that no one dares interrupt, not even with a startled gasp.

headline: Intent on a Reckoning With Georgetown’s Slavery-Stained Past
abstract: In 1838, the university kept itself afloat through the sale of slaves. Now its president is reaching out to descendants and exploring ways to make amends.
lead_paragraph: MARINGOUIN, La. — The rental car sped past acres of farmland and across a muddy bayou to an old plantation rippling with sugar cane. Stepping out was John J. DeGioia, the president of Georgetown University, who was on the most unusual journey of his tenure.

headline: Front-Page Editorials Aim to Soothe the Grief-Stricken
abstract: While more newspapers are taking this unusual step during recent spasms of violence, other bold decisions have been criticized for sowing divisiveness.
lead_paragraph: Last month, on the day after a gunman killed 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., The Orlando Sentinel ran a front-page editorial with the headline, “Our Community Will Heal.”

headline: Rudolph Giuliani Lashes Out at Black Lives Matter
abstract: Mr. Giuliani said Sunday on CBS’s “Face the Nation” that the movement unfairly focused on killings at the hands of the police.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, lashed out against the Black Lives Matter movement on Sunday, accusing it of ignoring black-on-black crime, inspiring violence against the police and promoting racism.

headline: What Trump and the G.O.P. Can Agree On: Tax Cuts for the Rich
abstract: The tax plan shepherded by House Speaker Paul Ryan would fundamentally change the system, but both plans reduce taxes on capital gains and high incomes.
lead_paragraph: In some important ways, the House Republicans’ new plan to overhaul the tax code has more in common with proposals from the candidates who lost their party’s presidential nomination than those from Donald J. Trump, the one poised to win it.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Set for Rally With Hillary Clinton, Says Campaigns Are ‘Closer and Closer’
abstract: Mr. Sanders is scheduled to appear on Tuesday in Portsmouth, N.H., alongside Mrs. Clinton, who has adopted some of his ideas on education and health care.
lead_paragraph: The awkward dance between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, her top Democratic primary opponent, is set to conclude on Tuesday, with Mr. Sanders appearing alongside her at a rally in Portsmouth, N.H.

headline: Death Toll Rises in Jammu and Kashmir During Protests Over Separatist’s Death
abstract: Two days of clashes between protesters and the police in Kashmir have resulted in at least 19 deaths and overwhelmed hospitals with the injured.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Protesters clashed with the police in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir on Sunday, the second day of widespread unrest after a separatist militant leader was killed in a gun battle with security forces on Friday.

headline: As Online Video Surges, Publishers Turn to Automation
abstract: Tronc, the rebranded Tribune Publishing, wants to offer 2,000 videos a day, up from about 200 now, and hands-off video production is central to that aim.
lead_paragraph: In a television appearance in early June, Michael W. Ferro Jr., the chairman of the newspaper and magazine publishing company Tronc — formerly known as Tribune Publishing — made an astonishing claim.

headline: Once an Afterthought in Tennis, Canada Breaks Through
abstract: Denis Shapovalov and Milos Raonic, two Canadians, played in the boys’ and men’s finals at Wimbledon on Sunday. Shapovalov came away with a victory.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Late in the third set of the boys’ tournament final at Wimbledon, a rousing round of the “Aussie! Aussie! Aussie!” and “Oi! Oi! Oi!” chant circled Court No. 1 during a changeover.

headline: After Food Safety and Drug Scandals, Chipotle Seeks a Fresh Start
abstract: The company, which has long advertised its high-quality ingredients, is using a new animated campaign and a loyalty program to win back clients lost after an E. coli outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The past 12 months have not been easy for Chipotle Mexican Grill.

headline: Before Vast Riches, Free Agency’s Focus Was Freedom
abstract: A settlement from a 1970 lawsuit filed by Oscar Robertson led to the easy movement and lavish salaries that are now commonplace in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the recent period of N.B.A. free agency, with owners making it rain like crazy, I kept thinking of Oscar Robertson.

headline: Second Russian Track Athlete Exempted From Ban by the Sport’s Governing Body
abstract: Darya Klishina was cleared by the International Association of Athletics Federations to compete as a neutral athlete at the Olympics in Rio. But the final authorization lies with the I.O.C.
lead_paragraph: Darya Klishina, a Russian long jumper, was cleared on Sunday to compete as a neutral athlete at the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: The Cabanas of Silver Gull
abstract: Members of a private summer colony in Queens rent cabanas every summer, often personalizing the shedlike rooms to reflect their styles — and checkbooks.
lead_paragraph: Members of a private summer colony in Queens rent cabanas every summer, often personalizing the shedlike rooms to reflect their styles — and checkbooks.

headline: Seattle C.E.O. Who Promised $70,000 Salaries Wins Suit Filed by Brother
abstract: Dan Price, a co-founder of Gravity Payments, had been accused by his brother Lucas of overpaying himself and of using a corporate credit card for personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: Dan Price, the chief executive of a small Seattle company who promised last year to pay every one of his workers at least $70,000 a year, has won a court battle with his brother.

headline: Adding Personal Flourishes to 112 Square Feet of Paradise
abstract: Trading up or staying put, members at the Silver Gull Beach Club make their cabanas their own, sometimes until death.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to paint her cabana at the Silver Gull Beach Club, Marianne Fezza went with orange and yellow.

headline: A Saudi Morals Enforcer Called for a More Liberal Islam. Then the Death Threats Began.
abstract: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — For most of his adult life, Ahmed Qassim al-Ghamdi worked among the bearded enforcers of Saudi Arabia. He was a dedicated employee of the Commission for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice — known abroad as the religious police — serving with the front-line troops protecting the Islamic kingdom from Westernization, secularism and anything but the most conservative Islamic practices.

headline: An Old Pro Returns to the Course That Taught Him How to Play
abstract: Colin Montgomerie, 53, will play in what could be his final British Open at Royal Troon, the golf course that he first played on as a child.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — If it truly is farewell to the British Open for Colin Montgomerie, one of golf’s more complex characters, Royal Troon is the right windswept place to do it.

headline: Texas Open-Carry Laws Blurred Lines Between Suspects and Marchers
abstract: The mayor of Dallas suggests tightening the state’s gun laws to make it tougher to carry long arms in public.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As a demonstration against police shootings made its way downtown here on Thursday, it differed from others around the country in one startling way: Twenty to 30 of the marchers showed up with AR-15s and other types of military-style rifles and wore them openly, with the straps slung across their shoulders and backs.

headline: Police Shoot Man in Brooklyn; Officials Say He Had a Gun
abstract: Paul Mathurin was wounded in the hip by police officers who were responding to reports of a man waving a gun. The accounts from some witnesses, however, differed from that of the police.
lead_paragraph: The calls came into 911 reporting a man with a gun. Shortly after 7 a.m. on Sunday, the authorities said, three New York police officers responded to an intersection in Brooklyn, where they faced a 31-year-old man and raised their weapons.

headline: Liberty Show Solidarity With Black Lives Matter in Rare Public Stance
abstract: The players wore T-shirts addressing the recent shooting deaths of black men by the police, without giving notice to the W.N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Before their game against the San Antonio Stars on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, the Liberty players wore black T-shirts addressing the recent shooting deaths of black men by the police in Minneapolis and Baton Rouge, La., and the fatal shooting of five Dallas police officers. The shirts, which were printed without notice to the W.N.B.A., read: #BlackLivesMatter and #Dallas5. The back of the shirts had another hashtag followed by a blank space.

headline: Two Shortstops Keep Close, in the Draft Order and Beyond
abstract: Dansby Swanson and Alex Bregman, the No. 1 and 2 draft picks in 2015, have led closely parallel lives since college, reuniting most recently on the United States team.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The Houston Astros drafted first over all in 2012, 2013 and 2014. Their choices neatly illustrate the vagaries of the process: One player became a star, one got traded and one got hurt.

headline: South Korea’s Golf Dominance Leaves Some of the World’s Best Out of the Olympics
abstract: South Koreans occupy half of the top 20 spots in global women’s golf rankings, but the country can send only four representatives to the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — They have been tracking results week after week as compulsively as players in a fantasy league do. In South Korea, where people are passionate about women’s golf and the Olympics, the composition of the team that the country will send to the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro next month has drawn intense scrutiny.

headline: Video of Fatal Shooting by Off-Duty Officer in Brooklyn Emerges
abstract: Footage of the death of Delrawn Small, 37, circulated as videos of other fatal encounters between black men and the police were broadcast nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The video was grainy, and the men on the street were blurs rendered in black and white. But the clip, recorded by a surveillance camera pointed at a Brooklyn intersection, shows a man approaching the driver’s side window of a car, and then, in an instant, stumbling away before collapsing onto the pavement.

headline: ‘The Night Of’ Series Premiere: Fate at the Wheel
abstract: A breathtaking series of outrageously misguided decisions are recounted and defended in equally great lengths.
lead_paragraph: Jack Stone has eczema on his feet. His doctor advised him to keep them aerated, so the fungus doesn’t spread any further. He explains this to his new client, Nasir Khan, who may be wondering why his lawyer — the only man currently standing between him and a murder conviction — is wearing sandals in a professional capacity. Or maybe Nasir, who goes by Naz, is just looking down, scared and exhausted by a night that’s gotten away from him.

headline: A Century Later, Memories of Fatal Shark Attacks Linger in New Jersey
abstract: Matawan, N.J., is recalling a series of 1916 attacks in which the same great white shark was believed to have attacked and killed four people along the state’s coast.
lead_paragraph: MATAWAN, N.J. — On a sweltering July afternoon in 1916, Lester Stillwell, 11, jumped into the secluded Matawan Creek here, not seeing the large mass moving toward him in the water.

headline: After Iraq, Trying His Hand at a Project Closer to Home: Brooklyn
abstract: Tucker Reed, who worked on reconstruction projects in Iraq and since 2011 has been the president of the Downtown Brooklyn Partnership, is stepping down.
lead_paragraph: Tucker Reed had spent the first five years of his career working in and around New York City government and real estate when he decided, in 2008, to tackle a different sort of municipal governing: rebuilding Iraq. In the wake of the military troop buildup there, Mr. Reed spent 13 months as a contractor for the State Department, working in Baghdad and in the countryside — good preparation, it turned out, for his most recent role, as president of the Downtown Brooklyn Partnership.

headline: Brittany Lang Wins U.S. Women’s Open in Playoff After Penalty on Anna Nordqvist
abstract: Nordqvist was assessed a two-stroke penalty for touching sand in the hazard, but she was not informed of the violation until three shots into the next hole.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — Brittany Lang loves the United States Women’s Open. Before this year, she had recorded three top-10 finishes in 11 starts in her national championship, including a tie for second as an amateur in 2005. Anna Nordqvist of Sweden had a more tortured history with the event, missing the cut in four of her previous seven appearances.

headline: After Shootings, Bahamas Joins Several Nations Urging Caution for Visitors to U.S.
abstract: At least three nations are urging citizens to avoid protests and crowds in travels to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Travelers, beware: Tensions in the United States over police shootings of black men and women may pose a threat to your safety.

headline: France Loses a Soccer Championship, but Achieves a Rare Unity
abstract: Despite a loss, France saw the finals of the European Championships as an opportunity to unite and recover after a difficult and divisive year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Among the 90,000 soccer fans watching the final of the European Championships on huge screens set up in front of the Eiffel Tower, it was Portugal’s supporters who were jumping in jubilation at the end, as their team won, 1-0.

headline: Activists Camp Out to Call for Completion of a Brooklyn Park
abstract: A congresswoman and the borough president were among those trying to persuade a developer to sell a piece of land that is crucial to Bushwick Inlet Park.
lead_paragraph: Throughout its well-documented transformation, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has hosted an array of outlandish incongruities. By now, the images are almost hackneyed: artists and Hasidim gliding along on bicycles, sporting parallel chest-length beards; coffee beans of every roast sharing shelf space with spices from the Caribbean and craft beers brewed in nearby warehouses that had long stood idle.

headline: The Races Before Rio
abstract: Images from the United States Olympic track and field trials, which began July 1 and continue through Sunday at the University of Oregon’s Hayward Field in Eugene.
lead_paragraph: Images from the United States Olympic track and field trials, which began July 1 and continue through Sunday at the University of Oregon’s Hayward Field in Eugene.

headline: U.F.C. Sells Itself for $4 Billion
abstract: The talent giant WME-IMG is getting backing from private equity heavyweights to acquire the mixed martial arts league from the Fertitta brothers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ultimate Fighting Championship seemed for years to be a curio, a niche sport for those interested in seeing combatants pummel one another in an octagonal cage.

headline: Gay Rights Groups to Air Ad During Donald Trump’s Acceptance Speech
abstract: The ad, which will air on Fox News, shows a transgender woman acting out a scene that advocates say occurs too often in states where anti-discrimination protections are not in place.
lead_paragraph: On the evening that Donald J. Trump is expected to accept the Republican nomination, a coalition of gay rights groups will run a commercial that criticizes laws recently passed in states like North Carolina that limit which public restrooms transgender people can use.

headline: Thumb Suckers and Nail Biters May Develop Fewer Allergies
abstract: Thumb sucking and nail biting worry parents, but now new research shows that children with those bad habits may develop fewer allergies later in life.
lead_paragraph: Babies have been seen sucking on their fingers in utero weeks before birth. But the sight of an older child with his fingers constantly in his mouth, sucking her thumb, biting his nails, can drive parents crazy, bringing up fears about everything from social stigma to germs.

headline: More Nonsmoking Teens Inhaling Flavored Nicotine Through Vaping
abstract: Teenagers who never would have smoked cigarettes are now ‘vaping’ with e-cigarettes, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Many teenagers who never would have smoked cigarettes are now “vaping” with flavored e-cigarettes, leading to a new generation using nicotine at rates not seen since the 1990s, a new study suggests.

headline: Who Was Buried at the Naval Hospital Cemetery in Brooklyn?
abstract: An exhaustive 1999 study of the abandoned cemetery included a list of all known burials, from Alexander Adams to Charles Zoller (Pages 115 to 174), as well as a detailed history.
lead_paragraph: An exhaustive 1999 study of the abandoned cemetery included a list of all known burials, from Alexander Adams to Charles Zoller (Pages 115 to 174), as well as a detailed history.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, July 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “There should be some way to say I shouldn’t be bringing my shotgun to a Mavericks game or to a protest because something crazy should happen.”

headline: Joe Perry, Aerosmith Guitarist, Is Hospitalized After Staggering Off Stage in Coney Island
abstract: The musician was performing in Brooklyn with the Hollywood Vampires, a supergroup that includes Johnny Depp and Alice Cooper, when he appeared to fall ill.
lead_paragraph: Aerosmith’s lead guitarist, Joe Perry, staggered off the stage at a concert in Brooklyn on Sunday night, amid reports from witnesses that he had appeared ill during the show.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: “Capital” skewers life on a London street where somebody wants what its residents have. And Jennifer Lopez and Lin-Manuel Miranda perform to benefit Orlando massacre victims.
lead_paragraph: “Capital” skewers life on a London street, pre-‘Brexit,’ where somebody wants what its residents have. Jennifer Lopez and Lin-Manuel Miranda perform to benefit those affected by the Orlando shootings. And Jessica Raine of “Call the Midwife” steams things up on “Jericho.”

headline: Corrections: July 11, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, July 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Football Player Who Runs Track? Or Runner Who Plays Football?
abstract: Doubts about taking on two sports can creep into an athlete’s mind. But passion and a competitive drive are hard things to ignore.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Devon Allen had already rehearsed the celebration in his mind, so after lunging across the finish line to win the 110-meter hurdles on Saturday night at the United States Olympic track and field trials, he just kept running.

headline: China’s Menacing Words for a Boat in Disputed Waters: ‘Get Out!’
abstract: A reporter who set out to see Scarborough Shoal in the disputed South China Sea found his boat quickly intercepted by the Chinese Coast Guard.
lead_paragraph: SCARBOROUGH SHOAL, South China Sea — We could see the glistening turquoise waters in the distance, a haven where deep-sea waves soften and, fishermen say, the grouper and snapper could feed a village for eternity.

headline: North Korea Cuts Off Only Diplomatic Channel With U.S. Over Sanctions
abstract: Although the two countries have no diplomatic ties, North Korea’s United Nations mission had long served as a point of contact.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Monday that it had cut off its only official channel of diplomatic communications with the United States in retaliation for Washington’s sanctions against its leader, Kim Jong-un, over human rights abuses.

headline: Animals in Trauma Training
abstract: A surgeon in the Army Reserves supports the call for a ban on using animals in military medical training.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How We Can Help Central American Refugees
abstract: Readers urge President Obama to offer refuge to those fleeing violence and discuss how Central Americans are victims of climate change.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Thin Blue Line Between Us
abstract: If I hadn’t believed change was possible, I could never have enrolled in the police academy.
lead_paragraph: THERE were days when I marched shoulder to shoulder with outraged New Yorkers, after the police-involved death of Amadou Diallo in the Bronx and police assault on Abner Louima in Brooklyn, and we chanted, “No justice, no peace.” There were evenings when I was policing the same protests and keeping the peace, and people came up to me and voiced their anger, not realizing I had stood with them just hours earlier.

headline: Unjamming the Sidewalks of New York
abstract: A former city official and other New Yorkers address the problem.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cheap Money Talks
abstract: And what it says is to invest in the future.
lead_paragraph: What with everything else going on, from Trump to Brexit to the horror in Dallas, it’s hard to focus on developments in financial markets — especially because we’re not facing any immediate crisis. But extraordinary things have been happening lately, especially in bond markets. And because money still makes the world go ’round, attention must be paid to what the markets are trying to tell us.

headline: Mr. de Blasio and the Spirit of the Campaign Finance Law
abstract: The mayor may have escaped legal jeopardy, but he should not feel absolved.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio is clearly relieved that the New York City Campaign Finance Board did not find that he and his aides violated the law by raising and spending large amounts of money through a nonprofit organization to promote his agenda.

headline: ‘A World That Demands More Clean Energy’
abstract: Environmentalists discuss the future of energy in the United States.
