headline: My Time With the Netanyahu Brothers
abstract: After “a fluke involving a friend of a friend of a friend in Nairobi,” our East Africa bureau chief ends up traveling with the Israeli prime minister, into highly emotional territory.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Jeffrey Gettleman, The Times’s East Africa bureau chief, shares what it was like for him to travel back with Benjamin Netanyahu — in mind and body — to Entebbe, Uganda, where the Israeli prime minister’s older brother was killed in 1976 leading a raid that rescued 100 hostages being held by terrorists.

headline: Beetle Is Named in Honor of Xi Jinping, but China Aims to Squash the News
abstract: The taxonomic gesture appeared to irritate propaganda bosses, who moved fast to block references to the “Xi beetle” from the nation’s heavily censored internet
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Under a microscope, the tiny beetle named in honor of China’s president, Xi Jinping, looks fierce, with black, armorlike ridges and beaded antennae.

headline: Retrial of Barclays Traders Set for February in Libor Case
abstract: A jury was unable to reach a verdict this month regarding two former Barclays traders, Stylianos Contogoulas and Ryan Michael Reich.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two former Barclays traders will be retried in February on charges that they plotted to manipulate a benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: A Conservationist’s Call for Humans to Curb Harms to Our Animal Kin
abstract: A conservationist explores climate change and implications of the blurring line between humans and other animals.
lead_paragraph: Research continues to accrue showing not only high levels of animal intelligence, but also social sophistication, as in the elephant field study described in The Times last week showing how, when older females have been killed by poachers, daughters “leverage their mothers’ prior social context to reconstruct networks.”

headline: England’s Last Gasp of Empire
abstract: The Brexit vote expressed white Britain’s nostalgia for a lost sense of greatness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From Elizabeth I to Elizabeth II, England was an empire. No more.

headline: For Coffee Drinkers, the Buzz May Be in Your Genes
abstract: Is coffee good for you or bad for you? The answer may be in your genetic makeup.
lead_paragraph: Like most of my work, this article would not have been possible without coffee.

headline: A Social Reflex: Police and Blacks, Seeing Threat, Close Ranks
abstract: When a social group perceives a threat, its members tend to shift how they see themselves, one another and, especially, outsiders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week of violence and anguish in the United States has prompted increasingly familiar discussions of race, policing, discrimination and gun violence. But amid those very real issues, another force is playing out, unseen and little discussed beyond the social scientists who study it.

headline: Pokémon Has Kids on the Move — and on Their Phones
abstract: The game gets children off the couch, but do our usual screen time limits apply?
lead_paragraph: Parents looking for a way to get children moving and off the couch this summer have found a surprising new ally: Pokémon.

headline: A Portland Project Keeps It Funky, With Design and Funding
abstract: The Fair-Haired Dumbbell is an unusual office building in Oregon that is getting part of its construction money from a crowdfunding push.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Directly across the Willamette River from this city’s downtown, a small area called Burnside Bridgehead is transforming, in a microcosm of what is happening throughout the city.

headline: Pokémon Go Mania Could Signal a Bright Future for Augmented Reality
abstract: The hugely popular smartphone game is easy to download and play. And it doesn’t involve fancy new headsets or other equipment, which virtual reality typically requires.
lead_paragraph: Just about anywhere you go, there is now Pokémon Go.

headline: Voice Searches With Cortana or Chrome
abstract: Microsoft restricted its virtual helper to work only with its Edge browser and Bing search engine, but you can do voice searches right in Google’s browser.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I do voice searches with Cortana in Windows 10, it always uses the Edge browser and the Bing search engine. Can I set it to use Google Chrome and search?

headline: Still Confused About Brexit Macroeconomics
abstract: What does “uncertainty” do?
lead_paragraph: OK, I am still finding it hard to understand the near-consensus among my colleagues about the short- and medium-term effects of Brexit. As I’ve tried to point out, while there are clear reasons to believe that Brexit will make Britain somewhat poorer in the long run, it’s not completely obvious why this should lead to a recession in the short run. I got some thoughtful responses, but they raised more questions in my mind. And I have to say that quite a lot of the reaction I’ve received has involved strange failures of reading comprehension; it’s as if economists simply can’t process the proposition that what’s bad in the long run might not have obviously bad consequences in the short run.

headline: 1966: Johnson Foresees Long War
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In July 1966, President Johnson predicts the Vietnam war will be long.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson told the American people tonight [July 12] that they would have to carry ‘‘perhaps for a long time the burden of a confusing and costly war in Vietnam.’’ At the same time, Mr. Johnson appealed to Communist China to open its closed doors to the world. Specifically, he urged that Peking allow in American scholars, newsmen, health experts and other specialists. It was a tough speech, reflecting the chief executive’s apparently increasingly firm commitment to the war. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 13, 1966

headline: ‘Cats’ is Back on Broadway. We Want Your ‘Memory.’
abstract: The New York Times invites you to perform a chorus from “Memory” from the Broadway musical “Cats.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times invites you to perform a chorus from “Memory” from the Broadway musical “Cats.”

headline: After Outcry, University of California Increases In-State Admission Offers
abstract: The growth will probably help defuse a controversy prompted by accusations that the school pursued nonresidents, who pay higher tuition.
lead_paragraph: The University of California said it had increased admission offers to California freshmen by more than 15 percent for the fall 2016 semester while reducing offers to international students at two of its prestigious campuses. The numbers are likely to help defuse a controversy sparked by accusations that the university has rejected Californians in favor of nonresidents.

headline: Mathieu Kassovitz on Hit French TV Spy Drama ‘The Bureau’
abstract: The French actor-director who made “La Haine” two decades ago talks about his series, now available in the United States on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: James Bond he is not. In “The Bureau,” Mathieu Kassovitz slips into the role of Malotru, an undercover agent for the French intelligence service, who, returning home to Paris after a six-year mission in Damascus, struggles to relinquish his alias — and a forbidden affair with a married Syrian woman. And suddenly a small untruth, juxtaposed with the lie that is his life, begins to snowball.

headline: Attorney General Loretta Lynch Testifies Before Congress
abstract: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch will testify before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday. She is expected to be questioned about the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server when she was secretary of state.

headline: Joe Paterno Knew of Sandusky Abuse in 1976, According to Court Testimony
abstract: Court documents released Tuesday show that a man testifying in 2014 said that Mr. Sandusky abused him in the shower in 1976 when he was 14 and that Mr. Paterno was told about it.
lead_paragraph: A graphic description of sexual abuse from 1976 detailed in court documents released Tuesday cast new doubt on assertions by Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, that he did not know until 2001 that his former assistant Jerry Sandusky had abused minors.

headline: Mimi
abstract: The French bistro New Yorkers dream of finding in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: The French bistro New Yorkers dream of finding in Greenwich Village.

headline: At Mimi, French Food Is a Celebration of Appetite
abstract: An updated version of the bistro New Yorkers dream of finding in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: It took three dinners at Mimi before I saw the restaurant that had other people so excited.

headline: Minuteman Co-Founder Sentenced to 19½ Years for Molesting 5-Year-Old
abstract: Christopher Simcox, who helped found a border patrol group that has now disbanded, was found guilty on several charges in Arizona last month.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Simcox, a founder of the now-disbanded Minuteman border patrol group, has been sentenced in Arizona to more than 19 years in prison for sexual abuse of a 5-year-old girl, in a case that drew the attention of the Supreme Court after Mr. Simcox tried to question the young victim.

headline: ScienceTake | A Seafloor Microscope
abstract: An underwater microscope that divers can use to view corals on the seafloor can show details down to one micron, or one-hundredth the width of a human hair.
lead_paragraph: An underwater microscope that divers can use to view corals on the seafloor can show details down to one micron, or one-hundredth the width of a human hair.

headline: Seafloor Microscope Zooms In on Tiniest Bits of Coral
abstract: Researchers built the first microscope that can be used to see, in a natural state, the details of coral polyps a fraction of the width of a human hair.
lead_paragraph: Coral reefs can extend more than 1,000 miles, but they are made by coral polyps as small as one sixteenth of an inch.

headline: Talking to Children About Race, Policing and Violence
abstract: Join six journalists from The New York Times for a live chat on Tuesday, July 12, at 2 p.m. ET about talking to kids about race, policing and violence.
lead_paragraph: Join six journalists from The New York Times for a live chat on Tuesday, July 12, at 2 p.m. ET about talking to kids about race, policing and violence.

headline: John Doe 150 Deposition
abstract: The 2014 deposition of John Doe 150 related to a lawsuit between Penn State and Pennsylvania Manufacturers’ Association Insurance.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 deposition of John Doe 150 related to a lawsuit between Penn State and Pennsylvania Manufacturers’ Association Insurance.

headline: Two JACK Quartet Founders to Depart
abstract: Ari Streisfeld and Kevin McFarland are leaving this new music group, and being replaced by Austin Wulliman and Jay Campbell.
lead_paragraph: The JACK Quartet, which has emerged in recent years as a vital force in the new music world, is getting some new blood: the ensemble announced Tuesday morning that two of its founding members plan to leave this summer and will be replaced by new musicians.

headline: Donald Trump Rebukes Ruth Bader Ginsburg for Deriding His Candidacy
abstract: Justice Ginsburg had said she “can’t imagine what the country would be” under Mr. Trump. He called her remarks “highly inappropriate” and said she should apologize.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Tuesday assailed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court for speaking out on the presidential race, calling her disdainful remarks about his candidacy “highly inappropriate” and suggesting that she owed other justices an apology.

headline: House Panel Questions Loretta Lynch on Hillary Clinton’s Emails
abstract: After nearly five hours, the attorney general appeared to emerge unscathed from a contentious hearing on her decision to shut down a yearlong investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans wanted to talk about Hillary Clinton’s emails on Tuesday. Attorney General Loretta Lynch and her Democratic defenders wanted to talk about almost anything else.

headline: Child Care Expansion Takes a Toll on Poorly Paid Workers
abstract: Early childhood services are meant to relieve poverty, but a new study says they can actually generate poverty in the predominantly female work force.
lead_paragraph: Carmella Salinas has worked steadily for 14 years as an early-childhood-education teacher, taking care of 4- and 5-year-olds at the nonprofit Family Learning Center in the hardscrabble community of Española, just north of Santa Fe, N.M. Even so, she rarely earns enough to cover all her bills, and has more than once received a disconnection letter from the water, gas or electric company. A few months ago, she arrived home with her 10-year-old son, Aaron, to find the electricity shut off.

headline: Lost at the Louvre? There’s an App for That
abstract: This museum has introduced a geo-locator application for multimedia devices that can help visitors navigate their routes to their favorite artworks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With crowds 10 deep in front of the Mona Lisa, how can a visitor plot an escape within the vast maze of the Louvre? Let the bouncing blue ball on your phone or tablet show you the way.

headline: Sliced at Tableside, That’s Not Beef. It’s a Beet.
abstract: The root gets a lavish preparation at Agern, a Nordic outpost in Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: At Agern, Claus Meyer’s graceful Nordic restaurant, which opened inside Grand Central Terminal in April, the most theatrical moment of a meal hinges on a humble root vegetable.

headline: Opinion Editors Tone Down Piece on Race, and Some Readers Cry Foul
abstract: When a published article needs to be recast, editors should make it clear to readers what has happened, and why.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Michael Eric Dyson were greeted with a passionate and sharp critique of white America when they saw his essay posted on The New York Times opinion section last Thursday night.

headline: Why Matt Damon and Paul Greengrass Couldn’t Quit Jason Bourne
abstract: The actor and the director discuss what led them to an additional chapter in the high-velocity life of a once amnesiac governmental assassin.
lead_paragraph: Paul Greengrass couldn’t have been clearer. He was done with Jason Bourne. And that meant his loyal star, Matt Damon, wouldn’t be returning as the covert operative for the C.I.A. who unraveled agency conspiracies while he recovered his memory.

headline: The Founding Fathers’ Fears
abstract: A political science professor responds to an Op-Ed article about the Declaration of Independence and racial exclusion.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Julian Woodhouse, Fashion Designer (and Army Officer)
abstract: New York’s men’s fashion week gets off to a good start with a new designer’s impressive presentation.
lead_paragraph: There would probably be reason enough to salute the appearance on the first morning of New York Fashion Week: Men’s of a designer who is an openly gay married African-American first lieutenant in the United States Army. That Julian Woodhouse, 26, is talented made the kickoff of another local fashion cycle seem all the more auspicious.

headline: A Photographer Captures Oxford University in the 1970s
abstract: Paddy Summerfield captured students at leisure — and in states of loneliness.
lead_paragraph: Paddy Summerfield captured students at leisure — and in states of loneliness.

headline: Images That Capture the Leisure — and Loneliness — of College
abstract: On the campus of Oxford University between 1968 and 1978, the photographer Paddy Summerfield captured students at leisure — and in various states of isolation and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Sprawled on grass, floating down a river, or gazing blankly into the distance — all the subjects captured, unawares, in the photographer Paddy Summerfield’s new book “The Oxford Pictures” share a certain listlessness. In 1968, having been “thrown out” of Guildford School of Art (“the staff weren’t particularly sympathetic towards my vision”), Summerfield returned to his hometown of Oxford, England. He spent the summers of the next 10 years wandering around the grounds of the elite Oxford University, where he photographed students at leisure.

headline: James Stavridis, Retired Admiral, Is Being Vetted as Hillary Clinton’s Running Mate
abstract: Some close to Mrs. Clinton say she was always likely to have someone with military experience on her vice-presidential shortlist.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign is vetting James G. Stavridis, a retired four-star Navy admiral who served as the 16th supreme allied commander at NATO, as a possible running mate, according to a person with knowledge of the vetting process.

headline: Turkey Makes Overtures to Minorities, but Old Enmities Linger
abstract: The government denies the Armenian genocide and threatens to punish countries that recognize it, but there are signs that history may be getting its due.
lead_paragraph: KARS, Turkey — The history of this city, about 30 miles from the border with Armenia, may best be told through its former Armenian cathedral, the Church of the Holy Apostles, poised at the base of an imposing fortress.

headline: Can Alexa Chung Become the Tory Burch of Britain?
abstract: The 32-year-old British TV host and It Girl is introducing her own brand, and it has some interesting implications.
lead_paragraph: When Alexa Chung, the 32-year-old English It Girl/television host/Madewell collaborator/British Vogue contributing editor known for combining loafers with tiny tea dresses, and high-waisted denim shorts with tailored jackets, announced this week that she was starting her own fashion brand, her myriad style followers greeted the news with paroxysms of joy. Comparisons to that other English personality who traded pop-culture stardom for industry credibility, Victoria Beckham, were suddenly rife.

headline: Regulators Ask Tesla About Autopilot
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has sent a letter to Tesla indicating the agency is investigating whether there are defects in the automaker's Autopilot system.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has sent a letter to Tesla indicating the agency is investigating whether there are defects in the automaker's Autopilot system.

headline: As U.S. Investigates Fatal Tesla Crash, Company Defends Autopilot System
abstract: Even as regulators are asking new questions in the wake of a fatal crash involving Tesla’s Model S car, executives say their technology is safe if properly used.
lead_paragraph: Even as federal safety officials step up their investigation of the fatal crash of a driver operating a Tesla car with its Autopilot system engaged, the company continues to defend the self-driving technology as safe when properly used.

headline: No More Waiting in Line?
abstract: A reader writes that the trend of rich people paying someone to wait in line for them is “indicative of an increasingly isolated global elite.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Record Prize Money at U.S. Open
abstract: The record payout, an increase of $4 million from 2015, will produce raises of about 10 percent per round for players.
lead_paragraph: Prize money at the United States Open will rise to a record $46.3 million at this year’s tournament, the United States Tennis Association announced Tuesday.

headline: ‘Shooter’ on USA Postponed After Dallas Attack
abstract: The premiere of this new series about a former sniper is being delayed in response to last week’s shootings, which killed five police officers.
lead_paragraph: “Shooter,” a new USA Network series about a former sniper, is being postponed in response to last week’s gunman attack in Dallas, which killed five police officers.

headline: The University of California’s Student Body
abstract: Janet Napolitano, the president of the University of California, discusses a rise in in-state admissions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Donald Trump and Nietzsche
abstract: A professor writes that Donald Trump is “a crude parody” of the philosopher.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 1916: Germany Shells English Town
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A German submarine fires on the British port of Durham in July 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The following communiqué is issued by Viscount French, Commander-in-Chief of the Home Forces. Last night [July 11] at half-past ten o’clock a German submarine appeared off the small defenceless port of Seaham, Durham. It approached to within a few hundred yards of the town and opened fire. About thirty shells were fired from a three-inch gun. Twenty shells fell in the direction of Dalton Dale and ten around the Seaham coal mine. A woman who was walking in the neighborhood of the mine was seriously wounded and succumbed this morning [July 12]. A house was struck by a shell. No other loss of life or material damage is reported. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 13, 1916

headline: With Competition in Tatters, the Rip of Inequality Widens
abstract: The decline in competition in many American industries costs more than just rising prices. It stunts entrepreneurship, hinders workers’ mobility and wages, and slows productivity.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is expected to rule soon on the biggest beer merger ever: a $100 billion-plus combination of Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller into a colossus that will reap some $3 out of every $10 spent on beer around the world.

headline: Jeurys Familia, Intimidating on the Mound, Stays Balanced with Clubhouse Humor
abstract: Familia, the Mets’ closer, has come a long way from a humble upbringing in the Dominican Republic, earning his first trip to the All-Star Game.
lead_paragraph: On the mound, the Mets’ Jeurys Familia strikes fear in opponents with his imposing 6-foot-3, 240-pound frame and his 96-mile-per-hour sinkers, among the hardest in the major leagues.

headline: Brooklyn Gang Struts in Vintage Ralph Lauren
abstract: A colorful crowd celebrated “Bury Me With The Lo On”, a chronicle of a Brooklyn gang’s obsession with Ralph Lauren.
lead_paragraph: A colorful crowd celebrated “Bury Me With The Lo On”, a chronicle of a Brooklyn gang’s obsession with Ralph Lauren.

headline: At Japan Cuts Festival, Films by Sion Sono That Don’t Fit His Bad-Boy Label
abstract: Japan Society’s festival will screen 29 features, including New York premieres that show a different side of Japan’s most recognizable director.
lead_paragraph: A dead girl’s body continues to grow hair, which is made into extensions that kill the people who wear them (“Exte,” 2007). A teenage boy discovers that he has an exceptional talent for taking photos up women’s skirts (“Love Exposure,” 2008). A crooked dealer in fancy pet fish is also a serial killer who, along with his half-clothed wife, joyously dismembers the bodies of his victims (“Cold Fish,” 2010).

headline: A Game-Changing Ping Pong Table
abstract: A luxurious upgrade you won’t want to hide in the basement.
lead_paragraph: Ping-Pong was first played in Victorian England, often with a row of books laid across the dining table as a net and a champagne cork volleyed between paddles made from cigar-box tops. Recently, the sport has been pursued with less glamorous accouterments. Until the Milan-based furniture designer Paolo Calcagni created perhaps the ultimate table: custom-hewed from flame-grained walnut briar-root (it can also be made from cherry or rosewood) with elegantly angular brass and wood legs and a net of Tuscan-tanned leather. Zebrawood paddles included.

headline: Joseph Abboud: Spring 2017
abstract: Mr. Abboud’s spring 2017 show.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Abboud’s spring 2017 show.

headline: Talking to Kids About Racial Violence
abstract: It’s tempting to avoid painful conversations. Experts say we shouldn’t.
lead_paragraph: My husband is white; as an Armenian man, I am a hue darker, and our 10-year-old daughter is biracial, with brown skin. We’ve tried to shield her from some of the recent painful news stories related to bias. But after last week’s killings of two African-American men by police officers, and then the killings of five Dallas police officers, we need to be ready to talk with her about the terrors of prejudice.

headline: Emerging Republican Platform Goes Far to the Right
abstract: Republican delegates neared approval of a party platform that is staunchly conservative in matters of gender, sexuality and marriage.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Republicans moved on Tuesday toward adopting a staunchly conservative platform that takes a strict, traditionalist view of the family and child rearing, bars military women from combat, describes coal as a “clean” energy source and declares pornography a “public health crisis.”

headline: The 2016 Presidential Election
abstract: Carolyn Ryan, The Times’s senior editor for politics, talks with Times political reporters Yamiche Alcindor, Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick about the state of the 2016 presidential elections.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Ryan, The Times’s senior editor for politics, talks with Times political reporters Yamiche Alcindor, Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick about the state of the 2016 presidential elections.

headline: Chicken Salad | Recipe Lab
abstract: Poached chicken, fresh tarragon and buttery pecans elevate the classic chicken salad.
lead_paragraph: Poached chicken, fresh tarragon and buttery pecans elevate the classic chicken salad.

headline: Regaining Chicken Salad’s Dignity, Any Time of Day
abstract: Make the classic with care and good ingredients to bring it back to its origins as a special-occasion summer meal.
lead_paragraph: The first time I was served a Southern luncheon plate, my mind froze, unable to make sense of what was in front of me. Why was a mound of chicken salad next to a mound of red Jell-O? What was their relationship to the dollop of mayonnaise and the celery sticks? How did the cheese straws fit in?

headline: A Look at the ‘Loving’ Trailer
abstract: The new film based on the interracial couple Richard and Mildred Loving, will open Nov. 4.
lead_paragraph: “I know we have some enemies. But we have some friends too.”

headline: Totally Thames Festival Celebrates London’s Major Waterway
abstract: All September, this thoroughfare will be a stage for music and for artworks like “Floating Dreams.”
lead_paragraph: London — “Floating Dreams,” a glowing, three-story box made of illustrated rice paper panels; and “Fluxland,” a roving freight boat covered in mirrors, are among the artworks that will appear on the River Thames in London this September for the Totally Thames festival, organizers announced this week.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Theresa May, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
abstract: Ms. May is set to become the country’s leader on Wednesday. She’s been a long-serving cabinet minister and has promised to guide Britain out of the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Theresa May, the new Conservative Party leader, will become Britain’s second female prime minister on Wednesday, entering 10 Downing Street three weeks after Britain voted to leave the European Union.

headline: Brooklyn Man Arrested a Day After Being Shot by Officers
abstract: Paul Mathurin, who was wounded during a confrontation with the police in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens on Sunday, was arrested on gun and drug possession charges.
lead_paragraph: The man was acting erratically, firing a handgun and threatening people with the weapon in a Brooklyn neighborhood, the police said. When three officers responded and confronted him, he turned and pointed the gun toward them, prompting them to fire 12 rounds, according to the authorities.

headline: Tim Coppens: Spring 2017
abstract: Mr. Coppens’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Coppens’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Have the Dallas Police Improved? Depends on Whom You Ask
abstract: Though Chief David O. Brown has worked to steer his department away from a history of racism and abuse, black residents expressed a wide range of views of the police.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — When Andre Stubblefield leaves his dilapidated apartment complex in southern Dallas, he always carries his work gloves, vest and hard hat, even when he is not going to work. The police have stopped him regularly over the years, asking for identification — about four times in the last four months alone. So he carries his work attire to show that he is a working man, not a criminal.

headline: Times Reporter Descends Into Pokémania
abstract: Even the staff of The New York Times isn’t immune to the charms of Pokéman Go.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Mike Isaac, a Times reporter based in San Francisco, describes his weekend spent playing Pokémon Go.

headline: Garciavelez: Spring 2017
abstract: Carlos Garciavelez’s spring show.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Garciavelez’s spring show.

headline: Parting Words for Bernie Sanders
abstract: Supporters of Bernie Sanders, known for their perseverance and passion, say farewell to a campaign they hope will give way to a movement as he endorses Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Bernie Sanders, known for their perseverance and passion, say farewell to a campaign they hope will give way to a movement as he endorses Hillary Clinton.

headline: Epidurals in Childbirth: I’ll Do It My Way
abstract: Readers say there is no wrong way or right way to give birth.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New York Council Won’t Vote on Police Reform Bills, but Agency Agrees to Changes
abstract: The proposals, which have broad support but have languished in the Council, will be handled internally by the Police Department, Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito has told her colleagues.
lead_paragraph: A package of police reform measures, known in New York’s criminal justice circles as the Right to Know Act, will not be considered for passage by the City Council, even though the bills have broad support.

headline: Common, Kellan Lutz and Nick Cannon Party at Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: CFDA and Cadillac host an opening night party for New York Fashion Week: Men’s. Celebrities included Kellan Lutz, Shaun White and Jerry O’Connell.
lead_paragraph: CFDA and Cadillac host an opening night party for New York Fashion Week: Men’s. Celebrities included Kellan Lutz, Shaun White and Jerry O’Connell.

headline: Common, Kellan Lutz and Nick Cannon Party at Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: CFDA and Cadillac host opening night party for New York Men’s Fashion Week. Celebrities also included Kellan Lutz, Shaun White and Jerry O’Connell.
lead_paragraph: Another installment of New York Fashion Week: Men’s kicked off on Monday with an opening night party at the Cadillac House, the car brand’s new public space in Lower Manhattan where designers like Timo Weiland and Gypsy Sport are showing their spring men’s collections. Celebrities like Nick Cannon, Kellan Lutz, Shaun White and Jerry O’Connell mingled with fashion insiders like Nick Wooster and Steven Kolb, before Common took the stage and performed his new song, “Love Star.”

headline: A Pop-Up for NYC Surfers — Minus the Board Shorts and Kitsch
abstract: Through Sunday, Token Surfboards is selling its grittier take on hang-ten style at a temporary shop in Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: Just a couple years ago in New York, surf fashion was all the rage. Stores like Saturdays NYC and the now-closed Mollusk Surf Shop ignited an international craze for wave-riding essentials in concrete jungles. So what can Token Surfboards, a next-generation surf brand based in Brooklyn, do to carve out its own niche? “There are a lot of surf brands, and that industry can seem formulaic,” says Christian Boalt, who along with his wife, Lisa, runs the year-old brand. “It’s a lot of recycled themes, either folky or preppy or tropical. I’ve surfed my whole life, but my interests and inspiration are much wider,” he adds. “We don’t try to follow the rules set by older brands.” Token sets itself apart from the mainstream — even the fashionable — with a miscreant approach to the style.

headline: Josephine Baker’s France
abstract: The entertainer, born in St. Louis, spent time in Paris and the latter half of her life at Château des Milandes, a Renaissance castle overlooking the Dordogne in the Périgord region of France.
lead_paragraph: The entertainer, born in St. Louis, spent time in Paris and the latter half of her life at Château des Milandes, a Renaissance castle overlooking the Dordogne in the Périgord region of France.

headline: Exploring the France That Josephine Baker Loved
abstract: The American entertainer had a rich relationship with her adopted country — and it with her.
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw Josephine Baker up close I was in London. I went to the Alexander Calder exhibition at the Tate Modern and there, at the entrance to the exhibition, was a wire sculpture of Baker.

headline: It’s Time to Think About Refinancing Your Mortgage (Again)
abstract: Homeowners can thank British voters and global central banks for lower rates, but so far lenders haven’t fully passed on falling rates to borrowers.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good time to check the rate on your home mortgage, because you might save money by refinancing. For that, American homeowners can thank British voters, central banks in Europe and Japan, and a global economy that just can’t get out of first gear.

headline: Baseball’s Winners and Losers (Based on Expectations)
abstract: The Baltimore Orioles were expected to be mediocre but now project to win 95 games. A look at baseball’s top overachievers and underachievers.
lead_paragraph: The All-Star break is traditionally a time to step back and judge how teams are doing. But rather than looking at the standings, it may be more instructive to compare each team with its expectations before the season began.

headline: In Iraq, Shades of Vietnam
abstract: A reader bemoans plans to add more troops in Iraq, fearing a repeat of America’s misguided intervention in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Grains Find a Home at Gristmill
abstract: The Park Slope newcomer emphasizes seasonal foods; Meat Hook takes up residence in a brewery; and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Gristmill No, the restaurant does not grind its own flour. But the chef and owner, Jake Novick-Finder, works grains into many dishes, including pizzas, panzanella, toasts and pies. His choices include spelt, triticale, cornmeal and wheat, notably warthog wheat, a richly flavored hard red wheat from Massachusetts. (Most of the grains, like his seasonal ingredients, come from farms in the Northeast.) Mr. Novick-Finder, 26, started cooking at age 12 in the pastry kitchen of Chanterelle, and has worked at Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, and in Boston. The restaurant is compact, with a bar area and a chef’s table facing the open kitchen. (Opens Wednesday): 289 Fifth Avenue (First Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-499-2424, gristmillbk.com.

headline: ‘That Ignoramus’: 2 French Scholars of Radical Islam Turn Bitter Rivals
abstract: A falling-out between the academics, Olivier Roy and Gilles Kepel, presents an important question: Which man holds the key to understanding the phenomenon?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — What propels Islamist terrorism and attacks against France is more than an academic debate: The answer shapes policy toward blunting the threat.

headline: Hyperloop One Co-Founder Claims Harassment in Lawsuit
abstract: Brogan BamBrogan and three other former executives sued the start-up on Tuesday, claiming that they were harassed and wrongfully fired.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Elon Musk proposed a very-high-speed train from San Francisco to Los Angeles, many analysts and observers regarded the idea as ludicrous. Shervin Pishevar and Brogan BamBrogan thought otherwise and began building a company to prove the naysayers wrong.

headline: Taser International Dominates the Police Body Camera Market
abstract: The company, best known for its stun guns, has drawn criticism for its relationships with the police and its sales tactics, which it says are common.
lead_paragraph: When Micah Johnson went on a deadly shooting rampage in Dallas last week, body cameras worn by police officers were rolling, capturing at least 170 hours of video of the mayhem.

headline: Pastor in Zimbabwe Is Arrested as Anger Toward Robert Mugabe Builds
abstract: The activism of the Rev. Evan Mawarire, who organized the country’s largest protests in a decade, has galvanized public outrage over the president’s rule.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The authorities in Zimbabwe on Tuesday arrested a pastor who organized the country’s largest protests in a decade, and whose activism has galvanized public anger over President Robert Mugabe’s 36-year rule and the nation’s crumbling economy.

headline: Ahead of the Election, Americans’ Climate Concerns Slosh
abstract: A new analysis of voters’ attitudes on global warming show partisans are alarmed and energized but most Americans are focused elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Fresh analysis from a research group tracking voter views on global warming shows the country’s range of attitudes sloshing more than surging.

headline: Ireland, Home to U.S. ‘Inversions,’ Sees Huge Growth in G.D.P.
abstract: The country, which attracts companies with a low corporate tax rate, saw its economy expand 26.3 percent last year, according to new figures.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, politicians, lawmakers and officials have derided “inversion deals,” which allow an American company to move its headquarters overseas to cut its tax bills. In Ireland, they are celebrating them.

headline: Philando Castile’s Last Night: Tacos and Laughs, Then a Drive
abstract: Philando Castile’s family recalled in detail his final hours before a fatal police stop in Minnesota. The official version of what happened remains largely opaque.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Philando Castile had just finished getting his hair styled last Wednesday when he called his sister, Allysza, and offered to deliver dinner to the suburban house she shares with their mother.

headline: Contested Sale of ExamWorks Could Put Lawyers in Line of Fire
abstract: A suit arising from a buyout of ExamWorks claims a conflict of interest involving the law firm Paul Hastings, and it could affect lawyers in other deals.
lead_paragraph: Then they came for the lawyers.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn Will Be on Ballot as Labour Party Schedules Election in Britain
abstract: Mr. Corbyn faced a revolt by fellow Labour lawmakers after Britain’s June 23 referendum to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The governing body of Britain’s opposition Labour Party agreed on Tuesday to schedule a new election for its leadership, and ruled that Jeremy Corbyn, who faced a revolt from fellow Labour lawmakers, would be assured of a place on the ballot.

headline: ‘You Broke My Heart’: Supporters of Bernie Sanders React to Endorsement
abstract: Backers of Bernie Sanders expressed disappointment and sadness at his endorsement of Hillary Clinton, with many saying they still would not vote for her.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders offered a full-throated endorsement of Hillary Clinton on Tuesday, urging his supporters to get behind the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee. But many of his most loyal followers are not feeling it just yet.

headline: Where Pokémon Should Not Go
abstract: The digital beasts have been reported at Auschwitz and memorials for the Holocaust and the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Are there places where Pokémon should not be allowed to tread?

headline: Back on a Motorbike: Old-School Reporting at the Tour de France
abstract: In the decades before France Télévisions’ live broadcasting system, many reporters followed the Tour de France from a motorbike.
lead_paragraph: REVEL, France — Most of the reporters at the Tour de France, including me, don’t see much of the racing through their own eyes.

headline: Roland Fryer Answers Reader Questions About His Police Force Study
abstract: A finding that there was no bias against black civilians in police shootings provoked debate, mostly about the volume of police encounters and the scope of the data used.
lead_paragraph: A new study on police force found no bias against black civilians in police shootings in 10 cities and counties, including Houston. It did find bias against blacks in every other type of force, like the use of hands or batons. The study provoked debate after it was posted on Monday, mostly about the volume of police encounters and the scope of the data it used. Below, the author of the study, Roland G. Fryer Jr., a professor of economics at Harvard, answered questions from readers.

headline: Whistle-Blower on N.S.A. Wiretapping Is Set to Keep Law License
abstract: Thomas M. Tamm, a former Justice Department lawyer who said he was a source for a 2005 New York Times article, will receive a “public censure” but is likely to keep his license.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A District of Columbia bar committee has agreed to a deal that would let a former Justice Department lawyer keep his law license even though he said he was one of the sources for a 2005 article in The New York Times about the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without the court-approved warrants ordinarily required for domestic spying.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Is Invited to Speak on Democratic Convention’s First Night
abstract: The invitation from the Clinton campaign to speak earlier than vice-presidential picks normally do was taken by many as a sign that the senator would not be chosen.
lead_paragraph: In an apparent sign that Senator Elizabeth Warren will not be named Hillary Clinton’s running mate, Ms. Warren was invited by Mrs. Clinton’s campaign on Tuesday to deliver a prime-time address on the first night of the Democratic convention this month — a marquee speaking slot but one that is earlier than vice-presidential picks typically appear.

headline: Bright Lights Focusing on AMC’s Purchase of Odeon & UCI Cinemas
abstract: As well as wrapping up Guy Hands’s stint in European cinema, the takeover may offer a sneak preview of future deal-making moves.
lead_paragraph: AMC Entertainment’s purchase of Odeon & UCI Cinemas is both the trailer and the closing credits. On Tuesday, New York-listed AMC said it would buy its European peer for 921 million pounds ($1.2 billion) including debt. That brings the curtain down on Odeon’s epic stint in private-equity ownership — and serves as a preview of coming attractions.

headline: EFM: Spring 2017
abstract: Donrad Duncan’s spring sportswear looks.
lead_paragraph: Donrad Duncan’s spring sportswear looks.

headline: Loris Diran: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Review: ‘Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru’ Depicts a Self-Help Prophet
abstract: This documentary, an immersive look at one of Mr. Robbins’s Date With Destiny mega-seminars, could pass for a promotional video.
lead_paragraph: Tony Robbins inhales your pain. Where a lesser person might be exhausted by the hordes of supplicants seeking transformation from one of his annual Date With Destiny seminars, Mr. Robbins only becomes more energized as the six-day event unfolds and the unburdenings pile up.

headline: Review: In ‘The Infiltrator,’ Bryan Cranston Tunnels Into a Menacing Drug Network
abstract: Based on a memoir, the film depicts a federal agent who poses as a money launderer to combat Pablo Escobar’s cocaine cartel.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, Bryan Cranston’s character in “The Infiltrator” is an alternate version of Walter White, the good-guy-turned-rotten he portrayed so magnetically in “Breaking Bad.” This seedy, drug-soaked thriller is based on a memoir by Robert Mazur (Mr. Cranston), a federal undercover agent who in 1986 posed as a high-rolling money launderer in a sting operation against Pablo Escobar’s Colombian drug cartel. Unlike Walter, Robert is a good guy who remains good when faced with temptation.

headline: Thousands Protest Sex Assaults at Bull Run in Pamplona, Spain
abstract: Fifteen people have been arrested in separate cases of sexual assault at the annual San Fermín festival, amid heightened awareness of such attacks in Europe.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The northern Spanish city of Pamplona has become famous worldwide for its high-risk festival in which revelers run through narrow streets in the early morning with charging bulls on their way to the ring.

headline: Jordan Spieth’s and Rory McIlroy’s Two Approaches to an Olympic Snub
abstract: McIlroy said skipping the Rio Games was not a difficult decision; Spieth said the decision would “loom over” him for the length of the Games.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — The ethos of the world’s most famed athletic competition is known as the Olympic movement, which in the men’s golf community is best signified by the stampede of top players dashing away from the 2016 Rio Games.

headline: Theresa May, Untested and Ascending to Manage ‘Brexit’
abstract: No one is quite sure if Ms. May, the next British prime minister, can successfully balance the nation’s economic and political needs with the exit from the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Theresa May took over on Wednesday as Britain’s prime minister facing a nation in such flux that she has a chance to leave a lasting imprint.

headline: Review: In Tracy Tynan’s Memoir, ‘Wear and Tear,’ Feeding on Explosive Drama
abstract: Ms. Tynan recounts life with her combative, hard-partying parents, the theater critic Kenneth Tynan and the novelist Elaine Dundy.
lead_paragraph: You’re no one in this life — or in the afterlife, at any rate — until one of your children has written an account of what an appalling parent you were.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Blink — Robert Frank,’ a Portrait of a Quintessential New York Artist
abstract: Laura Israel’s documentary is less like a full-scale biography than like a magazine profile of Mr. Frank’s long and prodigious career.
lead_paragraph: Laura Israel’s new film is called “Don’t Blink — Robert Frank,” and it’s at once a welcome admonition and an efficient motto. This compact, fast-moving portrait of the artist proceeds through a flurry of images, many of them gleaned from Mr. Frank’s long and prodigious career. The man himself, barreling through his early 90s with a mixture of impatience, resignation and good humor, has spent a lifetime looking, mostly at North American people and landscapes, but also somehow inward, using cameras as instruments of documentation and introspection.

headline: Africa’s Capital of Cool
abstract: With its thriving contemporary art and nightlife scenes, the Ghanaian city of Accra has become a cosmopolitan hot spot. Here’s what to do there.
lead_paragraph: On a sultry night in Accra, the air smells of wood smoke, brine from the wet but welcome breezes off the Gulf of Guinea and the plumeria trees that line the streets. This, and the soundtrack of chirping insects, barking dogs and gunning motor scooters, feels quintessentially West African.

headline: Robert Geller: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Sharon LaFraniere, Simon Romero and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: The Dark Magic of Black Jewelry
abstract: Spellbinding brooches, bangles, earrings and rings — in onyx, enamel or ebony.
lead_paragraph: Spellbinding brooches, bangles, earrings and rings — in onyx, enamel or ebony.

headline: An Opera That Springs From China but Laps Distant Shores
abstract: Qian Yi, who comes from the kunqu tradition, has performed in the West many times but faces new challenges in her latest vehicle, “Paradise Interrupted.”
lead_paragraph: Even the loveliest and most meaningful tribute may exact a significant toll, as the Chinese opera diva Qian Yi can attest.

headline: The Curious Case of the Fainting Models
abstract: Healthy young men and women, hired specifically for their freakish physical gifts, can sometimes pass out at a fashion show. What gives?
lead_paragraph: At the New York Fashion Week: Men’s shows last February, more than a dozen male models gathered in a building in the West Village for a presentation of the California-based line CWST. The label’s designers, Joe Sadler and Derek Buse, had been inspired by the Pacific Northwest and grunge rock. The models stood on high podiums, dressed in multilayers of wool and shearling, including beanies, with hot lights shining on them for over an hour.

headline: Carlos Campos: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Airbus to Sharply Cut Production of A380 Jumbo Jets
abstract: Airbus’s flagship model, which lists for more than $400 million, has been a tough sell with airlines increasingly concerned with fuel economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Airbus said on Tuesday that it would sharply curtail production of the A380 superjumbo jet, the world’s largest passenger plane, as airline demand dwindles for supersize aircraft.

headline: Pokémon Go? Get Outta Here!
abstract: Does Pokémon Go show that technology can bring people into the real world, or is it just tying them in a new way to the digital realm?

headline: Can the Circus Go On Without Elephants? Ringling Bets It Can
abstract: After Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey eliminated elephants from its lineup, the circus must balance its nostalgic appeal with modernization efforts.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — The wrinkled leading ladies of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus, wearing sequined headpieces and holding each other’s tails, performed their last routine in May. It was the end of an era: Animal-rights laws had finally made elephants, the 134-year symbol of the American circus, economically unviable as traveling entertainment.

headline: Bernie’s Uninspiring Endorsement
abstract: Was Tuesday’s speech really the best Sanders could do?
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders went off for a month to contemplate life after the revolution, and this was the best he could come up with? “Secretary Clinton has won the Democratic nominating process, and I congratulate her for that.”

headline: Review: ‘Twyla Tharp and Three Dances’ Lends a Look of Sensuous Improvisation
abstract: This program at the Joyce Theater covers 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Does the title “Twyla Tharp and Three Dances” — at the Joyce Theater through July 23 — lead you to expect to see Ms. Tharp onstage? Well, during the final applause on Monday, Ms. Tharp advanced down one aisle; two of her dancers leaned down and lifted her up to join them. The camaraderie between her and the group — cool, good-humored, no-nonsense — left an affable impression.

headline: How to Protect Privacy While Using Pokémon Go and Other Apps
abstract: The game’s developer made expansive permission requests — in error, it says, and it uses only basic data — but many apps make similar requests.
lead_paragraph: Pokémon Go has attracted hordes of players within days of its release. The mobile game has also attracted concerns about just how vulnerable our personal data can be in the hands of seemingly benign applications.

headline: For Diane Kruger, It’s All About Her Brows and Matte Red Lipstick
abstract: The actress shares her European beauty secrets.
lead_paragraph: The actress Diane Kruger, 39, has a full slate this summer with roles in “The Infiltrator,” opening Wednesday, and “Disorder,” which will be released in the United States by mid-next month.

headline: Season 2 of ‘Mr. Robot’ Turns Inward From the Cyberworld
abstract: This USA Network thriller focuses now on its maladjusted hacker hero’s identity crisis rather than on the conspiracy elements of its dystopia.
lead_paragraph: This time, “Mr. Robot” isn’t sneaking up on anyone. Last summer, this cyberdowner drama was a stealth success, arriving with little fanfare on the lightweight USA Network and walking away with a Golden Globe, a Peabody Award and widespread agreement that it was the coolest show on television. It returns for its second season on Wednesday, with the momentum of that attention and the weight of expectations. It’s even added its own live after-show, the less than elegantly titled “Hacking Robot.”

headline: Review: ‘The A Word’ Takes Unblinking Look at Autism
abstract: This six-part series on SundanceTV depicts the pain and tensions in a British family confronting an autism diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: Lately, television has quietly been doing better by people with disabilities, a trend that takes a significant step forward with “The A Word,” which begins Wednesday on SundanceTV.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Theresa May, South China Sea: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: David Cameron Gets Hustled Out of Downing Street, but the Cat Stays
abstract: The only resident of 10 Downing Street to be spared the indignity of one of Britain’s fastest political transitions in recent memory will be Larry the Cat.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The cat can stay.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $18.3 million

headline: $2,700 for Hillary Clinton at ‘Hamilton’? That Would Be Enough
abstract: A benefit performance of the hit musical raised money for Mrs. Clinton’s campaign — and featured speeches by the presumptive nominee and Lin-Manuel Miranda, the show’s creator and former star.
lead_paragraph: How does a former senator ... stateswoman ... hoping to build a financial stockpile ... find a way to make it worth her donors’ while?

headline: William H. McNeill, Professor and Prolific Author, Dies at 98
abstract: Professor McNeill’s catholic exploration of world history widened the traditional Eurocentric approach to the subject.
lead_paragraph: William H. McNeill, a professor and prolific author whose catholic exploration of world history widened the traditional Eurocentric approach to the subject, died on Friday in Torrington, Conn. He was 98.

headline: Two Hostages From Bangladesh Standoff Are Still Missing
abstract: Amnesty International urged the government to clarify the whereabouts of one of the men, who were questioned after surviving a terrorist attack on a Dhaka restaurant.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Amnesty International called on the Bangladeshi government on Tuesday to clarify the whereabouts of a former hostage from the recent attack on a Dhaka restaurant who was detained by the police but whose fate is now uncertain.

headline: Gypsy Sport: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: A Fight to Make ‘We Shall Overcome’ and ‘This Land Is Your Land’ Copyright Free
abstract: A firm that put “Happy Birthday” into the public domain now wants to rescind copyright protection for “We Shall Overcome” and “This Land Is Your Land.”
lead_paragraph: The song has rung out at marches and vigils throughout the country over the last week: “We Shall Overcome.”

headline: Theresa May and the Cutthroat Conservatives
abstract: Britain’s new prime minister inherits a raft of challenges, both for the country and within her party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BREXIT means Brexit, and we’re going to make a success of it,” Theresa May said on Monday, when she became the new leader of the Conservative Party — and therefore Britain’s new prime minister. It was the one discordant note in an otherwise clear, wide-ranging speech.

headline: Street Talk
abstract: Whether the subject is cavorting dogs or an outdoor filming, New Yorkers express their opinions to strangers in their common living room.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Administration Rebuts Soldier’s Suit That Calls ISIS Fight Illegal
abstract: While Mr. Obama has not received explicit authorization for the war, a legal brief said Congress’s funding for military action had conferred that authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, arguing that Congress’s funding of the fight against the Islamic State amounts to a ratification of President Obama’s power to wage that war, has urged a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit that says the military action is illegal.

headline: Cease-Fire Appears to Hold in South Sudan’s Capital, Juba
abstract: Hours after a truce was reached to end fighting between rival groups of soldiers, thousands of civilians remained in churches and schools out of fear and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — After a weekend of sudden bloodshed, an uneasy calm has fallen over South Sudan’s capital.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, Informed by His Family, Steps Into Debate on Race
abstract: The New York City mayor continues to push for changes in police tactics meant to bridge the gap between law enforcement and minorities.
lead_paragraph: With racial issues roiling the nation, Mayor Bill de Blasio has stepped to the fore, appearing on national television, speaking at church services and holding forth at news conferences to deliver a nuanced message of reconciliation.

headline: D.E.A. Needed Warrant to Track Suspect’s Phone, Judge Says
abstract: Seized drugs could not be used as evidence, a judge ruled, because the D.E.A. found the drugs after tracking a cellphone without a warrant.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that drugs seized from a man charged in a narcotics case could not be used as evidence, because agents had not obtained a warrant for a covert cellphone tracking device that led them to his Washington Heights apartment, where the drugs were found.

headline: Yale Drops Case Against Worker Who Smashed Window Depicting Slaves
abstract: The university will not press charges after a black dining hall employee broke a stained-glass panel in Calhoun College, the name of which has been the subject of intense debate on campus.
lead_paragraph: As Yale continues to debate the legacy of John C. Calhoun, an alumnus and leading 19th-century politician and slaveholder for whom one of its residential colleges is named, the university said on Tuesday that it would not press charges in the case of a black dining hall worker who smashed a stained-glass panel depicting slaves carrying cotton.

headline: Gretchen Carlson, Former Fox Anchor, Speaks Publicly About Sexual Harassment Lawsuit
abstract: Ms. Carlson repeated the allegations she made last week against Roger Ailes, her former boss at the news network.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — When Gretchen Carlson was asked how her last week had been, she looked down at her wrist.

headline: N. Hoolywood: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Lottery Will Cover Citizenship Application Fee for New York State Residents
abstract: The contest, part of an initiative called NaturalizeNY, will pay the fee, which costs about $700, for the 2,000 entrants who win.
lead_paragraph: For New York immigrant families just scraping by, the $680 it costs to apply for United States citizenship may be too much of an obstacle.

headline: Scholars Steeped in Dead Politicians Take On a Live One: Donald Trump
abstract: Experts assembled by the author David McCullough and the filmmaker Ken Burns are speaking with alarm on Facebook about the presidential candidate’s place in American history.
lead_paragraph: No one could mistake the voice of David McCullough, either in the books that have made him one of the most influential United States historians of his era, or in the documentaries he has narrated for the “American Experience” television series.

headline: Donald Trump Calls Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Remarks a ‘Disgrace to the Court’
abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court was rebuked by Donald J. Trump for voicing comments against him that he said were “beneath the court.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump on Tuesday said Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s involvement in the presidential campaign was a “disgrace to the court” after she expanded on the criticism of the presumptive Republican nominee that she first voiced last week.

headline: Despite Baseball’s Labor Peace, Battlefield Isn’t Deserted
abstract: Major League Baseball’s collective bargaining agreement expires after this season, and although labor battlegrounds remain, no one expects a strike or a lockout.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The managers of the All-Star Game on Tuesday reflected the relative health of the baseball industry. Ned Yost of the Kansas City Royals guided the American League team and the Mets’ Terry Collins the National League team. They had earned their jobs by meeting in the World Series last fall — one team from baseball’s biggest media market and the other from one of the smallest.

headline: Central Park Conservancy Aims to Raise $300 Million
abstract: A 10-year fund-raising and improvement effort, “Forever Green: Ensuring the Future of Central Park,” is to be announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A 10-year fund-raising and improvement effort, “Forever Green: Ensuring the Future of Central Park,” is to be announced on Thursday.

headline: Fighting Threatens Peace in South Sudan
abstract: Hundreds have been killed in South Sudan’s capital, Juba, in recent days, after fighting broke out between opposing factions. Jeffrey Gettleman, The Times’s East Africa bureau chief, discusses what’s at stake.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds have been killed in South Sudan’s capital, Juba, in recent days, after fighting broke out between opposing factions. Jeffrey Gettleman, The Times’s East Africa bureau chief, discusses what’s at stake.

headline: Immigration Detention Center in Arizona Failed to Contain Measles Outbreak
abstract: Health officials say the disease was spread by unvaccinated staff members at the facility in Eloy, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: Health officials in Arizona are pressing federal officials for better cooperation after an outbreak of measles at an immigration detention center was prolonged because some employees were slow to be vaccinated.

headline: A Croquet Standout, for His Age (15) and His Grit
abstract: When croquet’s best players gathered for the world championships, 15-year-old Edmund Fordyce defied odds to set new expectations.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Since 1989, the world’s best croquet players have been invited to compete in the World Croquet Federation’s world championships, which this year were held in April at the National Croquet Center.

headline: Testing the Rule of Law in the South China Sea
abstract: China’s reaction to a tribunal’s decision will say much about its approach to international law.
lead_paragraph: How China reacts to the sweeping legal defeat over its claims to the South China Sea will tell the world a lot about its approach to international law, the use — measured or otherwise — of its enormous power, and its global ambitions. So far, the signs are troubling. Beijing has defiantly rejected an international arbitration court’s jurisdiction over a case brought by the Philippines and insisted it will not accept Tuesday’s pathbreaking judgment.

headline: Bill Jones, Photographer of the Black Glitterati, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Jones first picked up a camera in the Air Force and later trained his lens on black actors and musicians whom the white media often ignored.
lead_paragraph: Bill Jones, who, as one of the first black photographers working the celebrity beat in Hollywood, brought attention to Halle Berry, Denzel Washington and other black stars early in their careers, died on June 25 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Baton Rouge Police Arrest 3 in Plot to Shoot at Officers
abstract: Officials said the investigation began in connection with the theft of eight handguns from a pawnshop.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Law enforcement officials said here Tuesday that they were investigating a plot by four people to shoot at police officers, and they cited the threat to explain the heavy police presence at protests within the last week.

headline: Juno Sends First Image Back While Orbiting Jupiter
abstract: NASA released the first photograph taken from its space probe since its camera was turned back on after it locked into orbit on July 4.
lead_paragraph: So it did happen.

headline: Characteristic of the Present
abstract: You have Tom McCoy’s little sister to thank for this one.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes the midweek puzzles can go unloved. Some solvers quit after the Monday and Tuesday grids, because they’re convinced that that is all they can do; others stick to the challenges of the late-week puzzles.

headline: Temple University Board Seeks to Dismiss President Over Shortfall
abstract: A vote of no confidence was connected with a $22 million deficit in the university’s financial aid budget, the chairman of the board of trustees said.
lead_paragraph: The Temple University board of trustees issued a vote of no confidence in the school’s president, Neil D. Theobald, and plans to seek his removal in connection with a $22 million deficit in the university’s financial aid budget, the board chairman said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: 33 Suspected of Overdosing on Synthetic Marijuana in Brooklyn
abstract: On the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, a longstanding problem became a local crisis. “It’s like a scene out of a zombie movie,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: There is a word that local residents and workers use to describe a group of drug users whose presence they say has grown around a busy Brooklyn transit hub: zombies. What was once a few familiar faces has turned into a tribe of strangers, walking around, staggering and looking lost, in the throes, it is believed, of the ill effects of K2, a synthetic drug that officials in New York have been working hard to eradicate.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, July 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’m here to insist that we are not so divided as we seem. I say that because I know America. I know how far we’ve come against impossible odds. I know we’ll make it because of what I’ve experienced in my own life.”

headline: Cadet: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Injuries Will Force Spanish Cyclist Alberto Contador to Miss the Rio Games
abstract: Contador, a two-time winner of the Tour de France, withdrew from the race during the ninth stage with a fever after falling in the opening two stages.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish cyclist Alberto Contador will miss the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro because of injuries that forced him to abandon the Tour de France.

headline: Ovadia & Sons: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: In the All-Star Game, the Mets Can’t Get Off the Bench as the Royals Lead the Way
abstract: For Terry Collins, who managed the National League, it may have seemed like a rerun of the World Series as Eric Hosmer and Salvador Perez pummeled his team.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The All-Star Game is supposed to represent one last callback to the previous year’s World Series. But things rarely go as planned for the Mets.

headline: Corrections: July 13, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, July 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: “Mr. Robot” returns for a second season of hacktivism and adds a recap show. And “The A Word” embeds with a family whose young son may be autistic.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Robot” returns for a second season of hacktivism, along with a new recap show. And “The A Word” explores a family dealing with possible autism in a way that Neil Genzlinger of The Times called both anguishing and drolly funny.

headline: 급부상하는 유럽의 극우 정당: 유력 정당 길라잡이
abstract: 난민 위기와 유럽연합에 대한 불만에 힘입어 유럽의 많은 극우 정당이 선거에서 성공을 거뒀다. 이 가운데 가장 주목할 만한 정당 여덟 개를 골랐다.
lead_paragraph: 난민 위기와 유럽연합에 대한 불만에 힘입어 유럽의 많은 극우 정당이 선거에서 성공을 거뒀다. 이 가운데 가장 주목할 만한 정당 여덟 개를 골랐다.

headline: Hermès Steps Into the Shoe Wars With a Stake in Pierre Hardy
abstract: The move makes Hermès something of a footwear power when shoes are proving to be the It bags of the moment.
lead_paragraph: The shoe wars are once again about to escalate. Hermès International, the French luxury group, announced on Wednesday that it had taken a minority stake in the shoe brand Pierre Hardy.

headline: Donald Trump Is Right About Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: Whatever their reservations about the presidential field, Supreme Court justices and the court benefit from remaining silent.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg needs to drop the political punditry and the name-calling.

headline: ‘They Will Not Drive Us Apart’
abstract: President Obama’s unifying speech at the memorial for five slain Dallas policemen will likely be remembered among the rhetorical peaks of his tenure.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama has now addressed the nation eloquently on 11 occasions following mass shootings in various parts of the country. But his speech on Tuesday, at the memorial for five police officers slain in Dallas by a black Army veteran who set out to kill whites, stands apart — both in terms of the challenges it presented and the feeling with which it was delivered. This speech, which found hope for national unity in a moment of profound division and despair, will most likely be seen among the rhetorical high-water marks of his presidency.

headline: Has Barack Obama Hurt Race Relations?
abstract: As the president spoke at a Dallas memorial, critics carped that he has set us back. Don’t believe it.
lead_paragraph: I have many qualms about Barack Obama’s presidency. I worry that he exhausted too much political capital too soon on Obamacare. That he overcorrected for his predecessor’s foreign debacle. That he wore his disdain for Congress too conspicuously.

headline: An Army for Everyone
abstract: The U.S. military’s recent decision to allow transgender people to serve shows that the institution is finally getting back on its progressive path.
lead_paragraph: Kansas City, Mo. — THE first war stories I heard came from my grandfather’s friend, Redman Callaway, who led a company of 140 black soldiers in Europe in 1944. Like most white men of his generation, when Lieutenant Callaway discovered that he had been put in charge of an African-American company, his first reaction was, “Why me?” followed by “How do I get a transfer?”

headline: The (G.O.P.) Party’s Over
abstract: The Republican Party hasn’t been a productive part in a two-party democracy for a long time, but a crushing loss this fall could force it to change.
lead_paragraph: This column has argued for a while now that there is only one thing worse than one-party autocracy, and that is one-party democracy. At least a one-party autocracy can order things to get done.

headline: Real Life South African Liberation Stories: Santu Mofokeng
abstract: Santu Mofokeng eschewed the traditional dramatic images of violence and resistance under Apartheid to produce photos of daily life that were surreal, haunting and spiritual.
lead_paragraph: Santu Mofokeng eschewed the traditional dramatic images of violence and resistance under Apartheid to produce photos of daily life that were surreal, haunting and spiritual.

headline: Report on China’s Coal Power Projects
abstract: Even though China has promised to reduce its dependency on coal power, there are 210 new coal-fired power plant projects approved for construction.
lead_paragraph: Even though China has promised to reduce its dependency on coal power, there are 210 new coal-fired power plant projects approved for construction.

headline: Let’s Grow Up, Liberals
abstract: I voted for Bernie Sanders. But it’s enough with the purity already.
lead_paragraph: At last! Senator Bernie Sanders joined Hillary Clinton on a New Hampshire stage Tuesday to say two things many of us had begun to despair we’d ever hear from him. One, that he actually did lose the 2016 primary campaign to Secretary Clinton, and two, that he was endorsing her for president of the United States.

headline: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)
abstract: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
lead_paragraph: Can a stretch of land be a person in the eyes of the law? Can a body of water?

headline: John Dickerson Is Tired of Politicians’ Propaganda
abstract: The host of “Face the Nation” on his famously tough questions, Washington’s cocktail-party culture and what it’s like to interview Donald Trump 19 times.
lead_paragraph: You took over at “Face the Nation” from Bob Schieffer, who is the longest-­running moderator of a Sunday network news show, in 2015. What advice did he give you? He told me to stick to the news. Everybody’s attention is shredded with all kinds of different distractions. You definitely see lots of efforts to reinvent and pitch a new model and redesign Coke, and that leads to lots of strange journalism. It sometimes leads to great journalism, but his advice was to stick to what people want to know.

headline: The Mysterious Metamorphosis of Chuck Close
abstract: The legendary artist has radically upended his distinctive style of portraiture — and his entire life. Why?
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, I went to visit Chuck Close at his beach house on Long Island. The drive there always reminds me of an escape to the Hamptons in reverse. From the aristocratic brownstones of Park Slope, you work your way steadily down the socioeconomic ladder, past the towering Soviet-­style apartment complexes of Coney Island, through strips of pawn shops and gimcrack hotels that give way to rowhouses fronted with plaster statuary, until at last the journey comes to an end at the sun-­beaten waterfront of Long Beach, a haven for cops and firefighters looking to blow off summer steam, where you pay for access to the sand amid a throng of rented umbrellas and creatine-­engorged pectorals, all of which vanish at sundown into a surfeit of bwomp-­bwomping nightclubs along the strip.

headline: After 300 Years of Collecting, Nearly 12,000 Amazon Tree Species Are Found
abstract: Researchers analyzed hundreds of thousands of samples in digitized museum collections to produce an estimate of species in the South American rain forest.
lead_paragraph: If Pokémon Go players think catching 151 different pocket monsters on their smartphones is tough, imagine trying to collect more than 15,000.

headline: Dallas Police Are Used to Recovering From Being in Harm’s Way
abstract: Thursday’s shooting deaths of five officers came about 13 months after another attack from a gunman, and about two years after an Ebola crisis.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The officer was standing in a hotel cafe here when he was asked — as he no doubt had been asked dozens of times since Thursday — how he was doing.

headline: 7 Teenage Deaths, but No Answers for Aboriginal Canadians
abstract: Seven students attending school far from home were found dead over more than a decade, but a coroner’s inquest could not determine why.
lead_paragraph: THUNDER BAY, Ontario — They were teenagers from tiny indigenous Canadian communities, isolated by a maze of lakes and forest. Thunder Bay, a metropolis by comparison, offered them their only opportunity for a high school education.

headline: Battle of the Network Stars: Trump vs. Clinton
abstract: The Republican and Democratic conventions will have an unusual job: rebooting two series we’ve been watching for decades.
lead_paragraph: In a year of reboot culture — “Fuller House,” “The X-Files,” “Ghostbusters” — it was perhaps inevitable that we should get a reboot election.

headline: Live Streaming Breaks Through, and Cable News Has Much to Fear
abstract: The Philando Castile shooting and its aftermath have catapulted services like Facebook Live and Periscope into the center of the news, challenging cable to adapt.
lead_paragraph: Cable news has functioned as the harrowing background soundtrack to much of 2015 and 2016. In covering terrorist attacks, protests against the police and a presidential election whose daily antics seem tailor-made for the overheated ethos of cable, Fox News, CNN and MSNBC have all won huge increases in viewership.

headline: Real-Life South African Liberation Stories: Santu Mofokeng
abstract: Santu Mofokeng eschewed the traditional dramatic images of violence and resistance under Apartheid to produce photos of daily life that were surreal, haunting and spiritual.
lead_paragraph: The South African photographer Santu Mofokeng knows that the photos you don’t see can matter just as much as the ones that dominate the historical narrative. He began as a teenaged street photographer during the early 1970’s in Soweto, working as an itinerant portrait photographer. He found work as a darkroom assistant and freelance photojournalist but soon grew disenchanted with what he saw as the agenda-driven orientation of some colleagues. Most news stories only covered the era’s violence and brutality. But Mr. Mofokeng was determined to also show his subjects as dignified people who, despite the repressive regime, were resilient, and whom he featured in photo stories filled with hazy black-and-white images that were surreal, haunting and spiritual.

headline: For Whites Sensing Decline, Donald Trump Unleashes Words of Resistance
abstract: Breaching boundaries on discussions of race, Mr. Trump has stoked antagonism among whites who feel disempowered and attracted college students tired of having to watch their words.
lead_paragraph: The chant erupts in a college auditorium in Washington, as admirers of a conservative internet personality shout down a black protester. It echoes around the gym of a central Iowa high school, as white students taunt the Hispanic fans and players of a rival team. It is hollered by a lone motorcyclist, as he tears out of a Kansas gas station after an argument with a Hispanic man and his Muslim friend.

headline: Cynthia Ozick Takes Up Arms Against Today’s Literary Scene
abstract: In “Critics, Monsters, Fanatics, and Other Literary Essays,” Cynthia Ozick longs for the re-establishment of a literary culture as profound as the one that reigned at midcentury.
