lead_paragraph: CRITICS, MONSTERS, FANATICS, AND OTHER LITERARY ESSAYSBy Cynthia Ozick211 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

headline: ‘I Want to Know What It Is Like to Be a Wild Thing’
abstract: In “Being a Beast,” the British naturalist Charles Foster goes to great lengths to experience the world as different species.
lead_paragraph: BEING A BEASTAdventures Across the Species DivideBy Charles Foster235 pp. Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $28.

headline: Taiwan, After Rejecting South China Sea Decision, Sends Patrol Ship
abstract: Taiwan’s claims in the contested waters match China’s, but it has not pushed them as aggressively as its neighbor and rival.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Taiwan is an often-overlooked player in the debate over control of the South China Sea, where its emphasis on multilateral negotiations tends to be drowned out by the bold claims of China, which considers Taiwan part of its territory and tries to limit its voice in world affairs.

headline: Can Running Make You Smarter?
abstract: To strengthen your mind, you may first want to exert your leg muscles, according to a sophisticated new experiment involving people, mice and monkeys.
lead_paragraph: To strengthen your mind, you may first want to exert your leg muscles, according to a sophisticated new experiment involving people, mice and monkeys. The study’s results suggest that long-term endurance exercise such as running can alter muscles in ways that then jump-start changes in the brain, helping to fortify learning and memory.

headline: Theresa May, David Cameron, Jennifer Aniston: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Law Enforcement Groups Press Trump and Clinton for Criminal Justice Overhaul
abstract: Members of leading law enforcement organizations wrote to the two presidential contenders, but the message was aimed mostly at Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In a letter released on Wednesday, members of leading law enforcement organizations are calling on the two presidential contenders to embrace the concept of criminal justice overhaul. But the message is aimed mostly at Donald J. Trump.

headline: New York Today: Documentaries About Our City
abstract: Wednesday: City-centric films, a synthetic marijuana crisis, and training for Trekkies.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this wishy-washy Wednesday.

headline: Myths About Teenagers and Risk-Taking
abstract: Yes, trouble heats up in the summer, but a quick spin around the research gives parents reason to feel hopeful, not helpless.
lead_paragraph: Teenage risk-taking heats up in the summer. Studies show that during the summer months adolescents are most likely to experiment with first-time use of alcohol, marijuana and cigarettes. For car crashes, the perennial leading cause of death among teenagers, June, July and August hold the grim honor of being the three consecutive months with the most adolescent traffic fatalities.

headline: Morning Agenda: Lawyers in Line of Fire at Delaware Courts
abstract: A Founder of Hyperloop One Claims Harassment in Lawsuit | Blythe Masters Steps Down as Chairwoman of Santander Consumer USA
lead_paragraph: LAWYERS IN LINE OF FIRE AT DELAWARE COURTS First investment banks came under fire for the roles they played in billion-dollar buyouts, and now there is a case that could extend liability to the lawyers in buyouts, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in Deal Professor.

headline: NBCUniversal Executive Is Denied Entry Into Russia
abstract: Jeff Shell, who oversees the company’s motion picture unit and is chairman of the federal agency that oversees Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, was detained and then sent away.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An executive with NBCUniversal said he had been denied entry into Russia and detained for several hours on Wednesday, raising the prospect that a growing spy and diplomatic confrontation could now be tipping into the world of business.

headline: Candidates Join Clinton in Push for Tuition Plan Inspired by Sanders
abstract: Democratic Senate candidates are uniting around the concepts that Mrs. Clinton rolled out last week, suggesting that easing student debt will be central to the party’s argument for a Senate majority.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders has at last enthusiastically endorsed Hillary Clinton. Now Democratic Senate candidates are rallying around the push to ease college debt that Mrs. Clinton embraced last week to show Sanders supporters that she had adopted some of his political and policy ideals.

headline: Theresa May, New British Prime Minister, Gives Boris Johnson a Key Post
abstract: Ms. May quickly put her stamp on the new government by appointing Mr. Johnson as foreign secretary and Philip Hammond as chancellor of the Exchequer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a startlingly swift transfer of power that made her Britain’s prime minister, Theresa May took charge of a new government on Wednesday, vowing to honor the referendum to leave the European Union and naming Boris Johnson, the former London mayor who had been widely considered politically dead, as foreign minister.

headline: Should I Have Talked to My Father About His Cross-Dressing?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on asking a parent about a secret past, handling a relative’s disastrous stock advice and bringing up a friend’s eating disorder.
lead_paragraph: My father died seven years ago. He was 93. When I was getting divorced in the late ’80s and sharing my sexual woes with my mother, she confessed to me that my father dressed up in women’s clothes, and that she never could deal with it. She wished she had gone to therapy years earlier when she first discovered it. She made me promise never to talk about it. I later found out that both my sisters knew about this as well.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Audiobooks Read by the Author
abstract: The deeper notes of literature emerge when they are heard in the master’s own voice.
lead_paragraph: In 1926, the year he died, Rainer Maria Rilke wrote to an acquaintance about a new device that he believed could change the way we appreciated poetry: the phonograph, or as he called it, the “talking-machine.” In the letter, Rilke lamented that the device was seldom used for recorded speech, but he envisioned a future in which we would read poems while simultaneously listening to a recording of the poem — but not just any recording. “The prerequisite,” Rilke explained, “for such an exercise would in any case be that the talking-machine had received the sound picture of the verse sequence from the poet’s own lips and not indirectly by way, say, of the actor.” The actor, however talented, must be kept from reading an author’s work, Rilke insisted, for “he almost always errs and goes astray.”

headline: Is Donald Trump Winning? Among Whites and Men, for Sure
abstract: This week’s politics chat also includes discussion on polling, Bernie Sanders’s endorsement, the Hispanic vote and a closer-than-expected race in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshot’s elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York, discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange. This week: Good poll/bad poll; Bernie Sanders’s endorsement; Nevada’s not-so-easy race for Hillary Clinton; and does Mike Pence make sense? But first ...

headline: Hillary Clinton, at Site of Lincoln Speech, Laments G.O.P.’s Turn to Donald Trump
abstract: Trying to present herself as an agent of harmony, Mrs. Clinton also admitted that she had “sometimes fueled the partisanship that stands in the way of progress.”
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — On the grounds of the Old State Capitol here, where nearly 160 years ago, Abraham Lincoln held forth on “a house divided,” Hillary Clinton on Wednesday lamented the Party of Lincoln’s transition to the Party of Trump, casting the present moment as an indelible stain on Republican history.

headline: South Korean Villagers Protest Plans for U.S. Missile Defense System
abstract: Thousands of residents of a rural county protested its selection as the site of the so-called Thaad system, which China has also bitterly opposed.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea announced on Wednesday that a rural southern county would be the site of an advanced American missile defense battery, the planned deployment of which has angered China and North Korea — and, now, thousands of local residents, who demonstrated against the plan.

headline: Not Forgotten: Frida Kahlo, Whose Self-Portraits Spoke to the Soul
abstract: She defined herself by her painting, especially when she painted herself. Kahlo died on this day 62 years ago.
lead_paragraph: She defined herself by her painting, especially when she painted herself. Kahlo died on this day 62 years ago.

headline: E.U. Offers New Immigration Plan, Hoping to Sway Reluctant Countries
abstract: The European Union authorities offered a series of proposals that reflected a renewed effort to impose clearer rules for both member states and migrants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities, seeking to balance the scale of the migration crisis with the reluctance of some countries to take in refugees, offered a series of proposals on Wednesday that would give member states more latitude while offering them 10,000 euros for each refugee they accept.

headline: Singer at All-Star Game Adds ‘All Lives Matter’ to Canadian Anthem
abstract: A member of a Canadian quartet singing “O Canada” altered some lyrics to make a political statement, setting off heavy criticism, including from his fellow singers.
lead_paragraph: The most memorable thing about the All-Star Game on Tuesday night might have been what happened before the first pitch was even thrown: A member of a Canadian quartet singing the country’s national anthem altered some lyrics and held up a sign that said “All Lives Matter.”

headline: Maybe North Korea’s Nuclear Goals Are More Serious Than Once Thought
abstract: The country’s weapons programs have long been understood as meant for propaganda, not military, purposes. That view might be dangerously wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under traditional understandings of North Korea, the country’s test launch of two medium-range ballistic missiles in late June should not have happened. Neither should its failed launch, on Saturday, of a submarine-based missile.

headline: Egypt’s Latest Tactic Against Critics: Block Their Movements, or Deport Them
abstract: Liliane Daoud, a Lebanese-British journalist who was sent to Beirut, Lebanon, in June, is one of many people who say they have been barred from the country.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Hours after being fired from her job as a presenter on one of the few remaining television news programs in Egypt critical of the government, Liliane Daoud found herself on a plane to Lebanon.

headline: Boston Takes Step to Elevate Citgo Sign From LED Beacon to Landmark
abstract: The city’s Landmarks Commission voted to study whether the giant sign that guides drivers, marathon runners and Red Sox fans should receive special status.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — This historic city has a booming downtown, colorful neighborhoods, charming parks and a skyline overlooking the river, but there is no single landmark — no Space Needle, statue or monument — that shouts “Boston” to the world as soon as it is spotted from a distance.

headline: Polls in 3 Crucial States Show Donald Trump Improving
abstract: New Quinnipiac University state surveys have Mr. Trump moving up in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida, with voters calling honesty an issue that could hurt Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are deadlocked in the crucial swing states of Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida, according to new polls showing the presumptive Republican presidential nominee gaining strength on his Democratic rival because of doubts about her honesty.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Pokémon Go and the ‘Singularity’
abstract: A weekly compilation of web gems includes a way to see how incomes in a host of professions are distributed.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the things on the internet that have recently caught our fancy.

headline: What You Get for … $1,300,000
abstract: An 1896 house in St. Louis, a contemporary in Arkansas and an apartment in Oregon
lead_paragraph: An 1896 house in St. Louis, a contemporary in Arkansas and an apartment in Oregon

headline: $1,300,000 Homes in St. Louis, Arkansas and Oregon
abstract: This week’s properties include an 1896 house in St. Louis, a contemporary in Arkansas and a condo in a 1913 building in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS

headline: Emmanuel Macron, French Economy Minister, Hints at Presidential Run
abstract: The re-election prospects for President François Hollande clouded further as Mr. Macron all but stepped into the ring.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The re-election prospects for France’s weakened president, François Hollande, clouded further Tuesday night as his economy minister, Emmanuel Macron, all but stepped into the ring against him in next year’s presidential elections at a crowded rally in central Paris.

headline: Emperor Akihito of Japan Plans to Abdicate Throne, Broadcaster Says
abstract: According to the country’s public broadcaster, the emperor told close aides that he intended to pass the throne to his son, Crown Prince Naruhito, before he dies.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For the first time in nearly two centuries, an emperor of Japan has said that he will abdicate the throne before he dies.

headline: China Pledged to Curb Coal Plants. Greenpeace Says It’s Still Adding Them.
abstract: The construction boom would result in about 400 gigawatts of excess capacity and waste more than $150 billion on building unneeded plants, the group said in a report.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government is trying to slow down the approval of new coal-fired power plants because of overcapacity, but projects already in the pipeline, as well as loopholes in policy, mean China is on track to add an average of one new coal-fired plant a week until 2020, according to a report released on Wednesday by Greenpeace East Asia.

headline: Why the U.S. Military Can’t Fix Syria
abstract: More American involvement in the Middle East’s biggest quagmire will definitely end badly.
lead_paragraph: The State Department “dissent channel” memo on the United States’ policy in Syria, leaked last month, is just the latest expression of a widespread belief in and out of government that American intervention in Syria is necessary and would be successful.

headline: 1916: Spain Under Martial Law
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: King Alfonso of Spain declares martial law in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despatches from Madrid state that at noon today [July 13] King Alfonso, who has just returned to the capital from La Granja in view of the grave situation caused by the railway strike, issued a decree suspending the Constitutional guarantees and establishing martial law throughout Spain.

headline: Watching Doping Scandal, Fourth-Place Olympian Asks, ‘Am I a Bronze Medalist?’
abstract: Katie Uhlaender finished fourth at the Sochi Games, behind Elena Nikitina, who was among the Russian athletes said to be part of a government-run doping program.
lead_paragraph: Katie Uhlaender was a three-time United States Olympian when she competed at the Sochi Games in February 2014. She was seeking her first Olympic medal, and after four runs down an icy 1.1-mile skeleton course, she was sure she had succeeded.

headline: Why Putin Loves Brexit
abstract: In the Russian president’s view, what makes Europe weaker makes him stronger.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s referendum decision last month to leave the European Union has plunged Europe into crisis. There will be institutional and political upheaval for years to come while the terms of Britain’s knotty disentanglement are worked out. The ability of both Britain and the European Union to maintain their international influence and remain major forces on the world stage is in doubt, with potentially dire consequences for Continental order.

headline: Horses, and the Palestinians Who Raise Them
abstract: In a tightly packed East Jerusalem and the wide West Bank, Palestinians breed an affinity for Arabian horses.
lead_paragraph: In a tightly packed East Jerusalem and the wide West Bank, Palestinians breed an affinity for Arabian horses.

headline: For Palestinians, Raising Arabian Horses Is ‘the Hobby of the Poor’
abstract: Stables dot villages and towns of every size in the occupied West Bank, and many families who share tiny, cramped homes raise their own horses.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the violent East Jerusalem slum of Issawiya, trash burned next to an open bin, filling the air with an acrid stench. Arabic graffiti covered a stone wall on one side of a steep lane scattered with stones left from clashes between Palestinian residents and Israeli soldiers. A knot of children stopped and eyed two strangers with suspicion.

headline: A Seven-Bedroom Country House in Kent
abstract: The property, on around 10 acres in the pastoral Weald region of southeast England, is on the market for $3.99 million.
lead_paragraph: The property, on around 10 acres in the pastoral Weald region of southeast England, is on the market for $3.99 million.

headline: House Hunting in .... England
abstract: As in the rest of Britain, the housing market in Kent fell sharply after the financial crisis and has been slowly rebounding.
lead_paragraph: A SEVEN-BEDROOM COUNTRY HOUSE IN KENT

headline: Red Bank: The Jersey Shore With an Urban Vibe
abstract: On the southern banks of the Navesink River, the town offers history, diversity, culture and entertainment for those seeking a hip, urban vibe.
lead_paragraph: When Cassie Murphy, a 31-year-old lawyer, got a new job in Red Bank, N.J., in 2014, she and her husband, Kellen, who were living in Hoboken, began to think about moving.

headline: Living in Red Bank, N.J.
abstract: The town, on the southern banks of the Navesink River, offers history, diversity, culture and entertainment for those seeking a hip, urban vibe.
lead_paragraph: The town, on the southern banks of the Navesink River, offers history, diversity, culture and entertainment for those seeking a hip, urban vibe.

headline: The New Officer Friendly, Armed With Instagram, Tweets and Emojis
abstract: Can break-dancing videos and online outreach improve police-community relations? Some departments keep trying.
lead_paragraph: While police departments across the United States have been the targets of anger and protests over the shooting deaths of black men, social media users have flocked to the accounts of an Arkansas police officer who offers a starkly different view of community policing — one that involves snacks, dancing and even a Slip ‘N Slide.

headline: Time Inc. Reshuffles in a Digital Reinvention
abstract: As part of a broad revamping of the company, Alan Murray will replace Norman Pearlstine, who will stay on as vice chairman.
lead_paragraph: During a recent meeting at Time Inc.’s headquarters in downtown Manhattan, Jeff Karp extolled the virtues of Sports Illustrated Play, the company’s new digital division focused on youth sports.

headline: Families and Fellow Officers Honor Victims of Dallas Sniper
abstract: Hours after President Obama presided over a memorial service, loved ones of three of the slain officers began saying goodbye.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — From a young age, Brent Thompson pushed the bounds of life so hard that he almost always found a way to get hurt.

headline: Jamaica Kincaid’s Antigua
abstract: How do you get to know this island? Go off-season, to Carnival, and use the writer’s books as your guide.
lead_paragraph: The air was heavy with mist when the lights were finally trained on the stage, illuminating a set that looked as if it had been transported from a low-frills scuba diving resort. Dancers wearing short shorts — known locally as batty-riders — ground their hips with mechanical precision. Typical Carnival fare. Until Dennis  Roberts entered stage right in a wet suit, jutting out his rotund belly to emphasize his seal-like silhouette.

headline: Central Park, Bucolic but Aging, Is in a Quest for $300 Million
abstract: A 10-year fund-raising and improvement effort, “Forever Green: Ensuring the Future of Central Park,” aims to restore and repair many areas.
lead_paragraph: Belvedere Castle in Central Park looks indestructible, a fortress of stone presiding over the Great Lawn. But the 144-year-old-building leaks like a sieve.

headline: A Novelist Who Knows the Real Jamaica
abstract: The author Nicole Dennis-Benn, who grew up in Jamaica, says the heart of its culture can be found in Kingston.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn writer Nicole Dennis-Benn’s debut novel, “Here Comes the Sun,” published this month, looks beyond Jamaica’s tourist staples to explore class, race and exploitation in her homeland. Ms. Dennis-Benn, 34, was raised in Kingston and moved to the United States to attend Cornell University. She later went on to receive a master of fine arts from Sarah Lawrence College and teaches writing at Baruch College.

headline: The Doctor-Patient Relationship Is Alive and Well
abstract: When I close the door to the exam room and it’s just the patient and me, the power of human connection becomes palpable.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2:20 p.m. and Ms. M. is precisely on time for her appointment. She’s brought her hand-printed list of questions, her sack of medications that need renewal, her mordant observations about her newest home attendant, and a box of chocolates that she will press upon me no matter how hard I protest. At 89, her medical conditions don’t have easy cures and the setbacks from aging are often implacable. Yet we always manage to find something optimistic to work on, even if modest in scope.

headline: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
abstract: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times. In this piece, reporter Anemona Hartocollis follows up with a Syrian refugee family she wrote about earlier this year.

headline: Tom Brady’s Latest Petition Is Denied; ‘Deflategate’ Suspension Stands
abstract: The Patriots quarterback is all but guaranteed to start the season on the sideline. His remaining hope would be to appeal to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady, the New England Patriots quarterback, is all but guaranteed to start the season on the sideline after a federal appeals court on Wednesday denied his request to review his four-game suspension for his role in a scheme to deflate footballs.

headline: European Court Backs Woman Dismissed in France for Wearing Head Scarf
abstract: The advisory opinion released by the European Court of Justice does not fully settle the fraught issue of religious attire in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A French company that dismissed a Muslim woman for wearing a head scarf when dealing with clients unlawfully discriminated against her, according to an advisory opinion that the European Union’s highest court released on Wednesday.

headline: Obama on Obamacare’s Flaws: An Assessment
abstract: Two Times health reporters discuss the president’s frank analysis that the health law has weaknesses that need to be addressed.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has published an essay on Obamacare in The Journal of the American Medical Association. While it hit a lot of the Affordable Care Act’s high points, it was also pretty frank that the health law has some weaknesses that need to be fixed. Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson, two New York Times reporters who have been covering Obamacare, discuss the policy changes that the president wants.

headline: Where the Silk Road Meets the Beach
abstract: Uma’s is a restaurant in the Rockaways with a minimalist décor and a menu based on the cuisine of Uzbekistan but with Russian, Indian and Middle Eastern influences.
lead_paragraph: Uma’s is a restaurant in the Rockaways with a minimalist décor and a menu based on the cuisine of Uzbekistan but with Russian, Indian and Middle Eastern influences.

headline: Surfing to Uzbekistan
abstract: Serving mostly Uzbekistan specialties in a laid-back, urban-chic setting, the restaurant draws a diverse clientele of surfers, locals and visitors.
lead_paragraph: Two blocks from the ocean, the funhouse-neon sign of an Uzbek restaurant called Uma’s beckons in the night like a lighthouse. It’s near the intersection of Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 92nd Street, where cozy clapboard homes give way to a cluster of small businesses. On a recent breezy Friday night, patrons shuffled into the restaurant wearing backward baseball hats, baggy pants and shirts stamped with palm trees.

headline: Unity Technologies, Maker of Pokémon Go Engine, Swells in Value
abstract: The company, which makes game engine software, announced that it had raised $181 million from investors, bringing its valuation to about $1.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Most game players have never heard of Unity Technologies, but its software was used in the creation of a large number of the world’s top mobile games, including the current hit Pokémon Go.

headline: Recipes for Right Now
abstract: Learn the fundamentals of perfect chicken salad, then keep it simple and fry some eggs for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Pokémon Go, Millennials’ First Nostalgia Blast
abstract: An augmented-reality mobile phone game that uses geolocation isn’t new. What’s important about Pokémon Go is that it’s proof millennials are aging.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Pokémon Go is a big deal. But not just for the reasons you think.

headline: Staying Under the OS X Radar
abstract: Apple’s software can track your Mac’s location for better search results, but you can turn off the setting if you would rather not be followed.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I stop Mac OS X El Capitan and the Safari browser from using my computer’s location?

headline: ‘Current: L.A.’ Brings New Art Projects to the City
abstract: This year’s theme is water, and it will include projects near the Los Angeles River.
lead_paragraph: Lacking an organization like New York’s Creative Time or Public Art Fund, Los Angeles artists have long depended on local museums and scrappy nonprofit galleries to fund of-the-moment public art. Now the city’s Department of Cultural Affairs has a new biennial to help fill the gap: “Current: L.A.,” which runs for a month starting on Saturday.

headline: Rob Corddry on ‘Ballers’ and the End of ‘Childrens Hospital’
abstract: Mr. Corddry talks about completing his Adult Swim medical parody, preparing to slap Dwayne Johnson and being middle-aged in Miami.
lead_paragraph: On “Ballers,” an East Coast version of “Entourage” on HBO, the misbehaving man-babies are National Football League players instead of Hollywood actors, but the profane banter and cocaine-fueled yacht parties remain much the same.

headline: Donald Trump, Stranded in Indiana, Brings Running-Mate Competition to Him
abstract: Slowed by a plane malfunction, the presumptive Republican nominee spent time with the state’s governor, a possible vice-presidential pick. Mr. Trump plans to announce his choice on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Stranded in Indianapolis on Wednesday after an aircraft malfunction, Donald J. Trump did what any gifted showman with a national campaign to run would do: He brought the presidential circus to him.

headline: American Ballet Theater Announces New Season
abstract: The troupe will feature a new ballet by Jessica Lang, a company premiere of Benjamin Millepied’s “Daphnis and Chloe.”
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater plans to present the world premiere of a new ballet by Jessica Lang and the company premiere of Benjamin Millepied’s “Daphnis and Chloe” during its fall season at the David H. Koch Theater, the company announced Wednesday.

headline: 1966: Sinatra to Wed Mia Farrow
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Frank Sinatra to marry Mia Farrow in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The engagement of Frank Sinatra to 21-year-old actress Mia Farrow was announced today [July 13] by her mother, actress Maureen O’Sullivan. Miss O’Sullivan said the 50-year-old singer-actor and her daughter will be married in the United States between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

headline: Here‘s ‘Looking’ at You, Jonathan Groff
abstract: There is a future after “Hamilton.” For Mr. Groff, lately departed from the role of King George III (Awesome! Wow!), is a version of “Looking: The Movie.”
lead_paragraph: “Raise a glass to finally finding something close to adulthood,” Patrick (Jonathan Groff) says not long into “Looking: The Movie,” which airs at 10 p.m. on Saturday, July 23, on HBO. After months of working as a video game designer — and swearing off relationships — in Denver, he has returned to San Francisco for the wedding of Agustin (Frankie J. Alvarez) and Eddie (Daniel Franzese). (After “Looking” was canceled in 2015, Mr. Groff spent time prancing through the hit musical “Hamilton” as the deliciously pouty King George III.) But there are loose ends to tie up: with Dom (Murray Bartlett), the friend who could be more; Kevin (Russell Tovey), his boss turned beau; and Richie (Raúl Castillo), his barber ex.

headline: Lifting the Second-Generation Curse
abstract: Founders of family-run businesses need to bring on the next generation and let it experiment, as well as know when to let go, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Sexton jokes that her earliest memory is being rocked to sleep on the machinery bottling her mother’s line of all-natural juices. She was just an infant when Marygrace Sexton started Natalie’s Orchid Island Juice Company in 1990, naming it after her.

headline: At Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, Inspiration Takes Flight
abstract: One of the two full-evening productions at the festival is inspired by 20th-century art, the other by aeronautical history.
lead_paragraph: Dances can spring from surprising sources. Take the two full-evening productions at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival. One is inspired by 20th-century art, the other by aeronautical history. At the Ted Shawn Theater (Wednesday, July 20, to Friday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m.; July 24 at 2 p.m.), BalletX of Philadelphia dances one of the most unusual narrative ballets in recent years: Matthew Neenan’s “Sunset, o639 Hours,” which traces the career of Edwin Musick, the pilot of the inaugural trans-Pacific flight in 1938. The Doris Duke Theater (Wednesday to Friday at 8:15 p.m.; Saturday at 2:15 and 8:15 p.m.; July 24 at 2:15 p.m.) offers ZviDance in Zvi Gotheiner’s “Escher/Bacon/Rothko,” inspired by the works of three artists: M. C. Escher, creator of dizzying spatial illusions; Francis Bacon, known for portraits of grotesque tormented figures; and Mark Rothko, creator of paintings in which blocks of colored rectangles convey an unexpected sense of transcendence. (Becket, Mass.; 413-243-0745; jacobspillow.org.)

headline: Steve Reich’s Minimalist Music, Dark and Bright
abstract: Using kinetic streams of repeated musical cells, Mr. Reich built positive and propulsive music, along with dark and bitter works.
lead_paragraph: The reputation of Steve Reich, the grandfather of American Minimalism, rests on the propulsive, positive energy of his music. But his technique, built on kinetic streams of repeated musical cells, is also capable of capturing profound darkness. On Tuesday, July 19, the Lincoln Center Festival presents the intrepid JACK Quartet joined by Ensemble Signal, in an all-Reich program centered on his most introspective and bitterly moving works, among them the Holocaust-inspired “Different Trains” and “WTC 9/11.”

headline: Saving a Relic of Jewish Life in Germany
abstract: The author of “The House by the Lake,” Thomas Harding, traces a tumultuous time in history through his family’s ties to an old summer house.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Thomas Harding, a Briton in his late 40s, led the way into a decrepit single-story wooden structure on an overgrown lakeside plot on Berlin’s westernmost border in Gross Glienicke. “There used to be French doors there that opened onto the terrace,” he said of his Jewish great-grandparents’ weekend house. “And behind there,” he said pointing to the wall on the right, “There was Elsie and Bella’s bedroom, with a door into the living room.”

headline: Joe Lovano, Running the Show With Sweeping Sax
abstract: Mr. Lovano is known for bringing together musicians into a band and shaping a distinctive sound and identity, then doing the same with another group.
lead_paragraph: The jazz saxophonist Joe Lovano has a beautiful sound: dark tone, big projection, sweeping phrases, bright and flexible logic. But he’s also one of the great connectors in the history of New York jazz over the last few generations, just through his role as a bandleader. Nearly all his records since the mid-’80s have been the work of different bands, almost all of which achieved their own identities. “Quartets,” from 1995, recorded live at the Village Vanguard, used two different groups; one was a short-lived, loose and bracing quartet with the trumpeter Tom Harrell, the bassist Anthony Cox and the drummer Billy Hart. They played a powerful index of the straight-ahead jazz language of the time, and Mr. Lovano is bringing them back to the Vanguard, from Tuesday, July 19, to Sunday. (212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com.)

headline: Replicas Illuminate Remote Buddhist Art Treasures From China
abstract: An exhibition at the Getty Center in Los Angeles includes replicas of the spectacular interiors of caves near Dunhuang in northwestern China.
lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s greatest art treasures are remote and immovable. Such is the case with the complex of nearly 500 Buddhist cave temples and monasteries known as the Mogao Grottoes near Dunhuang in northwestern China, an ancient trading city on the edge of the Gobi Desert. Hand-carved into stone cliffs between the fourth and 14th centuries A.D., many of the caves are covered with religious murals and painted clay sculptures of Buddhist deities.

headline: ‘Troilus and Cressida’ Brings Love and War to Central Park
abstract: Daniel Sullivan directs a version of one of Shakespeare’s problem plays at the Delacorte Theater for the free Shakespeare in the Park series.
lead_paragraph: Before problematic plays, there were problem plays — like “Troilus and Cressida,” the bitingly cynical 17th-century drama, set during the Trojan War, whose Ping-Ponging between genres and plotlines made it one of the more obscure, flummoxing and fascinating works in Shakespeare’s canon. But its often jaded outlook on romantic love and the futility of war has also made it seem like one of Shakespeare’s most modern plays, and over the years, it has inspired high-concept productions. (A 1995 Public Theater version featured a channel-surfing Ulysses.) Last year, the venerable experimentalists at the Wooster Group mounted a version.

headline: A New Voice (or Two) Starts a New Era at the British Open
abstract: David Lancaster will be the primary starter on the first tee of the Open beginning Thursday. He replaces Ivor Robson, who had handled the job since 1975.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — Over the past four decades, the soundtrack to the British Open has generally included the whistling wind, the patter (or sometimes pounding) of raindrops and, at the start of every single round for every single golfer, a distinctively singsong voice from Dumfriesshire.

headline: What Can the United Nations Do When Its Troops Can’t, or Won’t, Protect Civilians?
abstract: The United Nations Security Council says it wants peacekeepers to protect civilians in South Sudan, but it faces blistering criticism there.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The thousands of United Nations peacekeepers trying to stave off disaster in South Sudan already have a tough, clear mandate: to protect civilians by any means necessary.

headline: The Couch in Rainbow Colors: ‘L.G.B.T.-Affirming’ Therapy
abstract: An ‘L.G.B.T.-affirming’ philosophy in clinical psychology at one university is helping to shape the course of therapy, though not without detractors.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — “Are we ready to expose ourselves?” J. D. Fuller asked, halfway through the graduate-level psychology class she teaches on Tuesday nights at Antioch University.

headline: A Theater Company’s Secret to Success: Bedlam
abstract: In just four years, Eric Tucker and Andrus Nichols’s New York-based company has become a critical darling. It’s also keeping them busier than ever.
lead_paragraph: If there is someone to blame for the week in June that Eric Tucker spent shuttling madly up and down Amtrak’s northeast corridor, directing Off Broadway by day, acting in Cambridge, Mass., by night, he is the guilty party. Likewise for those three weeks this spring when he logged 14-hour days in Times Square, rehearsing two productions at once.

headline: Walter W. Naumburg Foundation Gets $4 Million Gift
abstract: The gift, announced on Wednesday, was made by the Alfred Mann Donor Advised Fund at the Nevada Community Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A family’s musical and philanthropic ties have come together in a $4 million gift to the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, which helps young musicians start their careers by sponsoring competitions and awards.

headline: Beijing Protests South China Sea Ruling With Modest Show of Strength
abstract: Two civilian planes went to artificial islands in the waterway, but warships were not sent there after the Philippines won its case against China’s claim.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A day after an international tribunal rejected China’s claims in the South China Sea, Beijing excoriated the panel and sent two civilian planes to artificial islands it occupies in the waterway to demonstrate control.

headline: Three Nonprofits, Former Koch Brothers’ Associates, Fined by F.E.C.
abstract: The commission found that the organizations violated rules requiring groups to identity the source of any money earmarked for a political expenditure in 2010.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Election Commission fined three nonprofit groups formerly connected with the political network overseen by the brothers Charles G. Koch and David H. Koch, according to documents released by a liberal watchdog group on Wednesday, a rare intervention by the commission into the world of outside spending.

headline: Two Old Visitors to the Metropolitan Museum Will Stay a While
abstract: Two ancient sculptures from “Pergamon and the Hellenistic Kingdoms of the Ancient World,” which closes on Sunday, will remain on display through fall 2018.
lead_paragraph: Two ancient sculptures, centerpieces of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s exhibition “Pergamon and the Hellenistic Kingdoms of the Ancient World” will stay on view at the museum through fall 2018. The show closes on Sunday.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Tim Coppens
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in New York on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in New York on Tuesday.

headline: Jennifer Aniston Is Not Pregnant. Why Do We Care?
abstract: In an online essay, Ms. Aniston lashed out at the celebrity news media for its ‘sport-like scrutiny and body shaming,’ which she has been subjected to for much of her career.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Aniston, the actress whose frequently exposed personal life has driven untold sums of money to the celebrity journalism business, would like for it to stop speculating about the contents of her uterus.

headline: After ‘Brexit,’ Britain Could Look to Norway as a Model
abstract: Norway is outside of the European Union, but it can trade easily with the bloc’s members; the hitch is that it must allow the free movement of people.
lead_paragraph: HOKKSUND, Norway — Sigurd Braathen worked for a lifetime to build his family’s industrial company into a profitable venture with sales across Europe. Then an environmental diktat from Brussels threatened to outlaw half of his company’s energy-efficient water heaters, even in his home country of Norway.

headline: Another Night, Another Shooting on Facebook Live
abstract: Three men are badly injured as video streams the gunfire and the aftermath in Norfolk, Va.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after the troubling images of Philando Castile, bloodied by gunshots from a police officer, were broadcast on Facebook Live, another shooting has been streamed as it happened thanks to the popular feature. This time three men in Norfolk, Va., were badly wounded.

headline: The Downside to Cord-Cutting
abstract: A comparison of popular cable replacement services finds annoyances, like restrictions on content and missing channels.
lead_paragraph: This year, Michael Gartenberg, a former technology analyst, took the brave step of canceling his cable subscription. After six months of tinkering with alternatives, he went running back.

headline: House Panel Urges I.O.C. to Eradicate Doping
abstract: In a letter, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce expressed concerns about doping allegations in Russia and conflicts of interest within the global antidoping effort.
lead_paragraph: United States lawmakers wrote to the International Olympic Committee this week, urging officials to seize “crucial and timely opportunities” to combat doping and clean up global sports ahead of the Rio de Janeiro Games next month.

headline: Theresa May, Britain's New Leader
abstract: Theresa May has been sworn in as Britain's second female prime minister. Stephen Castle, The Times's London correspondent, talks about the new leader.
lead_paragraph: Theresa May has been sworn in as Britain's second female prime minister. Stephen Castle, The Times's London correspondent, talks about the new leader.

headline: Wanderlust by Design: Organizing Your Summer Travel
abstract: Sidekix, Clarice and Google Translate can help you discover and navigate new cities and sites, and make the most of your time there.
lead_paragraph: SUMMER gives many people the opportunity to step out of their comfort zones and into new adventures. With plenty of apps designed to help plan vacations, smartphones can now act as a sort of personal tour guide.

headline: Germany Sells Bonds With Negative Yield at Auction
abstract: The sale highlights worries over slowing economic growth and political uncertainty, stemming largely from Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to bond yields in Europe, it seems there is no such thing as too low.

headline: ‘We Live in a Society Where the Word “Liberal” Is Considered an Insult’
abstract: Saudis and others who have lived there respond to an article in The New York Times about the practice of Islam in the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Many Muslims around the world chafe at the power that oil wealth and control of the holy sites gives Saudi Arabia to shape how their faith is interpreted. But for Saad, from Karachi, Pakistan, what’s more enraging is the support the kingdom receives from the West.

headline: Sanatorium, a Hospital-Theme Bar, Opens in the East Village
abstract: The bar is the creation of Albert Trummer, a madcap bartender from Austria known for playing with fire.
lead_paragraph: It has been six years since Albert Trummer (center, above), the madcap Austrian bartender, was arrested after setting his cocktails aflame at Apotheke, a Chinatown speakeasy. The results were spectacular but a fire hazard. In the interim, he licked his wounds in South Beach, Fla., where he continued to experiment with combustible elixirs and plotted a comeback. Last April, with the opening of Sanatorium, a hospital-themed cocktail bar in the Lower East Side, the pyrotechnic mixologist finally returned — with smoke but no fire.

headline: Tor Project, a Digital Privacy Group, Reboots With New Board
abstract: The former public face of the nonprofit promoter of anonymizing software was pushed out under a cloud of sexual misconduct allegations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Tor Project, a nonprofit digital privacy group, on Wednesday replaced its board with a new slate of directors as part of a larger shake-up after allegations of sexual misconduct by a prominent employee.

headline: A Need for Wall Street to Improve Efficiency
abstract: Return on equity at the nation’s lenders and investment banks remains too low, and banks need to try something new.
lead_paragraph: America’s banks require more creativity. That conjures up fears of accounting tricks or overly complex products with zero economic or social benefit. The truth is simpler: Return on equity at the nation’s lenders and investment banks remains too low, and banks need to try something new.

headline: Nearly Four-Fifths of White Evangelicals Say They’ll Vote for Donald Trump
abstract: Support for Mr. Trump among white evangelicals, a coveted bloc, is even stronger than it was for Mitt Romney in 2012, a new poll has found.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four-fifths of white evangelical voters plan to cast their ballots for Donald J. Trump despite his multiple marriages, lack of piety and inconsistency on the issues they care about most, a new poll has found.

headline: From Chili to the Underground Railroad, Cincinnati on a Budget
abstract: The “Queen City” has great opportunities for the budget-conscious traveler — including its famous chili.
lead_paragraph: While drawing up an itinerary for my trip to Cincinnati, I came across @cincygram, an Instagram account with over 33,000 followers curated by a native, Dave Schmidt. I admired his shots of the city, many of which were taken late at night or early in the morning (Mr. Schmidt has a family and works full time as a retail store manager).

headline: Chris Froome Keeps Tour de France Lead on a Day for Sprinters
abstract: Wednesday’s stage ended with a sprint between Froome and Peter Sagan, a refutation for critics who say Froome’s racing is too calculated and risk averse.
lead_paragraph: MONTPELLIER, France — The 11th stage of the Tour de France on Wednesday came just before what was supposed to be a major mountain test and featured a route that was flat by the event’s standards. So it was generally assumed that the race’s overall leader, Chris Froome of Britain, would keep out of trouble and leave things to the sprinters.

headline: The Return of the ’90s
abstract: From slinky slip dresses to nostalgic sitcoms, the era is back with a vengeance. Again.
lead_paragraph: There’s war in the Middle East. Financial markets are faltering. A Clinton may be on the cusp of entering the White House. Madonna’s touring. Skinny models are dressed in skinny dresses, suspended from skinny straps. Fashion imagery is raw and markedly unretouched. Calvin Klein just released a provocative campaign to a global furor. Gucci is cool. Kate Moss is on magazine covers.

headline: John Elliott: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Review: In Paris, a Bold Ballet Adventure From Justin Peck
abstract: “Entre Chien et Loup,” a new work for the Paris Opera Ballet, demands Mr. Peck’s very American energy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was possible on Monday night to rush from Justin Peck’s “Entre Chien et Loup,” a new work for the Paris Opera Ballet at the Opera Bastille, to his “Everywhere We Go,” danced by the New York City Ballet, currently on tour here at the Théâtre du Châtelet. The two works, and two companies, offer instructive lessons in national and company styles, but what is clear from both ballets is Mr. Peck’s bold and adventurous choreographic voice.

headline: Patrick J. Adams Is Happy to Take the Suits Out of ‘Suits’
abstract: As the sixth season of the series begins, Mike Ross is being put in prison and Mr. Adams, the actor who plays him, speaks about the show and his character.
lead_paragraph: When “Suits” returns for its sixth season on Wednesday night, you’ll be forgiven for thinking it has morphed into “Orange Is the New Black.”

headline: Assembly New York: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Convention Protests in Philadelphia Are Expected to Be Bigger Than Those in Cleveland
abstract: The city is expecting 35,000 to 50,000 protesters a day during the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: The city is expecting 35,000 to 50,000 protesters a day during the Democratic National Convention.

headline: The Bridge Bounced Too Much. Now, After 2 Years, a Fix Is in Store.
abstract: Squibb Park Bridge, a link between Brooklyn Heights and Brooklyn Bridge Park that closed in 2014, will undergo repairs in the fall.
lead_paragraph: In a city of majestic bridges, it is a relatively modest one. But this bridge near the Brooklyn waterfront became well known for all the wrong reasons.

headline: When Law Is Not Justice
abstract: Rule of law may be good for business, but in many parts of the world it’s not enough to ensure basic rights.
lead_paragraph: This is the sixth in a series of dialogues with philosophers and critical theorists on the question of violence. This conversation is with Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, who is a university professor in the humanities at Columbia University. She is the author of “An Aesthetic Education in the Era of Globalization,” and other books.

headline: Conversations: How a Convention Is Like a Wedding
abstract: The historian Jill Lepore explains the purpose of conventions today and why the “convention bump” may not apply in 2016.
lead_paragraph: “No nomination is ever entirely uncontested,” Jill Lepore wrote in The New Yorker earlier this month; “the only question is what form the contest will take—sound or fury.” Dr. Lepore, a staff writer at the magazine and a professor of history at Harvard, has spent a lot of time thinking about the sound and fury of nominating conventions past. In a recent interview, she explained how the events became what they are today, the why the “convention bump” may not apply in 2016 and how a convention is like a wedding.

headline: Justin Rose, Who Is Going to Rio, Addresses Those Who Aren’t
abstract: Rose, who will represent Britain at the Games, said he was disappointed by, but respectful of, the decisions of golfers who are skipping the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — The recent withdrawals by several top players from the 2016 Rio Olympics golf competition continued to be a frequent topic of conversation Wednesday on the eve of the 2016 British Open. Even the players who have committed to playing in the Rio Games were forced to comment on those who have declined to go, a group that now includes the top four golfers in the world: Jason Day, Dustin Johnson, Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy.

headline: Review: ‘Doc & Darryl’ Recounts the Fall of Two Mets Phenoms
abstract: This documentary spotlights the former baseball players Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry and how they self-destructed.
lead_paragraph: Take a look at the credits for the ESPN film “Doc & Darryl” on Thursday night (part of its “30 for 30” series), and what leaps out at you is the name of the comedy maven Judd Apatow, who directed along with Michael Bonfiglio. But there’s nothing remotely funny about the film, a somber and conventional documentary about the entwined stories of the fallen stars Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry. When it comes to baseball, Mr. Apatow is apparently just another heartbroken New York Mets fan.

headline: ‘Inverted Cheerios Effect’ Returns Physics to the Breakfast Table
abstract: Scientists’ discovery that liquids are repelled from one another on a thin enough surface could have implications for materials science and bioengineering.
lead_paragraph: Is it polite to discuss the fundamental forces of the universe at the breakfast table? The Cheerios effect — which described why those little O’s clump together on the surface of milk in your bowl — brought physics to morning mealtimes when it was identified more than 10 years ago. Now, scientists are extending that conversation over breakfast with “the inverted Cheerios effect.” But for this one, you should swap your bowl of cereal for a pan full of Jell-O.

headline: Amazon Fashion and Jefferson Hack Host Men’s Fashion Week Parties
abstract: Guests included Jack Huston, Anja Rubik, Ebon Moss-Bachrach and lots of male models.
lead_paragraph: Guests included Jack Huston, Anja Rubik, Ebon Moss-Bachrach and lots of male models.

headline: Deveaux: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Barcelona’s Support of Lionel Messi in Tax Fraud Case Creates a Backlash
abstract: The team’s campaign to support its star has infuriated those trying to collect Spanish taxes and has been described by a government agency as “completely wrong.”
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Among Barcelona’s roster of international superstars, the team has long singled out Lionel Messi for special care. But after Barcelona began an online campaign in support of Messi after he was sentenced in a tax fraud case, many in Spain are asking just how far a club should go to support its best player.

headline: A Tony Winner and Broadway Veterans Join the Chicago Cast of ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Karen Olivo will play Angelica Schuyler, and Miguel Cervantes has been cast as Alexander Hamilton. Alexander Gemignani will play King George III.
lead_paragraph: Karen Olivo, a 2009 Tony winner for her performance as Anita in “West Side Story,” will be among the stars in the Chicago cast of “Hamilton,” the producer Jeffrey Seller announced on Wednesday. The cast will also include the Broadway veterans Miguel Cervantes (“If/Then,” “American Idiot”) as Alexander Hamilton and Alexander Gemignani as King George III.

headline: Partying with Common, Kellan Lutz and Others at Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: The week’s top parties were hosted by Amazon Fashion, Cadillac and Dazed Media.
lead_paragraph: As far as partying is concerned, New York Fashion Week: Men’s does not compare to the debauchery of the larger fashion weeks. But there were still plenty of opportunities to hang with models, designers and celebrities.

headline: Where Is D.B. Cooper? F.B.I. Ends 45-Year Hunt
abstract: The agency interviewed hundreds of suspects and leads in the 1971 hijacking, but said this week it would put the case to rest.
lead_paragraph: It remains one of the greatest unsolved mysteries in the United States, a startling crime that captured the American imagination, inspiring songs, movies, TV shows and books.

headline: New Dinosaur and T. Rex Were Brothers in Tiny Arms
abstract: Gualicho shinyae was found to have evolved its stubby arms independently, suggesting there was some evolutionary advantage to the small size.
lead_paragraph: Tyrannosaurus rex may have been king of the dinosaurs, but it was also president of the itty-bitty forelimb committee.

headline: The South China Sea Dispute
abstract: An Asia scholar faults the United States for not ratifying the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fragments of a Life: A Curbside Mystery
abstract: A quest to solve the mystery behind an abandoned bag of photo slides found on a New York City street corner leads the reporter Deborah Acosta and her audience to uncover truths about life, love, and loss.
lead_paragraph: A quest to solve the mystery behind an abandoned bag of photo slides found on a New York City street corner leads the reporter Deborah Acosta and her audience to uncover truths about life, love, and loss.

headline: In the Court of Public Opinion: Justice Ginsburg vs. Donald Trump
abstract: Readers criticize and praise Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s comments about the candidate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Slow to Show
abstract: Every year, the city of Odessa, Tex., is witness to a strange phenomenon: cars that fly.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the city of Odessa, Tex., is witness to a strange phenomenon: cars that fly.

headline: Congressional Letter to the International Olympic Committee
abstract: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce sent a letter Tuesday to the I.O.C. expressing concern about doping in international sports.
lead_paragraph: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce sent a letter Tuesday to the I.O.C. expressing concern about doping in international sports.

headline: Rochambeau: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Slow to Show
abstract: Every year, the city of Odessa, Tex., is witness to a strange phenomenon: cars that fly.
lead_paragraph: When I played football as a teenager in the Midwest, the first book that I connected with was “Friday Night Lights.” To my adolescent mind, the high school in that book, in Odessa, Tex., and its football team represented the essence of small town America. Years later, when I discovered that Odessa was also home to the famous Tejano Super Car Show, I was intrigued.

headline: National Health Spending to Surpass $10,000 a Person in 2016
abstract: The Obama administration on Wednesday noted the milestone after years of slow growth and said health care would account for 20 percent of the economy by 2025.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — National health spending will average more than $10,000 a person this year for the first time, the Obama administration said Wednesday, a milestone that heralds somewhat faster growth in health spending after several years of exceptionally low growth.

headline: Let Pokémon Go Be Your Tour Guide
abstract: Hunting Pokémon can be a fun way to explore a city, though it’s not without its drawbacks. Here are tips on how and where to play as a traveler.
lead_paragraph: Maybe gaming isn’t your thing, but you’d like to know what all the fuss is about Pokémon Go, the mobile game that in the second week since its release is already rivaling Twitter in popularity in the United States.

headline: Buying the Shirt Off Justin Bieber’s Back
abstract: Pop stars like Justin Bieber and Kanye West are nudging their concert wares toward full-fledged fashion collections.
lead_paragraph: They waited three hours, sometimes in driving rain, to ascend to the fifth floor of a parking garage in Miami Beach. It was the Fourth of July weekend, but the lines went down the block. The promised land was a glass box aerie filled with Justin Bieber-branded T-shirts, sweatshirts and hats.

headline: 3 Ways to Punch Up Your Summer Look
abstract: A breezy new clothing line launching this week, an eyewear shop with hard-to-find frames and a repurposed picnic bag that'll go anywhere.
lead_paragraph: A breezy new clothing line launching this week, an eyewear shop with hard-to-find frames and a repurposed picnic bag that'll go anywhere.

headline: ‘All Possibilities’ Under Investigation in Italian Train Crash
abstract: The chief prosecutor said human error was only “a starting point” in the inquiry as the operation of that stretch of railway came under heavy criticism.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian authorities said on Wednesday that they were investigating an archaic phone alert system and delays in railway upgrades, along with human error, as possible causes of the head-on train collision that killed about two dozen people in the southern region of Puglia this week.

headline: Colorful Knits: The More, the Merrier
abstract: When it comes to mixing playfully hued and patterned pieces, there are no rules.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to mixing playfully hued and patterned pieces, there are no rules.

headline: Police and Race: The Lessons of Dallas, and Beyond
abstract: Reacting to the memorial service in Dallas, and to issues raised by the events of the last week.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Tour of Bed-Stuy with Monstah Black and Manchildblack
abstract: The choreographer/performance artist and his D.J./producer husband take T to their favorite neighborhood haunts for home décor, Senegalese food and more.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer/performance artist and his D.J./producer husband take T to their favorite neighborhood haunts for home décor, Senegalese food and more.

headline: A Day in Bed-Stuy With Its Favorite Creative Couple
abstract: The performance artist Monstah Black and his D.J. husband Manchildblack take T out for home décor shopping, Senegalese food and more.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer and performance artist Monstah Black is a neighborhood fixture in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn — and not just for his eccentric, eye-catching style. During a recent mild summer afternoon stroll there, Black and his longtime partner (and now husband), Manchildblack, seemed to know everyone. Friendship and collaboration — especially with Manchildblack, a D.J. and producer — are at the core of Black’s life and practice, with one notable exception: his current genre-bending, wild solo act “Hyperbolic! (The Last Spectacle),” playing at the experimental theater Dixon Place.

headline: Waves of Dark History Break on an Olympic Pool
abstract: Adriana Varejão, whose work will be on display in Rio de Janeiro, uses Baroque elements to create art that speaks of Brazil’s colonial days.
lead_paragraph: In a few weeks, as TV cameras swoop over the Olympic Park in the  Barra da Tijuca neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro, viewers will glimpse what looks like a colossal seascape mural encircling the new aquatics stadium.

headline: A Great Portuguese Escape
abstract: You could venture past the walls of Casa Mãe — a charming new resort, once a 19th-century estate — but you’ll want for nothing if you don’t.
lead_paragraph: In the small coastal town of Lagos, known for its romantically remote beaches, the new hotel Casa Mãe is a celebration of contemporary Portuguese design, and a little village unto itself. The formerly ruined 19th-century family estate showcases the work of dozens of local craftsmen in the form of textiles, ceramics and woodwork, found in 30 unique guest rooms (spread over three houses) and two restaurants (with their own organic garden) from chef Pedro Limão, plus an artisan boutique. There’s also a pool with cabanas, a farmer’s market, an outdoor movie theater, yoga and crafts classes and an in-house magazine. It’s the perfect sunny spot to hang your hat, forget your worries and eat the sweetest oranges in the world.

headline: The New York Men’s Shows: Sincere, Inclusive, Politically Engaged
abstract: A Black Lives Matter protest and heady designers let the real world in.
lead_paragraph: Topping off the clear liquid in his plastic drinking cup, Michael Kors signaled that it was time to get started. “I’ve refilled my vodka, so I’m ready to roll,” the designer said.

headline: Shedding New Light on the Gun Debate
abstract: A feature at the website FiveThirtyEight might change the way you think about America’s gun crisis.
lead_paragraph: The journalists at the website FiveThirtyEight have just made a serious contribution to the debate about gun violence in the United States.

headline: Can’t Get Through ‘Ulysses’? Digital Help Is on the Way.
abstract: Technically diverse artists have taken up the challenge of freshly interpreting “Ulysses” to make it more accessible to a wider audience.
lead_paragraph: It’s O.K. to admit it: You tried to read James Joyce’s “Ulysses” and ended up chucking the thing aside in frustration. You are not alone. According to her letters, Virginia Woolf (“Never did I read such tosh”) had a long stall after 200 pages. Several well-known authors in the Book Review’s By the Book interview feature admit to leaving the novel unfinished. “Ulysses” even notched the No. 3 spot in the Top Five Abandoned Classics poll published by the Goodreads site a few years ago.

headline: A Haircut for French Taxpayers? Hollande’s $10,000-a-Month Stylist Is Revealed
abstract: Revelations that President François Hollande’s hairdresser is paid about as much as a government minister have caused a stir in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As heads of state go, this one appears to be quite expensive.

headline: Review: ‘The Invention of Russia’ Examines the Post-Soviet Path
abstract: In Arkady Ostrovsky’s chronicle, the West plays a minor role in the chaotic emergence of a new, but no less authoritarian, state.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has spent time in Russia over the past 30 years should be deeply grateful for Arkady Ostrovsky’s fast-paced and excellently written book, “The Invention of Russia: From Gorbachev’s Freedom to Putin’s War.”

headline: Nautica: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Thaddeus O’Neil: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Catherine Keener Reads ‘Live Without Me. I’ll Understand.’
abstract: The actress reads the story of a woman who re-evaluates her role in the world as her plane comes close to crashing.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Catherine Keener (“The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” “Being John Malkovich”) reads the 2006 essay “Live Without Me. I’ll Understand.” In it, a woman’s near-death experience helps her come to terms with the inevitability of life going on in her absence.

headline: Court Rules Tort Claims Can Proceed in G.M. Ignition Switch Case
abstract: An appellate court said that the automaker’s bankruptcy did not preclude lawsuits over a problem that predated it, because G.M. hid the problem from the public.
lead_paragraph: The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has broadly agreed with the federal bankruptcy court in New York that a certain type of bankruptcy asset sale can bar successor liability claims, but disagreed with the bankruptcy judge’s “no harm, no foul” analysis in the specific case of General Motors and its failure to give proper notice to some potential creditors. Most people will focus on the second point of Wednesday’s decision, but the first has much more significance in the long run for Chapter 11 practice.

headline: Director Pulls ‘Hamlet’ From Theater for a New Audience
abstract: In an unusual artistic rift, Sam Gold is seeking instead to stage the play at the Public Theater, with Oscar Isaac still starring.
lead_paragraph: It seemed to be a coup for Theater for a New Audience: Its first summer Shakespeare production would be “Hamlet,” with the much-lauded Tony-winning director Sam Gold at the helm, and the rising Hollywood star Oscar Isaac in the title role.

headline: What Clinton Should Have Said About Race
abstract: It’s not enough to call for a “conversation.” To heal, the country needs strong policy ideas.
lead_paragraph: ON Wednesday, speaking on the same site where Abraham Lincoln delivered his “House Divided” speech just over 150 years ago, Hillary Clinton addressed race in a very modern fashion: by calling for a “conversation,” with the goal of bringing us all together. Fifty years ago the proactive approach to race was considered to be legislation; today it is considered enlightened to call for a kind of abstract discourse. The problem is that this conception of a race “conversation” has never added up to anything real.

headline: Michael Kiwanuka’s ‘Love & Hate’ Plunges Into Despair, With a Retro Feel
abstract: Mr. Kiwanuka’s second album, produced by Danger Mouse, is a sustained, stylized work, transported to an early-1960s soundstage.
lead_paragraph: In times of pain and fear, the past can feel like a refuge. Michael Kiwanuka’s second album, “Love & Hate,” is a sustained, stylized plunge into despair: plaints of isolation, doubt, lovelessness, racial injustice, longing, hopelessness and a certain resolve despite it all, often set to mournful minor chords. “Love and hate — how much more are we supposed to tolerate?” he asks in the title song, before quietly insisting, “You can’t break me down.”

headline: Theresa May, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: China, Sweltering, Doles Out Subsidies for High Heat
abstract: By law, many people who work outdoors are eligible for a subsidy whenever temperatures exceed 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After three days of torrid heat in Beijing, with thermometer readings in the upper 90s Fahrenheit, the air in the city’s concrete canyons and on its giant ring roads has cooled a little, to 95. Enough for city officials to drop the health warning they had posted on Sunday, as they do whenever temperatures exceed that threshold.

headline: Bessie Awards Announce This Year’s Nominees
abstract: The awards will be presented on Oct. 18. Twelve works are nominated for outstanding production, among them Justin Peck’s “Heatscape.”
lead_paragraph: Nominees for the New York Dance and Performance Awards, known as the Bessies, were announced on Wednesday evening.

headline: New Beginnings (and New Merch) at Dover Street Market and Comme des Garçons
abstract: New shops and pop-ups in the Hamptons, a first-ever sample sale for MAC, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday and Friday, you’ll find pretty bits like a Cienne hand-woven scarf ($85), an AUrate New York choker with black onyx cabochons ($200) and a Von Holzhausen leather bucket bag ($650) at a pop-up hosted by these three direct-to-consumer brands founded by women. At 156 Spring Street.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Kosovo Human Rights Report
abstract: The report by the Human Rights Advisory Panel, part of the mission in Kosovo, contains extraordinarily strong language about, among other things, failures to investigate disappearances and killings.
lead_paragraph: The report by the Human Rights Advisory Panel, part of the mission in Kosovo, contains extraordinarily strong language about, among other things, failures to investigate disappearances and killings.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,600 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted July 8 to 12 with 1,600 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,358 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Race Relations Are at Lowest Point in Obama Presidency, Poll Finds
abstract: A New York Times/CBS News Poll indicates that relations between African-Americans and the police are so brittle that the attack that killed five officers in Dallas left many respondents unsurprised.
lead_paragraph: Sixty-nine percent of Americans say race relations are generally bad, one of the highest levels of discord since the 1992 riots in Los Angeles during the Rodney King case, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Donald Trump Seeks $10 Million From Ex-Adviser Over Leaks
abstract: Lawyers for the candidate have taken Sam Nunberg, who was fired from the campaign last year, to arbitration over charges that he violated a nondisclosure agreement.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is demanding more than $10 million in damages from a former campaign adviser he accuses of leaking confidential information to the news media, court documents made public on Wednesday showed.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Frees Pastor Detained Over Protests Against Mugabe
abstract: A court ruled that the state’s efforts to increase the severity of charges against the pastor, the Rev. Evan Mawarire, were unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — A pastor who has emerged as a leading voice against the government of President Robert Mugabe was freed on Wednesday after a court ruled that the state’s efforts to increase the severity of the charges against him were unconstitutional.

headline: New York City Ballet Savors the City of Light
abstract: On Saturday, City Ballet will wrap its three-week season at the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Saturday, the New York City Ballet will wrap up a 20-ballet, three-week season at Théâtre du Châtelet here, the company’s longest international tour to one city since 1976. City Ballet was presented by Les Etés de la Danse, an annual summer festival that brings dance companies — often American ones — to the French capital.

headline: Dozens Possibly Overdosed on K2
abstract: In Brooklyn, 33 people who were suspected of overdosing on K2 — a synthetic drug — were transported to hospitals on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn, 33 people who were suspected of overdosing on K2 — a synthetic drug — were transported to hospitals on Tuesday.

headline: Armstrong Williams, Ex-Adviser to Ben Carson, Is Accused of Sexual Harassment
abstract: A former aide, Charlton Woodyard, is suing Mr. Williams on charges of having him fired after he rebuffed Mr. Williams’s advances.
lead_paragraph: Armstrong Williams, who was a top adviser to Ben Carson’s presidential campaign, has been sued on charges of sexually harassing a male aide and then having him fired after he rebuffed the advances.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Theresa May’s Style: Put Your Head Down and Get to Work
abstract: Britain’s new prime minister is widely seen as a safe pair of hands, but the times may demand that she be both steady and bold.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Her beloved father, an Anglican vicar, died in a car crash when she was 25, after she had been married only a year, and her mother, who had multiple sclerosis, died a few months later. For Theresa May, a cherished only child, the shock was devastating.

headline: Misty Copeland Joins Disney’s ‘Nutcracker’ Film
abstract: Ms. Copeland, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, will play the lead ballerina role in the live-action film “The Nutcracker and the Four Realms.”
lead_paragraph: Misty Copeland is joining Disney’s live-action “Nutcracker” film. Ms. Copeland, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, announced her involvement with the project on Instagram.

headline: Maralin Niska, Lyric Soprano at New York City Opera Who Won Hearts, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Niska, who appeared in 29 lead roles with City Opera, was known for her supple voice, her mesmerizing stage presence and her movie-star looks.
lead_paragraph: Maralin Niska, a lyric soprano whose mesmerizing stage presence and command of dozens of roles made her a mainstay of New York City Opera in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Saturday at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 89.

headline: Astronomers Discover New Likely Dwarf Planet, the Latest of Many
abstract: The object was seen in the Kuiper belt, a ring of icy debris beyond Neptune. Dozens of similar bodies may also meet the definition of a dwarf planet.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood beyond Neptune is becoming ever more crowded, with astronomers announcing this week the discovery of another likely dwarf planet.

headline: Tinkerbell at Starbucks
abstract: Asked what name to put on her drink orders, a woman likes to mention various Disney characters for fun.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Senate Approves Bill to Combat Opioid Addiction Crisis
abstract: The comprehensive measure was a rare instance of consensus in Congress, although Democrats say the bill is an empty promise without funding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday approved a bill to tackle the nation’s opioid crisis, sending to the president’s desk the most sweeping drug legislation in years in a rare instance of consensus in Congress.

headline: Gretchen Carlson’s Fox News Contract Could Shroud Her Case in Secrecy
abstract: If the former Fox News anchor’s suit is forced into arbitration, her chances of winning are lessened, and little will be made public about it.
lead_paragraph: When Gretchen Carlson sought her day in court with a sexual harassment lawsuit against Roger Ailes, her former boss at Fox News, Mr. Ailes’s lawyers had a quick response: Move the case to arbitration.

headline: Theresa May to the Rescue
abstract: The new prime minister faces the tough task of creating a future for Britain outside the European Union.
lead_paragraph: A lot has happened since Britain voted on June 23 to leave the European Union, most of it unexpected — including the result of the vote itself. That was followed by the swift exit of Prime Minister David Cameron, the unintentional instigator of the needless referendum, along with Boris Johnson, Michael Gove and Andrea Leadsom, all of whom had hoped to exploit their support of Brexit to win a promotion to Mr. Cameron’s office. In the end, it has been left to a competent, experienced and staid political veteran who did not support Brexit, but didn’t much campaign against it, to clean up the mess.

headline: In a High-Tech Era, Baseball Teams Still Talk With Their Hands
abstract: Nonverbal signs from coaches and catchers allow rapid adjustment by batters and pitchers, but players don’t always pick them up under the pressure of an at-bat.
lead_paragraph: In the moment of pause between pitches, a batter steps back and takes a peek at the third-base coach. The coach executes a series of taps on his body and the batter turns back and prepares for the next pitch. But only a handful of people in the stadium know the message that was sent, or whether there was one at all.

headline: Police Raid 5 Brooklyn Bodegas After Suspected K2 Overdoses
abstract: No K2, also known as synthetic marijuana, was found in the raids, which came a day after 33 people were sent to the hospital for suspected overdoses.
lead_paragraph: New York City police raided five bodegas in Brooklyn on Wednesday, a day after a wave of suspected overdoses from the synthetic drug K2 sent at least 33 people to the hospital and raised fears that the use of a substance that officials had indicated was on the wane was instead on the rise.

headline: United Nations Assailed in Report by Kosovo Rights Panel
abstract: The panel said its effort to make the United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo accountable for rights violations had been a “total failure.”
lead_paragraph: The United Nations received a stunning rebuke on Wednesday from a human rights panel attached to its troubled Kosovo peacekeeping mission, which described the panel’s efforts to make the mission accountable for rights violations as “a total failure.”

headline: Faiza Saeed to Become First Woman to Lead Cravath, Swaine & Moore
