abstract: Faiza J. Saeed’s 25 years at the law firm have included some of the most prominent corporate deals in recent history.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest deal makers at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a pre-eminent law firm on Wall Street, is poised to take over its top spot — and become the first woman to do so.

headline: Cleveland’s Police and Courts Prepare for Unruly Visitors
abstract: City officials have tightened security plans for handling what is expected to be a volatile atmosphere surrounding the nomination of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — With thousands of protesters expected to descend on Cleveland for next week’s Republican National Convention, city officials have devised intricate plans to handle mass arrests should chaos break out on the streets, identifying jail facilities to house more than 975 arrested protesters and keeping courts open for 20 hours daily to process cases.

headline: Republican Officials Brace for Chaos at Convention
abstract: Proposals to change the party’s platform and how delegates vote could upend the convention, which is normally a well-choreographed moment of party unity.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Republicans are bracing for the possibility of a drawn-out fight over Donald J. Trump’s nomination that could stretch into the convention next week, a spectacle party leaders are desperate to avoid.

headline: Bronx District Attorney Says New System Will Reduce Case Delays
abstract: Darcel D. Clark is addressing delays by adopting a new system this month that will assign every incoming case to a single prosecutor who will be responsible from beginning to end.
lead_paragraph: When Darcel D. Clark was a judge in the Bronx, she used to see criminal cases in her courtroom delayed for weeks, even months, as they were handed from one prosecutor to another.

headline: Bernardo Provenzano, Who Led Sicilian Mafia Clan, Is Dead at 83
abstract: Mr. Provenzano managed to elude the Italian police for four decades before being captured in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Bernardo Provenzano, the godfather of Sicily’s flesh-and-blood Corleone crime family who eluded the police for 43 years and who was a convicted conspirator in the murder of Italy’s two leading Mafia prosecutors, died on Wednesday in Milan. He was 83.

headline: Islanders Are ‘Full-Time Focus’ for New Majority Owner Jon Ledecky
abstract: Ledecky, a New York City native who took over the franchise with Scott Malkin on July 1, said he was committed to improving the fan experience at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Jon Ledecky is not shy about the paramount issues that will face the Islanders next season, his first as majority owner. He is focused on being accountable to fans as expectations grow to improve on the team’s first year at Barclays Center.

headline: 3 Plead Not Guilty in New York Police Corruption Case
abstract: Two former police leaders and a businessman were arrested last month on charges prosecutors say stem from gifts made in return for favors.
lead_paragraph: Two former commanders of the New York Police Department and a Brooklyn businessman were arraigned on Wednesday on federal corruption charges that prosecutors say stem from illegal gifts made in return for police favors.

headline: Construction Firm Found Guilty in Queens Worker’s Death Defies Sentence
abstract: Harco Construction, vowing to appeal, said it would not obey a judge’s order that it pay for public service announcements on worker safety.
lead_paragraph: A general contracting company that was found guilty of manslaughter in the death last year of a construction worker vowed on Wednesday to defy a judge’s order that it pay for public service announcements on worker safety.

headline: Obama Urges Civil Rights Activists and Police to Bridge Divide
abstract: The president, administration officials, police representatives and figures in the Black Lives Matter movement met at the White House, with tensions rising in closed-door sessions.
lead_paragraph: Washington — President Obama said on Wednesday that the profound tensions between the police and African-American communities were likely to worsen “for quite some time” after the series of wrenching shooting deaths this month, urging law enforcement officials and civil rights activists at a lengthy and at times tense White House gathering to keep pressing to bridge their differences.

headline: Iran Sticks to Terms of Nuclear Deal, but Defies the U.S. in Other Ways
abstract: The worst predictions of what would happen under the deal have not come to pass, but very little outside the strict confines of the agreement has improved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year after President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, the worst predictions of what would happen next have not come to pass.

headline: Howard Raiffa, Mathematician Who Studied Decision Making, Dies at 92
abstract: He was co-founder of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and a professor at the university for 37 years who pioneered decision science.
lead_paragraph: Howard Raiffa, an economics professor whose mathematical formulas for decision making were applied to the search for a missing nuclear bomb and the siting of a Mexico City airport, and were even suggested as a way to resolve a strike by professional hockey players, died on July 8 at his home in Oro Valley, Ariz. He was 92.

headline: Rights Groups Sue Over Police Tactics in Baton Rouge Protests
abstract: Local justice organizations and the A.C.L.U. asked for a temporary restraining order prohibiting the police from using strong-arm tactics against protesters.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Local justice organizations and the American Civil Liberties Union sued local and state officials and law enforcement agencies in federal court on Wednesday, accusing them of abusing peaceful protesters and violating their constitutional rights.

headline: NBC Has the Stars, if Not at the Olympics
abstract: The company last year secured a 12-year deal to carry the British Open. But the event is the least-viewed major, and some top players have bowed out the Rio Games, another NBC broadcast.
lead_paragraph: When the British Open begins Thursday at Royal Troon in Scotland, the links will be played by some of the world’s top golfers, like Jason Day, Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy. Their presence might lift NBC and Golf Channel as they begin televising the least-viewed major for the first time.

headline: You’ve Heard It Many Times Before
abstract: David Kahn spells it out for us.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE  — Hotel Alfa Papa Papa Yankee Tango Hotel Uniform Romeo Sierra Delta Alfa Yankee, Sierra Oscar Lima Victor Echo Romeo Sierra!

headline: The Mirrors Behind Rembrandt’s Self-Portraits
abstract: A new paper outlines optical techniques that the 17th-century Dutch painter may have used to make accurate self-portraits.
lead_paragraph: At age 18, Francis O’Neill, an aspiring young painter, went on a train trip around Europe and was struck by the Rembrandt masterpieces he saw in galleries. Like many before him, he was astounded by Rembrandt’s technical accuracy.

headline: Eye Injuries Flood Kashmir Hospitals After Police Fire Pellets at Protesters
abstract: More than 30 people have been killed during demonstrations since Saturday, authorities said, and more than 2,000 injured, including some with severe eye trauma.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Patients, some with severe eye trauma, have overrun hospitals in the Indian-administered part of Kashmir, doctors said on Wednesday, after security forces used pellet guns to break up demonstrations that have shaken the region.

headline: CP Company: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2 Premiere: The Hack Is Back
abstract: A series that initially hooked an audience with its kinetic twists and turns, has taken a somber tone. A risk that’s paying early rewards.
lead_paragraph: “Why this mask? It’s a bit silly, isn’t it?” The opening lines of the second season of “Mr. Robot” may emerge from the mouth of corporate creep turned America’s most-wanted missing person Tyrell Wellick, but the man speaks for many of us. Despite having joined forces with the show’s mentally unstable main character Elliot Alderson and his hacker confederacy fsociety, Wellick is not above questioning the group’s corny iconography. The Anonymous-indebted disguises, the snide sobriquet, the “Fight Club” posturing: Is there really a method to this madness, Wellick wonders, or is it all a cheesy cover for adolescent anarchism that won’t change a thing in the long run? That’s the question “Mr. Robot” is apparently trying to answer — and so far, that answer is a surprisingly grim one.

headline: Speakers at Donald Trump’s Convention: Tim Tebow, Peter Thiel, but No Sarah Palin?
abstract: The roster of speakers features some of Mr. Trump’s eclectic collection of friends, celebrities and relatives.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — A night highlighting the tragedy in Benghazi, Libya. An appearance by onetime football star Tim Tebow. A presentation detailing former President Bill Clinton’s sexual misconduct.

headline: Law Center Calls Seller-Financed Home Sales ‘Toxic Transactions’
abstract: In its new report, the National Consumer Law Center calls for greater federal and state oversight of certain seller-financed home sales that many view as predatory.
lead_paragraph: Seller-financed home sales are “toxic transactions,” a prominent national consumer law organization said on Thursday as it released a report and called for greater federal and state oversight of the sales.

headline: 9/11 Museum to Open Its First Art Exhibition in September
abstract: The show will include a nearly 3,000-piece painting installation representing each victim of the attacks.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the National September 11 Memorial Museum, built at ground zero, has presented visitors with a collection that reflects the moments of horror and heroism 15 years ago when terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center.

headline: An Early Bedtime for Kids May Fight Weight Gain
abstract: Preschool children who are in bed by 8 p.m. are far less likely to be obese during adolescence than children who stay up late.
lead_paragraph: Preschool children who are in bed by 8 p.m. are far less likely to be obese during adolescence than children who stay up late, a study has found. Their risk of teenage obesity is half the risk faced by preschoolers who stay up past 9 p.m.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: President Obama discusses recent shootings. And “30 for 30” follows the rise and fall of Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry.
lead_paragraph: At a town-hall meeting, President Obama discusses the recent shootings in Dallas, Minneapolis and Baton Rouge, La. “30 for 30” follows the rise and fall of Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry. And Jerry Seinfeld goes cruising with Lorne Michaels.

headline: Corrections: July 14, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, July 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, July 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s kind of like diamonds. The more pressure you get, the stronger you get, the more beautiful you are. No matter how much pressure you put on us, we’re just going to get better.”

headline: Nest Relies on New Outdoor Security Camera as Comeback
abstract: In light of recent upheaval, the company is trying to convey stability as it introduces Nest Cam Outdoor, a waterproof, rugged model of its smart security camera.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nest, the division of Alphabet that makes internet-connected household devices, has recently grappled with the resignation of its chief executive at a time of upheaval over his management style, as well as criticism that its products are unreliable.

headline: Blood on Your Hands, Too
abstract: Interpersonal and systemic racism are only part of the equation. There is also class conflict between those who are better off and those who are not.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that we should examine incidents of police violence for traces of bias, if for no other reason than to rule it out if it isn’t present. Indeed, we should all search ourselves for manifestations of racial bias.

headline: How Excessive Executive Pay Hurts Shareholders
abstract: A study casts doubt on the supposedly close link between how well investors and company executives are rewarded.
lead_paragraph: In theory, “pay for performance” — linking executive pay to a company’s stock price — aligns the interests of executives and shareholders. It’s supposed to ensure that executives are not tempted to enrich themselves at the expense of shareholders, who are too numerous and far-flung to influence a company’s behavior.

headline: Does Pence Make Sense for Trump?
abstract: Indiana is the center of the universe.
lead_paragraph: I am embarrassed to admit how much I’ve enjoyed the Donald Trump vice-presidential search. There’s nothing like a bunch of egomaniacs humiliating themselves in public to cheer up a dark day.

headline: A History of White Delusion
abstract: We’re in denial of racial inequity.
lead_paragraph: In 1962, 85 percent of white Americans told Gallup that black children had as good a chance as white kids of getting a good education. The next year, in another Gallup survey, almost half of whites said that blacks had just as good a chance as whites of getting a job.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Rude Awakening
abstract: Indifference and insults from Washington have left us no better off than a powerless colony.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — IT’S official now. Puerto Rico has about as much sovereignty as a United States colony.

headline: Packing Heat in Cleveland
abstract: In the name of gun rights and free speech, a number of groups plan to carry their weapons outside the convention center in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans gather in Cleveland next week, the life-and-death issue that party leaders regularly duck — the potential for violence that citizens with easy access to guns pose for the nation — will be on graphic display outside their convention center. A number of groups have announced plans to exploit Ohio’s lenient open-carry gun law to flaunt their military-style assault rifles and other weaponry in designated protest zones, all in the name of protecting gun rights and free speech.

headline: So Many Research Scientists, So Few Openings as Professors
abstract: There is such a surplus of Ph.D.s that in the most popular fields, like biomedicine, fewer than one in six reach their goal in academia.
lead_paragraph: The United States is producing more research scientists than academia can handle.

headline: What Ethics Should Guide the Use of Robots in Policing?
abstract: The decision by U.S. police to deploy a remote-controlled machine to kill the Dallas sniper last week appears to be unprecedented.

headline: 1921: Review of Jean Cocteau’s Dadaist ‘Ballet’
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A review of “Les Mariés de la Tour Eiffel,” by Jean Cocteau in 1921.
lead_paragraph: In July 1916, the Dada cultural movement was born in Zurich, largely as a reaction to World War I. It had a huge influence on dance, music and the visual arts. Below is the New York Herald review of Jean Cocteau’s Dadaist ballet “Les Mariés de la Tour Eiffel,” published in 1921.

headline: Politics as Unusual: Finding Magic in the Periphery
abstract: Jessica Dimson, a photo editor on the Politics desk of The New York Times, talks about how to find unique images in the midst of intensely covered and highly stage-managed campaign events.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Dimson, a photo editor on the Politics desk of The New York Times, talks about how to find unique images in the midst of intensely covered and highly stage-managed campaign events.

headline: College Men for Trump
abstract: White male college graduates play a bigger role in his nationalist movement than is commonly understood.
lead_paragraph: It’s relatively easy to understand how the bitter grievances of the white working class drive support for Donald Trump. What’s less understandable is why a plurality of college-educated white men backs the Republican Party’s combative soon-to-be nominee.

headline: When the Planets Align, Delhi Drowns in a Chorus of ‘I Do’
abstract: A certain astrological configuration is considered auspicious by many Indians, and in the capital it means something very specific: a wedding apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: Several times a year, the fearsome “shadow planets” Rahu and Ketu, along with slow-moving Saturn, destroyer of whatever house he occupies, are for a few days disentangled from the path of any other planet.

headline: A Bed-Stuy Rental via FaceTime
abstract: Caitlyn Higgins and Antony West were moving from Florida to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Caitlyn Higgins and Antony West shared a one-bedroom in Lake Eola Heights, a historic district in Orlando, Fla. It included what was most important to them — a fenced yard for their two dogs. The rent, $1,075 a month, was high for Orlando, Ms. Higgins said, “but we lived within walking distance to everything.”

headline: Politics as Unusual: Finding Magic in the Periphery
abstract: Jessica Dimson, a photo editor on the Politics desk of The New York Times, talks about how to find unique images in the midst of intensely covered and highly stage-managed campaign events.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, Jessica Dimson, a photo editor on the Politics desk of The New York Times, has helped lead a team of photographers in covering 50 primaries and caucuses, 21 debates and countless campaign events. Ms. Dimson, who graduated from Yale, joined the Times in 2011, working as a photo editor on the Metro and National desks. Prior to The Times, she was a photo editor at Departures and Vanity Fair.

headline: Russia Looks to Populate Its Far East. Wimps Need Not Apply.
abstract: A determined Cossack’s quest reveals the gap between fantasy and harsh reality in Moscow’s effort to settle a sparsely populated region.
lead_paragraph: KAMEN-RYBOLOV, Russia — Standing ankle deep in mud in a swampy grassland more than 4,000 miles from his home, Yuri A. Bugaev surveyed a mosquito-infested wasteland that the Russian government is offering to would-be pioneers under its own modern-day version of the 1862 Homestead Act in the United States.

headline: Swimmer Kathleen Baker Overcomes Crohn’s Disease to Become an Olympian
abstract: Baker, 19, who has been dealing with the disease since she was about 13, will compete for the United States in the 100-meter backstroke in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Kathleen Baker stared at the seemingly simple question on the form distributed to members of the United States Olympic swim team. What challenges did she have to overcome on her way to qualifying for the Rio de Janeiro Games?

headline: A Portrait of the Millennial Generation Changing China
abstract: Alec Ash, author of “Wish Lanterns: Young Lives in New China,” views this generation as the “thin end of a wedge” that is slowly opening Chinese society.
lead_paragraph: Alec Ash is a 30-year-old British writer and editor living in Beijing who first came to China in 2007 to teach English in a Tibetan village. From 2008 to 2010, he studied Chinese at Peking and Tsinghua universities and started a blog on student life. In 2012, he founded the Anthill, a website dedicated to fiction, nonfiction and poetry about China that resulted in the recent anthology “While We’re Here: China Stories from a Writers’ Colony,” which he edited with Tom Pellman.

headline: The South China Sea: Explaining the Dispute
abstract: Why this body of water is considered such a big deal, and why it may be a harbinger of global power politics in the decades ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After an international tribunal in The Hague ruled emphatically against China in a territorial dispute with the Philippines, many Chinese state media outlets responded on Wednesday by publishing a map. It showed the South China Sea, with most of the waters encircled with the “nine-dash line” that has long represented China’s claims there.

headline: Ben Ehrenreich Writes a Love Letter to Palestine
abstract: Ben Ehrenreich’s “The Way to the Spring” is an intimate, vivid look at daily life in Palestine.
lead_paragraph: THE WAY TO THE SPRINGLife and Death in PalestineBy Ben EhrenreichIllustrated. 428 pp. Penguin Press. $28.

headline: Was She a Feminist? The Complicated Legacy of Helen Gurley Brown.
abstract: “Enter Helen” and “Not Pretty Enough” assess the life and influence of the longtime Cosmopolitan editor Helen Gurley Brown.
lead_paragraph: ENTER HELENThe Invention of Helen Gurley Brown and the Rise of the Modern Single WomanBy Brooke HauserIllustrated. 462 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $28.99.

headline: Clearing the Way for a Railroad
abstract: The Fortress Investment Group’s private passenger rail project, All Aboard Florida, hinged on the blessing of government officials and has prompted concern from some towns along the route.
lead_paragraph: The Fortress Investment Group’s private passenger rail project, All Aboard Florida, hinged on the blessing of government officials and has prompted concern from some towns along the route.

headline: How Private Equity Found Power and Profit in State Capitols
abstract: Private equity firms have used sophisticated but indirect political maneuvering with state and local entities to smooth the way for growth and revenue.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Inside a cramped committee room on the cactus-dotted campus of Arizona’s Capitol, Kelsey Lundy stepped to the podium to detail new legislation and the higher costs it would impose on struggling borrowers.

headline: Emmy Nominations 2016: ‘Game of Thrones’ Rules Again
abstract: The HBO drama received 23 nominations. FX’s “The People v. O.J. Simpson” and “Fargo” were the second- and third-most nominated shows.
lead_paragraph: It will feel like a familiar affair at the 68th Primetime Emmy Awards, with “Game of Thrones,” “Modern Family” and Julia Louis-Dreyfus once again landing nominations on Thursday.

headline: Google Faces New Round of Antitrust Charges in Europe
abstract: The claims relate to some of the search giant’s online advertising tools and parts of its search business linked to online shopping.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Europe’s lengthy investigations into Google, Margrethe Vestager, the region’s competition chief, is hoping that the third time’s a charm.

headline: The Emails of Natalie Portman and Jonathan Safran Foer
abstract: On the eve of two milestones — her directorial debut, his first book in a decade — the famous actress and acclaimed novelist open up their inboxes.
lead_paragraph: For over a decade, the Oscar-winning actress Natalie Portman and the author Jonathan Safran Foer have amassed countless email exchanges about family, creativity and angry koalas — until earlier this year, when their epistolary archive mysteriously disappeared. On the eve of her ambitious directorial debut, the old friends start anew, reconnecting online to reflect on how the times have changed, and how they have changed over time.

headline: On Set | Natalie Portman
abstract: The actress (and cover of T’s Summer Entertainment issue) stars in a surrealist short film by Craig McDean and Masha Vasyukova.
lead_paragraph: The actress (and cover of T’s Summer Entertainment issue) stars in a surrealist short film by Craig McDean and Masha Vasyukova.

headline: Theresa May, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: House Democrats Unveil Campaign Agenda in Hopes of Gaining Ground
abstract: After months of polling, focus groups and consultation with experts, party members have settled on “Stronger America: A New American Security Agenda” as their message.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats will roll out their campaign season agenda on Thursday, hoping that their new message will help them replicate the takeover of the House that was spurred by their “Six for ’06” platform in 2006.

headline: For Wedding Dresses, Truly Binding Contracts
abstract: Restrictive wedding dress contracts forbid changes in weight or size.
lead_paragraph: Many brides will diet before their wedding day, embarking on any number of fitness regimens and lemon-juice cleanses to appear as wasp-waisted and slender-hipped as possible. I had never imagined being one of those brides.

headline: The ‘Intentional Summer’ Challenge: Try an Unusual Ice Cream Flavor
abstract: Research shows we are more likely to embrace a novel taste if we can choose it. How about chocolate-chili ice pops or corn ice cream?
lead_paragraph: Challenge No. 4: Make (or try) an unusual flavor of ice cream.

headline: Wedding Dressing for Two (or More)
abstract: Shopping for a wedding dress can be hard, and pregnancy can make it even harder. But expectant brides can still find the perfect bridal gown.
lead_paragraph: Deirdre Wall, an actress in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, was eight months pregnant when she was married on a New Hampshire mountaintop on June 25. While planning for the wedding, even amid a whirlwind engagement and impending motherhood, she found the task of dress shopping the most worrisome.

headline: Beach Bistro 96
abstract: A seaside shack in Rockaway Beach, Queens, conjures the spirit of the Brazilian coast.
lead_paragraph: A seaside shack in Rockaway Beach, Queens, conjures the spirit of the Brazilian coast.

headline: A Bit of Brazil Washes Up at Beach Bistro 96 in Queens
abstract: Croquettes, pastries and other South American snacks from a former pro surfer and his wife.
lead_paragraph: The crepe is moon-white. Folded, it looks like a beaded clutch, studded with pearls from the world’s tiniest oysters.

headline: New York Today: Celebrating Bastille Day
abstract: Thursday: A French party, Pokémon Go safety tips and a romance at the Queens Zoo.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:22 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: The First Woman to Lead Cravath, Swaine & Moore
abstract: How Private Equity Found Power and Profit in State Capitols | Law Center Calls Seller-Financed Home Sales ‘Toxic Transactions’
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST WOMAN TO LEAD CRAVATH, SWAINE & MOORE Faiza J. Saeed, one of the biggest deal makers at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, will become the 16th presiding partner in the law firm’s two-century history, Michael J. de la Merced reports in DealBook. Ms. Saeed’s 25 years at the firm have been punctuated by some of the most prominent corporate deals in recent history.

headline: Herta Müller: By the Book
abstract: The 2009 Nobel laureate and author of the recently translated “The Fox Was Ever the Hunter” had no books of fairy tales as a child: “The only ‘fantastic’ stories came from religion class.”
lead_paragraph: The 2009 Nobel laureate and author of the recently translated “The Fox Was Ever the Hunter” had no books of fairy tales as a child: “The only ‘fantastic’ stories came from religion class.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Seduction in Grandma’s High Waters
abstract: Hand-me-downs can make lousy turn-me-ons.
lead_paragraph: Katelynn writes: I recently received some hand-me-down pants from my grandmother, mostly thin-fabric high waters. I am a social worker, and they are perfect for my visits to homeless shelters and houses without air-conditioning. But my husband makes fun of my “Mamaw pants” and rebuffs my affection when I wear them. Our budget does not allow for cooler pants. I want to wear them without harassment!

headline: A Thai Shrimp Salad of Myriad Tastes
abstract: Learning to make a tart, floral, briny, tangy dish from a Thai diplomat’s family who have taken it with them around the world.
lead_paragraph: A few stories above a blessedly calm Midtown street, the elevator doors opened and I stared straight at a Garuda — fearsome mythic eagle, mount of Lord Narayana, reflection of the divine power of the kings of Thailand — inlaid into the seal of the Royal Thai Consulate General. I had come to talk with the consul general about shrimp salad. I had heard that his wife made a good one, a tart, spicy version, almost crunchy with herbs, called pla goong. Andy Ricker, the chef of the Pok Pok restaurants in Portland, Ore., and New York, had told me about it, and assured me that because the Thai government sees its food as one of its great contributions to the world, the consul general would take my calls.

headline: The American Who Accidentally Became a Chinese Movie Star
abstract: The journey of Jonathan Kos-Read, better known as Cao Cao, is a good guide for anyone seeking to make it in China’s budding, chaotic film industry.
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: What Caused This Man to Cough Up Blood?
abstract: For more than a year, his incessant hacking erupted with the least bit of activity, but doctors couldn’t figure out what was wrong.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, his incessant hacking erupted with the least bit of activity, but doctors couldn’t figure out what was wrong.

headline: So You Thought ‘Brexit’ Was Disruptive. Here Comes ‘Ab Fab.’
abstract: Edina and Patsy (and their friends, Champagne and vodka) invade American cinemas with “Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sweetie darling! They’re back!

headline: Poll Finds Voters in Both Parties Unhappy With Their Candidates
abstract: Voters expressed deep misgivings about their presumptive nominees in a New York Times/CBS News poll. The race between Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton is tied.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the major party conventions, voters are grudgingly rallying around the nominees while expressing broad misgivings about the candidates, the campaign and the direction of the country, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Review: ‘Café Society’ Isn’t Woody Allen’s Worst Movie
abstract: This ambivalent return to 1930s Hollywood mostly rearranges the director’s old themes. But, overall, it’s an amusing little picture.
lead_paragraph: “Café Society,” Woody Allen’s new movie, comes wrapped in a double layer of nostalgia. Set in the 1930s, partly in Los Angeles, its script compulsively mentions Hollywood stars of the era. Joan Blondell! Robert Taylor! Barbara Stanwyck! Cagney and Crawford! Astaire and Rogers! Their names ring out like answers to trivia questions nobody had thought to ask.

headline: Wall Street Earnings: Watching Brexit’s Impact
abstract: Goldman Sachs reported a 78 percent jump in quarterly profit as the Wall Street bank earned more from bond trading and its expenses fell.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs reported a 78 percent jump in quarterly profit as the Wall Street bank earned more from bond trading and its expenses fell.

headline: Bank of England Holds Key Interest Rate Steady Despite Uncertainty Over ‘Brexit’
abstract: The British central bank signaled that it could lower the rate as soon as August in a bid to bolster the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite the widespread uncertainty created by Britain’s vote last month to leave the European Union, the country’s central bank decided on Thursday to hold its main interest rate steady, although it signaled that economic pressures could necessitate a cut next month.

headline: Not Forgotten: An Outlaw by Any Name: Billy the Kid
abstract: The Times branded the violent cattle rustler Billy the Kid “one of the worst characters this country has produced” shortly after his death in 1881.
lead_paragraph: The Times branded the violent cattle rustler Billy the Kid “one of the worst characters this country has produced” shortly after his death in 1881.

headline: 7 Safety Tips for Your Cruise Vacation
abstract: Advice for travelers following the latest drowning of a child in a pool on a cruise ship, and other safety issues.
lead_paragraph: In light of the recent drowning death of an 8-year-old boy in a swimming pool on the Royal Caribbean ship Anthem of the Seas, cruise safety is in the spotlight, and people in the travel industry are offering advice for passengers.

headline: My Favorite Vacation: Summer Camp
abstract: “How can a few short weeks alter the course of a lifetime? Two words: summer camp,” writes Dominique Browning.
lead_paragraph: This is part of a series of articles devoted to summer vacations that had an enduring impact on a writer’s life. Other contributors include Sara Novic, Francine Prose, Jacqueline Woodson and Deborah Levy.

headline: 5 Places to Shop in Venice
abstract: Cannaregio, Venice’s northernmost section, is mostly frequented by locals, but visitors can find everything from trendy boutiques and cafes to kosher bakeries there.
lead_paragraph: Tranquil residential neighborhoods and commercial districts frequented mostly by locals make up Cannaregio, Venice’s northernmost section. Dotting its small canals, where workaday motorboats are more common than sightseeing gondolas, are cafes and shops, from trendy boutiques to family-owned gems. The Jewish ghetto used to inhabit one section where there are now a handful of shops selling books, artwork and Judaica, as well as kosher cafes and bakeries.

headline: BlackRock Reports Dip in Quarterly Profit
abstract: Despite the decline, the company’s assets under management — a telling financial indicator — grew 4 percent, ending the quarter at $4.9 trillion.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s largest publicly traded money manager, reported a small decrease in its second-quarter profit on Thursday, as volatile market conditions and political uncertainty kept many investors on the sidelines.

headline: Theresa May’s British Cabinet Has New Faces but Old Divides
abstract: The new prime minister continued to make big changes in her government, but could face splits over how to withdraw from the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Firing adversaries and promoting allies, Prime Minister Theresa May was finalizing a cabinet on Thursday intended to carry through Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union while underscoring her desire to pursue more centrist policies at home.

headline: Video Review: Honda Ridgeline, a Stylish Pickup for the Suburbs
abstract: Honda brings back its midsize pickup, a better-looking version than the previous model, but built more for suburbia than the rodeo.
lead_paragraph: PICKUPS are all about machismo. Sold with baritone voice-overs, country-rock music and images of heroic capability, trucks are testosterone in four-wheel form. Unless it’s the second generation Honda Ridgeline.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Lead Has Shrunk, but She Still Has an Edge
abstract: A politics chat includes a look at a close race and a very busy day of polls — and what to make of them.
lead_paragraph: Nate Cohn, The Upshot’s elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York, discussed a big day of polling results, posting a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

headline: David Samson, Ally of Christie, Admits to Bribery Over Airline Route
abstract: Mr. Samson said he used his position as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to pressure United Airlines to reinstate flights that benefited him.
lead_paragraph: David Samson, a longtime friend of Gov. Chris Christie, pleaded guilty to a felony count of bribery on Thursday and admitted that he had pressured United Airlines to operate a weekly flight to South Carolina for his personal convenience.

headline: After the Philippines Celebrates South China Sea Ruling, Reality Sets In
abstract: The Philippine government, not wanting to antagonize Beijing, has urged people to “exercise restraint and sobriety.”
lead_paragraph: MANILA — At a Shakey’s restaurant in Manila this week, dozens of Filipinos — some with Philippine flags painted on their faces — wept with joy and cheered when a tribunal in The Hague announced that Beijing’s claims in the South China Sea were invalid. Around the country, others took to social media and bought rounds of drinks in celebration.

headline: Townspeople and Treasure Hunters in Hungary Search for a Sultan’s Buried Heart
abstract: Residents of Szigetvar hope the discovery of a 16th-century encampment from the last days of Suleiman the Magnificent could spell a revival for their town.
lead_paragraph: SZIGETVAR, Hungary — In the shade of a wiry cherry tree, 72-year-old Jozsef Kovacs was digging in the dry dirt with a large gardening shovel.

headline: Amid Protests Over Police Shootings of Black Men, Latinos Note a Disparity
abstract: Some advocates say that Hispanics’ fatal encounters with law enforcement do not inspire the same kind of scrutiny, outrage or discourse.
lead_paragraph: The sheriff’s deputies arrived at the home in San Antonio on a call that a woman had been injured in a domestic dispute. A bystander started recording a video as they pursued a shirtless man armed with a knife outside the home. Though taken from a distance, the video seemed to show the 41-year-old man, Gilbert Flores, raising his arms as the deputies opened fire, killing him.

headline: College at Odds With Students Over Plan to House Police for Cleveland Convention
abstract: Case Western Reserve University draws criticism for agreeing to accommodate 1,900 officers and National Guardsmen providing added event security.
lead_paragraph: Even though its campus sits nearly five miles from the arena hosting the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, Case Western Reserve University on Monday announced a virtual shutdown of its operations next week for the convention’s duration, citing concerns that last week’s shootings in Dallas, Louisiana and Minnesota could provoke a “significant degree of conflict” in the city.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Has Strong Quarter as Earnings Top Estimates
abstract: The bank said that it was seeing broad demand for loans from consumers and businesses in the United States.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase reported better-than-expected financial results on Thursday and gave credit to improvement in the American economy.

headline: Phil Mickelson Comes Close to a Record by Shooting 63 at the British Open
abstract: Mickelson’s putt for birdie on the final hole looked good almost all the way, and it would have made him the first golfer to shoot a 62 in a major tournament.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — It was in.

headline: Hot on the Campaign Trail: Reporters Describe the Candidates Up-Close
abstract: Carolyn Ryan, The Times’s senior editor for politics, sat down with Amy Chozick, Yamiche Alcindor and Patrick Healy to talk about the 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: 1916: A Glorious Fourteenth of July
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: French soldiers celebrate the Fourteenth of July in Paris in July 1916.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Yesterday [July 14] was an epoch-making Fourteenth of July in the history of France. Never did the Republic’s National Holiday arouse more patriotic emotion, and never was there more cause for rejoicing.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Expresses Regret for Criticizing Donald Trump
abstract: Justice Ginsburg, who derided the presumptive Republican nominee in several interviews, said her comments were “ill-advised.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s indignant dissents from the bench have turned her into a heroine of the left, beloved for methodically skewering her conservative colleagues. On the internet, she has become the Notorious R.B.G.

headline: ‘Sunday in the Park With George,’ With Jake Gyllenhaal, Adds 2 Performances
abstract: In addition to a Oct. 24 performance at City Center, sold out, shows have been scheduled for Oct. 25 and 26. And Annaleigh Ashford will play the love interest.
lead_paragraph: One night of Jake Gyllenhaal just isn’t enough.

headline: At Donald Trump’s Convention, Matters of Control (and Self-Control)
abstract: For some Republicans, Mr. Trump’s fiery style has heightened their excitement about the four-day political pageant, while others are fearing what’s in store.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has asked his wife, Melania, to address “women’s issues” in her speech at the Republican National Convention, he says, and his daughter Ivanka will talk about “her passion for gender equality.” He plans to read their remarks beforehand and perhaps suggest “ideas, jokes, points about Trump.” And when they take the podium in Cleveland, he may hop on Twitter to offer his own analysis and feedback.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Equals’
abstract: Drake Doremus narrates a sequence from his film featuring Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult.
lead_paragraph: Drake Doremus narrates a sequence from his film featuring Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult.

headline: Drake Doremus Narrates a Scene From ‘Equals’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult.
lead_paragraph: The science-fiction drama “Equals” imagines a future where emotions have become pathologized and criminalized. Nicholas Hoult plays a man who is diagnosed with “switched-on syndrome,” what his colleagues see as a disease that begins to bring his suppressed emotions to the forefront. Kristen Stewart plays the object of his forbidden longings. In this scene, which takes place after hours in their workplace, the two are no longer able to prevent themselves from acting on their emotions. In a recent interview the film’s director, Drake Doremus, discussed the scene. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: After Hasidic Suicide, Israel Looks in the Mirror
abstract: A woman’s death and her memoir are forcing an uncomfortable discussion between Israel’s religious and secular communities.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — In death, Esti Weinstein has started a national conversation. A 50-year-old mother of eight, Ms. Weinstein disappeared on June 21 and was found dead in her car six days later in an apparent suicide. She left behind a note and a manuscript of a memoir. She also left a long list of questions that have rekindled animosity between Israel’s secular majority and its ultra-Orthodox minority.

headline: Tim Tebow Suggests He Won’t Speak at Republican Convention
abstract: Tebow, the love-him-or-hate-him quarterback, drew outsize attention after it was reported that he would speak next week at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: For a guy who has not played in a competitive football game in almost four years, Tim Tebow has a way of making news and polarizing opinion.

headline: Does This Flag Make You Flinch?
abstract: To protest police violence, an artist resurrected an old N.A.A.C.P. flag about lynching. I wondered if provocative art could help a divided nation confront its past and present.
lead_paragraph: When I saw a photograph in my Twitter feed last Thursday of a protester holding a flag in Union Square, it was difficult to look away from the flag’s blocky, capitalized type. “A Man Was Lynched by Police Yesterday.” It shouted the words so matter-of-factly that I felt myself physically flinch.

headline: Leader of 2014 Massacre at Pakistani School Is Killed in U.S. Airstrike
abstract: Omar Mansoor was the leader of the Taliban faction Tariq Gidar and was known as one of Pakistan’s most brutal militants.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Taliban commander responsible for the 2014 attack on a Pakistani school in which more than 130 children died has been killed in an airstrike in Afghanistan, United States and Pakistani officials said.

headline: Television, the Social Medium
abstract: A look at why we need big cable packages delivering live events says much about what still matters in a digital age.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, Bruce Springsteen recorded a song about media overload and its discontents. He called it “57 Channels (And Nothin’ On).”

headline: After Brexit, Europe’s Dueling Nostalgias
abstract: As the European Union hangs in the balance, both sides seem to be thinking of past golden ages instead of planning for the future.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — SAMUEL JOHNSON once wrote of the “wonderful concentration of the mind” that the prospect of being hanged brings. It is how European leaders should feel in the wake of Brexit. As the reality of a British departure from the European Union sinks in, policy makers are being forced to concentrate their minds on some very uncertain and unsettling repercussions.

headline: Keeping Hackers From Grabbing Your Twitter Account
abstract: Password-theft, phishing and unsecured apps can lead to a compromised Twitter account, but you can shore up your defenses.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do Twitter accounts get hacked and how can I protect mine if I see tweets that I didn’t write?

headline: When Runners Don’t Have Real Jobs: A Film Featuring Alexi Pappas
abstract: A short film about the different lives of elite runners.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time it occurred to me that I was the only one of all my college friends who did not have, by normal standards, a real job.

headline: Sotheby’s to Sell David Bowie’s Art and Furniture Collection
abstract: An exhibit of around 400 of Mr. Bowie’s pieces will travel from London to the U.S. and Hong Kong before going on sale in November.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Around 400 pieces from David Bowie’s private art and furniture collection, including work by Marcel Duchamp, Henry Moore, Damien Hirst and Jean-Michel Basquiat, will go on sale at Sotheby’s here in November. The sale will be preceded by a three-week exhibition from July 20 to Aug. 9; the exhibition will then travel to Los Angeles, New York and Hong Kong.

headline: Object Lessons: The New Museum Explores Why We Keep Things
abstract: Curators at the New Museum have created an exhibit with over 4,000 objects that examines the various ways we collect and own items.
lead_paragraph: We live in a sharing economy of collaborative consumption — services, not stuff. Crowdsourcing, peer-to-peer rentals like Airbnb: An interest, exemplified by millennials, in a temporary ownership of goods.

headline: Review: ‘Pond’ Makes Misanthropy Compelling
abstract: Claire-Louise Bennett’s slim first novel is about a young academic who has decamped to an Irish village, in flight from something unspecified.
lead_paragraph: The Irish writer Claire-Louise Bennett’s first novel, “Pond,” dabbles in a black art we don’t get enough of in summertime: misanthropy.

headline: Did a Hot-Button Upshot Story Lose Sight of the Readers?
abstract: The Upshot reported on a surprising study finding that white suspects are more likely to be shot by the police than black ones are. Well, maybe, many readers protested, but. . .
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, The Times presented readers with a startling research finding from a prominent economist: “When it comes to the most lethal form of force — police shootings — the study finds no racial bias.”

headline: 7 Times Boris Johnson, Britain’s New Foreign Secretary, Was Anything but Diplomatic
abstract: An author, journalist and former mayor of London, Mr. Johnson has a rich history of gaffes and controversies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s new foreign secretary, has a quality unusual for a nation’s top diplomat: He can be spectacularly undiplomatic.

headline: Crash Near Finish Throws Tour de France Into Chaos
abstract: Richie Porte crashed into a motorbike carrying a TV camera in Thursday’s stage, causing mayhem at the finish, but race officials ruled Chris Froome would keep his yellow jersey.
lead_paragraph: VAISON-LA-ROMAINE, France — His bike crushed under a motorcycle’s tires, his Tour de France lead in jeopardy and his rivals pedaling away, Chris Froome did the only thing he could think to do: He ran toward the finish line.

headline: World Music Institute to Honor Bowie and Coltrane
abstract: The institute, which will also honor Steve Reich, will put on shows at the Met Museum, Le Poisson Rouge and National Sawdust this year.
lead_paragraph: The World Music Institute will honor David Bowie, John Coltrane and Steve Reich in its coming season starting in September. The season, the second one put together by the artistic director Par Neiburger, will take place around the city and also feature a “Desert Blues” series with four celebrated African musicians.

headline: Here Are the 2016 Emmy Nominees
abstract: The 68th Primetime Emmy Awards will be presented in a Sept. 18 ceremony on ABC.
lead_paragraph: [ Our full report on the 2016 Emmy Awards | the list of Emmy winners | red carpet looks | our critic’s review of the show ]

headline: From Etna and the Salty Sea, a White of Great Potential
abstract: The carricante grape is little known, and not much is planted, but it can make wonderfully distinctive wines.
lead_paragraph: MILO, Sicily — The first thing you notice about Salvo Foti’s new Aeris vineyard in the foothills of Mount Etna is the sponginess of the soil. In parts of the closely planted 15-acre vineyard, where the young carricante grapevines are trained to grow vertically on chestnut posts in the ancient alberello fashion, powdery soil can seem to engulf a shoe pressed too heavily into the earth.

headline: 1966: Britain Tightens Credit
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Britain tightens credit in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government stepped in today [July 14] to forestall mounting pressure on the pound by raising the bank rate and warning the nation that further deflationary steps will be taken to strengthen the economy. Prime minister Harold Wilson told the House of Commons that in addition to raising the basic lending rate from 6 to 7 percent, the government will move to restrain domestic demand, both public and private, and to reduce government expenditures overseas. The immediate effect will be to severely tighten credit. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 15, 1966

headline: Do You Have an Unusual Collection? Tell Us About It.
abstract: Do you have an unusual collection? The New York Times would like to hear about it.
lead_paragraph: Do you have an unusual collection? The New York Times would like to hear about it.

headline: How Much Weed Is in a Joint? Pot Experts Have a New Estimate
abstract: Data from drug-related arrests offered a new insight into a matter critical for marijuana research and drug policy.
lead_paragraph: How much marijuana is in a typical joint? Believe it or not, the question has perplexed experts for years. A new study claims to have an accurate estimate based on federal arrest data, and it’s less than regular users think.

headline: David Hart x Hart Schaffner Marx: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Guns and Domestic Abuse
abstract: The group Prosecutors Against Gun Violence offers its perspective.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Questions for Donald Trump’s Running Mate (Whoever It Is)
abstract: He or she will have some explaining to do.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump says he will be announcing his running mate selection within a few days, almost certainly by Friday. For all the suspense, manufactured or otherwise, Trump claims it won’t matter. “History has said nobody ever helps,” he told Chris Cillizza of The Washington Post on Monday. He is mostly right: No running mate has proved decisive in a presidential election since Lyndon Johnson helped John F. Kennedy carry Texas in 1960. But precedent has proved a cruel mistress in 2016, so really, who knows?

headline: Be Your Own Tesla
abstract: Navigating the busy streets of New York City can be difficult — until, that is, you install an autopilot system.
lead_paragraph: Thank you for coming to the first public demonstration of the autopilot system I had implanted in my head.

headline: A Year After Pluto
abstract: Spinnable maps of Pluto and Charon, one year after the NASA flyby.
lead_paragraph: Spinnable maps of Pluto and Charon, one year after the NASA flyby.

headline: Donald Trump Postpones Naming Running Mate
abstract: The presumptive Republican nominee cited the events in Nice, France, though Gov. Mike Pence is widely considered his likely choice.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign signaled strongly on Thursday that he would name Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana as his running mate, but abruptly postponed a long-planned unveiling of the Republican ticket after an  attack that left dozens dead in France.

headline: For Trump, Business Leaders Are More Elites to Resist
abstract: Donald Trump’s embrace of economic policies that are anathema to members of the Business Roundtable is seen as a betrayal of bedrock Republican principles.
lead_paragraph: Of all the groups promoting pro-business, pro-growth economic policies, none is more prominent and influential than the Business Roundtable. An elite group of chief executives of major American corporations, Roundtable members collectively have more than $7 trillion in annual revenue and employ nearly 16 million workers.

headline: Keeping a Move to a New House in Perspective
abstract: The magnitude of cancer provides a scale against which every other crisis falls happily short.
lead_paragraph: At midnight, the ice cube dispenser on the refrigerator is not merely dripping. Water pours onto the floor. I drop down towels, empty the accumulated cubes from their plastic container and pop it back inside the freezer.

headline: Line Rises in Initial Public Offering, Cheering Skittish Tech Industry
abstract: The strong debut of Line, a Japanese messaging service, in New York breaks a dry spell for technology start-ups.
lead_paragraph: The Line Corporation, the owner of a Japanese instant messaging app with a colorful cast of cartoon characters, cheered the technology industry on Thursday when its shares jumped 30 percent in their American trading debut.

headline: De Blasio Campaign Raised $1.1 Million in First Half of Year
abstract: The origin of the donations shifted considerably as Mayor Bill de Blasio, under investigation for large-scale fund-raising efforts, moved to solicit modest donations from more individuals.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s re-election campaign said on Thursday that it had raised $1.1 million over the first six months of the year.

headline: Exploiting Circus Animals
abstract: “It’s good the circus doesn’t perform with elephants anymore, but we can’t forget the rest of the animal kingdom,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Is a Protest Dance: Alvin Ailey Performs to Beyonce’s ‘Freedom’
abstract: The troupe member Sean Aaron Carmon discusses how he choreographed a piece that responds to police shootings and is set to Beyoncé’s political anthem.
lead_paragraph: Robert Battle found out that members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater had performed a new dance the same way many others on social media did — by checking his Facebook feed. “Freedom,” choreographed by the company member Sean Aaron Carmon, clocks in at less than a minute, but length isn’t the point. Set to Beyoncé’s “Freedom,” featuring Kendrick Lamar, this is a protest dance.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in New York on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in New York on Wednesday.

headline: Yale Sexual Harassment Case
abstract: A Yale official writes, “Public discretion should not be mistaken for passivity in preventing and punishing sexual harassment.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bayer Raises Takeover Bid for Monsanto
abstract: A sweetened offer of $125 a share comes after weeks of discussions between the two companies.
lead_paragraph: The German industrial giant Bayer raised its all-cash takeover bid for Monsanto on Thursday, turning up the heat in its pursuit of the American agricultural company.

headline: A Call for Unity at Services for Philando Castile
abstract: Hundreds of mourners filed into the Cathedral of St. Paul to remember Mr. Castile, who was killed last week by a suburban police officer.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — A Baptist preacher delivered a eulogy in a Roman Catholic cathedral, black and white worshipers joined hands in prayer, and nearly every inch of pew was occupied as friends, family and supporters mourned the death of Philando Castile at his funeral on Thursday.

headline: Congress Takes a Vacation Without Doing Anything About Zika
abstract: The failure to fund the fight against Zika will put thousands of people at risk.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress are leaving Washington for seven weeks without passing a bill to pay for the fight against Zika. Their failure to do so will delay the public health response to the mosquito-borne virus that causes birth defects, unnecessarily putting thousands of people at risk.

headline: Dallas Museum of Art Names Agustín Arteaga as Director
abstract: The museum has been without a leader since the unexpected departure of Max Anderson last September.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Museum of Art, which has been without a leader since the unexpected departure of Max Anderson last September, announced Thursday that its board had selected Agustín Arteaga, a veteran museum administrator and curator, to be its new director.

headline: Microsoft Wins Appeal on Overseas Data Searches
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed a ruling that Microsoft must turn over email stored in a data center in Dublin.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, American technology giants have been embroiled in a power struggle with the United States government over when authorities get to see and use the digital data that the companies collect.

headline: Extreme Anger Management: Is It O.K. to Kill the Hulk’s Alter Ego?
abstract: In the mini-series Civil II, Marvel’s heroes are divided, and the conflict has taken another victim, Bruce Banner, in defense of the greater good.
lead_paragraph: Marvel’s heroes have found themselves divided in the mini-series Civil War II and the conflict has taken another victim. In Wednesday’s issue, Bruce Banner, the alter ego of the Incredible Hulk, is killed by his fellow hero Hawkeye, who believed he was preventing an even more horrible future from coming to pass: a rampage by the green behemoth that would have left even more heroes dead.

headline: 6 Syd Schanberg Stories You’ve Never Read Before
abstract: The gravitas of Sydney H. Schanberg comes through in his stories for The Times’s house organ. So does a wicked sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at the life and work of Sydney H. Schanberg.

headline: Family of Slain Man in India May Be Charged With Cow Slaughter
abstract: A court ruled that villagers can open a criminal case against the family of a Muslim man bludgeoned to death over rumors that he slaughtered and ate a cow.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nearly a year after a mob bludgeoned to death a Muslim man, Mohammad Ikhlaq, over rumors that he had illegally killed and eaten a cow, a court ruled on Thursday that villagers could open a criminal case against the dead man’s family for cow slaughter.

headline: Bearing the Burden of Student Loans
abstract: Responses to “Even Death Is No Reprieve From a Student’s Debt,” about a New Jersey loan program.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Yahoo Is Said to Collect Final Bids as Auction Nears Its End
abstract: The bids, for Yahoo’s core internet operations, are said to be due on Monday, with the board prepared to make a decision soon after.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The gavel is finally poised to drop in the drawn-out auction for Yahoo’s core internet business.

headline: Previously Unseen Arbus, Unearthed Years After Her Death
abstract: “Diane Arbus: In the Beginning” shows, among other things, that Arbus settled early on many of her major themes.
lead_paragraph: Like many driven artists, Diane Arbus was a pitiless self-editor and a liberal self-documenter. The editor produced exactingly hard-won images, now classics of American 20th-century photography. The documenter saved every shred of preparatory matter that went into making those images: research files, handwritten notes, rejected alternatives and old experiments on which new work was built.

headline: Emmy Nominations 2016: Tracy Morgan on His Emotional Return to ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: Two years after his accident, Mr. Morgan reflects on returning to television and his Emmy nomination.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, it seemed almost impossible that Tracy Morgan would ever perform comedy again: On June 7, 2014, he was critically injured in a car crash when a tractor-trailer struck the back of a luxury van he was traveling in. A fellow passenger, James McNair (known as Jimmy Mack), was killed; three other passengers were injured; and Mr. Morgan was airlifted by helicopter to a hospital. A monthslong recovery process followed.

headline: Remembering a ‘Keystone’ Ecologist, Robert Paine
abstract: A biologist who turned sustained tide pool studies into an enduring ecological concept is remembered.
lead_paragraph: A few scientists are great theorists. A few do remarkable fieldwork. A few are inspiring teachers.

headline: Duck, Duck, Goose, Goose. Newborn Ducklings Judge Shapes and Color
abstract: New evidence suggests that 1-day-old ducklings can distinguish between same and different with no training required.
lead_paragraph: It pervades our thinking processes, from situations as simple as choosing which socks to wear in the morning to more nuanced scenarios like knowing to laugh during a wedding toast but not at a funeral.

headline: John Kerry Meets Vladimir Putin to Discuss New Syria Plan
abstract: The proposed agreement would create a joint Russia-U.S. command center to share intelligence and targeting information for “integrated operations.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Secretary of State John Kerry met with President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow late Thursday night to discuss a proposed extensive military cooperation agreement that for the first time would coordinate American and Russian air attacks on the Islamic State and the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria.

headline: Transgender Woman Is Charged With Voyeurism at Target in Idaho
abstract: Detectives said she recorded a woman changing in a fitting room. The retail chain recently changed its policy to accommodate transgender customers.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Idaho charged a transgender woman this week with secretly taking pictures of an 18-year-old woman changing in a Target fitting room.

headline: Todd Snyder: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Emmy Nominations 2016: This Year’s Snubs and Surprises
abstract: “The Americans” finally makes the Emmy list, but some fan favorites will be staying home when the awards are given out on Sept. 18.
lead_paragraph: The Television Academy announced the nominees for the 68th Emmy Awards earlier Thursday. HBO once again had the most nominations of any platform, with 94 — though that’s down substantially from last year’s 126. FX and Netflix made up the difference: FX had 56 nominations and Netflix had 54, up from 38 and 34 last year.

headline: ‘Bernie Has Shown Us That Change Is Possible’: Readers on Clinton and Sanders
abstract: Many Sanders supporters said they would vote for Hillary Clinton, but some said they couldn’t bring themselves to support her.
lead_paragraph: Many supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders said they are satisfied with his endorsement of Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign, and expressed the full range of enthusiasm — from lots to not at all — in response to recent columns.

headline: Three’s a Trend: The Return of NoLIta’s Cool Kids
abstract: A trio of stylish downtown designers — Jane Mayle, Tracy Feith and Wendy Mullin — is back.
lead_paragraph: A trio of stylish downtown designers is back.

headline: An Icelandic Volcano Reveals Secrets of Its Eruption
abstract: The gradual collapse of the top of Bardarbunga volcano in 2014 contributed to a lengthy lava flow.
lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s most cataclysmic volcanic eruptions are associated with the collapse of a caldera, a depression in the top of the volcano that forms and deepens as a reservoir of magma below it empties out.

headline: Google’s Antitrust Charges in Europe Need Quick Action
abstract: The European Commission’s newest charges add more time to the clock, a disadvantage in the ever-shifting tech market.
lead_paragraph: The European Commission has hit Google with a third antitrust charge. This time it says the tech company abused its search dominance on third-party websites. It also reinforced a claim, first made in 2010, that Google favored its own shopping service.

headline: The ESPY Awards
abstract: LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Serena Williams all won at the ESPY Awards on Wednesday night. Here are the red-carpet photos.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Serena Williams all won at the ESPY Awards on Wednesday night. Here are the red-carpet photos.

headline: Why François Hollande’s $10,000 Hair Is Good News for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Like it or not, hair is a hot subject in elections these days. But it’s no longer just an issue for women.
lead_paragraph: The news that François Hollande, the French president, spends $10,000 a month on his hair may have a lot of people rolling their eyes, and social media pretty excited (and some wondering how, exactly, he managed to spend so much on what appears to be so little), but the revelation also has implications beyond the country’s borders.

headline: Pokémon Go See the World in Its Splendor
abstract: My mantra in the classroom was “Phones away!” But then I downloaded the smartphone counterpart of the game of my youth.
lead_paragraph: IT is strange to live in a place where the skeletons of Alaskan king salmon, loosed from bald eagles’ talons, sometimes plummet to the sidewalk. It is strange to live in a place where brown bears are so populous that hikers tie bells to their dogs and wrists. Where ravens as big as house cats caw and the sun barely sets into the ocean beside a dormant volcano.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Lisson Gallery 504 West 24th Street Chelsea Through Aug. 12

headline: G.M.O. Labeling Bill Gains House Approval
abstract: The bill would require companies to indicate that foods have genetically engineered ingredients, but disagreement remains over how that would be done.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives voted on Thursday to require the labeling of foods that contain genetically engineered ingredients, clearing the bill’s final obstacle before it heads to the White House, where President Obama is expected to sign it into law.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on responses to Dallas Shootings, Paul Ryan and Bernie Sanders
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on responses to Dallas Shootings, Paul Ryan and Bernie Sanders

headline: Athletes Trade Sweats for Suits at the ESPY Awards
abstract: LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Serena Williams took home prizes at the ESPY Awards on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Serena Williams were recognized for their athletic achievements Wednesday night at the ESPY Awards, which drew guests from the worlds of Hollywood, music and more. Here are the red-carpet photos.

headline: Fresno Police Shooting Video Shows Dylan Noble Ignoring Orders to Stop
abstract: Mr. Noble, a 19-year old white man, was shot after a traffic stop in June, and new video shows him advancing, hand behind his back, ignoring orders to stop.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Fresno, Calif., have released video of a fatal police shooting that has spurred protests and calls for a federal investigation. The footage shows Dylan Noble, 19, ignoring commands from two officers to show his hands, get on the ground and stop walking toward them before he was shot.

headline: Road Seems Dark to You? New Tests Blame Your Headlights
abstract: Citing limits to an aging American standard for automobile headlamps, insurers are pushing carmakers to do more to help drivers see in the dark.
lead_paragraph: Jeanne Robillard has headlight envy.

headline: How the Headlights Rated
abstract: Even the best headlights didn’t always get passing grades in the insurance group’s test.
lead_paragraph: Even the best headlights (often available as an option or on a model’s higher trim levels) on 21 small S.U.V.s tested by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety seldom received passing grades. (All vehicles tested were 2016 models, except where noted.)

headline: ‘Macavity’ Reintroduces T.S. Eliot’s Beloved Feline Creation
abstract: Just in time for the return of “Cats” to Broadway, a new picture book series features T.S. Eliot’s many-lived creatures.
lead_paragraph: MACAVITYThe Mystery CatBy T.S. EliotIllustrated by Arthur Robins32 pp. Faber & Faber. Paper, $9.95. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: Snapshots of Race Relations in America Today
abstract: A reader says of Donald Trump, “many will vote for him not in spite of the bigotry but because of it.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 16 Through 24
abstract: Walk among fireflies at the Ansonia Nature & Recreation Center where park rangers are taking hikers along a wooded path for glowworms.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: New Spies Went for a Joyride in Moscow. Russia Isn’t Happy.
abstract: A video of about 50 recent graduates of the Federal Security Service riding in a fleet of luxury S.U.V.s has provoked national contempt, and may get the graduates fired.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Officers and recent graduates of Russia’s top security academy will be reprimanded or fired after a video circulated online showing them joyriding around Moscow in a parade of gleaming black luxury vehicles, the Federal Security Service said on Thursday.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 16 Through July 24
abstract: The comedian Chris Tucker, and the singing groups En Vogue and Boyz II Men will perform at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center this month.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Palmiers du Mal: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on responses to the Dallas shooting, Paul Ryan and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into working and thinking at The New York Times. Today, Andrew Rosenthal, an opinion columnist, responds to recent news: the good, bad and most maddening.

headline: When Is It My Turn to Talk?!
abstract: Also, missing wedding gifts, and what to do about uninvited travel companions.
lead_paragraph: My sister-in-law lives far away. She calls to check in every week or so and runs through a laundry list of topics: her husband, their kids, their dog. She has a million stories. Trouble is, by the time she’s finished, her time is up: “Gotta go!” This leaves no room for me to share my news. So while I know her son’s ACT scores, she wouldn’t be able to tell you the first thing about my family. This has been going on for over a year. Is there a way to point out the imbalance that won’t make me sound needy or her self-absorbed?

headline: Paying Farmers to Go Organic, Even Before the Crops Come In
abstract: Demand for organic crops so outstrips the supply that some food brands are underwriting farmers’ arduous and costly transition to organic production.
lead_paragraph: DENAIR, Calif. — The last time Wendell Naraghi tried to make money from organic nuts, in the 1980s, he failed miserably.

headline: K2 Overdoses Surge in New York: At Least 130 Cases This Week Alone
abstract: The tally for Monday through Wednesday nearly matched the total for all of June, a rise in use of the synthetic drug that is alarming officials.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as the young man crouching on a trash-strewed street in Brooklyn pulled out a crumpled dollar bill from his pocket and emptied its contents of dried leaves into a wrapper, he had company. A half-dozen disheveled men and women walked swiftly to where the young man was rolling a cigarette of a synthetic drug known as K2 to wait for a chance to share.

headline: Devon Halfnight Leflufy: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Boats, Birds and a Billion Oysters at City of Water Day
abstract: This free family festival will include events like sailing, face painting and bird-watching to help residents better understand the waterfront.
lead_paragraph: New York may be the quintessential concrete and steel metropolis, but on Saturday, environmental organizations would like residents to drink in the power and promise of another substance that’s indispensable to its existence: water.

headline: Review: In ‘Phantom Boy,’ an Ailing Hero Takes On a Villain
abstract: This animated film by Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli (“A Cat in Paris”) tells the story of a boy whose illness has given him a gift.
lead_paragraph: The 2010 animated film “A Cat in Paris” was a nifty enough confection to have been nominated for an Academy Award; “Phantom Boy” is the second effort from its directors, Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli, and it’s not nearly as nifty, alas.

headline: Emmy Nominations 2016: Maura Tierney on ‘The Affair’ and Helen’s Swearing
abstract: Ms. Tierney was nominated for best supporting actress in a drama for her role in this Showtime series.
lead_paragraph: Maura Tierney charmingly bumbled her Golden Globes speech in January after winning for best supporting actress as Helen Solloway in Showtime’s “The Affair.” But she started her Emmy journey this morning on a much more composed note.

headline: Review: ‘Lucha Mexico’ Offers a Repetitive Look at Pro Wrestlers
abstract: This documentary, from Alex Hammond and Ian Markiewicz, introduces the stars of “lucha libre,” the Mexican form of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Wrestling may be fake, but “Lucha Mexico” works overtime to portray the men and women who participate in it as heartfelt and lovable. This documentary from Alex Hammond and Ian Markiewicz introduces the stars of “lucha libre,” or freestyle fighting, the Mexican version of professional wrestling.

headline: Ethics Inquiry Finds Kentucky Republican Violated House Rules
abstract: Representative Edward Whitfield gave his wife, a registered lobbyist working for the Humane Society of the United States, access to his House staff.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Edward Whitfield, Republican of Kentucky, has been issued a “public reproval” by the House Ethics Committee for allowing his wife, who served as a registered lobbyist, to meet with his House staff as she worked on behalf of the Humane Society of the United States.

headline: Review: ‘Outlaws and Angels,’ a Cross Between Western and Home-Invasion Horror
abstract: Starring Chad Michael Murray and Clint Eastwood’s daughter Francesca, JT Mollner’s film features outlaws who descend on a seemingly innocent frontier family’s home.
lead_paragraph: When Clint Eastwood’s “Unforgiven” won four Oscars, including best picture, in 1993, it was said that he’d created the ultimate western. A generation later, that doesn’t mean filmmakers have stopped making them. Still, in trying to find new uses for the genre, too many have subverted it. Sadly, Clint’s daughter Francesca Eastwood finds herself in “Outlaws and Angels,” which seems to aspire to horror festivals. (Ms. Eastwood’s mother, Frances Fisher, makes a brief appearance as well.)

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, July 16 Through 24
abstract: “Beauty and the Beast” is being staged on weekends through July 24 at the Woodstock Playhouse. A meet-and-greet with the characters follows each performance.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: New York Officials Were Warned About Lifting Nursing Home’s Deed Limits, Report Says
abstract: A city agency cited communication breakdowns surrounding Rivington House, which was sold to condominium developers.
lead_paragraph: A New York City agency issued a stern report on Thursday that found city officials had been warned that a Manhattan nursing home could end up in the hands of luxury condominium developers if deed restrictions were removed — despite having denied any such prior knowledge.

headline: Review: ‘The Annotated History of the American Muskrat’ Is Worried About America
abstract: This play wants to be many things, most of all a commentary on the American Dream, but it is dreamlike in the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t know that song?” a man asks a colleague in “The Annotated History of the American Muskrat,” one of the more whimsically titled plays of the summer. “It’s an old song. About muskrats. It’s terrible.”

headline: Review: With ‘Stranger Things,’ Netflix Delivers an Eerie Nostalgia Fix
abstract: In this eight-part series, a supernatural mystery set in 1983, a boy disappears near a government lab, and a small Indiana town is upended.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t already had enough 1980s nostalgia — a big if for anyone who watches a lot of television these days — Netflix’s “Stranger Things” is a tasty trip back to that decade and the art of eeriness without excess.

headline: Review: In ‘How He Fell in Love,’ an Extramarital Bond Unfolds
abstract: This Marc Meyers film focuses on how the relationship between a young musician and a middle-age woman affects them and others in their orbit.
lead_paragraph: How do you transition from downward-facing dog into bed with an older woman?

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, July 16 Through July 24
abstract: The dog behaviorist Cesar Millan will train rescue dogs on stage at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center next week.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Watteau’s Peacefully Bittersweet War Scenes
abstract: Watteau paintings in a show at the Frick Collection depict 18th-century French soldiers far from the battle, in scenes at once ordinary and mysterious.
