lead_paragraph: One of the most naturally gifted painters in the history of Western art, Jean-Antoine Watteau (1684-1721) has been beloved for his bucolic, operatic scenes of Rococo frivolity and elegant hedonism known as fêtes galantes. In his masterpiece “Pilgrimage to the Isle Cythera” (1717), aristocratic lovers attended to by fluttering cupids prepare to set off in a golden boat for the fabled island of love, the birthplace of Aphrodite. With his delicate, sensuously flickering touch, lush colors and luminous atmospheres, Watteau anticipated Impressionism, and his dreamlike visions of erotic yearning and melancholic hypersensitivity inspired the 20th-century Surrealists.

headline: Review: At Lincoln Center Festival, Timeless Japanese Noh Dramas
abstract: Plays at the Rose Theater include “Okina,” a prayer for peace and long life, and “Hagoromo,” in which an angel loses her robe.
lead_paragraph: Most art forms evolve and change radically over the years. A French painting created today is unlikely to resemble one created in the 18th century. But the genre of Japanese theater known as Noh has hewed to traditional texts and performance styles for centuries, so that a Noh performance you see today resembles, to a remarkable degree, a performance in the 14th or 15th century. This form, which combines dance, music and drama, is performed primarily by specialists from families who have been steeped in its traditions for generations.

headline: Review: A Search for Meaning in ‘Garnet’s Gold’
abstract: This documentary by Ed Perkins chronicles a search for a stash of gold, but also ends up telling a larger story about one man’s life.
lead_paragraph: The plot is incidental to the poetry in “Garnet’s Gold.” Approaching the story for the traditional trappings — narrative, action, even logic — is to ensure disappointment. But look to it for beauty and lyricism, and you may find a deeper satisfaction.

headline: Parke & Ronen: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: Review: A Sport Comes a Long Way in ‘Free to Run’
abstract: This documentary recounts the extraordinary growth of running, from exclusive clubs to a social revolution on the streets.
lead_paragraph: “Free to Run” is an idiosyncratic account of the rise of long-distance running over the last 50 years, viewing it not so much as sport as a social revolution shaking off the tyranny of running federations that limited participation. Amid glimpses of Jim Fixx, Frank Shorter and Joan Benoit, the director Pierre Morath tells the stories of Fred Lebow and the New York City Marathon; of Steve Prefontaine, the greatest American long-distance runner before his untimely death in 1975; and of Noël Tamini, whose Swiss running journal, Spiridon, urged European runners to hit the road.

headline: Bleak Reality in Nan Goldin’s ‘The Ballad of Sexual Dependency’
abstract: The photographer’s autobiographical slide show at MoMA reflects the devastating effects of a 1980s counterculture.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-three years ago, Nan Goldin began taking the photographs that would make up the first iterations of her astounding, autobiographical slide show, “The Ballad of Sexual Dependency.” Named after a song from “The Threepenny Opera,” it eventually came to consist of more than 700 images of friends, lovers and herself disporting themselves with shameless abandon in the bohemian squalor of the Lower East Side. Set to a rousing, eclectic selection of music including opera, pop, rock and blues, and projected for about 45 minutes, it was in its time an emotionally wrenching revelation, and it was almost immediately recognized as a defining achievement of art in the 1980s.

headline: From Japan, a ‘Chicago’ You Probably Haven’t Seen
abstract: The Takarazuka Revue, a 102-year-old theater company, is bringing its take on this Broadway musical to the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — On any given night outside a theater in central Tokyo, hundreds of women can be found waiting in neat phalanxes, dressed in matching T-shirts or sporting identical colored handkerchiefs — the uniform of what may be the most rabidly loyal fans in Japanese entertainment.

headline: Review: A Powerful Opera of Eastern and Western Allure
abstract: The arts of eras and cultures that do not usually merge are brought together in the Chinese-inspired opera “Paradise Interrupted.”
lead_paragraph: The engrossing chamber opera “Paradise Interrupted” could easily have ended up a clichéd, cross-cultural mess. Opera has long been an art form that draws together music, poetry, theater, dance and other genres. But few works mingle different elements so ambitiously as “Paradise Interrupted,” first performed at the Spoleto Festival USA last year. This production, at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, was one of two works that opened the Lincoln Center Festival on Wednesday.

headline: Why Can’t You Take Canned Soup to the Republican Convention?
abstract: A number of items are banned from the downtown Cleveland area next week, raising civil-rights concerns.
lead_paragraph: Grappling hooks, lasers, drones and axes are just some of the items banned from the official convention “event zone” in Cleveland next week. Also prohibited are more mundane objects like canned goods, coolers, glass bottles and tennis balls.

headline: Philip May, a Financier Who May Find It Harder to Be Low Key
abstract: The spouse of Britain’s new first gentleman is likely to face a brighter spotlight and harsher scrutiny for his ties to the world of finance.
lead_paragraph: When Theresa May pulled up at 10 Downing Street as Britain’s new prime minister, her husband, Philip, got out of the car and waited for her to emerge. He trailed slightly as the pair walked toward cameras. Then he quietly stood far to the side as she gave her speech.

headline: Theater Listings for July 15-21
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: ‘Divine Pleasures’ Celebrates the Colors of Desire in Indian Paintings
abstract: This show features nearly 100 Hindu watercolor and ink works made in northern regions from the 16th to 19th centuries.
lead_paragraph: It is the colors that awe most in Hindu painting of the 16th to 19th centuries: the saturated reds, the lambent golds, or the milky blues of Krishna’s skin and the sky at twilight. They are as vivid as ever in “Divine Pleasures,” a handsome and uncommon show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which features nearly 100 watercolor and ink paintings from northern India. Illustrations of the Ramayana and other holy texts, portraits of rajahs with horses and elephants, and love scenes both spiritual and erotic plot the development of Indian aristocratic taste over three tumultuous centuries. But the color gleams throughout, alive with otherworldly devotion.

headline: Homespun Hippie or Backwoods Gucci? ‘Captain Fantastic’ Melds the Two
abstract: The film offers a mash-up of ’70s castoffs and rustic staples with a giddy twist.
lead_paragraph: If Ken Kesey and Alessandro Michele of Gucci had a passel of kids, their offspring might look something like the high-spirited ménage of “Captain Fantastic,” about a family living off the grid in the densely wooded Pacific Northwest.

headline: Scores Die in Nice, France, as Truck Plows Into Bastille Day Crowd
abstract: Graphic images showed the vehicle tearing through the crowd. The driver was shot to death by the police, and France’s president called the assault “a monstrosity.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Bastille Day fireworks celebration was shattered by death and mayhem Thursday night in the southern French city of Nice when a large truck barreled for more than a mile through an enormous crowd of spectators, crushing and maiming dozens in what France’s president called a terrorist assault. It came eight months after the Paris attacks that traumatized the nation and all of Europe.

headline: Winona Ryder, an Emblem of ’90s Cool, Grows Up
abstract: The actress, who is in the new Netflix series “Stranger Things,” has taken her time returning to the spotlight after her youthful stardom and public fall.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In an early episode of the new Netflix supernatural drama “Stranger Things,” a single mother played by Winona Ryder sits in a cubby hole communicating with her youngest son through a tangled ball of blinking Christmas lights. He has vanished under mysterious circumstances. To better understand how to sell such a strange, emotional moment, Ms. Ryder looked no further than her own mother, Cynthia Palmer.

headline: A Brontë Exhibition, Complete With a ‘Jane Eyre’ Manuscript
abstract: To celebrate that author’s 200th birthday, the Morgan Library & Museum will host “Charlotte Brontë: An Independent Will,” opening on Sept. 9.
lead_paragraph: In Charlotte Brontë’s “Jane Eyre,” Jane tells Mr. Rochester, “I am no bird; and no net ensnares me: I am a free human being with an independent will; which I now exert to leave you.”

headline: A Brooklyn Cemetery Is a Resting Place Rich in History
abstract: Graveyards like Evergreens, in Bushwick, have been organizing their archives and databases to educate visitors and mine historical information.
lead_paragraph: At the bustling offices of Evergreens Cemetery in Bushwick, Brooklyn, staff members often pore over hefty reference books with frayed spines and tattered pages. These handwritten burial records, dating to 1849, when the still-active graveyard was founded, hold the answers to unsolved mysteries and various queries, including research requests from genealogists, biographers, historians and descendants of the more than half-million buried there.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, Boris Johnson: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

abstract: Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult star as workers in a dystopian commune who break the rules by experiencing feelings for each other.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Stewart, the movies’ sullen “it girl” of the moment, and Nicholas Hoult play futuristic lovers in “Equals,” a dystopian sci-fi snooze that suffers from imagination deficit disorder.

headline: New York City Pension Fund to Divest Itself of Gun Retailer Stock
abstract: The fund is selling shares in Dick’s Sporting Goods, Cabela’s, and Big 5 Sporting Goods, worth $10.5 million as of mid-June.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s employee pension fund will sell all its holdings of three American retailers because they sell guns, and will continue to press ahead in its efforts to get Walmart and a division of the supermarket chain Kroger to remove guns from their store shelves.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on Voters’ Opinions Heading Into the Conventions
abstract: On the eve of their party conventions, Democrats and Republicans are grudgingly rallying around their nominees while expressing broad misgivings about the candidates, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of their party conventions, Democrats and Republicans are grudgingly rallying around their nominees while expressing broad misgivings about the candidates, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted July 8-12 with 1,600 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,358 said they were registered to vote.

abstract: Revelers had gathered in the southern city of Nice for Bastille Day celebrations when a truck drove through the crowd.

headline: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
abstract: This week, survivors and supporters retraced a route through the mountains to the site where ethnic Serbs carried out the slaughter of more than 8,000 Muslim men and boys.
lead_paragraph: This week, survivors and supporters retraced a route through the mountains to the site where ethnic Serbs carried out the slaughter of more than 8,000 Muslim men and boys.

headline: 6,000 Headstones After ’95 Srebrenica Massacre, and Counting
abstract: Since Carlotta Gall last reported from Srebrenica in 2000, some of the 8,372 victims of a mass killing have been buried there, with more remains discovered each year.
lead_paragraph: SREBRENICA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Over three days this week, survivors and thousands of supporters retraced a familiar route through the mountains to the site at Srebrenica where 21 years ago ethnic Serb forces carried out Europe’s worst mass killing since World War II.

abstract: Rival Republican factions fought behind closed doors over changes to the party’s nominating process that threatened to disrupt the convention next week.

lead_paragraph: A truck plowed into a crowd in the southern French city of Nice during Bastille Day celebrations.

headline: Republicans Brace for a Clash of Visions Over Party’s Future
abstract: If Donald J. Trump wins the White House, he would have the opportunity to lead a Republican Party with a fundamentally different character.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have begun gathering for their convention even as they are gripped by an identity crisis.

headline: Jazz Listings for July 15-21
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Family of Robert Durst’s First Wife Asks Court to Declare Her Dead
abstract: Kathleen Durst’s relatives contend that Mr. Durst killed her in 1982, when she vanished. Her disappearance was the subject of the HBO documentary “The Jinx.”
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Durst’s storybook marriage to a wealthy real estate heir had descended into violence and recrimination by 1982, when she suddenly vanished on a rainy winter night from the couple’s stone cottage on Lake Truesdale, about 50 miles northeast of Manhattan.

headline: Ernie Els Puts Protocol Aside to Give Phil Mickelson a Chance for History
abstract: Els decided to putt out of order on the 18th hole at the British Open so Mickelson could focus before trying to record the lowest round in a major.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — Walking down the 18th fairway in the first round of the 145th British Open on Thursday, Ernie Els knew at once what he had to do and how important it was, transcending competition. Phil Mickelson, whom he was grouped with, had a golf ball just off the fairway and a shot at golf immortality.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

abstract: A witness said the truck “crushed everyone in its path.”
lead_paragraph: A witness said the truck “crushed everyone in its path.”

headline: Minnesota Police Officer’s ‘Bulletproof Warrior’ Training Is Questioned
abstract: Critics say its teachings run counter to the reforms that police departments should adopt if they are to win back community trust, especially among black residents.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The Minnesota police officer who fatally shot an African-American man during a traffic stop last week had recently undergone specialized training that critics say can lead officers to believe they are under constant threat of being harmed and can intensify encounters with civilians.

lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Silicon Valley Writes a Protest Letter Against Trump
abstract: Calling American innovation “the envy of the world,” more than 140 tech leaders let out a collective howl at what a Trump presidency might do to tech.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley techies have made little secret of their dislike for Donald J. Trump. On Thursday, they took their antipathy to the next level.

headline: Film Crew vs. Street Repair Crew
abstract: It was odd to see pipeline repair workers and a film’s camera and microphone operators standing silently on the street while the shooting progressed.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for July 15-21
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Salvadoran Court Overturns Wartime Amnesty, Paving Way for Prosecutions
abstract: The Supreme Court struck down a law that had protected members of the military, rebel groups and death squads for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a ruling that clears the way for El Salvador to prosecute the perpetrators of war crimes committed during its brutal civil war, the country’s highest court has struck down an amnesty law that has protected soldiers, rebel fighters and death squads for more than two decades.

headline: In Audition With Hillary Clinton, Tim Kaine Nails Most of His Lines
abstract: Mr. Kaine, a contender to be Mrs. Clinton’s running mate, gave an enthusiastic introduction at her rally in Virginia, although some of his lines seemed to work better than others.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE, Va. — Senator Tim Kaine had already mastered the requisite body language of a vice-presidential hopeful.

headline: Justin Dunn, Mets Pitching Prospect, Grows Up and Moves Closer to Home
abstract: A 5-foot-5 high school freshman who sprouted into a 6-foot-2 first-round pick grew up less than 30 miles from the mound in Brooklyn where he made his home debut on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Justin Dunn used to sleep with his glove. And he had known from age 7 that he wanted to get to where he was now, on the mound, pitching in a professional baseball game.

headline: Congress Recesses, Leaving More Stalemates Than Accomplishments
abstract: A failed bill to help fight the Zika virus was among the high-profile casualties as partisan fights continued Thursday even as legislators were leaving town.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress limped out of town Thursday for a seven-week recess, leaving behind a trail of partisan fights, a failed bill to help fight the Zika virus, a stalemate on gun safety and a few mundane accomplishments that members hoped to sell as awesome to voters in an unsparing mood.

headline: Tour de France Crash Is the Latest Caused by Fans or Vehicles
abstract: There is a long line of disruptions at professional cycling races.
lead_paragraph: VAISON-LA-ROMAINE, France — The crash provoked by spectators who blocked a television motorcycle at the Tour de France on Thursday is the latest in a long line of disruptions caused by fans or vehicles at professional cycling races, including a previous incident at this year’s Tour and episodes in earlier editions.

headline: Clevelanders Open Homes and Churches to Convention Demonstrators
abstract: The city’s hotels have been booked for months and renting an apartment downtown can cost more than $2,500 a day.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Rosemary Palmer has spent the last three weeks stocking up on toilet paper, buying large boxes of cereal, and figuring how to fit as many people as possible into her three-bedroom Cleveland home, which in just a few days will be filled with activists from around the country in town for the Republican National Convention.

headline: As Rory McIlroy Takes Flak for Olympics Comment, He Affirms His Stance
abstract: After he finished his first round at the British Open on Thursday, the superstar stood by his claim that he will not watch Olympic golf.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — Fans in the grandstand stood to applaud Rory McIlroy as he approached the 18th green at Royal Troon on Thursday afternoon. When his par putt completed a round of 69, which kept him near the first-round leaders, a woman’s voice, enriched by a Scottish accent, called out: “Just lovely, Rory.”

headline: Closing Arguments Sound Familiar at 4th Trial in Freddie Gray Case
abstract: Prosecutors used the same narrative that failed to convict in three previous cases in arguing that Lt. Brian Rice had committed a crime during Mr. Gray’s arrest.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The arguments were familiar, but the stakes for prosecutors perhaps as high as ever.

headline: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, the ‘Mendel of Cancer Genetics,’ Dies at 93
abstract: A 1971 theory on the inheritable nature of retinoblastoma in children, proved in 1986, is credited with helping advance the framework of how cancers are studied.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, who deduced how certain cancers strike a family generation after generation, died on Sunday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93.

headline: Mets’ On-Field Success and Yankees’ Off-Field Squabble Propel a Switch in Viewership
abstract: The Mets are vying for a playoff spot after a World Series appearance while a dispute with Comcast is keeping the Yankees off nearly a million television screens.
lead_paragraph: The SNY network is benefiting greatly from the Mets’ surprising run to the World Series last year and the anticipation that they will reach the postseason again — even if their 47-41 record is a bit of a disappointment.

headline: Obama Warns of Growing Mistrust Between Minorities and Police
abstract: At a town hall event Thursday, President Obama spoke of finding solutions to promoting a dialogue on race and reconciliation to bridge a growing divide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday defended the Black Lives Matter movement and said the legacy of racial conflict in the United States had driven dangerous mistrust between the police and minority communities.

headline: Truck Attack in Nice, France: What We Know, and What We Don’t
abstract: President François Hollande said it was a terrorist attack, but authorities didn’t know who was responsible, or why.
lead_paragraph: A large truck plowed into a crowd gathered to watch Bastille Day fireworks in Nice, France, on Thursday, killing scores of people in what the French president called a terrorist attack.

headline: Tim Scott, Black Republican Senator, Recounts Run-Ins With Police
abstract: The South Carolina lawmaker has had positive experiences but also disturbing encounters with police officers in the course of his life.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was not one particular shooting that moved Senator Tim Scott to come to the Senate floor, speaking in strikingly personal terms about being a black man in America. Rather, it was the fact that they just kept coming: the police shooting in Baton Rouge, La.; another in Falcon Heights, Minn.; and then the shooting in Dallas that left five police officers dead.

headline: At a Refuge for New York City’s Hungry, Summer Brings Scarcity
abstract: Hour Children Food Pantry in Queens, which served 24,000 families last year, has to beg or borrow to overcome a lag in available funds during the season.
lead_paragraph: In need of space for a food pantry in Long Island City, Queens, a few years ago, Sister Tesa Fitzgerald finagled control of an old storeroom on the grounds of St. Rita’s Roman Catholic Church. It had once been the domain of two workers who were almost never available for chores. They were no longer around. Sister Tesa discovered why it had been hard to get their attention. On a loft in the storeroom were tables and a dozen or so telephones, chalkboards and charts. Someone had been running a wire room for an illegal gambling racket.

headline: U.S. Privacy and Civil Liberty Watchdog Faces Limits in Congress
abstract: Some in Congress want to restrain the work of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, which guards against government intrusion into Americans’ lives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A leading Democrat in Congress is pushing back against an effort to impose new constraints on a civil liberties watchdog agency that investigates the nation’s security programs.

headline: Michael Crawford, Wiseacre With a Pen, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Crawford was a student of habits, trends and human interaction, most of which he exploited for gentle ridicule or defiant amusement.
lead_paragraph: Michael Crawford, whose cartoons salted the pages of The New Yorker with mischievous observations of ballplayers, lovers, the art world and the city life of people who probably read The New Yorker, died on Tuesday at home in Kingston, N.Y. He was 70.

headline: Hector Babenco, Director of ‘Kiss of the Spider Woman,’ Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Babenco, one of Latin America’s most visible directors, established himself as a filmmaker unafraid to push boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Hector Babenco, the Argentine-born Brazilian director whose low-budget 1985 film, “Kiss of the Spider Woman,” became an unlikely hit that challenged conventions of masculinity and stunned the Hollywood establishment, died on Wednesday in São Paulo. He was 70.

headline: Rising Generation
abstract: Matt Ginsberg returns with a Friday puzzle that delivers bonus content.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — “Never overthink things,” that’s my new motto. When I sat down to solve Matt “I Invented Dr.Fill” Ginsberg’s Friday crossword, I saw that there were some cross-referenced clues hinting at a mini-theme and that got my attention because, how often do we see that on a Friday?

headline: Edmond L. Browning, an Episcopal Church Presiding Bishop, Dies at 87
abstract: A leader who declared the church “open to all,” emphasizing women’s ordination, gay and lesbian congregants and civil rights.
lead_paragraph: Edmond L. Browning, who as the presiding bishop in the United States welcomed women into the hierarchy of the Episcopal Church, supported a role for gay and lesbian congregants, and lobbied aggressively for civil rights and against the nuclear arms race, died on Monday at his home in Dee, Ore. He was 87.

headline: In Nice, a Vibrant Celebration Gives Way to a Trail of Death
abstract: A speeding truck that barreled into a crowd on Bastille Day left a trail of bodies, shock and despair.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — A red ambulance, its lights flashing, sped down the road and jerked to a stop. The driver jumped out, asking, “Where are the wounded?”

headline: Letter Sent to City College Officials
abstract: A lawyer for the 21st Century Foundation sent a letter to City College officials saying that in light of a federal subpoena the foundation had received.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for the 21st Century Foundation sent a letter to City College officials saying that in light of a federal subpoena the foundation had received.

headline: Finances of City College’s President Are Under Federal Investigation
abstract: After a report that one of the college’s foundations had paid for some personal expenses for President Lisa S. Coico, a United States attorney is taking a closer look.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are investigating the finances of the president of the City College of New York and her family, as well as those of a nonprofit foundation affiliated with the institution, according to the college and a lawyer’s letter obtained by The New York Times on Thursday.

headline: John Varvatos: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 men’s collection.

headline: What China’s Economic Growth Figures Mean
abstract: China on Friday reported its second-quarter economic growth figures. The numbers are among the world’s most closely watched, but data from the country are notoriously questionable.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China on Friday reported its second-quarter economic growth figures. The numbers are among the world’s most closely watched because the country has been a major driver of global economic growth. But data from China are notoriously questionable. This is what you should take away from Friday’s results.

headline: Tim Tebow Says He Won’t Speak at the Republican Convention
abstract: The former N.F.L. player was supposed to be one of the biggest names to appear at the convention, but he dismissed reports that he would speak as a “rumor.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Tim Tebow, the Heisman Trophy winner, reality television star and former N.F.L. player who was supposed to be one of the biggest names to appear at the Republican National Convention, said Thursday that he would not speak after all.

headline: Firms Offer Cash to Help New Lawyers Pay Student Debt
abstract: They join a wave of other workplaces that are providing student loan repayment programs to attract and retain millennial employees.
lead_paragraph: Young lawyers, struggling with tens of thousands of dollars in student debt, are finding relief from a new source: their employers.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: “Stranger Things,” starring Winona Ryder, is nostalgic for 1980s films. And Robert F. Kennedy Jr. talks about the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley.
lead_paragraph: “Stranger Things,” starring Winona Ryder, is nostalgic for 1980s films like “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial” and “Poltergeist.” “East Los High” begins a new season by exploring some pressing issues for Latino millennials. And Robert F. Kennedy Jr. talks about the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley.

headline: Corrections: July 15, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, July 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, July 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If we don’t come together, we cannot survive.”

headline: Republican Convention Panel All but Ends Anti-Trump Rebellion
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s opponents had hoped to force a vote that would have put the question of whether delegates are free to vote their consciences to the entire convention next week.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump staved off a potentially embarrassing effort to throw the Republican National Convention into disarray, with delegates voting late on Thursday to squash what remained of a fading rebellion.

headline: The Week in Pictures: July 15, 2016
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: As China’s Economy Slows, Beijing’s Growth Push Loses Punch
abstract: High debt and a glut of unneeded factories are hindering the government’s usual method of using spending and lending to create more activity.
lead_paragraph: LEIZHOU, China — Mo Ping for years made his living by tending the mango and jujube trees that he grew on less than an acre on this tip of land in the far south of China.

headline: The Week in Pictures: July 15, 2016
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: We Take Care of Our Own
abstract: The phrase has two meanings, and that difference is at the center of election 2016.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Bruce Springsteen came out with a song called “We Take Care of Our Own.” The chorus’s theme seemed upbeat and proud: We take care of the people closest to us. But like in a lot of Springsteen songs (including “Born in the U.S.A.”), the lyrics in the verses sit in tension with the lyrics in the chorus.

headline: A Step Forward for Fair Pay at McDonald’s
abstract: The granting of class-action status for a lawsuit is another step toward establishing fair pay practices for employees of the fast-food giant.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, one of several lawsuits filed in recent years accusing McDonald’s of unfair pay practices has been granted federal class-action status, which is often the only practical and affordable way to sue when many people are affected.

headline: How to Prevent Violence in Cleveland
abstract: The potential for clashes at the Republican convention is high. The Cleveland police can avoid them by working with protest leaders.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — THE police killings of Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, and the sniper killings of Dallas police officers are terrible reminders that the disconnect between American citizens and the police officers hired to protect and serve them is greater and increasingly deadly. That is why, as the Cleveland Police Department prepares for next week’s Republican National Convention, it must take special precautions to avoid clashes inside and outside the convention hall.

headline: With Obama, the Personal Is Presidential
abstract: No matter what you think of his time in office, it’s hard to argue that the human being has been anything less than a model of class and dignity.
lead_paragraph: We always knew he could keep his head when others were losing theirs and blaming him, knew it from the 2008 financial crisis and on to the hard, lasting words he spoke at Tuesday’s memorial for the slain police officers in Dallas.

headline: Where Are the Hurricanes?
abstract: Despite a recent lull in powerful storms, climate change will strengthen tropical cyclones.
lead_paragraph: THE United States coastline has been calm so far this hurricane season, just as it has been over the last decade. Since 2005, the year of Hurricanes Katrina, Rita and Wilma, the country has been in a hurricane “drought,” with no major hurricane (Category 3 or above, meaning winds above 110 miles per hour) making landfall. The nation’s most hurricane-prone regions, the Southeast and Gulf Coasts, have been eerily quiet.

headline: Bull Market Blues
abstract: In some ways, the stock market’s gains reflect economic weaknesses, not strengths.
lead_paragraph: Like most economists, I don’t usually have much to say about stocks. Stocks are even more susceptible than other markets to popular delusions and the madness of crowds, and stock prices generally have a lot less to do with the state of the economy or its future prospects than many people believe. As the economist Paul Samuelson put it, “Wall Street indexes predicted nine out of the last five recessions.”

headline: Keeping NATO Relevant and United
abstract: Amid Russia’s aggressive tactics and Britain’s Brexit vote, the alliance serves as a regional anchor and a reassurance to Eastern European nations.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the unsettling news coming out of Europe, not least Britain’s divorce from the common market, one traditional trans-Atlantic alliance remains essentially intact: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization. At its latest summit meeting in Warsaw, NATO did what it had to do to stay relevant and reasonably united. “We’re moving forward with the most significant reinforcement of collective defense any time since the Cold War,” was the way President Obama summed things up.

headline: Hong Kong Says Legislative Candidates Must Endorse Chinese Rule
abstract: As calls for autonomy grow, Hong Kong’s government wants legislative candidates to pledge that the city remains an “inalienable part” of China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong government said on Thursday that candidates for the legislature must acknowledge the semiautonomous city as an “inalienable part” of China and faced possible criminal penalties if they did not uphold the pledge.

headline: A Trail of Terror in Nice, Block by Block
abstract: Documenting devastation along a one-mile stretch of waterfront.
lead_paragraph: Documenting devastation along a one-mile stretch of waterfront.

headline: South Korean Villagers Pelt Premier With Eggs Over Missile Site
abstract: The prime minister, Hwang Kyo-ahn, told rural residents that South Korea needed the Thaad system to defend against North Korean missiles.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s prime minister was pelted with eggs and water bottles by angry villagers on Friday as he paid a visit to the rural county chosen as the site of a planned United States missile defense system.

headline: Never Mind Grass-Fed, How About Elixir-Fed Meats?
abstract: In China, meat from livestock fed on traditional herbal remedies fetches a premium price from health-conscious shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Forget grass-fed beef and free-range poultry. China’s farmers say they have found the next big health-food craze: cows, pigs and ducks raised on a steady diet of ancient Chinese medicine.

headline: At Sea, and Seeking a Safe Harbor
abstract: A woman who escaped the Cambodian genocide as a child hopes her mother can accept her for who she is now.
lead_paragraph: This past December, after not talking to me for several months, my mother called from her rural Oregon home. I listened from Seattle as she offered updates on cousins in Cambodia, inventoried her latest aches and pains, and noted my father’s failing memory.

headline: After 1963, a Silence Fell Upon Dallas. Not This Year.
abstract: For years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, Dallas was labeled the “city of hate.” Decades later, it is responding to new horror very differently.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Two months after this city’s darkest day in November 1963, when President John F. Kennedy was killed by a sniper in Dealey Plaza, James F. Chambers, publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, was ordered out of a cab in the Detroit snow. He had made the mistake of telling the driver he was from Dallas.

headline: Wanted: 2BR, Near Bars and Restaurants
abstract: Cafes, restaurants and bars play a major role in the often arduous and angst-ridden drama of home hunting.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, Susana Vivares, a financial services executive who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, has found herself increasingly disenchanted with her environs. She feels that ravenous development, both retail and residential, has eroded the neighborhood’s architectural and communal vitality.

headline: Ping-Pong? Child’s Game. Table Tennis? That’s a 16-Year-Old’s Ticket to Rio.
abstract: Kanak Jha, the first American born in the 2000s to qualify for an Olympics, hopes to increase the profile of a sport better known in the United States as a basement game.
lead_paragraph: HALMSTAD, Sweden — Kanak Jha is not sure when he made the change. He thinks it was maybe when he was 9 or 10. He does not remember the precise moment, but he knows it was significant all the same.

headline: You Mean It’s Next Week? Why Some G.O.P. Senators Will Skip the Convention
abstract: As the nomination of Donald J. Trump approaches, more than a dozen have cited conflicts as varied as lawn mowing, fly fishing, volunteer work and campaigning for themselves.
lead_paragraph: In a normal convention season, most politicians are working every lever to try to get a prime speaking slot and bathe themselves in the glow of the party’s nominee.

headline: Ask Well: Can You Eat Foods Past the ‘Sell By’ Date?
abstract: As a general rule, most foods can be consumed days, weeks or even months past the dates printed on packaging — unless they’re moldy.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Review: ‘Faith Healer,’ ‘Unreachable’ and ‘The Spoils’
abstract: Three London openings put the creative process and creators center-stage
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been a longstanding given that writers should write what they know, so is it any surprise that three plays running concurrently in London all deal with the creative process, though in differing ways? Each inhabits its own distinct world, while sharing an interest in the often maddening process that leads — or maybe not — to art.

headline: Nice, Donald Trump, ‘Ghostbusters’: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Fecal Transplants Can Be Life-Saving, but How?
abstract: Fecal transplants have proved effective against a bacterial infection. But scientists still have a lot to learn.
lead_paragraph: A fecal transplant is exactly what it sounds like: To treat certain gut disorders, doctors transfer stool from a healthy donor to a sick patient.

headline: No Hearing Aid? Some Gizmos Offer Alternative to ‘Speak Up!’
abstract: Some personal sound amplification products work as well as traditional hearing aids, researchers find — and cost far less.
lead_paragraph: An estimated one zillion older people have a problem like mine.

headline: My Autistic Son’s Lesson: No One Is Broken
abstract: Instead of telling our son to stop running and humming, we thumped and flapped along with him.
lead_paragraph: My youngest son, Sawyer, used to spend far more time relating to his imagination than he did to the world around him. He would run back and forth humming, flapping his hands and thumping on his chest. By the time he was in first grade, attempts to draw him out of his pretend world to join his classmates or do some class work led to explosions and timeouts. At 7 he was given a diagnosis of being on the autism spectrum.

headline: Mixing Love and Work, Eventually
abstract: Two White House staff members, Kristen Bartoloni and Cody Keenan, married on July 3 in Washington. She had rejected his first three attempts to get a date.
lead_paragraph: Two White House staff members, Kristen Bartoloni and Cody Keenan, married on July 3 in Washington. She had rejected his first three attempts to get a date.

headline: For Obama’s Speechwriting Team, the Message Finally Got Through
abstract: A White House wordsmith was instantly smitten with a new arrival, but the word he kept hearing was “no.”
lead_paragraph: When Kristen Bartoloni came on board as a researcher on the White House communications team in 2011, there was one rule she was intent on following: Don’t mix dating and work.

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo Is Said to Collect Final Bids
abstract: Firms Offer to Help New Lawyers Pay Student Debt | Bayer Raises Bid for Monsanto
lead_paragraph: YAHOO IS SAID TO COLLECT FINAL BIDS Final bids for Yahoo’s core internet business are due Monday, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The board is set to make a decision soon afterward, according to people briefed on the process.

headline: New York Today: Outdoor Gaming
abstract: Friday: Alternatives to Pokémon Go, the Lowline to the Highline, and National Ice Cream Day.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:04 a.m.

headline: Brooklyn Fencer Seeks Olympic Gold
abstract: Nzingha Prescod, 23, says she is excited by “the idea of little black girls turning on the TV to see someone like them fencing.”
lead_paragraph: Last month, practice was winding down at the Fencers Club in Manhattan when a group of young students paused to watch a Brooklyn-born Olympian relentlessly attack a padded wall. The athlete, Nzingha Prescod, carried on unfazed, her feet shuffling like a tap dancer’s, her eyes darting behind the mesh of her mask. Ms. Prescod is getting used to the increased scrutiny. This summer, she hopes to become the first African-American fencer to win Olympic gold.

headline: 36 Hours in Seoul
abstract: Thanks to the Korean pop culture wave, the once underrated South Korean capital, with its new museums, plazas and restaurants, is reveling in a tourism boom.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the Korean pop culture wave, the once underrated South Korean capital, with its new museums, plazas and restaurants, is reveling in a tourism boom.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Backing Clinton to Run Major Ad Campaign Against Trump
abstract: The digital spots will run in nine swing states, and they will focus on millennial women, seeking to use Donald J. Trump’s previous statements against him.
lead_paragraph: A group of “super PACs” backing Hillary Clinton’s campaign is opening a major digital advertising campaign targeting a specific subset of voters: millennial women.

headline: Doctors Should Listen to Patient Instincts
abstract: How patients say they feel may be a good indicator of their general health.
lead_paragraph: When a patient complains that he or she doesn’t feel well, doctors should pay attention.

headline: The 7.3.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: GENDER GAMES

headline: How to Ask Family Members to Donate Sperm or Eggs
abstract: Tell them you prefer a relative to an anonymous donor. Go to counseling together.
lead_paragraph: “Ask in a way that is more statement than direct question,” says Andrea M. Braverman, a psychologist specializing in third-party reproductive relationships and an author of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine’s guidelines for using family members as donors or surrogates. So as not to burden your relative with undue pressure, state that you are seeking a donor and that you’d prefer that person be a family member. Give reassurance that you have the option of using an unknown donor if his or her participation does not feel like the right choice. Allow time to think it over. “This needs to be a decision that lasts a lifetime,” Braverman says.

headline: Intolerance and Love in Jamaica
abstract: For a young gay man, a family visit brings revelation.
lead_paragraph: I went to the island for a family reunion. And while I’d already hit high school, I’d never seen Jamaica, so I flinched at the shouts once the airport came into view, and then again at all the clapping once we finally hit the tarmac, and I thought, So the hell what. We’ve landed. Big deal. But the lady sitting beside me squeezed my arm, as if to say, Isn’t this marvelous. She told me she was home. She told me I was home.

headline: [untitled]
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Daniel S. Glaser: The Challenge of Keeping It Simple
abstract: Mr. Glaser, the chief of Marsh & McLennan, says the world is full of smart people who love complicating things, so it’s important to simplify.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Daniel S. Glaser, C.E.O. of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Flight of the Conchords: Aimless, and That’s O.K.
abstract: “The audience thinks everything is a bit,” said Bret McKenzie, one member of the comedy group. “But often it’s not a bit — it’s just us figuring something out.”
lead_paragraph: MORRISON, Colo. — Surrounded by the awe-inspiring geological formations that cradle Red Rocks Amphitheater here, Jemaine Clement and Bret McKenzie could not help but contemplate the passage of time.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 5 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: Whether you were interested in politics or Pokémon, to participate this week, just post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 22.
lead_paragraph: Update | Winners for this week have been announced.

headline: 36 Hours in Charleston, S.C.
abstract: The city is in the midst of a restaurant boom, and King Street has become the embodiment of a new, saccharine-free Southern charm.
lead_paragraph: The city is in the midst of a restaurant boom, and King Street has become the embodiment of a new, saccharine-free Southern charm.

headline: Chappatte on the Bastille Day Attack in Nice, France
abstract: Scores were killed by a large truck, which tore through a crowd celebrating the annual holiday.
lead_paragraph: Scores were killed by a large truck, which tore through a crowd celebrating the annual holiday.

headline: 36 Hours on the Left Bank, Paris
abstract: The Right Bank may be more international and trendy, but sometimes you want to pretend you’re inside a black-and-white Robert Doisneau photo.
lead_paragraph: The Right Bank may be more international and trendy, but sometimes you want to pretend you’re inside a black-and-white Robert Doisneau photo.

headline: France Says Truck Attacker Was Tunisia Native With Record of Petty Crime
abstract: The man, 31, had no known links to the militant extremists who have targeted and traumatized France.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — French officials on Friday identified the man who used a 19-ton truck to massacre dozens of people on the French Riviera as a 31-year-old native of Tunisia with a history of petty crime and marriage problems — but no links with the militant extremists who have targeted and traumatized France.

headline: North Korean Defector Surfaces in Pyongyang, Saying He Tried to Abduct Orphans
abstract: The man, Ko Hyon-chol, said he had tried to smuggle two North Korean girls to the South at the behest of intelligence officers there.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A man who had defected to South Korea from the North turned up in a government-arranged news conference in the North’s capital on Friday, saying that he was arrested there this year while trying to smuggle orphans out of the impoverished country.

headline: A Cure for Trumpism
abstract: The case for a conservative politics that stresses the national interest abroad and national solidarity at home.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Donald Trump accepts the Republican nomination on Thursday in Cleveland, it will represent a stunning moment in American politics — the triumph of a raw populism, embodied by a shameless demagogue, over both the official establishment and the official ideology of a major political party.

headline: How to Spend That Three-Day Summer Weekend
abstract: Travel companies are hoping that targeted deals will encourage a mini-vacation mind-set for stressed-out Americans.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to wait until Saturday to start your weekend; the fun can begin on Friday afternoons. That’s the message hotels around the United States and throughout the Caribbean and Europe are trying to get across to an overworked, stressed-out American crowd by creating attractive packages valid for weekends in July and August.

headline: How to Pack a Carry-On Bag to Avoid Checking a Bag
abstract: Why bother with the hassle of checked luggage when it’s possible to travel to any destination with only a carry-on?
lead_paragraph: Why bother with the hassle of checked luggage when it’s possible to travel to any destination with only a carry-on? At least that’s what Anne McAlpin, a packing expert and the author of the book “Pack It Up: Travel Smart, Pack Light,” thinks.

headline: Bargains at the Beach
abstract: Resorts are offering off-season discounts in the Caribbean, Mexico and Florida.
lead_paragraph: You may have to contend with high heat or the increased risk of hurricanes, but for value-driven beach vacations, it’s hard to beat off-season deals.

headline: In San Francisco, the Classy Renewal of a Gilded Age Hotel
abstract: The refurbished Palace Hotel has gone through several iterations since it first opened in 1875 as the largest hotel in the world.
lead_paragraph: From $225.

headline: Nintendo to Re-Release NES Games, No Blowing Necessary
abstract: A mini-replica of the original NES console will be available in November, preloaded with 30 games, the company announced.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgic gaming fans can stop digging through their attics. Nintendo surprised traditionalists on Thursday with a new way to defeat Dr. Wily, Mother Brain and Bowser.

headline: Hillary Clinton Retains Edge in 4 Crucial States, New Polls Show
abstract: In new NBC/Wall Street Journal/Marist surveys, Mrs. Clinton leads Donald J. Trump in Colorado, Virginia, North Carolina and Florida, four swing states.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is leading Donald J. Trump in Colorado, Virginia, North Carolina and Florida, according to a new set of polls that show the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee with solid advantages in four crucial swing states.

headline: A London Outpost of a Paris Trendsetter
abstract: Despite its name, Frenchie’s accent is as British as it is French.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of expat restaurants in the busy Covent Garden area of London; the original outlets of most, like Orso and Balthazar, call New York home. A newer import from France is a branch of Frenchie, one of the trendsetters of Parisian bistronomy. But despite its name, Frenchie’s accent is as British as it is French.

headline: Liberal Chinese Journal, Claiming Interference by Overseers, Files Lawsuit
abstract: The move came after the Chinese National Academy of Arts announced that Yanhuang Chunqiu’s publisher was dismissed and its chief editor was demoted.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A liberal Chinese journal whose publisher and top editors were dismissed or demoted this week says it is fighting back with a lawsuit.

headline: New Rules for College Financial Aid Accounts
abstract: New federal rules prohibit colleges from steering students to specific bank accounts to deposit financial aid.
lead_paragraph: AS college students prepare for a new academic year, they can expect changes in the process of choosing a bank account to receive their financial aid balances.

headline: Robert Kennedy Jr., in Book, Says Michael Skakel Is Innocent of ’75 Murder
abstract: Forty years after the murder of 15-year-old Martha Moxley and three years after Mr. Skakel’s conviction was thrown out, his cousin claims to have definitively solved the case.
lead_paragraph: It has been 40 years since Martha Moxley, a 15-year-old in Greenwich, Conn., was bludgeoned to death with a golf club — a symbol of privilege in one of America’s most privileged communities. The horrific crime spawned years of police investigation, gossipy books that capitalized on a connection to the Kennedy family, Hollywood movies and finally, 27 years after the murder, a conviction.

headline: Phil Mickelson Avoids Letup at British Open, Keeping Lead
abstract: After just missing history in the first round, Mickelson continued his push for the British Open, recording a two-under-par 69.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — With the wind thrashing and the rain clouds hanging heavy in the sky late Friday morning, Royal Troon was no place for long, syrupy swings. So Phil Mickelson took his arms back and through quickly, like saloon doors whipping on their hinges, and his tee shot on the par-3 eighth hole bore low, cutting through the air and bouncing left of the hole before turning back on itself and rolling toward the cup.

headline: Shopping for Kitchen Islands With Nate Berkus
abstract: Expert tips from the interior designer.
lead_paragraph: Nate Berkus isn’t much of a cook, yet the kitchen has always been one of his favorite rooms. “I can’t cook at all,” he said. “I can set the table and design the kitchen, but I can barely make myself an egg.”

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Marianne Faithfull
abstract: The singer shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the singer Marianne Faithfull, who shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: Want to Work in 18 Miles of Books? First, the Quiz
abstract: Four decades ago, the Strand created a short literature test for job applicants, which has become as much a part of the bookstore’s identity as its tote bags.
lead_paragraph: As Jennifer Lobaugh arrived at the Strand Book Store to apply for a job this spring, she remembered feeling jittery. It wasn’t only because she badly wanted a job at the fabled bookstore in Greenwich Village, her first in New York City, but also because at the end of the application, there was a quiz — a book quiz.

headline: Test Your Book Smarts
abstract: Can you pass the Strand's literary quiz? Match each book with its author.
lead_paragraph: Can you pass the Strand's literary quiz? Match each book with its author.

headline: Newt Gingrich Echoes Donald Trump With Remarks on Muslims and Terrorism
abstract: The former House speaker said that American intelligence agencies need to more closely scrutinize mosques, and that any Muslim who believes in Sharia law should be required to leave the country.
lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich is clinging to hopes that he might become Donald J. Trump’s running mate, and on Thursday night he offered a fresh take on one of Mr. Trump’s most provocative proposals for combating terrorism, calling for a religious test for all Muslims who wish to remain in the United States.

headline: Reporting Within the Lines in Putin’s Russia
abstract: What do censorship and traffic have in common in Russia? The rules keep shifting.
lead_paragraph: When a perfect metaphor is born, the world comes into focus.

headline: Defending David Against the World’s Goliaths in International Court
abstract: Paul S. Reichler began his career defending the Sandinistas, and this week he added another victory: the Philippines’ case against Beijing and its claims in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Paul S. Reichler’s first big break came in the late 1970s, when, not long out of Harvard Law School, he was a litigation associate at a blue-chip Washington law firm. The Sandinistas had just come to power in Nicaragua, and the partners did not mind putting an idealistic young lawyer to work full time to recover national assets spirited away by the Somoza dictatorship.

headline: Cuba, a Country Frozen in Time
abstract: My land is an insular museum, stuck between the Iron Curtain and the industrial capitalism of the 1950s, and visitors view us an exotic species.
lead_paragraph: Havana — Never had a country appeared as old as Cuba did when it started to upgrade itself. The mad rush to develop serves only to confirm our comical, almost antediluvian backwardness. The New7Wonders Foundation, an organization that aims to preserve monuments worldwide, has just chosen Havana as a “wonder city.” In a strict sense it is, although the local residents struggle to believe it.

headline: Herbalife Settlement With F.T.C. Ends Billionaires’ Battle
abstract: Regulators fined the company but didn’t shut it down, handing a victory to the investor Carl C. Icahn over the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman.
lead_paragraph: In the Wall Street dogfight between two billionaire investors, William A. Ackman won a moral victory but Carl C. Icahn won the war over the future of Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company.

headline: The $1,600 Marathon
abstract: I wondered how much this, my sixth marathon, would cost me. And not just the race fee, but the total of every little thing that I would spend money on to get me from my first training run to race day.
lead_paragraph: In May I ran the New Jersey Marathon. Before I started training for the race on New Year’s Eve, I wondered how much this, my sixth marathon, would cost me. And not just the race fee — I knew that one, since I had signed up for the race in November — but the total of every little thing that I would spend money on to get me from my first training run to race day.

headline: 1916: Shark Scare in New Jersey
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Shark attack scare at New Jersey seashore in July, 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Further details of New York’s ‘‘shark scare’’ are published here today [July 15]. A cablegram to the ‘‘Daily News and Leader’’ reports that holiday-makers at New Jersey seaside resorts are panic-stricken in consequence of the news from Atlantic Highlands and Asbury Park that sharks have appeared in shallow water, killing two bathers at the former place and three at the latter.

headline: Benjamin Millepied Left the Paris Opera Ballet. Now What?
abstract: Leaving Paris, the choreographer has plans for his L.A. Dance Project: touring, partnerships and digital efforts that “you can monetize.”
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Millepied is once again a free man. As of July 15, he is no longer at the helm of the Paris Opera Ballet, where in February he unexpectedly announced that he would step down after nearly two years. (He has been succeeded by Aurélie Dupont, a former company étoile.)

headline: Can Opera Become an Agent of Change?
abstract: Using opera to understand the connections between cultures is no longer a possibility; it’s a moral necessity.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — “Mesdames et messieurs,” a voice calmly boomed from the loudspeakers a few minutes into intermission at the Lyon Opera on July 7. A murmur passed through the throng waiting at the bar as the announcement continued: The audience would have to evacuate the theater.

headline: T’s New Entertainment Issue: Editor’s Letter
abstract: A feature two years in the making proves some stories are worth waiting for — and poring over.
lead_paragraph: Print magazines are little hermetic worlds — each issue a controlled and finite environment edited and art-directed down to every minute detail. It is quite unlike the floodgates of the internet forever swinging open, where treats and opportunities dangle from every tree. You can fail to crack open a magazine or choose to read just one article, skim its pages, save it or toss it, but that’s about as far as you get in controlling the experience.

headline: With ‘Seriously Funny,’ MoMA Celebrates Leo McCarey, an Early Film Talent
abstract: Beginning in the silent era, McCarey directed work ranging from the slapstick (Laurel and Hardy) to the unsparingly bleak (“Make Way for Tomorrow”).
lead_paragraph: In “Seriously Funny: The Films of Leo McCarey,” the Museum of Modern Art surveys the portfolio of an often overlooked early Hollywood director who in his prime was one of the industry’s biggest names. Originally a lawyer, McCarey, who earned his spurs in the silent era, directing dozens of shorts for the Hal Roach Studios, is credited with bringing Laurel and Hardy together. From there, he would make all manner of comedies: subversive (the Marx Brothers’ “Duck Soup”); patriotic (“Ruggles of Red Gap,” with Charles Laughton); and screwball (“The Awful Truth,” with Irene Dunne and Cary Grant).

headline: Lost Culture on Found Film
abstract: “The Daughter of Dawn,” rediscovered from 1920, is released on video, and “The Return of a Man Called Horse” is reissued on Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: As our nation’s original “others,” Native Americans were a screen on which white settlers and their descendants projected their fantasies, if not their sense of guilt — particularly at the movies. Mainly in westerns, indigenous Americans were alternately nature’s noblemen and creatures of untrammeled id, stand-ins for Chinese communists and the third world’s oppressed masses.

headline: Calls for Social Security Expansion Grow Louder in Washington
abstract: After years of talk about reining in Social Security, the discussion has turned to making it more generous instead.
lead_paragraph: JANA PANARITES was about to make a midlife career shift in 2010 when her father died. At age 50, she had completed a master’s degree in cultural diplomacy at the University of Southern California and was looking for a position in the nonprofit sector. That plan ground to a halt when she moved back to Maryland, where she grew up, to take care of her mother.

headline: Character, Fate and Yahoo
abstract: Forget the years of lousy deals and seedy shenanigans: Yahoo’s real problem was a contradiction it couldn’t resolve.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo, we hardly knew ye.

headline: Finding a Hard Drive in Just the Right Size
abstract: Many new lightweight laptops come with solid-state drives that work faster but store less, but explore your options when buying a new machine.
lead_paragraph: Q. Many lightweight laptops these days come with solid-state drives that have only 256 gigabytes or sometimes 512 gigabytes of space. Why are the drives so small? My old computer has a 500-gigabyte hard drive and I’m worried about fitting all my stuff.

headline: Truck Attack in Nice, France: What We Know, and What We Don’t
abstract: Although the Islamic State has claimed responsibility, the motives of the attacker, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, remain unclear.
lead_paragraph: The driver of a large white truck mowed down a crowd gathered to watch Bastille Day fireworks in Nice, France, on Thursday night. Scores of people were killed and injured in what the French government has called a terrorist assault, the third major attack on the country in 19 months.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Trade Deal Talks, 14 Rounds In, Are Faltering. What’s at Stake?
abstract: The trade and investment accord, aimed at creating the world’s largest trading zone, faces stiff headwinds in Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States and the European Union have had 14 rounds of talks over three years on a trade and investment deal aimed at creating the world’s largest trading zone, but they are making slow progress.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to a recent work of fiction by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Arrangements’

headline: Journals of the Plague Years
abstract: “The deal was 30,000 words in 30 days,” Donald G. McNeil Jr. said of his new book, “Zika: The Emerging Epidemic.”
lead_paragraph: As a science reporter for The New York Times, Donald G. McNeil Jr. was busy covering the Zika epidemic in April when John Glusman, the editor in chief of W.W. Norton, asked him whether he could write a “miracle book” about the disease in one month. “The deal was 30,000 words in 30 days,” McNeil said in an email interview, “or I didn’t get a penny of the advance.” The result is “Zika: The Emerging Epidemic,” a paperback original that was released at the end of June, in time for the summer travel season and the Rio Olympics.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Seinfeldia,” No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list, goes behind the scenes of the groundbreaking sitcom about nothing.
lead_paragraph: Must See: It’s been almost 20 years since the “Seinfeld” series finale left Jerry and his friends in orange prison jumpsuits — ­convicted, fittingly enough, of doing nothing — and changes to the industry since then have pretty much ensured that even as television gets smarter and more daring, no subsequent show will have the reach and mass cultural impact of “Seinfeld” at its height. (Consider: More than 76 million viewers tuned in for the “Seinfeld” finale, while the much anticipated “Mad Men” finale drew approximately 4.6 million.) Now the show and its influence are the subject of a new book, “­Seinfeldia,” by the entertainment writer Jennifer Kei­shin Armstrong, which lands on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 13. “They elevated the art of the sitcom,” Armstrong told NBC News recently. “They did things with it that they were told they couldn’t do.” What’s more, she said, for a show that was supposedly about nothing, “Seinfeld” managed to take on many of the social preoccupations of its time. That makes it tempting to imagine what the series would be like today had it continued. “It sounds weird,” Armstrong said, “but I would have loved to see them addressing things like 9/11 or terrorism. . . . When something is far enough away, you can start to attack it.” She added: “I’d be interested to see how they would address even more benign things like internet trolling, that sort of thing. Could they possibly pull off an episode about transgender issues? I would be interested.” Actually, the trans thing isn’t so hard to picture — remember when Kramer came up with the Bro, his bra for men?

headline: Adrienne Rich’s Poetry Became Political, but It Remained Rooted in Material Fact
abstract: Work from seven decades illuminates Adrienne Rich’s ethical mission in “Collected Poems: 1950-2012.”
lead_paragraph: COLLECTED POEMS1950-2012By Adrienne Rich1,164 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $50.

headline: A Past of One’s Own: Vita Sackville-West’s Granddaughter Describes Her Extraordinary Ancestors
abstract: In “A House Full of Daughters,” Juliet Nicolson reviews the lives of her family’s extraordinary, and extraordinarily troubled, women.
lead_paragraph: A HOUSE FULL OF DAUGHTERSA Memoir of Seven GenerationsBy Juliet NicolsonIllustrated. 326 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: Von Miller Agrees to Huge Contract With Denver Broncos
abstract: Patience paid off for the linebacker, who rejected an earlier offer before accepting a deal that will make him the highest-paid nonquarterback in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: Linebacker Von Miller of the Denver Broncos will be one of the N.F.L.’s richest players.

headline: Religion
abstract: New books include “Putting God Second” and “Agnostic: A Spirited Manifesto.”
lead_paragraph: A NONE’S STORYSearching for Meaning Inside Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism and IslamBy Corinna Nicolaou289 pp. Columbia University, $35.

headline: Roads to Fabulous
abstract: Celebrities (and Stanley Fish) hold forth on health, happiness and winning arguments.
lead_paragraph: When taking advice from celebrities, it helps to be sad. It helps even more to be drunk and fat. Normally I might scoff at health and relationship tips from the professionally beautiful. But after a fight with my husband, 10 pounds of weight gain and a bottle of chardonnay, things change. Gwyneth Paltrow, what you got for me?

headline: An Unusual Bequest to Each Member of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra
abstract: In her will, the philanthropist and longtime supporter Marjorie S. Fisher left $5,000 to each of the ensemble’s 70 full-time musicians.
lead_paragraph: Many benefactors leave bequests to an orchestra when they die. One has now left a bequest to the players.

lead_paragraph: Governor Mike Pence of Indiana, who Donald J. Trump announced as his running mate on Friday, has a relatively low approval rating among governors.

headline: 36 Hours in Cape Town
abstract: A plan for this stunning city might include a 5K run (or walk), browsing farm markets, dinner at a wine estate and, no surprise, heading up Table Mountain (by cable car).
lead_paragraph: A plan for this stunning city might include a 5K run (or walk), browsing farm markets, dinner at a wine estate and, no surprise, heading up Table Mountain (by cable car).

headline: How Donald Trump Finally Settled on Mike Pence
abstract: Advisers and family members stressed to Mr. Trump that he was selecting a running mate to unite the party, not a new best friend, according to people briefed on the process.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump raged at the leaked reports of his plan to choose Mike Pence, the governor of Indiana, as his running mate. In public, he denied having made a “final, final decision,” and postponed a planned event to unveil his choice. In a Thursday evening phone call with top aides, he asked for reassurance that Mr. Pence was really right for the job.

headline: Twist in Zika Outbreak: New York Case Shows Women Can Spread It to Men
abstract: The evidence widens the pool of those at risk from the virus, which had been thought to pass only from men to women or between two men during sex.
lead_paragraph: The first case of female-to-male sexual transmission of the Zika virus has been documented in New York City, raising the prospect that the disease could spread more widely beyond the countries where it is already endemic and largely transmitted by mosquitoes.

headline: A New England Shop Where the Goods are Plainly Perfect
abstract: In a small cottage, the owners of Plain Goods sell understated pieces for the home — and the closet.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, the iconic SoHo design store Hope & Wilder was among the first to rekindle the romance of homespun New England, rousing tastemakers to replace their Biedermeier with white painted furniture and their silk curtains with mattress ticking. The shop closed its doors in 1998, but one of its co-founders, Michael DePerno, has opened a new iteration in a converted cottage in New Preston, Conn. Chockablock with antique rugs and Japanese and Native American baskets, Plain Goods is deeply faithful to DePerno’s aesthetic: purity of design, understated textures and a natural palette and materials.

headline: Syrian Refugees: Welcome in Canada
abstract: The reporters Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn talk about the warm welcome private Canadian citizens have extended to Syrian refugees.
lead_paragraph: The reporters Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn talk about the warm welcome private Canadian citizens have extended to Syrian refugees.

headline: Report on Female-to-Male Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a report outlining the first case of female-to-male sexual transmission of the Zika virus, raising concerns about the ability of the virus to spread more widely.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a report outlining the first case of female-to-male sexual transmission of the Zika virus, raising concerns about the ability of the virus to spread more widely.

headline: Syrian Refugees: Welcome in Canada
abstract: The reporters Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn talk about the warm welcome private Canadian citizens have extended to Syrian refugees.
lead_paragraph: For months, two Times reporters, Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn, wrote an article about ordinary private citizens in Canada who essentially adopt Syrian refugees, one family at a time, for up to a year.

headline: How Mike Pence and Donald Trump Compare on the Issues
abstract: The two men at the top of the Republican ticket agree on many subjects and policy positions, but have differed on Muslim immigration, gay rights and the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: Mike Pence, who has served as governor of Indiana since 2013, will be Donald J. Trump’s running mate on the Republican presidential ticket. Mr. Pence, a staunch social conservative, was elected in 2000 to the House of Representatives, where he served in the party leadership. Here is a look at his stand on important issues, and how he compares with Mr. Trump.

headline: Mike Pence: A Conservative Proudly Out of Sync With His Times
abstract: With his deep social conservatism, public religiosity and aversion to negative campaigning, Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is a throwback to an earlier era.
lead_paragraph: Long after government regulators had confirmed the lethal consequences of cigarette smoking, Mike Pence mocked their warnings as “hysteria” in 1998.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: On a morning and weekend full of more terrible news, look for peace in cooking for yourself and those you love.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Who Is Mike Pence?
abstract: Mr. Pence, Indiana’s governor, was named Donald J. Trump’s running mate on Friday. He is a former congressman and radio host.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump announced on Friday that he had chosen Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana as his running mate. Here is some background on Mr. Pence, who called himself “Rush Limbaugh on decaf” when he hosted a talk radio show and who quoted the Bible when he was in Congress.

headline: Baylor Sexual Assault Report Produces Punishment, but No Paper Trail
abstract: Outside lawyers investigated sexual violence at Baylor University. But a full accounting of the inquiry was never written down — at the university’s request.
lead_paragraph: The former Baylor president Kenneth W. Starr complained that he had never seen it. Baylor’s alumni association called for its release. The Big 12 Conference has asked for it — twice.

headline: For This Greek Pie, You Don’t Need a Crust
abstract: Filled with yogurt, dill and mint, these pitas are wrapped in chard leaves, rather than pastry.
lead_paragraph: In summer, I find myself leaning vegetarian for the most part. I want ultrasimple meals: feta, tomatoes, olive oil, bread. They seem to somehow veer Greek, more often than not, and I want to eat them outdoors, in a shady spot.

headline: False Alarm: Damien Hirst’s Formaldehyde Fumes Weren’t Dangerous
abstract: A scientific paper that said a 2012 exhibition at Tate Modern had high levels of fumes will be retracted.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A scientific article published in April, asserting that a 2012 exhibition of work by Damien Hirst at Tate Modern had dangerously high levels of formaldehyde fumes, will be retracted. Mr. Hirst’s company, Science Ltd., and one of the paper’s authors, Pier Giorgio Righetti, announced the decision on Friday.

headline: Terry McMillan Finds Her New York Oasis
abstract: The author spends an afternoon downtown and appreciates the area’s new charm.
lead_paragraph: “Wow, how times have changed,” said Terry McMillan as she gazed at a yacht floating in the Hudson River along Lower Manhattan. “There used to be rats down here. I’m not into rats.”

headline: Why ‘All Lives Matter’ Is Such a Perilous Phrase

lead_paragraph: [For more about police violence and unrest, go here]

headline: The Times Gives an Update on Anonymous Source Use
abstract: The Times updates the newsroom on how well its push to limit anonymous source is working.
lead_paragraph: Many readers have written in to the public editor over the past months and years complaining about The Times’s persistent use of unnamed sources. This past March, The Times laid out new rules aimed at tightening up the circumstances under which these unnamed sources could be used.

headline: Posters in Pakistan Urge a General to Take Control of the Government
abstract: The signs, placed by Move On Pakistan, call on the popular general Raheel Sharif to take over for an increasingly unpopular prime minister.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Posters urging the Pakistani Army chief to take over the country in a military coup sprouted suddenly across Pakistan this week, with a photograph of Gen. Raheel Sharif, a burly man with a thick mustache, and an emphatic, pleading request: “For God’s sake, take over.”

headline: Three Bedrooms on ‘Billionaires’ Row’ for $27 Million
abstract: Four more apartments sold at 432 Park Avenue, the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: Four more apartments have officially sold at 432 Park Avenue, the supertall luxury skyscraper in the heart of the city’s “Billionaires’ Row” in Midtown. They were the most expensive closed transactions of the week, according to property records.

headline: Why Land and Homes Actually Tend to Be Disappointing Investments
abstract: It’s true, as the adage goes, that they’re not making land anymore, but technology that allows more intensive use of land has held down values in the long term.
lead_paragraph: Buy land: They’re not making it anymore. That often repeated adage sounds like good financial advice.
