abstract: Could Donald make a deal with a spaceship?
lead_paragraph: One thing Donald Trump ought to be good at is throwing a celebrity-packed convention, right?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Helen Gurley Brown
abstract: This week, Moira Weigel discusses new biographies of Helen Gurley Brown; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Juliet Nicolson talks about “A House Full of Daughters”; and Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Moira Weigel discusses new biographies of Helen Gurley Brown; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Juliet Nicolson talks about “A House Full of Daughters”; and Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: 1966: Pilot Fights off Lions in Cockpit
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Pilot Paul Wuhrman fights off lions in plane, July 1966.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The copilot of a chartered plane fought three angry lions with a hatchet in midair today [July 16] while the pilot steered the aircraft to an emergency landing here. When the plane landed, the terrified pilots smashed the cockpit window with the hatchet and jumped to the ground, leaving the lions snarling behind them. The lions, one of them a cub, were on their way from West Germany to London. They broke out of their cage while the Swiss-chartered cargo plane was over Belgium.

headline: Viacom’s Effort to Sell Paramount Stake Takes Another Blow
abstract: National Amusements, the private theater chain company through which Sumner Redstone controls Viacom, said a sale now could hinder Viacom’s prospects.
lead_paragraph: Even as Philippe P. Dauman, Viacom’s embattled chief executive, pushes ahead with plans to sell a 49 percent stake in the company’s Paramount Pictures film and television studio, it appears increasingly unlikely that such a deal will come to fruition.

You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our upcoming website.

headline: ‘Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie’ Gets a Style Update
abstract: The stylist Rebecca Hale modernizes Patsy’s and Edina’s over-the-top looks from the series while maintaining their cheeky personal styles.
lead_paragraph: What happened to Patsy’s and Edina’s closets in the 24 years between the beginning of the hit British television series “Absolutely Fabulous” and its new movie incarnation? Rebecca Hale, the stylist for “Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie,” had only six weeks to find looks that reinvent the characters for a modern fashion audience. Patsy (Joanna Lumley) and Edina (Jennifer Saunders) have updated their over-the-top Lacroix looks for British designers like Stella McCartney and Sibling, while still maintaining their quirky personal styles. Ms. Hale explains the story behind the makeovers:

headline: Nazi Art Loot Returned ... to Nazis

lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Years after World War II, American officials here entrusted more than 10,000 confiscated artworks to Bavarian authorities to return to the rightful owners, many of them Jews whose property had been plundered.

headline: Policing Bias in the Ranks
abstract: Members of the Police Department will soon be trained to identify their implicit biases, but what about more explicit ones?
lead_paragraph: Several days ago, while Mayor Bill de Blasio was visiting a senior center in the Bronx to talk about the dangers of heat waves, he shifted course to address the police killings of Alton Sterling in Louisiana and Philando Castile in Minnesota. Heralding what New York City was doing to prevent similar annihilations of both human life and public trust from occurring, he mentioned programs to train and regularly retrain officers in the techniques of de-escalating violence and, more pointedly, the work that officers would soon begin doing to help them understand “implicit bias.”

abstract: The president and the former mayor of New York approach race from different perspectives, to say the least.

lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s selection of Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana to be his running mate was attended by the frenzied will-he, won’t-he drama Americans have come to expect from his campaign. But there’s more political realism than reality show in the choice of Mr. Pence, Mr. Trump’s biggest compromise yet with the establishment Republicans he claims to reject.

abstract: Pasta with a sauce of puréed corn off the cob makes for a sweet summery meal.

abstract: You can make a silky, luscious sauce for pasta with sweet corn purée.

headline: Stretch of Market Volatility Makes It Stormy at the Top
abstract: Stocks thrashed higher and lower in the second quarter — and didn’t go very far. With valuations and uncertainty high, where are investors to go?
lead_paragraph: The stock market at midyear hovered around a record high. But after several disturbing weeks in which prices soared, then plunged, then soared again, the view from the summit, or near it, may not be so pleasant.

headline: A Fading Mural
abstract: A mural of a Cuban woman, which was plastered on an exterior wall of a Chelsea art gallery in 2013, slowly disappeared behind the construction of a high rise next door.
lead_paragraph: A mural of a Cuban woman, which was plastered on an exterior wall of a Chelsea art gallery in 2013, slowly disappeared behind the construction of a high rise next door.

headline: A Mural Fades From a City Canvas
abstract: As part of a 2013 exhibition, artists plastered a portrait on the side of gallery in Chelsea. Over two and a half years, the figure began to disappear behind construction.
lead_paragraph: Leda Antonia Machado lived through the Cuban Revolution and the decades of deprivation that followed. But in the hypercapitalism of New York real estate, she met her match. The artists José Parlá and JR discovered Ms. Machado in May 2012, when they were interviewing and photographing elder residents of Havana for a street art project called “The Wrinkles of the City.” She was 94 and took some convincing, Mr. Parlá, who lives in Brooklyn, said. Her regal portrait, embellished with tracings by Mr. Parlá, went up on a crumbling building in Havana that year. Within 18 months, all that remained of the wall was a column bearing her head and torso. “She said, ‘You see, no one can tear me down,’” Mr. Parlá said.

headline: How Much Can Mike Pence Help Donald Trump?
abstract: The choice of a running mate generally has little effect on a presidential election, which seems even more likely to be true this time.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a good rule about vice-presidential selections: Even when they matter, they usually don’t matter much.

lead_paragraph: Q. In the 1980s and early 1990s, during the bad old days of Times Square, I would walk by men who would mutter: “Sess? Sess?” Never marijuana, pot, weed or grass. Why sess?

lead_paragraph: Since 2008, Hélène Darroze has been the marquee chef at the famed Connaught hotel in London, serving lunch and dinner in the sumptuously appointed dining room just Monday through Friday.

abstract: “Democrats will lay out the clear stakes in this election between building walls and tearing people down or an optimistic unifying vision,” the committee said.

abstract: Some favorite looks from the sidewalks of New York during men’s fashion week.

headline: Chris Froome Keeps Lead on a Somber Day at the Tour de France
abstract: With everyone thinking of the truck attack in Nice, Froome maintained his hold on the yellow race leader’s jersey in Friday’s time trial.
lead_paragraph: VALLON-PONT-D’ARC, France — Booming loudspeakers often give the start area of the Tour de France the aura of a disco, one that inexplicably opens for business at midmorning. On Friday in Bourg-St.-Andéol, however, even the Tour announcer abandoned his exuberance for a somber tone.

abstract: Two doctors discuss the disparities among communities and generations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In 9/11 Document, View of a Saudi Effort to Thwart U.S. Action on Al Qaeda
abstract: The 28 pages were part of the congressional inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks, but had been kept secret out of concern that they might fray relations with Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-classified document detailing possible connections between the government of Saudi Arabia and the Sept. 11 terrorist plot released on Friday is a wide-ranging catalog of meetings and suspicious coincidences.

headline: 28 Pages of the 2002 Congressional Inquiry into the Sept. 11 Attacks
abstract: Congress released the so-called "28 pages" on Friday that discuss the possible involvement of Saudi Arabia in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The pages have been withheld since the conclusion in 2002 of a congressional inquiry into the attacks..
lead_paragraph: Congress released the so-called "28 pages" on Friday that discuss the possible involvement of Saudi Arabia in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The pages have been withheld since the conclusion in 2002 of a congressional inquiry into the attacks..

headline: Met Job Cuts Could Exceed 100 in a Move to Steady Finances
abstract: Just three months after announcing a hiring freeze and voluntary buyouts, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is turning to layoffs in core areas.
lead_paragraph: Just three months after the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced a hiring freeze and voluntary buyouts, the museum is turning to layoffs as part of an effort to cut its deficit by $30 million, through cost reductions and revenue growth.

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Rabbi Pulls Out of Appearing at Republican Convention
abstract: Rabbi Haskel Lookstein told his congregation in an email that he had backed out of delivering the invocation because it had become too political.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Yet another prominent person Donald J. Trump hoped would appear at the Republican National Convention has rebuffed his invitation, the latest sign of disarray in the campaign’s planning of an event that starts in just three days.

headline: She’s Still on the Case
abstract: Ida Van Lindt has been secretary to Robert M. Morgenthau, the former Manhattan district attorney, for 41 years.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll be right with you, Mr. Morgenthau,” Ida Van Lindt said to her boss, Robert M. Morgenthau, the famously longstanding Manhattan district attorney who retired in 2009.

headline: After 75 Years, the Cheese Stands Alone
abstract: After changing times led an Italian immigrant to shut down his grocery store, his relatives passed down a wheel of Romano as they moved around the New York area.
lead_paragraph: At a bend in Hudson Avenue, across from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, there is a manhole cover that once lay just outside my grandparents’ grocery store. It is the last trace of a block of long-gone shops and stores straight out of an Edward Hopper painting. In my refrigerator sits another keepsake of this lost place — a quarter-wheel of cheese saved after the store closed in 1941. That anything as perishable as cheese should survive 75 years is remarkable, and so is the tale it tells.

headline: At Boscobel House, Conversations Between Antique and Modern Furnishings
abstract: A house museum in Garrison juxtaposes contemporary studio furniture produced in the region with incomparable antique furnishings of the past.
lead_paragraph: One of the best exhibitions in the Hudson Valley this summer explores a trend that art museums have embraced with mixed success in recent years: trying to achieve an aesthetic interplay by exhibiting contemporary art alongside the work of old masters.

headline: Art Installation in Torrington Is a Colorful Reflection of a River, and a Community
abstract: Danielle Mailer enlisted local volunteers to help create a mural-like work, with enormous fish covered in bright patterns, along the Naugatuck.
lead_paragraph: A warehouselike space across from the Warner Theater in Torrington is strewn with large, oddly shaped cutouts. Some are still bare aluminum, others are colorfully painted, and still others are somewhere in between.

headline: Review: HBO’s ‘Vice Principals’ Features Power Struggles and Potty Mouths
abstract: Danny R. McBride and Walton Goggins star as rival high school administrators in this new comedy series, in which their characters unite to bring down a new principal.
lead_paragraph: Walton Goggins makes a habit of being the best thing about the television shows he’s in. He’s managed it in some pretty great series, like “The Shield” and “Justified.” He has an easier time of it in the new HBO series “Vice Principals,” beginning on Sunday, where his eccentric performance is the one reliable reason to watch.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Night of Ballyhoo’ at Bay Street Theater
abstract: A serious comedy set in Atlanta examines the lives of a group of Jews and how they relate to their own religion and to each other.
lead_paragraph: The Christmas tree tucked into a corner of the living room depicted on the stage of the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor is not particularly large. Its significance, however, is huge.

headline: Review: ‘Coriolanus’ in Madison Has 20th-Century Costumes and 21st-Century Conflict
abstract: The rarely produced play, visually updated in this revival by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey, pits a scornful Roman consul against a boisterous populace.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey presented “Coriolanus” was in 1987. The company’s current staging of the play in Madison is a fine opportunity for audiences to encounter Shakespeare’s dark, absorbing and, in some ways, remarkably timely drama.

headline: Terror by Truck: The Massacre in Nice
abstract: “They’re smart and willing to die. That’s a bad, bad combination,” a writer says of terrorists after the latest attack.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Jet Lag Can Feel Worse When You Travel From West to East
abstract: Researchers produced a mathematical model of certain brain cells to help explain why travel’s toll on fliers feels more severe in one direction than the other.
lead_paragraph: Jet lag may be the worst part of traveling. And it hits many people harder traveling east than west. Why they feel this way is unclear. But scientists recently developed a model that mimics special time-keeping cells in the body and offers a mathematical explanation for why traveling from west to east feels so much worse. It also offers insights on recovering from jet lag.

headline: Popcast: The Return of Pop-Punk and Emo
abstract: Pop music writers discuss Blink-182’s influence on modern pop-punk bands.
lead_paragraph: Pop music writers discuss Blink-182’s influence on modern pop-punk bands.

headline: Behind Volkswagen Settlement, Speed and Compromise
abstract: It was one of the fastest civil settlements in the history of corporate malfeasance, but fraught with pitfalls, including clashing egos and cultures.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the fastest civil settlements in the history of corporate malfeasance, coming together in six months instead of the years usually required for such complex negotiations. But the path to Volkswagen’s $15 billion deal last month with American officials and car owners over the company’s diesel deception was fraught with pitfalls, including clashing egos and cultures, arguments over mathematical formulas and frayed nerves from late nights and lost weekends.

headline: Popcast: The Return of Pop-Punk and Emo
abstract: Blink-182’s influence can be heard in the echoes of in modern pop-punk bands and joyful bands of the nth-wave emo revival currently taking place.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

headline: Hello, Handsome: The Best of New York Fashion Week: Men’s
abstract: The top looks from four days of sartorial art and trashy fun.
lead_paragraph: The top looks from four days of sartorial art and trashy fun.

headline: Russian Images of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Were Altered, Report Finds
abstract: Researchers determined that two images the Russian government released after the civilian jet crashed over eastern Ukraine in 2014 had been manipulated.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A group of arms control researchers have determined that two images released by the Russian government, ostensibly to help clarify why a civilian airliner was shot down two years ago, were digitally altered using Photoshop before being posted online.

headline: Already Shaky, U.S. Profits Shudder After ‘Brexit’ Vote
abstract: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union bolstered the dollar, which could hurt the earning of American companies that make most of their sales abroad.
lead_paragraph: To the growing list of problems brought about by June’s “Brexit” vote, you can add corporate profits in the United States.

headline: How Fredrik Eklund, Broker and Reality TV Star, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Eklund, 39, starts a busy workday with meditation and Swedish coffee, and ends it with sunset dinners.
lead_paragraph: You could say that the Swedish-born Fredrik Eklund, 39, is a triple threat. Besides being an associate real estate broker at Douglas Elliman, he is a star of a Bravo reality series, “Million Dollar Listing New York,” which just wrapped up its fifth season, and an author of “The Sell: The Secrets of Selling Anything to Anyone.” When he is not in front of the camera, writing or selling, Mr. Eklund likes to relax with his husband, Derek Kaplan, 41, an abstract painter, and their miniature dachshunds, Mini Mouse and Fritzy, who all live in a three-bedroom loft in TriBeCa. JULIE SATOW

headline: Texas Boy Known as ‘Copeland Crush’ and His Father Are Mourned
abstract: Brodie Copeland, 11, a baseball player, and his father, Sean, were identified as American victims of the attack in Nice, France.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Brodie Copeland, 11, one of the victims of the attack in Nice, France, was such a hard-hitting baseball player that teammates at his club in Texas called him the “Copeland Crush.”

headline: My Hands Grip the Wheel Now, but Financial Autopilot Is Coming
abstract: Technology is fine for steering around traffic jams, but can it be trusted with our retirements?
lead_paragraph: I love tech but it scares me. Every year it seems to be taking over another part of my life.

headline: Selling a Business Involves More Than Money
abstract: Owners should run businesses as if they could be bought at any moment, but not rush the process once a deal is made, experts say.
lead_paragraph: THE first time Chris Ludwig sold his refrigerant reprocessing company, he said he acted as if the deal was done long before it was. He beefed up inventory, added sales staff and generally increased his expenses.

headline: April Bloomfield Won’t Open Restaurant in Financial District
abstract: An ambitious deal for a four-story spread in 70 Pine Street has been called off.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, the chef April Bloomfield and Ken Friedman, her business partner, announced that they would open a complex of restaurants and bars on the top floors and in the lobby of 70 Pine Street, in Manhattan’s financial district. But now they have resigned from the project by mutual agreement with Adam Rose, the developer, who is converting the Art Deco skyscraper, formerly the AIG Building, into apartments.

headline: Good News for Bond Buyers That May Be Fleeting
abstract: The jury is still out on whether negative yields will spur economic growth, but central banks have engineered short-term gains for American bond investors.
lead_paragraph: The jury is still out on whether the negative-yield experiment playing out in Japan and across Europe will deliver on its intended goal of spurring economic growth. But central banks have managed to engineer some short-term good news for American bond investors.

headline: Emerging Markets, Even in Turmoil, Have a Place in a Portfolio
abstract: Troubled by low returns and high expense ratios, investors are fleeing the struggling asset class. But portfolio managers say the worries could be overblown.
lead_paragraph: Over the last five years, investors in emerging-markets mutual funds have paid plenty and gotten little in return.

headline: Omari Hardwick on Taming His Drug Kingpin Persona on ‘Power’
abstract: As the show opens a third season this weekend on Starz, Mr. Hardwick talks about a multifaceted role with Shakespearean overtones.
lead_paragraph: On any given day, Omari Hardwick might be portraying one of three people, and sometimes all at once. As the star of “Power,” which opens its third season Sunday night on Starz, he plays a man struggling to untangle himself from the drug world, where he is known as Ghost, and become a legitimate businessman (James St. Patrick), while trying to start anew with his high school sweetheart (who refers to him as Jamie).

headline: Funds That Find Speedsters, Even in a Slow Economy
abstract: The top-performing funds of the second quarter included three that identify small and midsize companies with earnings that are expected to grow at above-average rates.
lead_paragraph: Craigh A. Cepukenas, lead portfolio manager of the Artisan Small Cap fund, likens his approach to farming. First, he said, he and his colleagues on Artisan’s growth team identify promising companies and place them in their “garden,” with a holding equal to 0.5 percent to 1 percent of the fund’s assets. Starting small minimizes mistakes, he said.

headline: The Risk of Building on Real Estate Funds’ Profitable Past
abstract: Real estate investment funds, which produce income from sources like malls and data centers, are appealing but some potential pitfalls loom.
lead_paragraph: Past performance, we are repeatedly and rightfully reminded, is no guarantee of comparable performance in the future.

headline: Yahoo’s Failed Alibaba Spinoff May Benefit Other Deals
abstract: New I.R.S. rules proposed after the agency declined to bless the spinoff set limits for when certain spinoffs cannot not get tax-free treatment.
lead_paragraph: Call it the “Yahoo rule.” The internet company’s failure to spin off Alibaba to shareholders could be a boon for future separations. The Internal Revenue Service has proposed modified regulations on when such splits can qualify for tax-free treatment. The move occurred after the I.R.S. declined to bless Yahoo’s carve-out of its Alibaba stake last year. Similar deals have been delayed since.

headline: Timing May Be Right for Investors to Seek Protection
abstract: Various factors could prompt owners of equity portfolios to go on the defensive. If so, it’s crucial to determine whether to focus strategies on the short or long run.
lead_paragraph: Stocks have shown no clear trend in more than a year; valuations are high and corporate earnings have been weak.

headline: Unexpected Luxury Rentals in Brooklyn
abstract: High-end housing continues to rise in untested markets, like an industrial section of Borough Park, Brooklyn, and a rough-edged corner of Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: An industrial section of Borough Park, Brooklyn, and a rough-edged corner of Williamsburg may not be the most obvious places to put up luxury housing. But high-end rental buildings are rising in both places, as developers continue to push into untested markets.

headline: High-End Brooklyn Rentals
abstract: Luxury housing continues to rise in untested markets, like an industrial section of Borough Park, Brooklyn, and a rough-edged corner of Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Luxury housing continues to rise in untested markets, like an industrial section of Borough Park, Brooklyn, and a rough-edged corner of Williamsburg.

headline: Personal Finance Book for Millennials Advises Starting With Lifestyle Goals
abstract: In “You Only Live Once,” the author Jason Vitug says starting financial planning with specifics can be a mistake, but he offers few details on how to achieve economic security.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to planning your financial future, you may be starting in the wrong place.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Turkish President Returns to Istanbul in Sign Military Coup Is Faltering
abstract: Vowing that faction leaders will “pay a heavy price,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan made a dramatic appearance after his supporters flooded the streets of Turkey’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A military coup attempt plunged Turkey into a long night of violence and intrigue on Friday, threatening its embattled president, leaving nearly 200 dead and injecting new instability into a crucial NATO member and American ally in the chaotic Middle East.

headline: John Varvatos and Todd Snyder Animate Men’s Fashion in New York
abstract: But the attack in Nice intrudes on a show meant to evoke the easy life in the South of France.
lead_paragraph: It was a Kellan Lutz season. The “Twilight” hunk popped up seemingly everywhere during New York Fashion Week: Men’s — a style Zelig. There he was at 9 a.m. on Tuesday, seated at a cafe table in a Chelsea restaurant that served as the setting for a Joseph Abboud show.

headline: What Is a Constant Cycle of Violent News Doing to Us?
abstract: Nothing good. Experts suggested limiting your exposure to violent imagery and social media.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rough year.

headline: Witnesses Describe Nice Attack
abstract: Witnesses tell of the attack in Nice that claimed the lives of at least 84 people on Thursday night after a truck barreled through a massive crowd.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses tell of the attack in Nice that claimed the lives of at least 84 people on Thursday night after a truck barreled through a massive crowd.

headline: Takata Settles Airbag Suit, Averting Testimony by Its Chief
abstract: The company had long resisted settling the case of Patricia Mincey of Florida, who was paralyzed after the airbag in her Honda Civic forcefully deployed.
lead_paragraph: The airbag maker Takata on Friday settled a closely watched lawsuit involving the injury and eventual death of a woman whose car crashed in 2014.

headline: Review: An Anemic Tribute to Tap Dance History
abstract: The main event of this year’s Tap City festival, at the Duke on 42nd Street, offered a deflating contrast to feats of dance masters of the past.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of “Tap Treasures,” at the Duke on 42nd Street on Thursday, the veteran hoofer Ted Levy announced that he had the honor of performing a tribute to the great and too-little-remembered John Bubbles. Before trying to reproduce part of a Bubbles routine from the 1937 film “Varsity Show,” Mr. Levy first recounted the unbelievable succession of wonders in the movie number, building up to his own sucker punch line: “This ain’t that show.”

headline: Review: Modern on the Rails Brings Italian to a 19th-Century Station
abstract: The Mamaroneck station, unused for travel for years, became home to Modern on the Rails in October.
lead_paragraph: Westchester County has some evocative old train stations, and the 19th-century brick beauty in Mamaroneck is among the loveliest. Unused for travel for years, it opened last October as the setting for Modern on the Rails, a new outpost of the beloved Modern restaurant in New Rochelle.

headline: More Coverage: Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: After a night of chaos and intrigue that left hundreds dead in a military coup, Turkey’s government rounded up thousands of military personnel, moving swiftly to re-establish control.

headline: Attack in Nice, France, Represents Terrorism’s New Reality
abstract: Populations targeted by terrorists confront a danger that can be managed or policed but perhaps never entirely overcome.
lead_paragraph: For all the years of worry that terrorists would develop more sophisticated methods, Thursday’s attack in Nice realized a fear that turned out to be far worse: a form of violence so crude that it renders many of our usual defenses useless.

headline: Gotta Catch ’Em All! New York’s Fashion Frenzy
abstract: Devon Halfnight LeFlufy’s high-end digital mélange abuts the beefcakes of Parke & Ronen at New York Fashion Week: Men’s.
lead_paragraph: Throughout New York, fans are racing to catch them all. It was inevitable they’d sneak into fashion week, too.

headline: A Podcast on Climate Science, Communication, Pokémon, the Presidency…
abstract: A weekly climate podcast in which a curious paleoecologist, worried meteorologist and gray-bearded environmental journalist discuss the end of the world as we knew it.
lead_paragraph: What happens when a podcast producer connects a climate-focused paleoecologist, a climate-freaked blogging meteorologist and a longtime climate journalist? You get “Warm Regards,” a weekly conversation on climate science, science communication and the challenging intersection of data and decisions (and, too often, indecision).

headline: Review: Common Lot, in Millburn, Is a Newcomer With a Global Touch
abstract: The restaurant, which has found a following just months after opening, comes from a husband-and-wife team with an international résumé.
lead_paragraph: Two visits to Common Lot, a new restaurant in Millburn, convinced me that Ehren Ryan, an owner and the executive chef, is among the most talented cooks in the state. By May, only eight weeks after it had opened, Common Lot was booked for every seating on Friday and Saturday nights through July, and the restaurant does not take reservations more than 60 days in advance.

headline: Missouri City to Pay $4.7 Million to Settle Suit Over Jailing Practices
abstract: Jennings, Mo., which borders Ferguson, has agreed to compensate nearly 2,000 people, many of them poor and black, who had been jailed for unpaid traffic fines and fees.
lead_paragraph: A small city bordering Ferguson, Mo., has agreed to pay $4.7 million to compensate nearly 2,000 people who spent time in the city’s jail for not paying fines and fees related to traffic and other relatively petty violations.

headline: Health Concerns for Estelle Parsons Prompt Early Closing of Play
abstract: “Out of the Mouth of Babes,” at the Cherry Lane Theater, had been scheduled through July 31, but the actress dropped out at the advice of her doctor.
lead_paragraph: An Off Broadway nonprofit theater this week abruptly ended the run of a play, citing the health of its Oscar-winning star, Estelle Parsons.

headline: Review: At 7T8 European Fusion in Northport, a Blended Menu
abstract: Chef Stephen Claussell’s offerings represent cuisine from different European countries, with some American dishes, too.
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone has heard of Asian fusion. But European fusion?

headline: How Killing of Prominent Separatist Set Off Turmoil in Kashmir
abstract: Kashmir is divided between India and Pakistan, and Indian-administered Kashmir has long been plagued by the aftershocks of an armed insurgency in the late 1980s.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Thousands of protesters thronged streets in towns across the Kashmir valley on July 9, the first of days of clashes with security officers. The violence was among the worst in the restive region in years, leaving more than 30 people dead, including a police officer, and thousands injured. Most of the deaths were protesters shot by security forces, and hospitals were crowded with wounded civilians. Protesters  attacked police vehicles, security posts and other government property.

headline: Review: At the Country Bistro, the Feel of Vacation
abstract: The restaurant has evolved from a breakfast and lunch spot to one that serves dinner as well.
lead_paragraph: On a recent dinner visit to the Country Bistro in Salisbury, the hostess led me to a table by the oriel window, where a hula skirt was the centerpiece of a seaside-themed display.

headline: Scenes From the Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: A group within the Turkish military attempted a coup on Friday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A group within the Turkish military attempted a coup on Friday, officials said.

headline: Heard of ‘Aureliano in Palmira’? You Probably Know the Overture
abstract: This 1813 opera seria by Rossini — part of which was recycled in a more famous comedy — will have its American premiere at Caramoor on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Most opera buffs can whistle the overture to Rossini’s “Aureliano in Palmira,” even if they’ve never heard of the work, which is rarely performed.

headline: Will Mike Pence Satisfy the Insatiable Right?
abstract: Trump presumably thought Pence would please Christian conservatives. But not all of them are happy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump can be a lot of things: outrageous, bigoted, mercurial, funny, unthinking and relentless. But in this long presidential campaign he has not been dull — until, that is, he selected Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana as his running mate.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Ben Hubbard, Nicholas Kulish and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Travis Mills, Ryan Reynolds and Michael B. Jordan Party at Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: Parties hosted by Esquire, Piaget and John Varvatos capped off the week’s festivities.
lead_paragraph: Parties hosted by Esquire, Piaget and John Varvatos capped off the week’s festivities.

headline: After Hours During Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: Travis Mills, Ryan Reynolds, Michael B. Jordan and Kellan Lutz were among the celebrities spotted during the fashion week’s parties.
lead_paragraph: Pockets of well-groomed men were spotted throughout the city last week, dashing from one party to the next. There were after-parties hosted by designers, kale salad dinners hosted by magazine editors, and corporate brands like Amazon Fashion, Cadillac and Piaget jockeying for attention. In other words, New York Fashion Week: Men’s, which concluded its third season on Thursday, is settling into its groove.

headline: David Margolis, a Justice Department Institution, Dies at 76
abstract: Known for a sharp legal mind and unpredictable attire, Mr. Margolis over 50 years led some of the nation’s biggest mobster and espionage investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Margolis, a brash and revered prosecutor who in more than 50 years at the Justice Department helped it navigate through some of its most difficult chapters, died on Tuesday in Falls Church, Va. He was 76.

headline: 46 Things to Do in Cleveland During the G.O.P. Convention
abstract: A guide to easily reachable ways to eat, drink and play (beyond the security perimeter).
lead_paragraph: The 50,000 officials, delegates, journalists, protesters and gawkers expected to head to Cleveland during the Republican National Convention will encounter extra-tight security around the Quicken Loans Arena, known locally as the Q, where the main event takes place from July 18 through July 21.

headline: Review: Stacy Sullivan Performs an Act of Remembrance
abstract: Ms. Sullivan’s thrilling show “A Night at the Troubadour” recalls the work of David Ackles, who performed with Elton John at Mr. John’s American debut.
lead_paragraph: Who remembers David Ackles, the American singer-songwriter whose promising career was upended by a premature flood of hype when one well-meaning critic compared his 1972 album, “American Gothic,” to “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band”? The backlash was immediate and devastating. Mr. Ackles’s career lost its momentum.

headline: Faces in the Crowd at New York Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: Some of the best looks from New York Fashion Week: Men’s could be seen on the street.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week: Men’s wrapped up on Thursday, but the show continued as models and showgoers took their top looks to the streets.

headline: Tracy Tynan’s Costume Drama
abstract: In “Wear and Tear,” a wardrobe designer reflects on her out-sized parents, her roller-coaster youth and the comfort she found in fashion.
lead_paragraph: “Wear and Tear: The Threads of My Life,” by Tracy Tynan. Scribner, 320 pp., $25.

headline: Tumult in Turkey: The Key Players
abstract: About four hours after an apparent coup attempt by a faction of military forces in Turkey, the movement appeared to be faltering.
lead_paragraph: A faction of military forces in Turkey attempted a coup on Friday night, but within a few hours it appeared to be faltering. Here is a list of the key players involved in, or held responsible for, the night’s events.

headline: Turkey, Nice, Presidential Race: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In France, the Mood Darkens as a Harsh Reality Sets In
abstract: In an aftermath different from those in previous attacks, ordinary citizens and political opposition leaders after the Nice episode questioned whether enough had been done to protect the country.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Twice before in the past year and a half, the French people and their leaders had faced devastating attacks with a remarkable spirit of unity and resilience. On Friday, as the country woke up to the slaughter in Nice, the mood was different.

headline: Apple, in Seeming Jab at Spotify, Proposes Simpler Songwriting Royalties
abstract: Apple proposed that streaming services pay 9.1 cents for every 100 plays of a song. That would significantly increase what its rival Spotify pays.
lead_paragraph: In the music industry’s streaming battles, the fight extends to even the minutiae of copyright.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Asperger’s Are Us Comedy Troupe Jokes About Everything but That
abstract: Members of this group came together because of their shared condition, but that’s not the point.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Audiences don’t usually know what to expect from Asperger’s Are Us, a Boston sketch comedy troupe made up solely of artists on the autism spectrum. Will they use self-deprecating humor about life with Asperger’s syndrome? Are they hoping to shed light on a serious condition? Will they be something like Sheldon, the socially inept character on CBS’s “The Big Bang Theory”?

headline: World Pays Tribute to Nice Victims
abstract: Victims of the terror attack on Bastille Day were honored on Friday in Nice, Paris, Rome, New York and Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Victims of the terror attack on Bastille Day were honored on Friday in Nice, Paris, Rome, New York and Moscow.

headline: Pro-Government Forces Advance in Syria Amid Talk of U.S.-Russia Cooperation
abstract: Civilians are dying from lack of food and medical care as the Syrian government tightens sieges and increases airstrikes in Aleppo and outside Damascus.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In Moscow on Friday, Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia laid bunches of flowers in memory of the victims of the truck attack in Nice, France, then spent hours debating proposals for new cooperation in Syria.

headline: To Calm His Jittery Nerves, Keegan Bradley Embraces Them
abstract: Amid a slump that can be measured in years, Bradley, the winner of the 2011 P.G.A. Championship, has learned to accept anxiety and has found himself back on the leaderboard.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — On Monday, several days before the start of the 2016 British Open at Royal Troon, Keegan Bradley and a couple of his golf buddies surreptitiously scaled the giant yellow scoreboard perched atop the sprawling grandstand at the 18th green. Bradley and his companions, whom he did not name, did a bit of dreaming.

headline: A Lesson for Newt Gingrich: What Shariah Is (and Isn’t)
abstract: His proposal for a religious inquisition is rife with misunderstanding.
lead_paragraph: FORTUNATELY, no one is going to follow Newt Gingrich’s unconstitutional and un-American plan for an inquisition to “test every person here who is of a Muslim background” and deport the ones who “believe in Shariah.” Even Mr. Gingrich himself, a day after suggesting this policy in the wake of the terrorist attack in Nice, France, conceded that such a plan was impossible. But his proposal is a reminder of a persistent and inexcusable misunderstanding of what Shariah is, both in theory and in practice.

headline: ‘There’s Something That’s Not Right. Someone Lost Control of Their Truck.’
abstract: Survivors of the attack in Nice, France, describe a windy night at the beach, fireworks, and then terror.
lead_paragraph: Survivors of the attack in Nice, France, describe a windy night at the beach, fireworks, and then terror.

headline: Makers of Humira and Enbrel Using New Drug Patents to Delay Generic Versions
abstract: Six years after the Affordable Care Act cleared the way for biosimilars, as the generic versions of biotechnology drugs are called, progress has been slow.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling drugs Humira and Enbrel have a lot in common. They both use biotechnology to treat rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis and other autoimmune diseases. And they come with giant price tags approaching $50,000 a year.

headline: Can We Just "Live With" Terrorism?
abstract: Were the French premier's words defeatist or a recognition of  the need for a democracy to live freely?

headline: Our Best Defense Against Terrorists
abstract: In responding to attacks, democratic nations should be careful not to forget their ideals.
lead_paragraph: How we react to terrorism has become a measure of who we are, as individuals and as a society. It is not clear yet whether the heinous massacre in Nice, France, was the work of a “lone wolf” or a terrorist network, but in a way it doesn’t matter. Each new attack, each new convulsion of fear, horror, grief and anger is a progressively greater test of enlightened civilization’s commitment to its core values.

headline: Sally Beauman, Author Whose Advance Set a Record, Dies at 71
abstract: Ms. Beauman was unknown in the publishing world when her steamy romance novel, “Destiny,” sold for more than $1 million.
lead_paragraph: Sally Beauman, a British journalist and romance novelist whose first book under her own name, the steamy “Destiny” (1987), drew an advance of more than $1 million, then a record for an unknown author, died on July 7 in Northern England. She was 71.

headline: A Second Round That Jordan Spieth Would Rather Forget
abstract: Spieth, who narrowly missed winning his third straight major at last year’s British Open, barely made the cut after a round plagued by wind and rain.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — One year ago, Jordan Spieth left the British Open having just barely missed an opportunity to win three major tournaments in a row. This year, Spieth very nearly had to leave after just two rounds.

headline: The Times on the Air: France’s Fresh Grief, Dallas’s Healing and More
abstract: Highlights from television and radio interviews featuring reporters and editors from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. Below are highlights from television and radio interviews featuring Times reporters and editors.

headline: Funeral for Alton Sterling Is an Expression of Grief and Anger
abstract: Politicians and religious leaders joined family and friends at a 7,500-seat arena to mourn the man fatally shot by Baton Rouge police.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — They called Alton B. Sterling “the CD Man” and “Big Boy;” he was a 37-year-old father of five who sold bootleg music in front of a neighborhood convenience store.

headline: U.S. and Russia Agree on Steps to Combat ISIS in Syria
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry reached a tentative deal in Moscow but did not list the terms of the agreement.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The United States and Russia announced a tentative deal on Friday to coordinate airstrikes against the Islamic State and the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria.

headline: In Ex-Fox Anchor Harassment Case, Accusations of ‘Judge Shopping’
abstract: Lawyers for Roger Ailes, Fox News chairman, want the case heard in federal court in Manhattan, not New Jersey. Both sides accused the other of seeking a more favorable venue.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Fox News chairman, Roger Ailes, are looking to transfer a sexual harassment lawsuit filed by the former anchor Gretchen Carlson to a New York federal court, a move her lawyers immediately dismissed as “judge shopping.”

headline: Chris Christie Lost Out on the Job He Wanted. And His Bad Year Got Worse.
abstract: The New Jersey governor, who hoped to be Donald J. Trump’s running mate, saw his political fortunes crash after backing Mr. Trump in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: “Black Thursday,” one of Gov. Chris Christie’s least favorite local newspaper columnists called it, under a headline that declared it his “worst day ever.” At the least, it was the New Jersey governor’s terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

headline: Can We Stop Terror-by-Truck?
abstract: The Nice attack shows how the West has lost its focus against ISIS, and what it needs to do to win.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S terror-by-truck attack in Nice, France, was shocking in its outcome — 84 people killed and hundreds injured — but not in its methods. Jihadis have long called on sympathizers to transform everyday vehicles into instruments of mass slaughter.

headline: The Wrong Way to Count Prisoners
abstract: By including inmates in the population of the place where they are held, the Census Bureau is unfairly giving some voters more political power.
lead_paragraph: Voting rights advocates have been pressing the Census Bureau for more than a decade to stop counting prison inmates as “residents” of prisons — where they typically remain for only a short time — instead of the communities they call home. The bureau, in a rejection of common sense and fairness, has proposed rules for the 2020 census that continue this discredited practice.

headline: Donald Trump and Mike Pence, Republicans as Different as Night and Day
abstract: Mr. Trump and the Indiana governor differ on some issues and are dissimilar religiously and temperamentally, creating a challenge for Mr. Pence to conform.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, who has a weakness for impromptu stops at county fairs, took his future — and still only — wife ice-skating on their first date and is serious enough about his faith that he regularly meets with a small group of men who hold one another accountable to Christian principles.

headline: The Four Seasons: A Most American Experience
abstract: The famous restaurant wasn’t just about status and power.
lead_paragraph: MY introduction to the Four Seasons restaurant, when I was in my 20s, came courtesy of Alexander Liberman, then the editorial director of the Condé Nast magazines and my boss (though to say he was my boss is like calling Barack Obama the boss of your local postmaster). I was a kid from Pittsburgh in love with New York as the capital of wit and style, neither of which I possessed, though I was hoping I could acquire them. I can only assume that he took me to the Four Seasons because he thought it was something I needed to experience.

headline: Eliot Spitzer Sues Woman Who Accused Him of Assault
abstract: The former New York governor alleges that he is subject of an expanding extortion attempt by Svetlana Andreevna Zakharova.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York has filed a lawsuit against a Russian woman who accused him of an assault at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan this year, alleging that he is the subject of an extended and expanding attempt at extortion.

headline: Alaskans Brace for Spending Cuts as Oil Prices Tumble
abstract: Nearly $1.3 billion in cuts by Gov. Bill Walker mean that people will receive less money from the state every month, and public schools will receive less aid.
lead_paragraph: The impact of falling oil prices in Alaska, which has seemed for many residents like a distant worry until now, is about to land. The turning point came on Friday, when the State House of Representatives, meeting at the Capitol in Juneau in the fifth special session since last summer, failed to override a line-item veto of the budget by Gov. Bill Walker.

headline: In Truck Attack in Nice, Mainstay of Commerce Reinvented as Tool of Death
abstract: The rampage opened a frightening new landscape of terrorism, using a weapon that is ubiquitous on roads in the United States and was encouraged by Al Qaeda years ago.
lead_paragraph: More than five years ago, Al Qaeda called on its followers to use cars as tools of terror. Soon after, the terrorist group that had brought down the twin towers scrapped the idea, feeling that the tactic was too indiscriminate, too likely to kill Muslims.

headline: Trump Wants War Declared on ISIS and ‘Extreme Vetting’ of Immigrants
abstract: The statements strike the same chords of hostility and suspicion toward Muslims and immigrants that are at the heart of Mr. Trump’s appeal to many voters.
lead_paragraph: Within four hours of the attack on the French Riviera, Donald J. Trump pledged to seek a rare declaration of war from Congress against Islamic terrorists and called for “extreme vetting” of immigrants and a complete ban on those from “terrorist nations.”

headline: A Surly Misfit With No Terror Links Turned a Truck Into a Tank
abstract: The suspect in the rampage that killed 84 people in Nice had run-ins with the law but no record of radicalization, and left no declaration of a motive.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — He lived on the 12th floor of a high rise in a heavily immigrant housing project and was known to his neighbors only as a moody and aggressive oddball. He never went to the local mosque, often grunted in response to greetings of “bonjour” and sometimes beat his wife — until she threw him out.

headline: Julian Schnabel on Hector Babenco, His Movies and Their Friendship
abstract: Hector Babenco’s “Pixote” had a major influence on Julian Schnabel. The artist and filmmaker explains why.
lead_paragraph: The conversation was never over. We would just take up where we left off. That’s the way it was with Hector. (That is, Hector Babenco, the director who died on Wednesday.) He was always ready, always in the process of doing, about to do, just getting finished, and getting ready to start the continuum of what was next in his lifelong pursuit of making film and telling stories that were all part of the same thing: his desire to describe life below the Equator.

headline: Muhammad Wilkerson and the Jets Reach a Long-Term Deal
abstract: The veteran defensive end signed a five-year extension after a stalemate that lasted over two years.
lead_paragraph: The Jets have been saying that they want to re-sign Muhammad Wilkerson, and Wilkerson has been saying that he wants to re-sign with the team. But it took a deadline for the sides to set aside their differences and reach a long-term extension.

headline: Man Arrested in San Diego in Killings of Homeless People
abstract: A string of attacks in early July put many homeless people on edge, and set off a debate on how to deal with the city’s exploding homeless population.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Calif. — For those sleeping under freeways and in back alleys, the threat of violence is nearly constant.

headline: Professors, Stop Opining About Trump
abstract: Academic expertise does not entail political wisdom.
lead_paragraph: PROFESSORS are at it again, demonstrating in public how little they understand the responsibilities and limits of their profession.

headline: K2’s Sudden Surge Tests New York Authorities
abstract: After 33 people overdosed on what authorities suspected was the synthetic street drug, a police crackdown failed to seize even a single packet of K2.
lead_paragraph: The police raids around a gritty Brooklyn intersection were meant to show that city officials were taking charge after 33 people had been stricken by suspected overdoses of K2. But the spectacle, captured by a crush of news media, came up all but empty, without a single packet of the drug seized.

headline: Mets Still Tending to Their Wounds as They Make Push for Playoffs
abstract: The team has a careful balancing act ahead as it tries to stay in playoff contention, relying on young starters who have been plagued by injuries.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Nearly five hours before Friday’s game, Citizens Bank Park was full of action. Mets pitchers played catch on the field or threw in the bullpen. Infielders took grounders, and outfielders chased down fly balls. The second half of the season had begun, and the Mets — mostly rested, partly battered — were easing back into action.

headline: Struggling Yankees Face a Reckoning Out of the All-Star Break
abstract: A challenging stretch of games could determine whether the team becomes a buyer or a seller as the non-waiver trade deadline approaches.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the Chicago Cubs followed a sweep of the defending champion Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park with a win at Washington. The Cubs were in last place, but they were on the fringe of the wild-card race, seven and a half games back in early July. For the first time in Starlin Castro’s career there was hope.

headline: Balance Sheets
abstract: Do you have what it takes to crush this Saturday puzzle by Byron Walden?
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Speaking of YOGA MATS and “Balance Sheets?”, let’s talk about balance. And stay tuned, because we have some notes from puzzlemaster Will Shortz after the post.

headline: Donations Slow for New York’s Politicians, According to Reports
abstract: New York politicians are reporting low fund-raising figures in the latest declarations.
lead_paragraph: Fund-raising declarations filed by New York politicians and their allies on Friday were perhaps most notable for what they did not contain.

headline: U.S. Finds Itself on Shakier Ground as Erdogan Confronts Mutiny
abstract: Even though the coup attempt appeared to be failing by early Saturday morning in Turkey, the country has suddenly become another tumultuous one in a region that knows no end of turmoil.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With all the crises in the Middle East, the Obama administration took solace in the fact that there was one reliable, democratically elected strongman — a stalwart member of NATO — that Washington could depend on: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.

headline: Judy Feiffer, Who Helped Develop Two Top Memoirs, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Feiffer urged Maya Angelou to write “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” and worked with Christina Crawford on “Mommie Dearest.”
lead_paragraph: Judy Feiffer, a photographer, novelist and book editor who fostered best-selling memoirs by two fledgling authors, “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” by Maya Angelou and “Mommie Dearest” by Christina Crawford, died on June 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Xu Jiatun, Chinese Official Who Opposed Tiananmen Crackdown, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Xu, who was expelled from the Communist Party, fled to the United States in 1990.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Xu Jiatun, a senior Communist Party official who opposed the Chinese military’s suppression of the pro-democracy demonstrations around Tiananmen Square in 1989 and fled to the United States the following year, died on June 29 in Chino Hills, Calif. He was 100.

headline: Gregg Smith, Choral Leader Who Elevated Standards, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Smith founded the Gregg Smith Singers in 1955 when he was still a graduate student and most choruses were made up of amateur singers.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Smith, a choral conductor and composer whose ensemble, the Gregg Smith Singers, established new standards for professional choral singing and championed the work of contemporary American composers in performance and on recordings, died on Tuesday in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: Arrest Warrants Issued for Former Atlanta Officer in Driver’s Death
abstract: The former officer, James Burns, faces charges of murder and assault with a deadly weapon in the fatal shooting of Devaris Caine Rogers in June.
lead_paragraph: Arrest warrants have been issued for a former Atlanta police officer who has been charged with murder in the shooting death of a black driver in June, an official said on Friday.

headline: Stephen Strasburg Improves to 13-0
abstract: Strasburg allowed one run and three hits in eight innings, tying his longest start of the season for the Washington Nationals.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Strasburg threw eight masterful innings and bunted in a run, Michael Taylor hit a two-run homer that broke the game open, and host Washington beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-1, in its first game after the All-Star break.

headline: Rubens Provides an Upbeat Close to London Auction Season
abstract: “Lot and His Daughters” shows there’s life left yet in the old masters game.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Biblical story of how Lot’s daughters seduced their father to sustain the family gene pool after escaping the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah might not seem the most obviously commercial theme for an artwork.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: “Straight Outta Compton,” F. Gary Gray’s gangster-rapper chronicle, moves to cable. And Will Smith plays Dr. Bennet Omalu in “Concussion.”
lead_paragraph: F. Gary Gray chronicles the rise of the gangster rappers N.W.A in “Straight Outta Compton,” now on cable. Will Smith plays Dr. Bennet Omalu, who pushed the N.F.L. to admit the truth behind head injuries, in “Concussion.” And Bret Baier reports on what to expect at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, July 16, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Why Nice? Because it is a city that is known worldwide, one of the most beautiful cities on the planet. Why on the 14th of July? Because it is a celebration of freedom.”

headline: Tumult in Turkey: What We Know and Don’t Know
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the coup plotters would “pay a heavy price.” The prime minister said 265 people had been killed and more than 2,800 military personnel had been detained.
lead_paragraph: Military forces in Turkey attempted a coup on Friday, plunging the country into a long night of violence and intrigue. Hundreds of people were killed, and the embattled president’s location was unknown for hours. He later emerged, and by Saturday morning, the coup appeared to be unraveling.

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, July 16, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: ‘We Are a World Awash in Weapons and Grievances’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss the attempted military coup in Turkey, the terrorist attack in Nice, France, playing Pokémon Go and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Donald Trump’s Deals Rely on Being Creative With the Truth
abstract: Over the span of his career, project after project has produced allegations of bad faith, broken promises, blatant lies or outright fraud.
lead_paragraph: There was the time Donald J. Trump told Larry King that he had been paid more than $1 million to give a speech about his business acumen when in fact he was paid $400,000. Or the time he sought a bank loan claiming a net worth of $3.5 billion in 2004, four times as much as what the bank found when it checked his math. Or the time he boasted that membership to Trump National Golf Club in Westchester County, N.Y., cost $300,000 when the actual initiation fee was $200,000. Or the time he bragged on CNBC about his new Trump International Hotel and Tower in Las Vegas, claiming, “We have 1,282 units, and they sold out in less than a week.” As Mr. Trump knew, more than 300 units had not been sold.

headline: When Yahoo Ruled the Valley: Stories of the Original ‘Surfers’
abstract: As Yahoo puts itself on the auction block, some of its first employees revisit their youth spent building a company that defined the early web.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Back in the mid-1990s, before Google even existed, the world’s best guides to the internet sat in Silicon Valley cubicles, visiting websites and carefully categorizing them by hand.

headline: Exhibit: 2026
abstract: An idealized vision of black masculinity 10 years into the future.
lead_paragraph: An idealized vision of black masculinity 10 years into the future.

headline: Breaking Men’s Wear Barriers — in 2026
abstract: A photography exhibition in London challenges gender and racial stereotypes with a utopian fashion vision for the future.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The young black man stands defiantly on the grass in front of the tin-roof bungalow, separated from the house via a pastel-colored fence and a dusty sidewalk that cracked long ago under the searing African heat.

headline: Childhood Tales From the Chelsea Hotel
abstract: A precocious 17-year-old, described as a “bohemian Eloise,” writes a memoir of her coming-of-age.
lead_paragraph: Like many an only child, Nicolaia Rips grew up largely in the company of adults. While other Manhattan youngsters were being herded into Mommy and Me classes and the soccer leagues at Pier 40, Ms. Rips, who grew up in the Chelsea Hotel, was spending her afternoons with the unruly oddballs on West 23rd Street.

headline: ISIS Claims Truck Attacker in France Was Its ‘Soldier’
abstract: Officials said the attacker, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, may have “radicalized himself very quickly.” Four of his acquaintances have been detained.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — The Islamic State claimed on Saturday that the man who attacked the seaside city of Nice was one of the group’s “soldiers.” France’s defense minister promptly blamed the terrorist network for inspiring the assault, while its top law enforcement official said the attacker, who was not previously known to intelligence agencies, may have “radicalized himself very quickly.”

headline: Not Forgotten: John F. Kennedy Jr.: A Life Under a Microscope, Cut Short
abstract: John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr. was as close to a prince du sang as an American can be, and like his father he came to an untimely and tragic end.
lead_paragraph: John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr. was as close to a prince du sang as an American can be, and like his father he came to an untimely and tragic end.

headline: Turkey Moves to Regain Control
abstract: As a chaotic night gave way to morning, soldiers who had taken part in an attempted coup surrendered as the government worked to re-establish control.
lead_paragraph: As a chaotic night gave way to morning, soldiers who had taken part in an attempted coup surrendered as the government worked to re-establish control.

headline: Turkey Rounds Up Thousands of Military Personnel
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government moved swiftly to re-establish control after the failure of the attempted coup.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s government, rallying behind its defiant leader, rounded up thousands of military personnel on Saturday who were said to have taken part in an attempted coup, moving swiftly to re-establish control after a night of chaos and intrigue that left hundreds dead.

headline: Gabby Douglas Seeks to Rebound From Her Olympic Stardom
abstract: Douglas will attend a pre-Olympics training camp as she attempts to refocus her career in order to defend her all-around title at the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — To start her final push to the Rio Olympics, Gabby Douglas — the defending Olympic gymnastics champion in the all-around — will pack her bags and head to the Sam Houston National Forest, about 65 miles north of Houston, for a nine-day boot camp.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from a funeral in Dallas to a stable in East Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from a funeral in Dallas to a stable in East Jerusalem.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: One Game to Rule Them All
abstract: Tech leaders oppose Donald J. Trump, a privacy verdict favors Microsoft and Pokémon Go gets tens of millions to play in the streets.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Donald Trump Delivers a Long, Passionate Speech. He Introduces Mike Pence, Too.
abstract: Mr. Trump’s introduction of Mr. Pence as his running mate was a remarkable reminder that, ultimately, the Trump campaign is about one person.
lead_paragraph: If ever there was a moment for Donald J. Trump to share the spotlight, his formal announcement of his running mate on Saturday was it.

headline: Keeping Bedbugs at Bay
abstract: Avoiding an infestation, spending a co-op’s funds and dealing with leftover furniture.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, my daughter bought a townhouse. Soon after she moved in, she had an infestation of bedbugs, which she treated. When my daughter asked the next-door neighbors if they had bedbugs, they said no. But my daughter’s exterminator saw evidence of an infestation on items left at the curb in front of their house. Just a few weeks ago, my daughter again saw furniture on the curb in front of the neighbor’s house. If the problem has returned, there is no guarantee that the neighbor will treat it. Does my daughter have any recourse? How can she keep the infestation from spreading to her house?

headline: China Cites Negligence as Cause of Landslide That Killed 73
abstract: A seven-month investigation concluded that a mountain of construction debris in Shenzhen collapsed in December after shoddy oversight and the improper storage of waste.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A landslide of dirt and construction debris that killed 73 people in the city of Shenzhen in December was caused by negligence and the improper storage of waste at a huge dump site, the Chinese government has concluded after a seven-month investigation.

headline: Donald Trump and Mike Pence: Highlights
abstract: Mr. Trump and Mr. Pence appeared for the first time in public together since Mr. Pence was named as Mr. Trump’s running mate. Here’s how we analyzed it.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump and Mr. Pence appeared for the first time in public together since Mr. Pence was named as Mr. Trump’s running mate. Here’s how we analyzed it.

headline: A Lifelong Tinkerer Who’s Taking Robots to the People
abstract: Chetan Kapoor, director of technology for Yaskawa Innovation, is helping make industrial robots that accept simple commands instead of complex code.
lead_paragraph: Chetan Kapoor, 47, is director of technology at Yaskawa Innovation in Austin, Tex.

headline: Paying With Cash Hurts. That’s Also Why It Feels So Good.
abstract: New research finds that spending cash is more painful than using cards. But that same sting makes people feel that their purchases are more valuable.
lead_paragraph: Paying with cash is painful — and that’s a good thing, according to new research.

headline: Spotify and Apple Music: The Goth vs. the Stoner
abstract: The perfect music streaming service, the Haggler writes, would be Spotify without the ghoulish user interface, combined with a clearheaded Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, we depart from the familiar letter-and-intervention format for a dive into the world of music streaming services. It is a topic that fascinates the Haggler, who can still barely fathom that for a mere $10 a month, he can get access to just about any musical recording on the planet.

headline: An Unfinished Bridge, and Partnership, Between Russia and China
abstract: The nations’ leaders are close, but the faltering project highlights a problem in their collaboration: elaborate plans, with little follow-through.
lead_paragraph: NIZHNELENINSKOYE, Russia — Trumpeted for the past decade as an emblem of Russia’s destiny as an Asian as well as a European power, the huge steel bridge thrusts out from the Chinese side of the Amur River, stretching more than a mile across the turbid waters that divide the world’s most populous nation from its biggest.

headline: A Secret Life With the Misfit Toys
abstract: A high school sophomore’s part-time job at an offbeat toy store taught her how to embrace life’s strange characters, leading to a career in journalism.
lead_paragraph: During my sophomore year of high school, my parents gave me a choice: Play an after-school sport or get a job. In the end, it came down to vanity. After six long, terrible, socially exiled years of wearing braces on my teeth, the idea of dodging lacrosse, field hockey or tennis balls did not appeal to me. Employment seemed a reasonable act of self-preservation.

headline: Eggs That Clear the Cages, but Maybe Not the Conscience
abstract: The country’s biggest food companies are embracing cage-free eggs, but hens raised in aviaries may not be much healthier than their caged counterparts.
lead_paragraph: American hens produce more than 83 billion eggs a year. Most hens — more than 285 million in all — are housed in cages not much bigger than a shoe box. Stuck in one of these so-called battery cages, a hen might live her whole life without seeing the sunlight, let alone stretching her wings.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop returns with Split Decisions.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — You know the drill here and, if you’re just joining us, give this change-of-pace puzzle a try.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of July 15
abstract: Bernie Sanders endorsed Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump picked Gov. Mike Pence as his running mate and preparations continued for next week’s Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders endorsed Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump picked Gov. Mike Pence as his running mate and preparations continued for next week’s Republican National Convention.

headline: As Turkey Coup Unfolded, ‘the Whole Night Felt Like Doomsday’
abstract: Thousands of soldiers and officers were purged from the military as the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sought to assert control.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Thousands of soldiers and officers purged from the military. A helicopter shot down over the capital. Hundreds of people lying dead on city streets.

headline: Philando Castile Was Pulled Over 49 Times in 13 Years, Often for Minor Infractions
abstract: Mr. Castile’s death from a police shooting during a traffic stop is seen by many as an illustration of the disproportionate risks black motorists face.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Turning into a parking lot without signaling. Failing to repair a broken seatbelt. Driving at night with an unlit license plate. Driving with tinted windows.

headline: At Royal Troon, the Bunkers Bury the Best
abstract: The 98 bunkers, including the Coffin bunker, are the star features of the course where the British Open is being played.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — In Thursday’s first round of the 145th British Open, Bubba Watson’s tee shot landed in the Coffin bunker alongside the par-3 eighth hole at Royal Troon.

headline: A Grounded Plane and Anti-Clinton Passion: How Mike Pence Swayed the Trumps
abstract: When mechanical problems stranded Donald J. Trump in Indiana, the state’s governor seized the opportunity with an impassioned monologue.
lead_paragraph: When mechanical problems grounded Donald J. Trump’s private plane on Tuesday night in Indiana, Gov. Mike Pence seized the opportunity.

headline: Turkey Wakes Up to Aftermath of a Coup
abstract: A failed coup attempt on Friday night has gripped Turkey. By Saturday morning, thousands of soldiers had been detained, accused of trying to overthrow the government, and civilians were left in a state of unease.
lead_paragraph: A failed coup attempt on Friday night has gripped Turkey. By Saturday morning, thousands of soldiers had been detained, accused of trying to overthrow the government, and civilians were left in a state of unease.

headline: Donald Trump the Political Showman, Born on ‘The Apprentice’
abstract: On the reality show that Donald Trump began hosting in 2004, he displayed the showmanship and other traits that have come to define his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: He hounded network executives at all hours, demanding Nielsen reports and asking: “How’d we do? How’d we do?”

headline: The Counter-Coup in Turkey
abstract: The fallout from a failed coup is likely to undercut Turkey’s democracy and the fight against ISIS.
lead_paragraph: It was ironic that, as members of the military launched a coup against him on Friday night, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey resorted to guerrilla media tactics — broadcasting via the FaceTime app on his cellphone — to urge Turks to oppose the plotters. Mr. Erdogan has been no friend to free expression, ruthlessly asserting control over the media and restricting human rights and free speech. Yet thousands responded to his appeal, turning back the rebels and demonstrating that they still value democracy even if Mr. Erdogan has eroded its meaning.

headline: At Least 88 Cities Have Had Protests in the Past 13 Days Over Police Killings of Blacks
abstract: A day-by-day look at photographs from the protests.
lead_paragraph: A day-by-day look at photographs from the protests.

headline: What Travelers Need to Know About Turkey
abstract: A coup attempt in turkey has left 265 dead, many injured and has caused chaos in the country. Here’s information for travelers and their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: An attempted coup in Turkey has left 265 dead, 1,440 wounded and chaos in its wake. Here’s what travelers need to know about how to stay safe there, including updates on flights.

headline: Donald Trump Portrayed as a Poor Role Model for Children
abstract: A commercial from Hillary Clinton’s campaign, timed to coincide with the Republican National Convention, shows young viewers soaking up Mr. Trump’s R-rated remarks.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton campaign is continuing to focus its negative advertising efforts on provocative remarks made by Donald J. Trump, this time in a commercial that invites adults to imagine what a child might be learning from his campaign.

headline: Turkey’s Coup That Wasn’t
abstract: A failed coup in Turkey does not mean democracy is the winner. In fact Erdogan may now undermine democracy further.
lead_paragraph: As coups go, the Turkish effort was a study in ineptitude: No serious attempt to capture or muzzle the political leadership, no leader ready to step in, no communication strategy (or even awareness of social media), no ability to mobilize a critical mass within either the armed forces or society. In their place a platoon of hapless soldiers on a bridge in Istanbul and the apparently uncoordinated targeting of a few government buildings in Ankara.

headline: Qandeel Baloch, Pakistani Social Media Celebrity, Dead in Apparent Honor Killing
abstract: Qandeel Baloch, a controversial figure on social media in Pakistan, was strangled on Friday night. The police have arrested her brother in connection with the case.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Qandeel Baloch, a Pakistani social media sensation, was strangled by her brother in central Pakistan, police officials said Saturday, in what appears to have been a so-called honor killing.

headline: We’re Helping Deport Kids to Die
abstract: A hypocritical U.S. policy puts Central American refugees back into danger.
lead_paragraph: TAPACHULA, Mexico — Elena was 11 years old when a gang member in her home country, Honduras, told her to be his girlfriend.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Citrusy Mystery of Trump’s Hair
abstract: For a gauge of his temper, gaze at his tresses.
lead_paragraph: WATCHING Donald Trump on TV early last week, I got a shock. He read from a teleprompter. He sounded like a statesman — well, sort of. He kept the boasting to a minimum. He held the taunts in check.

headline: Can We Find Our Way Back to Lincoln?
abstract: The struggle for the nomination is over, but the struggle for the soul of the party is not.
lead_paragraph: FOR my entire adult life I have listened to the invective leveled against the Republican Party by liberals: It is a party sustained by racist appeals, composed of haters and conspiracy nuts, indifferent to the plight of the poor and the weak, anti-woman.

headline: Pool of Thought
abstract: Why I get all my best ideas in the water.
lead_paragraph: THERE is no drug — recreational or prescription — capable of inducing the tranquil euphoria brought on by swimming. I do all my best thinking in the pool, whether I’m trying to figure out how to treat a patient’s complicated ailment or write a paper. Why that is is mysterious, but I have a theory.

headline: Riders Get Little Room for Fashion at Tour de France
abstract: Rules and sponsors define much of the style in cycling, leaving shades and socks as the best sources of sartorial self-expression.
lead_paragraph: PONT ST. ESPRIT, France — While few people question mandatory helmets in professional cycling and sunglasses are unlikely to disappear any time soon, the combination has an unfortunate side effect. From a distance, most of the riders at the Tour de France have become as indistinguishable as the storm troopers commanded by Darth Vader.

headline: Attack in France Fuels Anti-Immigrant Parties on Europe’s Right
abstract: The killing in Nice came at a time of political flux and gives populist movements and the far right new opportunities to press their case.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The devastating attack in Nice, carried out by a Tunisian man living in France, came at a moment of political ferment in Europe and seems likely to give even more fuel to anti-immigrant, anti-Muslim movements that are challenging established parties across the region.

headline: Spanish Archive Raises Franco-Era Ghosts and Shadows of a New Chasm
abstract: Eighty years after the Spanish Civil War began, the return of family documents kept by the government shows that the consequences continue to ripple through Spain.
lead_paragraph: SANT CUGAT DEL VALLÈS, Spain — Monday marks 80 years since the uprising led by Gen. Francisco Franco plunged Spain into civil war. But Pere Bartolomé, 93, says he can still remember the day Franco’s soldiers ransacked his village, confiscating family booklets and photos.

headline: Turkey Interrupts U.S. Air Missions Against ISIS at Major Base
abstract: A Pentagon spokesman said United States officials were “working with the Turks to resume air operations there as soon as possible.”
