lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Turkish authorities on Saturday halted, at least temporarily, all American-led strike missions against the Islamic State that had been flying from the Incirlik air base — the first major impact of the attempted coup on the broader allied campaign against the terrorist group, United States officials said.

headline: Insurers, Pushing for Higher Rates, Challenge Key Component of Health Law
abstract: A federal review process intended to keep premiums down is being tested in Missouri, Oklahoma, Texas and Wyoming, where companies have requested big increases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For several years, the Obama administration has urged state insurance regulators to use tools provided by the Affordable Care Act to hold down health care premiums.

headline: One Dead and 3 Hurt After Off-Duty Officer’s S.U.V. Hits Pedestrians in Brooklyn
abstract: The officer, who was off duty when his vehicle mounted a sidewalk in the Williamsburg section early on Saturday, was charged with manslaughter, assault and driving while intoxicated.
lead_paragraph: The scene that unfolded in Brooklyn early on Saturday was a tragically familiar one in New York City: a driver losing control of his sport utility vehicle, mounting a sidewalk and plowing into a group of pedestrians, leaving one man dead and three other people seriously injured.

headline: Wind Keeps Tour de France Riders at Bay, but Mark Cavendish Barrels Through
abstract: A strong headwind could not stop Cavendish, who earned his fourth stage victory of this Tour.
lead_paragraph: VILLARS-LES-DOMBES, France — When sprinters get on a roll at the Tour de France, sometimes there is no stopping them.

headline: The Guns of My Girlhood
abstract: There were guns in the bedside tables and behind the face of the mantel clock.
lead_paragraph: Nashville — GROWING up on a farm outside Nashville, I shot Coke cans off sawhorses. I didn’t use a shotgun because I wasn’t big enough. I was once thrown to the ground from the kick of a rifle, so at 9 I stuck to handguns. There were six of us when we were all together — two children from my mother’s first marriage (my sister and I) and four children from my stepfather’s first marriage. We lined up by age and took turns. In the pantheon of summer activities in the country, guns were better than catching frogs but not as much fun as riding a horse.

headline: W., Borne Back Ceaselessly
abstract: At long last, the 28 pages on the Saudis and 9/11 have been released, putting the House of Saud and the House of Bush in a bad light.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DURING W.’s 2000 convention in Philadelphia, my sister showed up at my door.

headline: It’s O.K., Liberal Parents, You Can Freak Out About Porn
abstract: Conservatives take it too far, but I’m tired of liberals pretending it’s not a problem.
lead_paragraph: THE draft of the 2016 Republican platform released last week takes such conservative stands on sexual issues it begs to be made fun of. Particularly easy to lampoon is a plank calling pornography a “public-health crisis that is destroying the life of millions.”

headline: Russia’s Sports Minister Strives to Contain Damage
abstract: Vitaly Mutko, the country’s minister of sport, tourism and youth policy, is preparing for what could prove a damning indictment of his administration.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On the top floor of Russia’s antidoping laboratory, the largest office is empty but for two unopened glass bottles of Montblanc writing ink, in Irish Green and Midnight Blue.

headline: I Named My Mixed-Race Daughter for a Slave-Trading Town
abstract: A family comes to terms with its history.
lead_paragraph: FOR nearly 20 years, my great-great-great-grandfather’s portrait has watched over me from my red dining room wall. With his high collar, ruffled cravat and black waistcoat, Samuel Fales, 1775-1848, is the very image of the upstanding 19th-century New England gentleman. An eminent merchant and alderman of Boston, he was the founder of the family’s shipping business. I’ve known his face and taken comfort in his smile since I was a child attending Sunday lunch at my grandmother’s in the 1960s.

headline: How to Get More Women Into the Director’s Chair
abstract: Hollywood knows gender equality is a problem, but it still won’t fix it.
lead_paragraph: THE new “Ghostbusters,” led by four all-star actresses, is not the most significant step toward gender equality that will happen this month — Philadelphia has a lock on that. But if you’ve been waiting your whole life for a summer blockbuster that focuses on women in the workplace, “Ghostbusters” is a big deal.

headline: After Trading Shots, Henrik Stenson Comes Out Ahead of Phil Mickelson at the British Open
abstract: Stenson’s three-under-par 68 gave him a one-shot lead over Mickelson, and the two will be paired again in Sunday’s final round.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — From the start on Saturday, Phil Mickelson and Henrik Stenson seemed unconnected to the rest of the British Open field. Cast against the horizon like a lonely weekend twosome, they doggedly marched into the stiff breeze off the Firth of Clyde with their heads down and their chilled hands shoved in their pockets.

headline: Ashraf Ghani: Afghan Consoler in Chief
abstract: In a departure from the practices of his predecessor, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan has been making condolence calls to the families of fallen security officers.
lead_paragraph: In a departure from the practices of his predecessor, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan has been making condolence calls to the families of fallen security officers.

headline: A Night at the Coup
abstract: On Friday evening in Istanbul, I was expecting a silent end to a busy week. Then, Parliament was bombed and fighter jets were flying overhead.
lead_paragraph: Istanbul — AS I walked by the military museum in the Harbiye neighborhood of Istanbul on Friday evening, I was expecting a silent end to a busy week. I was on my way to an adjoining coffee shop where I planned to drink a cup of hot cocoa and read a literary magazine. The museum was eerily silent, but I didn’t think much of it, passing the human-sized mannequins of Ottoman-era janissary soldiers displayed in the windows.

headline: In Wartime, Ghani Assumes Role of Comforting Afghans
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani, whose security forces in 2015 sustained their highest death toll in years, has for months made condolence calls to relatives of those killed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The first condolence call was to the brother of a dead police officer, struck down in a Taliban ambush last month. President Ashraf Ghani spoke gently, offering a short prayer for the dead and words of gratitude for the family’s sacrifice. “We will not forget anyone,” he vowed.

headline: Turkey Moves to Regain Control
abstract: As a chaotic night gave way to morning, soldiers who had taken part in an attempted coup surrendered as the government worked to re-establish control.
lead_paragraph: As a chaotic night gave way to morning, soldiers who had taken part in an attempted coup surrendered as the government worked to re-establish control.

headline: Abroad in America, Deciphering the 2016 Presidential Race
abstract: I hope to turn my focus as a foreign correspondent to illuminating the fears, hopes and motivations that are driving voters of every hue.
lead_paragraph: The last election I covered didn’t work out so well for me. It was May 2013, and I was in Pakistan. As I was returning from a polling station in the southern city of Lahore, military intelligence officials flagged down my car. Hours later I was on a plane out of the country, having been deported.

headline: Obamacare’s Kindest Critic
abstract: The Affordable Care Act has accomplished a lot, but too many people are still left out.
lead_paragraph: History will almost surely rank health care reform as one of President Obama’s greatest accomplishments. About 20 million Americans have insurance that might otherwise have been unaffordable, and the law has cost much less than anticipated. But one senior administration official thinks the Affordable Care Act has fallen short. His name: Barack Obama.

headline: The Tesla Experiment: Drive, It Said
abstract: Defenders and skeptics discuss an Autopilot system that recently led to a fatality.
lead_paragraph: Defenders and skeptics discuss an Autopilot system that recently led to a fatality.

headline: Don’t Vote for Me, I’m Not Worthy
abstract: That’s what George Washington said. Imagine a modern presidential candidate saying that.
lead_paragraph: Washington — IN 1788, as the states met to ratify the Constitution, George Washington began to get letters from his Revolutionary War friends urging him to serve as the first president of the United States. “In the Name of America, of Mankind at large, and Your Own fame, I Beseech you, my dear General, Not to deny your Acceptance of the office of president,” wrote the Marquis de Lafayette. Alexander Hamilton nudged him: “I take it for granted, Sir, you have concluded to comply with what will no doubt be the general call of your country.”

headline: Ultimate Fighting Championship Ends a Long Odyssey to Legalization
abstract: The sale of the U.F.C. for $4 billion last week may have hinged on March’s regulatory approval from New York, the last state to legalize the sport.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship has made a name for itself by promoting fast-paced, hard-hitting mixed martial arts action in glitzy venues, a sport where extreme machismo meets Las Vegas.

headline: For Suicidal Veterans, a Frayed Lifeline
abstract: A safety net meant to help former military members in free fall is in disarray, hobbled by incompetence and inefficiency and overwhelmed by demand.
lead_paragraph: Veterans make up 8.5 percent of America’s adult population but account for 18 percent of its suicides. In 2014, according to new data from the Veterans Affairs Department, 7,403 veterans killed themselves. That is about 20 deaths a day.

headline: Mark Trumbo Is a Home Run Deal for the Orioles
abstract: Trumbo, finding a home in Baltimore, led the majors in home runs at the All-Star break with 28.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Orioles bring their slugging show to Yankee Stadium for a four-game series starting Monday, and the best player in baseball advises fans to arrive early for maximum exposure to Mark Trumbo.

headline: The Day That Went Missing
abstract: Out of nowhere, I was struck by a rare form of amnesia and lost an entire day in my life.
lead_paragraph: DO you remember June 27, 2015? If you knew you had been on a sailboat, and that the weather was miserable, and that afterward you had a beer with the other sailors, would you expect to recall — even one year later — at least a few details?

headline: How Mike Pence Became a Conservative Hero: Unwavering Opposition to Abortion
abstract: Mr. Pence’s reputation as a longstanding, implacable and dogged opponent of abortion has made him a hero to the country’s cultural conservatives.
lead_paragraph: One by one, Republican women of the Indiana state legislature rose to describe, in anguished terms, why they could not support an anti-abortion measure hurtling toward passage.

headline: The Arc of a Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: A violent and chaotic insurrection began Friday night as two bridges in Istanbul were seized by military forces. In the hours that followed, factions fought for control of government buildings in the capital, Ankara, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan re-emerged in Istanbul. By the next day, hundreds were dead, and thousands of military personnel were rounded up as the coup faltered.
lead_paragraph: A violent and chaotic insurrection began Friday night as two bridges in Istanbul were seized by military forces. In the hours that followed, factions fought for control of government buildings in the capital, Ankara, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan re-emerged in Istanbul. By the next day, hundreds were dead, and thousands of military personnel were rounded up as the coup faltered.

headline: The Arc of a Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: Here is a visual timeline of the country’s violent and chaotic insurrection.
lead_paragraph: Here is a visual timeline of the country’s violent and chaotic insurrection.

headline: France Agonizes Over Whether Truck Rampage Could Have Been Stopped
abstract: Many people in Nice and around the world are asking how a lone driver could so easily flout traffic rules and then race unimpeded through throngs of people.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — Returning home after an abortive trip to find some ice cream late on Thursday evening, Mario Aufiero, a French retiree, waited patiently on the sidewalk as a big truck lumbered down the short street he needed to cross to get to his apartment building just off the Promenade des Anglais.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To The Sports Editor:

headline: Double Features
abstract: Jerry Miccolis makes his New York Times Crossword debut with a puzzle that will make you look twice.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Let’s get this out of the way right at the top: I’m of the generation that cannot hear the phrase “Double Features” without thinking of “Rocky Horror Picture Show.”

headline: Donald Trump Forces G.O.P. to Choose Between Insularity and Outreach
abstract: Mr. Trump’s political approach would have Republicans court working-class and rural whites at the grievous cost of alienating minorities and women.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans stream into Cleveland to nominate Donald J. Trump for president, they confront a party divided and deeply imperiled by his racially divisive campaign. He has called for cracking down on Muslims and undocumented immigrants, stoked fears of crime and terrorism and repeatedly declared that the United States is in a war for its very survival.

headline: England’s Andrew Johnston Is an Obscure Figure With an Unforgettable Presence
abstract: Johnston, who is known as Beef and is ranked 104th in the world, finds himself among the leaders at the British Open, and he is loving every minute of it.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — His name is Beef.

headline: Terror Through the Eyes of Innocents: The Children in Nice
abstract: The attack during the Bastille Day fireworks show, an annual attraction for families, underscored the act’s brutality, with at least 10 children killed and leaving many with memories of trauma.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — It was the first and last fireworks show in this seaside city that 4½-year-old Yanis Coviaux ever saw. He died in the carnage Thursday night. So did Brodie Copeland, 11, who was visiting from the United States.

headline: Yearning for Playing Time, Alex Rodriguez Practices at First Base
abstract: Rodriguez, who was replaced in the designated hitter role by Carlos Beltran, may more easily return to the Yankees’ lineup as a first baseman.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees first asked Alex Rodriguez to learn how to play first base, before last season, his enthusiasm for the task was as absent as his glove, which had disappeared from his cubicle on the first day he was to participate in drills.

headline: Antidoping Officials Are Expected to Ask That Russia Be Barred From Rio Olympics
abstract: Antidoping officials from leading countries in global sports are awaiting the results of an investigation into allegations of a state-sponsored doping program in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Antidoping officials from at least 10 nations and 20 athlete groups are preparing the extraordinary step of requesting that the entire Russian delegation be barred from the Summer Olympics over allegations of a state-sponsored doping program, according to email correspondence obtained by The New York Times.

headline: An Exiled Cleric Denies Playing a Leading Role in Coup Attempt
abstract: Fethullah Gulen, accused by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of inspiring an effort to overthrow the Turkish government, compared Mr. Erdogan’s government to that of Nazi-era Germany.
lead_paragraph: SAYLORSBURG, Pa. — Fethullah Gulen, the Turkish cleric whom President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has accused of inspiring the coup attempt against his government, gave a rare interview on Saturday at his compound here in which he denied involvement in the coup, but compared Mr. Erdogan’s administration to that of the Nazi SS.

headline: Red Sox Chip Away at C. C. Sabathia and Stifle Yankees’ Offense
abstract: The Red Sox won in Yankee Stadium for the second consecutive day as the Yankees fell further behind in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: When Red Sox catcher Sandy Leon connected with the baseball, the sound reverberated off the bat in that crisp, unmistakable sound of square contact between two rounded objects.

headline: With Yoenis Cespedes Still on the Mend, Juan Lagares Relishes the Opportunity to Take the Field
abstract: Cespedes has been recovering from a quadriceps injury, so the Mets have been turning to Lagares in center field, a position he played every day until the team traded for Cespedes last summer.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For the fourth straight game, Yoenis Cespedes, the Mets’ best offensive player, was watching from the bench. Cespedes ran in the outfield before Saturday’s 4-2 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies to test his injured right quadriceps. He has felt better, but the leg muscle still had not healed enough for him to start.

headline: Nate Thurmond, Warriors Center and Defensive Wall, Dies at 74
abstract: A seven-time All-Star and Hall of Fame player went toe-to-toe with the N.B.A.’s dominant big men.
lead_paragraph: Nate Thurmond, the Hall of Fame center for the Golden State Warriors who became one of the National Basketball Association’s most dominant defensive players and rebounders while battling some of the leading big men in league history, died on Saturday in San Francisco. He was 74.

headline: Some Predict Tuition Increases Under Hillary Clinton’s College Plan
abstract: Experts see evidence that colleges have responded to past increases in federal subsidies by raising their prices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton’s plan to allow most Americans to attend public universities at no cost could have the perverse effect of driving tuition higher as the federal government chased a tuition target that universities would simply raise at taxpayers’ expense, some experts warn.

headline: Mike Pence, Ambitious Outsider, Gets the G.O.P. to Come Around
abstract: Slowly but surely, the affable Mr. Pence used his 12 years in the House to convince the Republican leadership that there was a place for his brand of conservatism.
lead_paragraph: Senior members of Congress and their aides used to give me a hard time for paying too much attention to Representative Mike Pence, an amiable conservative from Indiana who wore his staunch ideology and evangelical Christianity on his sleeve.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, July 17, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The nation will never forget this betrayal.”

headline: Turkey Was an Unlikely Victim of an Equally Unlikely Coup
abstract: The uprising appeared to diverge wildly from the usual patterns of such attempts. And for several reasons, Turkey should have been at little risk.
lead_paragraph: If the attempted coup in Turkey came as a surprise, there was good reason: The event went against decades of research on how, when and why coups happen.

headline: Nicole DiBella, Robert Liguori
abstract: She is an account group supervisor at a division of Havas Worldwide, an advertising agency; he is a research editor at The New York Times Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Lilly DiBella and Robert Andrew Liguori were married July 16 at the Watch Hill Chapel in Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Cynthia A. Stravers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

abstract: She is a social worker who works with low-income seniors, and he works for UBS.

Alkon of Manhasset, N.Y. Rabbi Marc J. Margolius is to officiate at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York.

abstract: The couple met at Columbia Law School.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Jean Bodner, the daughter of Candida Cherchi Bodner and Gerald T. Bodner of Manhasset, N.Y., was married July 16 to Benjamin John Rankin, the son of Janis Johnson of San Rafael, Calif., and Robert A. Rankin of Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. lead_paragraph: Alexandra Paige Locker, a daughter of Lori E. Locker and Frederick B. Locker of New York, was married July 16 to Jason Andrew Wald, a son of Sue D. Wald and David J. Wald of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Angela Buchdahl officiated at the bride’s parents’ summer house in Southampton, N.Y.

Hambley and Darryl J. Hambley of Butler, Pa. Eliseo Olvera, the pastor of Living Mosaic, a nondenominational Christian church in Portland, Ore., officiated at Villa Catalana Cellars, a winery.

abstract: She is a pediatric rehabilitation nurse, and he does research for Morgan Stanley.
lead_paragraph: Heather Ashley Snow, a daughter of Lois R. Snow and Jeffrey A. Snow of Newtown, Conn., was married July 16 to Andrew Richard Ruben, a son of Melinda S. Ruben of Boca Raton, Fla., and Lawrence A. Ruben of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Jessica Minnen officiated at Battery Gardens, a restaurant and event space in New York.

headline: Elizabeth Bernardi, Shane Dunn
abstract: He advocates for charter schools in Massachusetts, and she will begin soon as business strategy director at Liberty Mutual Insurance.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Michelle Bernardi, the daughter of Vicki S. Bernardi and David J. Bernardi of Westlake, Ohio, was married July 16 to Shane Aaron Dunn, the son of Cheryl D. Elias of Rome, N.Y., and Wendell J. Dunn of Verona, N.Y. Barbara Behrmann, a Humanist celebrant, officiated in the Sage Chapel on the campus of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

abstract: She works for a human rights organization and he is a reality TV producer.
lead_paragraph: Lilach Adie Shafir, a daughter of Nedda D. Shafir of Phoenix and the late Shlomi Shafir, is to be married July 17 to David Arthur Abraham, a son of Michael J. Abraham of Howard Beach, Queens, and the late Barbara P. Abraham. Rabbi Megan GoldMarche, a cousin of the bride, will officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Christina Conroy, Adam Kost
abstract: They went to high school together but didn’t introduce themselves until several years later.
lead_paragraph: Christina Marie Conroy and Adam Alexander Kost were married July 15 at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y. Msgr. Steven R. Camp performed the ceremony.

abstract: She is a lawyer for Warner Bros., and he is an account executive for a strategic communications firm in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Jill Neubauer and Anthony Sanders Alexander Freinberg were married July 16 at the Ebell of Los Angeles, a women’s club. Judge Joseph A. Greenaway Jr. of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Newark, for whom the bride once worked as a law clerk, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Alexis Lyn Robinson and Alan Gary Garten were married July 16 at the Trump Winery in Charlottesville, Va. The officiant was the Rev. Martin Malzahn, the chaplain at Wagner College in Staten Island and an ordained minister in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America.

abstract: The couple graduated from Dartmouth but did not meet until they attended a mutual friend’s birthday dinner in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Lee Kindermann and Case Dorkey were married July 16 at Sanford Winery in Lompoc, Calif. The officiant was Dr. David Randell, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

abstract: The couple got to know each other at a ski cabin at Lake Tahoe.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Rachel Ginach and Nicolas John Jezienicki were married July 16. The Rev. Raymond P. Allender, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Olympia’s Valley Estate, an organic farm and wedding venue in Petaluma, Calif. Rabbi Mikki Bourne took part in the ceremony.

headline: Amanda Newberg, Michael Thomas
abstract: The couple met online.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Sara Newberg, a daughter of Cecile Doelger Newberg and David A. Newberg of Westport, Conn., was married July 16 to Michael William Thomas, a son of Michele M. Thomas and William G. Thomas Jr. of Norwalk, Conn. Msgr. Andrew G. Varga performed the ceremony at Saint Luke Catholic Church in Westport, where he is the pastor.

headline: Maya Simon, Alexander Gordon
abstract: The couple were introduced in 2010 through HowAboutWe, a dating website that was in beta testing at the time. It worked.
lead_paragraph: Maya Simon and Alexander William Arthur Gordon were married July 16 in Washington. Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb officiated at the Hay-Adams hotel.

abstract: They met at Georgetown at an orientation for international students.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Rohrmann Marcucci, a daughter of María Teresa Marcucci de Rohrmann and Francisco Rohrmann of Guatemala City, was married July 16 to Haig Nerguizian, a son of Nirva Nerguizian and Varouj Nerguizian of Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Zabarian, the vicar general of Armenian Catholics in Canada, leading the couple through their vows.

abstract: She is a voice-over actress and he is a photographer.
lead_paragraph: Sabrina Farhi and Adam Claypool Ryder were married July 16 in Brooklyn. Rabbi Rachel Timoner officiated at the Brooklyn Winery.

lead_paragraph: Jeanette Marie Hoffman and Joshua Korey Henne are to be married July 17 at Castle Hill Inn in Newport, R.I. Rabbi Howard Voss-Altman is to officiate.

Garber and Michael L. Garber of San Diego. lead_paragraph: Alix Michelle Olian, the daughter of Terri R. Olian and Robert M. Olian of Highland Park, Ill., was married July 16 to Kevin Francis Burke Jr., a son of Mimi H. Burke and Mr. Burke of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Wendi S. Geffen officiated at the Standard Club in Chicago, where the couple also received a blessing from the Rev. Michael O’Keefe, a Roman Catholic priest.

Salberg and Michael A. Salberg of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi David E. Greenberg performed the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford Corners, N.Y.

abstract: The couple met in a yoga class.
lead_paragraph: Amy Anna Kass and Jeffrey Mitchell Golubchick are to be married July 17. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein is to officiate at Battery Gardens, a restaurant and events venue in Manhattan.

Jager and Steven L. Jager of Sherman Oaks, Calif. Rabbi Ari Lucas is to officiate at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles.

headline: Alexandra Lamm and Peter Weinberg: Giving His Bedside Manner an Early Test
abstract: A collapsed lung postponed the wedding, but everyone took a deep breath, figuratively at least, and rescheduled.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Elena Lamm, a daughter of Dr. Carin I. Lamm and Dr. Steven Lamm, both of Manhattan, is to be married July 17 to Peter Garner Weinberg, the son of Ann Kirschner and Dr. Harold J. Weinberg, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove is to officiate at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

headline: Jennifer Albinson and Justin Cohan-Shapiro: Walking to Their Wedding, 1,200 Miles Away
abstract: They had a map and a compass, but at first, the nearest bar was all they could find.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer McCouen Albinson, the daughter of Sharon Jones Albinson and Robert David Albinson of Chevy Chase, Md., was married July 16 to Justin Cohan-Shapiro, a son of Carol J. Shapiro and Bruce D. Cohan of New York. Lindsay Schroll Carson, a friend of the couple who was appointed a temporary marriage commissioner by Alameda County, Calif., officiated at Sardine Lake in Sierra City, Calif., near the halfway point of the couple’s current hike along the Pacific Crest Trail, a 2,650-mile trek from Mexico to Canada.

headline: Anuradha Gajjar, Sagar Ravi
abstract: She is a fellow in pediatric nephrology, and he is an assistant U.S. attorney.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anuradha Amar Gajjar, a daughter of Poorna A. Gajjar and Dr. Amar J. Gajjar of Germantown, Tenn., was married July 16 to Sagar Kananur Ravi, the son of Shailaja Ravi and Kananur V. Ravi of Estero, Fla. Sri Satyanarayana Marathe, a Hindu priest, led the couple in a Hindu wedding ceremony at the Schermerhorn Symphony Center in Nashville.

headline: Marni Perlmutter, Joshua Cohen
abstract: The engagement took place on a rooftop, with a dinner of their favorites, all served by friends.
lead_paragraph: Marni Eve Perlmutter, a daughter of Mara Rotsky Perlmutter and Keith Perlmutter of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married July 16 to Joshua Ross Cohen, the son of Lauren Greene Cohen and Gary A. Cohen of Bedford Corners, N.Y. Cantor Jill Abramson officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Rosemary Miller, Derick Stace-Naughton
abstract: The bride, 26, and groom, 27, met at Stanford, from which they graduated, she with a master of arts degree in education, and he with an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Rosemary Anne Miller, the daughter of Anne M. Sweeney and Philip H. Miller of Los Angeles, was married July 16 to Derick John Stace-Naughton, the son of Denise K. Stace-Naughton and Patrick J. Stace-Naughton of Madison, Wis. Msgr. Lloyd Torgerson performed the ceremony at St. Monica Catholic Church in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Elenor Mak, Richard Tsai
abstract: She, a business consultant, and he, a neurology professor, met while training for triathlons in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Elenor Hui-Tung Mak, the daughter of Anna Yam-Choo Teo and John Kok-Fan Mak of Brooklyn, was married July 13 to Dr. Richard Mengchun Tsai, a son of Cynthia L. Tsai and Peter J. Tsai of Taipei, Taiwan. Joanna K. McClure, a deputy marriage commissioner for San Francisco County, officiated at City Hall in San Francisco.

headline: Fiona Reeves, Chris Liddell-Westefeld
abstract: The couple met at the White House while reading and organizing heaps of mail sent to President Obama in the correspondence office.
lead_paragraph: Fiona O’Neill Reeves and Christopher Scott Liddell-Westefeld were married July 16 at Old Engine 12, a restaurant and event space in a former firehouse in Washington. Officiating was Howli J. Ledbetter, a friend of the couple who received permission to do so from the District of Columbia Superior Court.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: HBO’s “Vice Principals,” the latest from Danny R. McBride and Jody Hill, tackles white male rage. And “MLB Network Presents” looks at Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hitting streak.
lead_paragraph: In “Vice Principals,” Danny R. McBride and Jody Hill of “Eastbound & Down” put their imprint on white male rage. “MLB Network Presents” looks at Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hitting streak. And the Season 3 premiere of “Power” finds Ghost haunted.

headline: Wild, Wonderful, Wacky Hair on the Men’s Runways
abstract: On the runways, designers from Comme des Garçons to Gosha Rubchinskiy festooned men’s heads in spiky hair, flower crowns and splashes of color.
lead_paragraph: From Comme des Garçons to Gosha Rubchinskiy, on the runway men’s heads have become a canvas for decoration, festooned with spikes, flowers and splashes of color.

headline: Corrections: July 17, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, July 17, 2016.
lead_paragraph: METROPOLITAN

headline: The Last Dinner at the Four Seasons
abstract: An American fine dining institution in the Seagram Building has moved out after 57 years.
lead_paragraph: It was business as usual on Saturday evening in the grand old guts of the Seagram Building in Midtown Manhattan, where Pecko Zantilaveevan, the executive chef of the Four Seasons restaurant, was overseeing the roasting of 102 ducks for dinner service.

headline: Top South Korean Prosecutor Arrested on Charges He Accepted Bribes
abstract: Accused of taking payment from an online game maker, the official, Jin Kyung-joon, is the most senior Korean prosecutor ever arrested while in office.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A top South Korean prosecutor was arrested on Sunday on charges of taking millions of dollars in bribes from the owner of Nexon, a leading online game maker, in a case that the country’s news media has portrayed as the epitome of corruption among its elite.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Baton Rouge, Turkey, U.S. Presidential Race: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Seek Long-Term Aims Over Short-Term Results
abstract: Nicolas Bos, chief of the jeweler Van Cleef & Arpels, says that “luxury companies only last if they are both creative and good businesses.”
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Bos is chief executive of Van Cleef & Arpels, part of the Richemont Group.

headline: 1916: Kaiser Tries to Prop Up Subsiding German Faith
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Kaiser William attempts to prop up subsiding confidence in the war effort in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — That the German people’s confidence in a victorious issue of the war has been badly shaken by the long series of Allied successes on the eastern and western fronts, is shown by a Note issued by the German Staff under date of July 13. The Note is an endeavor to prop up the subsiding confidence of the Kaiser’s subjects by accusing France and Great Britain of publishing highly colored and sometimes truthless communiqués calculated to stagger German opinion.

headline: The Week Pokémon Go Took Central Park
abstract: This week, Central Park earned a new distinction on the city’s grid: It became the go-to hunting ground for swarms of people playing Pokémon Go.
lead_paragraph: This week, Central Park earned a new distinction on the city’s grid: It became the go-to hunting ground for swarms of people playing Pokémon Go.

headline: Turkey Allows Resumption of U.S. Missions From Incirlik Air Base
abstract: The missions by American warplanes flown from Turkey against Islamic State targets were shut down in the hours after the failed coup in the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Missions by American warplanes flown from the Incirlik air base in Turkey against Islamic State targets will resume following a temporary shutdown in the hours after the failed coup, Defense Department officials announced Sunday.

headline: Sparkling and Blighted, Convention Cities Spotlight Ignored Urban Issues
abstract: Cleveland and Philadelphia, with areas of gleaming renewal and others of crushing poverty, illustrate the plight of America’s cities, little discussed in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was a sparkling scene of urban renaissance: Children scampered through the fountain in Public Square, spruced up at a cost of $50 million just in time for the Republican convention here. Electricians installed security cameras on the redesigned plaza as carpenters put the finishing touches on a new cafe.

headline: A Civil Start to Protests, but Cleveland Is Bracing for Worse
abstract: At the height of the protests early Sunday evening, about 200 demonstrators marched in the heart of downtown, stopping traffic and shouting, “No justice, no peace, no racist police!”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The barricades were up and the police were ready, but the rowdy protests expected to descend this week on Cleveland for the Republican National Convention were contained to small pockets of unrest amid largely peaceful demonstrations across the city.

headline: Who’s Taking a Soapbox to Cleveland? Trump Backers and Critics (and Nude Women)
abstract: Organizers of the Republican convention are bracing for an array of protesters on both the right and left, along with 100 women without clothes.
lead_paragraph: Delegates preparing to nominate Donald J. Trump at the Republican National Convention this week are just some of the thousands of people descending on Cleveland. Organizers are also bracing for the arrival of protesters and supporters of Mr. Trump. They will all pack the city, itself packed with security, to have their say.

headline: Ominous Signs as Republicans Gather to Chart Their Future
abstract: Even if Donald J. Trump turns out to be a unique phenomenon, analysts see a growing gap between Republican leaders and Republican voters.
lead_paragraph: The tensions at the 2016 Republican National Convention are not like those typically seen at the party’s divided gatherings: Theodore Roosevelt challenging the hierarchy in 1912; or the moderates versus conservatives — Dwight D. Eisenhower against Robert A. Taft in 1952, or, 12 years later, Barry M. Goldwater and Nelson A. Rockefeller; then Ronald Reagan taking on President Gerald Ford in 1976.

headline: Officers Fatally Shoot Brooklyn Man Who They Say Fired at Them
abstract: The authorities said that the man, Jermaine Johnson, 42, had fired at least five shots at officers in the East Williamsburg neighborhood before he was killed.
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of robbing people at gunpoint in Brooklyn was fatally shot on Sunday by New York City police officers after exchanging gunfire with them, the authorities said. It was the third time in just over a week that police officers had fired on an armed suspect in Brooklyn.

headline: A Crisis in Cleveland
abstract: The housing bust continues for many in Cleveland, especially in predominantly black neighborhoods. The city is tearing down hundreds of homes to deal with the blight that has resulted.
lead_paragraph: The housing bust continues for many in Cleveland, especially in predominantly black neighborhoods. The city is tearing down hundreds of homes to deal with the blight that has resulted.

headline: Baton Rouge Shooting Jolts a Nation on Edge
abstract: Three officers were killed and three wounded in the attack, which left many wondering whether anger at the police had prompted yet another act of retaliation.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — A gunman fatally shot three law enforcement officers and wounded three others here on Sunday before being killed in a shootout with the police. The attack’s motive was unclear as of Sunday evening, leaving an anxious nation to wonder whether the anger over recent police shootings had prompted another act of retaliation against officers.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Today, take it easy and cook a few ears of summer corn.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Live Updates: Baton Rouge Law Enforcement Officers Shot
abstract: Police are responding to a shooting that left at least three Baton Rouge officers seriously wounded early Sunday, according to the mayor-president of East Baton Rouge Parish.

headline: Drug Spot, Tow Lot, Entrance at Rikers: Pokémon Go’s Unlikely New York Stops
abstract: People playing the game in the five boroughs can hunt their quarry all over, including near the city’s jail complex, in a Manhattan car pound and at an overdose-scarred intersection in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Devin Reams stepped out of the bar where his girlfriend works into the afternoon heat. He walked near the intersection of Myrtle Avenue and Broadway in Brooklyn, a hot zone for addicts whose overdoses from the drug K2 brought ambulances and the police in swarms last week.

headline: 1891: New China for the White House
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: New china dinner service for the White House in 1891.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A set of china has been designed for Mrs. Harrison by her painting master for future use in the White House. The set will go down into history as ” the Harrison China.” Part of a set which Presidents Lincoln and Grant used is still there; and the Hairland set, which is always called the Hayes China, because its purchase was superintended by Mrs. Hayes, is what is used upon all state occasions. This, however, is being rapidly depleted, much of it is chipped and shows signs of wear and tear.

headline: ‘Ghostbusters’ Is No. 2, Behind ‘Secret Life of Pets,’ but Sony’s Giddy
abstract: The reboot, starring Melissa McCarthy, Kate McKinnon, Leslie Jones and Kristen Wiig, took in about $46 million over the weekend at theaters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “We got one!”

headline: Remembering James Cagney, a Tough Guy With a Green Thumb
abstract: At the Players club in Manhattan, a producer of the musical “Cagney” and the show’s star swap stories about the pugnacious actor and his surprising hobbies.
lead_paragraph: In journalism, there are five W’s — who, what, why, where and when. Just this once, let’s tackle them in a different order.

headline: John Kerry Rejects Suggestions of U.S. Involvement in Turkey Coup
abstract: “We think it’s irresponsible to have accusations of American involvement,” the secretary of state said.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — Signs of testy relations between Turkey’s embattled government and the United States continued Sunday, as Secretary of State John Kerry denounced any suggestion of American involvement in Friday’s coup.

headline: Erdogan Triumphs After Coup Attempt, but Turkey’s Fate Is Unclear
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s victory over the uprising may have bolstered his popularity among Islamists, but wider support was not yet certain.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Standing atop a bus outside his mansion in Istanbul on Saturday night, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, victorious after putting down a coup attempt by renegade factions of the military, told his followers, “We only bow to God.”

headline: Henrik Stenson Beats Phil Mickelson in British Open Duel
abstract: Stenson, who had a one-stroke lead entering the day, held off Mickelson in a memorable one-on-one battle to become the first Swedish man to win a golf major.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — Phil Mickelson had turned back the clock for a fourth consecutive day. He had made a birdie on the opening hole of Sunday’s final round at the 2016 British Open and never looked back. His game was as sharp as it had ever been on the final day of a major championship. Winless for the past three years, the 46-year-old Mickelson was tied for the tournament lead, just five holes and perhaps one last surge from becoming the oldest British Open champion in 149 years.

headline: Baton Rouge Police Shooting: What We Know
abstract: Three police officers were shot dead and three others were wounded in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday morning, and the gunman was killed, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three police officers were shot dead, and three others were wounded, in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday morning. The gunman was killed, the authorities said. The area where the shooting took place has been the scene of protests in the weeks since the police shooting of Alton B. Sterling on July 5.

headline: Is It Time to Celebrate Democracy in Turkey?
abstract: President Erdogan has a choice between embracing the opposition that defended him or becoming even more authoritarian.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — I HAVE lately been a frequent critic of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his increasingly authoritarian government. But a military regime, like the kind a group of coup-plotters tried to bring about on Friday night, would have been not only illegitimate but also far more repressive and bloody. The people of Turkey, including many of Mr. Erdogan’s political opponents, rightly rejected that.

headline: Keno Brothers, ‘Antiques Roadshow’ Stars, Face Debt and Legal Challenge
abstract: Leigh and Leslie Keno, celebrity appraisers who have appeared on “Antiques Roadshow,” went on a buying spree this spring that left them with nearly $600,000 in debt.
lead_paragraph: For decades the Keno brothers — telegenic twins and widely acknowledged experts on Americana and vintage automobiles — have been perhaps the country’s highest-profile antique dealers.

headline: How the Shooting of Police Officers in Baton Rouge Unfolded
abstract: A minute-by-minute account of the shooting, with maps and video.
lead_paragraph: A minute-by-minute account of the shooting, with maps and video.

headline: Tour de France Showdown Never Materializes as Chris Froome Maintains Lead
abstract: During a tough 15th stage in the Jura Mountains, the Englishman Froome’s rivals made no headway, and the standings at the top remained largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: CULOZ, France — The stalemate between Chris Froome and his rivals at the Tour de France continued Sunday as the race returned to the mountains.

headline: 3 More Reported Held in Bastille Day Truck Attack in Nice
abstract: They were the latest of seven people detained after the attack, French news media said, as the 84 deaths were marked on the second of three days of national mourning.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France, still reeling from the attack on Thursday in the southern coastal city of Nice that killed 84 people, observed its second of three days of national mourning on Sunday, as the French police held three more people in connection with the assault, according to news reports.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Swarms Silicon Valley on Wings and Wheels
abstract: The valley has found its next shiny new thing in A.I., and financiers and entrepreneurs are digging in with remarkable exuberance.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — For more than a decade, Silicon Valley’s technology investors and entrepreneurs obsessed over social media and mobile apps that helped people do things like find new friends, fetch a ride home or crowdsource a review of a product or a movie.

headline: Dominant Shutout by Jacob deGrom Leads Mets Over Phillies
abstract: DeGrom, who had been slotted near the back of the rotation to allow him to rest, allowed one hit and walked one in the first complete game of his career.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Before the All-Star break last week, Jacob deGrom sat down with Mets Manager Terry Collins to discuss his coming pitching schedule. After a slow start to the season, deGrom had found his groove. But he admitted to Collins that he was tired. To get deGrom rest, the Mets slotted him near the back of their rotation as the season resumed.

headline: Navy Secretary Ray Mabus Knows a Thing or 30 About First Pitches
abstract: Mabus has thrown the ceremonial ball at all 30 major league ballparks and is believed to be the only person to have done so.
lead_paragraph: Ray Mabus, the secretary of the Navy since 2009, began throwing out first pitches to bring attention to the Navy and the Marine Corps. Now he is believed to be the only person to have thrown one at all 30 major league ballparks.

headline: Review: Nostalgia for a 1970s British Adolescence in ‘Cradle to Grave’
abstract: This comedy, based on Danny Baker’s upbringing, delightfully chronicles the travails of a working-class London family at the dawn of globalization.
lead_paragraph: “Cradle to Grave,” a BBC series making its American debut online Monday on Acorn TV, is a highly likable example of the my-magical-childhood sitcom, a first-person exercise in narrated nostalgia that recalls “The Wonder Years,” “The Goldbergs” and Chris O’Dowd’s (even better) “Moone Boy.”

headline: Review: Dave Eggers’s New Novel, ‘Heroes of the Frontier’
abstract: A mother on the run from a bad relationship flies to Alaska with her two children, rents an R.V. and hits the road where they have one mishap after another.
lead_paragraph: Dave Eggers’s captivating 2012 novel, “A Hologram for the King,” was both a sad-funny portrait of a man in the midst of a midlife crisis and a light-handed allegory about the current frustrations of middle-class America. His latest novel, “Heroes of the Frontier,” is a kind of bookend to “Hologram”: another midlife crisis, captured in media res — through the story of Josie, a former dentist on the run from a bad relationship and on the lam in Alaska with her two children.

headline: In the Age of ISIS, Who’s a Terrorist, and Who’s Simply Deranged?
abstract: Instances of wanton violence have been swiftly judged to be the work of terrorists, even when there is little evidence of direct ties to terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In December 2014, a middle-aged man driving a car in Dijon, France, mowed down more than a dozen pedestrians within 30 minutes, occasionally shouting Islamic slogans from his window.

headline: Live, From Cleveland! Late-Night Comics Stake Their Turf at Conventions
abstract: Late-night TV satirists are setting up shop in Cleveland and Philadelphia at the G.O.P. and Democratic conventions.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Bill Maher, the host of HBO’s topical comedy series “Real Time With Bill Maher,” proposed to the network that it add special live episodes on Wednesday and Thursday nights to follow the Republican and Democratic National Conventions.

headline: Political Art in a Fractious Election Year
abstract: As the campaign season enters the nominating stage, no image has emerged that approaches the power of Shepard Fairey’s 2008 “Hope” poster for Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, when the artist Shepard Fairey created the graphically striking “Hope” portrait to support Barack Obama’s presidential campaign, it seemed as if a rich tradition of American political imagery reaching back at least to the middle of the 20th century — on posters, buttons, bumper stickers — was still very much alive. The art critic Peter Schjeldahl called the “Hope” poster “epic poetry in an everyday tongue.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 18
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: In Goya’s Shadow, Andrea Fraser’s Videos Skewer Social Institutions
abstract: The show “Andrea Fraser: L’1%, c’est moi,” at the Museu d’Art Contemporani de Barcelona, questions the collusion of business, government and art.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Spain might be the cradle of institutional critique, the brand of contemporary art that looks at how power and money shape art and how artists — often seen as independent operators — participate in this process.

headline: Review: In ‘Good’ and ‘No End of Blame,’ Politics and Prickly Debate
abstract: These revivals, presented by the Potomac Theater Project, speak to contemporary politics and cultural debate.
lead_paragraph: On the cusp of 30, Potomac Theater Project is having a Saturn returns moment. It’s made a summer season out of a pair of old British favorites from when it was young, each staged by the director who first staged it way back when.

headline: Place for Airing an Opinion
abstract: Jacob Stulberg makes his thoughts known.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Crosswords are supposed to be opinion-free, with the possible exception of the AVCX Crossword, an excellent indie continuation of the puzzles that used to run in The Onion’s A.V. Club. Today, however, we have OP-ED COLUMNS running all through Jacob Stulberg’s Monday crossword. Let’s find them.

headline: Precious Scents on Father’s Day
abstract: A woman at a garden in Greenwich Village received a gift from a stranger that reminded her of her parents.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Beyond Anne Frank: The Dutch Tell Their Full Holocaust Story
abstract: A memorial wall and a new Holocaust museum reflect a push in the Netherlands to give a more complete understanding of what happened under Nazi occupation.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Anne Frank is only part of the story.

headline: Obama Condemns Baton Rouge Shooting and Calls, Again, for Unity
abstract: “Attacks on police are an attack on all of us,” the president said, the fifth time in nine days that he had spoken publicly about shootings involving the police.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama condemned a shooting on Sunday in Baton Rouge, La., that killed three police officers and wounded three others, calling for Americans to “focus on words and actions that can unite this country rather than divide it further.”

headline: A Final Round for the Ages at the British Open
abstract: Phil Mickelson and Henrik Stenson provided their version of a heavyweight boxing match on Sunday in a duel that was among the best in the sport’s history.
lead_paragraph: TROON, Scotland — This was an arm wrestle, a free-throw shooting contest, a 50-yard dash. It was a tug of war, a sprint to the top of the hill, a game of rock-paper-scissors.

headline: Obama Speaks on Baton Rouge Shooting
abstract: After three police officers were killed and three were wounded in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday, the president discouraged polarization and violence.
lead_paragraph: After three police officers were killed and three were wounded in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday, the president discouraged polarization and violence.

headline: Heng on the South China Sea Verdict
abstract: An international tribunal in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: An international tribunal in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior in the South China Sea

headline: Iran’s President Is Confronted by Scandal Over Inflated Government Wages
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani is enduring a storm over disclosures showing astronomical bonuses and salaries paid to managers of state-run companies.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Less than a year before new elections, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran is confronting a major scandal involving inflated salaries for the managers and executives of state-run companies.

headline: Los Angeles’ ‘Subway to the Sea’ Is Less About Play and More About Work
abstract: The sheen of the extension has mostly worn off, replaced by workaday concerns of daily commuters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the so-called subway to the sea began running between downtown Los Angeles and Santa Monica this year, it was greeted with a kind of revelry and attention usually reserved for only the hottest celebrity-studded film screenings.

headline: Dissecting the Russian Doping Inquiry
abstract: A report from an independent investigator confirmed allegations of state-sponsored cheating during the 2014 Sochi Games. Here is what we know.
lead_paragraph: A two-month inquiry into allegations of state-sponsored doping in Russia, released Monday, confirmed a Russian whistle-blower’s claims. The inquiry, commissioned by the World Anti-Doping Agency, focused on Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov’s detailed account of cheating at the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

headline: Nigeria Finds a National Crisis in Every Direction It Turns
abstract: President Muhammadu Buhari promised to stamp out terrorism in the north and to rebuild the economy. But the nation now faces terrorism, separatism and low oil prices.
lead_paragraph: UGBORODO, Nigeria — Militants are roaming oil-soaked creeks in the south, blowing up pipelines and decimating the nation’s oil production. Islamist extremists have killed thousands in the north. Deadly land battles are shaking the nation’s center. And a decades-old separatist movement at the heart of a devastating civil war is brewing again.

headline: Ignoring Donald Trump, Republican Senators Orbit Their Own Worlds
abstract: Several senators in tough re-election fights are focusing on local issues, trying to avoid guilt by association with their party’s presumptive presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Senator Rob Portman of Ohio plans a very busy convention week as Republicans pour into his home state beginning Monday.

headline: Earnings Reports From Banking Leaders and Tech Giants
abstract: This week analysts will consider how banks are responding to the lull in interest rates and the so-called Brexit vote and auto industry officials will address cybersecurity in cars.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at what’s coming this week.

headline: Dynamite Entertainment Taps ’70s TV to Expand Lineup of Comics
abstract: The eclectic comic book publisher plans to team up the Bionic Woman and Wonder Woman in a mini-series and bring back Nancy Drew and the Hardy Boys.
lead_paragraph: The comic books published by Dynamite Entertainment do not fall into easy categories. Series have starred the internet sensation Grumpy Cat, the government spy James Bond and the sword and sorcery heroine Red Sonja.

headline: Many Turks Prefer Even Flawed Democracy to Coup
abstract: After the attempted overthrow of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, there was a sense of relief in Istanbul, and Sunday was a day of pro-government rallies and funerals.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s liberals have spent years feeling that the country was being piloted in the wrong direction by a very powerful captain. They have watched with trepidation as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan expanded his powers, enriched his allies and increased the role of religion in public life.

headline: Bridgewater, World’s Biggest Hedge Fund, Is Said to Be Slowing Hiring
abstract: The firm, which usually hires hundreds of people yearly, has canceled interviews and cut short negotiations, said people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: After years of rapid internal growth, the world’s biggest hedge fund appears to be slowing down.

headline: G.O.P. Arena Will Highlight Trump’s Media Blacklist
abstract: News organizations shut out by Donald Trump will enjoy official entry to a Trump-led event for the first time in months, complicating his fight with the press.
lead_paragraph: When the Republican National Convention begins in Cleveland on Monday, The Washington Post will be there at Quicken Loans Arena. So will Politico, The Huffington Post and BuzzFeed. Ditto The Des Moines Register.

headline: The Tiniest Homes
abstract: About five years ago, houses made of twigs, moss and fungi started appearing in the South Mountain Reservation in Millburn, N.J.
lead_paragraph: About five years ago, houses made of twigs, moss and fungi started appearing in the South Mountain Reservation in Millburn, N.J.

headline: Thumbelina’s Secret Architect, Creating Fairy Houses on a New Jersey Trail
abstract: Made of twigs, moss and acorns, the tiny enchanting houses in the South Mountain Reservation in Millburn, N.J., have inspired children as well as copycats.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — Intricate little fairy houses started appearing in the woods of South Mountain Reservation here about five years ago.

headline: Donald Trump and Mike Pence: One Ticket, Two Worldviews
abstract: Differences of opinion on trade, diplomacy and the use of force could be difficult to reconcile for the presumptive Republican presidential nominee and his running mate.
lead_paragraph: The congressman from Indiana reminded his colleagues of the necessity of “confronting tyranny.” He affirmed that he stood with President George W. Bush. And he declared Baghdad, simply, as “guilty.”

headline: With Pokémon Go, Nintendo Seeks to Salvage Lost Opportunity
abstract: Nearly two decades ago, the video game company released a forerunner to today’s game that foreshadowed much of mobile gaming. Then it lost its lead.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A video game featuring combative little critters called Pokémon hits mobile devices, and millions of fans are hooked. Players around the world search for rare and valuable Pokémon and connect with each other to do battle.

headline: Using Virtual Reality to Create a New Corporate Headquarters
abstract: Nvidia, a chip maker in Silicon Valley, is using an interactive visualization software that makes it easier than ever for architects to work with their ideas in three dimensions.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In the heart of Silicon Valley, you can slip on a virtual reality headset and fly through a photo-realistic three-dimensional building that will soon be the new corporate home for the chip maker Nvidia.

headline: TV News: Truth Squad or Trump Infomercial?
abstract: With convention plans calling for spectacle, truth will not come to the fore without hard work by the media and, potentially, a fight.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the months since he began pursuing the presidency, Donald J. Trump has exhibited a command over the national news media that is without parallel in modern times.

headline: Years of Punishing Waves Shaped a Rio Hero’s Olympic Hopes
abstract: Pedro Solberg, a beach volleyball player from Brazil, qualified for the Rio Olympics after an inaccurate drug suspension ruined his chances for the London Games.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — It is about a block and a half from where Pedro Solberg lives to where he practices on the sand of Ipanema, at the end of Rua Garcia d’Avila. Most days, when he is not traveling on the professional beach volleyball tour, Solberg does not venture more than about two blocks from home. All he needs is here: food, fun and practice.

headline: Alan Vega, Punk Music Pioneer and Artist, Dies at 78
abstract: Suicide, Mr. Vega’s band, was one of the first bands to bill themselves as “punk music.” In the 2000s, he resumed his career as a visual artist.
lead_paragraph: Alan Vega, the singer in the minimalist, proto-punk, proto-electro, proto-industrial two-man band Suicide and a prolific musician and visual artist on his own, died on Saturday. He was 78.

headline: Organic Valley Traces Milk Back From Table to Farm
abstract: Catering to people who want to know about where their food comes from, the group is telling its farmers’ stories and inviting consumers to tour member farms.
lead_paragraph: JANA McCLELLAND is a third-generation dairy farmer in Petaluma, Calif. This October, she expects 600 to 1,200 people to visit her family’s farm.

headline: Murdoch Brothers’ Challenge: What Happens Next at Fox News?
abstract: Since taking the reins of 21st Century Fox, James and Lachlan Murdoch have made changes big and small, but have largely left Fox News alone. Now they have little choice but to step in.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They have shaken up 21st Century Fox’s profile in Washington, replacing their father’s Republican lobbying chief with a Democratic one. They have jettisoned film executives, overhauled foreign TV operations and dug into the evolution of cable channels like National Geographic.

headline: Attack in Nice Turns Spotlight on City’s Religious Divisions
abstract: Muslims and non-Muslims have lived alongside each other in Nice for generations, but last week’s massacre has exacerbated tensions among residents.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — There is the Nice of popular imagination, the old-world resort dotted with palm trees and cafes that look out on the Mediterranean Sea, suffused with an incandescent light prized for centuries by artists.

headline: SoftBank Group Nears Deal to Buy ARM Holdings
abstract: While the negotiations are not yet final, the purchase of ARM, a British software company, could be the first large-scale transaction since Britain voted to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank is nearing a deal to acquire ARM Holdings, the British semiconductor company, said two people briefed on the matter who asked not to be named discussing private information.

headline: New York Public Hospitals Use Emojis to Reach Young People About Sex
abstract: The city’s public health system is using emojis like peaches and eggplants to encourage people ages 12 to 21 to seek care for sexual and reproductive health.
lead_paragraph: The birds and the bees are no longer confined to uncomfortable living-room conversations. They will start popping up as emojis in teenagers’ Facebook feeds on Monday.

headline: Scrambling, Planners of the Republican Convention Put ‘Showbiz’ Off to the Wings
abstract: Organizers of a program for a presidential candidate who is as much an entertainer as a politician had to deal with a lot of noes.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump was told, no, it was not sensible to have Don King, the flamboyant boxing promoter, address the Republican convention. But Mr. Trump, who has repeatedly boasted of having Mr. King’s support, kept pressing the matter.

headline: In Aggressive Deadline Deal, Red Sox Bet on Drew Pomeranz and Themselves
abstract: Boston activated Pomeranz on Sunday, sending veteran starter Clay Buchholz into the team’s bullpen. The Red Sox’ Sunday opponent, the Yankees, have yet to make a deadline decision.
lead_paragraph: In the visitors’ clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, the wide double lockers at certain corners of the room are usually reserved for star players and veterans.

headline: Mets’ Yoenis Cespedes Returns From Injury, Gladly Shifting Positions
abstract: Instead of his usual place in center field, Cespedes started in left, where he said he would like to continue to play.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Yoenis Cespedes, who had not started since July 8  because he had been nursing a strained right quadriceps, returned to the Mets’ lineup in a 5-0 win over the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, July 18, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The violence, the hatred just has to stop.”

headline: On Eve of G.O.P. Convention, Law and Order Takes the Floor
abstract: After three police officers were fatally shot in Louisiana, Donald J. Trump is likely to amplify his “law-and-order” campaign theme.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The attack on police officers in Baton Rouge, La., cast a grim mood over the opening of the Republican National Convention here, as Donald J. Trump responded to the killings with a stark warning that the country was falling apart.

headline: Two Olympians Need an Apology, Even if It Comes Years Too Late
abstract: In the 1968 Summer Olympics, John Carlos and Tommie Smith were suspended and sent home. Decades later, the U.S. Olympic Committee has yet to apologize.
lead_paragraph: The United States Olympic Committee owes John Carlos and Tommie Smith a long-overdue apology.

headline: Baton Rouge Attack Deepens Anguish for Police: ‘We’ve Seen Nothing Like This’
abstract: Law enforcement officials said it had been generations since the nation endured two separate episodes in which so many police officers were killed.
lead_paragraph: “Officer down!” an officer screamed frantically into his police radio Sunday morning in Baton Rouge, La. “Shots fired! Officer down!”

headline: ‘The Night Of’ Season 1, Episode 2: ‘You’re a Job to Him’
abstract: Naz’s case is a big get for Jack Stone, but the true stakes are for Naz and Naz alone. The machine will grind on no matter his fate.
lead_paragraph: “Friend of the family or right place, right time?”

headline: An International Reader’s Guide to the Republican Convention
abstract: A look at the American election by a Times foreign correspondent, approaching the topic in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.
lead_paragraph: Abroad in America, written by a Times foreign correspondent, approaches the election in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.

headline: The Second Anniversary of Eric Garner’s Death
abstract: In events around the region, protesters and those who were close to Eric Garner memorialized him and denounced the deaths of black people at the hands of police officers.
lead_paragraph: In events around the region, protesters and those who were close to Eric Garner memorialized him and denounced the deaths of black people at the hands of police officers.

headline: Anger Over Police Killings Pervades Memorials on 2nd Anniversary of Garner’s Death
abstract: To the people who turned out to memorialize Eric Garner on Sunday, it seemed that agonizingly little had changed.
lead_paragraph: The death of Eric Garner on Staten Island two years ago inflamed a nationwide debate over the treatment of blacks at the hands of law enforcement. To the people who turned out to march and memorialize him at events around the region on Sunday, it seemed that agonizingly little had changed.

headline: Yankees Answer the Call Behind a Well-Rested Masahiro Tanaka
abstract: Pitching on six days’ rest, Tanaka allowed one run and three hits in six innings as the Yankees earned their first win after the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: After Saturday’s 5-2 loss to the Boston Red Sox, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi hurried to his postgame news conference and then sat in uncomfortable silence in a mostly empty room as reporters trickled in. The delay may have allowed Girardi to parse his thoughts, which would become poignant and direct.

headline: Major League Baseball Prevails Upon Managers for Cooler Heads
abstract: The former Yankees manager Joe Torre, now a league executive, warned managers they would be fined for being ejected after arguing balls and strikes.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball wants managers to stop arguing with umpires over balls and strikes — and warned them not to rely on replays as grounds for their grumbling.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: The Republican National Convention begins. Can’t bear any more of real politics? There’s always “House of Cards” and “The West Wing.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump prepares to accept the presidential nomination as the Republican National Convention begins. Can’t bear another minute of real politics? Check out “House of Cards” or “The West Wing.” Or cross the Atlantic for some 1970s Brit-pop nostalgia with “Cradle to Grave.”

headline: What Tech Help Line?
abstract: A reader describes the steps tech companies need to take “to regain the respect of their customers.”

abstract: Educators expand on the idea of teacher residencies.

abstract: An British expatriate discusses what England gained from being part of the E.U.

headline: Kansas Zealot Helps Shape the G.O.P.’s Right-Wing Platform
abstract: A fervid ideologue and champion of voter I.D. laws has had major input in three planks of the Republican platform.
lead_paragraph: One of the most fervid ideologues expected at the Republican convention this week — the Kansas secretary of state, Kris Kobach — has been busy shaping extremist positions in the party platform to suppress immigration, gun controls and same-sex marriage. But he also found time last week to do actual damage to Kansans with a devious, 11th-hour policy that would disqualify 17,000 of them as state voters, even though they are allowed by law to vote in federal elections.

headline: Dealing With Sexism on Wall Street and Beyond
abstract: Two women describe their experiences, good and bad, working in the financial industry.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Countercoup in Turkey
abstract: While Turkish citizens appear to have chosen democracy, the man they kept in power is working hard against a democratic society.
lead_paragraph: It was ironic that, as members of the military launched a coup against him on Friday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey resorted to guerrilla media tactics — broadcasting via the FaceTime app on his cellphone — to urge Turks to oppose the plotters. Mr. Erdogan has been no friend to free expression, ruthlessly asserting control over the news media and restricting human rights and free speech. Yet thousands responded to his appeal, turning back the rebels and demonstrating that they still value democracy, even if Mr. Erdogan has eroded its meaning.

headline: All Roads Lead to Cleveland
abstract: The news has taken such a dark turn that politics almost feels like a welcome distraction.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: So, as we head into the Republican convention, Donald Trump has selected Mike Pence, the governor of Indiana, as his running mate. Before I get into my opinion, I know you’ve thought about him a lot, so how about a summary of your views?

headline: Mr. Obama’s Dubious Detention Centers
abstract: These privately run, unlicensed lockups are no place for children.
lead_paragraph: The family detention centers the Obama administration has been operating in Texas and Pennsylvania have been an expedient way to handle the soaring numbers of Central Americans, many of them young children, who have arrived at the Southern border since 2014. They give a sense that Homeland Security has the border situation under control, and they supposedly send a message to other would-be refugees not to come.

headline: Both Sides Now?
abstract: Many in the news media feel the need to set up a false equivalence between a candidate who lies repeatedly and his opponent.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump began his run for the White House, many people treated it as a joke. Nothing he has done or said since makes him look better. On the contrary, his policy ignorance has become even more striking, his positions more extreme, the flaws in his character more obvious, and he has repeatedly demonstrated a level of contempt for the truth that is unprecedented in American politics.

headline: The Class Politics of Decluttering
abstract: It’s only when you’re well off that you can afford to get rid of stuff.
lead_paragraph: Missoula, Mont. — SUDDENLY, decluttering is everywhere. It may have started with Marie Kondo and her mega-best seller, “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up,” but it has exploded into a mass movement, anchored in websites, seminars and — ironically — a small library’s worth of books about how to get rid of stuff.

headline: Trump’s Chance to Reboot
abstract: The Republican candidate has a golden opportunity at the convention to improve his standing with the voters, but don’t count on it.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican National Convention kicks off Monday, Donald Trump has a tremendous opportunity to rebrand and reboot his campaign, to make it look and feel more professional and less petulant.

headline: Confused by Contradictory Polls? Take a Step Back
abstract: There’s lots of presidential polling going on right now, and outliers are inevitable. But collectively, the picture is clearer.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rocky few weeks all over the world. Only a few surprising presidential poll results have broken through in a news cycle dominated by shootings by and of the police, the F.B.I.’s decision not to indict Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump’s vice-presidential pick, more terror in France and an attempted coup in Turkey.

headline: E.U. and U.S. Urge Erdogan to Show Restraint After Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: Even before the weekend’s events, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had represented a quandary for E.U. foreign ministers, who are meeting in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States and the European Union stepped up pressure on Monday on President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to not use an attempted coup as an excuse for an authoritarian crackdown.

headline: Why You Don’t Know Your Own Mind
abstract: Experiments in cognitive science, neuroimaging and social psychology are overturning a trope of philosophy.
lead_paragraph: It is often said that we can never truly know the minds of others, because we can’t “get inside their heads.” Our ability to know our own minds, though, is rarely called into question. It is assumed that your experience of your own consciousness clinches the assertion that you “know your own mind” in a way that no one else can. This is a mistake.

headline: Recalling Christ, Consumerism and Chile’s Coup
abstract: The ambrotypes of Mauricio Toro-Goya are dense tableaux that blend the graphic horrors of Chile’s post-coup repression with Christ’s passion.
lead_paragraph: The ambrotypes of Mauricio Toro-Goya are dense tableaux that blend the graphic horrors of Chile’s post-coup repression with Christ’s passion.

headline: Marie Kondo Mania
abstract: Are we overly obsessed with organization, or is a tidy life a happy life?

headline: Repeat After Me: Cold Does Not Increase Odds of Catching Cold
abstract: Enshrined in the very term we use for rhinovirus, it’s a myth that refuses to go away.
lead_paragraph: I’ve become somewhat known for medical myth-busting (having been a co-author of three books on the subject), so a fairly large number of emails sent to me are from people with articles or studies that they think prove me wrong.

headline: Republican Convention: Floor Fighting on Day 1
abstract: The floor of the convention turned into a scene of momentary discord and boisterous dissent as a faction of delegates tried to stage a last-ditch revolt against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Right Now: Follow our latest Day 2 coverage of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Convention Offers Donald Trump His Biggest Sales Opportunity
abstract: Mr. Trump can pitch himself to a skeptical electorate by showing discipline, detailed economic plans and the maturity to lead the nation, people in both parties say.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Republicans gathered for their 1968 convention in Miami Beach, they saw a new Richard Nixon, rising from defeat to appeal to an emerging coalition of voters upset with a country torn by political upheaval. Twenty years later, George Bush took the stage in New Orleans to calm Republicans suspicious of his conservative authenticity with a speech guaranteeing he would not raise taxes.

headline: Visiting Madagascar? Leave Red Swimsuits (and Lemur Recipes) at Home
abstract: Thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, are crucial to the identity and worldview of the Malagasy, but may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
lead_paragraph: If you visit a certain beach in northeastern Madagascar, don’t wear red and don’t even think of speaking French. Across most of the island nation, be very careful where you point, lest your finger accidentally find an ancestor’s grave. And in certain areas of the country, do your best not to defecate in the same place twice.

headline: In Choosing Mike Pence, Donald Trump Moves Closer to Big Donors Like the Kochs
abstract: Mr. Pence has relationships to donors aligned with the Koch brothers, along with many other big givers who have been reluctant to get behind Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: From his days as a dissident Republican congressman challenging President George W. Bush to his battles against his own party while governor of Indiana, Mike Pence has often relied on strong support from powerful allies: the conservative philanthropists David H. and Charles G. Koch and the vast political network they oversee.

As he weighed chemicals under a graduate student’s supervision, his father, James, a chemist at the University of Cincinnati, assembled glassware next to him, engrossed in his own experiment.

lead_paragraph: SOFTBANK TO BUY LEADING CHIP DESIGNER Softbank has agreed to buy ARM Holdings, the British chip designer, for $32 billion, Leslie Picker and Mark Scott report in DealBook.

lead_paragraph: With the Republican convention beginning in Cleveland with a theme of bringing law and order back to a fractured nation, Hillary Clinton told black leaders in Cincinnati on Monday that the country had “difficult, painful, essential work” ahead in rebuilding trust between African-Americans and police officers.

headline: Zika Data From the Lab, and Right to the Web

headline: Never-Trump Confidential
