lead_paragraph: The captain is at the controls, the tray tables are stowed, and nobody is smoking in the lavatories. We’ll be taking off shortly.

headline: Diary of an Editorial Cartoonist
abstract: Inspiration tends to find Patrick Chappatte at the kitchen table in his studio rather than at his desk: “It’s closer to the espresso machine.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Patrick Chappatte — whose editorial cartoons are published on Wednesdays and Saturdays in The Times’s international editions, on NYTimes.com and on its social media pages — treats us to a behind-the-scenes look at his creative process, from thought bubble to flatbed scanner, with a dark-chocolate-and-Nespresso fix somewhere in between.

headline: Hostage Standoff at Yerevan Police Building in Armenia Enters 2nd Day
abstract: Militants, who are possibly holding five people, demanded that the government resign and that it release an opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Militants who attacked a police building in the Armenian capital, Yerevan, killing one person, remained holed up with a number of hostages for a second day on Monday, demanding that the government resign and that it release an opposition leader.

headline: Kim Kardashian West and Kanye West Reignite Feud With Taylor Swift
abstract: Kim Kardashian West released snippets of a conversation between Kanye West and Ms. Swift in which he appears to get her support for lyrics that refer to her.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night’s episode of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” played less like a breezy record of the reality-star demimonde than a military-strategy documentary.

headline: Vast Purge in Turkey as Thousands Are Detained in Post-Coup Backlash
abstract: The Interior Ministry fired nearly 9,000 police officers on Monday, officials said, coming after the arrests of 6,000 military personnel and suspensions of nearly 3,000 judges.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government’s crackdown after a military coup attempt widened into a sweeping purge on Monday, cutting a swath through the security services and reaching deeply into the government bureaucracy and the political and business classes.

headline: 1916: Fears of a Pancho Villa Raid
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Fears of another Pancho Villa raid on the border in July 1916.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Warning has been received from high official sources in Mexico that it is probable that the bandit chief Pancho Villa, who is idolized by Northern Mexico for what is termed ‘‘his indomitable courage in saving Mexico from her ‘Gringo’ oppressors,’’ will soon attack General Pershing’s command. News coming through other channels indicates that Villa is contemplating another dash across the American border conducted along similar lines to the Columbus raid. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 19, 1916

headline: Gunman Stages Deadly Attack on Police Station in Kazakhstan
abstract: Three officers and two civilians were killed in Almaty, the country’s largest city, in an assault described as blending criminal and radical Islamist motivations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A gunman stormed a police station on Monday in Almaty, the largest city in Kazakhstan, and killed three officers and two civilians in an attack attributed to radical Islamist motivations.

headline: American Student, Nicolas Leslie, Died in Attack in Nice, France
abstract: Mr. Leslie, 20, a junior at the University of California, Berkeley, was an avid kite surfer and scuba diver who was fluent in Italian.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From the time he first got up on a surfboard (sometime around age 5), Nicolas Leslie seldom stood still.

headline: Campaign 2016: 365 Days in 3 Minutes
abstract: A brief look back at the 2016 presidential campaigns leading up to this year’s party conventions.
lead_paragraph: A brief look back at the 2016 presidential campaigns leading up to this year’s party conventions.

headline: The Aftermath of the Police Shooting in Baton Rouge
abstract: State and local law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge are investigating the fatal shooting of local police officers, as people across Louisiana mourn.
lead_paragraph: State and local law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge are investigating the fatal shooting of local police officers, as people across Louisiana mourn.

headline: An App to Deconstruct Your Food
abstract: Using yoga-posing pears and bike-riding melons, a new app deconstructs your food, giving you a trove of information not found on a typical food label.
lead_paragraph: Ever wondered how long you’d have to swim to burn off the calories in an organic peanut butter cup? Or how far the strawberries or burger on your plate traveled to get there?

headline: Russia May Face Olympics Ban as Doping Scheme Is Confirmed
abstract: The results of the investigation have led the World Anti-Doping Agency to call for the Russian federation to be barred from the Rio Olympics.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The world’s leading antidoping officials on Monday called for Russia to be barred from this summer’s Rio Games after a damning report confirmed a Russian whistle-blower’s claims of government-ordered cheating at the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

headline: Thrive Capital Raises $700 Million for Fifth Fund
abstract: With the new financing, the firm, known for early investments in companies like Instagram and Warby Parker, will be valued at just under $1.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Thrive Capital, which gained fame with early investments in technology darlings and then began incubating businesses like health insurers, is about to become bigger.

headline: Online Trail Illuminates Baton Rouge Gunman’s Path to Violence
abstract: The gunman, a Marine veteran, appears to have been obsessed with self-improvement, even as he spiraled toward an ambush that killed three officers.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — He joined the Marines, served in Iraq and earned a Good Conduct Medal. He was an entrepreneur, a self-published author, a nutrition and fitness counselor, a proponent of the American gospel of self-improvement. He considered himself a lifestyle coach, even though he had failed in marriage, neglected to pay his taxes and was, at one point, living on $500 per month. He had also embarked on a spiritual quest to find his roots as a black man, traveling around Africa for two years.

headline: What Makes Brazilians Sick
abstract: For local residents, “Olympic legacy” means living with Rio’s filthy water for decades after the athletes have left.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — As soon as I stepped out of Galeão International Airport, the stench hit me. Not the stench of political corruption — though Brazil has plenty of that to go around — but a bad smell like an open sewer.

headline: Leader’s Poems Grip Brazilians, but Not in a ‘Fiery Flames’ Way
abstract: Amid political turmoil, the poetry of Michel Temer has become a welcome source of amusement — and offers insight into the man now at the country’s helm.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Before becoming Brazil’s interim president, Michel Temer had a bit more free time on his hands. As a lawmaker shuttling between Brasília and São Paulo a few years ago, he found himself jotting his musings on cocktail napkins in airport lounges.

headline: A Pediatrician’s View on Gun Violence and Children
abstract: Pediatricians view guns and violence as a public health issue, which means talking to parents about how to keep their children safe, and looking for strategies — technological, behavioral and legal — to make everyone safer.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to consider gun violence a public health problem, especially when it comes to children?

headline: John Cho, Sulu of ‘Star Trek Beyond,’ Navigates a Beckoning Universe
abstract: The actor discusses the revelation that the Enterprise helmsman is gay, his response to stereotypical roles and his thoughts on future projects.
lead_paragraph: In “Star Trek Beyond,” the third film in the reimagined “Trek” universe, the helmsman Hikaru Sulu has a husband and a young daughter — but don’t expect the crew of the Enterprise to be as surprised as some fans were by the news that Sulu is gay.

headline: A Simple, Fuss-Free Swim Line, Made for the Water
abstract: Babes in Bathers is the brainchild of Maayan Sherris, who followed the women of the Columbia University swim team for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Babes in Bathers is the brainchild of Maayan Sherris, who followed the women of the Columbia University swim team for inspiration.

headline: Brand to Know: A Simple Swimwear Line — That Actually Celebrates Swimming
abstract: The just-launched Babes in Bathers was inspired, in part, by the women of Columbia University’s swim team.
lead_paragraph: Swimsuits should be made for swimming — yet surprisingly few on the market actually are. Unlike many lines, the just-debuted Babes in Bathers, founded by 27-year-old Maayan Sherris, not only facilitates swimming, but celebrates it. The brand evolved out of a passion project that Sherris, a recent Parsons graduate and former employee at The Row, began last year when she shadowed the Columbia University women’s swim team for months in search of inspiration. “I had this idea of using real women and real situations to provoke fashion and original beauty,” she says. Sherris chose to focus on female swimmers in part because she’d always been fascinated by water (the element served as a springboard for her Parsons thesis collection) and in part because she’d always found swimmers’ bodies to be quite beautiful. “I always thought female swimmers didn’t get enough attention in terms of the way they look,” she says. “The bodies of male swimmers are idolized; women who play sports, their bodies are often considered distorted.”

headline: England’s Legacy With Brexit
abstract: The vote rests on nothing but a passing phase in public opinion, and it is entirely unburdened by the responsibility of implementation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Learning From the Past After Brexit
abstract: The European Union came about, in no small part, to stop the ancient cycle of war that had beset Europe for millenniums.

headline: Ground Ibérico Pork Sliders to Sizzle at Home
abstract: Fry them in a heavy skillet, then use the residual fat to cook potatoes.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes this column prompts me to discard personal shibboleths like: Never buy pre-made hamburger patties. I could not resist these simple, chubby sliders made mostly of excellent ground Ibérico pork from Spanish pigs that feast on acorns. Modest salt and generous black pepper stoke the meaty flavor. Let them sizzle on a grill, or better yet, in a heavy pan so you get an ample pool of fat for frying potatoes. You’ll want them cooked to medium before tucking them into little buns. An appropriate garnish would be slices of piquillo pepper: Ibérico de Bellota pork sliders, six (one pound) for $19.95 (shipped frozen), tienda.com.

headline: Merkel, ‘Conservative’?
abstract: The German chancellor’s party is called “conservative,” which even by European standards is absurd.

abstract: Clemens, 53, heads a list of former major league players who plan to play for the Kansas Stars in the tournament in Wichita, Kan.

headline: A Hunger Crisis in the L.G.B.T. Community
abstract: The affluence of several prominent figures masks a bleak reality: Many people in the L.G.B.T. community go hungry, a new report shows.
lead_paragraph: Gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Americans are more visible than ever before. Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, and the talk show host Ellen DeGeneres are gay. Kate Brown of Oregon is the first openly bisexual governor. The Olympic gold medalist and transgender woman Caitlyn Jenner has a reality show.

headline: Le Corbusier’s Work Added to Heritage List

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Black Currant and Blueberry Juice From Red Jacket Orchards
abstract: For mixing with iced tea, adding to sparkling wine or offering to a teetotaler.
lead_paragraph: Last year when Red Jacket Orchards in Geneva, N.Y., introduced its black currant and blueberry juice, or “stomp,” as they call it, it was gone in a flash. This season, the tart deep-purple juice is back and more available. Mix it with iced tea, pour it into a teetotaler’s wineglass or add a splash to sparkling wine. It’s cold-pressed, unfiltered and flash-pasteurized with no additives. And, unlike many of the juices and nectars made by Red Jacket, it uses only a little bit of apple juice for sweetening: Black-n-Blue Stomp, black currant and blueberry juice, $35.50 for three 1-quart bottles, $37 for six 12-ounce bottles, Red Jacket Orchards, redjacketorchards.com.

headline: WADA Investigation of Sochi Allegations
abstract: The report by Richard McLaren, a Canadian lawyer commissioned by WADA, confirmed “beyond a reasonable doubt” that Russia was involved in an elaborate doping scheme that stretched beyond the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: The report by Richard McLaren, a Canadian lawyer commissioned by WADA, confirmed “beyond a reasonable doubt” that Russia was involved in an elaborate doping scheme that stretched beyond the Sochi Games.

headline: Salmon Tales
abstract: Notes from Alaska, a few recipes and some suggested reading.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Reasons to Believe the A.I. Boom Is Real
abstract: To determine why artificial intelligence is booming now, it’s helpful to look at the recent growth of search engines, social media and mobile technology.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence is booming. But why now?

headline: 1966: Kremlin Won’t Help U.S. Pilots
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In July 1966, the Kremlin rejects a British plea for Soviet intervention to save captured U.S. pilots in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin today [July 18] rejected a plea from British Prime Minister Harold Wilson for Soviet intervention to save captured U.S. pilots from being tried as war criminals by North Vietnam. The rejection was announced by the Soviet Foreign Ministry at an unusual late-night press conference. Mr. Wilson also failed in efforts to persuade Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin to join Britain in calling for new negotiations on Vietnam, British sources disclosed. Press chief Leonid Zamyatin said that U.S. pilots in Hanoi ‘‘must account fully for the international banditry of the United States.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1966

headline: Pies in Prospect Heights
abstract: Trading corporate marketing for pies, the baker Meghan Daly serves more than a dozen varieties at her new shop.
lead_paragraph: From business to baking: the career trajectory is familiar. Meghan Daly, 34, grew up in Vermont making pies with her mother, and thought for years about what work might joyfully replace her job in corporate marketing. Five years ago, she quit and began baking and selling pies to friends and in street markets. She opened her own bakery cafe in late June, with a roster of more than a dozen pies, about half of them available on any given day, as well as individual hand pies. Lately she has been featuring fruit flavors like peach-blackberry-ginger in an all-butter lattice crust: Pies $30 to $35, $5 to $6 per slice; hand pies $3.50, Daly Pie, 665 Vanderbilt Avenue (Park Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 347-425-9251, dalypie.com.

headline: Another Baltimore Police Officer Acquitted in Freddie Gray Case
abstract: After four trials, Baltimore prosecutors have not secured a conviction against any officers in the death of Mr. Gray last year after a ride in a police van.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It was the third straight acquittal, by the same judge, on the same set of facts: On Monday, Lt. Brian Rice, the highest-ranking Baltimore police officer charged in the death of Freddie Gray, was found not guilty of three charges, including involuntary manslaughter.

headline: Making Siri Spell Your Name Right
abstract: Apple’s virtual assistant has the ability to learn as it works, but you have ways to correct some of its common mistakes to speed up the process.
lead_paragraph: Q. The Siri app on my iPhone spells my name incorrectly when I talk to it and it transcribes its response back. How can I fix this?

headline: Suspect in Police Shootings in Baton Rouge Filed Name Change
abstract: Gavin Long, the man suspected of killing three police officers in Baton Rouge, La. on Sunday, filed a form in 2015 in Jackson County, Mo., to change his name to Cosmo Ausar Setepenra, a name freighted with ancient Egyptian references.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Long, the man suspected of killing three police officers in Baton Rouge, La. on Sunday, filed a form in 2015 in Jackson County, Mo., to change his name to Cosmo Ausar Setepenra, a name freighted with ancient Egyptian references.

headline: Trump Campaign Denounces John Kasich in Ohio, Where Convention Begins
abstract: Paul Manafort, Mr. Trump’s de facto campaign manager, accused Mr. Kasich, the Ohio governor, of acting “petulant” for refusing to support Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump’s chief adviser used the first day of the Republican National Convention on Monday to excoriate Gov. John R. Kasich for not endorsing Mr. Trump, touching off a remarkably bitter exchange between the campaign of the presumptive Republican nominee and advisers to Ohio’s popular Republican governor.

headline: 4 Small-Batch Gins, One for Each Season of the Year
abstract: Not in the dry London style; rather, floral, spicy, earthy or a little sweet.
lead_paragraph: At Brandywine Branch Distillers in Chester County, Pa., Riannon Walsh has started making small-batch seasonal gins. Calling them Revivalist Gins, each of the four has a seasonally appropriate flavor profile from the botanicals and spices with which they’re infused. None even approximate an austere London dry style. For summer, the Summertide Expression is light and floral, with whispers of mint and juniper; Harvest Expression, for fall, has a spicy, woodsy scent to brighten a martini. The wintry Solstice Expression has a gray tint and is earthy with juniper and burnt orange; it would add personality to a Negroni. And the Equinox Expression for spring is mild, delicate and brushed with sweetness: Revivalist Gins, $41.75 to $50.95 for 750 milliliters, brandywinebranchdistillers.com.

headline: To Carve a Watermelon, or Even a Cake
abstract: This knife will slice, then flipped, will serve.
lead_paragraph: One-purpose gadgets do not appeal to me, but this one works too well to pass up. Tuscan craftsmen specializing in stainless steel produced this double scythe-like knife for cutting and serving watermelon. Plunge it, curved side up, into half a melon near the edge, drag it along until you reach the other side, then reverse it, curved side down, to lift out a slice. It will work on a quartered melon, too, and even on a big cake: Angurello Watermelon Slicer and Server, $19.95, thegrommet.com.

headline: A Four Seasons Restaurant Memory You Can Take Home With You
abstract: No need to steal an ashtray when you can buy one at auction.
lead_paragraph: By the time you read this, the famed Four Seasons restaurant will be just a memory. But there is a chance to take a piece of it home. All the furnishings, tableware and other accouterments, from tiny ashtrays to classic Barcelona chairs, will be sold at auction by Wright, a company based in Chicago. Until then, starting July 20, there will be a wake, with the items on view at the restaurant, and you will be able to see its landmark interior: Pre-auction viewing, July 20, 1 to 6 p.m.; July 21 through July 24, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; July 25, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Auction July 26 at 10 a.m.; The Four Seasons, 99 East 52nd Street, wright20.com.

headline: U.S. Team Wins First Place at International Math Olympiad
abstract: The U.S. team has won the 2016 International Math Olympiad. Try two problems from this year’s test, moderated by U.S. Coach Po-Shen Loh.
lead_paragraph: The United States has won the 57th International Mathematical Olympiad, the world’s most prestigious problem-solving competition for high school students.

headline: When Is Peach Season? It’s a Bit Fuzzy
abstract: Rules are meant to be broken, and the latest is an adage on when to eat a peach.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Purvis, the Southern food writer most likely to let you know when you have something wrong, made a peach declaration on Facebook a couple of weeks ago.

headline: Funding for Internships
abstract: We should leverage the power of social media to make these opportunities more accessible, a university provost says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘I Feel a Deep Sense of Remorse,’ Donald Trump’s Ghostwriter Says
abstract: Tony Schwartz, in his first public interview about “The Art of the Deal,” tells The New Yorker he regrets presenting Mr. Trump as “more appealing than he is.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has regularly boasted about “The Art of the Deal,” his best-selling autobiography, as a business bible that demonstrates the sharp negotiating prowess he would bring to the presidency. The book, released in 1987, details his rise to the top of New York’s real estate world; it helped spawn his career as a reality television star and cemented his image as a winner with a golden touch.

headline: Moment of Silence Turns Into Outcry Against Government After Nice Attack
abstract: Anger in connection with the Nice attack is a product of accumulated frustration with the French government’s response to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The moment of silence on Monday for the victims of Thursday’s attack in Nice ended abruptly as boos and jeers rose from the crowd of thousands filling the Promenade des Anglais, where 84 people had been killed. The object of the derision was Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who had arrived flanked by national and local political leaders to pay his respects.

headline: Historians Sound an Alarm About Donald Trump
abstract: Historians defend their criticism of the candidate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Photographs From Tuesday at the Republican National Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 7 to Debut Later
abstract: HBO added that this popular drama’s 2017 season will contain seven episodes, three fewer than previous years.
lead_paragraph: The next season of “Game of Thrones” will debut a little later than normal and, as expected, it will be a little shorter.

headline: An Unintended Summer Morsel
abstract: If the ants that infest my kitchen in summer are inadvertently swallowed, are they likely to be harmful?
lead_paragraph: Q. If the ants that infest my kitchen in summer are inadvertently swallowed, are they likely to be harmful?

headline: SoftBank’s Deal With ARM Is a Financial Stretch
abstract: The Japanese conglomerate’s purchase of the British chip designer looks like a gamble that web-connected devices will be a far bigger deal than most are expecting.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank’s $32.2 billion offer for the British chip designer ARM Holdings is a big bet on the “internet of things.”

headline: Donald Trump’s Safe Choice for No. 2 Frees Hillary Clinton’s Hand, Strategists Say
abstract: The choice of Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, a far-right conservative, eases pressure on Hillary Clinton to make an adventurous choice for vice president, strategists say.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As Hillary Clinton prepares to announce her running mate later this week, the political calculations have suddenly changed.

headline: ‘America’s Moment of Reckoning’: Readers on Trump’s Language of Resistance
abstract: An article on Donald J. Trump’s appeal to white nationalists had readers debating working class struggles, ‘white privilege’ and the melting pot philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Few topics touch so raw a nerve in American politics as race. Readers made that clear after  our article about the ways that Donald J. Trump has reshaped how white Americans talk about their racial identity — and the grievances that sometimes come entangled with it.

headline: What You Should Watch: Long-Running Shows to Get Totally Lost In
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our upcoming website.

headline: Photographs From the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: Too Many Deer on the Road? Let Cougars Return, Study Says
abstract: A repopulation of cougars in the Eastern U.S., with their steady diet of deer, could reduce the number of lives lost to deer-automobile collisions.
lead_paragraph: What large mammal regularly kills humans in the Eastern United States?

headline: In Istanbul, Optimism Fades to a Familiar Melancholy
abstract: The coup attempt showed Istanbul to be perhaps Turkey’s most important city, but it is enveloped by a deep unease about terrorism, refugees and gentrification.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When the army cut off traffic in Istanbul on Friday night by shutting two bridges in the opening moments of a coup, the municipality ordered ferries to work overtime. City trucks blocked roads near army barracks. Buses and subways operated free of charge, and local officials and mosque preachers helped mobilize government supporters to the streets.

headline: Zika Virus Case in Utah Baffles Health Officials
abstract: A “family contact“ of an infected man who died last month got the virus but has fully recovered.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In another puzzling twist to the Zika epidemic, the Utah Department of Health on Monday reported the diagnosis of a new case of the virus that did not appear to have been contracted through either of the known sources of transmission: a mosquito bite or sexual contact.

headline: Shooter Background Visuals
abstract: Gavin Long
lead_paragraph: Gavin Long

headline: The Baton Rouge Shooter, Gavin Long, Saw World ‘Run by Devils’
abstract: Hundreds of online videos, podcasts and social media posts reveal Gavin Long as a man who saw himself as the devils’ feared enemy, and who talked of a need for revolution.
lead_paragraph: Recent posts on social media by Gavin Long, the Marine veteran who fatally shot three law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday morning, show a man with a paranoid and political message, describing a world “run by devils,” imagining himself as their feared enemy and talking of a need for revolution.

headline: Moment of Silence for Nice Victims
abstract: French leaders held a moment of silence in Nice, France, on Monday to honor the victims of last week's attack. Eighty-four people were killed and dozens more injured when a truck plowed through a crowd on Bastille Day.
lead_paragraph: French leaders held a moment of silence in Nice, France, on Monday to honor the victims of last week's attack. Eighty-four people were killed and dozens more injured when a truck plowed through a crowd on Bastille Day.

headline: Confronting a Lingering Question About Zika: How It Enters the Womb
abstract: Zika, unlike most viruses that infect pregnant women, is able to cross from the bloodstream through the placenta, and scientists think they are closer to finding out why.
lead_paragraph: As scientists learn more about how the Zika virus can cause brain damage in a developing fetus, a major question has remained: How does a virus that infects a pregnant mother through a mosquito bite on her skin get into her womb?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Hotlines Faster Than Hospitals in Pinpointing Dengue, Study Says
abstract: Calls to public health hotlines in Pakistan confirmed outbreaks two or three weeks earlier, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Calls to public health hotlines can predict dengue fever outbreaks two or three weeks earlier than local hospitals can confirm them, according to a new study from Pakistan.

headline: Turning the Call for Racial Reckonings Back on the U.S.
abstract: The United States endorses truth and reconciliation processes elsewhere, but with its history of slavery, perhaps it’s time for one of its own.
lead_paragraph: The terror and death and protest and racial resentment in the United States have revived an old question: Does the United States need to join South Africa, Cambodia, Rwanda and others in pursuing a truth and reconciliation process?

headline: Donald Trump’s Convention: Day 1
abstract: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.
lead_paragraph: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.

headline: Microsoft Case Shows the Limits of a Data Privacy Law
abstract: An appeals court decision dealt a blow to government efforts to obtain emails stored overseas, mainly because laws have not kept up with technology.
lead_paragraph: The battle over the privacy of electronic communications sought in government investigations shifted against the Justice Department last week.

headline: Drake’s ‘Views’ Returns to No. 1
abstract: This album has now been at the top of the Billboard album chart for 10 nonconsecutive weeks, after yielding last week to Blink-182’s “California.”
lead_paragraph: After an absence of just one week Drake is back at No.1 on the Billboard album chart.

headline: Peaceful Dueling Protests So Far as G.O.P. Convention Begins
abstract: An anti-Trump group and a pro-Trump group held rallies in Cleveland on Monday afternoon near the site of the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The start of the Republican National Convention on Monday instantly inspired dueling protests, with both supporters and critics of Donald J. Trump pressing their cases in neighboring demonstrations as Republicans strained to project party unity.

headline: A Sundress in an Age of Riot Gear
abstract: What’s striking in iconic photographs of demonstrators is the everyday clothes.
lead_paragraph: IN the days before yesterday’s killing of three officers by a gunman in Baton Rouge, La., a remarkable image surfaced that captured the protests over the shooting of Alton Sterling in that city on July 5. It communicated more powerfully, and globally, than any other the standoff between aggression and civility in the current turmoil around race relations in America: that of the woman in the summer dress.

headline: The GOP’s Original Sin
abstract: Charlatans and cranks since 1980.
lead_paragraph: Norm Ornstein has a piece in Vox laying out, once again, his (and Mann’s) thesis that the GOP went off the rails, becoming a radical party with little regard for truth, a long time ago. He’s right, of course; I’ve been saying much the same thing since the early 2000s, notably in the introduction to my book The Great Unraveling.

headline: Shaun Hergatt’s Next Restaurant: Elevated and Exclusive
abstract: The former chef of Juni will open a private restaurant for the residents of a new 96-story tower on Park Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The chef Shaun Hergatt, whose Michelin-starred Juni closed in May, will open a restaurant this fall on the 12th floor of 432 Park Avenue, a 96-story tower that, though already open, will become the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere when it’s completed.

headline: At Age 75, the Moscow Mule Gets Its Kick Back
abstract: The cocktail in the copper mug is enjoying a revival, with help from the vodka industry.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, I attended a seminar on the history of vodka at Tales of the Cocktail, the annual New Orleans convention. The moderator mentioned a cocktail named the Moscow Mule as “the drink that started it all” — that is, vodka’s popularity in the United States. Invented in 1941, the drink was a mix of vodka, lime juice and ginger beer, typically served in a copper mug.

headline: So That’s Who You Call: The Politics of the New ‘Ghostbusters’
abstract: The New York Times critics Manohla Dargis, A.O. Scott and Wesley Morris discuss the prerelease outcry, how the original film wasn’t that amazing and Kate McKinnon’s greatness.
lead_paragraph: The rebooted “Ghostbusters,” starring Kristen Wiig, Melissa McCarthy, Leslie Jones and Kate McKinnon as an all-female squad of ectoplasm fighters, sold $46 million worth of tickets in North America over the weekend, making it the second-best earning film behind “The Secret Life of Pets.” But even before any tickets had been sold, “Ghostbusters” was already surely the most argued-about movie of the year, attacked by angry male fans on the internet and hailed as a new milestone in Hollywood diversity. Wesley Morris, critic at large for The New York Times, joins its chief film critics Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott to survey the state of the debate now that people have actually seen the movie. The discussion may include spoilers.

headline: The 3 Officers Killed in Baton Rouge
abstract: The officers who died Sunday in the attack in Louisiana were a new father, a Marine and Army veteran, and a lawman whose mantra was “People First.”
lead_paragraph: One officer had just become a father. Another had been a police officer in Baton Rouge, La., for less than a year. A third left behind four children. All three were married.

headline: The Whole World Is Watching
abstract: The Times’s national political correspondent Jonathan Martin examines how protests have shaped the history of national political conventions ever since Chicago in 1968.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s national political correspondent Jonathan Martin examines how protests have shaped the history of national political conventions ever since Chicago in 1968.

headline: South African Telescope Spots 1,300 Unknown Galaxies
abstract: The distant galaxies were recorded by a set of 16 antennas that will eventually be a part of the largest telescope ever built on Earth.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers from South Africa on Saturday revealed more than a thousand galaxies nobody knew existed. They were showing off the first taste of the ultimate cosmic feast of what is to come, at least as seen from this particular dusty crumb called Earth.

headline: SoftBank-ARM Deal Brings Together Morgan Stanley Alumni
abstract: Among those directing the ARM acquisition is Alok Sama, a former Morgan Stanley banker who is now SoftBank’s chief financial officer and president.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s another reunion of Morgan Stanley alumni.

headline: Rangers Send Derick Brassard to Ottawa for Mika Zibanejad
abstract: The Rangers made their first major move of the off-season, trading Brassard, a center who was second on the team in scoring last season.
lead_paragraph: Just 14 months after he was acquired from the Columbus Blue Jackets in a multiplayer deal, Derick Brassard helped the Rangers roll into the 2014 Stanley Cup finals. As a reward, Brassard received a five-year, $25 million contract, and it appeared as if he would be in New York for at least that long.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Father’s Place
abstract: A reader urges more father engagement — a “Daddying Movement” — to benefit kids and dads alike. Readers are invited to respond.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Police and Race: A Time of Tension
abstract: Readers discuss recent shootings of police officers in Baton Rouge and Dallas after police killings of black men.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Slovenian Roots of Melania Trump
abstract: A look at the life of Ms. Trump before she married the man who would dominate the 2016 Republican presidential primary season.
lead_paragraph: A look at the life of Ms. Trump before she married the man who would dominate the 2016 Republican presidential primary season.

headline: Melania Trump: From Small-Town Slovenia to Doorstep of White House
abstract: Growing up in Sevnica under a Communist regime, Ms. Trump showed a determination to move ahead in the world, according to friends and acquaintances from her youth.
lead_paragraph: SEVNICA, Slovenia — On days when Melanija Knavs could not play outside or grew tired of knitting her navy blue sweaters, she and her friends would exchange notes along the lines of yarn they strung between their apartment block balconies.

headline: Fox News’s Convention Moment Overshadowed by Struggle Over Ailes’s Fate
abstract: As speculation swirled that the Murdoch family had decided Roger Ailes must leave, the company issued a statement that the matter was “not yet resolved.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — This was supposed to be Fox News Channel’s big week, a time to flex its muscles and flaunt its ratings dominance as the long-reigning media king of the Republican National Convention.

headline: In His Final Tour de France, Fabian Cancellara Falls Short of a Win at Home
abstract: Cancellara was cheered on as the local Swiss hero on a route he knows well, but Peter Sagan narrowly won the stage in a sprint. Chris Froome retained the overall lead.
lead_paragraph: BERN, Switzerland — Monday was supposed to be Fabian Cancellara’s day during his final Tour de France before retirement. If nothing else, the day’s route appeared tailored for him. Its most difficult feature — a steep, tricky climb and descent in central Bern — is part of a route he uses from his home here to training rides.

headline: Britain’s Kookiest Rituals, Shot in the ’70s
abstract: From chasing cheese to publicly weighing a newly elected official, the photographer Homer Sykes captured some of the country’s most far-out traditions.
lead_paragraph: From chasing cheese to publicly weighing a newly elected official, the photographer Homer Sykes captured some of the country’s most far-out traditions.

headline: Oddball British Rituals, in Playful Vintage Photos
abstract: Homer Sykes spent seven years documenting the unusual annual traditions — feasts, festivals and celebrations — of villages around the country.
lead_paragraph: A town mayor perched on a weighing scale; men dressed as clowns, dancing in the street; a crowd pursuing a rolling cheese down a hillside: At first glance, it’s not entirely clear what’s going on in this arresting series of early-70s images by the British photographer Homer Sykes, who spent seven years documenting obscure annual traditions taking place in communities around Britain. The resulting photos show people at their most eccentric, acting out customs — from symbolic spring rituals to harvest festivals — that often date back several centuries.

headline: Trevor Noah’s First Convention
abstract: At his first convention as host of “The Daily Show,” Trevor Noah talks to The New York Times about whether Donald Trump will appear on his show and the role of comedy in uniting the country.
lead_paragraph: At his first convention as host of “The Daily Show,” Trevor Noah talks to The New York Times about whether Donald Trump will appear on his show and the role of comedy in uniting the country.

headline: How Gena Rowlands Met John Cassavetes
abstract: The actress recounts her early days at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts with the director with whom she’d eventually make 10 films — and a life.
lead_paragraph: “I was always very lucky,” Gena Rowlands insists. “But I didn’t necessarily deserve it.” It’s an idea that the 86-year-old actress, currently in New York to present a series of films she made with her first husband John Cassavetes, returns to again and again. When asked about her career, which includes major successes on stage and on screen in films like “A Woman Under the Influence” and “Opening Night,” her responses take the form of screwball anecdotes imbued with an aw-shucks innocence suggestive of her Midwestern roots: Things just happened. She was fortunate to be in the right place at the right time.

headline: Videos of the G.O.P. Convention
abstract: The Republican National Convention began in Cleveland on Monday. Watch our full video coverage.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Convention began in Cleveland on Monday. Watch our full video coverage.

headline: To France From Israel: Lessons on Living With Terror
abstract: A truck plowing through a crowd in Nice? Israeli citizens, security officials and experts say they’ve lived with, and planned for, such threats for decades.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For many Israelis, the horrifying images of a truck plowing through crowds for more than a mile in the French resort town of Nice struck a macabrely familiar chord.

headline: 5 Surprising Trends From a Month of Men's Fashion
abstract: A look back at the men’s wear trends that emerged on the runways of the fashion capitals.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the men’s wear trends that emerged on the runways of the fashion capitals.

headline: Theresa May Wins Vote to Renew Britain’s Nuclear Program
abstract: The new prime minister gained approval from Parliament to authorize and update the weapons system, a move intended as a signal that Britain remains a world power.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Theresa May, in her first major parliamentary appearance since taking office last week, won a vote on Monday to authorize and update Britain’s nuclear arsenal, a move intended to underscore the nation’s commitment to remaining a global power despite its recent decision to leave the European Union.

headline: Gavin Long’s ‘War’ on ‘The System’
abstract: In the thirteenth of his 15 podcasts on his website, Convos With Cosmo, Mr. Long rails against “haters,” including ”government agents,” who he says prevent others from improving themselves.
lead_paragraph: In the thirteenth of his 15 podcasts on his website, Convos With Cosmo, Mr. Long rails against “haters,” including ”government agents,” who he says prevent others from improving themselves.

headline: How the Internet Saved Turkey’s Internet-Hating President
abstract: Who would have guessed that free online communication would come to Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s rescue?
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — When I was stuck at the airport in this city in southern Turkey, on Friday night, I had many things to worry about. A coup attempt had just begun and the country was in turmoil. My plane to Istanbul had almost flown into the worst of the fighting, but luckily we were prevented from taking off at the last minute when the airspace was closed.

headline: Shuna Lydon, Cooking for Artists
abstract: The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation’s first chef-in-residence shares her photo diary of the first few weeks in Captiva, Florida.
lead_paragraph: The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation’s first chef-in-residence shares her photo diary of the first few weeks in Captiva, Florida.

headline: Cooking for Artists at the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation
abstract: The institution’s first chef-in-residence, a French Laundry alum most recently located in Brooklyn, shares her photo diary of the experience.
lead_paragraph: Shuna Lydon has just finished cleaning up the weekly Friday brunch she prepares for 23 people and is off to walk Suzy the Dog, her sole companion at the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation in Captiva, Florida. For the last three months, she has been installed as that institution’s first chef-in-residence, cooking for the staff and visiting artists-in-residence. She’s also there to answer a personal question: “What is it that feeds me about being a professional cook?” Her tenure will last through the end of the year, but she’s already begun to find answers. “It’s a magnificent opportunity,” the pastry chef and restaurant veteran says, “to get back to the real basics of cooking; you’re making lunch and dinner. It’s not about being fancy. Some of these artists are doing really physical work in their field — sometimes it’s like feeding a bunch of workmen. They’re hungry.”

headline: Steven Spielberg Among 16 Selected as Academy Governors
abstract: Two African-Americans were elected to the governing board, increasing the number of black members to three.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Steven Spielberg will join the governing board of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, among 16 returning or new governors elected to three-year terms, the academy said on Monday.

headline: After 2 Years, Progress Is Hard to See in Some Struggling City Schools
abstract: With a deadline next year in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s $400 million initiative to turn around New York’s troubled schools, much is on the line.
lead_paragraph: At one troubled Brooklyn high school, the principal stepped down this month — after clashing with the teachers’ union — “for my own sanity,” she said. At another, the principal resigned  to go back to an easier job. And at still another, in Queens, the principal — the fifth in five years — wrote an end-of-the-year letter to the staff calling the place “the Hunger Game for Principals.”

headline: Why Yahoo Sold Its Internet Business
abstract: The internet giant struggled for more than a decade to find a winning strategy. Now it is giving up, selling its core business to Verizon for a small fraction of what it was worth at its height in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The internet giant struggled for more than a decade to find a winning strategy. Now it is giving up, selling its core business to Verizon for a small fraction of what it was worth at its height in 2000.

headline: Ken-David Masur, Back at Tanglewood, Feels His Father’s Spirit
abstract: Mr. Masur conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood on Saturday, filling in for Christoph von Dohnanyi.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — When the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced last week that Ken-David Masur would conduct its concert here at Tanglewood on Saturday evening, replacing Christoph von Dohnanyi, it seemed time to check on the state of Mr. Masur’s career.

headline: News Crackdown in Kashmir Leaves Locals ‘Surrounded by Rumors’
abstract: The authorities have blocked the mobile internet, prepaid cellphones and cable television stations, and banned the publication of newspapers.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The security lockdown in the Kashmir valley has hurt business badly, but Gulam Rasool still opens up his small grocery in Srinagar for a few hours each day.

headline: Haruki Nakamura's Complaint
abstract: Haruki Nakamura, who played defensive back for five seasons with the Baltimore Ravens and Carolina Panthers, is seeking $3 million from Lloyd's of London.
lead_paragraph: Haruki Nakamura, who played defensive back for five seasons with the Baltimore Ravens and Carolina Panthers, is seeking $3 million from Lloyd's of London.

headline: Review: In Megan Abbott’s ‘You Will Know Me,’ Gymnast Girl and Cute Dead Guy
abstract: Megan Abbott’s cunning new novel focuses on a teenage girl, sacrificing too much for the Olympics, and a tragic hit-and-run.
lead_paragraph: What Megan Abbott knows, as so many maestros of the heebie-jeebies do, is that it’s not strangers who are scary; it’s the people you think you know and love. That imperturbable spouse? Quite perturbable, actually. That angelic child? A vault of secrets. Those friends and relations you welcome with your arms outstretched? Not always worthy of your trust.

headline: ‘Shooter’ on USA Postponed Again After Baton Rouge Attack
abstract: Delayed after a gunman attack on Dallas police officers, the series was postponed indefinitely after a similar event in Baton Rouge.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive week, real-world gun violence has forced a delay in the debut of USA’s new series about an ex-sniper, this time indefinitely.

headline: Trial Balloons in Cleveland
abstract: The Times’s senior editor for operations, Walter Baranger, is in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention and sent this video along.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Convention opens today. A total of 2,472 delegates descend on Cleveland. And 100 naked protesting women. And teams of reporters, editors and broadcasters.

headline: U.S. Investigates Fiat Chrysler Over Sales Figures
abstract: The S.E.C. is asking whether the automaker has improperly inflated its monthly vehicle sales totals, potentially misleading investors.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has been on a hot streak for more than six years, reporting growth in new car sales in the United States for 75 consecutive months, a feat rarely seen in the auto industry.

headline: Street Style: Pitchfork Music Festival
abstract: The photographer Drew Anthony Smith documents the looks on some of the fans and artists at the festival in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Drew Anthony Smith documents the looks on some of the fans and artists at the festival in Chicago.

headline: A Dreaded Forecast for Our Times: Algae, and Lots of It
abstract: Projections of potentially dangerous and costly algal blooms may become as common as weather reports, but first scientists need more funding.
lead_paragraph: Every Thursday night, Bill Korbel, a veteran meteorologist, offers his standard weather forecast to viewers on a Long Island cable channel. Then he follows up with his outlook for toxic algae.

headline: Miles of Algae and a Multitude of Hazards
abstract: Algal blooms that have recently hit southeastern Florida waters are the latest of such environmental disasters that have hit with increasing frequency.
lead_paragraph: The stench of decaying algae began rising from coastal waterways in southeastern Florida early this month, shutting down businesses and beaches during a critical tourism season. Officials arrived, surveyed the toxic muck and declared states of emergency in four counties. Residents shook their heads, then their fists, organizing rallies and haranguing local officials.

headline: In ‘Hindutva or Hind Swaraj,’ a Warning Against Hindu Nationalism
abstract: A political tract by U. R. Ananthamurthy, a novelist and political commentator, still resonates in India as a remainder of the perils of an ideology.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — The last months of U. R. Ananthamurthy’s life were tumultuous. One of India’s foremost novelists and political commentators, Mr. Ananthamurthy, who died in August 2014 at 81, had threatened to leave the country if Narendra Modi, then leading the nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, won the vote in the national election. Mr. Ananthamurthy’s remarks drew vitriol, abuse and death threats from Mr. Modi’s supporters, and he remained under round-the-clock police protection for months.

headline: This Famous Art Was Hidden in a Shed for 16 Years
abstract: Harry Bertoia’s sculpture “Free Interpretation of Plant Forms” will move to the Woodmere Art Museum in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In a yard full of police tow trucks in North Philadelphia, a massive green sculpture of copper pipe and welded bronze sits outside a vehicle workshop, its extravagant curves forming a startling contrast to the gritty surroundings.

headline: Review: ‘The Execution of Mrs. Cotton’ Is More Erratic Than Rollicking
abstract: A nurse turned angel of death leaves behind a trail of poisoned husbands, lovers and children as she makes her way through the post-Civil War South.
lead_paragraph: It’s not much of a spoiler to reveal that the murderer in “The Execution of Mrs. Cotton” meets her maker. There is that title, after all, and the fact that the entire play takes place under a noose looming over a wooden platform.

headline: ‘That’s a Thing I Did’: Aparna Nancherla on Her Comedy Album
abstract: With comedy success and a new album, “Putting It Out There,” Ms. Nancherla no longer starts every show with a mention of being a woman and Indian.
lead_paragraph: In a Brooklyn theater last month, the host of a comedy show gently chided a petite woman in black overalls who rushed to the back shortly after the show began. It appeared as if the host did not recognize the latecomer: Aparna Nancherla, the show’s closing act.

headline: SoftBank’s ARM Deal May Signal Life After ‘Brexit.’ Or Not.
abstract: A $32 billion deal for an English semiconductor company sparked rejoicing, but some reflection suggests it may be a special case.
lead_paragraph: When Britain voted last month to leave the European Union, many deal makers predicted that future acquisitions there were all but dead.

headline: In Egypt, Many Leaders Quietly Cheered Turkish Coup Plotters
abstract: “Many public figures,” one member of Parliament said, would be happy to see President Recep Tayyip Erdogan removed so that Egypt could have “a better relationship with Turkey.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptians watched raptly over the weekend as military forces moved to unseat a democratically elected Islamist president in Turkey, reminding many of a similar move by the Egyptian military three years ago.

headline: Republican Convention, Baton Rouge, Turkey: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Suit by Haruki Nakamura, Former N.F.L. Player, Puts Concussion Spotlight on Insurers
abstract: Nakamura, who played defensive back for five seasons with the Baltimore Ravens and Carolina Panthers, is seeking $3 million from Lloyd’s of London.
lead_paragraph: Athletes have bought disability insurance for decades as a hedge against career-ending injuries like torn ligaments and broken bones. But players who leave the N.F.L. because of severe head trauma are being forced to convince insurers that their often invisible injuries are both real and serious.

headline: A Medal of Honor for a Daring Rescue in the Vietnam War
abstract: Charles S. Kettles, a helicopter pilot, was awarded the highest military honor by President Obama on Monday for actions 49 years ago in Duc Pho, Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was near dusk on a Monday in May 1967, and six American helicopter crews were on their third trip that day to rescue dozens of American paratroopers pinned down by North Vietnamese troops.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Bold Style Headlines Pitchfork Music Festival
abstract: At the Chicago music festival, attendees and artists showed off their personal styles.
lead_paragraph: At the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago’s Union Park, vibrant colors and patterns were practically a uniform. Flip through the freshest looks from the 11-year-old festival here.

headline: China Begins Air Patrols Over Disputed Area of the South China Sea
abstract: The patrols, seen as an assertion of sovereignty, were anticipated by analysts after an international tribunal ruled that Beijing had no legal right to the area.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China said Monday that it had begun what would become regular military air patrols over disputed islands and shoals of the South China Sea, highlighting its claim to the vast area a week after an international tribunal said Beijing’s assertion of sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.

headline: German Police Kill Assailant After Ax Attack Aboard a Train
abstract: A 17-year-old Afghan youth who came to Germany as a migrant last year attacked passengers with an ax and a knife. The motive was unclear, the police said.
lead_paragraph: WEIMAR, Germany — A 17-year-old Afghan youth who came to Germany as a migrant last year attacked several passengers with an ax and a knife on a train in the south of the country late on Monday, injuring at least four people, while 14 others were treated for shock, the police said.

headline: What to Expect on Day 2 of the Republican National Convention
abstract: Join New York Times staff members for live coverage of the events through Facebook Live, blogs and video highlights of the day.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday is Day 2 of the Republican National Convention. Here are highlights of The New York Times’s planned coverage of the events.

headline: The First Day of the Republican National Convention
abstract: The Republican National Convention kicked off in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Convention kicked off in Cleveland.

headline: Alcohol and Elephant Pillows at the Republican National Convention
abstract: New York Times correspondents are chronicling the colorful, the unusual and the quirky at the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — New York Times correspondents are chronicling the colorful, the unusual and the quirky at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

headline: Fuel Targets Threatened by Demand for Big Autos
abstract: Two federal agencies said in a report that it was unlikely the industry could meet the government’s ambitious projections a decade from now.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Despite praising automakers for recent gains in fuel economy, two federal agencies said on Monday that surging consumer demand for pickups and sport utility vehicles made it unlikely that the industry could meet the government’s ambitious projections a decade from now.

headline: In Cleveland, Rallies for and Against Trump
abstract: Supporters of Donald J. Trump voiced their approval of his policies at a rally Monday. At a separate gathering, protestors decried what they see as his racism.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Donald J. Trump voiced their approval of his policies at a rally Monday. At a separate gathering, protestors decried what they see as his racism.

headline: Taking Aim at Fatigue, Taxi Commission Limits Drivers to 12-Hour Days
abstract: The limits, which also include a cap of 72 hours per week, are the first such rules that New York City has set for both taxis and services like Uber.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission on Monday voted to limit the number of hours a driver can transport passengers to a total of 12 a day, or 72 hours per week, and for the first time such rules would be applied to both city taxi drivers and private for-hire drivers.

headline: Republican Convention Day 1: Analysis
abstract: Times journalists provided live analysis of the first night of the Republican National Convention as Donald J. Trump aims to unify the party.
lead_paragraph: Times journalists provided live analysis of the first night of the Republican National Convention as Donald J. Trump aims to unify the party.

headline: Staring Down a Sanitation Worker
abstract: A flustered commuter found her path blocked by pedestrians, mounds of ice, a garbage truck and a man with a sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Republican Convention Speeches on Day 1: What You Missed and Our Fact Checks
abstract: It’s been an eclectic mix of speakers, including two senators, a Benghazi victim’s mother, a sheriff, actors and a reality TV star.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest Day 2 coverage of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Robert B. Morgan, Senator Undone by His Panama Canal Votes, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Morgan, who represented North Carolina in the Senate, backed the treaty to give the canal to Panama and lost his re-election bid because of it.
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Morgan, a former United States senator from North Carolina whose votes for treaties to turn the Panama Canal over to Panama in 1978 cost him his seat after only one term, died on Saturday at his home in Buies Creek, N.C. He was 90.

headline: Clash of Values Emerges After Afghan Child Bride Burns to Death
abstract: Troubles began for Zahra, a promising schoolgirl, when she was bartered away at age 11 and later married off. Her father said she was 14 and pregnant when she died.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As a young girl, Zahra became consumed with the idea of a life of learning, seizing on every new opportunity that trickled to her isolated town in the western Afghan province of Ghor.

headline: Yahoo Edges Toward Its Sale With a Limp
abstract: As Yahoo accepted the final bids for its core business, it revealed just how badly that business was deteriorating: revenue fell 15 percent last quarter and profit dropped 64 percent.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo accepted the final bids for its core business on Monday, the internet company revealed just how badly that business was deteriorating.

headline: Administration Asks Supreme Court to Rehear Immigration Case Once It’s Full
abstract: The justices deadlocked last month over a challenge to President Obama’s plan to spare millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday asked the Supreme Court to take the unusual step of reconsidering a major immigration decision once a full nine-member court can hear the case.

headline: The Colorful and the Quirky at the Republican National Convention
abstract: A Democratic opposition group is displaying a collection of anti-Trump artifacts, and conventiongoers are ordering a flood of Arnold Palmers.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Cleveland may be Donald J. Trump country this week, but as the Republican National Convention got underway, a small band of his most strident liberal opponents hunkered down in a sixth-floor industrial loft and built what could be the world’s most comprehensive collection of anti-Trump artifacts.

headline: Baltimore Orioles, So Consistent, Crave Another Measure of Success
abstract: The team has the most victories in the American League during the last five seasons but no pennants to validate its achievements.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Orioles have the most victories in the American League in the last five seasons. Let that sink in for a moment.

headline: Veterans Worry Baton Rouge and Dallas Shootings Will Spread Stereotypes
abstract: Both gunmen served in the military, raising fears that people will “make the leap that all veterans are killers with PTSD that are going to blow at a moment’s notice,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Many military veterans thought they were making strides in recent years to overcome “the Rambo narrative” — the idea that all veterans come home as mentally scarred ticking time bombs, waiting to explode. But with the revelation that both gunmen implicated in fatal ambushes of police officers in Dallas and Baton Rouge, La., were young military veterans, they say they fear a big step backward.

headline: Slovenians in Cleveland React to Melania
abstract: Slovenian-Americans in Cleveland talked about Donald Trump’s wife, a native of what is now Slovenia.
lead_paragraph: Slovenian-Americans in Cleveland talked about Donald Trump’s wife, a native of what is now Slovenia.

headline: In Aftermath of Baton Rouge Shooting, Obama Directs Message to His Successor
abstract: The president’s address was a shift in tone from previous talks intended to console the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He seemed to have finally run out of words.

headline: The Most Extreme Republican Platform in Memory
abstract: The G.O.P. has traded plans for a big, open tent for a big, exclusive wall built on planks out of touch with American lives.
lead_paragraph: For all the disruption and damage that Donald Trump has meant for Republicans, the party’s  statement of its views in its newly written convention platform rivals him for shock value. Platforms are traditionally written by and for the party faithful and largely ignored by everyone else. But this year, the Republicans are putting out an agenda that demands notice.

headline: Republican Platform Defends ‘Traditional’ Marriage, a Border Wall and Coal
abstract: The Republican Party on Monday adopted perhaps its most socially conservative platform ever. Here are some excerpts.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Follow our latest Day 2 coverage of the Republican National Convention.

headline: A Slain Officer’s Example for Us All
abstract: Montrell Jackson, who was killed Sunday in Baton Rouge, knew you could oppose both excessive force and violence against the police.
lead_paragraph: Baton Rouge, La. — I was sitting in our church service, which was packed more than usual, when a peek at my Facebook feed revealed the grim news. I elbowed my wife, who was trying to silence our 2-year-old twins. “Officers shot,” I whispered, discreetly flashing her my phone screen. The look on her face conveyed all of the heartbreak I’m sure everyone else in Baton Rouge, La., felt when they heard the news. We both knew that the fragile steps toward normalcy that our community was beginning to make had instantly unraveled. We were back at square one. Or worse.

headline: Netflix, Once Invincible, Suffers Big Drop in Growth
abstract: Just 1.7 million new streaming members were added in the three months ended June 30, about half the net additions from the same period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Netflix isn’t looking so invincible anymore.

headline: Baton Rouge Gunman Moved ‘Tactically’ to Target Police Officers, Officials Say
abstract: The authorities pieced together and described how Gavin Long systematically killed and wounded law enforcement officials during a rampage on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The black-clad man in Baton Rouge, La., barely bothered to conceal that he was heavily armed and looking for trouble, rounding corners in a ready-to-fire-stance, pointing a military-style weapon and prompting a 911 call of “a dude with a rifle,” behaving ominously. He ignored the easiest prey, the scores of civilians around him, hunting only people in uniform — methodically, mercilessly, even as they lay wounded on the pavement.

headline: Synchronized Swimmers Find Danger Lurking Below Surface: Concussions
abstract: Concussions, usually the concern of contact sports such as football and hockey, have become a worry in the pool, as synchronized swimmers perform more moves in tighter formations.
lead_paragraph: To many fans, synchronized swimming is an aquatic ballet performed by petite women who wear makeup, nose plugs and flashy bathing suits, a sport largely defined by Esther Williams movies or spoofs by comedians like Martin Short.

headline: Byron Lima Oliva, Bishop’s Killer, Dies in Attack at Guatemala Prison
abstract: Mr. Lima, who was convicted in a 1998 murder and accused of building a criminal operation in prison, was killed along with 12 others, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Convicted of killing a bishop who had cataloged human rights crimes during Guatemala’s long civil war, Byron Lima Oliva, an army captain, went to prison and, prosecutors said, built a powerful criminal operation from behind bars.

headline: Trump and Pence: On the Same Ticket, but Not on the Same Page
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Gov. Mike Pence are on the record as having very different attitudes on recent fiscal policy.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing consistent about the business views of Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana — better known as Donald J. Trump’s running mate — it is that they are often at odds with the views of Mr. Trump, who has campaigned on his business expertise.

headline: Who’s Not Speaking? How This Republican Convention Differs
abstract: An analysis of convention speakers since 1992 suggests this year’s convention features much less support from establishment Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The list of speakers for the Republican convention looks less luminous than Donald Trump had planned.

headline: Rancor Reigns as Bitterly Divided Republicans Begin Their Convention
abstract: Renegade delegates forced a floor fight to embarrass Donald J. Trump on Monday, while a top aide excoriated Ohio’s governor for not endorsing Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Rancor and hard-edged attacks dominated the start of the Republican National Convention on Monday as speakers branded Hillary Clinton as a liar who deserved to be in prison and two African-American Republicans ridiculed the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: It’s Donald Trump’s Convention. But the Inspiration? Nixon.
abstract: On the opening night of the Republican National Convention, Donald J. Trump was conspicuously trying to conjure somebody else: Richard M. Nixon.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Let Trump be Trump, his aides have always insisted. And let his convention serve as an unapologetic tribute to his singular, erratic, untamed persona.

headline: Michael Conforto Rejoins a Mets Outfield in Flux
abstract: Conforto arrived from the minor leagues to find he may play center or right field instead of his preferred left, in part because of an ailing Yoenis Cespedes.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Sporting his usual broad smile and with renewed confidence at the plate, Michael Conforto returned to the Mets on Monday from the minor leagues, with the team hoping his bat can help a still-inconsistent offense.

headline: Cuomo Details Redesigned Subway Cars and Major Station Renovations
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unveiled the features of the new subway cars, including wider doors and accordionlike passageways. Upgrades are planned at 31 stations.
lead_paragraph: Imagine your subway train is pulling up to the platform, its wider doors easing the claustrophobic dance between riders struggling to alight as others board. Once inside, you are able to walk freely between cars during rush hour, allowing passengers to find, and create, less-crowded cars.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Is Using His Voice and Olympic Platform for Social Change
abstract: While training with the United States basketball team that will be headed to the Rio Olympics, Anthony spoke about his activism against gun violence.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Carmelo Anthony said he was having trouble sleeping. In the aftermath of the fatal police shootings of two black men, followed by the retaliatory killings of five police officers in Dallas by a sniper, Anthony awoke in the middle of the night this month and logged on to his Instagram account.

headline: Review: ‘Privacy,’ a Play That Urges You to Keep Your Smartphone On
abstract: Secrets are revealed — perhaps your own — in this production, starring Daniel Radcliffe, at the Public Theater. It’s a magic show for the online age.
lead_paragraph: Grim tidings are spread with great cheer in “Privacy,” James Graham and Josie Rourke’s perky investigation into the consequences of living your life online. This London-born production from 2014 — which opened in an updated, Americanized version (“Brexit” jokes!) at the Public Theater on Monday night — stars a charmingly woebegone Daniel Radcliffe as a writer who has conflicted feelings about all his relationships, but especially the one with the internet.

headline: Just Before Hitting the Pool
abstract: In which I do an inordinate amount of research to understand James Mulhern’s theme, totally due to my own shortcomings.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a beautiful day for a baseball-themed crossword — let’s play, too. James Mulhern is back today with a theme that I had to Google, because baseball.

headline: North Korea Fires 3 Missiles After U.S. and South Agree to Defense System
abstract: Days after the United States and South Korea agreed to deploy an advanced missile defense system, North Korea fired three ballistic missiles.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired three ballistic missiles on Tuesday, six days after South Korea revealed the location in the South where the United States planned to deploy an advanced missile defense system.

headline: Pigeons May Predict Lead Contamination, Study Finds
abstract: A study found a link between elevated lead levels in pigeons and those in children, suggesting that scientists may be able to use the birds to assess environmental contamination.
lead_paragraph: Amid reignited fears about lead poisoning nationwide, the key to identifying solutions could lie in the common city pigeon.

headline: Zarrab’s Lawyers File Motion to Suppress Statements
abstract: Defense motion filed by lawyers for Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader charged in New York with conspiracy to violate U.S. sanctions on Iran and other counts, to suppress statements he made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation when he was interrogated after arriving in the United States in March.
lead_paragraph: Defense motion filed by lawyers for Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader charged in New York with conspiracy to violate U.S. sanctions on Iran and other counts, to suppress statements he made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation when he was interrogated after arriving in the United States in March.

headline: Zarrab’s Lawyers File Motion to Dismiss Indictment
abstract: Defense motion to dismiss the indictment against Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader charged in New York with conspiracy to violate United States sanctions on Iran and other counts.
lead_paragraph: Defense motion to dismiss the indictment against Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader charged in New York with conspiracy to violate United States sanctions on Iran and other counts.

headline: Reza Zarrab’s Lawyers File Motion to Dismiss Indictment
abstract: Lawyers for the Turkish gold trader, who is charged with conspiracy to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, called the case a “prosecutorial overreach.”
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a gold trader from Turkey who has been charged in New York with conspiracy to violate the United States sanctions on Iran asked a judge on Monday to dismiss the indictment, calling the case “a prosecutorial overreach of the first order.”

headline: What, Congressman Steve King Asks, Have Nonwhites Done for Civilization?
abstract: Mr. King, a Republican representative from Iowa, was criticized on TV and Twitter after contrasting the contributions of “old white people” with those of “subgroups” on MSNBC.
lead_paragraph: Representative Steve King, Republican of Iowa, questioned the historical contributions of nonwhite “subgroups” during an appearance on MSNBC on Monday, igniting swift backlash online.

headline: Wendell Anderson, Governor Behind the ‘Minnesota Miracle,’ Dies at 83
abstract: A popular, two-term governor who was also an Olympic silver medalist, Mr. Anderson oversaw reforms in education financing and local property taxes.
lead_paragraph: Wendell Anderson, a Democratic wunderkind who as governor wrought legislation hailed as “the Minnesota Miracle” to finance education, only to be rejected by the voters after engineering his own appointment to a Senate vacancy, died on Sunday in St. Paul. He was 83.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Homers, and Ivan Nova Helps Yankees Edge Orioles
abstract: The Yankees began a four-game home series with Nova (7-5) picking up a win against one of baseball’s toughest lineups.
lead_paragraph: The math confronting the Yankees on Monday was simple. They arrived at Yankee Stadium two weeks from the trade deadline, eight and a half games back in the American League East, and hosting first-place Baltimore for four games.

headline: Black Police Officers Feel the Inner Tug of a Dual Role
abstract: Killings involving the police, and the fatal attacks on officers that have followed, have intensified the tug of war that black officers experience.
lead_paragraph: The day after five Dallas police officers were killed in an ambush, Montrell Jackson, a black police officer in Baton Rouge, La., took to Facebook to voice his frustration.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, July 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “No officer leaves his house and says, ‘Man I want to kill somebody today.’”

headline: Cubs End Their Streak of Futility Against the Mets
abstract: After having lost eight straight games to the Mets, including a sweep in last season’s National League Championship Series, Chicago got to starter Steven Matz.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Since losing all seven of their regular-season matchups last year, the Mets had clobbered the Chicago Cubs, toppling them eight consecutive times, from a sweep in the National League Championship Series to a four-game series sweep this month.

headline: Jake Gyllenhaal, Back on Broadway
abstract: Mr. Gyllenhaal will star in the Lanford Wilson play “Burn This” at a refurbished Hudson Theater next year.
lead_paragraph: Jake Gyllenhaal is planning a return to Broadway next year, headlining the first show in a longtime event space that is reopening as a theater.

headline: Race Strongly Influences Mortgage Lending in St. Louis, Study Finds
abstract: Banks made fewer loans to borrowers in minority neighborhoods than to those with similar incomes in white neighborhoods, a consumer group found.
lead_paragraph: In the two years since the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., the nation has come to learn much about the stark socioeconomic differences between black and white neighborhoods in the St. Louis area.

headline: Questions Over Melania Trump’s Speech Set Off Finger-Pointing
abstract: Ms. Trump’s remarks at the convention came under scrutiny over similarities to those delivered by Michelle Obama at the Democratic convention in 2008.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Republican Party woke up to a cascade of finger-pointing and confusion on Tuesday as the Trump campaign was rocked by accusations that parts of Melania Trump’s convention speech had been cribbed from the one that Michelle Obama delivered to Democrats in 2008.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Celebrate the 20th anniversary of “Trainspotting” and Aziz Ansari’s Emmy nominations for “Master of None.” And the Republican National Convention pushes an employment theme.
lead_paragraph: Celebrate the 20th anniversary of Danny Boyle’s “Trainspotting” and three Emmy nominations for Aziz Ansari and “Master of None.” Meanwhile, on Day 2, the Republican National Convention gets pumped up about employment.

headline: Review: ‘War Paint’ Recalls Two Cosmetics Titans
abstract: In this musical, Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole portray the beauty market rivals Helena Rubinstein and Elizabeth Arden.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For a musical that covers so many years — and so many shades of lipstick — “War Paint” never really seems to move forward. This portrait of battling cosmetic titans, which opened on Monday at the Goodman Theater here starring a deliciously paired Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole, doesn’t just show its whole hand from the get-go; it does so as eagerly as a debutante with a fabulous new manicure.

headline: Comparing Melania Trump’s Speech With Michelle Obama’s
abstract: Parts of Melania Trump’s speech during the Republican National Convention in Cleveland were strikingly similar to Michelle Obama’s speech during the Democratic convention in 2008.
