lead_paragraph: Parts of Melania Trump’s speech during the Republican National Convention in Cleveland were strikingly similar to Michelle Obama’s speech during the Democratic convention in 2008.

headline: Putin’s Swift Reaction to Doping Report Blames Anti-Russian Politics
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin responded unusually quickly to a World Anti-Doping Agency report that accused his government of running a covert doping program for the country’s Olympians.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin responded within hours Monday to accusations that his government ran a covert doping program for Russian Olympians and other elite athletes, indicating how seriously the Kremlin took the charges.

headline: Corrections: July 19, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Nixon’s Mark on Republican Convention
abstract: As Donald J. Trump seeks to position himself as a “law and order” candidate, there are echoes of Richard Nixon, a candidate who sought to do the same in 1968.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump seeks to position himself as a “law and order” candidate, there are echoes of Richard Nixon, a candidate who sought to do the same in 1968.

headline: Don’t Confuse Veterans and Violence
abstract: A truer image of the American veteran is seen not in these killers, but in their victims.
lead_paragraph: IT was clear the shooter had some training.

headline: The Road to Baton Rouge
abstract: Elected officials, political candidates and protesters have a responsibility to temper their remarks so as not to inflame a dangerous situation.
lead_paragraph: Americans are understandably on edge about the horrific ambush in Baton Rouge on Sunday, when a gunman killed three police officers and wounded three others.

headline: Ban Russia From the Rio Olympics
abstract: A new report gives the International Olympic Committee all the evidence it needs to ban every Russian team from the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: The latest and most comprehensive report on Russia’s cheating at the 2014 Winter Olympics gives the International Olympic Committee all the evidence it needs to ban every Russian team from the forthcoming Rio Games.

headline: Virginia Needs to Fix Its Racist Voting Law
abstract: State lawmakers want to strip the right to vote from more than 206,000 people, including one in five African-American adults in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: THE Virginia Supreme Court will hear arguments on Tuesday in a lawsuit that aims to strip the right to vote from more than 206,000 people, including one in five African-American adults in the state. If state lawmakers win, they will keep Virginia trapped in a shameful part of history: when former Confederate states passed felon disenfranchisement laws after Reconstruction to suppress black political power.

headline: Winning the Campaign to Curb Teen Pregnancy
abstract: Pregnancy among teenagers in America is falling, due to unpredicted influences. And Colorado is leading the way toward another drop.
lead_paragraph: MTV viewers first met Maci, Amber, Farrah and Catelynn in 2009 on the hit show “16 and Pregnant.” The four girls were among the first of 47 pregnant teenagers on “16,” which ran for five seasons. The show followed each girl, beginning in her pregnancy, then through the baby’s birth and early infancy. And viewers have been able to stay with their lives on the spinoffs “Teen Mom,” “Teen Mom 2” and “Teen Mom 3.”i

headline: Trump Is Getting Even Trumpier!
abstract: Is the Republicans’ nominee losing it?
lead_paragraph: Does anybody else have the sense that Donald Trump is slipping off the rails? His speeches have always had a rambling, free association quality, but a couple of the recent ones have, as the Republican political consultant Mike Murphy put it, passed from the category of rant to the category of full on “drunk wedding toast.”

headline: Can Republicans Rock Cleveland?
abstract: Sometimes there aren’t enough right-leaning musicians for the playlist.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland — THE Republican Party is really trying to sell us on the rock ’n’ roll theme of this year’s convention. The convention logo is a red elephant strutting across the neck of a guitar. If you tweet with the GOPConvention hashtag, a tiny red guitar pops up.

headline: Republican Convention Day 1: Highlights
abstract: On the first day of the convention on Monday, a lot of things did not go as anticipated. The Republican Party sought to show that it had unified behind Donald J. Trump. Instead some delegates tried to stage a last-ditch revolt.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of the convention on Monday, a lot of things did not go as anticipated. The Republican Party sought to show that it had unified behind Donald J. Trump. Instead some delegates tried to stage a last-ditch revolt.

headline: Jon Stewart Returns on ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert’
abstract: Another beloved character appeared with Mr. Stewart: “Stephen Colbert,” the fictional conservative persona who hosted “The Colbert Report.”
lead_paragraph: In his first live “Late Show” broadcast since the start of the Republican National Convention, Stephen Colbert promised the return of an old friend from his basic-cable days, but instead, viewers got to see two familiar faces: first, Jon Stewart, the longtime host of “The Daily Show,” and then “Stephen Colbert,” the unctuous conservative commentator that Mr. Colbert portrayed for nearly a decade on his Comedy Central program, “The Colbert Report.”

headline: Photos That Challenge Stereotypes About African-American Youths
abstract: The book “Picturing Children” resonates with the joy, contentment, resistance, determination, dissent and the routines of everyday African-American life.
lead_paragraph: The book “Picturing Children” resonates with the joy, contentment, resistance, determination, dissent and the routines of everyday African-American life.

headline: Afghan Teenager Spoke of Friend’s Death Before Ax Attack in Germany
abstract: German investigators found evidence that may link the young man to the Islamic State, but denied a firm connection with the group despite it claiming responsibility.
lead_paragraph: WÜRZBURG, Germany — Over the weekend, an Afghan teenager who had arrived as a refugee last year told confidants in Germany that he had lost a close friend in Afghanistan, but who had been killed, and how and where, remained unclear.

headline: KFC Targeted in Protests Over South China Sea
abstract: Accusing the United States of encouraging a case against China’s maritime claims, demonstrators called for boycotts in about a dozen cities.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Protests against the South China Sea ruling by a tribunal in The Hague broke out in several Chinese cities on Monday, with people targeting KFC outlets as a symbol of United States interests.

headline: Business Owners Turn to an Unlikely Mascot: Hitler
abstract: The Nazi dictator’s image has been used to sell fried chicken, shampoo and jeans in places as varied as India and the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Aunt Jemima and Uncle Ben are often criticized as racist brand ambassadors, but there’s a corporate mascot popping up all over the world who makes their alleged sins looks small: Adolf Hitler.

headline: The Trump Convention: A Painful Moment for the Bush Family Network
abstract: Representatives of the last Republican White House, confounded by what has happened to their party, will be almost invisible at the convention this week.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Amid the balloons and parties, speeches and spectacle, one faction of the Republican Party is almost invisible at the national convention this week: the Bush family network.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Day 2 Takeaways: A Party Unites, at Least for a Night
abstract: Tuesday was billed as a focus on jobs and the economy, but the speakers strayed from the theme on a night when Donald J. Trump was formally nominated.
lead_paragraph: The second night of the Republican National Convention was a whipsaw of conflicting themes and messages. The printed schedule suggested a focus on jobs and economic policy. The reality: A party learning to acclimate itself to Donald J. Trump, figure out if he can win a national election, and help him (if possible). Our takeaways:

headline: What Does Mayor de Blasio Do at the Gym? He Runs New York
abstract: Upon close investigation, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s routine at the Prospect Park Y.M.C.A. is more rigid and leisurely than previously known.
lead_paragraph: On most mornings, Mayor Bill de Blasio departs Gracie Mansion, the mayoral residence of New York City, in a black sport utility vehicle, accompanied by a police escort.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Day 1 Takeaways: Message Is Clear, Doom Is Near
abstract: The first night of Mr. Trump’s coronation struck a dark and foreboding tone unmatched by any convention in recent history.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest Day 2 coverage of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Bangladesh, Blaming Local Groups for Attacks, Seeks Suspects Tied to ISIS
abstract: A list of suspects released after the Dhaka cafe siege includes men that the police have long sought as operatives for the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Bangladesh, reeling from a sudden intensification of terrorism this summer, has begun an urgent search for men suspected of building an Islamic State presence in the country and recruiting young Bangladeshis to fight in Syria and Iraq.

headline: Photos That Challenge Stereotypes About African-American Youths
abstract: “Picturing Children,” the latest in a series of books published by the Smithsonian’s soon-to-open National Museum of African American History and Culture, resonates with the joy, contentment, resistance, determination, dissent and the routines of everyday African-American life.
lead_paragraph: The photographs in the new book “Picturing Children” affirm that kids will be kids: They study. They play. They interact with family. But those lives are often overshadowed by prejudice and preconceptions.

headline: Theresa May’s Shock Therapy
abstract: Britain’s new prime minister wants to make things better by shaking them up.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There is a genteel savagery to the British prime ministerial system. If you blinked last week, you’d have missed David Cameron’s exit and the arrival in No. 10 Downing Street of Theresa May. No period of transition separates one regime from the other, allowing the nation to acclimatize to its new head of government. One prime minister is hustled out No. 10, and another is hustled in.

headline: The Fallout From the Coup in Turkey
abstract: How will Turkey's relations with NATO, its role in the region and its future as a democracy be affected by the revolt and the crackdown after?

headline: What Makes Florida So Weird? A Native Tries to Explain.
abstract: In “Oh, Florida!,” Craig Pittman serves as a guide to his native state.
lead_paragraph: OH, FLORIDA!How America’s Weirdest State Influences the Rest of the CountryBy Craig PittmanIllustrated. 320 pp. St. Martin’s Press. $26.99.

headline: For Generous Parental Leave and Great Schools, Move to Finland
abstract: In “The Nordic Theory of Everything,” the Finnish journalist Anu Partanen maintains that life is better in her native land.
lead_paragraph: THE NORDIC THEORY OF EVERYTHINGIn Search of a Better LifeBy Anu Partanen418 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

headline: Republican Party, Baton Rouge, Russia’s Olympians: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: The Hills Are Alive
abstract: Tuesday: The Hills open on Governors Island, new subway cars and music from Mars.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:50 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: Trump and Pence: Same Ticket, but Not the Same Page
abstract: SoftBank Shares Plunge After Deal Announcement | Yahoo’s Revenue Slumps
lead_paragraph: TRUMP AND PENCE: SAME TICKET, BUT NOT THE SAME PAGE If there is one thing consistent about the business views of Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, it is that they are often at odds with those of Donald Trump, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in DealBook.

headline: Mitch McConnell Leads Senate Delegation to Republican Convention
abstract: As one of several members of Congress scheduled to speak, Mr. McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader, is expected to slam Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky sometimes struggles to work up much enthusiasm for Donald J. Trump. But he can definitely get excited about the opportunity to trash Hillary Clinton.

headline: The Trouble With Hillary Clinton’s Free Tuition Plan
abstract: Differences in how states finance higher education mean such a policy could end up being hugely expensive, grossly unfair or both.
lead_paragraph: This month, Hillary Clinton announced a plan to make public colleges free for the children of any family earning less than $125,000 a year. The move was widely seen as an appeal to supporters of her primary opponent Bernie Sanders, who made free college a pillar of his insurgent campaign.

headline: Paul Tollett Discusses His Latest Project, Panorama Music Festival
abstract: This weekend on Randalls Island, the festival will feature performers like Kendrick Lamar, Arcade Fire and Alabama Shakes, as well as the Lab, a high-tech exhibition space.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the Panorama festival will make its debut on Randalls Island with LCD Soundsystem, Kendrick Lamar, Arcade Fire, Alabama Shakes and a few dozen other acts, as well as a high-tech exhibition space designed for visual dazzle.

headline: Can Silicon Valley Really Do Anything to Stop Police Violence?
abstract: Tech companies love to hitch themselves to progressive causes, even if they’re beyond the industry’s grasp.
lead_paragraph: In the moments immediately after Philando Castile was shot several times by a police officer during a traffic stop in Minnesota, his girlfriend, Diamond Reynolds, began streaming the scene on Facebook Live. The recording of Castile’s death — like that of Alton Sterling’s in Louisiana the day before — was disseminated widely on Facebook and Twitter, giving the rest of the world a visceral encounter with the stark and violent reality of racist policing. Soon after, Mark Zuckerberg penned a mildly self-congratulatory note about his company in a post on his personal Facebook page. “It reminds us why coming together to build a more open and connected world is so important,” he wrote, “and how far we still have to go.”

headline: How ‘Political Correctness’ Went From Punch Line to Panic
abstract: The label used to be a conservative joke. To Trump and his supporters, it is a national-security threat.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2016, and we’re rewriting the 1990s. Monica Lewinsky has transformed herself from the butt of a joke into an antibullying advocate. The first lady who refused to stay in the White House and bake cookies is running for president as a kindly grandmother. And “political correctness,” the decade’s shorthand for liberal politics, has returned as something more menacing.

headline: Liberal Chinese Journal’s Purged Editors Declare Publication Dissolved
abstract: The journal, Yanhuang Chunqiu, has carried articles advocating political change and examining delicate issues in Chinese Communist history.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A scholarly journal backed by liberal-minded retired Communist cadres has ceased publication after 25 years, according to a statement by its ousted publisher and senior editors.

headline: By Bulgaria’s Beautiful Black Sea
abstract: With its inexpensive lodging, fantastic seafood, and gorgeous beaches, is the Black Sea coast of Bulgaria the new “hot” destination in Eastern Europe?
lead_paragraph: When I first set foot onto the hot sand of a Bulgarian beach and laid eyes on the Black Sea, I thought to myself, “This has to be the ocean.” I was wrong, of course, but I couldn’t get over how vast it was, stretching seemingly forever toward the horizon.

headline: Price-Fixing Truck Makers Get Record E.U. Fine: $3.2 Billion
abstract: The $3.2 billion penalty comes less than a week after the bloc’s antitrust chief announced a new round of charges against Google.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s antitrust chief imposed a record fine of 2.9 billion euros, or $3.2 billion, on a group of truck makers on Tuesday, part of a trend toward steeper penalties for competition violations in the 28-nation bloc.

headline: Suddenly Considering Travel Insurance? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: Consumer interest in terrorism and trip cancellation coverage has grown in the wake of attacks in Europe, though rates and policies remain unchanged.
lead_paragraph: If the attacks in Nice, Brussels and Paris have you thinking about travel insurance, you’re not alone.

headline: Mountain Resorts Moving Beyond Biking and Hiking
abstract: Vail Resorts is being viewed as a test case by other ski resorts that may be considering summer programs beyond hiking and mountain biking.
lead_paragraph: Mountain resorts generally build their reputations on snow sports. But for many mountain regions, summer is the busier season based on school vacations and the appeal of cool mountain weather when other places are sweltering.

headline: Google, Trying to Endear Itself to Europe, Spreads $450 Million Around
abstract: The company is financing a series of projects supporting European culture and education as its regulatory woes continue to compound.
lead_paragraph: A yearlong digital training course for Irish high school teachers started in 2014. A fund to help European news outlets adapt to the web popped up in 2015. And in March, a virtual reality exhibition began at a Belgian museum to showcase a Renaissance painter.

headline: Philippines Clears Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, Ex-President, of Graft Charges
abstract: The Supreme Court also ordered that Mrs. Arroyo be released from a Manila hospital where she has been detained since 2012.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Supreme Court of the Philippines dismissed corruption charges on Tuesday against a former president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, and ordered her release from a Manila hospital where she has been detained since 2012. Her lawyer said she was likely to be freed on Wednesday.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 3 | On ‘How Wall Street Bro Talk Keeps Women Down’
abstract: This week we crown Alison Oh, who writes about how a Times Op-Ed made her realize that, until societal problems are personal, most of us take little action against them.
lead_paragraph: Week 3 of our Summer Reading Contest attracted 583 responses. And as the number of participants rises each week, it gets harder and harder to choose between them.

headline: Donald Trump’s Biker Force
abstract: Chris Cox leads Bikers for Trump, a group that drove into Cleveland on motorcycles on Monday to patrol the Republican National Convention and to rally behind the presumptive nominee.
lead_paragraph: Chris Cox leads Bikers for Trump, a group that drove into Cleveland on motorcycles on Monday to patrol the Republican National Convention and to rally behind the presumptive nominee.

headline: 1891: Wave of Russian Immigration
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Wave of Russian Jewish immigration to Germany in July, 1891.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The detention of Russian Jews at the Barge Office is due to the orders of Colonel Weber, the Immigration Commissioner. This is pending the result of the investigation ordered by the Treasury Department at Washington into the strenuous efforts alleged to have been made by a British official, said to be a prominent member of a Jewish social organization, to divert from England the destitute expatriated Russian Jews who are flowing into Germany at the rate of 700 a day, by warning them that the labor market in England is overstocked, and suggesting that they be sent to America or Palestine. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 20, 1891

headline: Melania Trump’s Speech May Not Have Been Original, but Her Dress Was
abstract: Unlike pretty much every would-be first lady, Ms. Trump wore a dress not by an American label, but by Roksanda Ilincic, a Serbian-born designer based in London.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump’s  speech at the Republican National Convention on Monday evening may have had a striking similarity to some parts of Michelle Obama’s address at the 2008 Democratic convention, but in one aspect, at least, her appearance was original: her clothes.

headline: Baton Rouge Grapples With Anxiety and Grief Amid Vigils for Officers
abstract: The gatherings came after a 29-year-old Missouri man, Gavin Long, killed three officers in what the police say was a crime targeting law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — The emotionally battered residents of Baton Rouge settled into church pews across the region on Monday for an evening of vigils filled with anxiety, grief and questions.

headline: Air Transat Pilots Pulled From Jet and Arrested on Suspicion of Being Drunk
abstract: The flight to Toronto from Glasgow was delayed more than 20 hours, and passengers seemed to display relief as well as outrage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At a time when flying seems ever more stressful, the controlled demeanor and calm authority of an airline pilot can instill confidence.

headline: Ava DuVernay Documentary to Open New York Film Festival This Fall
abstract: “The 13th,” about the United States’ sky-high incarceration rate, will be the first nonfiction film to kick off the festival in its 50-plus years.
lead_paragraph: A documentary by Ava DuVernay about the United States’ sky-high incarceration rate will open the New York Film Festival in the fall, the first time a nonfiction film will kick off the event in its 50-plus years.

headline: First Medal of Rio Olympics Deserves to Go to ... a Whistle-Blower
abstract: The I.O.C. is considering slapping Russia with a swift and stinging ban. But it takes guts to do that.
lead_paragraph: Who knew that the hero of the Rio Games would be a gray-haired, mustachioed Russian in his late 50s, who used his scientific brilliance not to search for a disease’s cure but to help Russians win Olympic medals by dissolving banned performance-enhancing drugs into Chivas and vermouth?

headline: 36 Hours on the Beach in Barcelona
abstract: Dine seaside, sip cocktails high above the water or just stretch out in the sand during this coastal weekend in Catalonia.
lead_paragraph: Dine seaside, sip cocktails high above the water or just stretch out in the sand during this coastal weekend in Catalonia.

headline: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2, Episode 7: ‘You Need to Get Over Me’
abstract: Quinn and Rachel are forced into exhausted honesty, and their power struggle nearly upends “Everlasting.”
lead_paragraph: During Monday night’s romantic gondola ride on “Everlasting,” the “UnREAL” camera tracks a path from Graham resentfully steering, to Darius and Chantal pretending to be in their own world, to the crew huddled around monitors, to a wide shot of the boat perched in a rickety dry dock. The “Everlasting” cameras hide it all, of course — they’re in the business of making it work.

headline: Monsanto Rejects Bayer’s Revised Takeover Bid of $125 a Share
abstract: Monsanto, which produces genetically modified crop seeds, said that its board viewed Bayer’s new takeover bid as too cheap.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto, the American maker of genetically modified crop seeds, on Tuesday rejected a revised takeover bid by Bayer of Germany as too cheap, an expected move that prolongs the bidding contest for the company.

headline: Volkswagen Scandal Reaches All the Way to the Top, Lawsuits Say
abstract: The suits claim the decision to thwart pollution tests involved dozens of engineers and managers, and reached into the company’s boardroom.
lead_paragraph: Three attorneys general on Tuesday directly challenged Volkswagen’s defense over its emissions deception, calling the decision to thwart pollution tests an orchestrated fraud that lasted more than a decade, involved dozens of engineers and managers and reached deep into the company’s boardroom.

headline: After ARM, Is More British Tech for Sale?
abstract: ARM Holdings was attractive partly because it had little relation to the local economy. That’s true of many things that live online.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Britain voted to leave the European Union. This week, that looked like pretty good news for at least one acquisitive company, when SoftBank of Japan announced it would buy the British firm ARM Holdings for $32 billion. Could more foreigners move on British tech?

headline: Opening Links in New Windows
abstract: Some web pages are coded to automatically open links in new windows, but you can also use keyboard tricks with your mouse clicks to pop open new pages.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I’m on my computer and I click links on web pages, sometimes the links open in new windows and sometimes they don’t. Why is this, and is there a way I can get links to open in new tabs so I don’t lose my place on the original page?

headline: High Stakes for Trump as All Eyes Turn to Cleveland
abstract: Even in their shrunken state, conventions provide parties and candidates opportunities to connect with an immense chunk of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Just months ago, the political world dreamed that this Republican convention would be a riveting, unpredictable throwback, reviving the deal-making intrigue that once produced presidential nominees.

headline: A Third of Nice Truck Attack’s Dead Were Muslim, Group Says
abstract: The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the rampage, but it took a heavy toll on Muslims, who numbered at least 30 of the 84 killed.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — When a Tunisian man drove a truck down a crowded street in Nice last week in an attack claimed by the Islamic State, more than one-third of the people he killed were Muslim, the head of a regional Islamic association said on Tuesday.

headline: Strangled for Being Too Sexy
abstract: In Pakistan, a brother murdered his sister for her provocative videos on social media.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — ON Friday, Pakistan’s most controversial social media starlet, Qandeel Baloch, was strangled by her brother. Like many Pakistanis, I was horrified, but I was not completely surprised.

headline: Sorry for Having Insulted China? Here’s Your Chance to Apologize
abstract: A tongue-in-cheek Facebook page invites people to apologize to the country for real or perceived slights.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese leaders have often accused those who disagree with them of “hurting the feelings of 1.3 billion Chinese.” Getting into the spirit, Taiwanese and Hong Kongers are responding enthusiastically to a satirical Facebook page calling on them to say “sorry” to China.

headline: Cutting Sugar Rapidly Improves Heart Health Markers
abstract: Obese children who cut sugar from their diets saw improvements in markers of heart disease after just nine days.
lead_paragraph: Obese children who cut sugar from their diets saw improvements in markers of heart disease after just nine days, a study in Atherosclerosis found.

headline: Olympic Officials Hold Off on Russia Ban, for Now
abstract: In the wake of a damning report detailing state-sponsored doping at past Games, officials appoint a disciplinary commission.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee, under fierce pressure to respond aggressively to a doping scheme that corrupted the results of the past two Olympics, said Tuesday that it was considering legal options to discipline Russian athletes ahead of the coming Games in Rio de Janeiro and had appointed a five-person disciplinary commission.

headline: Too Nice a Day to Stay in the Office? Then Don’t.
abstract: Developers are taking on the challenge of squeezing terraces into office space so workers can relax outdoors.
lead_paragraph: With foosball tables, TV lounges and golf simulators, amenity-rich office buildings can often seem more like a place to live than work.

headline: I.V.F. Does Not Raise Breast Cancer Risk, Study Shows
abstract: The largest study to date shows little evidence of an increased risk in breast cancer among women who have undergone fertility treatments.
lead_paragraph: Women undergoing in vitro fertilization have long worried that the procedure could raise their risk for breast cancer.

headline: Donald Trump’s Convention: Day 2
abstract: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.
lead_paragraph: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.

headline: ‘Black Twitter’ Criticizes Melania Trump on Convention Speech
abstract: Many accused Ms. Trump of plagiarism, and others went a step further by focusing on the wider racial implications involving the Trumps and the Obamas.
lead_paragraph: Word spread fast that Melania Trump’s speech at the Republican National Convention on Monday bore striking similarities to one delivered by Michelle Obama at the Democratic convention in 2008, and the furor ignited an intense backlash among blacks posting on Twitter.

headline: How the Government Supports Your Junk Food Habit
abstract: The most popular junk foods come from crops that are heavily subsidized by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: At a time when almost three-quarters of the country is overweight or obese, it comes as no surprise that junk foods are the largest source of calories in the American diet. Topping the list are grain-based desserts like cookies, doughnuts and granola bars. (Yes, granola bars are dessert.)

headline: How Renewable Energy Is Blowing Climate Change Efforts Off Course
abstract: Solar and wind produce temporary power gluts that drive out other sources that are needed to maintain stable supplies. Worse, they are helping push nuclear power into bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Is the global effort to combat climate change, painstakingly agreed to in Paris seven months ago, already going off the rails?

headline: 2016 Election Forecast: Who Will Be President?
abstract: The Upshot’s presidential forecast, updated daily.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot’s presidential forecast, updated daily.

headline: Fighting Obama’s Climate Plan, but Quietly Preparing to Comply
abstract: Some states, including several suing to stop the Clean Power Plan, are moving forward with efforts to follow the proposed rules or to analyze other plans.
lead_paragraph: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — Matt Mead, the governor of Wyoming, the nation’s leading coal-producing state, fiercely opposes President Obama’s climate change regulations, which could shutter hundreds of coal plants and deeply wound his state, one of 27 that are suing to block the plan.

headline: For Sia, Dance Is Where the Human and the Weird Intersect
abstract: The soulful singer-songwriter and her choreographer, Ryan Heffington, are working hard to raise the standards of pop-music movement.
lead_paragraph: Sia — the enigmatic, soulful singer-songwriter who conceals her face behind wigs while belting out lines like, “there’s a scream inside that we all try to hide” — was “expelled from ballet at age 5,” as she put it in an email interview, “for disrupting the class.”

headline: Women Who Prefer Men’s Wear
abstract: The fashion bloggers Danielle Cooper and Sara Geffrard wear men’s suits in a manner all their own.
lead_paragraph: Two fashion bloggers stood side by side at the Stampd presentation during the second day of New York Fashion Week: Men’s. Each wore a crisply tailored suit with white sneakers that appeared to have been spared an encounter with the street.

headline: VW Lawsuit
abstract: Excerpts from New York attorney general’s lawsuit against Volkswagen.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from New York attorney general’s lawsuit against Volkswagen.

headline: Introducing The Upshot’s Presidential Prediction Model
abstract: It doesn’t put much stock in so-called fundamentals; it’s based almost entirely on polls.
lead_paragraph: For now, at least, Hillary Clinton has a 76 percent chance of defeating Donald Trump to become president of the United States.

headline: Who Was the Baton Rouge Shooter?
abstract: The Louisiana State Police released images of the Baton Rouge shooting suspect who killed three police officers on Sunday. The suspect, Gavin Long, had a history of posting social media tirades.
lead_paragraph: The Louisiana State Police released images of the Baton Rouge shooting suspect who killed three police officers on Sunday. The suspect, Gavin Long, had a history of posting social media tirades.

headline: Fashion That Gets Under the Skin
abstract: As we get more obsessed with celebrity and personalization, could DNA-infused clothes be the next big thing?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it comes to fashion, how far would you go to show your appreciation of your favorite celebrity?

headline: Leslie Jones, Star of ‘Ghostbusters,’ Becomes a Target of Online Trolls
abstract: Twitter said it has taken action to close the accounts of people who sent the actress racist messages and pornography.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Jones, one of the most visible and accessible stars in the all-female remake of the “Ghostbusters” movie, said that she would leave Twitter after becoming the target of online trolls who sent her a stream of pornography, racist speech and hateful memes.

headline: Israeli Parliament Passes Law Enabling Ouster of Legislators
abstract: The law would allow for the suspension or ouster of legislators accused of racial incitement or supporting armed struggle against Israel. Critics have called it discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Parliament passed contentious legislation early Wednesday that enables the suspension or ouster of members accused of racial incitement or of supporting armed struggle against Israel. Critics said it was intended to target Arab legislators and harmed democratic principles like freedom of expression.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Begins With Trump Written All Over It
abstract: The first night of the Republican National Convention had the incitements and emotions of a Donald J. Trump rally, but didn’t go entirely well.
lead_paragraph: This was not the way Jeb Bush would have entered a room.

headline: Le djihad et l’exception française
abstract: La France n’est pas plus islamophobe que ses voisins. Elle est juste plus frontale dans sa gestion de l’islam dans l’espace public.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Que Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, qui a tué plus de 80 personnes à Nice le 14 juillet, ait agi au service de Daech ou qu’il soit un déséquilibré qui s’est approprié les symboles djihadistes du groupe, la même question essentielle se pose : Pourquoi autant d’attentats d’une telle envergure ont-ils lieu en France plutôt que dans d’autres pays d’Europe?

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’ Returning With New Episodes
abstract: The Netflix documentary series will revisit the cases of Steven Avery and Brendan Dassey.
lead_paragraph: “Making a Murderer,” the true-crime documentary series that became an unexpected sensation for Netflix at the end of 2015, will return for new episodes revisiting the cases of Steven Avery and Brendan Dassey, the streaming service announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Summer Day With Gregory Crewdson
abstract: The photographer takes T through his daily routine in Great Barrington, Mass. — including a hike and a lake swim.
lead_paragraph: The photographer takes T through his daily routine in Great Barrington, Mass. — including a hike and a lake swim.

headline: How Gregory Crewdson Spends His Summer
abstract: The photographer goes on daily hikes and swims — and makes his signature salad — in Great Barrington, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Gregory Crewdson likes to start his day with a long swim. For most of the year, he resigns himself to pools in Brooklyn, New Haven and Great Barrington, Mass. But come June, it’s finally warm enough to swim at his preferred spot: Upper Goose Pond, a lake in the Berkshires not far from where he spent summers growing up. Accessible via a tranquil, wooded stretch of the Appalachian Trail, the lake is a secluded spot — and the hike to get there has become part of a summer ritual for Crewdson and his partner, Juliane Hiam. After his requisite morning cup of coffee from Fuel, a local coffee shop in Great Barrington that Crewdson has frequented for the past 20 years, the pair sets off for the trailhead.

headline: Turkey Seeks to Rid Education of Erdogan Opponents After Coup Attempt
abstract: More than 15,000 workers in Turkey’s education ministry were suspended, 1,500 university deans were ordered to resign and 21,000 teachers lost their licenses.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish authorities extended their purge of state institutions on Tuesday, suspending more than 15,000 employees of the education ministry for suspected links to a failed military coup last week.

headline: Pondicheri Brings Indian Food From Houston to NoMad
abstract: A Texas transplant, a Whole Foods for Williamsburg and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Pondicheri This is the first out-of-town foray for a popular Indian restaurant in Houston, and it will start by serving breakfast, lunch and snacks. The wide-ranging pan-Indian menu includes stuffed parathas and rotis, cooling chaat salads and curries. Customers place orders at a counter, and the food is delivered to their tables. Dinner, which will not begin until mid-August, will be more formal, with full waiter service. The owner is Anita Jaisinghani. The pastry chef is Ashley Dickson, who infuses items like madeleines with exotic spices, and the sommelier is Rajat Parr, who has assembled a global list of wines, most of which you may not find elsewhere. The décor is simple, highlighting an original tile floor, with bare tables and a very long bar. “It’s a big bar,” said Ajna Jai, Ms. Jaisinghani’s daughter. “We’re from Texas.” (Opens Monday):  15 West 27th Street, 646-878-4375, pondichericafe.com.

headline: Lenny Singleton’s Life Sentences
abstract: A prisoner’s wife tells her story.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Chamber for Big Business
abstract: Public Citizen writes that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has become “a big-spending lobbyist with an extreme agenda.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Baton Rouge Gunman and ‘Targeted Individuals’
abstract: In online posts and videos, Gavin Long interacted with online groups loosely organized around the belief that government agents secretly stalk and harass everyday Americans.
lead_paragraph: Many labels for Gavin Long have emerged from the rich digital footprint that he left behind — former Marine, antigovernment radical, alpha male, life coach. But one has stood out for its peculiarity, that of “targeted individual.”

headline: How Much Money Can I Make Off Trump’s Convention?
abstract: The locals are divided on the politics but united on the desire to make the convention work for Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland Heights, Ohio — MY family’s platform for the Republican National Convention is “whatever the market will bear.” My wife, Alice, is renting out our guest room on Airbnb, and my older son, a lawyer, moonlights as an Uber driver. Our Airbnb guest, Omri Nahmias, is a reporter for Walla News in Israel. My son is driving delegates, reporters and off-duty cops from out of state, some of whom want to see the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

headline: In Death, Qandeel Baloch, Pakistani Social Media Star, Is Celebrated as a Feminist Hero
abstract: Authorities arrested Ms. Baloch’s brother, who said he killed her because of “shameful” pictures she had posted to Facebook.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Qandeel Baloch, a social media star some called the Kim Kardashian of Pakistan, provoked an outcry on social media from Pakistani feminists and others who saw the 26-year-old as a symbol of women’s empowerment.

headline: ‘Nothing Short of a Miracle’: No Serious Injuries in Tappan Zee Crane Collapse
abstract: The collapse of the crane, which was being used in the construction of the bridge’s replacement, snarled traffic and left at least four people with minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: In the ambitious business of New York bridge building, it has been a tragic consequence of the work: More than 20 people, including the bridge’s lead engineer, lost their lives during the construction of the Brooklyn Bridge. As workers raised the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in the 1960s, three people paid the ultimate price. And during construction of the original Tappan Zee Bridge in the 1950s, a worker fell to his death.

headline: Skyscrapers’ Rise in China Marks the Fall of Immigrant Enclaves
abstract: Baishizhou, an urban village within surging Shenzhen, has been a source of cheap housing for immigrants for decades, but its days are numbered.
lead_paragraph: BAISHIZHOU, China — The concrete block buildings that shade the narrow asphalt alleyways of Baishizhou are so closely situated that they are called “handshake” buildings — it is that easy for neighbors to greet one another.

headline: Review: In ‘The Accidental Life,’ Golfing on LSD Is Just Part of an Editor’s Job
abstract: Terry McDonell recounts a career editing writers like Hunter S. Thompson, Peter Matthiessen and Thomas McGuane.
lead_paragraph: There’s a book I’ve been meaning to buy, a memoir called “Reflections of an Angry Middle-Aged Editor” (1960), by James A. Wechsler of The New York Post, because I like its title. I want a copy, too, because I know so many middle-aged editors who are angry and, after a drink or two, given to reflection.

headline: Secrecy in Arbitration: The Suit Against Roger Ailes
abstract: A lawyer for a former Fox News anchor, Gretchen Carlson, bemoans the confidentiality clauses of arbitration agreements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Food From Ipanema
abstract: Visiting Rio for the Summer Olympics? Some of Florence Fabricant’s picks for where to eat during the games or while on vacation.
lead_paragraph: Visiting Rio for the Summer Olympics? Some of Florence Fabricant’s picks for where to eat during the games or while on vacation.

headline: Where to Eat in Rio de Janeiro
abstract: Seven restaurants that showcase the flavors and culinary traditions of Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Although economic woes and the mosquito-borne Zika virus are deterring many from attending this summer’s Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, it’s really too bad, as the vibrant flavors of the city’s restaurants should not be missed. On a trip to Rio a few months ago, I consulted locals (Cariocas) for recommendations that seemed to be in touch with the country’s many intriguing ingredients and culinary traditions. Here are the places, high end and modest, traditional and cutting edge, that I would be happy to revisit.

headline: Gagosian Gallery to Pay New York State $4.3 Million
abstract: The amount, in back taxes, interest and penalties, came after the state attorney general’s office found that the gallery failed to pay sales tax on hundreds of art transactions over a decade.
lead_paragraph: The Gagosian Gallery, one of the most successful art dealerships in the world, failed to pay New York State sales tax on hundreds of art transactions over a decade, according to Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, who on Tuesday announced an agreement to collect $4.28 million in back taxes, interest and penalties from the business.

headline: Melania Trump’s Speech: Signs of Plagiarism
abstract: The similarities to a speech by Michelle Obama reflect “bush league carelessness,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A ‘Moderate’ Saudi Arabia?
abstract: A professor writes that American leaders “have defined as ‘moderate’ those Middle Eastern countries important to us economically or militarily.”

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Tuition Plan
abstract: The American Council on Education writes that “concern that the Clinton plan will increase tuition” is unfounded.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Enlightening Books, and Why Viggo Mortensen Read Them
abstract: The actor — and enthusiastic reader — shares thoughts on the titles that helped him get into character for his new film, “Captain Fantastic.”
lead_paragraph: In the new film “Captain Fantastic,” Viggo Mortensen plays Ben, an off-the-grid patriarch raising his six children to be intellectuals and survivalists in equal measure — “philosopher kings” as adept at discussing Marxist theory and speaking Esperanto as they are at hunting game. “The kids have to express some pretty mature ideas and concepts,” Mortensen says. “They have to verbalize things that would be difficult even for an adult actor to sound convincing or knowledgeable about. That takes time, a real effort to get the right casting down and to work with them.”

headline: All the Different Things the Trump Campaign Said About Melania Trump’s Speech
abstract: Donald J. Trump and his allies hastened to argue that similarities between Ms. Trump’s speech and one Michelle Obama gave in 2008 were meaningless.

headline: German Train Attacker Pledges Allegiance to ISIS
abstract: A man with an ax stormed a train in southern Germany on Monday night, leaving four passengers injured. The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A man with an ax stormed a train in southern Germany on Monday night, leaving four passengers injured. The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Tuesday.

headline: 10 Favorite 36 Hours Destinations
abstract: Revisit cities like Charleston, Hong Kong and Barcelona in this selection of popular 36 Hours columns.
lead_paragraph: Revisit cities like Charleston, Hong Kong and Barcelona in this selection of popular 36 Hours columns.

headline: Old Teeth Tell New Stories About People Who Didn’t Get Enough Sun
abstract: Researchers discovered a permanent record of vitamin D deficiency in old teeth that could provide insights on rickets and children’s health today.
lead_paragraph: You don’t just have teeth in your mouth: You have around 32 fossils that tell a microscopic history of your health. And scientists have found that even the old, discarded, not-so-pearly whites of people that lived hundreds of years ago tell a story about them, too.

headline: Rejection of Bayer Bid May Shortchange Monsanto Shareholders
abstract: Monsanto, the American maker of genetically modified crop seeds, says it’s open to further discussions.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto is overvaluing its independence. The American crop-science giant rejected Bayer’s latest $64 billion takeover offer on Tuesday, saying the $125 a share bid was “financially inadequate,” though the leadership was open to further discussions. But Monsanto would struggle to reach the German bidder’s price on its own over three years – even with aggressive assumptions. Monsanto’s chief executive, Hugh Grant, is protesting too much.

headline: Soul-Searching Within the Republican Party
abstract: Readers discuss Peter Wehner’s call for “an honest reckoning” as he wondered: “How on earth did our party produce Mr. Trump as its nominee?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jihad and the French Exception
abstract: France is no more Islamophobic than its neighbors. It’s just more frontal in the way it handles Islam in the public sphere.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Whether Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed more than 80 people during Bastille Day celebrations in Nice, was an agent of the Islamic State or an unhinged loner who borrowed the group’s jihadist symbols, the slaughter raises the same fundamental question: Why do so many more attacks of this magnitude occur in France than in other European countries?

headline: Jennifer Saunders, Joanna Lumley and Jon Hamm at ‘Absolutely Fabulous’ Premiere
abstract: Co-stars, drag queens and other “fantastic creatures” celebrate the movie version of the ’90s British sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Co-stars, drag queens and other “fantastic creatures” celebrate the movie version of the ’90s British sitcom.

headline: Review: In ‘The Power of Punctuation,’ Judging Potential Mates by Their Texts
abstract: Natalie Margolin’s play centers on three female college roommates whose bonds are tested by the strict rules they use for dating in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Saturday night has turned into 4 a.m. on Sunday by the time Jenny and Fran stumble through the door of their college apartment, drunk but festive, dancing to music until calamity strikes: Fran drops her iPhone. It cracks and won’t turn on.

headline: An Unapologetic Boris Johnson, Diplomat, Meets the Press
abstract: Britain’s new foreign secretary, known for past insults of President Obama, Hillary Clinton and others, said he would not apologize for such comments, which he said had been misconstrued.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In his first news conference as British foreign secretary, Boris Johnson stood beside Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday and said he would not apologize for his past insults of President Obama and Hillary Clinton.

headline: Left Out of the Party
abstract: For some Republicans, the rise of Donald Trump to the head of their party has been acutely painful. We asked them to share their anguish.
lead_paragraph: For some Republicans, the rise of Donald Trump to the head of their party has been acutely painful. We asked them to share their anguish.

headline: Perfume Genius’s Most Magical Possession
abstract: The musician discusses his “kitchen witch” — a totem that’s been looking after him for the past seven years.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: Labour Dissidents Unite Around Challenger to Jeremy Corbyn as Leader
abstract: Owen Smith, the British opposition party’s former spokesman on welfare issues, won a contest for support among Labour deputies, prompting his rival to withdraw from the race.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rebellious lawmakers in Britain’s opposition Labour Party agreed on Tuesday on a single candidate to challenge their leader, Jeremy Corbyn, intensifying a bitter struggle to oust the left-wing party boss after months of internal feuding.

headline: The Story Behind Six Dishes at In Situ
abstract: Dishes from the chefs Alice Waters, David Chang, Wylie Dufresne, René Redzepi, Mauro Colagreco and Virgilio Martínez explained.
lead_paragraph: Dishes from the chefs Alice Waters, David Chang, Wylie Dufresne, René Redzepi, Mauro Colagreco and Virgilio Martínez explained.

headline: Fashion’s Newest Frontier: The Disabled and the Displaced
abstract: For years, designers responded to social problems by fund-raising. Now they’re taking it to a new level. Welcome to the world of solution-based design.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Maura Horton, a housewife in Raleigh, N.C., received a call from her husband, Don, the assistant football coach at North Carolina State. He was on the road for a game and having so much trouble buttoning his shirt, he had to ask a player (Russell Wilson, now the quarterback of the Seattle Seahawks) for help.

headline: In Situ
abstract: The chef Corey Lee’s new restaurant in the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art pays homage to the culinary arts.
lead_paragraph: The chef Corey Lee’s new restaurant in the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art pays homage to the culinary arts.

headline: This Is America’s Most Original New Restaurant
abstract: Corey Lee’s new restaurant regards chefs as practitioners of high culture and iconic dishes as works of art, like literature, music or painting.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — By avoiding originality, In Situ is the most original new restaurant in the country.

headline: As Americans Fall Behind at the Tour de France, a Wave of Britons Floods the Gap
abstract: British cyclists are dominating this year’s Tour — an unthinkable achievement not long ago. For the United States, things are trending in the opposite direction.
lead_paragraph: BERN, Switzerland — It would have been unthinkable just over a decade ago, but the dominant nation at this year’s Tour de France is Britain.

headline: Photographs From Day 2 of the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: When Subpoenas Threaten Climate Science
abstract: A subpoena issued by a Republican congressman to a science advocacy organization is a constitutional travesty.
lead_paragraph: Last week, my organization — the Union of Concerned Scientists — received a subpoena signed by Lamar S. Smith of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology. The subpoena orders me to hand over correspondence between my staff members and state attorneys general, and between my staff members and environmental organizations and funders. This demand impinges on our group’s constitutional rights, and it would set a terrible precedent affecting many other advocacy groups were we to comply with it.

headline: Theresa May’s Vision of a Radical British Conservatism
abstract: In a speech just before she became Britain’s prime minister, she called for more protectionism, a greater say for workers and limits on C.E.O. pay.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s new prime minister, Theresa May, is the leader of the Conservative Party there. Yet when it comes to the corporate world, she can sound more like Bernie Sanders than Margaret Thatcher.

headline: So You Want to Join a Community-Supported Agriculture Group
abstract: What to consider before joining a farm share or community-supported agriculture group.
lead_paragraph: What to consider before joining a farm share or community-supported agriculture group.

headline: When Community-Supported Agriculture Is Not What It Seems
abstract: As demand for local and organic produce has ballooned in the last five years, so have other ideas for connecting farmers to customers.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, a farm-to-table subscription service called Local Roots NYC dropped off boxes at pickup spots in New York City including a cafe, a brew pub and the offices of BuzzFeed.

headline: Photographs From the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: Copy Edit This!
abstract: The Times’s standards editor, Philip B. Corbett, invites readers to correct grammatical errors in recently published Times stories.
lead_paragraph: Philip B. Corbett, The Times’s standards editor, also oversees the newsroom style manual and advises reporters and editors on questions of grammar and usage.

headline: The Shed Announces Its First Art Commissions
abstract: This arts center, in a new building on the Far West Side, plans to show work by Lawrence Weiner and collaborate with Reggie Gray (Regg Roc) and the D.R.E.A.M. Ring.
lead_paragraph: While the arts center on the Far West Side now known as the Shed – formerly Culture Shed – has been on the boards for some time, its content has remained unclear. Now some of that programming is beginning to take shape.

headline: Justice Dept. Will Seek to Block 2 Health Insurance Mergers
abstract: Antitrust officials are concerned that Aetna’s deal with Humana and Anthem’s pursuit of Cigna would harm competition in the health insurance industry.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing lawsuits to block two giant health insurance deals, according to a person briefed on the matter, continuing a spate of antitrust actions in a whirlwind year for mergers and acquisitions.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Baker, Kim Severson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Review: A Restaged ‘Small Mouth Sounds’ Still Sparkles
abstract: The play, much of which is silent, is just as intimate and lucid as its performances at Ars Nova last year.
lead_paragraph: “Small Mouth Sounds,” a quiet gem of a play by Bess Wohl that was first seen Off Broadway at Ars Nova last year, has been restaged at the Pershing Square Signature Center with all its wit, compassion and sparkle fully intact. The sound of silence onstage has rarely made such sweet music.

headline: Accused of Sexual Harassment, Roger Ailes Is Negotiating Exit From Fox
abstract: The company has been investigating accusations of sexual harassment in a lawsuit filed against him.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes’s tenure as the head of Fox News appears to be over.

headline: Not Even Plácido Domingo Can Say No to ‘Mozart in the Jungle’
abstract: Mr. Domingo is the latest classical star to shoot a cameo for the Amazon show at a time when TV opportunities for artists have dried up.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — It was after midnight on the Grand Canal here, and Plácido Domingo was standing on a floating stage slowly motoring toward the Accademia Bridge, singing the opening lines of a duet from “Don Giovanni.”

headline: Brooklyn Blowhards Navigate the Free Jazz of Herman Melville
abstract: Inspired by Melville and the saxophonist Albert Ayler, Jeff Lederer’s jazz band plays a frothy blend of sea chanteys and avant-garde jazz.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon Jeff Lederer could be found caterwauling with his tenor saxophone in an unlikely but meaningful setting: the grave of Herman Melville, in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. What brought Mr. Lederer there was the same confluence of interests that had created Brooklyn Blowhards, his newest band.

headline: Tired of the Convention? A Guide to Shows to Watch Instead
abstract: Off-the-beaten-trail entertainment options that aren’t reruns, including “HarmonQuest,” “t@gged” and “Ozzy and Jack’s World Detour.”
lead_paragraph: An informed citizen is, of course, the best citizen, but every citizen needs a break from convention coverage now and then. Yet with reruns ruling much of the rest of the television spectrum, what’s a viewer to do? Poke around in the less-well-traveled reaches of the cable and streaming universes, that’s what. Here are four ways to seek relief from too much political coverage:

headline: Global Temperatures Are on Course for Another Record This Year
abstract: While El Niño may be partially behind rising temperatures, NASA says greenhouse gases are the main culprit.
lead_paragraph: The world is on pace to set another high temperature benchmark, with 2016 becoming the third year in a row of record heat.

headline: An ‘Absolutely Fabulous’ Premiere
abstract: All the “fantastic creatures,” including co-stars, drag queens and other fans of the ’90s sitcom gather for the film’s release.
lead_paragraph: “I’m sweating like a pig,” Jennifer Saunders said Monday night, standing on a red carpet at the School of Visual Arts Theater in Chelsea, where drag queens were lined up by the dozen and fans stood around holding up pictures for her to sign.

headline: Republican Convention, Hillary Clinton, Roger Ailes: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Governors Island, a Grand Space to Play
abstract: Seersucker dandies and ball-capped Brooklyn dads, ice cream trucks and rosé festivals ... the summer spectacle in New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: One recent Saturday on Governors Island, with a glorious gray dome of clouds covering New York Harbor, a Mister Softee truck idled on the car deck of the Lt. Samuel S. Coursen as passengers boarded the 6 p.m. ferry to Manhattan.

headline: One Russian Security Agency Raids Another, in Rare Sign of Dysfunction
abstract: Three senior prosecutors were arrested as the main domestic intelligence service searched the Moscow offices of a powerful branch of the prosecutor’s office.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s main domestic intelligence service raided the Moscow headquarters of an investigative agency on Tuesday, in a rare sign of dysfunction in the country’s domestic security services.

headline: Mike Pence’s Record on Education Is One of Turmoil and Mixed Results
abstract: Mr. Pence ended the Common Core and expanded vouchers and charter schools during a contentious time for public education in Indiana.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump has said little about what he would do on education.

headline: Cash Pay Dips a Bit for Corporate Lawyers
abstract: As a group, corporate lawyers were paid 2 percent less in cash in 2015 than in 2014. Those at the top fared better. And noncash pay wasn’t included.
lead_paragraph: Cash pay for in-house lawyers dipped over all last year, but not for the very top.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $6.5 million

headline: WhatsApp Is Briefly Shut Down in Brazil for a Third Time
abstract: The app, owned by Facebook, was shut down by a state criminal court when it did not hand over data requested by authorities. The order was overturned.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — For months, authorities in Brazil have sought access to digital data from WhatsApp to aid in criminal investigations. WhatsApp has repeatedly resisted the requests.

headline: A Boehner Party Starts Slow, and Beer and Burgers at the R.N.C.
abstract: New York Times correspondents are chronicling the colorful, the unusual and the quirky at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — New York Times correspondents are chronicling the colorful, the unusual and the quirky at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

headline: Review: Kidz Bop Kids, Singing Sanitized Pop With Relentless Cheer
abstract: The group performed sweetened and softened pop hits at the Ford Amphitheater at Coney Island Boardwalk, in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Last month, “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” ran a sketch about an imagined compilation called “Kidz Bop Hip-Hop,” a set of sanitized and cheerily naïve remakes of hip-hop songs. Ice Cube’s elegiac “It Was a Good Day” became “Snow Day,” and Ty Dolla Sign’s “Paranoid,” about dodging a vindictive lover, became “Dirty Boy,” about hating baths: “I see all these bubbles in the tub/got to hide from my mother.”

headline: G.O.P. Joins Democrats Urging Glass-Steagall’s Revival. (Don’t Hold Your Breath.)
abstract: Platform writers in both parties call for reviving Glass-Steagall to curb Wall Street. But the agreement is narrow and shallow.
lead_paragraph: Attacking big banks is as American as apple pie. But it’s a new entry on this year’s Republican menu.

headline: ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Revival to Close in December
abstract: The Broadway show will close on Dec. 31, a little over a year after the production opened on Broadway, the producers said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A much-praised revival of “Fiddler on the Roof” will close on Dec. 31, a little over a year after the production opened on Broadway, the producers said Tuesday.

headline: 3 Men in India Accused of Raping Woman a Second Time
abstract: The men were among a group of five who allegedly targeted a 20-year-old college student as punishment for accusing them of raping her before.
lead_paragraph: ROHTAK, India — Police officers in northern India on Tuesday arrested three men suspected of kidnapping and raping a 20-year-old college student last week, allegedly targeting her a second time as punishment for accusing them of raping her before.

headline: Michael Elliott, Newsmagazine Editor and Humanitarian, Dies at 65
abstract: A longtime journalist who left the industry to lead an advocacy group founded by the rock star Bono.
lead_paragraph: Michael Elliott, a journalistic anomaly who held management positions at the world’s three major English-language newsweeklies before mutating from editor to humanitarian, died on July 14 in Washington. He was 65.

headline: Hyperloop One Sues 4 Who Accused the Start-Up of Harassment
abstract: The start-up, which is developing a high-speed train, accuses its accusers of trying to start a competing venture with poached employees.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a lawsuit was filed against the high-speed train start-up Hyperloop One, accusing some of its top figures of harassment and mismanagement, the company is fighting back.

headline: Republican Convention Day 2: Analysis
abstract: We analyzed the second night of the Republican National Convention in real time. The highlights.
lead_paragraph: We analyzed the second night of the Republican National Convention in real time. The highlights.

headline: The Vanished Shoe Repair Shop
abstract: A poetic lament for the thin man on East 44th Street who stood for decades with his bootblacks and cobblers.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Republican Convention Night 2: What You Missed
abstract: Welcome to the prime-time lineup of Night 2 of the convention that just formally nominated Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump is officially the Republican presidential nominee  and tonight’s focus at the Republican National Convention — ostensibly, at least — was on jobs and the economy.

headline: Microsoft Earnings Are Up, Cushioned by Its Cloud Business
abstract: Quarterly revenue from Azure, the cloud business it introduced to compete with Amazon, rose more than 100 percent.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft is best known for software products like Windows and Office. If you bought a PC, more often than not it came with Windows, and chances are you bought a copy of Office to go with it.

headline: ‘We’re Coming to Get You!’ It’s Vintage Giuliani at G.O.P. Convention
abstract: In his speech, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York tapped into the emotions that helped get him elected in 1993, which are current themes in the Republican Party: fear, danger and anger.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stood before the nation, fists clenched, eyes wide and arms cast to the heavens. His message, on the opening night of the Republican National Convention, was as clear as it was apocalyptic: The world is full of danger and terror.

headline: Rob Portman’s Alternate Universe Convention
abstract: The Ohio senator lobbied for Cleveland to host his party this summer. Now he is steering clear of official proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland — It’s hard not to feel a little sorry for Rob Portman. The moderate Republican Ohio senator, now caught in a fierce re-election fight against the former Ohio governor Ted Strickland, lobbied hard in 2014 for Cleveland to host the Republican National Convention this summer. Two years later, he’s trying to stay as far away from the convention limelight as possible.

headline: G.O.P. Nominates Trump for President
abstract: Donald J. Trump was formally nominated as the Republican presidential candidate on the second day of the national convention.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was formally nominated as the Republican presidential candidate on the second day of the national convention.

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Said to Seek National Security Experience for Vice Presidential Pick
abstract: The shortlist includes James G. Stavridis, a former NATO commander, and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, who is on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
lead_paragraph: Facing a fall contest against a Republican opponent focused on law and order, Hillary Clinton has narrowed her search for a vice-presidential candidate, telling several potential running mates that she needs a No. 2 who would bring national security experience to the Democratic ticket.

headline: Carolyn See, Novelist Who Portrayed Quirks of Southern California, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. See often put portraits of intimate relationships and sociological observations of the lives of Angelenos together with grander fictional ideas.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn See, a novelist and memoirist who built a writing life on the singularities and peculiarities of Los Angeles and its environs, where she lived much of her life, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 82.

headline: Turkey Pursues Cleric Living in U.S., Blamed as Coup Mastermind
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Fethullah Gulen was behind a coup attempt last week that almost succeeded in taking over the state and killing Mr. Erdogan himself.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, says that a mild-mannered Muslim cleric living in self-imposed exile in rural Pennsylvania was pulling the strings of a coup attempt last week that almost succeeded in taking over the state, and killing Mr. Erdogan himself.

headline: Swimmer Dana Vollmer Seeks Another Gold Medal, This Time as a Mother
abstract: At 28, Vollmer is part of an older group of swimmers who have been able to stay in the sport because of professionalization, but training while caring for a 16-month-old poses logistical problems.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Dana Vollmer’s first reaction upon qualifying for her third Olympic team was relief. With a second-place finish in the 100-meter butterfly at the United States swimming trials in Omaha last month, she earned the right to defend her Olympic title in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Wisconsin Residents Can Vote Without a Photo ID in November
abstract: A federal judge ruled residents can vote if they sign an affidavit swearing to their identity.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin residents without photo identification can vote in November’s election if they sign an affidavit swearing to their identity, a federal judge ruled Tuesday, providing temporary clarity in a long-running dispute about voter identification.

headline: Giuliani’s Convention Speech: Same Old Volume, but a Far Different Tone
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s theme of fear contrasted sharply with reassuring comments he made as mayor of New York in the days after Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: We had gone a number of years without a good, ripping Rudy Giuliani shouting fit, and one began to wonder if the old lion had lost his roar. After all, he had, more or less, provided at least one astounding spell of public hollering every decade since the 1980s. Yet while his rhetoric has grown more reliably partisan, his decibel level seems to have dropped. Mother of mercy, as Edward G. Robinson asks at the end of “Little Caesar,” could this be the end of Rudy?

headline: New Jersey Drivers Fume as Road and Bridge Work Stops
abstract: Amid a stalemate over taxes, road rage is climbing, detours are lengthening and the state is losing precious summer days to complete hundreds of projects.
lead_paragraph: Several miles from Princeton, drivers are playing chicken as they detour across a single-lane bridge. In Summit, the prolonged shutdown of a century-old crossing has forced nearby businesses to lay off workers. And in Hoboken, the delay of the long-awaited rehabilitation of a critical connection to the Lincoln Tunnel threatens to disrupt back-to-school traffic.

headline: New Jersey Town Asks State to Deem Bridge Project Essential
abstract: Franklin Township asked the New Jersey Department of Transportation to deem a bridge repair project essential, citing the bridge's proximity to a local hospital. The state has halted all non-essential transportation repairs because its transportation trust fund is nearly out of money, causing the bridge to be closed indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: Franklin Township asked the New Jersey Department of Transportation to deem a bridge repair project essential, citing the bridge's proximity to a local hospital. The state has halted all non-essential transportation repairs because its transportation trust fund is nearly out of money, causing the bridge to be closed indefinitely.

headline: Yankees’ Best Move? Waiting for Another Team to Act
abstract: The Mariners’ need for a closer at the trade deadline in 1997 resulted in a steal for the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: For the Yankees to win at the trading deadline, they need another team to panic. In Aroldis Chapman, they have precisely the kind of player to make rival executives lose their sense of reason.

headline: John Gruen, Cultural Renaissance Man, Dies at 89
abstract: As a composer, critic, biographer and photographer, Mr. Gruen excelled at an unusually diverse set of talents.
lead_paragraph: John Gruen, a cultural critic renowned for the vast breadth of his artistic net and the vast candor of his art-world memoir, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: In Baton Rouge, a Divided City Faces Two Different Tragedies
abstract: The shootings of police officers after that of a black man have led to talk of healing, and of a widening rift.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Asha Bennie, a lifelong resident of this Deep South city, said she was horrified by the ambush-style shooting here on Sunday of six law enforcement officers by an African-American man.

headline: How Melania Trump’s Speech Veered Off Course and Caused an Uproar
abstract: Two veteran Republican speechwriters had created a draft last month. But inside Trump Tower, it turned out, Ms. Trump began tearing it apart.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was the biggest speech of Melania Trump’s life, and her husband, Donald, wanted it to be perfect.

headline: Final 9/11 Remnants Removed From Hangar in Solemn Ceremony
abstract: Many gathered in Hangar 17 at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday for a ceremony that commemorated the departure of the final items it housed from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: The 360-foot-tall antenna once stood atop the north tower of the World Trade Center, transmitting signals to televisions across New York City.

headline: In Cleveland’s Public Square, Rights Are Exercised. Loudly.
abstract: A few blocks from the arena hosting the Republican convention, in a 10-acre downtown commons, a full-throated national conversation is taking place.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The woman holding a handbag lets loose. Leaning in to the microphone, she decries police brutality, economic inequity, racial strife, domestic violence — just about every pressing issue of these American days.

headline: Prosecutor Offers Glimpse of Evidence in New York Police Corruption Case
abstract: Among the evidence under review were thumb drives, smartphones and business cards, which related to people currently and formerly at the New York Police Department and local elected officials.
lead_paragraph: When the authorities executed a search warrant last month at the home of Jeremiah Reichberg, a Brooklyn businessman arrested in a federal corruption investigation, they noticed one of Mr. Reichberg’s family members trying to leave the house carrying various items, a prosecutor told a federal judge on Tuesday.

headline: Doomed From the Start
abstract: The return of Gordon Johnson.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When last we saw Gordon Johnson, he was making his New York Times Crossword debut in a scientific manner. Today, he’s back to remind us of the great romances that have developed as a result of starring in movies.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 17 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 17 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Zika Investigated in Florida; Possible First Homegrown Case in U.S.
abstract: If the case is confirmed, it would be the first time the Zika virus had been transmitted locally by mosquitoes in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Department of Health said Tuesday that it was investigating what could be the first homegrown case of the Zika virus in the United States.

headline: Drudge Tweet on Roger Ailes Sets Off Media Scramble
abstract: A Twitter message sent, and then deleted, led to a high-speed internet chase to try to verify the future of the chairman of Fox News.
lead_paragraph: It was a tweet heard round the media world.

headline: Big 12, Moving Past Baylor Scandal, Considers Expansion
abstract: The smallest Power 5 conference is satisfied with the university’s response to an N.C.A.A. investigation and is vetting potential members.
lead_paragraph: The Big 12 is considering expanding beyond its current 10 members, the conference said Tuesday, and is satisfied with steps that Baylor, one of its members, has taken since an investigation found a lax institutional culture was to blame for a rash of accusations against and convictions of football players for sexual assault.

headline: California Staff Workers Are Sidelined by Illness
abstract: A stomach virus requires a hotel quarantine, a protest zone heats up and an artist is “unashamed” of painting his support for Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Thirteen staff members from the California delegation are having an experience unique among the thousands of delegates, volunteers and party officials who traveled here for the Republican National Convention: They are quarantined in their hotel rooms about 60 miles from the convention site.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, July 20, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Ninety-three percent of the speech is completely different.”

headline: Tom Kibble, Physicist Who Helped Discover the Higgs Mechanism, Dies at 83
abstract: Although Dr. Kibble was not awarded the Nobel Prize for his contributions to the discovery of the Higgs boson, his work sowed the seeds for other discoveries.
lead_paragraph: Though Tom Kibble never received a Nobel Prize in Physics, the consensus among his colleagues is that he deserved one. His research was at the root of at least three seminal discoveries that earned others the coveted prize.

headline: Black Republicans See a White Convention, Heavy on Lectures
abstract: For many black Republicans, speeches have veered toward moralizing on race, an off-putting posture given Donald J. Trump’s unpopularity with minority voters.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Mike Hill, a black Republican state representative in Florida, grew steadily more disheartened as he watched television clips of his party’s overwhelmingly white national convention lecturing African-Americans about the police and race relations.

headline: Donald Trump Claims Nomination, With Discord Clear but Family Cheering
abstract: With his campaign buffeted by criticism and denying claims of plagiarism, 721 delegates cast their votes for candidates other than the nominee.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump was formally crowned the Republican nominee for president at the party’s convention on Tuesday, ending a tumultuous primary season but not the nagging questions about his polarizing candidacy as he once again found himself embroiled in controversy.

headline: Yankees Beat Orioles Again to Climb Above .500
