headline: Mapping Detroit, Inch by Inch
abstract: What started as a small investing project became a larger effort to digitize Detroit’s property information and to establish channels between the public and the city.

headline: Federal Court Rules Texas’ ID Law Violates Voting Rights Act
abstract: While the court did not strike down the law entirely, Democrats and voting-rights advocates praised it for finding that the law discriminated against minorities.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled that Texas’ voter identification law, one of the strictest in the country, violated the Voting Rights Act and that the state must find ways to accommodate voters who face hardships in obtaining the necessary documents.

headline: Failure of 2 Health Insurer Mergers Is Unlikely to Stop the Efforts
abstract: The Justice Department is expected to block two mergers among the nation’s largest health insurers, but experts say that growth through partnerships will probably continue.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is expected to block two mergers involving four of the nation’s five largest health insurance companies, on the ground that the deals would harm competition. But don’t expect the action to stop the consolidation in the health care industry anytime soon.

headline: The Unexpectedly Cheerful Circus Outside the Republican National Convention
abstract: Among the T-shirt-hawking, selfie-taking, cable-celebrity-obsessed faithful in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Steve Scanlon, a roving souvenir vendor from Connecticut, was hawking “Hillary’s Lies Matter” and “Life’s a Bitch, Don’t Vote for One” buttons on a street corner in Cleveland when I met him here late Tuesday afternoon. “I usually go everywhere Trump goes,” he told me. Business is fat, and the crowds have been warm — downright festive, even. This was one of the things that struck me most about the Republican National Convention after spending a couple of days wandering around the Quicken Loans Arena and its environs: how much it called to mind the let-your-freak-flag-fly conviviality of a music festival, with Scanlon a bizarro-universe version of the hippies selling edibles in the parking lot outside a Phish show.

headline: Peter Copping Is Out at Oscar de la Renta
abstract: The designer lasted less than two years at the high-end New York fashion house.
lead_paragraph: In yet another startling turn in the fashion world, Peter Copping, the creative director of Oscar de la Renta, has left the brand after less than two years.

headline: Technology Is Monitoring the Urban Landscape
abstract: Much technical change in American cities will involve monitoring, which can make life easier but poses troubling questions about privacy and control.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Big City is watching you.

headline: Summertime Treats Popping up in the Hamptons
abstract: A lamé caftan for a night out, a whimsical holiday clutch, stripy silk tops and more.
lead_paragraph: Summertime and the living is easy … On Friday, Armarium, the on-demand platform for luxury fashion rentals, will drop anchor in the Hamptons for a two-week pop-up. There will be lots of breezy bits, like a Missoni sheer lamé caftan ($300 rental, $2,190 retail) that’s perfect for a summer night out. The items are also available via the mobile app, should you be vacationing elsewhere in the world. At Baron’s Cove, 31 West Water Street, Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: How Traders Use Front-Running to Profit From Client Orders
abstract: On Wednesday, federal prosecutors charged two HSBC employees with ‘front-running.’ But how do traders use this practice to maximize profits?
lead_paragraph: About $5.3 trillion changes hands daily in the foreign exchange market. When banks make trades in currencies on behalf of customers, similar to when they trade other securities like stocks or bonds, they are supposed to put the client’s interests ahead of their own. But that’s not how it always works out. In a case announced on Wednesday, prosecutors say two HSBC employees used information they had gotten about a pending client transaction to trade ahead of it, turning a profit for the bank in the process.

headline: Making America Safe for Whom?
abstract: Republicans are holding their convention just 10 minutes away from where 12-year-old Tamir Rice was shot in the stomach.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — So far, the Republican National Convention in Cleveland has been a slapdash spectacle of the absurd, with processions of B-list politicians and Z-list celebrities jockeying for the title of biggest embarrassment.

headline: The 61-Year-Old Club Kid
abstract: By day, Geraldine Visco works at Columbia University. By night, she’s having the time of her life.
lead_paragraph: “I’m an extrovert,” said Geraldine Visco, wearing a bell-bottom body suit, gold chains, a pink cowboy hat, neon blue lipstick and little stars painted on her face.

headline: A Doping Scandal Appears Unlikely to Tarnish Russia’s President
abstract: Mr. Putin is managing the crisis with his standard dual track: a message of cooperation for the international community, while telling Russians that the West is constantly plotting against them.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir V. Putin embraced sports as a metaphor for a resurgent Russia soon after he first became president, declaring as he sent athletes off to the Olympic Games in 2000, “Victories in sport do more to cement the nation than 100 political slogans.”

headline: Court Halts U.S. Seizure of New York Building Linked to Iran
abstract: A federal appeals panel ordered further proceedings in a case that could let relatives of terrorist victims collect proceeds from the property’s sale.
lead_paragraph: In a setback for victims of attacks linked to Iran, a federal appeals court in New York on Wednesday threw out a lower-court ruling that had upheld the government’s move to seize a landmark Manhattan building on charges that it was a front for Iran.

headline: Republican Convention Night 3: Analysis
abstract: Here’s how we analyzed the third night of the Republican National Convention, which featured Mike Pence, Ted Cruz and more.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the third night of the Republican National Convention, which featured Mike Pence, Ted Cruz and more.

headline: Donald Trump’s Convention Is a Low-Energy Show So Far
abstract: The Republican National Convention has struggled not only to make the most of prime-time speaking slots, but also to retain delegate attendance.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was just after 10:30 p.m. Tuesday, a coveted time slot at any political convention. But at the Quicken Loans Arena here, there were rows and rows of empty seats as Kimberlin Brown, a soap opera actress and California avocado farmer, struggled to talk over the chatter of delegates heading for the exits. The session was supposed to last until 11 p.m.; the gavel fell at 10:58.

headline: Republican Convention Night 3: What You Missed
abstract: All eyes were on Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana on Night 3.
lead_paragraph: All eyes were on Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana as he accepted the vice presidential nomination at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday, its third night, and made the case for Donald J. Trump as a Christian and a conservative.

headline: WADA Clears Rio Drug-Testing Laboratory After Brief Suspension
abstract: WADA’s director general endorsed the laboratory, which had been expected to handle testing at the Olympics before being suspended last month.
lead_paragraph: The Rio de Janeiro laboratory that had been expected to handle drug testing at the Summer Olympics but was suddenly suspended by global regulators last month has been cleared in time for the Games, the World Anti-Doping Agency announced on Wednesday.

headline: Military Leaders Discuss Plans to Counter ISIS Beyond the Battlefield
abstract: Officials from the United States and its allies reviewed a drive against Islamic State-held cities, but also discussed the broader campaign against the group.
lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE ANDREWS, Md. — Officials from the United States and its allies in the fight against the Islamic State hammered out details on Wednesday about how to stabilize and govern the cities of Mosul in Iraq and Raqqa in Syria — the last big strongholds held by the extremist Sunni militancy — in the event that Iraqi and Syrian fighters retake the cities in the coming months.

headline: The Loneliness of Being Black in San Francisco
abstract: As the tech industry thrives, San Francisco’s African-American population is dwindling and its black middle class has all but disappeared.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Gerald Harris was walking along Ocean Beach, the blustery coastline at the western edge of the city, when he passed Danny Glover, a star of Hollywood action movies and a San Francisco native. The men exchanged glances.

headline: Powerless Outlets on Staten Island Ferry Prompt Electric Reactions From Commuters
abstract: Some riders were frustrated to learn that the Transportation Department regularly shuts off power to outlets on ferries to prevent fights over them.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers can increasingly charge their smartphones anywhere — on buses, at sidewalk kiosks and in parks. But there is one place where they are not welcome: the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: Roger Ailes’s Exit Is Unlikely to Erode the Fox News Citadel
abstract: Fox News has been rocked by its chairman’s planned departure. But Mr. Ailes leaves the network in strong shape, with high ratings and huge profits.
lead_paragraph: Will Fox News’s prime-time lineup remain intact? Will the network’s ratings fall back to earth after this wild presidential election? Who could possibly replace Roger Ailes?

headline: Concerned About Zika, More Top Tennis Players Are Skipping Olympics
abstract: Concerns about the virus had been largely minimized by players questioned during the French Open and Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rafael Nadal, who has not played a match since withdrawing from the French Open in May because of a wrist injury, sounded a note of optimism that his recovery would allow him to compete in the Rio Olympics, after he missed the London Olympics four years ago with a different injury.

headline: Flawed Study of Advanced Prostate Cancer Spreads False Alarm
abstract: Widespread reports of a big increase in advanced prostate cancer were based on a study whose methodology has been criticized.
lead_paragraph: Bad news for men popped up in news media all over the country this week, based on a study from Northwestern University reporting that cases of advanced, aggressive prostate cancer had risen sharply from 2004 to 2013.

headline: To Keep Up, Big 12 Looks to Expand
abstract: No league better exemplifies the reality that big-time college sports are driven less by rivalries than by cable cords and subscriber fees.
lead_paragraph: Paul D. Ryan, the House speaker, turned to college football this week in persuading Texas delegates at the Republican National Convention to unify behind the presidential candidate Donald J. Trump.

headline: Nuclear Subsidies Are Key Part of New York’s Clean-Energy Plan
abstract: Approval of the subsidies would make New York one of the first states to reward nuclear plants for producing zero greenhouse-gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: The blueprint for New York State’s lofty clean-energy goals relies on the technologies of the future: The state, officials have promised, will draw half of its electricity from renewable and clean energy sources like wind and solar power by 2030.

headline: Testing a Replay System to Give Soccer Referees Another Set of Eyes
abstract: Soccer officials tested a video replay system at Red Bull Arena on Wednesday to get feedback on what it might look like for professional leagues in the future.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — In an empty Red Bull Arena, a group of teenage soccer players scrimmaged under the watch of a FIFA referee. They defended. They attacked. They scored.

headline: Nets, With Many New Players, Look to Build Something Lasting
abstract: The free-agent guard Jeremy Lin was among six players introduced Wednesday, as the team strives to improve.
lead_paragraph: In the five months since the Nets opened a new practice facility in Brooklyn’s Sunset Park neighborhood, the team has repeatedly spoken of the benefits of the gymnasium’s panoramic view of the Manhattan skyline.

headline: Obama’s Support of Erdogan Is a Stark Reminder of Turkey’s Value to U.S.
abstract: The Turkish leader may be a bitter disappointment to Mr. Obama, but he is still better than other options in the chaotic landscape of the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s hard to remember today that to President Obama, Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey once embodied a new kind of Muslim leader. Mr. Obama regarded him as “a man of principle, and also a man of action,” Tom Donilon, the president’s former national security adviser, said in 2011.

headline: Minnesota Priest’s Memo Says Vatican Ambassador Tried to Stifle Sex Abuse Inquiry
abstract: A newly released document says the envoy destroyed evidence in a 2014 investigation into sexual abuse in the Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Update: This article has been revised to include a response from the Vatican that was received after the article’s initial publication.

headline: Brandon Crawford, the Giants’ Shortstop, Is the Best at What He Does Best
abstract: One of Crawford’s teammates thinks he is having an M.V.P. season — not for what he has done with his bat, but rather what he has done with his glove.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Brandon Crawford, the splendid shortstop for the San Francisco Giants, is the best defensive player in baseball. If only he knew what to make of it.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, July 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “His speech is the whole game. Viewers have to watch it and say, ‘There is the next president of the United States.’”

headline: Lives Upended by Disputed Cuts in Home-Health Care for Disabled Patients
abstract: An insurance group has been systematically and improperly cutting the hours of home care for their disabled clients, according to a report by a coalition of more than 100 nonprofit groups.
lead_paragraph: Widowed and disabled after a lifetime of New York factory work, including decades making baby dolls with glue that proved to be toxic, Alejandra Negron depends on a little help for nearly every step she takes. For years, she has had just enough help to stay safely in her own tidy one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, despite pulmonary disease, asthma, diabetes, arthritis and a heart condition.

headline: New Trend for Terrorists: ‘Dying Live’ as Attacks Unfold
abstract: A New York police official says terrorists are now often streaming live video and pledging allegiance to the Islamic State during their attacks.
lead_paragraph: In a new twist, terrorists around the world are broadcasting their messages live during their deadly attacks, a New York police official told the Association for a Better New York  on Wednesday.

headline: Supposed Consequence
abstract: There are dire consequences for solving Jason Flinn’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — True story: When I was a wee lass, my parents took a much-needed vacation and left me in the care of my grandparents. My grandmother had immigrated from Eastern Europe and, in addition to making wonderful pierogies, she brought and kept with her many of the superstitions of the Old Country.

headline: Internal Inquiry Sealed the Fate of Roger Ailes at Fox
abstract: Lawyers hired by 21st Century Fox took statements from at least six other women who described inappropriate behavior by Roger Ailes, two people briefed on the inquiry said.
lead_paragraph: Executives at 21st Century Fox decided to end the tenure of Roger Ailes after lawyers they hired to investigate an allegation of sexual harassment against him took statements from at least six other women who described inappropriate behavior from Mr. Ailes, two people briefed on the inquiry said Wednesday.

headline: Donald Trump Sets Conditions for Defending NATO Allies Against Attack
abstract: Reiterating a hard-line nationalist approach, Mr. Trump raised new questions about his commitment to automatically defend NATO allies.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump, on the eve of accepting the Republican nomination for president, explicitly raised new questions on Wednesday about his commitment to automatically defending NATO allies if they are attacked, saying he would first look at their contributions to the alliance.

headline: New York City Wants to Move 16- and 17-Year-Olds From Rikers Jail to Bronx Center
abstract: The plan, which faces a lengthy review, would reconfigure a center that now holds 14- and 15-year-olds, and send the younger inmates to a youth center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Under intense pressure to improve conditions in the jail complex on Rikers Island, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has developed a plan to move 16- and 17-year-olds to a dedicated jail for youths in the Bronx.

headline: Bill Clinton Said to Back Virginia’s Tim Kaine for Vice President
abstract: Mr. Clinton believes that Mr. Kaine, a former governor and member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has the right domestic and national security résumé.
lead_paragraph: As Hillary Clinton prepares to make her choice for a vice-presidential candidate, Bill Clinton has privately expressed his support for Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, according to three Democrats briefed on the conversations with the former president this week.

headline: Donald Trump Goes to Bat for Wife’s Speechwriter
abstract: Mr. Trump praised Meredith McIver, who assumed blame for passages in Melania Trump’s convention speech that were lifted from a speech by Michelle Obama.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump on Wednesday praised the longtime corporate employee who assumed blame for two passages in Melania Trump’s convention speech that were lifted from Michelle Obama’s 2008 Democratic National Convention address, but he conceded that the public admission should have come a day earlier.

headline: Republican Factions Find a Unifying Force: Hillary Clinton
abstract: Nothing has seemed to unite the Republican Party better than the shared desire to see Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, in prison.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Republicans here have not quite settled on a consistent affirmative message of support for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Pineda, Teixeira and Beltran Help Yankees Win Fourth Straight
abstract: Michael Pineda pitched six shutout innings, Mark Teixeira ended a career-worst home run drought, and Carlos Beltran drove in the Yankees’ first and last runs against the Orioles.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to know these Yankees at the moment. There was Michael Pineda, pitching out of trouble instead of into it. There was Mark Teixeira, picking up the offense instead of letting it down.

headline: Cruz Booed After Not Endorsing Trump
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz’s speech was a striking snub on the eve of Donald J. Trump’s formal acceptance of the party’s nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz’s speech was a striking snub on the eve of Donald J. Trump’s formal acceptance of the party’s nomination.

headline: Even at Convention, Ted Cruz Can’t Escape Donald Trump’s Shadow
abstract: The nominee’s plane interrupts the senator’s speech, a rock ’n’ roller draws boos, and a former Obama aide says the Democratic primary fight hurt the Clinton campaign.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The revelers beamed, embracing like alumni at a high school reunion. The country music blared. The outdoor bar at a restaurant here was open and generously stocked.

headline: Ted Cruz Stirs Convention Fury in Pointed Snub of Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Cruz refused to endorse his party’s nominee for president and was booed off stage as the Republican convention erupted in an uproar.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Republican convention erupted into tumult on Wednesday night as the bitter primary battle between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz reignited unexpectedly, crushing hopes that the party could project unity.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 3: This Is Your Brain on Drugs
abstract: There are two very divergent story lines happening in this show.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, after over a season of portraying a character with bug-eyed, lock-jawed, pharmaceutical-numbed restraint, Rami Malek cut loose.

headline: The Many Faces of Innovation in U.S. Cities
abstract: Cities are undertaking groundbreaking projects to remake themselves physically, culturally and economically.
lead_paragraph: Cities are undertaking groundbreaking projects to remake themselves physically, culturally and economically.

headline: 100 T-Shirts From the Republican National Convention
abstract: From “Truckers for Trump” to “Vote for Pikachu,” a wide range of views were on display in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: From “Truckers for Trump” to “Vote for Pikachu,” a wide range of views were on display in Cleveland.

headline: C.E.O.s Meet in Secret Over the Sorry State of Public Companies
abstract: In a series of meetings, titans of business and finance grappled with what they see as a problem of too much money going and staying private.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett quietly walked through the lobby of JPMorgan Chase’s headquarters on Park Avenue in Manhattan last summer and was ushered up to the 49th floor by a security guard, trying to avoid drawing too much attention. Laurence D. Fink, chairman of BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager — with more than $4 trillion — soon was also escorted upstairs. Abby Johnson, the chief executive of Fidelity (which invests more than $2 trillion), and Frederick William McNabb III, chief of Vanguard ($3 trillion), were also shepherded to the elevator.

headline: Behind a Facade of G.O.P. Unity, Frayed Edges Painfully Exposed
abstract: A Times foreign correspondent is deciphering the action at the Republican convention for a global audience.
lead_paragraph: Abroad in America, written by a Times foreign correspondent, approaches the election in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Surreal Diversity Show
abstract: The party chairman’s claim that Donald Trump plans “a Hispanic engagement tour” is as ridiculous as Trump’s attacks on Latinos have been unjust.
lead_paragraph: The unrelenting whiteness of the Republican National Convention — perhaps the whitest in 100 years — is stunning in itself. Donald Trump has tried to mask its segregationist flavor by strategically featuring African-American speakers to colorize the hall and validate the pronouncements of white speakers like Rudolph Giuliani, the former New York mayor, who have ceaselessly lectured black people on criminality. Among these was David Clarke Jr., the Milwaukee County sheriff, who denounced the Black Lives Matter campaign and applauded the acquittal of a Baltimore police officer charged in the death of Freddie Gray.

headline: Joshua Wong and 2 Others Convicted Over Their Roles in Hong Kong Protests
abstract: Three leaders of the demonstrations in 2014 for freer elections in the self-governing Chinese city are to be sentenced next month.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three leaders of Hong Kong’s huge student-led demonstrations in 2014 were found guilty on Thursday of charges stemming from their roles in events that set off 79 days of defiant street protests for freer elections in the self-governing Chinese territory.

headline: Trump Lawyer Sends ‘Art of the Deal’ Ghostwriter a Cease-and-Desist Letter
abstract: Tony Schwartz, who spoke to The New Yorker magazine about his experiences with Mr. Trump, said the letter demanded he forfeit all royalties from the book.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Tony Schwartz, the ghostwriter of Mr. Trump’s best-selling autobiography “The Art of the Deal,” said on Wednesday that he had received a cease-and-desist letter from Mr. Trump’s chief legal counsel over his blistering assessments of the candidate and their work together.

headline: Mike Pence Stays on Script at Convention
abstract: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, the Republican nominee for vice president, delivered what may have been the only speech that closely resembled the typical presentation at a convention.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, the Republican nominee for vice president, delivered what may have been the only speech that closely resembled the typical presentation at a convention.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Pay tribute to the director Garry Marshall with “Pretty Woman.” Donald J. Trump, meanwhile, is to accept the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Pay tribute to the director Garry Marshall, who died on Tuesday, with “Pretty Woman,” the jewel in his crown. Donald J. Trump, meanwhile, is to accept the Republican presidential nomination. And Valery Gergiev conducts the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America.

headline: Corrections: July 21, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, July 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: New York Police Standoff With Queens Man Ends Quietly at Columbus Circle
abstract: A man suspected of tossing a suspicious object into a police van was taken into custody Thursday morning after refusing to leave his vehicle, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An hourslong standoff between the police and a man in a sport utility vehicle in Columbus Circle in Manhattan that disrupted traffic and subway service ended peacefully Thursday morning, when officers took the man into custody, the New York Police Department said.

headline: Report on Medicaid Home Care Reductions in New York
abstract: A detailed report by a coalition of more than 100 nonprofit groups found that since January 2015, Senior Health Partners of Healthfirst and at least two other companies have been systematically cutting the hours of home care to their disabled clients, typically without proper notice or legal justification.
lead_paragraph: A detailed report by a coalition of more than 100 nonprofit groups found that since January 2015, Senior Health Partners of Healthfirst and at least two other companies have been systematically cutting the hours of home care to their disabled clients, typically without proper notice or legal justification.

headline: Donald Trump May Break the Mold, but He Fits a Pattern, Too
abstract: Rather than being a singular phenomenon, Mr. Trump looks more like the political equivalent of a comet that crosses American presidential campaigns every few decades.
lead_paragraph: The New York media mogul approached his party’s convention having already shaken the political system: The power brokers had attacked him as a dangerous rogue, mocked his hairstyle and branded him a “low voluptuary” for his colorful personal life. And yet William Randolph Hearst loomed over the St. Louis gathering as a threat to seize the Democratic Party’s nomination for president.

headline: Congress Should Let the Boeing Deal Proceed
abstract: Republicans who are out to sabotage the Iranian nuclear deal voted to block the sale of passenger planes to Iran.
lead_paragraph: Before adjourning for the summer, lawmakers in Congress found time to pass several bills that could imperil one of the most significant global security achievements in many years: the year-old nuclear deal that President Obama struck with Iran.

headline: Port Authority Overhaul, Way Overdue
abstract: A former chairman of the agency, who was appointed by Gov. Chris Christie, pleaded guilty to bribery. It’s clear permanent reform is needed.
lead_paragraph: Privately, it was known as “Samson Air” or sometimes “The Chairman’s Flight.” In 2012, United Airlines decided to reinstate its money-losing flights between Newark and Columbia, S.C., leaving New Jersey on Thursday evenings and returning on Monday mornings.

headline: Why Men Want to Marry Melanias and Raise Ivankas
abstract: The women in Donald Trump’s life have sharply different roles. That difference is what many other men want, too.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news events.

headline: Pence Versus Trump Kids
abstract: Trump’s running mate got the spotlight for a while but got upstaged.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald Trump arrived here Wednesday with a few words to the fans assembled at the helicopter pad. Really, just a few. Win Ohio … make America great … Mike Pence … unbelievable vice president.

headline: How the G.O.P. Outsourced the Judicial Nomination Process
abstract: The National Rifle Association has become the gatekeeper for nominations to the federal courts.
lead_paragraph: The massacre of children and teachers in Newtown, Conn., didn’t do it. Neither did the mass murder of worshipers in Charleston, S.C., nor of county employees in San Bernardino, Calif., nor of people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla. Nor, most likely, will the recent coldblooded murders of police officers persuade the Republicans in Congress to enact even modest measures to make it harder for people to get their hands on weapons of destruction.

headline: The Apotheosis of Donald J. Trump
abstract: Who said it couldn’t happen here? Rising to the top of the Republican ticket, Trump has activated forces on the political right that cannot be deactivated.
lead_paragraph: As we take a step back and contemplate the actuality of Donald J. Trump’s nomination as the Republican candidate for president, one aspect of the situation stands out. Virtually the entire political class, Republicans and Democrats, knows Trump’s liabilities in extraordinary detail.

headline: Pistols at the Pool, Machine Guns on Parade and Nothing We Can Do
abstract: Why I can’t protect my city from guns.
lead_paragraph: Bloomington, Ind. — I’M the mayor of a small Midwestern city and I’m at my wit’s end about guns. My first job is to help keep my city safe, but two recent events showed me the limits of what I can do.

headline: What Republicans Really Think About Trump
abstract: Bigot, madman, bully, fraud and serial philanderer are just a sampling of the terms used by influential conservatives.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The arena here at the Republican National Convention echoes with applause for Donald Trump, but the cacophony and extravagant stage effects can’t conceal the chaos in the G.O.P. and in the Trump campaign.

headline: Should the U.S. Pull Its Nuclear Weapons From Turkey?
abstract: Has the upheaval there shown that our hydrogen bombs need to be kept in a more secure place?

headline: How Markets Can Help Us Adapt to Climate Change
abstract: Insurance markets can communicate important information about risk — unless prevented by well-meaning but harmful regulations.
lead_paragraph: We are on course to set another record for the hottest year, the third year in a row,  and 2016 may well have the most billion dollar weather disasters. Adaptation to a changing climate looks both necessary and inevitable.

headline: A Sad Homecoming to Puerto Rico’s Economic Crisis
abstract: Erika P. Rodríguez returned home to confront an exodus and an economic crisis that led her to examine the identity of a people whose island is neither a state nor a sovereign nation.
lead_paragraph: Erika P. Rodríguez returned home to confront an exodus and an economic crisis that led her to examine the identity of a people whose island is neither a state nor a sovereign nation.

headline: What Is the Republican Party?
abstract: Three former aides to President Ronald Reagan look at the state of the G.O.P. with hope, fear and doubt.

headline: Transcript: Donald Trump on NATO, Turkey’s Coup Attempt and the World
abstract: The Republican presidential nominee discussed his views on foreign policy with David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, discussed his views on foreign policy in Cleveland on Wednesday with David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman of The New York Times during the Republican National Convention. The following is an edited transcript of their interview.

headline: Day 3: Cruz Jolts Low-Energy G.O.P.
abstract: On the third day of the Republican convention, the refusal by Senator Ted Cruz to endorse Donald J. Trump widened cracks in the party’s veneer.
lead_paragraph: On the third day of the Republican convention, the refusal by Senator Ted Cruz to endorse Donald J. Trump widened cracks in the party’s veneer.

headline: China Investigating Data Leak and Swindling of H.I.V. Patients
abstract: People with H.I.V. across China report receiving calls from people with access to their medical information, and some say they were asked to send money.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Bai Hua, the director of a support network based in Beijing for people with H.I.V./AIDS, said he began receiving the messages about two weeks ago. Hundreds of people with H.I.V. across China were reporting that they were being called by someone who claimed to be from the government and had access to their medical records and other personal information.

headline: Obama Faces Growing Expectations on Race and Policing
abstract: Activists have questioned why he is not doing more to help. It’s complicated, he tries to explain — a response he acknowledges is accurate and unsatisfying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the White House last week, DeRay Mckesson, a Black Lives Matter activist who was arrested only days before in Baton Rouge, La., for protesting police violence against African-Americans, had a lengthy list of demands for President Obama.

headline: A ‘Heat Dome’ Is Coming. Domes Are Bad.
abstract: From Domesday to Thunderdome, domes have usually brought unwelcome news to someone. The sticky weather oozing across the country is no exception.
lead_paragraph: We are domed.

headline: Marc Lamont Hill Is Your Friendly Neighborhood Marxist
abstract: The political commentator on gun ownership, being fired from Fox News and his favorite black celebrity protests.
lead_paragraph: You’ve been a radical voice in mainstream political commentary for years. I think a lot of what you say is on the margins of what most white people usually hear on CNN. Part of that is just the delivery. I don’t have the luxury, nor the natural disposition, to be condescending or any of the other things that people on the left stereotypically do. There’s a reason America picks presidents based on whom they can have a beer with, you know?

headline: Jaap van Zweden: Before You See Him, Listen
abstract: One of our music critics explored recordings to get a feel for this conductor’s work before he takes the role of music director of the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: When Jaap van Zweden was announced in January as the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, I was at sea. I’d heard reports, and my colleagues at The New York Times and elsewhere had been generally impressed by his appearances. But I had never heard him conduct live. As he’s only visited the Philharmonic for four programs, you might have missed him, too.

headline: A Bed-Stuy Apartment: Well-Known Terrain
abstract: Patrice Fenton and Ra’id Bey searched Brooklyn for an apartment for their family of four.
lead_paragraph: Except for her years in college and graduate school, Patrice Fenton always lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Why Libraries Are Everywhere in the Czech Republic
abstract: The country has a public library for every 1,971 people — 10 times the U.S. rate — and a population that still borrows and reads printed books.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — In the age of Amazon and the internet, the idea of going to a public library to borrow a book may seem ever more quaint and old-fashioned in many parts of the world, but one country, at least, is clinging to it tenaciously: the Czech Republic.

headline: A Sad Homecoming to Puerto Rico’s Economic Crisis
abstract: Erika P. Rodríguez returned to the island of her birth to confront a mass exodus and economic crisis that led her to examine the identity of a people whose island is neither a state nor a sovereign nation.
lead_paragraph: Leer en Español.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Day 4 Takeaways: It’s Donald Trump’s Party
abstract: Mr. Trump completed his unlikely rise to Republican standard-bearer, capping a convention that rarely veered from his theme of restoring American dominance.
lead_paragraph: On the final night of a convention unlike any in memory, Donald J. Trump completed his unlikely envelopment of the Republican Party. His rule could last four months, or four years, or eight. All hail Trump. Our takeaways:

headline: Unearthing China’s Past at a Market Whose Raffish Air Is a Selling Point
abstract: Collectors of rare books and posters find gems in Panjiayuan’s ramshackle alleyways, or make discoveries in its more exclusive little shops.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The vast antiques market is awash in jewelry, snuff bottles, old clocks, brass paperweights, ceramics, and slabs of jade of many hues and dubious quality. It has the same feel as flea markets all around the world that advertise antiquities but do not always deliver the real thing.

headline: G.O.P.’s Moneyed Class Finds Its Place in New Trump World
abstract: At enclaves during the convention in Cleveland, even some of those who had worked against Donald J. Trump’s candidacy were now seeing opportunity.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In his unlikely rise to the Republican nomination Donald J. Trump attacked lobbyists, disparaged big donors and railed against the party’s establishment. But on the shores of Lake Erie this week, beyond the glare of television cameras, the power of the permanent political class seemed virtually undisturbed.

headline: Komatsu of Japan to Buy Joy Global for $2.9 Billion
abstract: The deal reflects the belief by Komatsu, a manufacturer of mining equipment, that the mining industry slump will ease over the long term.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Japanese manufacturer of mining equipment will spend nearly $3 billion to buy an American equipment maker as they contend with a global mining slump.

headline: Dave Eggers’s New Novel Follows a Family Into the Alaskan Wild
abstract: In Dave Eggers’s “Heroes of the Frontier,” a single mother imagining a new life takes her kids on the lam in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: HEROES OF THE FRONTIERBy Dave Eggers385 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $28.95.

headline: When Heidi Met Carrie
abstract: Scenes from the book I needed when I was 12.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the book I needed when I was 12.

headline: First a Leap, Then Love
abstract: Dr. Cooper Boone took a leap and found love with Mark Veeder. They married on June 25, to mark the anniversary of the court ruling legalizing same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Cooper Boone took a leap and found love with Mark Veeder. They married on June 25, to mark the anniversary of the court ruling legalizing same-sex marriage.

headline: Two Men Gone Country and Their Dreamgirls
abstract: Cooper Boone, who had little interest in a partner, began falling in love with Mark Veeder at a country fair. Now they’re married with children.
lead_paragraph: Cooper Boone is a study in contrasts. He has square-danced for nuns and saw fit to croon the theme song for Powdermilk Biscuits from “A Prairie Home Companion” at his father’s funeral in Minnesota.

headline: Sports Court Upholds Ban on Russian Track and Field Athletes
abstract: A ruling on Thursday said the sport’s governing body had the authority to bar Russians for doping.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court on Thursday upheld the ban on Russia’s track and field team from the Rio Olympics, empowering sports organizations to discipline other Russian teams after revelations of a government-run doping scheme.

headline: For Alexi Pappas, Nightmares Mean You Care
abstract: This is what elite runners dream about the night before a race.
lead_paragraph: Nightmares are a strange but not uncommon phenomenon for runners the evening before a race. I have had nightmares about running in clown shoes, running in a uniform constructed out of my own hair and running through a track filled entirely with pudding. I have known teammates to dream of running through oceans. But pre-race nightmares should not be feared. Rather, they should be embraced as a friendly indication that we care very much about the challenge ahead. Nervous is a cousin to excited.

headline: Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, Russia Doping: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The ‘Intentional Summer’ Quiz: Name That Plant!
abstract: This week’s challenge: Find a plant in nature that you can’t identify and figure out what it is.
lead_paragraph: Challenge No. 5: Name a flower, plant or tree.

headline: New York Today: All Hail the Heat
abstract: Thursday: Humidity on the horizon, Jeremy Lin is back, and how to keep your hot dog cool.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:47 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: Tesla’s New Grand Plan
abstract: Hedge Funds Accuse Puerto Rico’s Governor of Money Grab | Beer Mega-Merger Closer to Completion
lead_paragraph: TESLA’S NEW GRAND PLAN The chief of Tesla, Elon Musk, has published a new “master plan,” which involves installing a solar panel system into cars, building heavier vehicles and introducing a ride-hailing business.

headline: E.C.B. Keeps Rates Steady, but Still Faces Plenty of Uncertainty
abstract: The eurozone is dealing with aftershocks of earlier crises, while coping with more recent threats like Britain’s vote to leave the European Union and a shaky banking system in Italy.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The eurozone is in a state of uncertainty. It is still dealing with the aftershocks of financial and debt crises. It is coping with new threats like Britain’s vote to leave the European Union. And it is guarding against a shaky banking system in Italy.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on an Uneven Split of Backpacking Weight
abstract: Beware the hiking partner who praises your superior fitness level.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin writes: When my husband and I go backpacking, we split our gear so that we each carry about the same weight. But my husband outweighs me by almost 50 pounds! I think the gear should be distributed based on body weight. My husband claims that because I am in far superior shape, splitting the loads evenly is actually fair.

headline: A Clam Fritter That Brings the Bahamas to Your Home
abstract: Peppery heat and a zip of lime add an island flair to the familiar.
lead_paragraph: My friends and I had been fishing for striped bass for a few weeks, working the sandy flats of Peconic Bay, on Long Island, exactly as if we were chasing bonefish or permit across the shallows of the Bight of Acklins, in what are known as the Family Islands, northwest of Turks & Caicos. For dinner, I wanted to extend the fantasy, to make almost real the notion that we were not 100 miles from New York City in the middle of summer but 10 times that distance, and eating within sight not of oak trees but of mangroves, cascarilla and endless azure sea.

headline: How Sex, Animals and Obama End Up in Drink Names
abstract: Christening cocktails can be as bold an art as creating them.
lead_paragraph: The names of the most venerable and beloved mixed drinks — the Old-Fashioned, the Manhattan, the martini — are so deeply familiar to bartenders and our patrons, and spoken so often, that we seldom give much thought to their origins. We puzzle more over certain drinks of more recent vintage, the ones that many of us associate with the 1970s and ’80s and are embarrassed to utter, and others find so hilarious they just can’t say them often enough. I’ve never had an intense yearning for a drink made up of vodka, peach schnapps, orange juice and cranberry juice, but — out of professional interest, of course — I’ve had to make, and try, a Sex on the Beach more than once. If that’s what a customer wants, that’s what he or she will get.

headline: Megan Abbott: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “You Will Know Me” keeps a copy of “How to Protect Yourself Against Psychic Attack” on her shelves. “Those who know me well probably wouldn’t be surprised.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “You Will Know Me” keeps a copy of “How to Protect Yourself Against Psychic Attack” on her shelves. “Those who know me well probably wouldn’t be surprised.”

headline: Kashmir in Crisis
abstract: The death of a charismatic separatist inspires rage among young Kashmiris and a violent response from the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir is convulsed in lethal violence pitting stone-throwing youths against armed police officers and security forces. The unrest is a major setback for peace in the long-troubled region claimed by both India and Pakistan, where an insurgency movement peaked in the 1990s, then waned, but never completely disappeared.

headline: 1916: Happy in Villas at Deauville
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Good weather beings animation to Deauville in July 1916.
lead_paragraph: DEAUVILLE — After days of dull weather with heavy skies, the sun has at last decided to shine on Deauville, and with a pleasing intensity which gives promise of continued good weather. Though the Casino has been transformed into a hospital, one sees few wounded soldiers about and, with the tennis courts of the Sporting Club constantly in use, to say nothing of the golf course, which is equally popular, and the plage alive with bathers and promenaders and the usual number of children enjoying the never-tiring charms of the sand, Deauville is all animation. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 22, 1916

headline: Terra Firma Hires Andrew Geczy as C.E.O.
abstract: Mr. Geczy joins the private equity firm after stints at the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, the Lloyds Banking Group and Citigroup.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Terra Firma, the European private equity firm founded by the British financier Guy Hands, said on Thursday that it had hired Andrew Geczy, a banker who has worked at several different institutions, as its new chief executive.

headline: North Korea Revives Coded Spy Broadcasts After 16-Year Silence
abstract: Mysterious numbers aired by a North Korean radio station last month and again last Friday have puzzled South Korean intelligence officials and analysts.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In an era of sophisticated spycraft, North Korea appears to be returning to the days of shortwave radio.

headline: Players Criticize W.N.B.A. For Fines Over Shirts Worn to Underscore Shootings
abstract: Three teams were fined $5,000 and each player was fined $500 for wearing T-shirts intended to raise awareness in the aftermath of recent shootings by and of the police.
lead_paragraph: Players from the Liberty and the Indiana Fever spoke out in dismay Thursday after the W.N.B.A. fined them for wearing T-shirts intended to raise awareness in the aftermath of recent shootings by and of the police.

headline: Singapore Cites Three Banks in Inquiry Into Malaysia’s 1MDB Fund
abstract: Officials found lapses in anti-money laundering controls at DBS Bank, Standard Chartered and UBS as part of a global investigation into the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The authorities in Singapore said on Thursday that they had identified significant lapses in anti-money laundering controls at three banks tied to a global investigation into money from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Sentence for Oscar Pistorius Challenged by South African Prosecutors
abstract: The six-year sentence that the sprinter received for the murder of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, was “shockingly too lenient,” prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South African prosecutors said on Thursday that they would seek a longer prison term for Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter convicted of murdering his girlfriend, harshly criticizing a six-year sentence handed down two weeks ago as “shockingly too lenient.”

headline: Eugene Monroe, Marijuana Advocate, to Retire From N.F.L.
abstract: Monroe, a veteran offensive tackle who became the first active N.F.L. player to publicly ask the league to let players use medical marijuana, will retire after seven seasons.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Monroe, a veteran offensive tackle who became the first active N.F.L. player to publicly ask the league to let players use medical marijuana, will retire after seven seasons.

headline: The West’s Crisis of Leadership
abstract: Through 18 awful months, the French have proved remarkably resilient. More so than their officials.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A few days before the Bastille Day terrorist attack in Nice, President Obama was in Poland for the NATO summit meeting, his mind obviously as much in Dallas as in Warsaw. As I listened to him during his closing news conference, on July 9, I was struck by the sad, tired, almost defeatist tone in the way the leader of the most powerful nation on earth addressed the divisions within American society, after that week’s killings. “This is not who we are,” he insisted, as if trying to convince himself.

headline: Two Tastes of Welty’s Mississippi for the Summer Swelter
abstract: Eudora Welty’s “Why I Live at the P.O.” and the memoir “One Writer’s Beginnings” are being staged at the Studio Theater at Theater Row.
lead_paragraph: Though New York theater has always had a soft spot for Southern eccentrics (paging Tennessee Williams!), the singular, vernacular lyricism of Eudora Welty has seldom been translated to the stage. This year, however, is allowing Welty her curtain calls. Following the Roundabout Theater’s recent, exuberant revival of the musical “The Robber Bridegroom,” based on a Welty fairy tale, comes “Eudora Welty — Mississippi Stories,” opening Thursday, July 28, at the Studio Theater at Theater Row.

headline: Donald Trump’s Convention: Day 4
abstract: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.
lead_paragraph: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.

headline: So Percussion, More Than Enough Bang for the Buck
abstract: The virtuosic ensemble plays three concerts as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. It will mix classics with newer works.
lead_paragraph: Beyond virtuosic, So Percussion really has no need to prove its technical bona fides. But it’ll do so anyway in a trio of concerts that are part of Lincoln Center Festival. Each show (at the Kaplan Penthouse) pairs a classic of the modern percussion repertoire with two of this ensemble’s vast trove of commissioned works.

headline: 1966: Kennedy Saw Romney as Foe
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: John F. Kennedy feared George Romney as a White House opponent, according to Paul B. Fay Jr. in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A close friend of John F. Kennedy said yesterday that the late president feared Republican Gov. George Romney of Michigan as a White House opponent. The friend, former Undersecretary of the Navy Paul B. Fay Jr., said that Kennedy told him in the spring of 1963: ‘‘The one man I don’t want to run against is Romney. That fellow could be tough. No, give me good old Barry.’’ In discussing Kennedy’s view of Gov. Romney, Mr. Fay quotes the president as saying: ‘‘You have to be a little suspicious of somebody as good as Romney. No vice whatsoever, no smoking, no drinking.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1966

headline: Eric Revis, Holding Down the Center Again
abstract: The jazz bassist, with a quartet, will be performing at the Jazz Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Eric Revis is a jazz bassist who understands the function of a pivot point, holding down the center against all manner of torque and strain. He’s often singled out for his ability to toggle between the postbop center and an experimental fringe, but when left to his own devices he tends to make those distinctions feel archaic.

headline: At the Whitney, Global Economy and Seductive Surfaces
abstract: The first solo show in this country of Sophia Al-Maria, an American-Qatari artist, writer and filmmaker, opens on July 26.
lead_paragraph: The first solo show in the United States of Sophia Al-Maria, an American-Qatari artist, writer and filmmaker, promises to be an immersive combination of artifice and reality, consumerism and human interaction — but don’t expect to relax. You’ll probably encounter a disquieting experience of the homogenizing effects of the global economy seen through a prism of shimmering surfaces and seductive technologies, especially as played out in the Persian Gulf region and the United States.

headline: Facebook Banned Gun Sales. So Why Is It Still ‘Full of Them’?
abstract: Critics say the social network needs to do more to stop circumvention of its six-month-old prohibition. Gun enthusiasts want the ban lifted.
lead_paragraph: A discussion group on Facebook called Texas Pew Pew Pew Show & Tell warned its users that it was intended to host conversations “about anything that goes pew pew pew,” but not to facilitate the sale or trade of firearms.

headline: ‘The Winter’s Tale’: Exit Dancer, Pursued by a Bear
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s adaptation of “The Winter’s Tale” is coming to the Lincoln Center Festival by way of the National Ballet of Canada.
lead_paragraph: Ballet choreographers used to be great storytellers: Petipa, Nijinska and Ashton, among others, gave us memorable characters, plots and narrative drama. And there used to be a revolving door between ballet and Broadway, too: Balanchine, de Mille and Robbins played in both worlds. Christopher Wheeldon, the British dancer-cum-in-demand-choreographer, has recently emerged as a salvager of stories and a modern torchbearer of the ballet/Broadway tradition. His lavish 2011 “Alice in Wonderland,” seen in New York two years ago, was the Royal Ballet’s first commissioned, evening-length story ballet in nearly two decades; last year, he directed and choreographed the Tony-winning “An American in Paris.”

headline: Jim Gaffigan, a Doormat on His Own Show
abstract: A three-episode arc on “The Jim Gaffigan Show” on TV Land finds this comic being taken advantage of by his best friend.
lead_paragraph: Jim Gaffigan might be the new Rodney Dangerfield. The fictional version of himself that he plays on “The Jim Gaffigan Show” is getting no respect in a delightful three-episode arc that concludes Sunday, July 24. The show, now in its second season on TV Land, is about a comedian and family man much like Mr. Gaffigan, and in the arc, “No Good Deed,” Jim has been getting thoroughly walked over, especially by his best friend, Dave (Adam Goldberg). In Part 1, Dave horned his way in as Jim’s opening act for a set at the comedy club Caroline’s. One thing led to another, and by Part 3, Dave has landed a deal for his own TV Land series, and Jim is auditioning to play himself on it. Can you count the layers of meta? Guest stars in the arc include Will Ferrell, John Mulaney, Kelly Ripa and — well, you’ll have to watch to see who ends up doing the part of Jim Gaffigan at the table read.

headline: Big-Screen Wonders at the Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: The museum begins its annual festival of movies shown in the 70-millimeter format. Among the highlights: “The Hateful Eight.”
lead_paragraph: Quentin Tarantino caused a stir in the film world late last year when he released “The Hateful Eight” in the rarely used 70-millimeter projection format. Regulars at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, were already familiar with the joys of 70-millimeter movie viewing thanks to the annual “See It Big!” series, which returns Friday, July 29, with a screening of “2001: A Space Odyssey.” If you want a technical explanation of the glories of the format, a cinephile will gladly talk your ear off about film size and aspect ratios, but the bottom line is that movies in the format just look bigger, more imposing, more vivid. This year’s “See It Big!” screenings continue through Sept. 4, with the program including “Spartacus,” “Khartoum,” “The Wild Bunch,” “Star!,” “Let’s Spend the Night Together,” “Hamlet” and, on Aug. 14 and 20, Mr. Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight.” (718-777-6888, movingimage.us.)

headline: 1976 | When Eliza Sprinkle Commanded the Fate of the G.O.P.
abstract: The 1976 Republican convention was not a foregone conclusion. The Times had to keep close tabs on uncommitted delegates — Eliza Sprinkle among them.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at The Times’s coverage of the 1976 Republican National Convention.

headline: What Happened at Oscar de la Renta?
abstract: As part of a worrisome trend, Peter Copping became the eighth designer to depart a brand after a single contract stint or less since last July.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know if it will work. But what I have seen looks very pretty. We’ll know soon enough.”

headline: Ted Cruz Mounts the Convention Stage in the Role of Brutus
abstract: Mr. Cruz used his speech not to endorse the nominee but to position himself for the future.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas did not come here this week to unite Republicans around their presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump. Armed with his usual arsenal of florid oratory, self-regard and blunt force, he came instead to rally them, someday, around Ted Cruz.

headline: Man, on Fire, Tries to Drive Car Into Australian Police Station Garage
abstract: The driver, who is in serious condition and has not been identified, was stopped after running his car into a steel door in the Sydney suburb of Merrylands.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A man was in serious condition Thursday night and receiving hospital treatment after setting himself aflame before trying to drive his car, laden with a fire accelerant, into a police station parking garage in the western suburb of Merrylands, police officials here said.

headline: Nonprofit Theater Plans to Build New Stage in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: Ensemble Studio Theater’s new street-level main stage on West 52nd Street will be financed primarily by the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: The expanding cluster of performing arts organizations in Hell’s Kitchen will add another new stage.

headline: U.S. Sues to Block Anthem-Cigna and Aetna-Humana Mergers
abstract: The Justice Department contends that allowing the mergers would quash competition, leading to higher prices for consumers and reducing their benefits.
lead_paragraph: Within a three-week span last summer, four of the five biggest health insurers announced two mergers totaling $85 billion. Suddenly, what was five would be three, reshaping the industry.

headline: Ron Bloom, a Top Lazard Banker, Leaves for Brookfield Asset Management
abstract: Mr. Bloom, perhaps best known for his work guiding G.M. and Chrysler through bankruptcies, will help manage Brookfield’s private equity operations.
lead_paragraph: A senior Lazard banker who previously had helped lead the Obama administration’s auto task force is leaving the investment bank.

headline: Pilgrimage: A 21st-Century Journey to Mecca and Medina
abstract: The Times has produced a virtual reality film from Islam’s holy cities, directed by the photographer Luca Locatelli.
lead_paragraph: The Times has produced a virtual reality film from Mecca and Medina, Islam’s holy cities. To view it, download the NYT VR app on your mobile device if you don’t already have it. (Go here for Android, and here for iPhone.)

headline: Video Review: Fiat 124 Spider Is Made in Japan, Polished in Italy
abstract: An Italian classic returns by way of Japan. More than a simple re-skin of Mazda’s MX-5 Miata, Fiat’s 124 Spider has a turbo engine and a personality of its own.
lead_paragraph: FOR the last few decades, people with modest bank accounts could only dream of buying a new Italian roadster. Ferrari doesn’t make anything in the $30,000 range, except perhaps seats. At over 65K, the Alfa Romeo 4C Spider is attainable only after raiding the children’s college fund and selling the spouse’s Camry.

headline: Review: Drake Opens Tour in Austin, Rapping, Singing and Sneering
abstract: As Drake continues to refashion his sing-rap hybrid, his tour is bookended by tough talk, but oscillates between that and smoother, more tender sections.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — As Drake began his show on Wednesday night at the Frank Erwin Center here, the word “revenge” was splashed across the huge screen at the back of the stage, with virtual flames shooting off the edges of the letters. The stage was mostly dark, and he stepped out to perform “Summer Sixteen,” one of his surliest songs.

headline: Peter Thiel and the G.O.P. Convention
abstract: The venture capitalist is the rare tech figure who openly supports Donald Trump’s candidacy. He is set to address conventiongoers on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: You have to give credit to Peter Thiel: The man keeps it interesting.

headline: Pointing a Finger at the Fed in the Lehman Disaster
abstract: A respected economist argues that the Federal Reserve could have saved the financial firm from its chaotic collapse eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: As the last eight years have unfolded, the enormous economic and political consequences of the Lehman Brothers failure have emerged with stark clarity, never more evident than in this week’s Republican convention.

headline: Changing Your Google Account Settings
abstract: Google recently changed its ad-tracking practices, but you have a say in whether you want to use the new tools.
lead_paragraph: Q. In using Gmail, Chrome and Drive, I know I’ve sold my privacy to the god of convenience. Still, today Google wanted to tell me about “some new features” and prompted me to click my acceptance. I’m reluctant to click. What is this?

headline: Water Out of the Tailpipe: A New Class of Electric Car Gains Traction
abstract: In California, state subsidies for hydrogen filling stations are encouraging clean-energy advocates to try fuel-cell vehicles.
lead_paragraph: STEVE MANNING, a financial consultant in Southern California, liked the idea of driving a car that would go easy on the environment.

headline: Trump Children Take Convention Spotlight
abstract: If the convention has any stars, it’s Donald J. Trump's children. And their presence reflects the influence they have on their father and his presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: If the convention has any stars, it’s Donald J. Trump's children. And their presence reflects the influence they have on their father and his presidential campaign.

headline: Mobbed by Fans, New Celebrities Emerge: Trump’s Kids
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s children have assumed an outsize role at the Republican Convention, drawing a following of their own.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — “Tiffany! Tiffany!” a middle-aged Republican delegate yelled to Donald J. Trump’s 22-year-old daughter on the floor of the Republican National Convention Wednesday night. “You were amazing last night,” he said of her speech.

headline: Party Hopping in the Hamptons
abstract: Soledad O’Brien and others honored at Russell Simmons’s Art for Life benefit; Lady Bunny spins at Hamptons Tea Dance, a popular gay charity.
lead_paragraph: Soledad O’Brien and others honored at Russell Simmons’s Art for Life benefit; Lady Bunny spins at Hamptons Tea Dance, a popular gay charity.

headline: The Long, Final Goodbye of the VCR
abstract: Yes, there was a company still manufacturing VCRs. It has decided it’s time to stop.
lead_paragraph: Many new technologies are born with a bang: Virtual reality headsets! Renewable rockets! And old ones often die with a whimper. So it is for the videocassette recorder, or VCR.

headline: Review: ‘Absolutely Fabulous’ Brings Its Snickers and Bubbly to the Big Screen
abstract: Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley are back as Eddy and Patsy in this happily self-conscious feature-length goof, a film iteration of the BBC TV series.
lead_paragraph: “Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie” opens with Edina Monsoon (Jennifer Saunders) and her bestie, Patsy Stone (Joanna Lumley), blundering into a fashion show. While ordinary latecomers might try a discreet entrance, bobbing and weaving as they scamper for seats, the constitutionally unmindful Eddy and Patsy stumble onto the catwalk, creating a distraction that forces everyone’s attention on them. What seems like mere table-setting — Eddy galumphing among the gazelles — is a sly declaration of intent in a happily self-conscious feature-length goof.

headline: Dawa’s
abstract: A former cook at Reynard serves casual American brunch and Tibetan food in Queens.
lead_paragraph: A former cook at Reynard serves casual American brunch and Tibetan food in Queens.

headline: At Dawa’s in Queens, a Fusion of Earth and Sky
abstract: At this Tibetan and American cafe, the thrill is the hidden tracks on the flip side of the menu.
lead_paragraph: The bowl of ragged-edged pork belly is a recipe from Bhutan, the meat vested with the deep sour of fermented bamboo shoots. Its flavor hints at turned earth or wood broken down by rain, a funk wonderfully, perilously close to rot.

headline: Aretha Franklin to Headline a New City Winery Festival in Queens
abstract: Jakob Dylan and the Wallflowers, Gillian Welch and Dawes will also perform at this two-day festival at Forest Hills Stadium in September.
lead_paragraph: City Winery is entering the festival circuit. The downtown Manhattan venue will present City Winery Open, a two-day music, food and wine festival featuring Aretha Franklin and Sheryl Crow, at Forest Hills Stadium Sept. 17-18.

headline: Police Shoot Unarmed Black Man in Florida
abstract: Charles Kinsey, a behavior therapist, was shot by the police in North Miami, Fla., on Monday while trying to help a patient with autism. Mr. Kinsey was lying on the ground with his arms up when the police opened fire.
lead_paragraph: Charles Kinsey, a behavior therapist, was shot by the police in North Miami, Fla., on Monday while trying to help a patient with autism. Mr. Kinsey was lying on the ground with his arms up when the police opened fire.

headline: Cruz on Why He Didn’t Endorse Trump
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas said Thursday that he is not “in the habit of supporting people who attack my wife and attack my father,” in regard to his decision not to formally endorse Donald J. Trump the night before.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas said Thursday that he is not “in the habit of supporting people who attack my wife and attack my father,” in regard to his decision not to formally endorse Donald J. Trump the night before.

headline: Sperm Banks Accused of Losing Samples and Lying About Donors
abstract: One lawsuit, by a California woman, claims a Los Angeles fertility center lost her late husband’s banked sperm, denying her the ability to have his children.
lead_paragraph: MONTECITO, Calif. — Even as she mourned the death of her 29-year-old husband from a rare genetic disorder, Sarah Robertson was comforted by knowing that six vials of his sperm were safely stored at the Reproductive Fertility Center — in Tank B, Canister 5, Cane G, Position 6, Color Blue — waiting until she was ready to have the baby they had both longed for.

headline: Partying for Diverse Causes in the Hamptons
abstract: Soledad O’Brien and others are honored at Russell Simmons’s Art for Life benefit, and Lady Bunny spins at the Hamptons Tea Dance, a popular gay charity.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday in Water Mill, N.Y., a pair of fund-raisers brought a more diverse crowd to the East End. At the Hamptons Tea Dance, gay men in tight polo shirts took selfies with Edie Windsor, 87, the same-sex marriage plaintiff. Funds benefited three L.G.B.T. nonprofits. Nearby, Russell and Danny Simmons hosted their annual benefit for the Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation. Leaders like Suzanne de Passe, Debra Lee and Soledad O’Brien were honored by Gayle King, the M.C. for the proceedings.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: The News With Andrew Rosenthal
abstract: The opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on news from the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: The opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on news from the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, Ohio.

headline: Groups Unite Across America to Protest Police Shootings
abstract: A coalition of black racial-justice organizations demonstrated in more than a dozen cities on Thursday to protest police shootings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coalition of black racial-justice organizations started a series of coordinated demonstrations in more than a dozen cities across the United States on Thursday to protest police shootings.

headline: Brazil Arrests 10 in Terror Plot as Olympics Near, Officials Say
abstract: The arrests were announced at a time when the Brazilian authorities are coming under scrutiny over security preparations for the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian authorities arrested 10 members of an Islamist militant group that was organizing terrorist attacks, officials announced Thursday, raising tension around the country just two weeks before the start of the Olympic Games.

headline: Convention Comedy, ‘Update’-Style, Has Its Pitfalls and Pratfalls
abstract: Michael Che and Colin Jost, anchors of the “Saturday Night Live” fake news, almost didn’t make it into the studio in time for their show at the Republican convention.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was 10 minutes before the first live “Weekend Update” from the floor of a national political convention, and Michael Che and Colin Jost, the two anchors, had a problem: They couldn’t get into their studio.

headline: Erdogan Sends a Text Across Turkey, Urging Loyalty
abstract: As a post-coup-attempt purge by the government intensified, Turkish officials assured citizens that the state of emergency would not trample on personal freedoms.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The day after Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, declared a national state of emergency in the wake of a failed coup, an anxious nation awoke on Thursday to a text message from its leader, personally exhorting continued loyalty as the government moved against its enemies.

headline: Searching for Soul Among Douro Reds
abstract: The wine panel sought and found some distinctive wines, but glossy modern winemaking too often took the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: In theory, the Douro Valley of Portugal ought to be making fascinating, distinctive red wines. It has a singular array of indigenous grapes and excellent hillside terroirs proven through centuries in the port business.

headline: Jon Favreau on Speechwriting, Life After D.C. ... and Melania Trump
abstract: Feeling burned out, President Obama’s former chief speechwriter moved to Los Angeles, but he hasn’t left Washington completely behind.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Stretched out on his living-room couch here, Jon Favreau watched Melania Trump’s speech at the Republican National Convention on Monday night with little more than a passing interest, since he was already thinking of bed and an early flight the next morning.

headline: North Miami Police Officers Shoot Man Aiding Patient With Autism
abstract: Video shows Charles Kinsey, a 47-year-old black man, on the ground with his hands in the air before he was wounded in the leg.
lead_paragraph: A black man said the police in North Miami, Fla., shot him on Monday as he tried to help a patient with autism who had run away from the group home where he works.

headline: Facebook Moves One Step Closer to Light-Based Wireless Communication
abstract: Researchers from Facebook’s Connectivity Lab have created a new light detector for receiving communication signals through laser beams
lead_paragraph: The internet is often called the “World Wide Web,” but it’s not actually accessible to residents of a large portion of the world. Today, four billion people are offline, and 1.6 billion of them live in sparsely populated areas around the world.

headline: Live From Prison, Oscar Wilde’s Letter
abstract: Patti Smith, Colm Toibin and others will read from “De Profundis,” a meditation by Wilde, in the prison in Reading, England, where he wrote the work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Patti Smith, Ben Whishaw, Ralph Fiennes and the novelist Colm Toibin are among the artists who will read from Oscar Wilde’s “De Profundis,” in the prison in which he wrote it.

headline: Attacker in Nice Plotted for Months and Had Accomplices, French Prosecutor Says
abstract: There was no evidence that Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people on Bastille Day, had direct contact with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people in a terrorist attack in Nice, France, last week, planned his assault over several months and got help from at least five people, the Paris prosecutor said on Thursday.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: The News With Andrew Rosenthal
abstract: The opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on news from the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into working and thinking at The New York Times. Today, Andrew Rosenthal, an opinion columnist with The Times, responds to news from the Republican National Convention in Cleveland: the good, the bad and the most maddening.

headline: ‘Come From Away,’ a Musical About Sept. 11 Connections, Is Coming to Broadway
abstract: The show, based on the events in Gander, Newfoundland, when flights were grounded because of the terrorist attacks, is to begin performances in February.
lead_paragraph: “Come From Away,” a small and unusual Canadian musical about a remote community’s heartwarming response to Sept. 11, will make its Broadway bow in February.

headline: Heroin and Pill Overdoses Claim Immigrant Victims, Catching Families Off Guard
abstract: Parents from Russia and the Middle East are often unfamiliar with the signs of drug abuse and may not know how to navigate the world of treatment and recovery.
lead_paragraph: In the last two years, the director of an Islamic funeral home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, buried six young men. Heart attacks, some neighbors said, but the whispers and witnesses said something else: heroin. The families of the men would not discuss the causes of death.

headline: Leave London After ‘Brexit’? Steve Cohen Doubles Down
abstract: The billionaire investor is expanding the London office of his firm, Point72 Asset Management, even as other firms pare back.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As some financial companies consider moving jobs out of London after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen’s firm, Point72 Asset Management, is taking a contrarian view.

headline: Elon Musk’s Tesla Plan: More Models, More Self-Driving
abstract: In a blog post, Mr. Musk says nothing about the Autopilot controversy, while envisioning a future of self-driving buses and tractor-trailers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Despite federal safety investigations of Tesla’s self-driving cars, the company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, is hardly backing off on his grand plans for autonomous vehicles.

headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Deadlocked in New Ohio Poll
abstract: The survey, from Suffolk University, finds that Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton each have the support of 44 percent of likely Ohio voters.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are deadlocked in Ohio, according to a new poll that shows the crucial state very much in play as Mr. Trump prepares to accept the Republican Party’s presidential nomination in Cleveland on Thursday night.

headline: Viking Ship Sailing the Great Lakes Is Getting Conquered by U.S. Regulations
abstract: The Draken Harald Harfagre made it from Norway to the Great Lakes, where it was told that it would have hire a pilot to continue through.
lead_paragraph: When a Viking ship, meticulously recreated in Norway, crossed the Atlantic last month, the feat captivated history buffs in the United States. They could hardly wait to get a look at the vessel, which was scheduled to visit a series of ship festivals along the Great Lakes this summer.

headline: Prototype Festival to Offer Premieres, One Somewhat Gruesome
abstract: David Lang’s ‘anatomy theater,’ a piece about the public dissection of a murderer, will be one of the highlights of the festival, which begins Jan. 5.
lead_paragraph: The fifth annual Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival, a font of innovative new operas, next January will feature the New York premiere of David Lang’s “anatomy theater.”

headline: Elon Musk’s Futuristic Plans Give Shareholders Cause to Worry
abstract: The carmaker’s leader reveals a new master plan; investors wonder how he’ll pay for it.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s new master plan will test the Tesla shareholder faithful. In a blog post late on Wednesday, the electric carmaker’s boss laid out his vision for the next decade or so. He has some compelling ideas: building more vehicle types and increasing autonomous-driving capabilities for a sharing economy. The trouble is that plenty of rivals want a piece of that business, too. And his missive fails to address several more immediate concerns – not least how to finance his ambitions.

headline: Betsy Bloomingdale, Socialite and Friend of Influencers, Dies at 93
abstract: Mrs. Bloomingdale was a fashion leader who, with her department store heir husband, maintained friendships with politicians and entertainers, keeping diaries of parties she hosted.
lead_paragraph: Betsy Bloomingdale, the socialite and renowned fashion leader who was the widow of Alfred S. Bloomingdale, the department store heir, and a celebrated hostess to royalty, world dignitaries and show business luminaries, died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 93.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates, Michael Lewis and Zadie Smith to Appear at 92nd St Y
abstract: The literary season at the Y will kick off on Sept. 19 with Ian McEwan, in the only New York reading from his new novel, “Nutshell.”
lead_paragraph: A post-election autopsy with Bob Woodward; a literary round-table with Ta-Nehisi Coates, Jennifer Egan and Don DeLillo; and a friendly face-off between the ideas-guys Michael Lewis and Malcolm Gladwell will be among the highlights of the 92nd Street Y’s 2016-2017 season.

headline: Israeli Defense Minister Compares Beloved Palestinian Poet to Hitler
abstract: Avigdor Lieberman, an ultranationalist, said that Army Radio should not have aired a show about Mahmoud Darwish, who is considered the Palestinians’ national poet.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s ultranationalist defense minister, Avigdor Lieberman, managed to offend both Palestinians and free-speech advocates on Thursday, comparing the Palestinians’ national poet to Adolf Hitler and threatening the independence of Israel’s Army Radio station.

headline: Enduring ‘Sphere’ Sculpture to Return to World Trade Center Site
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted on Thursday to relocate the piece by Fritz Koenig, which survived the 2001 terrorist attack on the towers, to Liberty Park.
