lead_paragraph: Fritz Koenig’s “Sphere for Plaza Fountain,” once the sculptural centerpiece of the World Trade Center, will be reinstalled there this year, returning a visceral symbol of death and rebirth to an understated — and all but sanitized — landscape.

headline: Review: In Liane Moriarty’s ‘Truly Madly Guilty,’ a Very Unfortunate Barbecue Indeed
abstract: Liane Moriarty’s new novel, heavy on contrivance, centers on a bad afternoon in suburban Sydney.
lead_paragraph: Liane Moriarty usually packs her books with dishier secrets than those that give “Truly Madly Guilty” its title. And you need to get through endless hinting, foreshadowing, stalling and chapters that end with loud noises (“there was a piercing yell from upstairs”) even to find out what they are.

headline: 36 Hours in Parma, Italy
abstract: This riverside city may be synonymous with fine food — Parma ham, Parmesan — but it also satisfies appetites for art, music and history.
lead_paragraph: This riverside city may be synonymous with fine food — Parma ham, Parmesan — but it also satisfies appetites for art, music and history.

headline: On the Ground, With Eyes and a Cellphone: Note From Nice
abstract: Andrew Higgins, a Moscow correspondent, happened to be in southern France, near Nice, when terror struck last week.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — Based in Moscow as a correspondent, I had come to the French Riviera, a stress-free and sunny shelter for wealthy exiles from the former Soviet Union, to meet some Russians before I went on a planned holiday with my wife in Haute-Provence to the north.

headline: Macedonia’s Political Parties Reach Deal to End Crisis
abstract: The deal clears the way for early elections in the tiny Balkan nation, which has been consumed by a wiretapping scandal.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — The four largest political parties in Macedonia have agreed in principle to early elections under a deal brokered by the European Union and the United States intended to resolve a political crisis that has consumed the tiny Balkan nation.

headline: As a Heat Wave Builds, Obama Wisely Presses for Community Cohesion
abstract: With a heat wave building, President Obama uses Twitter to press communities to check for vulnerable neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Along with commander in chief, President Obama could justify adding “chief resilience officer” as a new title, given how he smartly used Twitter on Wednesday to amplify government warnings about a dangerous heat wave spreading from the heartland to the East Coast in the next few days.

headline: Utica Settles State Claim Alleging Biased Enrollment for Refugee Students
abstract: The lawsuit claimed that immigrant students had been funneled into substandard alternative programs rather than being enrolled in the district’s only public high school.
lead_paragraph: The Utica City School District has settled a lawsuit filed by New York State accusing it of discriminatory enrollment practices that worked against refugee children.

headline: K2 Drug Overdoses
abstract: A New York psychiatrist writes that “criminalizing use without adequately addressing social determinants is unlikely to be effective.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Group Backed by U.S. Gives ISIS 48 Hours to Leave Syrian City
abstract: The ultimatum comes after reports that dozens of civilians were killed this week near the city of Manbij in airstrikes by the United States-led coalition.
lead_paragraph: Islamic State fighters holed up in one of the militant group’s last major strongholds in northern Syria have 48 hours to leave the city, according to an ultimatum issued by the local military council of the United States-supported Syria Democratic Forces.

headline: A Rarity at a Republican Convention: ‘I Am Proud to Be Gay’
abstract: Peter Thiel, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur, is believed to be the first person to utter those words at a Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Peter Thiel, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur, declared “I am proud to be gay” in a speech on Thursday night, making him the first person believed to utter those words from the stage of a Republican National Convention.

headline: Veterans and Mass Shootings
abstract: A professor defends his position that military veterans account for a disproportionate number of mass shooters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 5 Places to Go in Bogotá
abstract: From restaurants to indie boutiques, the vibe in Chapinero Alto is edgy and proudly Colombian.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, if you asked artists in Bogotá, Colombia, where the city’s creative types spent their time, they might have said the old colonial quarter, La Candelaria. Now it is just as likely to be the alt-district of Chapinero Alto, where graffiti scruffs up an orange brick mix of stately Tudor-style homes and blocky modern apartment buildings. The once-residential neighborhood abuts the sleek financial district, but its cheaper rents allow bold entrepreneurs to take more risks, even alongside the older family shops, or tiendas. From restaurants to indie boutiques, the vibe is original and proudly Colombian.

headline: The Republican Platform and Ukraine
abstract: Senator Ben Cardin writes that the Republican Party platform reflects “dangerous thinking.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Quiz: Name That Batting Stance
abstract: We asked former big leaguers Sean Casey and Cliff Floyd to impersonate their favorite batting stances. Can you match the stance (and swing) to the player?
lead_paragraph: We asked former big leaguers Sean Casey and Cliff Floyd to impersonate their favorite batting stances. Can you match the stance (and swing) to the player?

headline: Chris Froome Stretches His Lead in the Tour de France With a Decisive Time Trial Win
abstract: If the Tour continues as it has, Froome’s win in the 18th stage, an individual race against the clock, all but clinched his claim on this year’s trophy.
lead_paragraph: MEGÈVE, France — With a single fist pump after he crossed the finish line Thursday in this fashionable ski resort town, Chris Froome celebrated his convincing win of the final time trial in the Tour de France and the unofficial beginning of the competition to join him on the podium.

headline: In Jamaica, Running in Usain Bolt’s Footsteps
abstract: My parents liked to run, but I was not enthusiastic — and then I went to Jamaica, where I followed the trail of the Olympic gold medalist Usain Bolt.
lead_paragraph: To get to Sherwood Content, the hometown of the Jamaican track star Usain Bolt, rent a Toyota Yaris at Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay. Drive 27 miles along narrow unmarked roads through sugar cane fields, swerving to avoid cavernous potholes, goats and drivers who holler out the window to offer “the good stuff.”

headline: Outside the Hall, Protesters Keep the Peace
abstract: The mood was closer to festive as Donald Trump prepared to speak inside the Quicken Loans Arena.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The final evening of the Republican National Convention passed with little tumult among protesters and the police, capping a week in which predictions of wide-scale unrest on the streets were well off the mark.

headline: Ivanka Trump: A Real First Lady?
abstract: Donald Trump’s daughter Ivanka played an active role in his campaign, while his wife, Melania, preferred to take a back seat. The Times’s Jennifer Steinhauer explains how Ivanka Trump "whispers in his ear."
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s daughter Ivanka played an active role in his campaign, while his wife, Melania, preferred to take a back seat. The Times’s Jennifer Steinhauer explains how Ivanka Trump "whispers in his ear."

headline: I Left Him. Now I Want Him Back. How Do I Get Him?
abstract: Also, staying cool about a property dispute, discussing a father-in-law’s infidelity, and dealing with an inability to reciprocate lavishly.
lead_paragraph: I just finished my junior year of college. For most of it, I hung out with this super nice guy. He is smart and funny, and the sex was good. We went to parties and had lots of fun. But then he asked me if I wanted to “get serious.” Honestly, I didn’t. I just wanted to keep having fun. So, at his request, we stopped hanging out in May, and I kept having fun, which turned out to be less fun without him. I miss him and would like to try “getting serious” now, whatever that means. Do you think it’s too late to go back to him? If not, how do I do it?

headline: Donald Trump to Donors: A Cruz Endorsement ‘Doesn’t Mean Anything’
abstract: According to Politico, Mr. Trump also said that if he had been beaten as badly as he beat Gov. John Kasich in the primaries, “I wouldn’t support him either.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump told donors at a private meeting on Thursday that an endorsement from Senator Ted Cruz “doesn’t mean anything” to him and noted that his former opponent was run out of the convention hall on Wednesday night after being booed during his speech.

headline: Two’s Company, Three’s a Lichen?
abstract: New research challenges the one fungus-one alga paradigm of how lichens form.
lead_paragraph: “Fred took a likin’ to Alison.” It was a mnemonic device a high school biology teacher taught me to remember that a fungus plus an alga made a lichen, and I never forgot it.

headline: Moving Photographs, Inspired by Loss
abstract: The photographer Muyi Xiao began to work on her delicate series “Forget Me Not” with her mother, after the death of her grandmother.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Muyi Xiao began to work on her delicate series “Forget Me Not” with her mother, after the death of her grandmother.

headline: Photographs From the Final Day of the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: Photographs From the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: Ukraine’s Security Services and Rebels Are Said to Be Equals in Torture
abstract: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International cites abuses by both sides in the war, including waterboarding and the use of electric shocks.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A report by two leading human rights groups released on Thursday accuses Ukraine’s Western-backed security services of practicing abuse and torture in a manner similar to that of the rebel groups they are fighting.

headline: Show Them the Money
abstract: The percentage of Manhattan homes bought with cash in the first half of 2016.
lead_paragraph: The percentage of Manhattan homes bought with cash in the first half of 2016.

headline: Roger Ailes Leaves Fox News, and Rupert Murdoch Steps In
abstract: Mr. Murdoch himself broke the news to staff members in New York, barely two weeks after Mr. Ailes was named in a sexual harassment suit.
lead_paragraph: In the dark for days, Fox News staffers finally got word on Thursday about the future of their network.

headline: The Pokemon Go of the 1930s: Excuse Me, I Need to Find a Monkey and Head to the Waldorf
abstract: Long before Pokémon Go sent smartphone-clutching players on wild pixel chases, scavenger hunts had New York socialites flitting around in search of outlandish finds.
lead_paragraph: Oh, Pokémon Go. You are so today. Let’s look at yesterday for a moment.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, July 23 Through July 31
abstract: Sneaker collectors can buy, sell and restore their footwear at ‘Laced Up,’ a convention entirely dedicated to kicks. The event will take place at the Cradle of Aviation Museum in Garden City on July 30.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, July 23 Through 31
abstract: Annie DeWitt, author of the forthcoming novel “White Nights in Split Town City,” will read at the Spotty Dog Books and Ale during the Volume Reading and Music Series in August.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 23 Through July 31
abstract: Photographs by Peace Corps volunteers are on display at 70 South Gallery in Morristown through Oct. 14.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: In L.A., a Sleek Accessories Brand Opens a New Shop
abstract: The cult label Building Block opens the doors to its store in Chinatown this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Building Block, the burgeoning West Coast indie accessories brand, opens a new store Saturday in downtown L.A.’s Chinatown, showcasing its full range of industrial design-minded leather accessories. Located in Mandarin Plaza, just a chicken wing’s toss from chef Andy Ricker’s popular outpost of PokPok and the artist Frances Stark’s studio, Building Block’s outpost occupies a former Chinese bookstore. “We’re keeping the sign,” says Nancy Wu, who started the brand with her sister Kimberly Wu in May 2011.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 23 Through 31
abstract: The comedian, Eddie Izzard, brings his ‘Force Majeure World Tour’ to the Bushnell Center for the Performing Arts in Hartford on July 26.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Outdoor Art Across the City: 4 Things New Under the Sun
abstract: Artworks to see without going to a museum: A Trojan horse look-alike in Madison Square Park, a wall in Queens and tiny buildings on old Army bases.
lead_paragraph: There are at least two good things about the seasonal efflorescence of outdoor art in this city. One is that those who go looking for it may find their ways to places they’ve not been before. The other is that seekers — as well as casual passers-by — get to see art outside the hygienic shelters of museums and galleries, set loose in the world, where the relationship between the object and its site may catalyze the stretching of minds. Four notable works currently on view here and there in New York do just that.

headline: Donald Trump’s Remarks Rattle NATO Allies and Stoke Debate on Cost Sharing
abstract: The candidate’s contention that he might not defend allies that do not pay enough of the costs raised alarms across a continent unsettled by Russia and rising populism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Donald J. Trump’s statement that the United States might not come to the defense of NATO allies that do not foot their share of the bill fueled anxiety on Thursday in a Europe that is already deeply unsettled about Russia’s assertive posture, Britain’s decision to withdraw from the European Union and the rise of inward-looking populist and nationalist parties.

headline: Hotels for Going Out, Sleeping In and Everything in Between
abstract: Too tipsy to make it home? At these nightspots-turned-hotels, you don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: Too tipsy to make it home? At these nightspots-turned-hotels, you don’t have to.

headline: A Clue to the Scarcity of Financial Crisis Prosecutions
abstract: The Justice Department forced banks to pay fines and penalties, but mystery surrounds the dearth of individual prosecutions for wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: One of the enduring mysteries of the 2008 financial crisis has been why the Justice Department made so few attempts to prosecute the individuals responsible for it, given the abundance of tangible evidence of wrongdoing by Wall Street bankers, traders and executives in the years leading up to the great unwinding.

headline: Timelapse: A Day of R.N.C. Protests
abstract: The Times graphics editor Tim Wallace observes a day of protests on Wednesday at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: The Times graphics editor Tim Wallace observes a day of protests on Wednesday at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

headline: Treating Sports Photographers as the Artists They Are
abstract: An exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum invites visitors to reconsider work that has long been seen as ephemeral.
lead_paragraph: THEY compete in crowded stadiums and on hazardous terrain, using hands and eyes, tools and experience, and sometimes their elbows, too.

headline: A Son’s Sleuthing, a Father’s Archive and Capote’s Vanished Brooklyn
abstract: Unpublished images from 1958 make up “Truman Capote’s Brooklyn: The Lost Photographs of David Attie,” at the Brooklyn Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Truman Capote, stern-faced, looks down from the spiral staircase of his sprawling home in Brooklyn Heights. Three women — one framed by her furs — sit by the glow of a window at the Hotel Bossert, once known as the Waldorf Astoria of Brooklyn. A dignified W. E. B. Du Bois poses in his house at 31 Grace Court, near the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Review: In ‘Ice Age: Collision Course,’ a Squirrel Reorders the Universe
abstract: The fifth movie in the “Ice Age” franchise includes endless wisecracks and family-values twaddle, but the 3-D animation packs some punch.
lead_paragraph: The woolly mammoth couple Manny and Ellie contend with possible empty-nest syndrome and a possibly nest-destroying asteroid in “Ice Age: Collision Course,” the 37th installment in the popular computer animation franchise. O.K., actually it’s only the fifth feature, but what with the shorts and TV specials and video games, it feels as if there have been so, so many more.

headline: With an Air-Kiss, Donald Trump Shows His Softer Side
abstract: Body language experts said that, while a sign of progress, the awkward air-kiss by the Republican ticket showed that the running mates were still getting to know each other.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On most occasions when Donald J. Trump takes the stage, he exudes an air of unrivaled authority, dispatching protesters with the wave of a hand, clenching his fists for effect and, if necessary, squashing bugs that intrude on his air space.

headline: Rocking Out in the Mosh Pit, With Baby in Tow
abstract: As the festival industry grows, parents are starting to take their children with them — but not without some sidelong glances.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Melissa Auf der Maur goes to work, she often takes her 4-year-old daughter, River, as well as River’s protective earmuffs: twin plastic clamshells that nearly double the circumference of her head.

headline: Tarantulas to Pet and Crickets to Taste: It’s Bug Day at the Hall of Science
abstract: The New York Hall of Science’s annual Bug Day will include children’s crafts, intriguing favors and unusual hors d’oeuvres.
lead_paragraph: The cynical among us might say that every date in June, July and August is Bug Day. Not to mention Bug Night: Who hasn’t struggled to fall asleep while hearing the high-pitched buzz of a hungry mosquito?

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Worry Baby’ and a Case of Uncertain Paternity
abstract: This mildly humorous Julian Branciforte film, fortified with veteran actors, centers on whether a photographer or his father is the parent of a young girl.
lead_paragraph: The primary focus in the light comedy-drama “Don’t Worry Baby” — the promising feature debut of the writer-director Julian Branciforte — may be its millennial actors, but it’s the older players who bring the weight. Robert (John Magaro) is a hangdog Manhattan photographer flailing after initial success; now he endures the indignity of working for his philandering father, Harry (Christopher McDonald), who runs an Upper East Side preschool.

headline: When Form Meets Function: Cuff Links Throughout the Centuries
abstract: Cuff links, which serve an aesthetic yet functional purpose, are taking on a more prominent role in museums and private collections.
lead_paragraph: Cuff links have a simple purpose, but their innumerable forms reflect their owners’ personalities and manufacturers’ ingenuity. After decades of neglect from academics, they are coming to the fore in museum shows and private collections.

headline: The Batter’s Box Gets a Little Boring
abstract: Baseball history is rich with famous and bizarre stances at the plate. Today’s batters tend toward a more common and straightforward form.
lead_paragraph: Todd Frazier snatched a bat from his locker recently and raised the handle to his head, behind his right ear, wriggling it like a fishing rod about to be cast.

headline: The Little Things Hurt the Yankees in a Loss to the Orioles
abstract: Three defensive miscues proved costly as the Yankees failed to complete a four-game sweep against their American League East rivals.
lead_paragraph: Baseball players engage in all sorts of rituals to maintain their gloves, pounding the hardened spots with customized tools or using a variety of oils to soften them. Although it seems easy, closing a glove around a baseball is sometimes harder than it looks.

headline: Review: In ‘Quitters,’ a Teenager as Sinister as Iago
abstract: Noah Pritzker’s film stars Ben Konigsberg as a defiant son who moves out of his troubled family’s home and pursues an egotistic, amoral path.
lead_paragraph: Noah Pritzker’s small, sour debut film, “Quitters,” is steeped in the metaphysical malaise of its main character, Clark Rayman (Ben Konigsberg), an arrogant San Francisco teenager and budding Iago from an upper-middle-class family. In the opening scene, his mother (Mira Sorvino), addicted to benzodiazepines and dressed only in a bathrobe, crashes her car into a stop sign while driving him to a friend’s house.

headline: Donald Trump’s Convention of Chaos
abstract: Readers discuss Ted Cruz’s snub, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, Melania Trump’s speech and Mike Pence’s record.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Hooligan Sparrow,’ a Chinese Activist’s Hair-Raising Defiance of the State
abstract: Nanfu Wang’s guerrilla-style documentary tracks Ye Haiyan’s struggle to win justice for sexually abused schoolgirls and others.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, for a show of his work at the Brooklyn Museum, the Chinese artist and refusenik Ai Weiwei created an installation called “Ye Haiyan’s Belongings.” It looked simple enough, starting with the four walls, which had been covered with rows of photographs depicting quotidian objects like socks, undies, a bicycle and appliances. The orderliness of the wall display was in stark contrast with the artful jumble scattered on the floor, which included a few suitcases, various taped cardboard boxes and assorted other forlorn items — a table fan, a pillow, a fridge, a motorbike.

headline: Testing New York City’s Longest Slide, on Governors Island
abstract: Two experts, ages 3 and 5, tried out Slide Hill, the newest playground on Governors Island.
lead_paragraph: A verdant expansion of parkland opened on Governors Island this week, a 10-acre parcel called the Hills, with singular views of Upper New York Bay, far across to the bustling docks of Bayonne, N.J., out toward the arc of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, or north to the spiky Manhattan skyline.

headline: Karl Case, Economist Who Developed Home Price Index, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Case, a professor at Wellesley College, worked with a Yale economist to develop the Case-Shiller Index to track home values in an opaque market.
lead_paragraph: Karl E. Case, an economics professor at Wellesley College who helped revolutionize how home prices are tracked by real estate professionals and home buyers alike, died on July 15 in Wellesley, Mass. He was 69.

headline: At New York’s Pierre, Restoring the Romantic Rotunda Room
abstract: The Rotunda Room at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan has a storied history — and now, after a renovation, it has a new glow.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, the muralists arrived, tiptoeing into the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan at midnight. They erected scaffolding in the grand oval space known as the Rotunda Room, climbed up and stretched out on their backs, daubing at the painted clouds that have long drifted across the sky-blue ceiling.

headline: Review: In ‘Lights Out’ an Invisible Friend Turns Malicious
abstract: The director David F. Sandberg extracts maximum frights from a simple concept: an entity that appears in the dark and vanishes in the light.
lead_paragraph: Psychosis begets substance in “Lights Out,” a shameless piggyback — at least in apparition design and deployment — on the popularity of 2014’s terrifyingly effective Australian movie “The Babadook.”

headline: Ted Cruz Might Be the Only Republican Who Understands Donald Trump
abstract: On the pro-wrestler logic of Cruz’s Republican convention speech.
lead_paragraph: Viewed through the lens of conventional politics, Ted Cruz’s performance last night was the sort of thing you just don’t do at the Republican National Convention. But we’re pretty far removed from conventional politics by now, aren’t we? If that wasn’t clear before the lights went up in the Quicken Loans Arena on Monday, it certainly was by the time Trump made his from-the-shadows entrance that night. Within minutes, you could find photos of the scene paired with shots of “the Undertaker” entering a crazed arena that made overt what we already suspected: that this week’s festivities were going to be as much W.W.E. as R.N.C.

headline: Edward Snowden to Help Develop a Safer Phone for Journalists
abstract: Mr. Snowden, speaking from Russia to an M.I.T. Media Lab conference, said the idea was to alert users to electronic surveillance in dangerous areas.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden said Thursday that he planned to help develop a modified version of Apple’s iPhone for journalists who are concerned that they may be the target of government surveillance.

headline: Review: ‘For a Few Bullets,’ an Antic Race Through Plot Contrivance
abstract: Set in China in 1940, the film depicts a pair of heroes trying to secure a rare treasure in manic chase scenes.
lead_paragraph: The bad guys can’t shoot straight and the good guys (and gals) rarely miss in “For a Few Bullets,” a movie whose lack of logic is mostly forgivable until it chucks coherence altogether.

headline: Review: In Takarazuka’s ‘Chicago,’ the Midwest Looks a Lot Like Japan
abstract: The celebrated all-female Japanese theater company Takarazuka performed as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: Do the Japanese have an expression similar to the British one, noting the folly of bringing coals to Newcastle? Maybe something about bringing a tuna fish sandwich to a sushi bar?

headline: Review: All Aboard ‘Train to Busan’ for Zombie and Class Warfare
abstract: Yeon Sang-ho’s film, set on a South Korean bullet train, pits passengers against the spastic undead.
lead_paragraph: Elite passengers on a South Korean bullet train face a twitching, hissing threat from the cheap seats in “Train to Busan,” a public-transportation horror movie with a side helping of class warfare.

headline: Roger Ailes Fused TV With Politics, Changing Both
abstract: With Fox News, Mr. Ailes changed and shaped what we talk about when we talk about news and government.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes has died at 77. This assesment of his career by our chief television critic was originally published in July 2016, following the departure of Mr. Ailes from Fox News.

headline: Review: In ‘The Childhood of a Leader,’ a Monster Made, Not Born
abstract: The movie, set in France just after World War I, follows a boy with problems and delivers a sense of foreboding.
lead_paragraph: Family and fascism march in lock step in “The Childhood of a Leader.” A visually sumptuous, slow-boil freakout set in France in the aftermath of World War I, it hinges on an unruly boy, Prescott (Tom Sweet), who goes to battle with his authoritarian parents as his American father (Liam Cunningham) is helping negotiate the peace terms with Germany. Having arrived as part of President Woodrow Wilson’s political retinue, the unnamed father has moved into a sprawling, dilapidated farmhouse. There, he and his European wife (also nameless, and played by Bérénice Bejo) settle into their own uneasy peace, one increasingly disturbed by their eccentric son.

headline: Gail Collins in Cleveland: ‘For Journalists, You Can’t Get Better Than This’
abstract: The opinion columnist Gail Collins reflects on the Republican convention, Donald Trump and the goings-on in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: The opinion columnist Gail Collins reflects on the Republican convention, Donald Trump and the goings-on in Cleveland.

headline: Review: ‘The Seventh Fire’ Explores Drug Abuse on an Indian Reservation
abstract: A searing documentary that shows the bleak lives of two residents of Pine Point, an Ojibwe village in northern Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: The only genuine moments of peace in the searing documentary “The Seventh Fire” come at the very beginning: lyrical shots of headlights moving forward on a long stretch of road at daybreak. After that, the director, Jack Pettibone Riccobono, practically grabs viewers by the backs of their necks and shows them the bleak lives of two residents of Pine Point, an Ojibwe village in northern Minnesota on the White Earth Indian Reservation.

headline: Review: ‘Motown: The Musical’ Offers Easy Nostalgia and a Jolt of Racial Relevance
abstract: This celebratory jukebox musical, with a book by Berry Gordy, who founded the Motown record label, has returned to Broadway for a limited run.
lead_paragraph: “What’s going on?”

headline: Review: In ‘Hillary’s America,’ Dinesh D’Souza Warns of a Plan to ‘Steal’ the Country
abstract: The conservative author’s film paints a forbidding portrait of Hillary Clinton and her fellow Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The new movie by the conservative author and pundit Dinesh D’Souza, “Hillary’s America,” directed and written with Bruce Schooley, opens with an animated montage of a map of the United States going up in flames in various spots. A close-up image of Hillary Clinton caps the scene. The film then recounts Mr. D’Souza’s own guilty plea to violating federal campaign finance laws. He was set up, he insists. “If you make a film criticizing the most powerful man in the world,” he says, referring to his 2012 documentary, “2016: Obama’s America,” “expect the empire to strike back.”

headline: N.B.A. to Move All-Star Game From North Carolina
abstract: The league’s move came as a reaction to state legislation perceived as being hostile to gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: The National Basketball Association on Thursday dealt a blow to the economy and prestige of North Carolina by pulling next February’s All-Star Game from Charlotte to protest a state law that eliminated anti-discrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: Review: Avenging a Sister’s Death in ‘Fight Valley’
abstract: A street-fighting crew from New Jersey called the Knock-Around Girls is the focus of this punch-drunk action drama.
lead_paragraph: Take that, Ronda Rousey. The former mixed martial arts champion — now a budding movie star with turns in “Entourage,” “The Expendables 3” and “Furious 7” — is challenged by her former Ultimate Fighting Championship peers in Rob Hawk’s “Fight Valley.” Don’t get me wrong; she’s not in the movie. But a few of her erstwhile rivals take a swing at the big screen (and Ms. Rousey’s Hollywood status) in this punch-drunk action drama, starring Miesha Tate (the former U.F.C. women’s bantamweight champion); the featherweight Cris Cyborg (Cristiane Venancio, but here billed under her nom de octagon); and Holly Holm, who bested Ms. Rousey in a championship bout in 2015.

headline: Review: Rich, Crude and Craving Acceptance in 17th-Century France
abstract: “Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme,” Molière’s 1670 comedy, is being presented as part of the Lincoln Center Festival by a French company.
lead_paragraph: Monsieur Jourdain, the hapless hero of Molière’s 1670 masterpiece, “Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme,” is the original culture vulture. A wealthy commoner, he craves acceptance by those highborn and dedicates himself to learning their refined pastimes, like fencing and dancing the minuet. His daughter falls in love with a former soldier? Tough — she’ll have to marry a lying, cheating count instead.

headline: Mets Fan? You May Be Better Represented at Cooperstown Than You Think
abstract: When Mike Piazza is inducted into the Hall of Fame on Sunday, he will be only the second inductee with a Mets cap on his plaque. But 15 others have appeared on Mets rosters over the years.
lead_paragraph: When the Baseball Hall of Fame inducts Mike Piazza on Sunday, its membership among Mets will double. Sort of.

headline: The Drama of Ted Cruz: A Little Bit of Shakespeare in That Speech?
abstract: The senator’s address to the Republican National Committee reminded some of Marc Antony’s funeral speech in “Julius Caesar.”
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is no stranger to the theater: In seventh grade, he played Rolfe in “The Sound of Music”; in law school, he was the Rev. Samuel Parris in “The Crucible”; and in the Senate, he declaimed from “Henry V” to pass time during a filibuster.

headline: Gail Collins in Cleveland: ‘For Journalists, You Can’t Get Better Than This’
abstract: The opinion columnist Gail Collins reflects on the Republican convention, Donald Trump and the goings-on in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into The New York Times and how it works. In this podcast, the opinion columnist Gail Collins talks to us about the goings-on at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

headline: Kanye West Will Perform at a Benefit for the Watermill Center
abstract: Mr. West will join the arts center’s event next week; the Guggenheim puts an artist on its board; recreating a Matthew Barney moment.
lead_paragraph: If you ever needed proof of the increasingly high-powered glamour of the art world, look at which celebrity the Watermill Center in the Hamptons has just lined up for its annual summer benefit on July 30: Kanye West.

headline: His Tone Dark, Donald Trump Takes G.O.P. Mantle
abstract: Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination with an unusually vehement appeal to Americans who feel that their country is spiraling out of control.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald John Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday night with an unusually vehement appeal to Americans who feel that their country is spiraling out of control and yearn for a leader who will take aggressive, even extreme, actions to protect them.

headline: ‘The Keeper’ Reveals the Passion for Collecting
abstract: A captivating show fills the New Museum with objects gathered and sorted by some 30 retentive artists.
lead_paragraph: You call it collecting. I call it hoarding. The New Museum calls it art and has a captivating exhibition devoted to it. Titled “The Keeper,” the show fills three floors and a lobby gallery with hundreds of thousands of mostly small objects and images gathered, sorted, arranged and recorded by some 30 retentive artists — keepers — over the course of the 20th century and into the 21st.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Think Twice’: Mike Birbiglia’s Smart Comedy
abstract: The movie follows an improv troupe and its members, who can be both supportive and catty.
lead_paragraph: “Has anybody here had a particularly hard day?”

headline: Your Evening Briefing

headline: Review: Warm Burst of Romantic Bliss in ‘Summertime’
abstract: A film about the struggle for sexual freedom and women’s rights, and also about the power of region, class and custom in the lives of its characters.
lead_paragraph: Delphine and Carole meet in Paris in the early ’70s, a time of post-’68 agitation and fertile ground for French filmmakers mining their nation’s recent history for resonant stories. Catherine Corsini’s “Summertime,” with the clarity of hindsight and a deep reservoir of empathy, examines the commingling of the personal and the political from a fresh angle. This is a film about the struggle for sexual freedom and women’s rights, and also about the power of region, class and custom in the lives of its characters.

headline: Tim Kaine Seems Likely for Hillary Clinton’s No. 2, but Liberals Balk
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign has kept a tight lid on its search for a vice-presidential candidate but was expected to make her choice known on Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Democrats close to Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign signaled strongly Thursday that she would choose Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia as her running mate, rounding out the ticket with a popular politician from a battleground state.

headline: Exxon Mobil Acquires InterOil for $2.5 Billion
abstract: InterOil’s holdings in Papua New Guinea are a potential source for liquefied natural gas.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil agreed on Thursday to buy InterOil, a driller focused on projects in Papua New Guinea, for at least $2.5 billion as the petroleum giant seeks newer fields.

headline: Review: Jeff Beck’s Virtuosic Sleight of Hand at Madison Square Garden
abstract: There was something particular, specialized and unusual about nearly every sound Mr. Beck produced.
lead_paragraph: The paranormally skilled guitarist Jeff Beck, now 72, has just released a new album called “Loud Hailer,” with a very mundane image on the front cover: a megaphone. He made it with new band members, including the young English singer Rosie Bones and the guitar player Carmen Vandenberg; its songs are full of passionate, if clumsy, protests and allegations about war, income inequality, oil dependency and consumer passivity.

headline: Donald Trump’s Ambivalence on the Baltics Is More Important Than It Seems
abstract: In an interview Wednesday, Mr. Trump suggested breaking a NATO obligation that is central to upholding the postwar peace in Europe and the balance of power with Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump was asked on Wednesday whether, if elected president, he would defend the Baltic nations against a hypothetical Russian attack, his answer was, essentially: It depends.

headline: This Week’s Movies | July 22, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Star Trek: Beyond,” “Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie” and “Don’t Think Twice.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Star Trek: Beyond,” “Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie” and “Don’t Think Twice.”

headline: Chipotle’s Rough Spell Is No Help for Its Rivals
abstract: The failure of its competitors to capitalize on its food safety problems may provide some hope to Chipotle, whose business has been battered.
lead_paragraph: At least one group saw opportunity in Chipotle Mexican Grill’s string of food safety crises last year — the restaurant chain’s competitors.

lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — New York Times correspondents are chronicling the colorful, the unusual and the quirky at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

headline: Indiana Hometown Molded Mike Pence Even as It Began to Change
abstract: Many of Mr. Pence’s deeply conservative views hark back to the tranquil, insular Columbus, Ind., of decades ago, a place that is vastly different today.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ind. — “For the last three Sundays, the Edward Pence family has lit a candle in their Advent wreath and had a reading from the Mass proper for a part of their devotion to Christmas,” The Columbus Republic’s society page reported. “Christmas Eve they will follow the tradition of opening their gifts, placed under a tree which they picked themselves at the tree nursery, and going to midnight Mass at St. Columba.”

headline: In Convention’s Shadow, Indiana Republicans Vie for Mike Pence’s Old Job
abstract: Intrigue has set in among Indiana’s delegation as officials scrambled for the nomination for governor now that Mr. Pence is the vice-presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Mike Pence’s quest to be vice president has suddenly left a gap on Indiana’s ballot for governor, and the battle to replace him has been playing out in the unlikeliest of places: a desolate airport hotel in Cleveland, the temporary home of Indiana’s Republican delegation.

headline: What Did It Take to Make ‘Equity,’ a Film About Women on Wall Street?
abstract: The budget for the financial thriller, which stars Anna Gunn of “Breaking Bad” and opens on July 29, was raised from 25 female investors.
lead_paragraph: When Sarah Megan Thomas and Alysia Reiner were pitching “Equity,” their film about female executives on Wall Street, they showed potential backers a video of the way women were typically depicted in finance movies: as demeaned assistants, “background players, hookers, strippers,” Ms. Reiner said. Rarely were women the bosses who made the deals, or even the negotiators who enabled them.

headline: Chasing Pokémon, a Baby Step Toward Virtual Reality
abstract: With a charged cellphone in hand, a reporter joins San Francisco’s first large planned Pokémon Go event.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In this season of random assassinations and political uproar, who could resist the temptation to supplement a high-strung and frightening reality with some gentle make-believe?

headline: Secrecy Reigns as U.N. Seeks a New Secretary General
abstract: Diplomats emerged from the nearly two-hour voting session with lips sealed about whom they had given a thumb’s up or thumb’s down to.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The race for the next United Nations secretary general has been marked by two things: A clamor for a woman to take the helm after 70 years of male leadership, and a push for more sunlight into the mysterious process by which the Security Council makes its selection.

headline: Jazz Listings for July 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: WA selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

abstract: Many delegates at the Republican National Convention were disappointed when Senator Ted Cruz failed to endorse Donald J. Trump during his speech on the third night of the convention.
lead_paragraph: Many delegates at the Republican National Convention were disappointed when Senator Ted Cruz failed to endorse Donald J. Trump during his speech on the third night of the convention.

headline: Republican Convention Night 4: What You Missed
abstract: The final night of the Republican National Convention was Donald J. Trump’s night.
lead_paragraph: Night 4 of the Republican National Convention was Donald J. Trump’s night: He was introduced after a speech by his daughter Ivanka. Mr. Trump’s speech — and the balloons that follow his acceptance of the Republican nomination — kicked off the final phase in his quest for the presidency.

headline: Sewage Spill, Check. Rerouted Race, Check. Contracting the Zika Virus ...
abstract: Insurance companies for the Rio Olympics are already serving notice that they may not cover every type of loss related to Zika.
lead_paragraph: Come what may, the Rio Olympics set to begin Aug. 5 will be largely covered. By insurance, that is.

headline: Dance Listings for July 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: Reince Priebus Thinks This Went Great
abstract: A visit with the Republican National Committee chairman in his Cleveland bunker.
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday afternoon, the Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus was sitting in a fancy bunker suite deep in the intestines of the Quicken Loans Arena. The Trump Room is what the space is called this week. It is part of the decked-out lair where the soon-to-be Republican nominee will “hold” before delivering his acceptance speech tonight sometime around 10. It resembles a boardroom not dissimilar to the set of “The Apprentice” — bottles of Trump-brand water, a shiny Formica table and poster-size pictures of the candidate all over the walls.

headline: Hollywood Screenwriter Subpoenaed for Hours of Bergdahl Tapes
abstract: Lawyers subpoenaed for over 25 hours of conversations between the screenwriter and Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in an apparent move for his prosecution.
lead_paragraph: The only time the public has heard Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl explain in his own voice why he left his base in Afghanistan — to expose problems in his Army unit, he said, and to “prove to the world” his soldiering skills — was on taped interviews broadcast on the podcast “Serial.”

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 22-28
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Islanders May Build Hockey Arena in Queens With Mets’ Help
abstract: The Islanders’ ownership is reportedly exploring a site in Queens next to Citi Field, which is closer to their former home in Uniondale.
lead_paragraph: After a bumpy first season at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the Islanders are talking with the owners of the Mets about building a hockey arena next to Citi Field in Flushing, according to Bloomberg, which did not cite anyone by name. The talks have been going on for months.

headline: F.C.C. Backs Swedish Company to Run American Phone Routing System
abstract: Major wireless carriers pushed for Telcordia because of the cost savings, but some intelligence officials have raised national security concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission has decided to make a European-owned company the clearinghouse for routing billions of cellphone calls and text messages across the United States, despite claims by critics that the plan poses national security risks, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Package Thrown at Police Leads to Frantic Drive and 6-Hour Standoff
abstract: After a man tossed a blinking device into a police van in Times Square, officers urgently drove it away from crowds out of fear that it was a bomb.
lead_paragraph: The night had all the trappings of a regular shift for the two New York police officers sitting in a van parked amid the crowd in Times Square. Then a man passing in a vehicle threw an odd, blinking package into their van.

headline: Around Town for July 22-28
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: In Texas, Fixing Voter ID Law Ruled to Be Discriminatory Will Be Tricky Task
abstract: A judge must create procedures to soften the effects of the restrictions before the November election after an appeals court ruled that the law discriminated against minorities.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ever since Texas’ strict voter identification law was passed in 2011, Democratic lawmakers and minority groups had focused on how to get it struck down. This week, after a federal appeals court ruled that the law discriminated against minorities, there is a new, equally vexing question: how to fix it.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for July 22-28
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Inside Fox News, ‘There Are People in Tears’
abstract: Several veteran anchors spoke of their sadness at Roger Ailes’s departure, and looked to the future.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of Fox News employees gathered in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention, the abrupt resignation of Roger Ailes came as a disorienting shock. Mr. Ailes, who dominated the network for two decades, is facing multiple allegations of sexual harassment by women who worked at Fox, including Gretchen Carlson, the former anchor who sued Mr. Ailes this month.

headline: Mexican Journalist Who Exposed Scandal Says Lawsuit Is Meant as a Warning
abstract: The broadcaster who helped break news that President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife had secretly bought a luxury home says she is being sued by her former boss.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In an effort to put a scandal that has rocked his presidency behind him, President Enrique Peña Nieto apologized this week for his wife’s purchase of a luxury home from a favored contractor.

headline: Second Possible Zika Infection Is Found in Florida
abstract: If the two cases are confirmed, they would be the first transmissions in the continental United States.
lead_paragraph: Florida health officials are investigating a possible second case of the Zika virus that may have been locally transmitted. The announcement of the case, in Broward County, comes two days after the state said it was investigating a possible homegrown case in Miami-Dade County.

headline: Gay Republicans at the Convention: Scarce, Except in D.C. Delegation
abstract: This has not been the best week for the seven out of 19 District of Columbia delegates who are gay or lesbian.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Tucked into a remote corner of the Quicken Loans Arena, behind Puerto Rico and next to the spillover seats for Texas, were the 19 delegates for the District of Columbia. The delegation, packed with city-dwelling lawyers and lobbyists and representing a Democratic stronghold, is always an outlier at a Republican National Convention.

headline: Billy Name, Who Glazed Warhol’s Factory in Silver, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Name was a photographer, a muse and a lover of Warhol who captured the Factory coterie in black-and-white pictures.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol’s New York loft on East 47th Street in Midtown Manhattan, called the Silver Factory because every surface was embellished with aluminum foil and silver paint, was to the social life of postwar art what Gertrude Stein’s Rue de Fleurus apartment in Paris or the Royal Academy of Art’s drawing rooms in London were to previous eras.

headline: Queens Crusader Turned the Tide for a Crumbling Park and Its Sea Wall
abstract: Elizabeth McQueen leaned on elected officials to revitalize Queensbridge Park in Long Island City. Its esplanade reopened in summer 2014, but her work still wasn’t done.
lead_paragraph: Into her 80s, Elizabeth McQueen patrolled Queensbridge Park in Long Island City, Queens, wheeling her walker, a grandson or a great-grandchild at her side, eyes sweeping the walks and lawn. “If someone was barbecuing, she made sure they had garbage bags,” her grandson, Desmen Williams, said. “She had a bin of supplies. A rake if you needed to rake up. She made sure the fire barrels were out there, so you put coals in the barrel when you were done.”

headline: Envisioning Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy: The U.S. Steps Back
abstract: Mr. Trump’s unconventional proposals on NATO, troop deployment, trade and intervention would most likely reduce engagement with other nations, with potentially risky results.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump, in a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times here on Wednesday, outlined an approach to the use of American power that was decidedly unconventional — especially for the Republican Party, which has long favored an internationalist approach to foreign policy.

headline: Seen From Outer Space
abstract: Martin Ashwood-Smith and George Barany stack ’em high.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s not a Friday without some sort of cruciverbal derring-do, and the derring we are doing today are quad stacks (four grid-spanning entries stacked on top of each other) crossed by three 16-letter entries (today’s puzzle has 16 rows and 15 columns, as opposed to the more typical 15×15 grid).

headline: Ventilation to Be Required in All New York Nail Salons
abstract: The new rule, announced by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, is one of the most sweeping changes in an effort to make the industry safer and more equitable for workers.
lead_paragraph: All nail salons in New York State will be required to have ventilation systems to protect manicurists and others from the potentially dangerous health effects of chemicals used in nail products, the governor announced this week.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, July 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “While we recognize that the N.B.A. cannot choose the law in every city, state and country in which we do business, we do not believe we can successfully host our All-Star festivities in Charlotte.”

headline: Thiel at R.N.C.: ‘I Am Proud to Be Gay’
abstract: Peter Thiel, the billionaire Silicon Valley venture capitalist and entrepreneur, spoke at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Peter Thiel, the billionaire Silicon Valley venture capitalist and entrepreneur, spoke at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland on Thursday.

headline: ‘Motown: The Musical’ to Close for Second Time on Broadway
abstract: The show is abruptly ending its return engagement on Broadway, just 19 days after it began.
lead_paragraph: “Motown: The Musical” is abruptly ending its return engagement on Broadway, only 19 days after it began.

headline: Introducing Her Father, Ivanka Trump Is Character Witness
abstract: The speech was a sharp departure in tone from some of the earlier presentations at the convention, including chants of “lock her up!” about Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Ivanka Trump, the eldest daughter of the Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, and perhaps the most poised and articulate defender of his character and ideas, introduced her father as “a fighter” who will “fight for you.”

headline: What Donald Trump Doesn’t Understand About the Trade Deficit
abstract: Part of what makes the United States powerful is the great importance of the dollar to global finance.
lead_paragraph: This is an updated version of an article that first ran on March 27, 2016.

headline: Fact-Checking the Truth That Donald Trump Promised
abstract: Many facts in Mr. Trump’s acceptance speech appear to be true, though he sometimes failed to offer the entire story or provide all of the context.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump’s acceptance speech here was filled with Trump-like hyperbole and the kind of vague political rhetoric that is hard to pin down.

headline: New Geometry of Citi Field Puts Mets’ Retired Numbers on the Move
abstract: When the outfield dimensions shrunk, it became difficult to see the numbers in left field. They are now displayed at the top of the stadium.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, when Citi Field opened in 2009, the Mets’ retired numbers — and there are not that many of them — were situated on the left-field wall.

headline: The Dark Knight
abstract: Donald Trump’s promise to save us from a malevolent world employs the same argument used by just about every other demagogue since the dawn of time.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to a world without rules. (I want you to read this paragraph in your super-scary movie trailer voice.) Welcome to a world in which families are mowed down by illegal immigrants, in which cops die in the streets, in which Muslims rampage the innocents and threaten our very way of life, in which the fear of violent death lurks in every human heart.

headline: Escape His Caricature? Donald Trump Passes Up the Chance
abstract: To an electorate that remains anxious about his demeanor, his honesty and his character, Mr. Trump offered no acknowledgment, no rebuttal, no explanation.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was Donald J. Trump’s best chance to escape his own caricature.

headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign of Fear
abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign has rested on assertions of power, not workable ideas. It’s time for him to justify voters’ trust.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump ascended the dais on Thursday night as the most improbable of Republican presidential nominees.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: “BoJack Horseman” kicks off a new season of absurdist comedy. And Robert F. Kennedy Jr. makes a case for why his cousin Michael C. Skakel did not kill Martha Moxley.
lead_paragraph: “BoJack Horseman” kicks off a new season of absurdist comedy as its fame-hungry star chases after an Oscar. “The Campaign” sends in the political clowns. And Robert F. Kennedy Jr. makes a case for why his cousin Michael C. Skakel did not kill Martha Moxley.

headline: Corrections: July 22, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, July 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Ivanka Trump Softens Father’s Image
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s eldest daughter, Ivanka, introduced the Republican presidential nominee on Thursday night. In her speech, Ms. Trump offered a different tone than most of the other convention speakers.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s eldest daughter, Ivanka, introduced the Republican presidential nominee on Thursday night. In her speech, Ms. Trump offered a different tone than most of the other convention speakers.

headline: Trump’s Speech Casts U.S. in Dark Light
abstract: Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination with an emphatic appeal to Americans who feel that their country is spiraling out of control.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination with an emphatic appeal to Americans who feel that their country is spiraling out of control.

headline: Pictures From the Republican Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converge this week in Cleveland for the Republican National Convention.

headline: Transcript: Donald Trump at the G.O.P. Convention
abstract: Following is a transcript of Donald J. Trump’s remarks at the Republican National Convention, as prepared for delivery by the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Donald J. Trump’s remarks at the Republican National Convention, as prepared for delivery on Thursday by the campaign:

headline: Speakers at the G.O.P. Convention Talked About Hillary Clinton a Lot. Is That Unusual?
abstract: Mentions of Democratic opponents at Republican conventions.
lead_paragraph: Mentions of Democratic opponents at Republican conventions.

headline: Fast Footwork as ‘Events’ Intrude on British Politics
abstract: After unsettling developments at home and abroad, a fresh slate of leaders is staking out new positions in a time of not-so-nimble reinvention.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Theresa May, the new British prime minister, entered Parliament on Monday to support the renewal of Britain’s submarine-based nuclear deterrent, she was asked whether she was prepared to authorize “a nuclear strike that could kill a hundred thousand men, women and children.”

headline: Who Was Behind the Coup Attempt in Turkey?
abstract: It seems likely that a Pennsylvania-based Muslim cleric initiated the putsch. The United States must help Turkey find justice.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The bloody coup attempt in Turkey last week, which cost more than 200 lives, brought the world’s attention to the group that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared responsible: the Islamic community led by Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish cleric who has lived in self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania since the late 1990s.

headline: Get Juveniles Out of Rikers Island
abstract: A plan to move young prisoners out of a notorious New York City jail could help end the inhumane treatment they have received.
lead_paragraph: New York City has developed a plan to move adolescents out of the notorious Rikers Island jail complex to a jail in the Bronx dedicated exclusively to 16- and 17-year-olds. This is an excellent and long-overdue idea that would do much to humanize the way the correctional system treats juveniles.

headline: Restoring the Right to Vote in Texas
abstract: While a voter ID law was not struck down entirely, the court found discrimination against minorities and ordered another court to devise a remedy.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people stymied by Texas’ absurdly strict voter ID law will finally get a fair break in casting their ballots in November.

headline: Make America Hate Again
abstract: Nothing about this Republican Party even remotely resembles the Grand Old Party of before. The convention was all doom, dystopia, dread and darkness.
lead_paragraph: They didn’t riot in the streets of Cleveland, as Donald Trump said his supporters would do had things not gone his way. But you saw the raw essence of a riot, the madness and loss of reason, on display in four days of chaos at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Donald Trump, the Siberian Candidate
abstract: The Republicans’ presidential nominee doesn’t just admire Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: If elected, would Donald Trump be Vladimir Putin’s man in the White House? This should be a ludicrous, outrageous question. After all, he must be a patriot — he even wears hats promising to make America great again.

headline: The Death of the Republican Party
abstract: Donald Trump’s acid bath hollows out the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On the surface, this seems like a normal Republican convention. There are balloon drops, banal but peppy music from the mid-1970s and polite white people not dancing in their seats.

headline: The World Roger Ailes Created
abstract: I sincerely doubt we would have had Donald Trump without him.
lead_paragraph: When I first met Roger Ailes in 1993, I was working for The Los Angeles Times. I was surprised by how engaging he was and how much he seemed to enjoy debating a newspaper reporter. I was there to interview Mr. Ailes about CNBC, NBC’s cable business channel, which he had just been hired to run.

headline: Jon Stewart, Back on ‘Late Show,’ Lets Loose on Fox News and More
abstract: Jon Stewart appeared on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” delivering a 10-minute monologue on the state of politics.
lead_paragraph: When Jon Stewart appeared Monday on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” it was mostly to play comedic foil to that CBS host (and former Comedy Central colleague) in a sketch that featured Mr. Stewart soaking Mr. Colbert in spit-takes of water.

headline: A Donald Trump Speech Whose Sunny Spots Came Mostly From the Stage Lights
abstract: Mr. Trump delivered a grim, angry message to close a grim, angry convention, casting himself as the only leader capable of saving America.
lead_paragraph: My fellow Americans, the state of the union is dark and full of terrors.

headline: The Week in Pictures: July 22, 2016
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: Justice Department Complaint on 1MDB Assets
abstract: The Justice Department filed a complaint on Wednesday in federal court in California to seize $1 billion dollars in assets said to be stolen from Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund. Here is the complete court filing.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed a complaint on Wednesday in federal court in California to seize $1 billion dollars in assets said to be stolen from Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund. Here is the complete court filing.

headline: Day 4: Trump Hits Clinton With Ominous Message
abstract: Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Cleveland on Thursday, presenting himself as the savior needed for a doomed nation.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Cleveland on Thursday, presenting himself as the savior needed for a doomed nation.

headline: The Incalculable Value of Finding a Job You Love
abstract: To be happy, research suggests, earning a high salary isn’t enough. Once you have met your basic needs, satisfaction comes from developing an expertise.
lead_paragraph: Social scientists have been trying to identify the conditions most likely to promote satisfying human lives. Their findings give some important clues about choosing a career: Money matters, but as the economist Richard Easterlin and others have demonstrated, not always in the ways you may think.

headline: Recipe for a Chinese Ritual Dish: Eggs, Time and Plenty of Urine
abstract: In Dongyang, “virgin boy eggs” are a traditional (and some say healthy) delicacy that depends on nature’s call to add just the right flavor.
lead_paragraph: China is a place with many unusual annual traditions, including a mud-flinging festival in the country’s tropical southwest and a June celebration of eating worms. But one of the most exotic rituals comes in spring, when residents of Dongyang, in coastal Zhejiang Province, chow down on eggs simmered in steaming pots of — wait for it — boys’ urine.

headline: A Crash Course in Honeymoon Survival
abstract: Lost in the Amazon jungle, a newly married couple finds hope in fantasizing about the future (while clad in underwear and headlamps).
lead_paragraph: Four days into our honeymoon, my husband and I faced the end of our marriage, the end of our lives. Large bruises marred my thighs and shins. A corrosive leaf had burned a fiery triangle into Jeremy’s neck. Mosquitoes competed for space on our pocked flesh.

headline: The Week in Pictures: July 22, 2016
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: Helping the Elderly Downsize
abstract: Some move managers specialize in helping seniors downsize, divest, donate or simply declutter for safety’s — and sanity’s — sake.
lead_paragraph: In her long career as a psychiatrist, Dr. Phyllis Harrison-Ross has been described by friends and colleagues as practical and calm. But two other traits, humor and patience, went right out the window when she decided to downsize.

headline: A Runner’s Career Ends, but Her Mission Goes the Distance
abstract: Lauren Fleshman is retiring at 34, but her push for reforms in track and field and in the role of women in the sport continues.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Fleshman was the top female collegiate distance runner in American history. Then, as a professional athlete, she transformed herself into an entrepreneur and a forceful advocate for women in sports. When she included a photo of her pregnancy-loosened belly in a blog post a year after trying out for the 2012 Olympics, it drew more attention than any race she had won.

headline: Is There Any Hope for Peace in South Sudan?
abstract: Residents of Juba, the capital, are caught in the crossfire of a power struggle between the rival factions of the country’s transitional government.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — For nearly two weeks, they have hunkered in a schoolyard with nothing to do and nowhere else to go, dozens of people battling hunger, swarms of mosquitoes — and fear.

headline: Why You Should Feel Free to Ignore Polls for a Few Weeks
abstract: Because of the conventions, we’re entering a period of polling volatility.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump officially became the Republican party’s nominee Thursday night, and on Monday, the Democratic convention begins in Philadelphia. In the coming weeks, you can expect lots of polls — and headlines — suggesting new insight into the state of the presidential race.

headline: Can Statins Cause Diabetes?
abstract: Numerous studies have shown that cholesterol-lowering statin drugs are linked to a small increase in the risk of Type 2 diabetes, even as they reduce the risk of heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: Question:

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: New York Today: Surfin’ N.Y.C.
abstract: Friday: Surf destinations near the city, blistering heat and philosophers among us.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:56 a.m.

headline: Summer Ice Cream Adventures
abstract: Reader responses to last week’s Intentional Summer challenge included ice cream made with beer, a cabbage sorbet and a politically minded family holding an “ice cream nominating convention.”
lead_paragraph: In last week’s Intentional Summer challenge, we proposed making or trying an unusual flavor of ice cream. You did not let us down.

headline: Madison Keys, on Rackets and Mascara
abstract: Always bring extras, says Madison Keys. For the tennis player, that means extra rackets, extra bottles of hand sanitizer and, yes, emergency mascara.
lead_paragraph: This year has been a career-making one for the tennis player Madison Keys. She is ranked No. 11 in the world, won her second Women’s Tennis Association title in June, and will be competing at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Ms. Keys doesn’t do much vacationing, preferring to spend her limited time off with her family. When she does travel for pleasure, she isn’t the type to lounge around.

headline: A Three-Step Guide to Tipping on Vacation
abstract: Wondering how much to give your concierge? Your tour guide and driver? Here are some rules of thumb.
lead_paragraph: It’s a question that confounds even the most seasoned travelers: Just how much are you supposed to tip the staff during your hotel stay? And, what about tour guides and drivers? Also, the attendant looking after you on your cruise?

headline: Skinny and 119 Pounds, but With the Health Hallmarks of Obesity
abstract: A small group of thin patients who develop disorders typically tied to obesity pose a medical mystery and a potential opportunity for scientists.
lead_paragraph: Claire Walker Johnson of Queens was a medical mystery. No matter how much she ate, she never gained weight.

headline: Morning Agenda: Roger Ailes Is Out at Fox News; Rupert Murdoch Steps In
abstract: Goldman Sachs Raises a New Private Equity Fund | Continuing Debate Over the Financial Crisis
lead_paragraph: ROGER AILES IS OUT AT FOX NEWS; RUPERT MURDOCH STEPS IN An unsettling two weeks for Fox News has culminated with the ouster of its chairman and chief executive, Roger Ailes. Rupert Murdoch, the media mogul who started the company with Mr. Ailes, will be taking over in the interim, a move that signals there is not going to be an overhaul of the network. Fox News’s parent company, 21st Century Fox, had learned that Mr. Ailes was trying to get his on-air stars to criticize those who cooperated with investigators looking into accusations of sexual harassment against him.

headline: Learning to Scale Peaks From My Underprotective Mother
abstract: A parent’s job is often to keep children safe, to teach them to respect authority and stay out of trouble. Not my mom.
lead_paragraph: I grew up hearing stories of my mom’s grad school days at M.I.T. in the early ‘90s: pulling all-nighters in the Fishbowl, a cluster of computers off of the Infinite Corridor; writing messages to other Project Athena users on black screens with green text; sneaking through tunnels at night. Later, after dropping out, she gave birth to me.

headline: Pokémon Go, With a Corporate Tie-in, Debuts in Japan
abstract: The game’s availability, after millions of downloads elsewhere, was a national event. McDonald’s is being featured as a special game location.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Pikachu, Bulbasaur and other creatures of the Pokémon universe returned like conquering heroes to their home country on Friday, and they brought with them a message: Eat at McDonald’s.

headline: The Creative Life in Manila
abstract: Trying to find yourself in the big city.
lead_paragraph: I was 21 when I decided to quit university and help my boyfriend create an eco-village community on the island of Palawan. It was truly heartbreaking news for my parents. I grew up in a modest city called Cagayan de Oro, on the island Mindanao in the Philippines. When I was young, every night before bed my father would read to me a chapter of whatever book he was reading, and both my parents taught me to speak English at an early age. My dad used to say that because he didn’t have property or wealth to pass on to me, my education was the one thing he and mom could give me. So after I left school, I knew I was on my own.

headline: How to Breathe
abstract: Do it with purpose. Sit up straight.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t need special lungs or special techniques,” says Giora Feidman, 80, an Argentine-born Israeli clarinet player and klezmer musician who first blew into his father’s clarinet as a toddler. Feidman reckons the problem arises when people unlearn what they innately know. When you emerged from the womb, it’s very likely you instinctively drew oxygen deep into your lungs. You probably did not hunch over, draw your shoulders up to your ears or otherwise restrict your airflow.

headline: The World According to ‘BoJack Horseman’
abstract: The show’s creators have turned the travails of an anthropomorphic horse into a hilarious meditation on a peculiarly modern kind of unhappiness.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, Michael Eisner, the television executive and former chairman of the Walt Disney Company, found himself sitting next to Michael Bloomberg’s longtime girlfriend, Diana Taylor, at a dinner in Aspen, Colo. At the time, Bloomberg was contemplating a third-party bid for the presidency. Eisner, who has never been shy about sharing his views, relayed two stories to Taylor he thought would help Bloomberg as he grappled with no longer being in charge of America’s most important city.

headline: Climbing Down the Corporate Ladder Without Alarming Your Boss
abstract: We are conditioned to seek positions of more responsibility, which is why a request to step back and take a junior role may require careful framing.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: The 7.10.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: DRUG TESTING

headline: After the Dragonflies
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Lisa Borders of the W.N.B.A.: It’s Impossible to Refute Results
abstract: Ms. Borders, president of the W.N.B.A., says she focuses on tangible outcomes because doing so allows her to rise above others’ good or bad opinions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Lisa Borders, president of the W.N.B.A., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Republicans and Democrats in Congress Speak in Completely Different Languages
abstract: Three economists parsed 136 years of transcripts of congressional speeches and found a significant rise in polarization of language.
lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats aren’t just polarized on policy. To an unprecedented degree, they also speak different languages.

abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz
