abstract: Our 10-week-long Summer Reading Contest is now half over, but by posting here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 29, you can enter for Week 6.
lead_paragraph: Update | Winners for this week have been announced.

headline: Search for Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet to Be Suspended
abstract: The hunt will be suspended if the plane isn’t found in the dwindling target zone, officials said, but it could be revived if new information emerged.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The countries leading the effort to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared two years ago with 239 people aboard, said Friday that they would suspend but not end the search if the missing plane was not found in the rapidly shrinking target area.

headline: Not Forgotten: Long Before Muhammad Ali, Another Cassius Clay Was Larger Than LIfe
abstract: The 19th-century scion of a slaveholding family became a belligerent emancipationist, globe-trotting statesman, unsparing duelist, early Republican and larger-than-life American eccentric.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century scion of a slaveholding family became a belligerent emancipationist, globe-trotting statesman, unsparing duelist, early Republican and larger-than-life American eccentric.

headline: Amid Broad Movement Against Police Abuse, Some Act on the Fringe
abstract: While the cause to curb police shootings of black people has drawn diverse groups of activists, a slice of them borrow tactics from past militant resistance in the nation.
lead_paragraph: As demonstrators flooded the streets of Baton Rouge, La., recently to protest the police killing of a black man there, about 15 men in black military fatigues broke off on their own. They marched toward the police station, three of them carrying AR-15 rifles.

headline: Deciding on the Consecrated Life, With the Help of Speed Dating
abstract: A teaching program at Notre Dame helps those agonizing over not whom to date but whether to answer a call to join the priesthood or a religious order.
lead_paragraph: NOTRE DAME, Ind. — As the seconds ticked away, the timekeeper cast her eyes across a student lounge on the Notre Dame campus here and announced it was time for the speed daters to change partners. So April Adalim, 24, got up and moved to a tall chair at a round table across from her newest suitor: a graying, bespectacled woman in a religious habit, Sister Theresa Sullivan of the Daughters of Charity.

headline: Justice Dept. Rejects Account of How Malaysia’s Leader Acquired Millions
abstract: The Justice Department complaint alleges that the money was stolen from a Malaysian government investment fund that Prime Minister Najib Razak oversaw.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A United States Justice Department complaint filed in federal court this week directly contradicts repeated assertions by the Malaysian prime minister, Najib Razak, about the origins and purpose of hundreds of millions of dollars that ended up in his personal bank accounts.

headline: Downing Street and British Foreign Office Do Battle, and the Fur Flies
abstract: Britain’s new prime minister had been in office barely a week when a skirmish broke out between Larry the Cat and his counterpart on Whitehall, Palmerston.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s new leader had been in office barely a week when a skirmish broke out between 10 Downing Street and the Foreign Office.

headline: Indian Air Force Plane With 29 Aboard Disappears
abstract: The plane, which is missing over the Indian Ocean, was carrying mostly service personnel, an official said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian Air Force plane with 29 people on board is missing over the Indian Ocean, officials said on Friday.

headline: Texas Rape Victim Was Jailed for Fear She Would Not Testify, Lawsuit Says
abstract: The suit against county officials says the woman was beaten by an inmate, punched by a guard and accidentally classified as a sexual assault suspect in the Harris County Jail.
lead_paragraph: A rape victim who was jailed in Texas for nearly a month because prosecutors feared she would not return to testify after having a mental breakdown on the stand has sued the Harris County district attorney’s office, county officials and jail employees.

headline: I Returned My Rental Car. Didn’t I?
abstract: The adventures of a man who had only a few hours to return his Hertz keys and couldn’t remember if he had even returned the vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Buy It With Cash, Mortgage It Later
abstract: Some who can swing it pay cash for a home upfront, then take out a loan afterward.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Corbisiero wanted a quick sale on his studio pied-à-terre in West Chelsea, as he planned to use a portion of the proceeds for his daughter’s looming college expenses.

headline: Ordering at Cafe Dizain
abstract: A dizain is an old French poem or stanza of 10 lines, each with eight to 10 syllables. These dizains celebrate the flood of coffees and teas at New York cafes.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Policing the G.O.P. Convention
abstract: The riots that so many expected to accompany the crowning of Donald J. Trump as the Republican presidential nominee in Cleveland did not materialize. Instead, the convention ended with relative calm.
lead_paragraph: The riots that so many expected to accompany the crowning of Donald J. Trump as the Republican presidential nominee in Cleveland did not materialize. Instead, the convention ended with relative calm.

headline: Why Insurance Companies Don’t Renew Policies
abstract: Insurance industry experts discuss the two big factors in deciding not to renew your policy: the size of a claim and the frequency of claims.
lead_paragraph: FOR the better part of a week last year, Nancy Wergeles searched her home in Weston, Conn., for the engagement ring her husband had given her 53 years before. They had had a string of health care aides in their home and were also putting their house on the market, so real estate agents had been coming through, too.

headline: Russia’s Paralympic Team Is Facing a Ban of Its Own
abstract: Olympic officials, meanwhile, said that in retesting urine samples from the 2008 Beijing Games and 2012 London Games, 23 more medalists were tainted.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s determination to use state-sponsored doping to dominate the medal haul at recent Olympic Games, as outlined by investigators, did not end there. The country wanted success at the Paralympics, too, and several of its athletes took banned substances to gain an advantage over other disabled competitors.

headline: Canadian Lawyer Uncovers a Doping Scheme, and Russian Anger
abstract: Richard McLaren laid the groundwork for a potential ban of Russian athletes from the Rio Games with a report on how Russian doping had tainted numerous competitions.
lead_paragraph: He wrote a report that has prompted demands by antidoping officials for Russia to be banned from next month’s Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. Russian officials have called him a liar and a part of a Western plot to denigrate their nation.

headline: Laying Bare the Trump Family’s Costume Designs in Cleveland
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s children and wife understood that their statements of support did not stop at the podium or the teleprompter. Offstage, they continued the narrative.
lead_paragraph: There they were Thursday night in Cleveland, arrayed onstage as confetti and red, white and blue balloons tumbled from the ceiling: the Trump family, resplendent for all to see, smiling and waving and standing around a little awkwardly, but mesmerizing in their consistent style. Rarely has one family looked so, well, coordinated. And well coordinated.

headline: 1966: Brooklyn Negro Boy Shot Dead
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: An 11-year-old boy is shot in Brooklyn in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — An 11-year-old Negro boy was shot dead in a Brooklyn slum district during the night and ten policemen were injured in street clashes between whites and Negroes. Nearly 1,000 police rushed into the area to head off an explosion of racial violence over the boy’s death. Some witnesses said he was shot by a sniper, others said he was fired on from a passing car. The killing came after angry Negroes stoned a group of whites who paraded through streets carrying banners reading ‘‘Long Live Jim Crow.’’

headline: Continents Split Up at the Same Speed Finger Nails Grow. And That’s Fast.
abstract: As the supercontinent Pangea broke apart, its pieces entered phases where they accelerated to speeds 20 times as fast as they were traveling before
lead_paragraph: Continents cruise in the slow lane.

headline: Do Puzzles and Do Something Positive
abstract: Want to solve puzzles and do something positive at the same time? Has Mike Selinker got a deal for you.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The evil geniuses at Lone Shark Games, captained in a very Jack Sparrow sort of way by Mike Selinker, have put together a puzzle project that is raising money for three worthy charities and, if you choose to contribute, the best part — are you sitting down for this? — is that you get loads of puzzles in return. And you can pay almost anything you want for them.

headline: Europe’s Continuing Shame
abstract: The E.U. has failed to develop a coherent plan to deal with the flow of people fleeing violence and persecution in the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: First came Britain’s decision to leave the European Union. Then the horrific attack in Nice, France, which killed 84 people. Then, on Friday, a shooting near a shopping mall in Munich, which the police are treating as a possible terrorist attack.

headline: I.M.F. Chief Faces Trial in France, Far From Duties in U.S.
abstract: The ruling, which will most likely require Christine Lagarde to spend more time away from her duties, threatens to overshadow her second term at the fund’s helm.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court ordered Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, on Friday to face a criminal trial on charges of negligence dating to her time as finance minister, threatening to overshadow her second term at the helm of the organization.

abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Mark Danner’s “Spiral: Trapped in the Forever War” and more.
lead_paragraph: Trapped in the Forever War

lead_paragraph: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

headline: Sci-Fi in Bulk
abstract: “The Big Book of Science Fiction” is nearly 1,200 pages of stories by the genre’s luminaries and lesser-known authors.
lead_paragraph: “The Big Book of Science Fiction” is exactly what it says it is, nearly 1,200 pages of stories by the genre’s luminaries, like H.G. Wells, Arthur C. Clarke and Ursula K. Le Guin, as well as ­lesser-known authors. Edited by the husband-and-wife team of Jeff and Ann VanderMeer, the anthology bills itself as the ­“Ultimate Collection.”

headline: Lazio Inches Closer to an Italian Soccer Title ... From 1915
abstract: An Italian committee is set to decide next month whether to award Lazio a championship title from the 1914-15 season, which was interrupted by the onset of World War I.
lead_paragraph: Lazio is closing in on the Italian soccer championship.

headline: A Fond Look Back at the International Jet Set in Old Shanghai
abstract: Taras Grescoe’s “Shanghai Grand” is a love song to “the wicked old Paris of the Orient.”
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI GRANDForbidden Love and International Intrigue in a Doomed WorldBy Taras GrescoeIllustrated. 455 pp. St. Martin’s Press. $28.99.

headline: Caught on Camera
abstract: Surveillance cameras capture what pets do when they think no one is watching.
lead_paragraph: Surveillance cameras capture what pets do when they think no one is watching.

headline: Ms. or Mrs.? It’s Up to You. As for Me, Just Call Me Spayd
abstract: If Melania Trump is a Ms. while Michelle Obama is a Mrs., does that mean The Times is up to something? Not really.
lead_paragraph: They don’t come in swarms but they land at a steady clip, these reader letters probing why The Times refers to some women as “Ms.” and others as “Mrs.” This week, readers were circling the convention coverage, suspicious as to why Donald Trump’s wife, Melania, was labeled “Ms.” Trump while the president’s wife, Michelle Obama, was deemed a “Mrs.” One person writing in suggested that whoever made this decision must have intended to disparage the Trump marriage.

headline: Reconsidering the Work of a Chinese Immigrant Writer of the 1930s
abstract: In “A Floating Chinaman,” Hua Hsu revisits a Chinese immigrant writer who could not surmount ethnocentrism and racism.
lead_paragraph: A FLOATING CHINAMANFantasy and Failure Across the PacificBy Hua Hsu276 pp. Harvard University Press. $29.95.

headline: Watching Brazil’s Rich: A Full-Time Job
abstract: Years of covering Brazil’s tycoons yield Alex Cuadros’s “Brazillionaires,” a collage of immense wealth and government corruption.
lead_paragraph: BRAZILLIONAIRESWealth, Power, Decadence, and Hope in an American CountryBy Alex Cuadros346 pp. Spiegel & Grau. $28.

headline: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
abstract: Bill Loehfelm’s “Let the Devil Out,” Joseph Finder’s “Guilty Minds” and more.
lead_paragraph: We first met Maureen Coughlin when Bill Loehfelm’s woman-of-steel protagonist was a cocktail waitress in Staten Island, and we got to know her better after she moved to New Orleans and became a police officer. Maureen is still on the right side of the law, if only barely, in LET THE DEVIL OUT (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26), which finds this volatile cop on her worst behavior, using her month of disciplinary probation to beat down men who stalk and attack women leaving bars alone at night. It’s the kind of after-hours vigilante work that’s gotten Maureen in trouble in the past. But “she was tougher now. Meaner. And she hoped she was smarter.” Well, maybe. But physical violence has become her raison d’être; in fact, the only time she feels safe is “when she was running and when she was chasing. And when she was hurting someone else.”

headline: Time-Traveling Poems Consider the Self in Its Many Guises
abstract: The poet Jana Prikryl’s debut, “The After Party,” elevates the everyday and nods to influences from the past.
lead_paragraph: THE AFTER PARTYPoemsBy Jana Prikryl112 pp. Tim Duggan Books. Paper, $15.

headline: A Novel Explores Tragedy’s Aftermath in a Colombian-American Family
abstract: For the family in Patricia Engel’s “The Veins of the Ocean,” the past infects the present when a violent act is repeated.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through Patricia Engel’s sumptuous second novel, Reina Castillo, a young woman fleeing the demons of her past, stands on the deck of a boat contemplating her first dive into open water. “Out here is where the ocean floor drops off,” one of her more experienced companions explains, pointing to the darkness all around. “Didn’t you notice how clear and light the water is when we’re closer to land? That’s because it’s not so deep. Then the ocean floor takes a big hit hundreds of feet down and you’re out here, in the blue.”

headline: A Debut Novel Traces a Woman’s Life in Solitude
abstract: The linked vignettes in Claire-Louise Bennett’s “Pond” trace the streaming thoughts of a solitary woman.
lead_paragraph: PONDBy Claire-Louise Bennett195 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.

headline: Outlaws Like a Good Book Too
abstract: Donald Ray Pollock’s “The Heavenly Table,” a raw, riotous satire set in the rural South of 1917, takes aim at literary snobbery.
lead_paragraph: THE HEAVENLY TABLEBy Donald Ray Pollock365 pp. Doubleday. $27.95.

headline: Jesse Ball’s New Novel Features a Teenage Arsonist
abstract: The unhappy protagonist of Jesse Ball’s “How to Set a Fire and Why” joins an “arson club.”
lead_paragraph: HOW TO SET A FIRE AND WHYBy Jesse Ball283 pp. Pantheon Books. $24.95.

headline: A Second Mississippi Novel by Brad Watson
abstract: Brad Watson’s “Miss Jane” imagines the ways a real woman with a birth defect insisted on her humanity in the old South.
lead_paragraph: MISS JANEBy Brad Watson284 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $25.95.

headline: A Novel of Egypt’s ‘Cheated Generation’
abstract: Yasmine El Rashidi’s “Chronicle of a Last Summer” is about a heroine’s path to adulthood during and after Mubarak.
lead_paragraph: CHRONICLE OF A LAST SUMMERBy Yasmine El Rashidi181 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $22.

headline: Secret Lives of Real Pets
abstract: In the post-privacy age, pet cams reveal the mystery of what Fido and Fluffy do when we’re not around.
lead_paragraph: The footage is grainy, randomly framed.

headline: Will Fear Strike Out?
abstract: Things aren’t bad, but will people vote as if they are?
lead_paragraph: If you want to feel good about the state of America, you could do a lot worse than what I did this morning: take a run in Riverside Park. There are people of all ages, and, yes, all races exercising, strolling hand in hand, playing with their dogs, kicking soccer balls and throwing Frisbees. There are a few homeless people, but the overall atmosphere is friendly – New Yorkers tend to be rushed, but they’re not nasty – and, well, nice.

headline: Dignity in Death for Black Families at a Brooklyn Funeral Home
abstract: Two sisters in Brooklyn help black residents whose families have been shattered by violence navigate their most painful moments.
lead_paragraph: Before he could even talk, A’mani Miller worked as a model. As early as 2 years old, he graced billboards and magazine pages, walnut-brown eyes squinting above a wide smile. Family and friends took to calling him “Mado,” mimicking the way his relatives from the Caribbean said the name of his profession. So his mother, Allison Shinn, found it a particularly cruel irony that when Mr. Miller was murdered at 23, his killer had left him nearly unrecognizable.

headline: 1916: German Food Riots Increasing
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Food riots increase in Germany in July 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every day there are fresh indications that the internal situation in Germany is steadily growing worse, and food troubles are becoming more and more acute throughout the empire. A despatch from Geneva says that it is learned from Berlin that Herr von Batocki, the German food dictator, has resigned and that he was immediately replaced by Herr von Berg. A subsequent message from Amsterdam states, however, that he has merely resigned his position as High President of Eastern Prussia and that he still retains office as food dictator.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Daniel Silva’s “The Black Widow,” No. 1 in hardcover fiction, opens with an ISIS bombing in Paris. “I wrote this book as a warning about what was coming,” Silva says.
lead_paragraph: Too Real: To a certain kind of thriller writer, current events are catnip. Take Daniel Silva, whose novel “The Black Widow” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. You and I might be duly terrorized by terrorism, but Silva — whose series hero is the art restorer and Israeli spy Gabriel Allon — is tantalized. So “The Black Widow” opens with ISIS bombings in Paris and Amsterdam that inevitably call to mind actual attacks carried out since last fall in France and northern Europe. Yet any similarities, Silva notes in a foreword, are coincidental. “I commenced work on this novel before the Islamic terrorist group known as ISIS carried out a wave of shootings and bombings in Paris and Brussels that left more than 160 people dead,” he writes. “After briefly considering setting aside the typescript, I chose to complete it as originally conceived. . . . I take no pride in my prescience. I only wish that the murderous, millenarian terrorism of the Islamic State lived solely on the pages of this story.”

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Celebrate Edward Hopper’s birthday with some peach recipes.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Another Word for ‘Illegal Alien’ at the Library of Congress: Contentious
abstract: A decision by the library to drop the term, at a time when immigration has become a big topic, has ignited an angry response from conservative lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Melissa Padilla was doing research on immigration in her university library at Dartmouth College when she noticed the term “illegal aliens” popping up again and again. The more she saw it, the angrier she became.

headline: Verizon Is Said to Be Near a Deal to Acquire Yahoo
abstract: Verizon has long been considered a front-runner to buy Yahoo’s core internet businesses. An announcement could come as early as next week.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The end of Yahoo as an independent company may be near, and Verizon — long considered the leading contender to buy the aging web pioneer — is the most likely acquirer.

headline: The Demographics Behind #InternsSoWhite
abstract: A photo of Paul Ryan with interns made some people sit up and ask: Why doesn’t this picture look more like America?
lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House, recently shared a selfie on Instagram, with dozens of congressional interns in the background. The picture was quickly shared on the internet, drawing comments about the lack of diversity in the group, culminating in the derisive hashtag #InternsSoWhite.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘We Are Not Such Things’
abstract: This week, Justine van der Leun talks about “We Are Not Such Things”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; David Goldblatt discusses “The Games: A Global History of the Olympics”; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Justine van der Leun talks about “We Are Not Such Things”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; David Goldblatt discusses “The Games: A Global History of the Olympics”; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘We Are Not Such Things’
abstract: Justine van der Leun talks about “We Are Not Such Things”; and David Goldblatt discusses “The Games: A Global History of the Olympics.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Texas Investigates Violent Traffic Arrest of Black Teacher
abstract: Videos show a white officer throwing the teacher to the ground and another telling her that whites may be wary of black people because of their “violent tendencies.”
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Austin, Tex., were investigating a year-old traffic encounter in which a black female driver was dragged from her car and thrown to the ground twice by a white police officer.

headline: Donald Trump Basks in Convention ‘Love’ (but Has None for Ted Cruz)
abstract: After bragging that he had unified Republicans in one of the most “love-filled” conventions in history, the nominee went on an extended diatribe against his primary rival.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump lashed out at Senator Ted Cruz on Friday, rehashing a long list of grievances from their primary battle during a news conference here only hours after he accepted the Republican Party’s presidential nomination at a convention meant to unite the party.

headline: Donald Trump and the Limits of the Improv Campaign
abstract: Donald J. Trump had some good moments at his convention, but there were signs that his seat-of-the-pants style may be failing him.
lead_paragraph: Abroad in America, written by a Times foreign correspondent, approaches the election in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.

headline: Sports Reporter Cries Foul When Own Son’s Youth League Is Bilked
abstract: When another youth sports volunteer, in an adjacent town, was convicted of pocketing almost $35,000, “I suspected it was not just happening in my backyard.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Bill Pennington, a Times sports reporter, recalls how his continuing, far-reaching investigative series on trusted adults who steal millions from youth sports unfolded.

headline: Is China Stealing Jobs? It May Be Losing Them, Instead
abstract: With a slowing domestic economy, rising costs and stiffer foreign competition, China’s laborers are losing jobs, including to the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Throughout his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump has claimed that China is stealing American manufacturing jobs.

headline: If a $2 Trillion Saudi Aramco Goes Public, Will It Withstand Outsider Scrutiny?
abstract: The company will need to elevate its governance practices to retain the support of Western institutional investors.
lead_paragraph: Simon C. Y. Wong is an independent adviser affiliated with Northwestern University and London School of Economics and Political Science.

headline: An Olympic Odyssey: Where the Games Began
abstract: A road trip in Greece back in time nearly 3,000 years to the precursors of the modern Olympic Games. Plato sweated here.
lead_paragraph: Some dream of going to the Olympics. I’d long dreamed of going to Olympia. I wanted to take a solo road trip like no other, searching for the four sites of the ancient Greek athletic games — Isthmia, Nemea, Delphi and Olympia — precursors to the Olympics spectacle opening in Rio on Aug. 5.

headline: Skipping Out on the Sizzling Heat
abstract: A new club is offering people who can’t handle high temperatures (and lack a second home) the opportunity to spend weekends at a well-appointed house out of the city with strangers.
lead_paragraph: Chances are that if you are reading this in or near New York City now, meaning sometime between the 22nd and 26th day of the seventh month of the 17th year of the 21st century, you are very hot. You are almost assuredly irritated as well as hot, because as Samantha Gillison recently put it in a column in The Guardian, explaining New York summers to those fortunate enough to spend them in London, “Being confronted by your own cosmic insignificance as you struggle through an inferno to get to your dumb job can be a deeply unpleasant sensation.”

headline: What the Emmys Got Right ... And Wrong
abstract: The television critics James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger evaluate the 2016 Primetime Emmy nominations.
lead_paragraph: The television critics James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger evaluate the 2016 Primetime Emmy nominations.

headline: A Park Avenue Duplex for More Than $17.6 Million
abstract: A sprawling home in a limestone condominium developed by Toll Brothers City Living was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling duplex at 1110 Park Avenue, a nine-unit limestone condominium in Carnegie Hill developed by Toll Brothers City Living, sold for $17,615,815.62 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to property records.

headline: Make Vibrant Mezze the Whole Meal
abstract: These Middle Eastern and Mediterranean small plates are a brilliant solution for summertime dining.
lead_paragraph: A bowl of olives, a burnished slice of roasted feta cheese, a smoky eggplant dip, perhaps some lemony stuffed grape leaves or a plate of creamy hummus: These are all mezze, tapas-like appetizers that are served at room temperature, meant to accompany drinks and conversation.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

headline: Gorbachev Letter to the I.O.C.
abstract: Mikhail Gorbachev sent a letter to Thomas Bach and the International Olympic Committee on Russia's behalf.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Gorbachev sent a letter to Thomas Bach and the International Olympic Committee on Russia's behalf.

headline: At the Hudson River Museum, Art With an Inflated Sense of Itself
abstract: The artist Jimmy Kuehnle once created pieces from old cathode-ray tube monitors. Now his pieces are light as air.
lead_paragraph: The artwork created by Jimmy Kuehnle literally fills a gallery at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, pressing against walls, spilling over a railing and nearly obstructing passage. Outside, bulbous forms engulf the entrance’s austere geometric archway with what resembles two colossal lapping tongues, and they encircle the limestone tower of Glenview, the Victorian mansion on the museum grounds.

headline: U.S. Says Florida Network Defrauded Medicare and Medicaid of Over $1 Billion
abstract: Federal prosecutors charged three people, saying a scheme at a network of nursing and assisted-living facilities operated over a period of 14 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the biggest health care fraud case the Justice Department has ever brought, prosecutors charged on Friday that the owner of a network of Florida nursing facilities orchestrated an elaborate scheme to defraud Medicare and Medicaid of more than $1 billion over the last 14 years.

headline: The Playlist: Miranda Lambert Bounces Back and Michelle Obama Sings the Hits
abstract: Our pop critics on the week’s nine most notable new tracks, from Sleigh Bells’ “Hyper Dark” to Wilco’s “If I Ever Was a Child.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in the Playlist. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: How the Rich Are Hurting the Museums They Fund
abstract: Wealthy patrons like to pay for flashy new buildings but not for upkeep.
lead_paragraph: THE recent announcement of a wrenching round of layoffs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has sent a shiver through the museum world. Yet as recently as March, the Met seemed to be on a roll, when it opened a flashy contemporary art annex, the Met Breuer.

headline: Matthew Gerald, Officer Killed in Baton Rouge, Is Honored at His Funeral
abstract: Officer Gerald, 41, a military veteran, was remembered as a man whose decision to join the Baton Rouge Police Department renewed his sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Family, friends and close comrades came Friday to pay their last respects to Matthew Gerald, a 41-year-old rookie police officer and one of three officers slain by a gunman who was targeting the police.

headline: James Schamus, a Hollywood Honcho, Takes on Directing
abstract: Mr. Schamus, who ran Focus Features for years, is trying his hand at directing with “Indignation,” an adaptation of a Philip Roth novel.
lead_paragraph: After James Schamus was fired in 2013 from his job running Focus Features, where, over the course of nearly a dozen years, he had brought to the screen such indie gems as “Brokeback Mountain,” “Lost in Translation” and “Milk,” he vowed to take it easy, and more or less failed.

headline: The Quiet Comeback of Reverse Mortgages
abstract: Some retirees are using reverse mortgages, once unpopular after years of lending abuses, to supplement income sources or to finance long-term care.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Peter and Joyce Hill wanted to buy a home in a community for people 55 and older in an area they had always admired in Lancaster County, Pa., they used a reverse mortgage to finance building in that development.

headline: Crunchy Berry Almond Crumble
abstract: Fresh summer berries and slivered almonds elevate this classic crispy crumble recipe.
lead_paragraph: Fresh summer berries and slivered almonds elevate this classic crispy crumble recipe.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Grim First: New York City Reports Baby Born With a Zika-Related Defect
abstract: Health officials on Friday reported a baby born with microcephaly, a Zika-related condition marked by an abnormally small head and impaired brain development.
lead_paragraph: Health officials on Friday reported the first baby born in New York City with the Zika-related birth defect known as microcephaly, a condition marked by an abnormally small head and impaired brain development.

headline: G-Rough, a Roman Hotel Both Refined and Rugged
abstract: A boutique hotel in a 17th-century palazzo has a sense of place and style.
lead_paragraph: Rooms from 400 euros (high season), about $441.

headline: Music Festival to Celebrate Newark’s 350-Year History
abstract: A series of cultural events pays tribute to a major anniversary for New Jersey’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Dupré Kelly has had plenty of triumphs in his career, but the 45-year-old never thought that hosting a music festival in Newark, his hometown, would be one of them.

headline: At Kali in Los Angeles, California Cuisine Without the Pretension
abstract: The menu at Kali skirts preciousness in favor of seriously beautiful food.
lead_paragraph: The theory of creative limitation states that by proposing constraints upon a project or an idea, one gains the freedom to become more creative within those constraints. In the case of Kali, a restaurant in the Larchmont neighborhood of Los Angeles that opened in January, that limit is the border that divides California from the rest of the country. Within that fortunate constraint, the partners Kevin Meehan and Drew Langley have constructed a world as colorful, complex and wild as the Golden State itself.

headline: Gunman in Munich Kills 9, Then Himself, the Police Say
abstract: The police said the attack outside a mall was probably the work of a single gunman. At least 21 people were wounded.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — A gunman opened fire outside a shopping mall in Munich late on Friday afternoon, killing nine people, wounding 21 and sending Germany’s third-largest city into lockdown as the police scrambled to find what they initially thought were as many as three assailants.

headline: Gary Erbe Tricks the Eye With a Dose of Pop Culture
abstract: Works on display at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington can provide a delightful summer diversion, especially if you are into contemporary trompe l’oeil.
lead_paragraph: “Master of Illusion: The Magical Art of Gary Erbe,” now on display at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, can provide a delightful summer diversion, especially if you are into contemporary trompe l’oeil.

headline: The Grief That White Americans Can’t Share
abstract: For our white friends and colleagues, police shootings are a tragedy in the abstract. For black people, they’re agonizingly personal — and devastating.
lead_paragraph: The last thing I thought about when I closed my eyes that Wednesday night, July 6, was the bullet tearing into the flesh of Alton Sterling as he lay pinned to the ground beneath two Baton Rouge police officers. I couldn’t get Mr. Sterling’s face out of my head — his chestnut skin and gold teeth reminding me of my own uncles. The swiftness with which his life was taken, broadcast on a loop like so many others over the last few years, had shaken me. I slept a restless sleep.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘BoJack Horseman’ and ‘Looking: The Movie’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Lisa Yuskavage
abstract: The artist shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the artist Lisa Yuskavage, who shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: With Roger Ailes Out, Will Fox News’s Influence on Politics Change?
abstract: In its 20 years, the network has provided a path for Republican politicians and candidates to raise issues, set agendas and shape opinions.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Donald J. Trump wanted to proclaim his doubts about President Obama’s birth certificate, he went to Fox News.

headline: How Fox News’s Influence Grew Under Roger Ailes
abstract: The network’s pugnacious style and its position as a platform for conservative politics and ideas made it a hit with an audience that felt ill-served by other news outlets.
lead_paragraph: Fox News has been the highest-rated cable news network for 15 years, making it a source of immense profit for its parent company, 21st Century Fox. It is a significant voice in national politics and, with its extensive use of graphics and its comfort with editorializing, a major influence on its competitors.

headline: Angel Food Cake, an Airy Bed for Summer Fruit
abstract: There’s a trick to making this light, versatile classic.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I was at a dinner party at which the host served angel food cake with berries for dessert. “I always buy angel food cake when I entertain,” he told me. “It’s so light, and you can serve anything with it.” And, I think, he liked having the leftovers to snack on during the week.

headline: African Tribesmen Can Talk Birds Into Helping Them Find Honey
abstract: Tribesmen and honeyguides share an ancient pact and communicate in trills and grunts, scientists report. The shared goal: beehives full of honey and wax.
lead_paragraph: Their word is their bond, and they do what they say — even if the “word” on one side is a loud trill and grunt, and, on the other, the excited twitterings of a bird.

headline: Obama Rejects Donald Trump’s Vision of America
abstract: The president said that the nation was not on the verge of collapse and that violent crime and unauthorized immigration were at the lowest levels in decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday rejected what he described as Donald J. Trump’s vision of America as a nation “on the verge of collapse,” and he disputed the Republican presidential nominee’s assertion that the United States was being inundated with illegal immigrants.

headline: Dennis Green, Pioneering Coach of the Vikings and the Cardinals, Dies at 67
abstract: Green was only the second black head coach in the modern era of the N.F.L. when he took over at Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Green, a pioneering head coach who led the Vikings to a consistent run of excellence in the 1990s, died on Thursday. He was 67.

headline: Keegan-Michael Key and Mike Birbiglia Take Pizza and Obama Imitations Seriously
abstract: The comedians and stars of the new film “Don’t Think Twice” take in some improv ... then some calories.
lead_paragraph: Mike Birbiglia and Keegan-Michael Key were laughing — hard.

headline: Musing on Meat as Two Bulls Enjoy Brief Pre-Slaughter Freedom
abstract: Some meaty thoughts arise as two bulls bound for a slaughterhouse briefly roamed West Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: A news blip from West Baltimore caught my attention. Two bulls briefly escaped an urban slaughterhouse and had a quiet moment grazing a neatly mowed lawn near an apartment complex before police cordoned them off and they were recaptured.

headline: How to Join the Political Party in Philadelphia
abstract: Philadelphia is hosting the Democratic National Convention this month, and caucus meetings and watch parties will be open to the public (a happy hour too).
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention, where the official candidates for president and vice president are confirmed, will be held in Philadelphia from July 25 to 28 at the Wells Fargo Center. Though the city was host to the Republican National Convention in 2000, there hasn’t been a Democratic convention in Philadelphia since 1948.

headline: Luciano Pavarotti’s Family Wants Him Off Donald Trump’s Soundtrack
abstract: Pavarotti’s widow and daughters have asked the campaign to stop using his music, saying that Pavarotti’s values are incompatible with Trump’s worldview.
lead_paragraph: It is not just rockers who are objecting to the use of their songs by Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee. Now the family of the tenor Luciano Pavarotti, who died in 2007, is protesting the Trump campaign’s use of his recording of Puccini’s aria “Nessun Dorma.”

headline: David Duke, Ex-K.K.K. Leader, to Seek Senate Seat in Louisiana
abstract: Mr. Duke is running as a Republican and trying to capitalize on a history of inflammatory speech and on the presidential campaign of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: David Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan, embarked on a campaign on Friday to seek a United States Senate seat as a Republican in Louisiana, where he will try to capitalize on his history of inflammatory speech and on the presidential campaign of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Dick Bellamy: The Man Hiding at the Center of Everything
abstract: An art dealer and, more important, a free spirit, Bellamy was a quiet catalyst behind the art of the ’60s.
lead_paragraph: He was slight and unassuming with a bushy mop of dark hair and deep circles under his eyes hinting at the alcoholic dissipation of a poète maudit. His voice was a suggestive murmur, both musical and raspy from smoking too much. Most people called him Dick. To friends he would announce himself as George, a mannerism dating back to when he and his father addressed each other as “George” and “Lennie,” after characters in Steinbeck’s Depression novel “Of Mice and Men.”

headline: Police Investigating Deadly Munich ‘Shooting Rampage’
abstract: Police said they were investigating if one of the nine dead may have been involved in the attack outside a shopping mall in Munich on Friday. The authorities said they were treating the shooting as a possible terrorist act.

headline: The Olympics Will Be a Boon for Rio, the Mayor Says
abstract: Answering criticisms, Rio’s mayor says the Games will be a success and “have been an opportunity to attract investments and improve citizens’ lives.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What I Love | Linda Emond
abstract: The actress has long lived in a tiny studio on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The actress has long lived in a tiny studio on the Upper East Side.

headline: A Big Life in a Tiny Home
abstract: How the actress Linda Emond made the most of her 200-square-foot studio on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The actress Linda Emond moved to New York in the mid-90s with few possessions and no idea where she wanted to drop anchor.

headline: A Trip Through Time, With a ’60s Sound
abstract: “The Bikinis” takes baby boomers back to the days of girl groups and beach-party movies.
lead_paragraph: It may look like a trailer park, but in New Jersey they call Sandy Shores a “mobile home beach resort.” A developer is offering the residents $250,000 each to clear out and make way for luxury condos. Another episode in the business history of Donald J. Trump? Another chapter in the still-unfolding aftermath of Hurricane Sandy? No, just the fragile pretext for another mostly jukebox musical, “The Bikinis,” taking baby boomers back to the girl groups and beach-party movies of the 1960s, with second-act excursions to the protest songs and disco music of the ’70s and ’80s.

headline: As Dallas Sniper Prowled, Quick Decisions and Life-Altering Consequences
abstract: Amid the chaos of gunfire, there was confusion akin to the fog of war, improvisation under fire and acts of bravery to shield loved ones and strangers alike.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Officer Patrick Zamarripa was down.

headline: Fancy Swimming Pools as Building Perks
abstract: Pools in some new apartment buildings have been elevated from their usual basement locations or embellished with high-end finishes.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who slog on the subway to Rockaway for a dip in the ocean, or sit in traffic en route to weekend houses by the water, the idea of having a pool in our apartment buildings might sound like the ultimate luxury. Simply push an elevator button and, moments later, dive in.

headline: A Tribute to the South Bronx
abstract: Edwin J. Torres, a child of Hunts Point, has been photographing the human pageant of his borough ever since he decided in college that there was no place like home.
lead_paragraph: Edwin J. Torres, a child of Hunts Point, has been photographing the human pageant of his borough ever since he decided in college that there was no place like home.

headline: Paying Tribute to the Bronx
abstract: Edwin J. Torres realized while away at college that there was no place like his home borough, and he has spent years documenting it.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Edwin J. Torres first really saw the Bronx when he left it. A child of the Hunts Point neighborhood, he went to Colby College in Maine, and when he rode the train home for spring break in his freshman year, his eyes opened to the incredible human pageant he had been missing. “I saw this African lady with her four kids, all in traditional clothing, and I thought, my God, this is so beautiful,” he said. “Everything was coming to life around me.”

headline: Deadly Shooting at Munich Mall
abstract: A gunman opened fire at the Olympia-Einkaufszentrum mall in Munich on Friday, killing several people and wounding others. “It is not clear whether is one or many shooters,” a police spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire at the Olympia-Einkaufszentrum mall in Munich on Friday, killing several people and wounding others. “It is not clear whether is one or many shooters,” a police spokesman said.

headline: What Happened in the Shootings in Munich
abstract: Maps and timeline of the events according to the German police.
lead_paragraph: Maps and timeline of the events according to the German police.

headline: Review: Scratch Cooking at Agostino’s in New Rochelle
abstract: Agostino’s offers an array of pastas from an area in Italy particularly admired for it.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in a corner of New Rochelle, Agostino’s, an unpretentious neighborhood restaurant, has been serving fine Italian food for more than a decade. Its simple hospitality and scratch regional cooking have attracted not only locals but also boaters and golfers from the marinas and country clubs nearby. They don’t make many Italian restaurants of this quality anymore, and more’s the pity.

headline: Violent Arrest of Black Teacher
abstract: Video released by the Austin Police Department at a news conference on Thursday shows how the violent arrest of a black teacher unfolded last year. The authorities are investigating the episode.
lead_paragraph: Video released by the Austin Police Department at a news conference on Thursday shows how the violent arrest of a black teacher unfolded last year. The authorities are investigating the episode.

headline: Donald Trump’s Journey: From Crashing a Party to Controlling Its Future
abstract: It is hard to imagine the Republican Party returning anytime soon to being the party of free trade, democracy building and at least modest immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump and the army of voters he brought into politics, overpowering all attempts at dissent, have pushed through fundamental changes in the Republican Party, many of which seem likely to endure whether or not he wins the White House in November.

headline: Of Countertenors, Medieval Poetry and Capturing a Silvery Tone
abstract: Mr. Benjamin, who wrote the opera “Written on Skin,” talks about his latest work, “Dream of a Song,” which has its American premiere at Tanglewood.
lead_paragraph: What do you write after you write your masterpiece?

headline: Cabana Boys, a Queens Throwback, Hustle for Big Tips and Bigger Dreams
abstract: At the Silver Gull Beach Club, the workers who carry members’ beach gear and fetch their drinks work hard, smile nonstop and hope it all pays off.
lead_paragraph: Sunday is “split day,” or payday, for Matt Goldman and his crew of cabana boys at the Silver Gull Beach Club.

headline: Chappatte on Hesitant Hillary Supporters
abstract: I’m with ... her?
lead_paragraph: I’m with ... her?

headline: Review: Bar Sugo’s Seriously Italian Menu Goes Beyond the Sauce
abstract: Bar Sugo in Norwalk is a place for people who know that Italian food is much more than spaghetti and red gravy.
lead_paragraph: What makes Bar Sugo special among the Italian places in Norwalk is its chef’s creativity, its two dozen small plates (plus half a dozen pizzas), and a focus on farm-to-table fare.

headline: Street Style: The Republican National Convention
abstract: Delegates represent their states in distinctive style in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Delegates represent their states in distinctive style in Cleveland.

headline: Review: Le Dock in Fair Harbor, a Flavorful Encores From Jean-Georges
abstract: Owned by the French chef’s longtime business partner since 1976, the restaurant reopened on Memorial day weekend.
lead_paragraph: Stepping off the Fire Island ferry at Fair Harbor on a recent sunny afternoon was like stepping back in time. A young boy operated a lemonade stand from a red wagon on the boardwalk as his parents, tan and beach-casual, ate ice cream cones and watched the Great South Bay stretch to the horizon.

headline: Peter Thiel’s Heroic Political Fantasies
abstract: If the Silicon Valley tycoon shares anything with Donald Trump, it is a disappointment with small politics — and small people.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Peter Thiel gave a lecture series at Stanford that was later collected, lightly edited and published as a book titled “Zero to One: Notes on Start-ups, or How to Build the Future.” Mark Zuckerberg, an early beneficiary of Thiel’s largess as a venture capitalist, contributed an endorsement. “This book,” his blurb on the flap reads, “delivers completely new and refreshing ideas on how to create value in the world.”

headline: How Does This Garden Grow? To the Ceiling
abstract: Food produced by the high-tech, indoor farming facilities of AeroFarms is winning over even the toughest critics.
lead_paragraph: Steven Yglesias, owner of the popular tapas restaurant Mompou in Newark’s Ironbound neighborhood, knows his customers are food-savvy enough to want dishes made from the freshest local ingredients.

headline: A One-Man Show About Jack Lemmon, Performed by His Son
abstract: Chris Lemmon brings a story born out a “search for catharsis” about the man he called Pop to the Cinema Arts Center on July 28.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Lemmon, the Oscar-winning actor, died of cancer at age 76 in 2001, his son, Chris, began writing down memories of the complex man he called Pop. This “search for catharsis,” as he describes it, coalesced in a 2006 memoir, “A Twist of Lemmon: A Tribute to My Father,” and eventually, a one-man stage performance that developed over the course of a decade.

headline: Why Donald Trump’s Tactic on Crime May Not Meet Nixon’s Success
abstract: Concern about crime is concentrated among Donald Trump’s base of non-college whites; it’s not clear the issue has broad appeal.
lead_paragraph: In declaring himself “the law and order candidate” in his convention speech Thursday night, Donald Trump officially made crime one of his core issues. This emphasis is relatively new, and it’s strategic.

headline: Marvel’s World of Wakanda Will Spotlight Women, on the Page and Behind It
abstract: This new series will feature the feminist writer Roxane Gay and the poet Yona Harvey, who will join Ta-Nehisi Coates to create spinoff Black Panther narratives.
lead_paragraph: The world of the Black Panther, the Marvel Comics hero who hails from the fictional African country of Wakanda, is about to get bigger. Marvel announced on Friday a companion series, World of Wakanda, which is to premiere in November.

headline: Japan and Peru on the Same Menu
abstract: How two chefs went about creating a menu for a 190-seat Nikkei restaurant opening in Midtown Manhattan this fall.
lead_paragraph: It takes some people a long time to choose a dish from a menu. It takes chefs a much longer time to develop one. Mina Newman and Taku Nagai have been at it for two years.

headline: Nathan’s Famous, a Hot Dog Empire Built on Hard Work and Hype
abstract: Two books, published to coincide with the centennial of Nathan’s Famous by members of his family’s third generation, largely debunk a stubborn if serviceable legend.
lead_paragraph: By most accounts, Coney Island’s annual Fourth of July Hot Dog Eating Contest, perhaps the world’s most regularly celebrated display of gluttony, traces its origins to a rivalry among immigrants a century ago, which just happened to be the year that Nathan Handwerker opened his frankfurter stand on Stillwell Avenue.

headline: The Double Life of the Slimy, Acrobatic Leopard Slug
abstract: Leopard slugs, a hermaphroditic gastropod commonly found under a wide variety of boards rocks and flowerpots in New York City, has a mating ritual that would make Caligula blush.
lead_paragraph: The leopard slug is about as beautiful as a slimy garden pest can be, and at nearly five inches long, is impressive if not quite lovely. An import originally native to southern Europe, it has easily adapted to life in North America, and, much to the horror of gardeners and squeamish 5-year-olds, it is common under a wide variety of boards, rocks and flowerpots in New York City.

headline: Sex in the Nursing Home
abstract: A sociology professor asks, “Why shouldn’t we be sexually active throughout our lives?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Black Lives Matter’ Banner on City Hall Divides a Boston Suburb
abstract: Tensions rose in Somerville, Mass., this week after the mayor denied the police union’s request to replace the banner with one reading, “All Lives Matter.”
lead_paragraph: In a summer marked by racial tensions, the latest debate has surfaced in a Boston suburb, where residents are divided over the mayor’s refusal to remove a “#BlackLivesMatter” banner that has hung for nearly a year at the town’s city hall.

headline: Chasing Waldorf’s History as It Becomes History Itself
abstract: The 123-year-old Waldorf Astoria is one of the few hotels with an extensive archive, but its future is unclear as the hotel is closing in the spring to undergo a condominium conversion.
lead_paragraph: The Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan is known for its grand public spaces, such as its two-tiered ballroom and vast lobby. But upstairs, in a windowless corner of the hotel’s administrative offices, Deidre Dinnigan toils in a cramped room not much larger than a closet. Ms. Dinnigan, the hotel’s archivist, is responsible for cataloging and researching more than 4,000 objects, from filigreed brass room numbers to yellowing advertisements from the 1950s.

headline: How Denis Leary of ‘Sex&Drugs&Rock&Roll’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: The actor and producer Mr. Leary rises early, catches up with his adult children over brunch and strolls the empty summer streets of TriBeCa.
lead_paragraph: Denis Leary, the actor and producer whose show “Sex&Drugs&Rock&Roll” recently began its second season on the FX network, has an urban persona (and, after playing a New York City firefighter in the series “Rescue Me,” a distinctly local one, too). In real life, Mr. Leary, 58, lives in Roxbury, Conn., with his wife, the novelist Ann Leary, and their three horses and three dogs. On weekends, the couple often heads into New York while others flee, to relax at their TriBeCa apartment and to see their children Jack, 26, and Devin, 24.

headline: Day After R.N.C. Ends, Hillary Clinton Presents Herself as the Anti-Trump
abstract: In her first campaign event after Donald Trump accepted his party’s nomination, Mrs. Clinton met with relatives of the victims in the Orlando nightclub shooting.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Dystopic. Hard to watch. Terrifying.

headline: Summer Travel and the Zika Virus
abstract: Travelers are headed to the Olympics and other destinations where mosquitoes are carrying the infection. Here’s what they should know.
lead_paragraph: Health officials have warned pregnant women to avoid travel to the more than 45 countries and territories in which the Zika virus is circulating. Infection during pregnancy can lead to birth defects in infants, particularly brain damage and abnormally small heads, called microcephaly.

headline: Fact Check: The Republican Convention
abstract: A look at how some of the claims made by Donald J. Trump and other speakers hold up.
lead_paragraph: A look at how some of the claims made by Donald J. Trump and other speakers hold up.

headline: Changing Takeover Laws and the ExamWorks Deal
abstract: A recent case will shape how the ExamWorks case unfolds and also chart a path for the future of merger litigation.
lead_paragraph: The ExamWorks Group buyout and related lawsuit shows how changing takeover laws are steering shareholders toward more appraisal actions and making deals riskier for buyers.

headline: Popcast: Dissecting the Legacy of Alan Vega and Suicide
abstract: Days after Mr. Vega’s death, the journalist Geeta Dayal discusses Suicide’s early days.
lead_paragraph: Days after Mr. Vega’s death, the journalist Geeta Dayal discusses Suicide’s early days.

headline: Failed Turkish Coup Accelerated a Purge Years in the Making
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whose officials had compiled lists of those with questionable loyalties, has labeled many civil servants as potential enemies of the state.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Night had fallen and the weekend had begun, but the head of Turkey’s spy agency remained at work in the main security compound in Ankara, struggling to track reports of strange military activities across the country.

headline: The Finale: Donald Trump’s Fiery Speech
abstract: “Now he wants us to believe that he is suddenly compassionate and will do everything to help the poor and disadvantaged,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Zapping Their Brains at Home
abstract: The surprisingly astute world of do-it-yourself neural stimulation.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, in the journal Annals of Neurology, four neuroscientists published an open letter to practitioners of do-it-yourself brain stimulation. These are people who stimulate their own brains with low levels of electricity, largely for purposes like improved memory or learning ability. The letter, which was signed by 39 other researchers, outlined what is known and unknown about the safety of such noninvasive brain stimulation, and asked users to give careful consideration to the risks.

headline: Popcast: Dissecting the Legacy of Alan Vega and Suicide
abstract: Days after Mr. Vega’s death, the journalist Geeta Dayal discusses Suicide’s early days in the ’70s and other sounds from that period.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

headline: On the Convention Floor, Cowboy Hats and Trump Caps Were the Uniform
abstract: Republican delegates in Cleveland blended support for their nominee with tributes to their home states.
lead_paragraph: Delegates at the Republican National Convention represented their states with distinctive badges, and many showed support for Donald J. Trump, the party’s presidential nominee, by wearing “Make America Great Again” hats.

headline: What Does Donald Trump Mean to You?
abstract: Everyone in Cleveland this week had something to say about the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was impossible to look around Cleveland and not see the word “Trump” plastered over everything in sight: on billboards, on signs, on hats, on T-shirts, on storefronts. Trump, Trump, Trump.

headline: A Colorado Town Tests Positive for Marijuana (in Its Water)
abstract: A well in Hugo, population 740, was found to be tainted with THC, even though there are no marijuana businesses nearby.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — There are no marijuana dispensaries or greenhouses in the tiny railroad town of Hugo, where Theodore Roosevelt once ate breakfast with the local cowboys. But this week, Hugo’s 740 residents were told to stop drinking the water after the town’s water supply tested positive for THC, the psychoactive chemical in Colorado’s most famous cash crop.

headline: For Trump, an America That Is Not a Nation of Nations
abstract: In his convention speech on Thursday, the presidential candidate took a negative tone on immigrants, avoiding even a boilerplate mention of their positive contributions.
lead_paragraph: With all the political orthodoxy that Donald J. Trump tore up in his convention speech on Thursday night, he set aside a core tenet of the American narrative on immigration: that the United States is a nation of nations, built on the sweat and initiative of people who came from other countries.

headline: Shooting in Munich: What We Know, and What We Don’t
abstract: Nine people were killed in a shooting rampage in Munich. The gunman’s body was found less than a mile from the scene of the attack, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A lone gunman killed nine people and seriously injured 27 others near a shopping mall in Munich late Friday afternoon. The gunman, whose body was found about half a mile from the mall, fatally shot himself, officials said.

headline: Fantasy Wear
abstract: The Her Universe Fashion Show, a competitive event reminiscent of “Project Runway,” involved 27 designers showcasing pop-culture-inspired ensembles at Comic-Con in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: The Her Universe Fashion Show, a competitive event reminiscent of “Project Runway,” involved 27 designers showcasing pop-culture-inspired ensembles at Comic-Con in San Diego.

headline: Comic-Con Makes a Fashion Statement
abstract: A dress made from Legos and another made from recycled trash inspired by “Wall-E” were just some of the designs modeled on the Her Universe runway.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — It won’t be joining New York, London, Milan and Paris on the official fashion month schedule any time soon, but San Diego, perhaps best known for annually hosting over 130,000 comic book fans who descend on the city during Comic-Con International each July, is the unlikely epicenter of a fashion movement that has achieved every supervillain’s dream of taking over the world. To be specific: wearable pop culture.

headline: Payday Loan Limits May Cut Abuse but Leave Some Borrowers Looking
abstract: Lenders and some consumer advocates ask what borrowers will do if stricter regulations remove their main source of short-term financial aid.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ohio — This city of 73,000 is known for a few things — the Pro Football Hall of Fame, the presidential library of William McKinley, a lively downtown arts scene.

headline: Elliott Management Shows PulteGroup Founder How to Get Things Done
abstract: The hedge fund, 4.7 percent shareholder in the home builder, tones down its aggression.
lead_paragraph: Elliott Management has just shown a dilettante how activism is done.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Fernanda Santos, Quentin Hardy and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Republican Convention Falls Short of TV Ratings Expectations
abstract: Television producers grumbled throughout the week about the less-than-ideal spectacle, with relatively unknown speakers appearing in the prime 10 p.m. hour.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Television is Donald J. Trump’s comfort zone, the medium where he ruled as master of “The Apprentice,” lured record audiences to Republican primary debates, and deftly outmaneuvered opponents with his camera-ready skills.

headline: Tour de France Leader Chris Froome Takes a Spill, but His Lead Grows
abstract: Friday’s 19th stage, in the French Alps, was made treacherous by pouring rain, which resulted in several crashes. Two riders were hospitalized with broken bones.
lead_paragraph: ST.-GERVAIS MONT BLANC, France — The honor of France was salvaged in the Tour de France on Friday, in a stage marred by rain-induced wreckage that snared the presumptive overall winner, Chris Froome of England, as well as several other cyclists, two of whom were taken to the hospital with broken bones.

headline: Delays Threaten to Unravel Iranian Plans to Buy 200 Jetliners
abstract: Fresh complications for an intended purchase that was seen as one of the most prominent commercial outcomes of a year-old nuclear accord.
lead_paragraph: Agreements for Iran to buy more than 200 jetliners from Boeing and Airbus, the most prominent commercial outcomes of the nuclear accord reached a year ago, face delays that could reduce or even unravel them, aviation lawyers and analysts said.

headline: Review: ‘Looking: The Movie’ Finds Change (and Angst) Are Constant
abstract: The film, on HBO, is a delayed finale for a show that ran two seasons.
lead_paragraph: “Are you all right?” a friend asks the angsty video-game designer Patrick (Jonathan Groff) early in “Looking: The Movie.” It’s the guiding question of the film, one that refers to two inquiries, actually: Are Patrick and his friends, 30- and 40-something gay men in the San Francisco Bay Area, all right with the way greater acceptance — symbolized by legal marriage — is changing their lives? And is Patrick, a narcissistic relationship saboteur, all right as his friends start pairing off for life?

headline: Brooklyn Woman, a Correction Recruit, Dies After Collapsing During Training
abstract: Jessica Louis, 33, died during a physical-training exercise on Thursday afternoon, the Correction Department said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old Brooklyn woman training to be a New York City correction officer died this week after collapsing during an exercise, the Correction Department said on Friday.

headline: N.C.A.A. Will Quiz Host Cities About Anti-Discrimination Policies
abstract: The questionnaire requires current and prospective host cities of championship competitions to outline “how they will protect participants and spectators from discrimination.”
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. unveiled a questionnaire Friday that requires current and prospective host cities of its championship competitions “to specifically outline how they will protect participants and spectators from discrimination,” including details on how they would mitigate any local discriminatory laws or rules that permit the refusal of services to members of any group.

headline: William Gaines, Prizewinning Investigative Reporter, Dies at 82
abstract: A longtime journalist whose reporting on corruption in Chicago won two Pulitzer Prizes.
lead_paragraph: William Gaines, an investigative reporter for The Chicago Tribune who shared two Pulitzer Prizes for exposing corruption in Chicago and was a finalist for a third, died on Wednesday in Munster, Ind. He was 82.

headline: A Vivacious Celebration of Steve Reich, a Maverick Turned Music Hero
abstract: Three concerts at the Lincoln Center Festival drove home how a younger generation has embraced Mr. Reich’s music as its own.
lead_paragraph: Steve Reich turns 80 on Oct. 3, and the party has already started.

headline: Finra Sides With Brokers in Battle Against Credit Suisse
abstract: In fight for hundreds of millions in deferred compensation, former Credit Suisse brokers can now take their claims to Finra for arbitration.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of former Credit Suisse advisers who have been fighting for their deferred compensation after leaving the bank last year scored a partial victory on Friday when the brokerage industry’s main regulator said member firms cannot make workers waive their rights to settle disputes in the regulator’s own arbitration forum.

headline: Blue Man Group Is Sued in Royalties Case
abstract: Ian Pai, who composed music used by the global theatrical brand, contends that he has been underpaid for decades.
lead_paragraph: Blue Man Group, whose shows feature a trio of mute, alienesque, marshmallow-tossing, percussion-thumping bald and painted characters, has grown from its beginnings in the 1980s New York performance art scene to a global brand that has entertained more than 35 million people.

headline: EgyptAir Flight 804 Broke Up in Midair After a Fire, Evidence Suggests
abstract: Investigators do not know, however, if the blaze that is thought to have caused the plane to come apart was an accident or caused by terrorism.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Evidence gathered in an investigation into the crash of EgyptAir Flight 804 in the Mediterranean Sea in May indicates that the plane most likely broke up in midair after a fire near or inside the cockpit that quickly overwhelmed the crew, according to Egyptian officials involved in the inquiry.

headline: Review: A ‘Macbeth’ at Ease in the Dark and Noisy City
abstract: Outdoors at Marcus Garvey Park, a Shakespeare classic plays out in a free production enhanced by its urban surroundings.
lead_paragraph: We’ll discuss the human performers anon, but let’s begin our look at Classical Theater of Harlem’s outdoor “Macbeth” with a nod to the uncredited stars: nature and New York City.

headline: In ‘Golem,’ the Troupe 1927 Shares a Stage With a Claymation Co-Star
abstract: A fanciful adaptation of this ancient Jewish legend fits well with this company’s dependence on useful, risky technology.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Sottile Theater on the College of Charleston campus, like so many stages, was riddled on a recent afternoon with “spikes”: pieces of glow-in-the-dark tape designed to help actors find their exact spots on an unlit stage.

headline: Review: ‘The Merchant of Venice’ With Extra Fog, Moral and Atmospheric
abstract: At the Lincoln Center Festival, Jonathan Pryce stars as Shylock in a production filled with scorn, violence and anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: Light barely seems to penetrate the atmosphere of “The Merchant of Venice” in the brooding, powerful production from Shakespeare’s Globe that’s being presented through the weekend as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Little illumination filters through the carved wooden walls that dominate the set, and a blanket of smoke often shrouds the stage like a thick fog, as if to hide the iniquity so vividly on display.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Munich, Republican Convention, Hillary Clinton: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Michael Jordan, a Chance to Speak Up (for Once)
abstract: As a franchise owner, Jordan has broken barriers. But in the wake of North Carolina’s “bathroom law,” perhaps it’s time for him to break free of his corporate cautiousness.
lead_paragraph: When Adam Silver informed Michael Jordan that he was pulling the 2017 N.B.A. All-Star Game from Charlotte, was Jordan tempted to reprise the most memorable sociopolitical statement of his storied playing career?

headline: Munich Under Attack
abstract: A deadly shooting rampage shut down much of Munich on Friday, and the German police said they were treating the assault as a suspected terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: A deadly shooting rampage shut down much of Munich on Friday, and the German police said they were treating the assault as a suspected terrorist attack.

headline: Smirk or Smile? The New York Tabloids Disagree About Trump
abstract: The New York Post and The Daily News covered Trump’s nomination speech in their own inimitable — and opposing — ways.
lead_paragraph: If, as some New Yorkers still do, you had woken up on Friday morning, poured a cup of coffee and sat down with your dog to read The New York Post and The Daily News, you would have seen the latest installment in a two-sided saga that has been playing out for months. Here, after all, on the morning following Donald J. Trump’s coronation as the Republican presidential nominee, was the best chapter yet in the Tale of Two Tabloids.

headline: Testing Sites for Self-Driving Cars Become a Priority
abstract: After a fatal crash involving a Tesla Model S, the idea of establishing a federally supervised site to ensure safety is catching on.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Spurred by the fatal crash of a driver operating his Tesla Motors car in Autopilot mode, lawmakers and car executives are urging the Transportation Department to intensify the testing of self-driving vehicles.

headline: Obama Denies U.S. Involvement in Coup Attempt in Turkey
abstract: Rumors that America was behind the failed military action threatened the safety of U.S. citizens in Turkey, Mr. Obama said, and could damage the nations’ ties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday pushed back against persistent speculation in Turkey that the United States was behind the failed military coup there, saying that the rumors threatened the safety of Americans in the country and could damage its ties with the United States.

headline: The Obamas’ Example
abstract: Readers write that the personal example that President Obama and Michelle Obama have set “is an important part of this admirable couple’s legacy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Oliver Stone’s ‘Snowden’ Gives Comic-Con Its Moment of Gravity
abstract: A new trailer, a showing of “Snowden” and some unusual swag accompanied Mr. Stone’s appearance.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Serious films, the kind with Oscars on their minds, rarely bother with Comic-Con International, the circuslike pop culture festival that got underway here on Thursday. This isn’t exactly a sophisticated crowd — unless you want to discuss the latest “Sharknado,” Klingon lifestyles or the deeper meaning of “My Little Pony.”

headline: By Russian Standards, Melania Trump Would Be a Plagiarism Amateur
abstract: The uproar over Melania Trump’s speech this week would barely tip the plagiarism scale in Russia, where an organization claims that many politicians have stolen others’ work.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — By Russian standards, the few lines that Melania Trump used from Michelle Obama for her speech at the Republican National Convention this week would barely tip the plagiarism scale.

headline: Hillary Clinton Selects Tim Kaine, a Popular Senator From a Swing State, as Running Mate
abstract: Mr. Kaine, a former governor of Virginia who is now on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, speaks fluent Spanish and has a strong friendship with Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: How Tim Kaine and Hillary Clinton Compare on the Issues
abstract: The Democrats agree on many issues, including proposals for the criminal justice system and foreign policy agreements, but may not be equally keen on trade deals.
lead_paragraph: In choosing Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia as her running mate, Hillary Clinton has selected someone who shares her political philosophy and pragmatic approach to governing. Here are Mr. Kaine’s positions on some key issues, and how they align with Mrs. Clinton’s views.

headline: Who Is Tim Kaine? Virginia Senator Is Hillary Clinton’s Running Mate
abstract: Mr. Kaine is a senator and former governor from Virginia, a crucial swing state, but his credentials as a moderate might not satisfy the Democratic Party’s base.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has chosen Tim Kaine as her running mate. Mr. Kaine is a senator and former governor from Virginia, a crucial swing state, with a reputation as a pragmatic consensus builder. But his credentials as a moderate might not energize the Democratic Party’s base.

headline: Hershey Trust Reaches Tentative Deal With Pennsylvania on Governance
abstract: A deal would settle a monthslong legal dispute and change the rules governing the Hershey Trust Company, which controls more than 80 percent of the chocolate maker’s special voting shares.
lead_paragraph: The charitable trust that controls Hershey has reached a tentative deal with the Pennsylvania attorney general that would shake up its governance, in exchange for warding off a potential legal battle.

headline: Abolish Superdelegates. It’s Only Democratic.
abstract: Convention V.I.P.s have enough privileges without their nomination votes counting more than those of ordinary party members.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — In no recent American election has the divide between a powerful elite and a frustrated public been so apparent and so central as in 2016. How we address this issue will define the future of our country. For many Democrats, the living symbol of this divide are the superdelegates.

headline: If Tim Kaine Can Help Clinton in Virginia Even a Bit, It’s a Big Deal
abstract: Hillary Clinton might not need Mr. Kaine to secure Virginia, but it’s a crucial state, and he can only help.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s selection of Tim Kaine as her running mate on Friday night will not excite the progressive base or electrify crowds. But by all other standards for judging a vice-presidential selection, he checks the boxes — and more.

headline: Tim Kaine: A Self-Effacing Senator in a Sharp-Elbows Era
abstract: Mr. Kaine, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, a senator and former governor of Virginia, is known for his calm temperament, willingness to build bridges and Catholic faith.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after Barack Obama became the first African-American to win the White House, Tim Kaine, then the governor of Virginia, visited a civil rights memorial in Richmond. There, in a former capital of the Confederacy, he summed up the history-making moment in four words.

headline: Tim Kaine Picked as Clinton Running Mate
abstract: Hillary Clinton announced Friday that Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia would be her vice-presidential choice.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton announced Friday that Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia would be her vice-presidential choice.

headline: A Coolant That Threatens to Heat Up the Climate
abstract: World leaders should agree on a plan to replace greenhouse gases in air-conditioners, refrigerators and aerosols with safer alternatives.
lead_paragraph: GASES found in air-conditioners, refrigerators and aerosols are among the biggest threats to our climate. Pound for pound, these hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, can be vastly more powerful for planetary warming than carbon dioxide. World leaders are in Vienna to discuss these pollutants and should agree on a plan to quickly replace them with safer alternatives.

headline: Zack Wheeler Is Eager to Return to the Mets, but Time Is Running Out
