abstract: Lab tests run over the weekend countered earlier findings that the water supply in Hugo contained traces of THC, psychoactive chemical in marijuana.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It turns out that the water in a tiny eastern Colorado town never had a marijuana problem.

headline: One Sculptor’s Fantastical, Unplayable Musical Instruments
abstract: Adrian Nivola’s new pieces are equally inspired by ancient sculpture, the real machinery of functional strings and horns and abstract work by artists like Calder and Gabo.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Nivola’s new pieces are equally inspired by ancient sculpture, the real machinery of functional strings and horns and abstract work by artists like Calder and Gabo.

headline: The Democrats’ Damaging Damage Control
abstract: On Debbie Wasserman Schultz’s long exit.
lead_paragraph: What we have here is a “distraction.” And there must never be a distraction. This is politics, where everyone must always remain focused, never distracted.

headline: Review: ‘The Wicked Boy,’ a Young Killer’s Twisty Path to Atonement
abstract: Kate Summerscale resurrects a notorious true-life tale of murder in the Victorian era committed by a 13-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: On a bright July Monday in 1895, Robert Coombes, 13, and his 12-year-old brother, Nathaniel, called Nattie, set off from their East London home to see a cricket match. Before leaving, they gave a neighbor money to pay the rent when the landlord arrived. Their father, a ship’s chief steward, had recently set out to sea, and their mother, Robert explained, was going to visit an aunt in Liverpool.

headline: Democrats Allege D.N.C. Hack Is Part of Russian Effort to Elect Donald Trump
abstract: Officials in Philadelphia for the party’s national convention sought to spread the idea that the Kremlin wanted to see Mr. Trump elected instead of Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Cold War-era intrigue permeated the 93-degree heat in Philadelphia on Monday, as Democrats sought to spread the idea that the release of thousands of hacked emails from the Democratic National Committee is part of a Russian effort to help elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: If You Want to Find Your Way Out of ‘Paradiso,’ Think Fast
abstract: Michael Counts’s newest adventure mixes theatrical flourishes with the escape-room fad.
lead_paragraph: The veteran theatrical entrepreneur Michael Counts applies his skills to the escape-room fad with “Paradiso: Chapter 1,” an audience-participation experience that is part puzzle, part performance, part technological razzle-dazzle. What you get out of it will depend on what you put into it, and perhaps on whom you bring along.

headline: String of Attacks in Europe Fuels a Summer of Anxiety
abstract: The Continent is struggling with how to respond to terrorism that does not fit neat definitions or lend itself to easy answers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly every day seems to bring a new horror to the streets of Western Europe, leaving innocent men, women and children dead or broken, fueling political and social tensions and creating what some are already calling the summer of anxiety.

headline: Yahoo Mail and Tumblr and Flickr: What Happens Now?
abstract: Here are answers to some common questions about the impact Verizon’s purchase will have on Yahoo’s numerous services.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Verizon’s announcement that it is acquiring Yahoo’s operations is a turning point for an internet pioneer that claims a billion users visit its services each month.

headline: Review: Dark Comedy, a Farcical Marriage and the Self at the New York Musical Festival
abstract: “A Scythe of Time,” “Icon” and “Eh Dah? Questions for My Father” investigate themes of death, love and cultural identity in funny and moving ways.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Allan Poe isn’t exactly known as frolicsome company, so I was skeptical about the fun potential of a musical based on his work — let alone a show called “A Scythe of Time.” Can we agree that it’s a terrible title?

headline: 2 Sides Clash Over Wasserman Schultz
abstract: At a breakfast for Florida delegates, the Democratic National Committee's outgoing chairwoman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, was met with praise from constituents and jeers from Bernie Sanders supporters.
lead_paragraph: At a breakfast for Florida delegates, the Democratic National Committee's outgoing chairwoman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, was met with praise from constituents and jeers from Bernie Sanders supporters.

headline: Heritage Sunday, Where the Dancer Is the Drummer
abstract: “Global Beat of the Bronx: From Bambara to Breakbeats,” at Lincoln Center, showcased lively dance troupes from New York’s northernmost borough.
lead_paragraph: As the temperature crept up to 90 degrees on Sunday, a three-hour outdoor performance didn’t seem like the most attractive afternoon activity. But any qualms about the heat quickly faded as Heritage Sunday, an annual presentation of Lincoln Center Out of Doors and the Center for Traditional Music and Dance, got underway.

headline: Introducing Times Insider’s New Cooking Club: The Gray Ladle
abstract: On Thursday, July 28, Kim Severson and Julia Moskin were on hand to answer readers’ questions about all things food.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, July 28, Kim Severson and Julia Moskin were on hand to answer readers’ questions about all things food.

headline: Review: LCD Soundsystem Makes a Return and a Homecoming at Panorama
abstract: The band, which announced it was disbanding in 2011, played at the Panorama Festival on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: Lights hit the big disco ball above LCD Soundsystem during the first song of its set on Sunday night, headlining the Panorama Festival on Randalls Island. “The time has come today,” band members sang in “Us v Them,” and the disco ball blasted a simple, unmistakable message: Time to dance.

headline: Ribeyron’s Industrial Accessories — for Everyone
abstract: The year-old accessories line is intentionally gender-neutral — and the designer says he’d like both men and women to wear the pieces.
lead_paragraph: The year-old accessories line is intentionally gender-neutral — and the designer says he’d like both men and women to wear the pieces.

headline: Brand to Know: Fine Jewelry, Made From Industrial Materials
abstract: Ribeyron’s bags and jewelry are inspired by pieces from hardware stores, as well as the sculptural works of John Chamberlain.
lead_paragraph: Jacques-Elie Ribeyron doesn’t speak like a typical fashion designer. “I work very fast when I design, actually,” he says. “I draw these files and send them to the 3-D printer. If I spend more than two to three days on it, I get bored.” That may explain the minimal, industrial aesthetic of his year-old accessories and jewelry brand, Ribeyron, which draws as much from objects found at hardware stores and bondage shops as it does from the automotive artworks of John Chamberlain.

headline: For Yahoo, Question Is What to Do With $40 Billion in Leftovers
abstract: After a sale of its core internet business to Verizon, Yahoo will still have stakes in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan, along with cash and a collection of patents.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has agreed to sell the bulk of what people know as Yahoo — its mail services, its news sites, the Tumblr social network — to Verizon for nearly $5 billion.

headline: ‘Sweeney Todd’ and ‘The Crucible’: Not New, but Darkly Up-to-Date
abstract: Operatic performances of these works highlight the Glimmerglass Festival, while “Iris” serves as a kind of preview of the Bard Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was the campaign yard signs on the drive through upstate New York to the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown. Or it may have been that the journey began just hours after Donald J. Trump’s fiery acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Virtual Reality Waits for the Music Industry to Catch Up
abstract: Many companies are ready to create VR concerts, but not enough consumers have the headsets needed to experience the immersive performances.
lead_paragraph: The club is jam-packed with eager fans dancing with their hands up, but before you can join them you have a job to do. You must get Deadmau5, the electronic music producer and performer, safely to the stage. With help from a digital avatar of Deadmau5’s cat, Meowingtons, you have to maneuver over and around sound equipment and security guards as selfie-seeking fans begin to swarm. When you finally deliver him in one piece, you’re awash in the sounds of his latest track, “Saved.” You look up, down, left, right, and you are standing in the middle of a concert. The crowd comes alive, dancing to the pulsing music.

headline: Six Sunscreens That Actually Improve Your Skin
abstract: The season’s SPF-loaded moisturizers do more than protect against harmful rays.
lead_paragraph: The season’s SPF-loaded moisturizers do more than protect against harmful rays.

headline: Japan Knife Attack Kills 19 at Center for Disabled
abstract: A former employee who broke into the center overnight in Sagamihara also wounded 25 people before turning himself in, local officials said.
lead_paragraph: SAGAMIHARA, Japan — A former employee of a center for the disabled in a Tokyo suburb broke into the building and killed 19 people with a knife early Tuesday, local officials said.

headline: Draft Checklist on Mild Behavioral Impairment
abstract: A group of psychiatrists and other experts proposed this 34-question checklist to help identify people at greater risk for Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: A group of psychiatrists and other experts proposed this 34-question checklist to help identify people at greater risk for Alzheimer’s.

headline: Lael Brainard, Donning a Global Lens, Champions Low Rates at Fed
abstract: The Fed is expected to again pass on an opportunity to raise its interest rate, a move partly owing to the efforts of Ms. Brainard, a Fed governor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard is poised to win another round this week in her fight for the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low.

headline: Democratic Convention, Verizon and Yahoo, Fort Myers: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Democrats Followed by Their Own Divisions to Philadelphia
abstract: Hillary Clinton promised a Democratic convention different from the bitterly divided Republican gathering. The scene in Philadelphia signals otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Abroad in America, written by a Times foreign correspondent, approaches the election in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Tim LaHaye Dies at 90; Fundamentalist Leader’s Grisly Novels Sold Millions
abstract: Dr. LaHaye, an evangelical minister and prolific writer, was co-author of the apocalyptic “Left Behind” novels and promoted traditional conservative organizations.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Tim LaHaye, a leader of the Christian fundamentalist movement and co-author of the best-selling “Left Behind” series of apocalyptic novels prophesying mass slaughters and the end of the world, died on Monday in a San Diego area hospital. He was 90.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Unconventional Hardly Covers It
abstract: Brooks and Collins on Sanders, Trump, Cruz, Clinton, Kaine, friends, Romans and countrymen.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Lots to talk about this week. An unusual G.O.P. convention is in the books. The Democrats’ meeting in Philly is already off to a chaotic start, to say the least. But sandwiched between Trump’s address and the D.N.C. email drama, Hillary actually picked a V.P. Let’s start today with your hot take on Tim Kaine.

headline: In D.N.C. Hack, Echoes of Russia’s New Approach to Power
abstract: Deception and disinformation, not tanks and planes, have become new tools of power for Moscow, and it would be well within Russian strategy to stir up trouble.
lead_paragraph: Of the questions raised by charges that Russia was involved  in the release of hacked Democratic National Committee emails, at least one — why would Russia do such a thing? — can be answered with a little-noticed but influential 2013 Russian military journal article.

headline: Why The Upshot Forecasting Model Still Has Hillary Clinton Ahead
abstract: History suggests that, before the conventions are finished, you’re better off focusing on a two-month average than a two-week average.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has had a rough few weeks. She was publicly admonished by the F.B.I. for using a private email server as secretary of state, and Democratic National Committee emails were recently leaked, forcing the resignation of the party chairwoman.

headline: Amazon Expands Drone Testing in Britain
abstract: The British Civil Aviation Authority will allow the company to test several technologies that the United States has not permitted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amazon has partnered with the British government to significantly expand drone testing, a move that could allow the devices to deliver packages to British homes far earlier than in the United States.

headline: Adults Have Become Shorter in Many Countries
abstract: Average heights appear to have peaked 30 to 40 years ago and have declined slightly since then, according to results compiled from 1,472 studies.
lead_paragraph: Average adult heights in many countries appear to have peaked 30 to 40 years ago and have declined slightly since then, according to a new study that the authors say is based on the largest set of such data ever gathered.

headline: Review: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ Casts a Spell Onstage
abstract: Time is a crucial element in this drama, which captures the narrative grip of J.K. Rowling’s prose in a staging at the Palace Theater in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oh, for a wizard’s spell that would allow me to tell you everything, and then erase it completely from your memory. But though I paid rapt attention during the afternoon and evening I spent at “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child,” which opened in a blaze of outrageous enchantment on Monday night at the Palace Theater here, I failed to pick up on any recipe for inducing post-tell-all amnesia in Muggles, which is Potter-speak for nonwizards like you and me.

headline: New York Athletic Commission Inquiry
abstract: A long-awaited investigative report by the New York Office of the Inspector General describes the State Athletic Commission as an organizational mess, short on proper practices and procedures but long on conflicts of interest and other improprieties.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited investigative report by the New York Office of the Inspector General describes the State Athletic Commission as an organizational mess, short on proper practices and procedures but long on conflicts of interest and other improprieties.

headline: The One Demographic That Is Hurting Hillary Clinton
abstract: White voters without a college degree, particularly men, strongly favor Donald Trump. And that’s still a large voting bloc.
lead_paragraph: The list of voting groups generally alienated by Donald J. Trump is long: Hispanics, women, the young, the college educated and more. How is it that he’s in such a close race with Hillary Clinton?

headline: Democratic Convention Night 1: Analysis
abstract: How we analyzed in real time the first night of the Democratic National Convention, featuring Michelle Obama, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: How we analyzed in real time the first night of the Democratic National Convention, featuring Michelle Obama, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.

headline: Inquiry Finds Widespread Disorder at New York Athletic Commission
abstract: An investigation into the state agency that regulates boxing — and, soon, mixed martial arts — found that it was short on proper practices and procedures but long on conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited investigative report by the New York Office of the Inspector General described the state agency that regulates boxing — and, soon, mixed martial arts — as an organizational mess, short on proper practices and procedures but long on conflicts of interest and other improprieties.

headline: Colombia Declares End to the Zika Epidemic
abstract: The country is the first in South America to turn the tide on the disease.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Health officials here on Monday declared an end to the Zika epidemic in Colombia, the first time a South American country had turned the tide on the disease, they said.

headline: Charles Rangel, a Veteran of Democratic Conventions, Has Had Enough (but First, a Few Quips)
abstract: Mr. Rangel, a New York congressman nearing the end of a 23-term career, opined on Donald J. Trump, party unity and bagels as he trudged through the convention center.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — He lumbered through the convention center in white shoes and pants to match — his destination several hundred feet and an escalator away — wheezing a bit as he neared the end.

headline: N.F.L. Introduces New Rules to Back Its Concussion Protocol
abstract: After calls for enhanced measures to protect players from head injuries, the league announced new penalties for teams that fail to follow protocol.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. teams will be subjected to fines of hundreds of thousands of dollars and possibly the loss of draft picks if they fail to take players out of games after sustaining a concussion, according to new rules announced on Monday by the league and the N.F.L. Players Association.

headline: 9-Year-Old Child Worker Dies in Bangladeshi Textile Mill
abstract: The father of Sagar Barman accused the supervisors at Zobeda Textile Mill in Dhaka of killing his son by pumping air into his rectum.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A supervisor at a textile mill was arrested after a 9-year-old worker died over the weekend, and the boy’s father accused the supervisor and others of killing him because he had protested against abuse.

headline: Democratic Convention Night 1: What You Missed
abstract: The prime-time lineup for Night 1 of the Democratic National Convention was full of political star power, including Michelle Obama and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The prime-time lineup for Night 1 of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia was full of political star power: the first lady, Michelle Obama; Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont all addressed the crowd, and speeches were given by athletes, activists and celebrities.

headline: Virginia Governor Says Fight for Felons’ Voting Rights Is Not Over
abstract: After the State Supreme Court ruled against his blanket order restoring the vote to more than 200,000 ex-felons, Gov. Terry McAuliffe vowed to continue “the struggle for civil rights.”
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia ordered the blanket restoration of voting rights to more than 200,000 former felons in April, Republicans who control the state legislature swiftly filed a petition in court, accusing him of exceeding his authority. And when the state’s highest court agreed on Friday, voiding the governor’s declaration in a biting ruling, that briefly seemed to put the matter to rest.

headline: Woman With Zika Virus in Spain Gives Birth to Baby With Microcephaly
abstract: The birth is probably the first case of its kind in Europe, according to the hospital in Barcelona where the infant was born.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A woman infected with the Zika virus gave birth on Monday to a baby with microcephaly in Barcelona, in what is probably the first case of its kind in Europe, according to the hospital where the infant was born.

headline: Hall of Fame Plaques of Mike Piazza and Ken Griffey Jr. Are a Hit
abstract: The wall hangings honoring Piazza and Griffey drew long lines of fans in Cooperstown, N.Y., the day after the two baseball stars were inducted.
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — The line of fans to see Mike Piazza and Ken Griffey Jr.’s Baseball Hall of Fame plaques early Monday snaked through the plaque gallery, up a ramp and almost to the A. Bartlett Giamatti Research Center. It would take nearly 90 minutes for some to see the gallery’s newest additions.

headline: As ISIS Loosens Grip, U.S. and Iraq Prepare for Grinding Insurgency
abstract: The Islamic State’s suicide attack in Baghdad this month, officials say, foreshadows the violence it will unleash as it reverts to its guerrilla roots.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State’s latest suicide attack in Baghdad, which killed nearly 330 people, foreshadows a long and bloody insurgency, according to American diplomats and commanders, as the group reverts to its guerrilla roots because its territory is shrinking in Iraq and Syria.

headline: One Thing Both Parties Want: To Break Up the Banks Again
abstract: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump both called for the reinstatement of Glass-Steagall, a 1933 law that separated investment and commercial banks.
lead_paragraph: Could the Glass-Steagall Act — the Depression-era legislation that forced the separation of investment banking from commercial banking, among other things — be coming back?

headline: At Site of P.G.A. Championship Lies the Legend of Baltus Roll
abstract: The name Baltusrol Golf Club is linked to the memory of a farmer and his coldblooded murder in 1831.
lead_paragraph: WESTFIELD, N.J. — On a bright, smoldering afternoon late last week, the golf historians Bob Trebus and Rick Wolffe parked their sport utility vehicle alongside Mountain Avenue and walked through a rusted iron fence into a small cemetery behind a white-steepled church.

headline: Thinking About Suing Uber? Let This Be a Warning.
abstract: A Yale environmentalist filed a lawsuit against Uber accusing it of price-fixing. In response, Uber hired a Ergo, an outside agency, to look into his background.
lead_paragraph: When Uber’s chief executive was sued last winter in an antitrust case, the company’s general counsel, Salle Yoo, wanted a bit of intelligence on the opposition.

headline: Principals Chosen for 2 Troubled Brooklyn High Schools
abstract: Boys and Girls High School and Automotive High School, two of New York City’s lowest-performing schools, are part of a turnaround effort by the Education Department.
lead_paragraph: Trying to get its school turnaround effort back on track, the New York City Education Department moved on Monday to fill principal vacancies at two of the city’s lowest-performing high schools, Boys and Girls High School and Automotive High School, both in Brooklyn.

headline: Peru Scrambles to Drive Out Illegal Gold Mining and Save Precious Land
abstract: A force of marines and rangers is outnumbered as it tries to protect the area anchored by the Tambopata reserve, one of the most biologically diverse places on earth.
lead_paragraph: ON THE BORDER OF THE TAMBOPATA RESERVE, Peru — The raid began at dawn. In four small wooden boats, the forest rangers and Peruvian marines, checking and rechecking their automatic weapons, headed silently downriver toward the illegal gold miners.

headline: Yankees’ Depth Made the Flamethrower Aroldis Chapman Expendable
abstract: Bargaining from a position of pitching strength, the Yankees upgraded their stable of position players by sending Chapman to the Cubs.
lead_paragraph: Most major trades involve some level of pain. A good deal rarely comes without a downside, without something each team will sorely miss.

headline: To Democrats, Email Hack Suggests Trump Has New Supporter: Putin
abstract: A breach tied to Russian intelligence agencies has raised questions about whether the Kremlin has thrown its support behind Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Donald J. Trump prepared to take his beauty pageant to Moscow in 2013, he relished the participation of one man above all: President Vladimir V. Putin. “Do you think Putin will be going to The Miss Universe Pageant in November in Moscow — if so, will he become my new best friend?” he wrote on Twitter.

headline: Prince Harry Says He Regrets Not Discussing His Mother’s Death
abstract: The prince was 12 when his mother, Princess Diana, died, but did not speak of it until three years ago. He made the comments while hosting a barbecue for a mental health charity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry, who was 12 when his mother, Princess Diana, was killed in a car crash, has expressed regret that he did not talk openly about her death for many years.

headline: Soldiers Calm French Nerves, but Are Paying a Steep Price
abstract: The state of emergency is keeping thousands of heavily armed troops on the streets, which is proving to be a drain on both personnel and morale.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Day in and day out for the past 18 months, two or three French soldiers have been posted by the doors of a small synagogue on the Rue St.-Lazare in central Paris, where they have become as much of a fixture as the bar on the corner and the place selling rotisserie meats across the street.

headline: Mets G.M. Suggests Big Move at Trade Deadline Is Unlikely
abstract: Alderson, the general manager, made a productive last-minute trade to obtain Yoenis Cespedes last season, but he said, “Deals at the deadline don’t always work out that way.”
lead_paragraph: If television cameras had been in the office of Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson around last season’s nonwaiver trade deadline, viewership could have brought in record ratings.

headline: France’s Permanent Emergency State
abstract: A stricter state of emergency will not improve counterterrorism efforts.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel killed 84 people by driving a truck through the crowd gathered on Nice’s seafront, France’s president, François Hollande, announced he would ask Parliament to extend for another three months the state of emergency declared immediately after the Paris terrorist attacks last November.

headline: Carmelo Anthony and Michael Jordan Address Social Issues With Differing Approaches
abstract: Anthony hosted a community forum with local youth and police officers, while Jordan said in a statement that he was “deeply troubled” by recent violence.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Carmelo Anthony followed through on his pledge to move forward with his growing interest in social issues by staging a community event here on Monday to address the recent spate of killings committed by and against police officers.

headline: Democrats May Not Be Unified, but Their Convention Speakers Are
abstract: Judging by the speakers’ list, the Democratic convention will show significantly more harmony and continuity than the Republican one.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Democrats began their national convention in Philadelphia, featuring a “United Together” theme.

headline: Girl’s Name
abstract: Bruce Haight returns, and has advice on playing ping pong with Will Shortz.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I was of two minds about today’s puzzle.

headline: Sarah Silverman Scolds ‘Bernie or Bust’
abstract: Speaking at the Democratic National Convention, the comedian Sarah Silverman told delegates continuing to back Bernie Sanders that they were “being ridiculous.”
lead_paragraph: Speaking at the Democratic National Convention, the comedian Sarah Silverman told delegates continuing to back Bernie Sanders that they were “being ridiculous.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, July 26, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We have hurt ISIS’ morale, but nobody can deny that ISIS still has its sleeper cells, and we expect anything from it.”

headline: Yogurt Plant’s Closing Prompts Questions on Cuomo’s Economic Growth Plans
abstract: The Müller Quaker Dairy plant in Batavia, N.Y., closed less than three years after opening despite receiving major tax credits from the state’s Excelsior Jobs Program.
lead_paragraph: BATAVIA, N.Y. — It was meant to be the Colosseum of yogurt plants: a sprawling $200 million testament to the popularity and economic potential of fermented milk, nearly the size of five football fields and no less patriotic, with an American flag and one of New York State.

headline: Michelle Obama Joins Forces With Her Predecessor (and Former Adversary)
abstract: The first lady’s speech in support of Hillary Clinton was a testament to their evolving relationship.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — They began as adversaries, with Michelle Obama often fuming about what she viewed as brutal, unfair attacks by Hillary Clinton on her husband during the 2008 primary campaign.

headline: Colombian Cocaine Kingpin Sentenced to 35 Years in Prison
abstract: Daniel Barrera, known as El Loco, was also fined $10 million for running a brutal drug syndicate that spanned four continents and lasted more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Barrera, described by prosecutors as “one of Colombia’s most notorious, prolific and violent drug traffickers,” was sentenced on Monday to 35 years in prison and fined $10 million for running a brutal cocaine syndicate that spanned four continents and lasted more than a decade.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Urges Liberals to Vote for Hillary Clinton
abstract: The Massachusetts senator issued an implicit warning to supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders that not voting for Mrs. Clinton could put Donald J. Trump in the White House.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Fists clenched, eyes focused intently behind her rimless glasses, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts took the stage Monday on the first night of the Democratic National Convention with an urgent and fiery plea to liberals hesitant to support Hillary Clinton.

headline: Michelle Obama Talks of Future at D.N.C.
abstract: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke on Monday at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, framing the election in terms of America’s children.
lead_paragraph: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke on Monday at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, framing the election in terms of America’s children.

headline: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Reveals a Slower Road to His Recovery
abstract: Jeff Gordon will race again this weekend in place of Earnhardt, who is recovering from concussionlike symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Dale Earnhardt Jr. warned on Monday that his return to Nascar could take longer than planned.

headline: Bernie Sanders Faces Task of Putting Down Revolt He Started
abstract: Despite Mr. Sanders’s pleas to unite around Hillary Clinton, his supporters booed, heckled and protested on the first night of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Bernie Sanders likes to boast that he has ignited a fiery movement.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Makes Push for Clinton
abstract: The Massachusetts senator made the case for Hillary Clinton as president and continued to indict the business record of the Republican nominee, Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts senator made the case for Hillary Clinton as president and continued to indict the business record of the Republican nominee, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Sanders Urges Unity Behind Clinton
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders appealed for unity at the Democratic convention, mentioning Hillary Clinton’s name 15 times in his speech on Monday and declaring that she “must become the next president of the United States.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders appealed for unity at the Democratic convention, mentioning Hillary Clinton’s name 15 times in his speech on Monday and declaring that she “must become the next president of the United States.”

headline: China Scolds Indian Government for Expelling 3 of Its Journalists
abstract: An Indian official said the visas of the Chinese journalists from Xinhua, the state news agency, had expired and had been valid only on short-term extensions.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Chinese state-run news media on Monday criticized a decision by the Indian government to not renew the visas of three Chinese journalists from Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Cool off with “Ice Fantasy,” a Chinese drama with “Game of Thrones” in its DNA. Or watch former President Bill Clinton address the Democratic Convention.
lead_paragraph: Cool off under the heat dome with “Ice Fantasy,” a new Chinese drama with “The Lord of the Rings” and “Game of Thrones” in its DNA. Watch former President Bill Clinton speak at the Democratic National Convention. Or punk out with the Sex Pistols.

headline: Yankees’ Win Over Dallas Keuchel and Astros Offers a Lift
abstract: Keuchel, who has gained a reputation as a Yankee killer, gave up two runs, and the Yankees cobbled together a victory after trading Aroldis Chapman to the Cubs.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A couple of hours after Aroldis Chapman left the clubhouse at Minute Maid Park on Monday, it looked as if the Yankees’ playoff hopes were ready to follow in his footsteps.

headline: Bangladesh Police Kill 9 Militants in Gun Battle
abstract: A shootout erupted after officers surrounded a hide-out in Dhaka, the capital, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Nine militants were killed in a gun battle with police officers who had surrounded their hide-out in Dhaka, the capital, the authorities said Tuesday. Another militant was wounded and in custody.

headline: Editors’ Note: July 26, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, July 26, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Rihanna and Kendrick Lamar to Headline Global Citizen Festival
abstract: Selena Gomez and Metallica are also among the headliners at this festival in Central Park, which aims to combat extreme poverty.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna, Kendrick Lamar, Selena Gomez and Metallica will headline the fifth Global Citizen Festival, coming to the Great Lawn in Central Park on Sept. 24. The festival, which aims to encourage activism and put pressure on leaders to combat poverty, will be streamed live.

headline: Week of Violence Rattles Germany
abstract: In a span of six days in July, four high-profile attacks occurred in Germany, putting the nation on edge. Ten people were killed and more than 40 wounded in Würzburg, Munich, Reutlingen and Ansbach.
lead_paragraph: In a span of six days in July, four high-profile attacks occurred in Germany, putting the nation on edge. Ten people were killed and more than 40 wounded in Würzburg, Munich, Reutlingen and Ansbach.

headline: Yahoo, a Web Pioneer, Cleared the Way for Many Innovations
abstract: A fond send-off for a company that brought order to the fast-growing internet forest.
lead_paragraph: If a team of entrepreneurs tried to sell venture capitalists on a business that sought to organize all the information on the internet, it would be laughed out of the room today. But during the early years of the web, which are not all that distant, Yahoo did exactly that — and did it well.

headline: Female Police Officers Save Lives
abstract: Women have been on the force for a century, but there are still far too few of them.
lead_paragraph: A HUNDRED years ago this week, Georgia Ann Robinson joined the Los Angeles police force, making her, to the best of anyone’s knowledge, the nation’s first African-American policewoman.

headline: Bill Clinton: A Perfectly Imperfect First Gentleman
abstract: If the former president returns to the White House as a presidential spouse, he will be novel in many ways — especially in his well-documented flaws.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton is scheduled to speak Tuesday evening at the Democratic National Convention, where he’ll presumably make a case for his wife, and for his own barrier-breaking role as first gentleman.

headline: Hillary, This Is Why Democrats Are Still Struggling
abstract: Madam Secretary, you need to fight your party’s materialistic mind-set.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Dear Hillary,

headline: A Strategy to Build Police-Citizen Trust
abstract: In Stockton, Cal., and five other cities, a pilot project seeks racial reconciliation through mutual respect.
lead_paragraph: First of two articles

headline: A Decision Dishonoring the Olympics
abstract: Russia should be banned from the Rio Games for its doping program, but the Olympic organization is letting the nation claim its cheating was isolated.
lead_paragraph: After the World Anti-Doping Agency confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt that the Russian government ran the biggest criminal doping program in the history of international sport, demeaning every notion of what athletic competition stands for, Russian athletes led by a Russian flag will still march at the Olympic opening ceremony in Rio de Janeiro on Aug. 5.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s New Democrats
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s supporters have led the party to its most left-leaning platform in many years.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992 with an agenda that drove the Democratic Party decisively toward the center. Now, as Hillary Clinton comes to Philadelphia to collect her own nomination, history’s pendulum, with a shove from Bernie Sanders, is pressing her party back the other way.

headline: Pope Francis Will Encounter a Socially Conservative Church in Poland
abstract: The more tolerant and inclusive language of the pope, visiting for World Youth Day, is sometimes at odds with the way the faith is taught and understood in Poland.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — When Pope Francis arrives in Poland this week to attend World Youth Day, one of the major events on the Catholic calendar, he will face a politically powerful church closely tied to the country’s new right-wing government. The church here carries a deep strain of social conservatism that does not always align with the pope’s more open and welcoming views.

headline: In a Mining Region, Lingering Echoes of Tunisia’s Uprising
abstract: “West of Life” looks at the troubled history of a region in Tunisia where protests by miners preceded the uprising that led to the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: “West of Life” looks at the troubled history of a region in Tunisia where protests by miners preceded the uprising that led to the Arab Spring.

headline: Sanders Supporters Throw Convention Into Disarray
abstract: The Democratic Party opened its convention to news of an embarrassing email leak, while Senator Bernie Sanders struggled to rally his supporters behind the presumptive nominee, Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party opened its convention to news of an embarrassing email leak, while Senator Bernie Sanders struggled to rally his supporters behind the presumptive nominee, Hillary Clinton.

headline: Grandson of China’s Most-Hated Landlord Challenges Communist Lore
abstract: Liu Xiaofei has spent the past two decades trying to prove that his paternal grandfather, Liu Wencai, actually aided the Communist forces in Sichuan Province.
lead_paragraph: ANREN, China — To many Chinese, Liu Wencai is the archetype of the despotic landlord from pre-Communist days, one who exploited his tenants, tortured those who fell behind on rent in a “water dungeon” and forced new mothers to breast-feed him as a longevity therapy.

headline: Post-‘Brexit’ Vote, Anheuser-Busch InBev Raises Offer for SABMiller
abstract: The sweetened bid for the rival brewer came in response to the sharp drop in the pound in the weeks since Britain voted to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The brewer Anheuser-Busch InBev raised the price it has offered to pay for its rival SABMiller on Tuesday, making it the latest in a series of deals that have been affected — or in some cases driven — by the declining value of the pound after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.

headline: Are You a Young European Working as a Temp? Share Your Thoughts
abstract: The Times wants to hear from young workers in Europe who are stuck in temporary jobs. How is this affecting your life?
lead_paragraph: The Times wants to hear from young workers in Europe who are stuck in temporary jobs. How is this affecting your life?

headline: Is Trump’s Campaign Too Small? Or Is Clinton’s Too Big?
abstract: In terms of spending, this year’s election is pitting a dinghy against an oil tanker — and offering a rare experiment.
lead_paragraph: Despite the view expressed by many commentators that last week’s Republican convention more closely resembled a grand-mal seizure than a smoothly coordinated rollout of a presidential nominee, Donald Trump emerged from Cleveland with exactly the kind of bounce such events are supposed to deliver. A CBS News poll now has Trump slightly ahead in 11 battleground states; FiveThirtyEight also shows him leading Hillary Clinton in Ohio, Florida, Pennsylvania, New Hampshire, Nevada and Iowa. If this lead holds, he would most likely be guaranteed victory on Nov. 8.

headline: Hong Kong Graft Buster’s Exit Stirs Fears Over Agency’s Independence
abstract: The resignation of Rebecca Li has focused attention on one of the anticorruption agency’s most delicate cases, a complaint against the city’s top official.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At Hong Kong’s graft-busting commission, Rebecca Li was a star, helping to bring corrupt tycoons and bent officials to justice. She received commendations for her work, won a coveted spot to train with the F.B.I. and last year became the agency’s most senior career official, a first for a woman.

headline: In a Mining Region, Lingering Echoes of Tunisia’s Uprising
abstract: “West of Life” looks at the troubled history of a region in Tunisia where protests by miners preceded the uprising that led to the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: To many, Tunisia symbolizes the success of the intense popular discontent that sparked the Arab Spring. There, in 2010, Mohamed Bouazizi, a young fruit vendor, set himself on fire, leading to protests that soon had a domino effect in neighboring Arab states. The subsequent ousting of Tunisia’s president, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, put the country on the path to democratic reform, and just last year the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for its role in helping to build that democracy.

headline: Steppes of Dreams: Russians Cling to Hopes of Glory in Baseball
abstract: Fans hope the grand old game, or a Russian sport with similar dynamics, can sustain the sort of passion that will make Olympic organizers take notice in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Some dedicated Russian athletes and businessmen are committed to beating America at its own game: baseball.

headline: De Blasio Administration Says It’s Ahead of Schedule on Affordable Housing
abstract: The mayor’s office announced that 53,000 units had been built or preserved, toward its goal of 200,000 within a decade.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio took office in 2014, he made affordable housing the centerpiece of his administration, vowing to build or preserve 200,000 units over a decade in a city where the cost of shelter was rocketing past the grasp of many residents.

headline: Why Dropping the Trans-Pacific Partnership May Be a Bad Idea
abstract: The pact has few friends left in Washington, but America’s Asian allies may see backing off as a betrayal of Washington’s commitment to the region.
lead_paragraph: It might seem pretty painless, at this juncture, to throw the Trans-Pacific Partnership under the bus.

headline: Brazilian Badminton Sways to Samba
abstract: The Chacrinha neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro is home to Brazil’s first Olympic badminton player. His father, Sebastião Dias de Oliveira, explains how he introduced badminton to the community using samba.
lead_paragraph: The Chacrinha neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro is home to Brazil’s first Olympic badminton player. His father, Sebastião Dias de Oliveira, explains how he introduced badminton to the community using samba.

headline: Keep Your Mouth Closed: Aquatic Olympians Face a Toxic Stew in Rio
abstract: Sewage and trash continue to flow untreated into Rio de Janeiro’s waters, and recent tests found pathogens including rotaviruses and drug-resistant “superbacteria.”
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Health experts in Brazil have a word of advice for the Olympic marathon swimmers, sailors and windsurfers competing in Rio de Janeiro’s picture-postcard waters next month: Keep your mouth closed.

headline: An Unlikely Olympic Story
abstract: Ygor Coelho de Oliveira, one of Brazil’s first badminton Olympians, learned the sport at a facility built by his father at their home in a Rio de Janeiro favela.
lead_paragraph: Ygor Coelho de Oliveira, one of Brazil’s first badminton Olympians, learned the sport at a facility built by his father at their home in a Rio de Janeiro favela.

headline: In Rio Slum, a Gleaming Hotbed of ... Badminton?
abstract: An Olympian got his start at a center hand-built by his father.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — One of the world’s most improbable sports centers is a hulking, light-blue building on a mud-caked alley in Chacrinha, a favela on the western outskirts of Rio de Janeiro. Inside are four gleaming, regulation-size courts for badminton, a game that until recently few Brazilians had ever heard of, let alone played.

headline: Democratic Convention Day 2 Takeaways: History Is Made
abstract: Hillary Clinton became the first female standard-bearer of a major party, and a lineup of Democrats, including former President Bill Clinton, offered revealing testimonials to her.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After formally voting to nominate Hillary Clinton, Democrats capped the occasion with a surprise appearance by their new standard-bearer. Mrs. Clinton briefly addressed the Democratic National Convention from New York, hailing the vote as a historic moment for American women. But before her cameo, a lineup of Democrats offered revealing testimonials to Mrs. Clinton — and new signals about how they plan to contest the fall campaign. Our takeaways:

headline: Australia Promises Inquiry After Video Shows Abuse in Juvenile Detention
abstract: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said he was “shocked and appalled” by a report that showed young detainees in the Northern Territory being shackled and tear-gassed.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced an investigation on Tuesday into the treatment of juvenile detainees in Australia’s far north, saying he was “shocked and appalled” by a news report that showed boys being stripped, sprayed with tear gas at close range and, in one case, shackled to a chair while forced to wear a hood.

headline: ISIS Says Its ‘Soldiers’ Attacked Church in France, Killing Priest
abstract: President François Hollande said that the Islamic State was behind the assault, the latest in a series that has left Europe stunned, fearful and angry.
lead_paragraph: ST.-ÉTIENNE-DU-ROUVRAY, France — Attendance was sparse at the 9 a.m. Mass on Tuesday at the Église St.-Étienne, a 17th-century church in a working-class town in Normandy. Many parishioners were on vacation; so was the parish priest.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton, Solar Impulse: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Morning Agenda: Both Parties Want to Rein In Big Banks
abstract: $40 Billion Leftovers for Yahoo│Fed Prepares Action Against Goldman Sachs
lead_paragraph: BOTH PARTIES WANT TO REIN IN BIG BANKS The Democratic convention has not started with quite the display of unity that Hillary Clinton would have hoped for to stand in contrast to the Republican convention last week, but that’s not the only thing the two parties have in common. Both have inserted the Glass-Steagall rule into their platforms. The act has only a slim chance of returning and it would probably lead to a loss of jobs as lending slows, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes.

headline: New York Today: L Train Alternatives
abstract: Tuesday: Traversing the East River, Commissioner Bratton nears the end of an era, and a subway race.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:12 a.m.

headline: Knife Attacker Wanted to Rid Japan of the Disabled, Authorities Say
abstract: The suspect, a former employee at the residential care center where 19 people were killed, had expressed extreme views about euthanizing disabled people.
lead_paragraph: SAGAMIHARA, Japan — A mass stabbing at a center for people with disabilities outside Tokyo on Tuesday shocked Japan, where violent crimes are extremely rare.

headline: The Oppressive Gospel of ‘Minimalism’
abstract: The movement turns possessions into objects of scorn and disgust — and self-denial into a virtue yet again.
lead_paragraph: It has become an ostentatious ritual of consumerist self-sacrifice; people who have it all now seem to prefer having nothing at all. And, as with watching birds or going Paleo, talking about the material purge is just as important as actually doing it. So there are blog posts — in which you can see minimalism’s can-do optimism curdle into something tyrannical.

headline: The Superhero Photographs of the Black Lives Matter Movement
abstract: Against the grim footage of unjust deaths, iconic images of protesters project power and will.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the photograph of Ieshia Evans began to circulate online, people said she looked like a superhero. There she stands, slim and straight, on a street in Baton Rouge. Her dress, abstractly patterned in black and white, swirls around her. She seems almost to be levitating. Opposite her are the cops, clad in black. They are only two, walking ahead of a phalanx of more than a dozen others. But because of the storm-trooper get-up — the shoulder pads, helmets and what look like rocket-booster backpacks — the two seem like three or four. Their legs advance while their upper bodies lean back, as though recoiling from an unseen force. She is unarmed and unafraid (the open space behind her emphasizes her singularity); they are militarized and unindividuated. The image told such an apparently clear story that when it hit social media, it went viral.

headline: A $1,000 Day in Moscow for $100
abstract: Enjoying Russia’s huge, dynamic capital can take a bit of work. But if you’re willing to put in the effort, the rewards are abundant.
lead_paragraph: It’s the simple things that sometimes present the biggest challenges. I was looking for a way to get to the Four Seasons Moscow, a huge beige box of a building that skirts Red Square in central Moscow — but I couldn’t figure out how to get across the road. The broad Mokhovaya Street stood in my way, imposing, and there were no crosswalks to be found. Jaywalking seemed inadvisable — no one else was doing it, so I wasn’t about to, either. A stairway that led down to a passage under the street eventually got me to my destination, late to my meeting with Gleb Kryuchkov, chief concierge at the hotel, where rooms are decidedly not frugal.

headline: Not Forgotten: George Gallup, Pollster Who Found the Pulse of Democracy
abstract: George H. Gallup pioneered better public polling techniques and helped make polls a critical part of the electoral process.
lead_paragraph: George H. Gallup pioneered better public polling techniques and helped make polls a critical part of the electoral process.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Dress May Have Looked Simple, but It Spoke Volumes
abstract: The first lady, in Christian Siriano, wore more than just a pretty frock. Read between the seams.
lead_paragraph: The first night of the Democratic National Convention on Monday was, rightly, not about the clothes: It was about trying to unify the party, rise above the opponent and so on, as many of my colleagues have described. Which is not to say it lacked a fashion statement or two.

headline: Diversity Questions Raised About Nascent ‘Prince of Egypt’ Musical
abstract: The Bay Street Theater announced plans to hold a concert performance of the developing show next month in a park in Sag Harbor, N.Y.; concerns have come up about the composition of the cast.
lead_paragraph: Concern about a lack of diversity dominated the Oscars this year. Pride about an unusually diverse theater season permeated the Tonys in June.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 4 | On ‘Theresa May’s Style: Put Your Head Down and Get to Work’
abstract: We congratulate this week’s winner, Catherine Zhang, who writes about an article on Britain’s new prime minister, Theresa May, and “how she will lead a deeply divided Britain through the uncertainty that is Brexit.”
lead_paragraph: Week 4 of our Summer Reading Contest ran from July 8 to July 14, days that saw the United States reeling from the attacks on police officers in Dallas and the struggle to find common ground on issues of race, policing and gun violence.

headline: Jacqueline Woodson: When a Southern Town Broke a Heart
abstract: For the author Jacqueline Woodson, a childhood summer in the deep green beauty of Greenville, S.C., revealed her place and time in history.
lead_paragraph: This is part of a series of articles devoted to summer vacations that had an enduring impact on a writer’s life. Other contributors include Sara Novic, Dominique Browning, Francine Prose and Deborah Levy.

headline: Face Plants, Fire Extinguishers and Other Fails: The Olympic Torch Stumbles Toward Rio
abstract: When protesters, pranksters and nonathletic torchbearers converge, things can — and often do — go wrong.
lead_paragraph: The torch relay for the Rio Olympic Games has been a sport of its own — a contact sport.

headline: Vivendi Seeks to Revise Deal for Mediaset’s Pay-TV Arm
abstract: The French giant has proposed buying 20 percent of the pay-TV business and then buying another 15 percent of Mediaset in three years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mediaset, an Italian media company controlled by Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy, said on Tuesday that the French giant Vivendi had backed away from a deal to acquire 100 percent of Mediaset’s pay-TV arm.

headline: In Low-Crime Japan, Rarity of Mass Killings Only Heightens the Shock
abstract: Decades of prosperity, relatively low economic inequality and strict gun laws are among the reasons that Japan is one of the world’s safest countries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Violent crime in Japan, like the deadly knife attack at a center for the disabled in a Tokyo suburb on Tuesday, is all the more shocking because of its rarity. The country is one of the safest in the world, where the murder rate, for example, has declined steadily for half a century.

headline: Shabab Suicide Bombers Kill at Least 12 in Somalia’s Capital
abstract: The blasts occurred near bases for the United Nations and African Union, but the two organizations said that none of their personnel were among the dead.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Suicide bombers from the Shabab militant group killed at least 12 people in Somalia on Tuesday morning, staging attacks near the airport and bases for the United Nations and African Union in the capital, Mogadishu, officials said.

headline: A Commute With Everything
abstract: First a yacht ran into a bridge, and then two guys were throwing punches on the No. 1 train. Good to be home.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1966: Mao’s Feat Raises Eyebrows
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In July 1966, Mao Tse-tung’s good health raises suspicion.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communists’ efforts to prove that party chairman Mao Tse-tung is overflowing with vitality and good health are raising suspicions. Specialists in Hong Kong are intrigued by both the assertive tone of official statements and the number of discrepancies in them. The two latest phenomena in the deliberate campaign to revive the image of a magnificently vital Mao Tse-tung occurred yesterday [July 25]. Mr. Mao, the official New China News Agency declared, had swum nine miles across the Yangtze River on July 16 in the presence of ‘‘tens of thousands of cheering people.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 27, 1966

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Hoping Her Steady Hand Will Be the Key
abstract: Voters may diverge on party alignment, but they agree broadly on qualities they want in a president: judgment, maturity, honesty.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On issues and ideology, the center of American politics has shrunk drastically. The vast majority of voters know which side they’re on.

headline: Mexico’s Wind Farms Brought Prosperity, but Not for Everyone
abstract: Investors have plowed $9 billion into wind farms in Mexico, but some residents, especially in poorer areas, say they have rarely seen the benefits.
lead_paragraph: LA VENTOSA, Mexico — At night, Juan Piñeda López hears the hum of a wind turbine that churns 300 yards away from his adobe house. Sometimes he catches the stench of lubricant that spews down the turbine’s mast.

headline: Kashmir Has Its Own Identity
abstract: Kashmiris wish to emphasize that their land is not real estate that can be parceled out between India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Future of the Past: Modernizing the New York Times Archive
abstract: Thanks to a cross-team migration effort, we’re thrilled to announced that nearly every article published since 2004 is available to our readers with the most current New York Times digital article design.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times recently celebrated its 20th year on the web. Of course, today’s digital platforms differ drastically from those of decades past, and this makes it imperative that we modernize the presentation of archival data.

headline: Building a Better Human With Science? The Public Says, No Thanks
abstract: A new survey shows distrust of scientists, a suspicion about claims of progress and discomfort with the idea of meddling with human abilities.
lead_paragraph: Americans aren’t very enthusiastic about using science to enhance the human species. Instead, many find it rather creepy.

headline: Pax Trumpiana
abstract: Donald, Lucullus, and Sulla.
lead_paragraph: With everything else going on, it may be hard to stay with the evolving Trump/Putin story. But it’s really crucial. I don’t think Trump is literally an agent of the Kremlin; instead, he’s someone Putin is aiding because he knows Trump is close to, probably financially entangled with friendly oligarchs. And equally important, Putin knows that Trump’s combination of ignorance and greed would quickly undermine the Western alliance: already we have, incredibly, a presidential candidate essentially proposing that we turn NATO into a protection racket, in which countries get defended only if they pay up.

headline: Suicide Bombers Target Somali Capital
abstract: At least 13 people were killed Tuesday morning when suicide bombers from the Shabab militant group detonated car bombs in Somalia's capital, Mogadishu.
lead_paragraph: At least 13 people were killed Tuesday morning when suicide bombers from the Shabab militant group detonated car bombs in Somalia's capital, Mogadishu.

headline: How a Homeless Teenager’s Viral Story Caused a Battle Over GoFundMe Money
abstract: A fund to help Fred Barley, 19, an aspiring college student in Georgia, raised $184,000. Now there are suspicions about where the money was going.
lead_paragraph: When a homeless teenager named Fred Barley rode a bicycle some 50 miles into Barnesville, Ga., this month, he set up a small tent in a clump of bushes near Gordon State College, where he had registered. When two police officers found him, he told them he wanted to get a job before classes started.

headline: 1916: Bacon and Lard Exports Startle Judge
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Rise in American exports of lard and bacon startle a New York judge, July 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Evidence regarding the increase in American exports of provisions to Europe since the outbreak of war was given yesterday [July 25] during the hearing in the Prize Court of the Crown’s application for condemnation of 3,200 tons of foodstuffs seized on the American ship Maracas. The compilation showed an enormous increase of bacon and lard exports from New York following the outbreak of the war. Sir Maurice Hill, K.C. for Messrs. Sulzberger and Sons, submitted that there was no proof that the destination of their consignments was Germany. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 27, 1916

headline: Dolly the Sheep’s Fellow Clones, Enjoying Their Golden Years
abstract: Scientists have answered a longstanding question about whether cloned animals age prematurely.
lead_paragraph: Dolly the Sheep started her life in a test tube in 1996 and died just six years later. When she was only a year old, there was evidence that she might have been physically older. At five, she was diagnosed with osteoarthritis. And at six, a CT scan revealed tumors growing in her lungs, likely the result of an incurable infectious disease. Rather than let Dolly suffer, the vets put her to rest.

headline: Goldman Sachs Is Sued Over Ties to Malaysia’s Prime Minister
abstract: A private equity firm asserts that Goldman Sachs provided bad advice to one of its clients to help the scandal-plagued administration of Najib Razak.
lead_paragraph: A private equity firm is suing Goldman Sachs, accusing it in court documents filed on Tuesday of improperly trying to curry favor with the scandal-plagued prime minister of Malaysia.

headline: Yes, Slaves Did Help Build the White House
abstract: Michelle Obama, speaking at the Democratic Convention, said she lived in a home built by slaves. Some were taken aback, but history supports her.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Michelle Obama said in her prime-time televised address to the Democratic National Convention on Monday night that the White House had been built by slaves, she was citing a little-discussed fact that dramatized her own African-American family’s place in history.

headline: Activists Call for Realistic Portrayal of Vietnam War on a Pentagon Website
abstract: For two years, a committee has been seeking changes to what it calls a rose-colored portrayal of the conflict on a website commemorating its 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While serving stateside during the Vietnam War, David Cortright took to the streets in his uniform, on base and off, to pass out pamphlets describing atrocities committed by American troops and calling for an end to the fighting.

headline: How Many Mayors Can Puerto Rico Afford? Tradition and Budgets Collide
abstract: As the island struggles under debt and a federal control board prepares to take charge of its finances, some see its 78 municipalities as ripe for consolidation.
lead_paragraph: QUEBRADILLAS, P.R. — Far from the bustle of the capital, San Juan, in places where time walks slowly, jobs are scarce and colonial history dates to the era of pirates, some of Puerto Rico’s most powerful figures — municipal mayors — spend their days obliging, cajoling and demanding.

headline: Deep Thinking About Immigration
abstract: Immigration is an emotional issue. Three new books offer rational perspective.
lead_paragraph: From Hobbes and Hegel to John Stuart Mill and John Rawls, the seminal figures of Western political theory are united in their almost complete neglect of the topic of immigration. No doubt they have their reasons. Who among them witnessed anything like the global refugee crisis of 2015? Or the anxieties about national identity that it inflamed? Be that as it may, with hostility toward immigrants and refugees fueling the “Brexit” movement and the presidential campaign of Donald J. Trump, we could use some deep thinking right now about the relationship between the state and its citizens. This deep thinking would no longer start with the assumption that we already know who is included in that relationship (thanks for nothing, John Locke!), but rather would inquire how, in light of often conflicting values like local democracy and global justice, we should go about figuring that out.

headline: Russians at the Rio Olympics: Who’s in, and Who’s Out?
abstract: A sport-by-sport look at which athletes, so far, have been cleared by individual sports federations to compete in Rio after the I.O.C.’s decision not to bar the entire Russian team.
lead_paragraph: When the International Olympic Committee declined to bar the entire Russian team from the Summer Games, it largely passed off the decision on Russian athletes and teams to the individual international sports federations. The opening ceremony in Rio de Janeiro is on Aug. 5, so the federations must swiftly determine which Russian athletes will be allowed to compete.

headline: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2, Episode 8: ‘That’s Not This Story’
abstract: This episode is a reminder that storytelling is deliberate, and that not all stories work.
lead_paragraph: There’s a hypnotic quality to watching things fall apart. Take “Fugitive,” this week’s episode of “UnREAL.” It’s so busy that it reaches for familiar shapes instead of trying to dig new ground, and ends up tripping over subplots that are too thin, and a big reveal that’s already casting a shadow over next season.

headline: Easy Editing for Mac Photos
abstract: Apple’s Photos for OS X has a button for one-click improvements to your pictures, but it also includes a toolbox for more detailed adjustments.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is the “Enhance” button in the Mac’s Photos for OS X program actually doing to make a picture look nicer? It seems to do better with some shots than others.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Convention: Day 2
abstract: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.
lead_paragraph: Arguments, provocations and observations from Times Opinion writers.

headline: What Goes Up Must Come Down: The End of Yahoo as We Know It
abstract: The sale of Yahoo’s core web business to Verizon for $4.83 billion caps a long downward spiral for the onetime pioneer, which at its height was valued at $125 billion.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry is constantly dealing with the push and pull of two opposing forces: ascendant stars counterbalanced by declining players. Both of these forces are on display this week.

headline: 4 Easy Sunny-Day Hairstyles
abstract: A great beach selfie doesn’t make itself. A cool hairstyle helps.
lead_paragraph: Beach hair: It sounds achievable simply by going to the beach while having hair. Or, at most, a result of mixing said hair with salty sea air.

headline: Boos, Cheers and Talk Therapy for the Democrats in Philadelphia
abstract: Wounds were ripped open, but a slate of speakers led by Michelle Obama and Bernie Sanders steadied the first night of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: He led millions of voters to feel the Bern. On Monday night in Philadelphia, the Democratic Party needed Bernie Sanders to keep the blaze under control.

headline: $1 Billion for Dollar Shave Club: Why Every Company Should Worry
abstract: The internet, mass transportation and globalization allow decentralized companies to be smaller and leaner and have fewer employees.
lead_paragraph: Unilever is paying $1 billion for Dollar Shave Club, a five-year-old start-up that sells razors and other personal products for men. Every other company should be afraid, very afraid.

headline: Democrats Make Hillary Clinton a Historic Nominee
abstract: The party is looking to move beyond lingering anger and unite behind the first woman to represent a major American political party in a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Democratic convention formally nominated Hillary Clinton for president on Tuesday, making history by choosing a woman to be the first standard-bearer of a major political party, a breakthrough underscored by a deeply personal speech by Bill Clinton calling her “the best darn change-maker I have ever known.”

headline: U.S. to Admit More Central American Refugees
abstract: The Obama administration will broaden the effort to allow families of children fleeing dangerous conditions to enter the United States with them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Tuesday announced a substantial expansion of a program to admit Central American refugees to the United States, conceding that its efforts to protect migrants fleeing dangerous conditions had left too many people with no recourse.

headline: Pasquale Jones
abstract: The team behind Charlie Bird opens an Italian restaurant in Little Italy.
lead_paragraph: The team behind Charlie Bird opens an Italian restaurant in Little Italy.

headline: Pasquale Jones Brings a Little Novelty to Little Italy
abstract: A new restaurant from the Charlie Bird team dabbles in pizzas and pastas, and specializes in wine.
lead_paragraph: As a New Yorker who wants each neighborhood to be different, each block to be like a pocket with a secret tucked inside it, I have strongly mixed feelings about gentrification. As a critic confronted with shiny new restaurants in changing neighborhoods, though, I have to admit that I often end up liking the shiny new places more than what came before.

headline: A Beer Garden Lays Down Roots for a Technology Hub
abstract: Plans call for Makers Quarter to have offices, stores and housing one day; for now, a beer garden, event space and community garden are attractions.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — At lunchtime on a Thursday, people seated at picnic tables dotting the Quartyard sip coffee from Meshuggah Shack. Music wafts from speakers, and the scent of sausages from S&M Sausage and Meat fills the air.

headline: ‘Arrest Me,’ Convention Protesters Say, but Police Officers Show Restraint
abstract: Those taking part in the demonstrations want to be taken into custody, if it will accentuate their cause. But the police seem to be using constraint more than their handcuffs.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The young man in the gray T-shirt grabbed a metal barricade outside the Wells Fargo Center on Monday afternoon and tried to haul himself over. Police officers on the other side pushed him back. Again, the man tried to cross the barrier, only to be pushed back a second time.

headline: Deutsche Börse Shareholders Approve London Stock Exchange Merger
abstract: At least 60 percent of the German stock exchange operator’s outstanding shares were pledged in support of the transaction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Deutsche Börse said on Tuesday that it had gathered enough support from shareholders for its merger with the London Stock Exchange Group to proceed.

headline: Strong Start for Four Seasons Auction
abstract: Early bidding is robust for midcentury furniture and objects from the birthplace of the power lunch.
lead_paragraph: With water jets gurgling in the background at the Pool Room, auctioneers on Tuesday began the breakfast-hour dispersal of the contents of the Four Seasons, a restaurant storied as the birthplace of the power lunch.

headline: Last Charges Dropped Against Abortion Foes in Making of Planned Parenthood Video
abstract: Two activists indicted after they covertly recorded a meeting with Planned Parenthood officials had all charges against them dropped, a lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A judge dismissed Tuesday the last of the charges against two anti-abortion activists who covertly recorded a video of themselves meeting with Planned Parenthood officials, effectively ending a case that had drawn national attention from both opponents and supporters of abortion rights.

headline: Why Home Solar Panels No Longer Pay in Some States
abstract: Utility regulators are upending the financial dynamics of residential solar as they try to meet their obligations to customers who don’t have roof panels.
lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, Calif. — It was only two years ago that Elroy Holtmann spent about $20,000 on a home solar array to help cover the costs of charging his new electric car. With the savings on his monthly electric bills, he figured the investment would pay for itself in about a dozen years.

headline: During Miami’s Low Season, Discounts at Hotels and Spas
abstract: Hotels, spas and restaurants in Miami and Miami Beach are offering deals all summer long.
lead_paragraph: The words “Miami” and “value” aren’t commonly found in the same sentence, but for a chunk of the year, from summer through fall, a surprising number of deals and discounts can be found.

headline: Indiana Republicans Choose Eric Holcomb to Run for Governor in Mike Pence’s Place
abstract: The state party chose Mr. Holcomb, the lieutenant governor, after scrambling to select a candidate in the wake of Mr. Pence’s move to join the Republican presidential ticket.
lead_paragraph: A committee of top Indiana Republicans picked a new candidate for governor on Tuesday, filling a sudden gap left when Gov. Mike Pence was tapped as Donald J. Trump’s running mate.

headline: Floyd Cardoz Returns to Indian Cooking at Paowalla
abstract: A new home for the former Tabla chef, a spot for Korean small plates, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Paowalla In the five years since he closed Tabla, the chef Floyd Cardoz has cooked at North End Grill and opened Bombay Canteen in Mumbai, India. Now he is back in New York with a restaurant he describes as “more Indian than Tabla.” Its focus is the food of Goa on India’s west coast, where he grew up, which is notable for its Portuguese influence. Take the name: Pao are Portuguese buns, usually made with cheese. Here they look like elongated Parker House rolls and can be ordered with fillings, in the street-food style called wada pao. Much of the menu adapts local seasonal ingredients to Indian dishes, like fried squash blossom pakoras. Pork dishes include ribs vindaloo and a sausage and bacon biryani that suggests fried rice. There’s a bread bar in the middle of the simply decorated room, which Mr. Cardoz said is meant to suggest his grandmother’s house. “It had a yellow front, just like we have here,” he said: 195 Spring Street (Sullivan Street), 212-235-1098, paowalla.com.

headline: David Duke’s Remarks on Senate Backing Put Donald Trump’s Camp on the Defensive
abstract: The former Ku Klux Klan leader said that the Republican presidential nominee might still support him in his Senate run, despite the Trump campaign’s continued disavowal.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Yahoo Is a Case Study in Poor Timing
abstract: The company’s $4.8 billion sale to Verizon caps two decades of deals and non-deals that shaped internet history.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo has fittingly closed a portal on tech mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Production Company Guilty in Harrison Ford’s ‘Star Wars’ Injury
abstract: Two years after Mr. Ford’s leg was broken and ankle dislocated, a Disney subsidiary has accepted responsibility for workplace safety breaches.
lead_paragraph: Two years after the actor Harrison Ford was badly injured on the set of “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” by a hydraulic door on the Millennium Falcon starship, a Disney subsidiary has accepted responsibility for workplace safety breaches at Pinewood Studios, near London.

headline: Needing Time to Recover, Roger Federer Will Miss the Rest of the Season
abstract: Federer, 34, said a knee injury sustained early in the year required more rehabilitation, forcing a long absence that includes the Olympics and the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer announced Tuesday that he would miss the rest of the tennis season, including the Rio Olympics and the United States Open, to rehabilitate a knee injury.

headline: Sweetgreen Makes Healthful Fast Food — But Can You Afford It?
abstract: The fast-food chain Sweetgreen has proved there is a big appetite for more healthful fast food, but so far nobody has been able to translate the concept to poor areas that need it most.
lead_paragraph: Healthful, fast and affordable food is the holy grail of the public health and nutrition community. A popular restaurant chain shows just how much of a challenge that is.

headline: Jacques Hamel, 85, a Beloved French Priest, Killed in His Church
abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the knife attack on Father Hamel as he was celebrating Mass.
lead_paragraph: Like many people who enjoy their work, the Rev. Jacques Hamel did not want to stop. At 85, he was well past retirement age, but he kept in shape and kept on going — baptizing infants, celebrating Mass and tending to parishioners in St.-Étienne-du-Rouvray, the working-class town in Normandy where he had spent much of his life.

headline: Photographs From Tuesday at the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

headline: A Worry if Hillary Clinton Wins: What to Do With Bill
abstract: Clinton aides are addressing a potentially thorny problem: Historically, when Mr. Clinton has time on his hands, he can create dangerous distractions for his wife.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman Continues to Deny C.T.E. Link
abstract: He blames the news media for the prevailing belief that blows to the head can cause long-term brain damage.
lead_paragraph: Responding to written questions from a United States senator about the effects of concussions in hockey, N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman continued to deny a link between concussions and the brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E.

headline: Photographs From the Democratic Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Food Fails: The Presidential Edition
abstract: Where there is political opportunity, there are gaffes.
lead_paragraph: Where there is political opportunity, there are gaffes.

headline: When Will Food Issues Be on Politicians’ Plates?
abstract: In the Democratic and Republican platforms, there’s been no battle cry over what we eat. But maybe it’s just a matter of time.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — After a long day at the Republican National Convention, protesters, delegates and reporters shuffled past the entrance to Mabel’s BBQ, Michael Symon’s restaurant in the heart of downtown.

headline: Bettman Responds to C.T.E. Concerns
abstract: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman's 24-page response to Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, who in June sent the commissioner a series of questions about the effects of concussions in hockey.
lead_paragraph: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman's 24-page response to Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, who in June sent the commissioner a series of questions about the effects of concussions in hockey.
