headline: Helping Suicidal Veterans
abstract: A reader writes that the V.A. must pay suicide prevention counselors more “to attract the most qualified and dedicated people.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Feuds! Favors! Name-Calling! But What About Those Russians?
abstract: The salacious details of cyberattacks draw the biggest headlines, but are they the biggest part of the story?
lead_paragraph: It’s a pretty sensational story, this flood of leaked emails that brought down the chairwoman of the Democratic Party. They contained the kind of salacious details a Washington reporter could salivate over for weeks, and probably will — feuds, favor-trading, name-calling between politicians and donors and the media. For reporters it was a blessed piece of news for a political convention, typically rather scripted affairs.

headline: Hunger in Working Families
abstract: A social service agency official writes, “When families are struggling to buy groceries, they are usually also struggling with other challenges of poverty.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: France and National Identity
abstract: A political scientist writes that France is “hardly exceptional” in enforcing values of national identity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Popularity of Donald Trump’s Racism
abstract: A sociology professor asks why.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Bernie Sanders Factor at the Democratic Convention
abstract: Early in the convention, much of the talk was about Senator Sanders and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Getting the Lowdown on High Heels in China
abstract: “Actually, your questions are a bit stupid,” said Chen Yan, the man behind the website sharpheel.com. Our thick-skinned correspondent took the conversation “in stride.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Didi Kirsten Tatlow, a Beijing-based Times correspondent, recounts a funny thing that happened on the way to her upcoming Sinosphere column on high heels.

headline: Into Corsica, From Rustic Villages to Stony Cliffs
abstract: A revelatory trip off the beaten path in Corsica reveals a resilient and dramatically beautiful island that holds itself apart from mainland France.
lead_paragraph: One reason the French island of Corsica can feel so bracing to a visitor is that — and I mean this in the best way possible — Corsicans don’t much care about you.

headline: Come On Along With Us
abstract: Exciting news: We’re moving, and you’re coming with us.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Exciting news: On Monday, August 1, Wordplay becomes a daily column in the digital New York Times.

headline: A French Chef Is Making Sure Leftovers Don’t Get Left Behind
abstract: Antoine Westermann’s Le Coq Rico, with branches in Paris and New York, has embraced and elevated the doggie bag, adding alluring recipes.
lead_paragraph: One of the first high-end restaurants in France to embrace the concept of le doggie bag was Le Coq Rico, a Parisian temple to roast chicken opened by the chef Antoine Westermann in 2012. The restaurant specializes in whole roast birds, and diners are encouraged to experience the chicken in its entirety: from egg to table, from cockscomb to tail feathers.

headline: Should You Get Screened for Skin Cancer?
abstract: To help you decide, here are some guideposts on skin cancer research and the views of some experts.
lead_paragraph: Every summer as Americans slather on sun lotion, they are reminded of the dangers of skin cancer.

headline: Robert Fano, 98, Dies; Engineer Who Helped Develop Interactive Computers
abstract: In the early 1960s, Dr. Fano and others developed a time-sharing operating system, which signaled a shift to a more interactive computing world.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fano, an electrical engineer who was instrumental in creating a world of instantly responsive computers, died on July 13 in Naples, Fla. He was 98.

headline: Review: In ‘Nerve,’ a Shy Girl Seduced by the Internet
abstract: Tired of playing it safe, a high-school senior joins a reality-style online game that soon escalates into dangerous stunts.
lead_paragraph: Pretending to warn us of online dangers, “Nerve” succeeds mainly in showing us how exhilarating it can be to embrace them.

headline: Journalists Targets of Purge in Turkey
abstract: Journalists are the latest to be caught up in the spate of arrests in Turkey after a failed military coup.
lead_paragraph: Journalists are the latest to be caught up in the spate of arrests in Turkey after a failed military coup.

headline: Marissa Mayer’s Media Problem at Yahoo Is Now Verizon’s to Solve
abstract: Before she led Yahoo, while still at Google, Ms. Mayer spoke of the difficulties for media companies of capitalizing on their own content.
lead_paragraph: In the end, the deal that Yahoo announced on Monday, that Verizon Communications would buy its internet business for $4.8 billion, looked more like an escape than an exit. Yahoo, once at the center of the consumer web, had been pushed to the margins, overwhelmed by direct competition and generational change.

headline: Bill Clinton, a Convention Fixture
abstract: For a generation, this has been a safe bet: If it’s a Democratic convention, Bill Clinton will be making a speech there that people will remember. The Times White House correspondent Mark Landler explains.
lead_paragraph: For a generation, this has been a safe bet: If it’s a Democratic convention, Bill Clinton will be making a speech there that people will remember. The Times White House correspondent Mark Landler explains.

headline: With No Heroes in Sight, the Big Apple Circus Will Fold Its Tent
abstract: The beloved New York nonprofit circus has announced that it is ending its public performances after failing to raise the $2 million it said it needed to stay viable.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 1981, the Big Apple Circus will not pitch its single-ring tent behind Lincoln Center for its holiday-season run this year.

headline: The Starliner Serves Stiff Drinks and Big Booths in Bushwick
abstract: Tucked under the elevated M line, the bar evokes the ballroom of a midcentury cruise liner.
lead_paragraph: Before the cocktail wizards came along, Brooklyn bars relied on an unfussy mix of low-price drinks, loud music and loose morals to draw patrons. Those days are back at the Starliner, a boat-shaped beer-and-shot bar now moored in the backwaters of Bushwick.

headline: Review: A Gussied-Up Gala of Mozart Opera Excerpts
abstract: “The Illuminated Heart,” which opened the Mostly Mozart Festival, was prettily staged and entertaining but skewed toward the most familiar works.
lead_paragraph: The Mostly Mozart Festival is now in many ways unrecognizable from its ancestor, “Midsummer Serenades — A Mozart Festival,” which began in 1966 when Lincoln Center’s new theaters opened, complete with air-conditioning.

headline: Youree Dell Harris, the TV Psychic Miss Cleo, Dies at 53
abstract: Ms. Harris’s Jamaican-accented character entered America’s pop culture zeitgeist in the late ’90s with the catchphrase, “Call me now!”
lead_paragraph: Youree Dell Harris, whose Jamaican-accented character Miss Cleo was the face (and voice) of ubiquitous psychic hotline commercials in the late 1990s before the company was fined by the federal government, died on Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 53.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Alissa J. Rubin, Randy Archibold and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Review: Hieronymus Bosch, for Whom the Devil Was Always in the Details
abstract: Pieter van Huystee’s new documentary chronicles the preparation for a historic museum show and the quest to authenticate several paintings as Bosch’s work.
lead_paragraph: In Pieter van Huystee’s new documentary, “Hieronymus Bosch: Touched by the Devil,” there is a bizarre, almost comical disconnect between the artworks assembled for a historic exhibition and the fuss surrounding its preparation. The show, which ran earlier this year at the Noordbrabants Museum in ’s-Hertogenbosch, in the southern Netherlands, commemorated the 500th anniversary of this Dutch painter’s death.

headline: Review: A Sublime and Provocative ‘Parsifal’ at Bayreuth
abstract: This new Wagner production, directed by Uwe Eric Laufenberg, focuses on what unites us, across and beyond religious lines.
lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — A large security force, with police officers and checkpoints, was present on Monday for the opening of this summer’s Bayreuth Festival, featuring the premiere of a new production of Wagner’s “Parsifal.” This was understandable, given the tensions here in southern Germany after a spate of violent attacks — four in just the last week, at least two of which were perpetrated by individuals claiming ties to radical Islamic groups.

headline: In Defense of Candid Reviews, Minus the Nastiness
abstract: A critic revisiting Cape Cod in the high season muses about “The Kritik,” a satire about theater, criticism and the nature of community in a small town.
lead_paragraph: WELLFLEET, Mass. — I was early for a performance here last week, so I took my sandals off and went for a barefoot stroll along the beach, on the hard, wet sand below the high-tide line. Not the sort of thing I had time to do eons ago, when I was a baby theater critic on Cape Cod, where the residents work long summer hours while the tourists play.

headline: Three New Seaside West Coast Resorts to Book This Summer
abstract: These California cool escapes offer everything from a total mind-body reboot to the perfect plate of fish and chips.
lead_paragraph: In the mountains of Malibu, 23 fertile ocean-view acres once owned by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt have been renovated by an Australian mystic and artist, Inannya Magick, into a new health and wellness sanctuary that opens next month. Guests will check in for a weeklong mind-body-spirit tuneup, complete with a restorative cleanse to rebalance the body’s seven chakras. In addition to sustainable design (reclaimed wood, a sustainable cooling system, solar-powered heat) the seven guest suites and gardens will feature walls and walkways embedded with thousands of crushed rose quartz crystals, and carved with blessings — to channel the energy of the heart.

headline: Review: On the High Seas, Anything Goes in ‘The Pirates of Penzance’
abstract: This operetta, guided by the trademark silliness of Gilbert & Sullivan, takes the audience along for a buoyant trip on the high seas.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — It’s hard to imagine more ideal summer entertainment than the exhilarating production of “The Pirates of Penzance” swashbuckling across the stage — and often tumbling merrily off it — at the Barrington Stage Company here. Rarely have I felt an audience and a cast coming together in such a happy communal bear hug. And we could all use one right now, no?

headline: Testing Comedy’s Role as a Beacon on Racial Issues
abstract: On CW, “MADtv” gets a revival, while A&E tackles race with “Black and White.”
lead_paragraph: Can comedy guide us through our most vexing issues and problems? Perhaps we’ll know more Wednesday night after A&E’s premiere of “Black and White,” an eight-episode series in which comedians take on race in the United States. Another new comedy show, though, seems reluctant to become the catalyst that it could be.

headline: The Professional Pop-Up Artist
abstract: Rirkrit Tiravanija’s culinary art projects have increasingly gotten the food world’s attention. This time, in Berlin, will one lead to a permanent restaurant?
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer evening in Berlin, the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija and the former model and self-trained cook Dalad Kambhu, both from Thailand, were cooking in the professional kitchen and HQ of Freunde von Freunden, a Berlin-based design blog. The two friends were happily tweaking Thai recipes by replacing traditional ingredients with local staples to make dishes like jungle venison curry, a green papaya salad that used kohlrabi rather than young papaya and a glass noodle salad with smoked trout. They ended up with about a dozen dishes for their two-week-long pop-up restaurant that opened today at Dottir, a Nordic dining room in the Mitte borough of Berlin. They will take the place of Dottir’s young chef Victoria Eliasdottir (the half sister of the likewise culinarily inclined artist Olafur Eliasson, who has his own cookbook); she will be cooking in Hong Kong for the next two weeks.

headline: DJ Khaled and His ‘Major Key’ World
abstract: This artist held a listening session for his new album, and it was a chance to see him at his self-promoting best.
lead_paragraph: On a recent muggy evening, the music producer, Snapchat philosopher and Beyoncé tour mate DJ Khaled sat at a mixing board in a recording studio six floors above Times Square enjoying a large sundae. A scrum of journalists, photographers and record label employees waited for permission to enter the control room, where DJ Khaled, a 40-year-old artist known for his collaborations with hip-hop and R&B’s biggest stars, was to play his new album, “Major Key,” out this Friday.

headline: The Scene at the Democratic Convention: Hunger, Heat and Storms
abstract: Stormy protests and actual thunderstorms disrupted delegates in Philadelphia, while long lines inside the arena made for hungry attendees.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — With email leaks, jeering delegates and the chairwoman’s resignation, the Democratic National Convention was chaotic even before the first prime-time speech.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $3.6 million

headline: Apple’s iPhone Sales Drop Again, but Services Are a Bright Spot
abstract: A second quarter of dismal sales leaves analysts wondering: Are customers out of love with Apple, or just waiting for the latest products?
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Have consumers lost their affection for Apple gadgets, or are they just waiting for the new iPhones to come out in September?

headline: Review: The Radical Transformation of Patricia Hearst
abstract: Jeffrey Toobin’s “American Heiress” gives new resonance to an American crime story that had tremendous notoriety in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: “American Heiress,” Jeffrey Toobin’s new book about Patty Hearst, is a clever companion piece to “The Run of His Life” (1996), his book about the O. J. Simpson case. Mr. Toobin has used the same winning formula of delving deeply into an American crime story that had tremendous notoriety in its day and retelling it with new resonance.

headline: A Prized Stettheimer Painting, Sold Under the Radar by a University
abstract: Fisk University’s quiet sale of Florine Stettheimer’s “Asbury Park South” highlights the minefield institutions must navigate when they use proceeds from art.
lead_paragraph: When Fisk University, the historically black school in Nashville, tried to sell two paintings several years ago from its storied Alfred Stieglitz art collection, a firestorm erupted. The proposed sale violated conditions of the gift of the collection from Stieglitz’s widow, Georgia O’Keeffe, according to her foundation.

headline: The Democrats (Try to) Grow Up
abstract: Hillary Clinton and her party are trying to cement their standing as the adults in the room this year — if the Bernie Sanders faithful will let them.
lead_paragraph: Probably the most remarkable and unexpected thing about the Bernie-or-busters’ showing at this week’s Democratic National Convention so far has been their ability to make a noisy, newsy spectacle out of the dullest of convention rituals, the delegation breakfast. Normally, these events are a forgettable festival of Sterno-heated sausages, sweaty carafes and hangover gas. A veteran politician with a national profile will probably hit between 12 and 16 of them in a week like this, if you assume about three or four a day multiplied by four convention mornings. I once asked Tom Harkin, then a Democratic senator from Iowa, whether any of the dozens of convention breakfasts he had attended in his career were memorable for any reason. He shrugged and simply said, “Blurrrr.”

headline: Bernie Sanders, Michelle Obama, France: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: The Trans-Pacific Partnership Trade Accord Explained
abstract: The giant trade pact, years in the making, has become a cornerstone of President Obama’s trade policy in his final term.
lead_paragraph: The Trans-Pacific Partnership, the largest regional trade accord in history, would set new terms for trade and business investment among the United States and 11 other Pacific Rim nations — a far-flung group with an annual gross domestic product of nearly $28 trillion that represents roughly 40 percent of global G.D.P. and one-third of world trade.

headline: Sarah Silverman on Bernie or Bust, and the Joke She Didn’t Tell
abstract: Ms. Silverman discusses her spontaneous appeal from the stage to the upset Bernie or Bust faction of Democrats at the party convention — and more.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Silverman has delivered many memorable lines in her career, but for now, she is perhaps most closely associated with these words she spoke onstage at the Democratic National Convention on Monday night: “Can I just say, to the Bernie or Bust people: You’re being ridiculous.”

headline: ‘An American in Paris’ to Close Earlier Than Expected
abstract: The Broadway musical had announced that it would close on Jan. 1, but on Tuesday the producers told the cast that it would instead close on Oct. 9.
lead_paragraph: “An American in Paris” is bidding adieu to Broadway earlier than expected.

headline: German Mood Is Shaken as Attacks Show Vulnerability to ISIS
abstract: A spate of violence has left Germans longing for a sense of order and questioning the wisdom of opening their doors to migrants.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After a week bookended by terrorist attacks, Germans are now clear that they, too, are targets of the Islamic State, leaving them longing for the sense of order that is their pride and bedrock of success.

headline: Assange, Avowed Foe of Clinton, Timed Email Release for Democratic Convention
abstract: Julian Assange, WikiLeaks founder, suggested in a June interview that he opposed Mrs. Clinton on policy grounds and saw her as a personal foe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six weeks before the anti-secrecy organization WikiLeaks published an archive of hacked Democratic National Committee emails ahead of the Democratic convention, the organization’s founder, Julian Assange, foreshadowed the release — and made it clear that he hoped to harm Hillary Clinton’s chances of winning the presidency.

headline: Democratic Convention Night 2: Analysis
abstract: How we analyzed in real time the second night of the Democratic National Convention, featuring Bill Clinton, Madeleine Albright and Lena Dunham.
lead_paragraph: How we analyzed in real time the second night of the Democratic National Convention, featuring Bill Clinton, Madeleine Albright and Lena Dunham.

headline: Democratic Convention Night 2: What You Missed
abstract: After a turbulent beginning to Democratic National Convention, members of the party heard from Lena Dunham, Madeleine Albright and former President Bill Clinton, the night’s main attraction.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After a turbulent beginning to their convention, Democrats nominated Hillary Clinton for president on Tuesday, making her the first woman to lead a major party’s ticket in the United States. They then turned to hear from a lineup of speakers that included Lena Dunham, Madeleine Albright and former President Bill Clinton, the night’s main attraction.

headline: W.H.O. Weighs Dropping Transgender Identity From List of Mental Disorders
abstract: A proposal to remove the designation from international guidelines is rapidly gaining support, and would lessen stigmatization.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization is moving toward declassifying transgender identity as a mental disorder in its global list of medical conditions, with a new study lending additional support to a proposal that would delete the decades-old designation.

headline: Twitter, Grappling with Anemic Growth, Tries to Bolster Its Advertising Business
abstract: The company, which reported its worst quarterly revenue growth ever, is betting on live streaming video and direct response advertising to combat stagnant demand.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This week brought a stark reminder of what can happen to internet businesses that are overtaken by rivals: Yahoo, an iconic web company that lost out to Facebook and Google, agreed to sell its core internet operations to Verizon for a fraction of its peak value.

headline: When a Boy Caught Sight of Ali
abstract: A recollection of seeing the Greatest about to get into a limousine, climbing up a light pole to watch him, and getting a raised-fist salute.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Fiat Chrysler Revises Sales Data Lower After Doubts Raised
abstract: The carmaker, suspected of inflating reports, said its 75 consecutive months of sales growth actually ended three years ago.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, Fiat Chrysler has been acclaiming a long run of rising new-car sales. At last count, it had higher vehicle sales 75 months in a row.

headline: New Yorkers Greet the Arrival of Wi-Fi Kiosks With Panic, Skepticism and Relief
abstract: If all goes according to the plan, the booths will be as commonplace as pay phones once were: more than 7,500, spread throughout every neighborhood of the city.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to acceptance of New York City’s rapidly growing network of sidewalk kiosks offering “free super fast Wi-Fi,” some people are Nekeya Browns and some are Alex Padillas.

headline: New York State Makes It Legal to Cry in Your Funeral Pie
abstract: A new law in New York State allows funeral parlors to serve light refreshments and nonalcoholic drinks, joining 46 other states that allow some eating and drinking during services.
lead_paragraph: In the West, a homey casserole of slivered potatoes, sour cream and canned mushroom soup is so often served at wakes and memorials that it is commonly known as “funeral potatoes.” In Pennsylvania Dutch country, the go-to dish is a custard and raisin pastry called “funeral pie.”

headline: Mass Killings May Have Created Contagion, Feeding on Itself
abstract: A small number of people with strong personal grievances appear to be mining previous rampages for methods and potential targets to plan their own attacks.
lead_paragraph: The horrifying rash of massacres during this violent summer suggests that public, widely covered rampage killings have led to a kind of contagion, prompting a small number of people with strong personal grievances and scant political ideology to mine previous attacks for both methods and potential targets to express their lethal anger and despair.

headline: In Williamsburg, Pondering Life Without the L Train
abstract: The Brooklyn neighborhood’s next chapter is likely to be defined by how it weathers the loss of its main subway line to Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Williamsburg neighborhood in Brooklyn has had plenty of incarnations of late: industrial waterfront; hipster hub; a village of expensive high-rises, soon to be christened by the borough’s first Apple store.

headline: For Different Reasons, Phil Mickelson and Jordan Spieth Practice Patience
abstract: Separated by 24 years in age, the two stars practiced together Tuesday. Mickelson is rebounding from another runner-up finish while Spieth is trying to reclaim his spot atop the golf world.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Jordan Spieth continues to tell people he is not in a slump. Phil Mickelson must once again expound on the heartbreak of another second-place finish in a major championship.

headline: Mohamed Khan, Egyptian Filmmaker, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Khan drew popular and critical acclaim for his neorealist films, which focused on social ills and often featured feminist protagonists.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Khan, one of Egypt’s leading directors, whose films focused on social ills and often featured feminist protagonists, died on Tuesday in Cairo. He was 73.

headline: At World’s Largest Hedge Fund, Sex, Fear and Video Surveillance
abstract: One employee’s complaint, as well as interviews with people who have worked for Bridgewater, describe an atmosphere of surveillance that silences those who don’t fit the mold.
lead_paragraph: Ray Dalio, the billionaire founder of the world’s largest hedge fund, Bridgewater Associates, likes to say that one of his firm’s core operating principles is “radical transparency” when it comes to airing employee grievances and concerns.

headline: Henrik Stenson Hopes to Claim Second Major in Three Weeks
abstract: Stenson, who won this year’s British Open, said the past two weeks had been a whirlwind, with the tight tour schedule separating two majors by two weeks.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Henrik Stenson opted for a traditional celebratory drink as his first out of the claret jug. And his second. And his third.

headline: For Twin Sisters, a Road to Progress That Began by Bending a President’s Ear
abstract: Things changed for Alba Somoza after her sister Anastasia, then 9, told President Clinton that Alba wasn’t getting a fair education.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Anastasia Somoza, 9, put it to the president of the United States that her twin sister, Alba, was getting a raw deal. “We go to the same school, but she can’t speak,” Anastasia said. “So because she can’t speak, they put her in a special class. But she uses computers to speak and I would like her to be in a regular class, just like me.”

headline: Pitcher Adam Warren Happy to Be Back With Yankees
abstract: Warren, a part of the organization since he was drafted in 2009, was traded to the Cubs in December but returned in the deal that sent closer Aroldis Chapman to Chicago.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Adam Warren learned the Yankees had traded him to the Chicago Cubs in December while he was vacationing with his wife in the Caribbean.

headline: Clinton Is Nominated, Aided by Sanders
abstract: In a gesture meant to unite the party, Senator Bernie Sanders asked that Hillary Clinton be nominated by acclamation during the roll call vote at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: In a gesture meant to unite the party, Senator Bernie Sanders asked that Hillary Clinton be nominated by acclamation during the roll call vote at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Mets Split Doubleheader With Cardinals, Another Wild-Card Contender
abstract: After the first game, Terry Collins declared that the Mets needed to start producing more runs and stringing wins together. His players heeded the call.
lead_paragraph: After the Mets dropped the first game of a rare single-admission doubleheader Tuesday at Citi Field against St. Louis, a team they are expected to fight for a playoff spot, Manager Terry Collins urgently declared that his club needed to start producing more runs and stringing wins together.

headline: Landlord Accused of Harassing Tenants Is Arrested
abstract: Ephraim Vashovsky, whose companies own over two dozen residential buildings in New York, was indicted, along with his manager and a contractor, on charges of reckless endangerment and other offenses.
lead_paragraph: During the single-digit temperatures in winter 2015, the family, with five children, had no heat and no hot water.

headline: At Athletes’ Village, a Nonstop Effort to Stem Flow of Complaints
abstract: Hundreds of handymen, electricians and plumbers were working round the clock to fix a multitude of infrastructure problems.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Olympic officials were scrambling and hundreds of handymen, electricians and plumbers were working round the clock Tuesday to fix a multitude of infrastructure problems plaguing the Olympic Village here, as complaints appeared to be more widespread than initially thought.

headline: Semiconductor Industry Shrinks Some More With Latest Deal
abstract: Analog Devices will acquire the Linear Technology Corporation, as pricing pressures and low profit margins force more consolidations in the sector.
lead_paragraph: Analog Devices agreed on Tuesday to acquire the Linear Technology Corporation for $14.8 billion, accelerating the already brisk consolidation within the semiconductor sector.

headline: Complaint Against Bridgewater
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board alleges that the hedge fund “has been interfering with, restraining and coercing” employees through its strict confidentiality agreements.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board alleges that the hedge fund “has been interfering with, restraining and coercing” employees through its strict confidentiality agreements.

headline: Spy Agency Consensus Grows That Russia Hacked D.N.C.
abstract: American intelligence agencies cautioned that they are uncertain whether the breach was an effort to manipulate the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies have told the White House they now have “high confidence” that the Russian government was behind the theft of emails and documents from the Democratic National Committee, according to federal officials who have been briefed on the evidence.

headline: Sandy Pearlman, Producer, Manager and Lyricist for Blue Öyster Cult, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Pearlman was also one of the first serious rock critics, writing and editing for the pioneering rock-culture magazine Crawdaddy.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Pearlman, a producer, lyricist, manager, executive and college professor who was a herald of developments from heavy metal and punk to the digital distribution of music, died on Tuesday in Novato, Calif. He was 72.

headline: Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington Speaks Up for Statehood
abstract: Ms. Bowser has helped put making the nation’s capital the 51st state back in the Democratic platform for the first time in 16 years.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Mayor Muriel E. Bowser rose to officially cast the votes of the District of Columbia on Tuesday evening, she had a message: The nation’s capital was past ready to join “the United States of America.”

headline: This Is What Democracy Looks Like
abstract: The Democrats, in their unruly way, seem to have risen above the dissension and near chaos that began their convention.
lead_paragraph: The jeers and boos and angry tears of Bernie Sanders die-hards so dominated the first hours of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia that it might have seemed doomed to collapse into hostility and chaos on the first day.

headline: James Nederlander, Theater Owner Known as Broadway’s Last Patriarch, Dies at 94
abstract: The man who built a theater empire was frequently a producer of shows as well.
lead_paragraph: James M. Nederlander, who, with mercenary guile and an admittedly plebeian aesthetic, presided for nearly half a century over a theater empire that encompassed as many as 10 houses on Broadway and stretched across the country to California and across the Atlantic to London, died on Monday in Southampton, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: Man Receives 20 Years to Life for Shooting at 2 New York Officers
abstract: Antonio Olmeda, 57, pleaded guilty to two counts of first-degree attempted murder in the 2011 encounter. No one was injured.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City police officers approached a bearded man on the street in Queens. His fedora and his trench coat had drawn a bystander’s attention. But instead of talking, the authorities said, he pulled out a gun and fired three shots. While the officers ducked for cover, the man fled.

headline: In Hopes of Deterring Violence at J’ouvert Festival, Officials Turn Up the Lights
abstract: Officials said the event that precedes the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn would be given a permit, more uniformed officers and roughly 200 floodlights.
lead_paragraph: Participants in the predawn street festival that precedes the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn will notice a striking change this year: light. Lots of it.

headline: Wagner Work
abstract: Finn Vigeland, Natan Last and the J.A.S.A. Crossword Class are back for seemingly endless fun.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Riddle me this: When is an O not really an O?

headline: 3 Are Charged in Hollywood-Style Bank Burglaries in New York
abstract: The men are accused of stealing almost $5 million in cash and valuables at two locations in Brooklyn and Queens in crimes the New York police leader says reminded him of the movie “Heat.”
lead_paragraph: It seemed like something out of a big-budget heist movie.

headline: Looking to Build Base, Democrats Court Those Aggrieved by Donald Trump
abstract: From Hillary Clinton and her campaign, a scorching indictment of her Republican opponent as someone who has spared almost no group from insult or injury.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — One after another, they have streamed across the stage of the Democratic National Convention, sharing their stories of being insulted, cheated or otherwise wronged by Donald J. Trump:

headline: Why Security Experts Think Russia Was Behind the D.N.C. Breach
abstract: A growing body of forensic evidence has implicated the Russian government in the breach of emails from Democratic National Committee officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since Democratic National Committee officials first discovered their data networks had been compromised this spring, a growing chorus of experts and officials have seen evidence that the Russian government was responsible.

headline: Hillary Clinton, a Reluctant Star of Her Own Prime-Time Show
abstract: Naturally guarded, Mrs. Clinton has seemed a reluctant star of her prime-time production at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along for our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, July 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Their relationship as a current president and a former president would be a very, very sensitive issue early on, and they’d need to carefully work out the rules of the road for the sake of both of them.”

headline: Arsenal, in America to Play M.L.S., Keeps Eye on Biggest Prize
abstract: Ivan Gazidis, Arsenal’s chief executive, discusses winning, pressure and what he wants his team to look like even after he and Manager Arsène Wenger are gone.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Gazidis became Arsenal’s chief executive in 2009, but before that he spent more than a decade as one of the founding executives of Major League Soccer, eventually rising to deputy commissioner. That makes his return to the United States this week with Arsenal, which was invited to play Thursday in the M.L.S. All-Star Game, a special moment. “It’ll be a great and slightly weird experience for me,” Gazidis said. “I’ll be watching two teams that I love and respect, and I’ll want them both to win.”

headline: Aroldis Chapman Has a Bumpy Introduction With the Cubs
abstract: Chapman said during a news conference that he couldn’t remember the details of a phone call with management that laid out expectations for off-the-field behavior.
lead_paragraph: The star closer Aroldis Chapman joined the Chicago Cubs on Tuesday, saying he could not remember what the team’s management had told him about off-the-field expectations and behavior.

headline: The Human Toll of Terror
abstract: A look at the lives of 247 men, women and children who were cut down in mass killings in six countries.
lead_paragraph: A look at the lives of 247 men, women and children who were cut down in mass killings in six countries.

headline: Mark Teixeira’s Bat Shows Pop in Spot Where Yankees Need It Most
abstract: Teixeira doubled, singled, walked and drove a ball to the warning track as the Yankees scored in each inning he reached base. The team has now won 11 of its last 16 games.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Perhaps it is foolish to read too much into one game, but there was a particularly heartening sign for the Yankees in their 6-3 victory over the Houston Astros on Tuesday night.

headline: Angry Bernie Sanders Supporters Protest Hillary Clinton’s Nomination
abstract: At least 1,000 people demonstrated in Philadelphia as Sanders voters joined supporters of the Black Lives Matter movement for a wide-scale march.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Several demonstrations pulsed through the Democrats’ convention host city here on Tuesday after the party formally nominated Hillary Clinton for president, attracting at least 1,000 people by nightfall as angered Bernie Sanders voters joined supporters of the Black Lives Matter movement for a wide-scale march.

headline: Black Mothers' Touching Plea for Clinton
abstract: The Mothers of the Movement, a group of black women who have lost their children or husbands to violence, spoke at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The Mothers of the Movement, a group of black women who have lost their children or husbands to violence, spoke at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.

headline: Wild Swing in Prices at Four Seasons Auction
abstract: Collectors bid on an Emil Antonucci sign depicting the restaurant’s arboreal logo and midcentury treasures from the birthplace of the power lunch.
lead_paragraph: On Day 2 of the Democratic convention at which Hillary Clinton was formally nominated for president, the contents of a storied New York City restaurant created during the Eisenhower administration were put up for auction.

headline: Sanders Delegates Revolt After Roll Call
abstract: Some supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders walked out of the Democratic National Convention after a roll call determined Hillary Clinton to be the official nominee for president.
lead_paragraph: Some supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders walked out of the Democratic National Convention after a roll call determined Hillary Clinton to be the official nominee for president.

headline: Why She Screamed: Meryl Streep’s Complex Bond With Hillary Clinton
abstract: Though Ms. Streep is a longtime advocate of women, the Democratic convention was a political coming-out of sorts: deeply personal, openly partisan and nationally televised.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Meryl Streep, the most accomplished, awarded and chameleonic actress of her generation, once confessed something approaching envy for Hillary Clinton: For women of her age, Ms. Streep said, Mrs. Clinton was the yardstick by which they inevitably measured their lives — sometimes flatteringly, sometimes not.

headline: Bill Clinton Offers Personal Tales of Hillary
abstract: Mr. Clinton delivered a long, personal recounting of the life of Mrs. Clinton, calling her a “change maker” and contrasted his account with the way she was portrayed at the Republican convention last week.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Clinton delivered a long, personal recounting of the life of Mrs. Clinton, calling her a “change maker” and contrasted his account with the way she was portrayed at the Republican convention last week.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: The Democratic Convention continues with President Obama and Senator Tim Kaine speaking. And Jerry Seinfeld puts a classic car on the auction block.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention continues with President Obama’s follow-up to the rousing Monday night speech by the first lady, Michelle Obama. Jerry Seinfeld puts one of his classic cars on the auction block. And now is the time to watch “Narcos,” about the rise and reign of Pablo Escobar, if you haven’t already.

headline: Corrections: July 27, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, July 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Meryl Streep Rallies Crowd for Clinton
abstract: Meryl Streep, the award-winning actress, situated the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, within the arc of women who have broken down barriers in American public life.
lead_paragraph: Meryl Streep, the award-winning actress, situated the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, within the arc of women who have broken down barriers in American public life.

headline: After a Convention’s Bruising Start, a Party Struggles for Unity
abstract: A Democratic uprising has come to an end. But can Democrats come together now, with the wounds of a divisive primary season still so fresh and near the surface?
lead_paragraph: Abroad in America, written by a Times foreign correspondent, approaches the election in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.

headline: 2 Weeks, 8 Terror Attacks, 247 Victims: How We Learned Their Stories
abstract: At first we set out to cover the month of March. But the attacks kept coming, so we scaled back, for fear of being overwhelmed.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Jodi Rudoren, deputy international editor of The Times, explains what was involved in deploying dozens of people around the world to develop fuller portraits of “these lives that were cut short.”

headline: Threat to Legacy Gives Obama Powerful Motive to Stump for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Donald J. Trump would probably reverse a host of the president’s policies — just as Mr. Obama did himself when he took office in 2009.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Nobody knows better than President Obama how easy it would be for Donald J. Trump to reverse the policies of the past eight years if he defeats Hillary Clinton this fall.

headline: Hillary Clinton Thanks Democrats
abstract: Mrs. Clinton made a semi-surprise appearance by video at the Democratic convention on Tuesday after she formally won the party’s nomination for president.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Clinton made a semi-surprise appearance by video at the Democratic convention on Tuesday after she formally won the party’s nomination for president.

headline: Towns That Defy Fair-Housing Law
abstract: Wealthy New Jersey suburbs and Westchester County shouldn’t be allowed to keep shirking their legal obligations.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled repeatedly over three decades that wealthy towns cannot legally exclude housing for low- and moderate-income families.

headline: The Trumpian Dreams of Silicon Valley
abstract: Other than Peter Thiel, the technology industry hasn’t embraced the Republican nominee, but many share his views on how to fix government.
lead_paragraph: There were more than a few dropped jaws when the Silicon Valley investor Peter Thiel agreed to a prime-time speaking slot on the final night of the Republican National Convention, barely an hour before the acceptance speech of Donald J. Trump. Mr. Trump wants to emboss a big fat T on government, promising huge infrastructure projects, starting with a wall between the United States and Mexico. What was a former Ron Paul supporter and proud libertarian like Mr. Thiel doing on the same stage?

headline: The Putin-Trump Admiration Society
abstract: The Republican candidate’s high regard for such a dangerous adversary should give voters pause.
lead_paragraph: One curious aspect of the 2016 presidential campaign has been Donald Trump’s startling affinity for Vladimir Putin, the increasingly authoritarian president of Russia. Mr. Trump and Mr. Putin have spoken admiringly of each other; exhibited similar strongman tendencies; and seemed to share certain views, notably a disdain for NATO. But would Mr. Putin really interfere in the American presidential race to help Mr. Trump, the Republican Party nominee, get elected over the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton?

headline: Web People vs. Wall People
abstract: Voters have a choice of candidates who embrace change and those who try to stop it.
lead_paragraph: Yes, we’re having a national election right now. Yes, there are two parties running. But no, they are not the two parties that you think. It’s not “Democrats” versus “Republicans.” This election is really between “Wall People” and “Web People.”

headline: Prostate Cancer Isn’t Colorblind
abstract: Black men are very vulnerable to prostate cancer. So why do doctors advise against screening them for it?
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — In 1966, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said, “Of all the forms of inequality, injustice in health care is the most shocking and inhuman.” While major advances have been made in health care, ethnic and racial disparities remain in the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses, particularly prostate cancer.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Radical Promise
abstract: She wants women and men to be paid the same. It’s a big, sweeping pledge.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton can’t make the kind of sweeping promises that voters want to hear.

headline: Could Third Parties Determine This Election?
abstract: The historic unpopularity of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton may make voters take a harder look at the Libertarian candidate, Gary Johnson, and the Green Party candidate, Jill Stein.

headline: Deutsche Bank, Facing Criticism, Surveys Limited Options
abstract: Despite investigations, failing grades from regulators and a critical I.M.F. report, the large German firm is clinging to Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank has plenty of reasons to abandon Wall Street, like many of its European brethren. It faces a raft of investigations, has received a failing grade from American regulators, and an official report suggests that no lender in the world has more potential to create financial mayhem.

headline: Searching for 43 Missing Students Deep Inside the ‘Real Mexico’
abstract: Months after 43 college students disappeared in Mexico in 2014, Emmanuel Guillén Lozano forsook his own graduation gift to spend time documenting the plight and protests of their parents.
lead_paragraph: Months after 43 college students disappeared in Mexico in 2014, Emmanuel Guillén Lozano forsook his own graduation gift to spend time documenting the plight and protests of their parents.

headline: Santander Profit Down on Restructuring and Bank Fund Charges
abstract: The Spanish lender took a €120 million second-quarter write-down for its contribution to a fund intended to share the burden of bad loans with investors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Banco Santander of Spain said on Wednesday that its profit declined by nearly half in the second quarter on restructuring charges and a contribution to a fund to help finance bank “bail-ins” in Europe.

headline: Clinton Clinches Nomination in Historic Vote
abstract: Hillary Clinton made history as the first woman to receive the presidential nomination from a major political party. The convention underlined this, prominently featuring women throughout the night.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton made history as the first woman to receive the presidential nomination from a major political party. The convention underlined this, prominently featuring women throughout the night.

headline: Tibetan Groups Upset Over China’s Demolition Work at Buddhist Institute
abstract: The bulldozing of many of the monastic homes at the institute is another attempt by China to shape Tibetan culture and religious life, Tibetan advocacy groups say.
lead_paragraph: In the Tibetan regions ruled by China, one religious institute stands out — Larung Gar, in the county of Sertar. There, thousands of monks and nuns live in rows of cells that sprawl across the undulating hills. It has been described as the largest Buddhist institute on the planet.

headline: ‘Friends’ Lives On in a Beijing Cafe
abstract: Playing off a Chinese obsession with the sitcom “Friends,” a cafe called Central Perk is designed like the fictitious place where Chandler, Joey, Ross, Rachel, Monica and Phoebe hung out.
lead_paragraph: High above Beijing’s financial district, on the sixth floor of a futuristic commercial complex, is a little slice of New York City.

headline: Protesters Fume as Zimbabwe Vice President Runs Up a Hotel Bill
abstract: Vice President Phelekezela Mphoko’s year-and-a-half stay in a luxurious hotel — at a taxpayer cost of $1,000 a night, including meals — may be coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The country’s A.T.M.s have run out of cash. Even the police and the army — linchpins of the government’s control — are not getting paid on time.

headline: The New Age in Power Dressing
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Theresa May don’t just wear the pants. They wear the skirts and dresses, too.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton takes the stage at the Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia on Thursday to formally accept the nomination as the Democratic candidate for president of the United States, she will make history and automatically become a role model for women in a way that goes beyond all of her achievements thus far.

headline: Naloxone Saves Lives, but Is No Cure in Heroin Epidemic
abstract: Critics say the highly effective antidote provides a safety net for those who keep abusing drugs, enabling them to be revived over and over.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — A woman in her 30s was sitting in a car in a parking lot here last month, shooting up heroin, when she overdosed. Even after the men she was with injected her with naloxone, the drug that reverses opioid overdoses, she remained unconscious. They called 911.

headline: New York Police Embracing a Weapon They Have a Complicated Past With: Tasers
abstract: Amid national anger over police killings of unarmed black men, the department is easing its limits on the devices, hoping to reduce police shootings by providing officers a less dangerous fallback.
lead_paragraph: Even as police departments across the country embraced Taser stun guns over the past 15 years, the New York Police Department kept them out of the hands of almost all officers. Only some sergeants and members of a specially trained unit were issued the handgun-shaped weapons, and regulations required many of them to keep the devices in the trunks of patrol cars.

headline: Confessor. Feminist. Adult. What the Hell Happened to Howard Stern?
abstract: Scattered among the gleefully vulgar mainstays are now intimate exchanges that have made Mr. Stern one of the most deft interviewers in the business.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of his interview with Bill Murray, Howard Stern turned an already somber discussion about missed career opportunities into an existential grilling.

headline: Searching for 43 Missing Students Deep Inside the ‘Real Mexico’
abstract: Months after 43 college students disappeared in Mexico in 2014, Emmanuel Guillén Lozano forsook his own graduation gift to spend time documenting the plight and protests of their parents.
lead_paragraph: Leer en Español.

headline: Living in Great Neck, N.Y.
abstract: Proximity to Manhattan and a picturesque setting draw residents to the Great Neck peninsula on the North Shore of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Proximity to Manhattan and a picturesque setting draw residents to the Great Neck peninsula on the North Shore of Long Island.

headline: On the Great Neck Peninsula, a Rich Blend of Many Cultures
abstract: Proximity to Manhattan and a picturesque setting draw residents to this area on the North Shore of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Proximity to Manhattan and Chinese food were among the lures when Lawrence and Crystal Tsang moved from a cramped rental on the Lower East Side of Manhattan to the affluent Great Neck peninsula on the North Shore of Long Island in late 2014.

headline: Democratic Convention Day 3 Takeaways: America First
abstract: The president, vice president and other Democrats sought to seize on the traditional core of Republican messaging: America as a place of exceptionalism.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Wednesday was a night of inversion and transition for the party at the Democratic National Convention. President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. gave what were likely to be the final widely viewed political speeches of their administration, seeking to defend their record, denigrate Donald J. Trump’s and persuade voters that Hillary Clinton is a worthy successor. And Democrats sought to seize on the traditional core of Republican campaign messaging: America as a place of virtue, optimism and exceptionalism. Our takeaways:

headline: Being Unfit May Be Almost as Bad for You as Smoking
abstract: Poor physical fitness may be second only to smoking as a risk factor for premature death.
lead_paragraph: Being out of shape could be more harmful to health and longevity than most people expect, according to a new, long-term study of middle-aged men. The study finds that poor physical fitness may be second only to smoking as a risk factor for premature death.

headline: Hillary Clinton, France, Olympics: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Just a Regular Doctor
abstract: “What’s your specialty?” That’s the question people always ask, as soon as they learn that you are a doctor.
lead_paragraph: “What’s your specialty?” That’s the question people always ask, as soon as they learn that you are a doctor.

headline: New York Today: Awaiting a Corpse Flower Bloom
abstract: Wednesday: A stinky flower in the Bronx, goodbye to the Big Apple Circus, and a slower ferry.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:48 a.m.

headline: Video Tribute Will Precede Harry Reid’s Final Convention Speech as Senator
abstract: Before Mr. Reid takes the stage to lacerate his political opponents, a few people who have worked closely with him will share their thoughts about him via a video.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid, the feisty Democratic leader from Nevada, will deliver his final speech to a party convention as an elected official on Wednesday; he is retiring from the Senate next year.

headline: Morning Agenda: Sex, Fear and Video Surveillance at World’s Largest Hedge Fund
abstract: Deutsche Bank Profits Take a Hit | Analog Devices Buys Linear Technology
lead_paragraph: SEX, FEAR AND VIDEO SURVEILLANCE AT WORLD’S LARGEST HEDGE FUND Bridgewater Associates, the world’s biggest hedge fund, has been described as a “cauldron of fear and intimidation” by an employee who has filed a complaint with the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. The employee, Christopher Tarui, an adviser to large institutional investors in Bridgewater, said that his supervisor sexually harassed him and, when he complained, managers pressured him to rescind his claims. Mr. Tarui also described an atmosphere of constant surveillance by video and security guards to silence employees that do not fit the Bridgewater mold.

headline: Police Scrutiny in China Hinders Condom Use Among Prostitutes, Study Says
abstract: Prostitutes in three major Chinese cities were found to be significantly less likely to carry or use condoms if the police had questioned them in the past.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The tendency by some police officers to view condoms as evidence of prostitution is hindering their use among sex workers and undermining efforts to prevent the spread of H.I.V. in China, a report has said.

headline: What It Means
abstract: Starbucks’ new dress code encourages employees to incorporate their personal taste. But some things are off the table.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks’ new dress code encourages employees to incorporate their personal taste. But some things are off the table.

headline: French Ask Whether Priest’s Killer, Listed as a Threat, Could Have Been Stopped
abstract: Adel Kermiche, 19, had spent nearly 10 months in detention but was released in March over prosecutors’ objections.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The question troubling France on Wednesday in the wake of the attack by a teenager who aspired to go to Syria, but settled instead for cutting the throat of a priest, is whether the crime was a result of failures by the French government, and what more could have been done to prevent it.

headline: N.F.L.-Backed Youth Program Says It Reduced Concussions. The Data Disagrees.
abstract: The Heads Up Football program has been sold to youth football leagues and parents as statistically proven to reduce injuries, but a review of the evidence tells a different story.
lead_paragraph: As increasing numbers of parents keep their children from playing tackle football for safety reasons, the National Football League and other groups have sought to reassure them that the game is becoming less dangerous.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘How It’s Made’
abstract: A show that reveals manufacturing to be nothing short of sublime.
lead_paragraph: When you turn on a TV set and immerse yourself in images of human beings doing human activities — looking for unusually small houses, awaiting elimination on a reality show, solving murders in a procedural — it’s easy to forget that what you’re watching is not people but a machine, its network of pixels, subpixels, liquid crystals and transistors working silently in the background, allowing us to dwell in a bustling kingdom of our own design. But “How It’s Made,” a show devoted to the manufacturing processes that yield our most mundane and treasured human creations, reminds the viewer that time spent watching TV is time spent not with people but in the company of an incredible object.

headline: Can I Stay Friends With an Abusive Husband?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on navigating friendship with a couple and their destructive dynamic, and whether to break confidentiality to let a friend know she will be fired.
lead_paragraph: I have been good friends with a couple, “Jack” and “Jane,” for about eight years. They have been together for about 15 years. Although historically I have spent more time with Jack because we share more interests, I consider both of them to be among my closest friends. Indeed, because of many shared life experiences, I think my connection with Jane is deeper than my connection with Jack. I knew for some time that they did not have the ideal relationship, but recently I have discovered that things are much, much worse than I thought. I have learned, both from Jane and from another close friend of hers, that Jack is verbally abusive.

headline: Denmark: Where It Is Always Wedding Season
abstract: In recent years, the island of Aero has gained a reputation as the go-to wedding destination for mixed-nationality and same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: The brides were everywhere — they floated like flower petals on the constant wind that wafted across the isle of Aero in Denmark. White dresses billowing, they ran into the red brick building of the municipal registry in Aeroskobing; they alighted before the landmark Old Merchant’s Court, one of Aero’s historic attractions.

headline: Hudson, N.Y.: An Elegant Transformation
abstract: In Hudson, Brooklyn comes to the country, via a train ride up the river from the big city.
lead_paragraph: I used to consider myself a bona fide traveler, exploring everywhere from Costa Rica to Buenos Aires, Biarritz to Brussels. I looked at every calendar year as a puzzle, figuring out where to go, and when. With a home base in New York City — and Paris for two years, which invited its own adventures — almost every destination was accessible.

headline: In Frank Lloyd Wright Country, Architecture and Apple Pie
abstract: In the Laurel Highlands in Pennsylvania, homes designed by Frank Lloyd Wright are the main draw, but local lamb and autumn leaves are memorable too.
lead_paragraph: In 1934, E. J. Kaufmann, a Pittsburgh department store magnate, took Frank Lloyd Wright to a section of untrammeled woods in southwestern Pennsylvania called Bear Run. Mr. Kaufmann hoped to build his summer home here, in a glen thick with maple and hemlock trees, where water pooled and then dashed over a sequence of cater-cornered rock ledges.

headline: Donald Trump’s Path: What Map Should Democrats Fear the Most?
abstract: A 269-269 tie in the Electoral College would be decided in the House, and why the Clinton campaign is now trying harder to defend Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshot’s elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York,  discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

headline: New U.S.-Mexico Vaquita Protections Useless Unless China Curbs Totoaba Demand
abstract: Now that Mexico and the United States have bolstered protections for the vanishing vaquita porpoise, it’s time for China to do its part.
lead_paragraph: In theory, July 9 was International Save the Vaquita Day, conceived to press Mexico to do more to protect the last few dozen members of a tiny and profoundly endangered porpoise species confined to overfished waters at the north end of the Gulf of California.

headline: Behind the Green Apron: Starbucks Dress Code Gets Some Flair
abstract: Baristas can now dye their hair and wear colored shirts (as long as they’re gray, navy, dark denim or brown).
lead_paragraph: Those who zombie-walk into Starbucks for a caffeine fix are accustomed to a standard look for the baristas: simple black-and-white clothes under a green apron.

headline: Is the Iran-Saudi Cold War Heating Up?
abstract: The Middle East’s two biggest rivals might be starting a tit-for-tat by backing rebel groups. It should stop before it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Throughout decades of ferocious rivalry, Iran and Saudi Arabia have, even while backing competing forces across the Middle East, generally maintained one red line: They wouldn’t interfere directly in each other’s domestic security. Policy makers in Riyadh and Tehran have known that backing militant groups among their rival’s Shiite minorities in Saudi Arabia or Sunni minorities in Iran could lead to an escalation for which neither country is ready.

headline: Erdogan Should Look Across the Aegean
abstract: The Turkish leader would see the benefits of liberal democracy in Greece, another country with a long history of military coups.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Military coups have been an integral part of politics through most of the modern history of Greece and Turkey, shaping them domestically and determining relations between them. If war is diplomacy by other means, in these two neighbors and NATO allies, military coups were politics by other means. The recent attempt by military forces to overthrow Turkey’s elected government underlines the different course the two countries have taken in the past few decades. What follows may lead them even further apart.

headline: Alzheimer’s Drug LMTX Falters in Final Stage of Trials
abstract: The drug did work on a handful of patients taking it alone, without another medication. But some experts were skeptical about the small subset.
lead_paragraph: A new type of drug for Alzheimer’s disease failed to slow the rate of decline in mental ability and daily functioning in its first large clinical trial. There was a hint, though, that it might be effective for certain patients.

headline: Aftermath of Qamishli Bombings
abstract: Two blasts hit the Kurdish-controlled city Qamishli in northeastern Syria, near the Turkish border, killing dozens of people and wounding many more on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Two blasts hit the Kurdish-controlled city Qamishli in northeastern Syria, near the Turkish border, killing dozens of people and wounding many more on Wednesday.

headline: Blast Kills Dozens in Kurdish-Held Syrian Town; Crisis in Aleppo Worsens
abstract: The explosion struck Qamishli, in the country’s northeast. Separately, Unicef said airstrikes hit four hospitals and a blood bank in Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Dozens of people in a Kurdish-controlled town in northeastern Syria died after an explosion on Wednesday, while a humanitarian crisis in the rebel-held sections of Aleppo, a city in the country’s northwest, intensified.

headline: 1966: Moderates’ Plan for Vietnam
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: “Moderate critics” of the American policy in Vietnam propose a plan in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Self-styled ‘‘moderate critics’’ of U.S. policy in Vietnam are gathering around a new idea. They advocate eliminating the Viet Cong from the most heavily populated areas as an alternative to escalating the war. This would mean concentrating military power in South Vietnam in the most populated areas and leaving the enemy the least desirable sectors. This would amount to a division of South Vietnam on a deliberately lopsided basis, with the object of forcing the enemy to negotiate or, as some propose, letting that division stand as ‘‘a bearable settlement.’’ This theme has been recurring in recent days in proposals by prominent members of the academic community, who range from partial to total critics of administration policy. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 28, 1966

headline: Chinese Court Sentences American Publisher to Prison
abstract: In a case bearing striking similarities to Beijing’s recent detentions of five Hong Kong-based booksellers, James J. Wang received a sentence of over five years.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese court has sentenced an American citizen to more than five years in prison for selling magazines about Chinese politics, in a case that bears striking similarities to Beijing’s recent, widely denounced detentions of five Hong Kong-based booksellers.

headline: The Same Healthy Food, but It’s Cheaper Across Town
abstract: In South Los Angeles, the price of a meal at Everytable restaurant will be about half as much as it is at a second location downtown.
lead_paragraph: When a new restaurant called Everytable opens on Saturday in the poverty-stricken area of Los Angeles known as South L.A., a grab-and-go Jamaican jerk chicken bowl with coconut rice, beans, plantains and carrots will be the most expensive meal on the menu at $4.50.

headline: What You Get for … $835,000
abstract: A house with a Hudson view in New York, a townhouse in Dallas and a 1925 house in North Carolina
lead_paragraph: A house with a Hudson view in New York, a townhouse in Dallas and a 1925 house in North Carolina

headline: $835,000 Homes in Dallas, North Carolina, and New York State
abstract: A 1925 house in Asheville, N.C., a house with a Hudson view in Hyde Park, N.Y., and a townhouse in Texas.
lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, N.Y.

headline: How Companies Like Dollar Shave Club Are Reshaping the Retail Landscape
abstract: Dollar Shave Club, recently acquired for $1 billion, typifies online-only companies that have upended traditional models of stores and advertising.
lead_paragraph: The world might be a mess, but look on the bright side: Men’s shaving products are much better than they used to be.

headline: Keeping Bankers’ Hours, European Observers Miss Most of Ukraine War
abstract: The fighting between Russian-backed separatists and the Ukrainian Army starts just as the unarmed cease-fire monitors pocket their notebooks and drive away for the day.
lead_paragraph: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — As the afternoon shadows grow long, nocturnal creatures begin to stir. A stray cat rises from a nap, stretches and trots off to hunt. Overhead, swallows swoop and screech in the deepening twilight.

headline: A Renaissance Revival Chateau in Northwest France
abstract: Built in the 1850s, the chateau is set on about 25 acres, with a guesthouse and a pool, near the city of Laval in the Mayenne department.
lead_paragraph: Built in the 1850s, the chateau is set on about 25 acres, with a guesthouse and a pool, near the city of Laval in the Mayenne department.

headline: House Hunting in ... France
abstract: Prices for chateaus in the Loire Valley and the neighboring Mayenne department have stabilized after the global economic crisis of 2008, agents said.
lead_paragraph: A RENAISSANCE REVIVAL CHATEAU ON 25 ACRES IN NORTHWEST FRANCE

headline: Tim Kaine, the Harmonica Player
abstract: Senator Tim Kaine: Democratic vice-presidential candidate, former governor — and mouth organist.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Kaine: Democratic vice-presidential candidate, former governor — and mouth organist.

headline: Tim Kaine, Harmonica in Tow, Often Relies on Music as a Mouthpiece
abstract: The Democratic vice-presidential nominee has jammed with members of big-name bands, and music has been an important part of his life as a politician.
lead_paragraph: He carries multiple harmonicas in his briefcase. He has played with members of the Dave Matthews Band and the Grateful Dead. And he has been known to show up unannounced at bluegrass jamborees around his home state, Virginia, simply looking to jam.

headline: Deaths in the Line of Duty
abstract: Across the country, at least 66 police officers have died so far in 2016. The biggest increase is in the number of firearms-related deaths.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, at least 66 police officers have died so far in 2016. The biggest increase is in the number of firearms-related deaths.

headline: John Hinckley, Who Tried to Kill Reagan, Will Be Released
abstract: A federal judge ruled that Mr. Hinckley, who shot and wounded the president in 1981, no longer posed a danger and would be allowed to leave a government psychiatric hospital.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John W. Hinckley Jr., who tried to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, will be allowed to live permanently with his elderly mother in Williamsburg, Va., leaving the psychiatric hospital where he has been imprisoned for several decades, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.

headline: In Films Like ‘Nerve,’ Players Become Pawns
abstract: Here’s a look at Hollywood plots constructed as games that unfold from the perspective of a central player.
lead_paragraph: Movies based on video games often get the big-screen treatment. But Hollywood has also had an interest in constructing plots as games that unfold from the perspective of a central player. They play these games not on a screen but with their own bodies, and the stakes are frequently perilous.

headline: All Charges Dropped Against Baltimore Officers in Freddie Gray Case
abstract: The prosecutor secured not a single conviction against six officers charged. But she offered a passionate defense of her decision to pursue the case.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The state’s attorney here dropped all remaining charges Wednesday against three city police officers awaiting trial in the death of Freddie Gray, closing the book on one of the most closely watched police prosecutions in the nation without a single conviction — and few answers about precisely how the young man died.

headline: أحد رجال 'الهيئة' يعبر عن شكوكه... ويدفع الثمن غاليًا
abstract: An Arabic language translation of an article about a longtime morals enforcer in Saudi Arabia who began to question the rules of the hyper-conservative strain of Islam practiced in the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: An Arabic language translation of an article about a longtime morals enforcer in Saudi Arabia who began to question the rules of the hyper-conservative strain of Islam practiced in the kingdom.

headline: Apple Pleases by Not Disappointing So Much
abstract: Shares of the company rose in after-hours trading on Tuesday because its earnings report, though not pretty, was less bleak than Wall Street expected.
lead_paragraph: The trajectory of the world’s biggest public company these days appears to be a zigzag.

headline: Rapping With Cervantes, 400 Years After His Death
abstract: In festivals and in an international competition, Spain and Mexico honor this master by taking inspiration from his words and characters.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD REAL, Spain — Jesús Camacho, 28, a schoolteacher, recalled a time in his youth when he refused to read “Don Quixote,” the most famous work by Miguel de Cervantes. “I saw that it was the same size as the Bible,” he said, “so I got scared.”

headline: Europe Decides Against Fines for Spain and Portugal
abstract: Officials apparently feared that punishing the countries for overspending would have spurred more austerity and helped fuel anti-European movements.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials, facing the rise of populist movements across the region, opted against hitting Spain and Portugal with sanctions on Wednesday for breaking the bloc’s rules on government spending.

headline: 1891: Objecting to Fiscal Union
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In July 1891, the idea of a fiscal union between Great Britain and her colonies meets objection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — According to a telegram from Montreal, the papers there object to Colonel Howard Vincent’s suggestions at Ottawa of a scheme of fiscal union between Great Britain and her colonies, on the ground that the Imperial relations with the United States would destroy the chance of reciprocity with that country. The Herald is also in opposition to the scheme. It says ‘‘Colonel Vincent’s animus against the United States is very marked, and Canada is indisposed to be drawn further in antagonism with her nearest neighbor, with whom her trade, despite the tariff, is as large as with Great Britain, aggregating 45 per cent, of her entire foreign commerce.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 28, 1891

headline: The Best Fried Chicken and Other Recipes
abstract: After you’re done frying, consider food as a political subject.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Checking the Delivery Date on That Android Update
abstract: If you cannot remember when, or if, you installed the most recent security patch for your Android device, there’s an easy way to find out.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to tell definitely if my Android Marshmallow tablet has the latest security patches from Google?

headline: Defeat of ISIS Could Send ‘Terrorist Diaspora’ to West, F.B.I. Chief Says
abstract: James B. Comey warned that eventual victory over the Islamic State could lead to an uptick of terrorist attacks in Europe and possibly the United States.
lead_paragraph: Eventual victory against the Islamic State could well lead to an uptick of terrorist attacks in the West, not a reduction in them, James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., said on Wednesday.

headline: The Next Ty Cobb? For Jose Altuve, Hyperbole, Like Limits, Hardly Exists
abstract: Batting title. Gold Glove. Every season, the Astros’ second baseman sets a new goal, and this season he wanted to improve his strike-zone judgment.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Of all his wondrous statistics this season, Jose Altuve cares most about games played. Altuve, the Houston Astros’ second baseman, has played all 101 this season, part of an active streak that leads the majors.

headline: Two Suspense Novels Track Down Girls Gone Lost
abstract: Amy Gentry’s “Good as Gone” and Megan Miranda’s “All the Missing Girls” are stories told in reverse.
lead_paragraph: GOOD AS GONEBy Amy Gentry273 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $23.

headline: Who Killed the Priest? An Inquisition Mystery Gets Its Confession
abstract: In Matthew Carr’s “The Devils of Cardona,” a priest’s murder draws investigators into the tensions of Inquisition-era Spain.
lead_paragraph: THE DEVILS OF CARDONABy Matthew Carr401 pp. Riverhead Books. $27.

headline: Kid Models (and Their Moms) Trade Summer Fun for City Auditions
abstract: While their friends enjoy the freedom of summertime, these youngsters pound the pavement, carrying the weighty expectations of their parents and communities.
lead_paragraph: Five children, in brightly colored T-shirts and wrinkled jean shorts, chattered in an eighth-floor office in Manhattan on a recent June day, taking breaks to lick ice pops and play with Spider-Man dolls. It looked like an all-American play date, the type you may see depicted in a magazine.

headline: Tor Project Confirms Sexual Misconduct Claims Against Employee
abstract: The group said that an internal investigation found that the claims involving Jacob Appelbaum, a top figure in the internet privacy movement, were accurate.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Tor Project, a nonprofit digital privacy group, announced on Wednesday that an internal investigation had confirmed allegations of sexual misconduct against a former employee who was the public face of the organization.

headline: Donald Trump Calls on Russia to Find Hillary Clinton’s Missing Emails
abstract: “Russia, if you’re listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing,” Mr. Trump said, essentially encouraging a foreign power’s cyberspying.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he hoped Russian intelligence services had successfully hacked Hillary Clinton’s email, and encouraged them to publish whatever they may have stolen, essentially urging a foreign adversary to conduct cyberespionage against a former secretary of state.

headline: Who Was the Ansbach Attacker?
abstract: Investigators are piecing together the motive behind a suicide bombing in Ansbach on July 24. The Syrian national died when he detonated an explosive near a crowded concert in the German town, wounding 15 people.
lead_paragraph: Investigators are piecing together the motive behind a suicide bombing in Ansbach on July 24. The Syrian national died when he detonated an explosive near a crowded concert in the German town, wounding 15 people.

headline: I.M.F. Financial Counselor to Join Standard Chartered as Chairman
abstract: José Viñals will join the lender’s board in October and assume the role of chairman on Dec. 1, succeeding John Peace.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Standard Chartered, an Asia-focused bank based in London, said on Wednesday that José Viñals, who oversees financial stability at the International Monetary Fund, would join the lender as its new chairman this year.

headline: Lee Child on a Thriller Set in Zimbabwe
abstract: The mysterious author C.B. George’s novel, “The Death of Rex Nhongo,” set in unstable Zimbabwe, is primarily about people going about their lives.
lead_paragraph: THE DEATH OF REX NHONGOBy C.B. George311 pp. A Lee Boudreaux Book/Little, Brown & Company. $26.

headline: Sculptures You Can Wear, From Six New Jewelry Brands
abstract: A handful of young designers are offering up modern — and minimal — styles.
lead_paragraph: A handful of young designers are offering up modern — and minimal — styles.

headline: Challenges of Getting a Product Made in the U.S.A.
abstract: Pad & Quill, a seller of cases for iPhones and other devices, has spent years finding suppliers to keep its products largely American made.
