lead_paragraph: Many manufacturers perform a cost-benefit analysis when deciding whether to move production abroad. Others, however, are determined to make their products in the United States, even when the costs are higher.

headline: Bill O’Reilly Defends Comments About ‘Well Fed’ Slaves
abstract: Slaves who helped build the White House were given meat and other staples, he said. “That is a fact. Not a justification, not a defense of slavery.”
lead_paragraph: Addressing Michelle Obama’s remarks about slaves having built the White House, Bill O’Reilly said Tuesday on his Fox News program that those slaves were “well fed and had decent lodgings provided by the government.”

headline: In Megan Abbott’s New Murder Mystery, a Teenage Gymnast Sharp as a Knife
abstract: Megan Abbott’s “You Will Know Me” is set in the world of young gymnasts and their obsessive parents.
lead_paragraph: YOU WILL KNOW MEBy Megan Abbott345 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

headline: No Corrections: July 25, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Recipe for the Home Bartender: Scroll, Tap and Pour
abstract: Making a good cocktail can be tricky, but many apps can help you become an expert mixologist.
lead_paragraph: ON a warm summer evening, there’s no better way to unwind than sipping a nice cold cocktail, made with the help of an app.

headline: Fine Homes and Fancy Foods in the Hamptons
abstract: The Hampton Designer Showhouse held a cocktail preview, and the James Beard Foundation hosted its annual Chefs & Champagne party.
lead_paragraph: The Hampton Designer Showhouse held a cocktail preview, and the James Beard Foundation hosted its annual Chefs & Champagne party.

headline: Knife Attack in Japan Leaves Many Wondering if Police Did Enough
abstract: The man accused of stabbing 19 people to death on Tuesday appears to have slipped through cracks in systems meant to identify mentally ill people and prevent them from harming others.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A day after the worst mass killing in its postwar history, Japan was grappling on Wednesday with why law enforcement and mental health officials were unable to stop a troubled man they had been aware of for months.

headline: Designers and Chefs Use Their Good Taste for Good
abstract: The Hampton Designer Showhouse held a cocktail preview, and the James Beard Foundation hosted its annual Chefs & Champagne party.
lead_paragraph: The benefit circuit took an epicurean turn in the Hamptons last Saturday. The Hampton Designer Showhouse held a special preview of its summer design house in Sag Harbor. Now in its 16th year, the cocktail gala benefited Southampton Hospital. Over in Sagaponack, the James Beard Foundation hosted its 26th annual Chefs & Champagne event. Some 40 chefs served a sumptuous feast under a giant tent at the Wölffer Estate Vineyard.

headline: Paul Beatty and Elizabeth Strout Among 13 on Longlist for 2016 Booker Prize
abstract: Other authors in contention for the prestigious award include J.M. Coetzee, Ottessa Moshfegh and Ian McGuire.
lead_paragraph: Five authors from the United States are among the 13 nominees on the longlist for the 2016 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, which was announced on Wednesday.

headline: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot Is Also Very Hot
abstract: Astronomers say the giant swirling storm on the solar system’s largest planet is generating quite a bit of heat for its upper atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is not only big and red. It’s also hot.

headline: Jesse Jackson: We Need a Right-to-Vote Amendment
abstract: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr. writes that we need a “unified national voting system with certain common-sense minimum standards.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Style of Betsy Bloomingdale
abstract: As a hostess, friend and fashion plate, the social doyenne was her own mistress.
lead_paragraph: You would not have called her camera shy. In more than half-century in the public eye, Betsy Bloomingdale courted photographers, drawing them into her orbit with a come-this-way cocktail of glamour and fizzy good cheer.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Convention: Day 3
abstract: Notes and provocations from Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Notes and provocations from Philadelphia.

headline: Forrest E. Mars Jr., Scion of a Candy Empire, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Mars played an early role in the company’s global expansion and became co-president with his brother in 1975.
lead_paragraph: Forrest E. Mars Jr., a billionaire scion of the reclusive family that satisfied America’s sweet tooth with the Milky Way candy bar and M&M’s and who helped build Mars Inc. into the world’s largest confectionary company, died on Tuesday in Seattle. He was 84.

headline: Bill Clinton Praises His Wife’s Feminine Side
abstract: Viewers of Mr. Clinton’s convention speech may have felt admiration, or unease, as the former president used intimate details to depict an attractive “girl” who changed his life.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — He spoke of desiring her: her thick blond hair, her flowery white skirt, her magnetic personality.

headline: A Chorus of ‘Cats’
abstract: To mark the return of “Cats” on Broadway, we asked readers to send in their renditions of “Memory.”
lead_paragraph: To mark the return of “Cats” on Broadway, we asked readers to send in their renditions of “Memory.”

headline: USA Freedom Kids Are in Dispute With Trump
abstract: The manager of the youth performance troupe, whose song at a Florida rally became an online sensation, said the campaign didn’t keep its promises.
lead_paragraph: A patriotic song-and-dance routine by a trio of young girls at a Donald J. Trump rally in Pensacola, Fla., in January drew huge numbers of views online.

headline: Sigalit Landau’s Dead Sea Sculpture
abstract: For a new installation and photography project, “Salt Bride,” the artist submerged a black gown into the salty water and allowed salt crystals to form on its surface, turning it white.
lead_paragraph: For a new installation and photography project, “Salt Bride,” the artist submerged a black gown into the salty water and allowed salt crystals to form on its surface, turning it white.

headline: An Artist’s Salt Crystal Gown, Created Deep Under the Dead Sea
abstract: Sigalit Landau submerged a severe black gown under water for three months, and let hundreds of pounds of white salt naturally encrust its surface.
lead_paragraph: Though she grew up partly in London and Philadelphia, the Jerusalem-born artist Sigalit Landau feels a particular, powerful connection to the Dead Sea. “That was my sea since I was a kid,” she says. “That’s where my family used to go on weekends — it’s really part of my biography.” Since 2005, this low, hyper-saline lake has acted as a collaborative presence in Landau’s works, its peculiar buoyancy, acoustics and aesthetic lending them an otherworldly quality. Her latest, “Salt Bride,” starts with a work of natural alchemy: a sort of time-lapse sculpture, in which a severe black gown submerged in the waters of the Dead Sea gradually turns sparkling white as crystals saltier than tears build across its surface.

headline: Flu Vaccine Has Added Benefits for People With Diabetes
abstract: People with Type 2 diabetes who got the flu vaccine had a lower risk of stroke and heart failure.
lead_paragraph: People with Type 2 diabetes may get an added benefit from the flu vaccine: a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease.

headline: How I Got the Shot: The Tappan Zee Crane Collapse
abstract: When assigned to shoot the crane collapse on the Tappan Zee Bridge, the photographer Fred R. Conrad called up an acquaintance who lived nearby.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this installment of “How I Got the Shot,” the photographer Fred R. Conrad describes his coverage of last week’s crane collapse on the Tappan Zee Bridge over the Hudson River.

headline: Anthony Weiner, Often a Democratic Outcast, Is Sticking Around
abstract: Since his resignation from Congress in 2011 amid revelations of lurid messaging and self-photographing, some have eyed Mr. Weiner’s political company warily.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Their eyes met outside Suite 10 in the convention hall: two political ships — both sunk, or close to it — passing in the Democratic night.

headline: He Won $3 Million in a Lottery. Then He Invested in Crystal Meth.
abstract: A Georgia man, Ronnie Music Jr., won the windfall last year and pleaded guilty to felony weapons and drug charges last week.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia man who invested his $3 million lottery winnings into a thriving crystal meth business is facing an unexpected return: decades behind bars.

headline: Brokering Peace, on Broadway: ‘Oslo’ to Transfer in Spring
abstract: The play by J.T. Rogers, about the unusual back story to the 1993 peace accords, will keep the same cast.
lead_paragraph: “Oslo,” an engrossing drama about a key chapter in the long and largely unsuccessful history of efforts to broker Middle East peace, will transfer to Broadway next spring.

headline: Alexa, What Else Can You Do? Getting More From Amazon Echo
abstract: Making Amazon’s voice-activated speaker smarter is not intuitive, but with a little tinkering, consumers can expand its skills.
lead_paragraph: BILL PYSZCZYMUKA was installing an air-conditioner in an upstairs window last spring when it occurred to him that there was a way to control the machine without getting up from the couch downstairs: his Amazon Echo.

headline: Think Cool Thoughts at Artists & Fleas in Brooklyn
abstract: An ethical-fashion pop-up in SoHo, a House of Harlow capsule, whopper sales at Fivestory and IF, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the East Village lingerie and swimwear mainstay Azaleas NYC will open a West Village branch stocked with independent brands, including a Mikoh neoprene-paneled wet suit ($326) and an Underprotection bralette made from a fabric that comes from banana leaves ($56). At 125 Greenwich Avenue.

headline: Fed Suggests a Growing Chance That Rates Will Rise This Year
abstract: The central bank held rates steady but said near-term risks to the United States economy had dimmed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Wednesday, but it issued an upbeat assessment of economic conditions that suggested a growing chance that it would increase rates later this year.

headline: U.S. to Expand Tracking of Home Purchases by Shell Companies
abstract: The Treasury Department announced plans to examine all-cash high-end purchases in more areas in an effort to uncover money laundering in real estate.
lead_paragraph: More than a quarter of the all-cash luxury home purchases made using shell companies in Manhattan and Miami were flagged as suspicious in a new effort to unearth money laundering in real estate, the Treasury Department said Wednesday. As a result, officials said they would expand the program to other areas across the country.

headline: Photographs From Wednesday at the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Indian Activist Says She Will End 15-Year Hunger Strike
abstract: Irom Chanu Sharmila, who has been the face of the fight against a law shielding the armed forces from prosecution, said she would end her fast and join politics.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — One of India’s most prominent human rights activists made a surprising announcement this week, saying she would end a 15-year hunger strike against a law shielding the armed forces from prosecution.

headline: DNA Study Reveals the One and Only Wolf Species in North America
abstract: The finding highlights the shortcomings of laws intended to protect endangered species that don’t take into account research of the evolution of species.
lead_paragraph: The first large study of North American wolf genomes has found that there is only one species on the continent: the gray wolf. Two other purported species, the Eastern wolf and the red wolf, are mixes of gray wolf and coyote DNA, the scientists behind the study concluded.

headline: Photographs From the Democratic Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Review: In ‘Jason Bourne,’ a Midlife Crisis for a Harried Former Assassin
abstract: Matt Damon returns in a film in which geopolitics and technology are scaffolding for what is essentially a story about human resources challenges in a large bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: Jason Bourne, taciturn and carb-free, hurries through various European capitals — Rome, Athens, London — with the grim determination of a tourist who desperately needs a men’s room but is too proud to ask for directions. Really, of course, he’s being followed and watched, at street level and from a wired-up surveillance hub on the other side of the ocean, where his erstwhile employers in the C.I.A. track him as if he were the quarry in a high-stakes game of Pokémon Go.

headline: Try Youths in Family Court
abstract: A criminal justice expert writes that New York should raise the age of family court to 18.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Twitter Might Want to Steal From Yahoo’s Playbook
abstract: With Twitter’s ad demand lower than expected and user growth stalled, now would be a good time for Jack Dorsey to find a suitor for his company.
lead_paragraph: Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive, may want to consider stealing a page from the playbook of the Yahoo boss Marissa Mayer and sell Twitter to a company with deeper pockets.

headline: Democrats Discreetly Turn Attention to Presidential Prospects of the Future
abstract: By tradition, personal ambitions at the Democratic National Convention are largely unspoken, but those who are eager to break out are in attendance.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Twelve years ago Wednesday in Boston, it was Senator John Kerry’s presidential convention. But it was Barack Obama’s night.

headline: Polish Court Limits World War II-Era Restitution Claims in Warsaw
abstract: The constitutional court in Warsaw upheld a 2015 law that substantially restricts potential claims by former property owners.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s constitutional court on Wednesday upheld a 2015 law that significantly limits the rights of people whose property in Warsaw was seized during or after World War II, and their descendants, to apply for restitution.

headline: May the Lessons of the Holocaust Still Guide Us
abstract: Readers call for a fuller remembrance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Karen Finley’s New Show Comes to New York
abstract: Her three short works will explore the American obsession with the unattainable, the narcissism behind gentrification and our fear of the unknown.
lead_paragraph: Karen Finley remains deservedly famous for her provocative 1980s performance art — smearing her naked body in chocolate and doing unseemly things with a yam were among her boldest exploits — and her resulting battle with the National Endowment for the Arts. While Ms. Finley has perhaps mellowed a bit in recent years, her work remains powerful, even if she does it fully clothed. “Written in the Sand,” her 2014 tribute to her friends who died of AIDS in the early days, was raw and well received.

headline: Women’s Voices: She Is the Nominee
abstract: Reacting to the historic nomination of Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The ‘Ice Bucket Challenge’ Helped Scientists Discover a New Gene Tied to A.L.S.
abstract: A social media campaign disparaged by some as “slacktivism” raised $115 million and encouraged research.
lead_paragraph: It turns out those much-mocked Ice Bucket Challenge videos helped do a lot of good.

headline: Trump and Putin's Mutual Admiration
abstract: President Trump and Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, have exchanged many compliments since the 2016 election. We look at the basis of the mutual respect between the two men. (Updated on July 5, 2017.)
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, have exchanged many compliments since the 2016 election. We look at the basis of the mutual respect between the two men. (Updated on July 5, 2017.)

headline: Order Granting Convalescent Release
abstract: A federal judge ruled that John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Reagan in 1981, no longer posed a danger and would be allowed to leave a government psychiatric hospital.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled that John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Reagan in 1981, no longer posed a danger and would be allowed to leave a government psychiatric hospital.

headline: Judge’s Opinion Granting Convalescent Release
abstract: A federal judge ruled that John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Reagan in 1981, no longer posed a danger and would be allowed to leave a government psychiatric hospital.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled that John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Reagan in 1981, no longer posed a danger and would be allowed to leave a government psychiatric hospital.

headline: My Father, the YouTube Star
abstract: I always knew my father loved food. I just didn’t know he’d been showing hundreds of thousands of people how to cook it.
lead_paragraph: The first few emails were marked “Fwd: Jeffrey Pang sent you a video,” so I ignored them. Statistics were on my side: In the history of parental email forwards, roughly 0.001 percent have been worth opening.

headline: Review: Tony Danza Reaches for Sinatra With Charisma
abstract: The actor and singer acknowledges the passing of years in his show “Standards & Stories” at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Tony Danza still has that million-dollar smile. When a boyish grin lights up the actor and singer’s face, the years fall away and he’s an adorable kid from Brooklyn who’s got the world on a string, while “sittin’ on a rainbow.” He exudes the kind of charisma that can’t be taught because it’s part of who he is. And in the liveliest moments of his opening-night show at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Tuesday evening, he had the string around his finger.

headline: LionTree Hires JPMorgan Banker to Lead European Division
abstract: LionTree Advisors, which recently helped Verizon acquire Yahoo for $4.8 billion, has hired Jake Donovan as the president of its European operation.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off helping Verizon buy Yahoo for $4.8 billion, the boutique investment bank LionTree Advisors has added a senior banker to its organization.

headline: Putin Says Doping Sanctions Devalue Rio Olympic Medals
abstract: Victories by other athletes at the Summer Games will be “tasteless,” Russia’s president says.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin blamed politics for the doping scandal that has led to the barring of more than 100 Russian athletes from the coming Rio Games, saying that the absence of some Russian athletes will devalue the medals of other Olympians and render their victories “tasteless.”

headline: The Magical Transformations of ‘The Winter’s Tale’
abstract: A look at three scenes in Christopher Wheeldon’s ballet that translate Shakespeare into dance.
lead_paragraph: “The Winter’s Tale,” one of Shakespeare’s final works, is an odd play: a devastating portrait of jealousy that ends in redemption, and a changeling’s tale that moves from joy to tragedy and back again. Over the course of its five acts, oracles are ignored and then fulfilled; a man is mauled by a bear; and a statue comes to life.

headline: What Donald Trump Said About Russian Hacking and Hillary Clinton’s Emails
abstract: Highlights from Donald J. Trump’s news conference during which he challenged Russia to find Hillary Clinton’s missing email correspondence.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump held a news conference Wednesday morning during which he challenged Russia to find Hillary Clinton’s missing email correspondence and made extensive comments about United States-Russian relations. Here are highlights of what he said:

headline: Earthquake Clues From Ancient Temples in the Himalayas
abstract: Damage to Hindu temples built in northern India the seventh century could provide clues about potential earthquakes to come in the region.
lead_paragraph: Adorned with hand-carved sculptures of Hindu gods and goddesses, the seventh-century stone and wooden temples scattered across northwestern India are marvels from an era when ancient kings ruled the Himalayas.

headline: The World’s Coolest, Most Cultured New Malls
abstract: From Beirut to Berlin, new shopping destinations also offer museum-grade art, the best local (and international) goods — and a cool place to hang.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago, the first fully enclosed, climate-controlled shopping center opened its doors in Edina, Minn., causing a retail revolution that reverberated across the country — ultimately leading its architect, Victor Gruen, to return to his native Austria, appalled by the soulless monster he helped create. Then, just as quickly, online shopping brought on its demise. But abroad, the dying icon of American consumerism is now being reborn in the way Gruen originally intended — as a hub for community and cultural experiences, not just commerce.

headline: How a Currency Intended to Unite Europe Wound Up Dividing It
abstract: In a new book, a Nobel laureate economist pins the blame for Europe’s economic tragedy on the euro.
lead_paragraph: It was started in the name of forging a greater sense of union among the disparate nations of Europe. It was supposed to enhance commercial ties, erode borders and foster a spirit of collective interest, furthering the evolution of former wartime combatants into fellow nations of a united Europe.

headline: $10,000 for Ashtrays? Highlights from the Four Seasons Auction
abstract: The mid-century treasures also included Brno chairs, custom Tulip tables and tarnished silver creamers.
lead_paragraph: The mid-century treasures also included Brno chairs, custom Tulip tables and tarnished silver creamers.

headline: Four Seasons Restaurant Auction Tops $4.1 Million
abstract: A 15-hour auction of midcentury treasures included ashtrays for $10,000, a lobby sign for $96,000 and a cotton candy maker for $6,000.
lead_paragraph: At least four weddings and one notable funeral were among the momentous life events that bidders came hoping to commemorate at an auction on Tuesday of the contents of the Four Seasons, home for decades not only of the power lunch, but also of the power bridal reception, the power bar mitzvah, the power date and the power wake.

headline: Our Chief Theater Critic Is in London and Wants to Hear From You
abstract: Ben Brantley is covering what’s happening on British stages during the next few weeks and is looking for input from audience members.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London is my summer camp. For most of this century, it has been where I head during the dog days, when New York turns still and sullen under a scratchy blanket of heat. To me, gray skies and cooler temperatures are as welcoming as the spires of Disneyland are to a child. But most important, I can binge on theater the way others devour Netflix from their couches.

headline: Pope Francis Says World Is at War, but It’s Not a Religious Conflict
abstract: As he began his first official visit to Poland, Pope Francis he challenged Central and Eastern Europe to soften their resistance to migrants seeking refuge.
lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — As he began his first official visit to Poland, Pope Francis on Wednesday said “the world is at war,” and he challenged the conservative governments of Central and Eastern Europe to soften their resistance to migrants seeking refuge.

headline: Review: ‘Landmarks,’ a Book on Language and Landscape
abstract: The British academic, nature writer and word lover Robert Macfarlane makes a passionate case for restoring the “literacy of the land.”
lead_paragraph: In a haunting scene in “Through the Looking Glass,” Alice wanders into a wood in which everything has been denuded of its name, and, by extension, its identity — the trees, the animals, even Alice herself.

headline: Review: L.A. Dance Project’s Eclectic Balancing Act
abstract: Benjamin Millepied’s young California company brings same-sex couples, lots of physicality and Martha Graham duets to its Joyce Theater debut.
lead_paragraph: What is the L.A. Dance Project? Is it modern dance — or ballet without point shoes? A vehicle for choreographers dead or alive?

headline: Charges Dropped in Freddie Gray Case
abstract: The final charges against Baltimore police officers involved in the Freddie Gray case have been dropped. The medical examiner had deemed his death a homicide as a result of injuries sustained in police custody.
lead_paragraph: The final charges against Baltimore police officers involved in the Freddie Gray case have been dropped. The medical examiner had deemed his death a homicide as a result of injuries sustained in police custody.

headline: Turkey Expands Purge, Shutting Down News Media Outlets
abstract: It has dismissed over 1,000 military personnel and ordered the shutdown of 45 newspapers, three news agencies, 16 television channels, 15 magazines and 29 publishers.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government ordered the closing of more than 100 media outlets on Wednesday, including newspapers, publishing companies and television channels, as part of a sweeping crackdown following a failed military coup this month.

headline: Stiglitz on Europe’s Economic Crisis
abstract: Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobel laureate economist, talks with The Times’s Peter Goodman about his book, “The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe.”
lead_paragraph: Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobel laureate economist, talks with The Times’s Peter Goodman about his book, “The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe.”

headline: Review: ‘Golem,’ a Visually Dazzling Fable for the Digital Age
abstract: This mind-pinching production from the British company 1927 combines live performance, animation and music.
lead_paragraph: Who, or what, is really in charge of our destiny? We like to believe that our will, our imagination, our reason are meticulously clicking away, taking hold of the future and shaping it to our desires. But what about that little companion in our pocket we consult so regularly, with its innumerable little helpers that we refer to dozens if not hundreds of times a day, attending to their chirps and beeps and rings as if to a relentless taskmaster?

headline: Review: Radiohead Revels in the Key of Dread
abstract: The band (and its musical disquiet) started the North American leg of its first tour since 2012 at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Grim and guarded tidings, delivered with beauty, strangeness and drive: That was Radiohead at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, starting the North American leg of its first tour since 2012. (The band played there again on Wednesday.) The group’s latest album, “A Moon Shaped Pool,” supplied the first five songs in the two-hour set and four more later — songs that extend a two-decade catalog of disquiet.

headline: Obama Is Said to Have Picked Presidential Library Site in Chicago
abstract: The location of the library is expected to be in Jackson Park on the South Side of Chicago, ending a debate within his inner circle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and the foundation helping to plot his path after the White House have selected Jackson Park on the South Side of Chicago as the site of his presidential library, ending a debate within his inner circle about the location, a person familiar with the decision said Wednesday.

headline: Incandescent With Rage
abstract: With the dropped charges in Baltimore, America is edging closer to telling people like me that the eye of justice isn’t blind but jaundiced.
lead_paragraph: No one need ask me anymore about how to heal the racial divide in America. No one need inquire about the path forward beyond racial strife. You will not be put at ease by my response.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Gaby Hoffmann Reads ‘Three Mothers, One Bond’
abstract: Hear the “Transparent” actress read the story of two hopeful mothers trying to navigate the often strange matchmaking process of open adoption.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Gaby Hoffmann (“Transparent,” “Girls”) reads the essay “Three Mothers, One Bond,” about a couple whose open-adoption application appeals to a birth mother because of, not despite, their sexuality.

headline: You Can Use Any Song You Want. Create a TV Show.
abstract: If you had access to the songs of some of the best-known musicians, what kind of TV show would you create? Tell us in 100 words or less.
lead_paragraph: If you had access to the songs of some of the best-known musicians, what kind of TV show would you create? Tell us in 100 words or less.

headline: Lil Yachty and 21 Savage: Atlanta Shows a Range of Hip-Hop
abstract: XXL magazine has chosen these two artists from the city for its Freshman issue, which highlights 10 up-and-coming rappers.
lead_paragraph: Every year, XXL magazine, the leading hip-hop publication, publishes its Freshman issue, in which its editors crown 10 up-and-coming rappers. It’s become something of a state of the union for emergent hip-hop movements, and the selection process helped the magazine become the first mainstream rap outlet to acknowledge the impact that the internet has on hip-hop taste.

headline: Obama, at Convention, Lays Out Stakes for a Divided Nation
abstract: The president revisited his own promise to guide the country into a new age of unity as a framework to rally Democrats around Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Flush With Cash, N.B.A.’s Players Union Will Improve Retiree Benefits
abstract: With the upgrade, players who were part of the league for at least three years can obtain a coverage plan that includes medical, hospital and prescription drug benefits.
lead_paragraph: Backed by a financial windfall that has distributed extraordinary wealth throughout the N.B.A. this summer, the National Basketball Players Association will offer improved access to health insurance to more than 1,500 retired players.

headline: Formaldehyde Rules Clear E.P.A. After 5-Year Fight
abstract: The rules, which go into effect next year, will impose testing and certification requirements to limit exposure to the toxic chemical.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday announced new limits to formaldehyde exposure, ending a battle of more than five years to regulate a toxic chemical commonly found throughout the home.

headline: Beetles Do Beatles: Music Coup for an Animated Netflix Show
abstract: “Beat Bugs” a children’s show, is one of several shows whose creator uses licensing deals to feature iconic song collections in unusually extensive ways.
lead_paragraph: If Josh Wakely was feeling a little fried, it was understandable: He had quickly become one of the busiest young writers and producers in television — with a little help from the Beatles, Bob Dylan and Motown.

headline: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Presides Over Shylock’s Appeal
abstract: In Venice, a mock appeal had the added appeal of seeing a production of “The Merchant of Venice” featuring Justice Ginsburg’s grandson.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — What do Supreme Court justices do on their summer vacations? For Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg — longtime liberal standard-bearer, recent Donald J. Trump critic — this year’s answer is: Go to Venice, watch your grandson perform in a production of “The Merchant of Venice” and preside over a mock appeal of the city’s most notorious resident, Shylock.

headline: Letter From Carolyn Torres to Mario Cuomo
abstract: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Carolyn Torres, a 17-year-old junior at St. Joseph High School in Brooklyn and an aspiring politician, typed this letter to praise the governor for being energetic and standing up for issues.
lead_paragraph: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Carolyn Torres, a 17-year-old junior at St. Joseph High School in Brooklyn and an aspiring politician, typed this letter to praise the governor for being energetic and standing up for issues.

headline: Letter From Jerry Tallmer to Mario Cuomo
abstract: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Jerry Tallmer, the drama critic for the New York Post, wrote to tell the governor how moved he was by the speech. “It was so tough. So angry. So right.”
lead_paragraph: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Jerry Tallmer, the drama critic for the New York Post, wrote to tell the governor how moved he was by the speech. “It was so tough. So angry. So right.”

headline: Letter From Janice Rugoff to Mario Cuomo
abstract: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Janice Rugoff, a Queens transplant living in Southern California, wrote to the governor to express some hometown pride over his “vital and moving keynote speech.”
lead_paragraph: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Janice Rugoff, a Queens transplant living in Southern California, wrote to the governor to express some hometown pride over his “vital and moving keynote speech.”

headline: Letter From Walt Michaels to Mario Cuomo
abstract: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Walt Michaels, a former head coach of the New York Jets, offered a pep talk. “Those of us who know you were never in doubt,” he wrote. “Now the entire nation is aware.”
lead_paragraph: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Walt Michaels, a former head coach of the New York Jets, offered a pep talk. “Those of us who know you were never in doubt,” he wrote. “Now the entire nation is aware.”

headline: Letter From E. Deloris Hairgrove-Brown to Mario Cuomo
abstract: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. In this letter, E. Deloris Hairgrove-Brown, a Texas Democrat, likened the governor to President John F. Kennedy.

headline: A Rogues’ Gallery of New True-Crime Titles
abstract: New books include “True Crime Addict” by James Renner and “The Dragon Behind the Glass” by Emily Voigt.
lead_paragraph: Proud as I am to identify myself as a lifelong addict of crime and mystery fiction, true crime unnerves me. It’s so . . . real. But fans of the genre make a strong case for their own peculiar obsession, to the point of making me want to have what they’re having. Whatever it is.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Ruth Ware, whose novel “The Woman in Cabin 10” is No. 4 on the hardcover fiction list, says she “definitely” owes a debt to Agatha Christie.
lead_paragraph: Agatha Redux: The British crime writer Ruth Ware has two best sellers this week — her new novel, “The Woman in Cabin 10,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, while her debut, “In a Dark, Dark Wood,” remains No. 8 on the trade paperback list after nine weeks. (My favorite thing about that book, which centers on an amnesiac and a bachelorette party gone very wrong, was learning that the British call such gatherings “hen parties.” One London reviewer described the story as “the hen party from hell,” which makes you think things might end in nuggets and dipping sauce.) Both of Ware’s novels resemble classic locked-door mysteries: Her first takes place in a remote English country house and her latest on a cruise ship in the North Sea — a horrifying enough prospect for some of us even before the protagonist witnesses a murder and is accused of losing her mind. Unsurprisingly, Ware said last year that she was a big fan of the golden-age mystery writers. “I love classic crime,” she told NPR’s David Greene during her “Dark Wood” publicity tour. “I read a huge amount of it as a kid, you know, Agatha Christie, Josephine Tey, Dorothy L. Sayers, Sherlock Holmes. And I didn’t consciously channel that when I was writing. But when I finished and reread the book, I did suddenly realize how much this kind of structure owed to, particularly, Agatha Christie. It wasn’t consciously done, but I think the setting, you know, the way it’s a closed cast of characters — I would say I definitely owe a debt to Christie.”

headline: The Speech That Made Obama
abstract: The Democratic National Convention address that launched a presidency, and the one that will begin drawing it to a close.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, almost to the day, Barack Obama’s flight from Springfield, Ill., landed in Boston around 4 a.m. He paced around the lobby of the Back Bay Hilton, ran into his campaign press secretary, Robert Gibbs, and together they contemplated the keynote speech Obama would deliver to the Democratic National Convention the next night. Sleep was not in the immediate plan for Obama, who was then running to become the only African-American in the United States Senate. He would head out again at 6 a.m. to tape “Meet the Press,” “Face the Nation” and “Late Edition” on CNN. It was not the normal Sunday morning regimen for little-known state lawmakers.

headline: Democratic Convention Night 3: What You Missed
abstract: On Night 3 of their convention, Democrats looked both backward and forward.
lead_paragraph: President Obama defended his legacy and laid out the ways Hillary Clinton would continue it at the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday. Other speakers included Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Tim Kaine, Mrs. Clinton’s running mate.

headline: Cuomo, in Convention Speech, Faces a High Standard: His Father’s
abstract: As he prepares to address the Democratic gathering, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York will draw inevitable comparisons with a landmark address Mario M. Cuomo gave in 1984.
lead_paragraph: It was the speech that would define liberalism for a generation of Democrats, powered by paeans to the American family, lean lyricism and a sonorous voice: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, onstage at the Moscone Center in San Francisco, giving the keynote address during the 1984 Democratic National Convention.

headline: U.S. Secures Vast New Trove of Intelligence on ISIS
abstract: Officials say the information, seized by American-backed militias in Syria, could help fight militants on the battlefield and prevent fighters from slipping into Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is poring over a vast trove of new intelligence about Islamic State fighters who have flowed into Syria and Iraq and some who then returned to their home countries, information that American officials say could help fight militants on the battlefield and prevent potential plotters from slipping into Europe.

headline: Mets’ Rally Goes for Naught as Cardinals Storm Past Jeurys Familia
abstract: Familia survived many tightrope walks this season, but he finally stumbled in a loss that negated Yoenis Cespedes’s dramatic two-run homer.
lead_paragraph: Jeurys Familia walked off the mound with an unfamiliar feeling on Wednesday night. Although he blew three saves during the World Series, the Mets’ All-Star closer had not done so in the regular season since July 30, 2015. Entering the ninth inning with a one-run lead against the St. Louis Cardinals, Familia had converted 52 consecutive save chances — the third-longest streak in history.

headline: Michael Bloomberg Trashes Donald Trump

lead_paragraph: Leaning on his own business record, the former mayor of New York, Michael R. Bloomberg, attacked Donald J. Trump’s record, saying, “I’m a New Yorker, and I know a con when I see one.”

headline: Championing Optimism, Obama Hails Clinton as His Political Heir
abstract: President Obama defended his legacy and laid out the ways Hillary Clinton would continue it at the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Obama delivered a stirring valedictory address at the Democratic convention Wednesday night, hailing Hillary Clinton as his rightful political heir and the party’s best hope to protect democracy from “homegrown demagogues” like the Republican Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 4: The Man in the Mask
abstract: On this week’s episode, a brief look at Elliot in happier times.
lead_paragraph: One of the most fascinating aspects of “Mr. Robot” has been its ability to capture the moment — whether airing its series premiere days after the revelation of a massive breach of United States government computer systems, or postponing its Season 1 finale because of a real-world shooting — despite being made months in advance of the news. So it feels right for the show to seize the pop culture moment as well. Thus, even as Netflix’s 1980s horror homage “Stranger Things” becomes one of the streaming service’s buzziest shows of the year, this week’s episode of “Mr. Robot” opens with a paean to getting high and reliving the fright flicks of your youth.

headline: A Torrent of Praise for Mario Cuomo’s 1984 Democratic Convention Speech
abstract: An archival search revealed hundreds of letters to the former New York governor after the speech, lauding his intellect, passion and precise diagnosis of the nation’s ills.
lead_paragraph: After Mario M. Cuomo, then the governor of New York, delivered his “Tale of Two Cities” keynote address during the 1984 Democratic National Convention in San Francisco, he received a torrent of praise from across the country and predictions of presidential ambitions.

headline: Joe Biden: Donald Trump Has ‘No Clue’
abstract: Vice President Joe Biden addressed the Democratic convention in Philadelphia on Wednesday, where he gave a personal account of Hillary Clinton while also attacking Donald J. Trump’s character.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joe Biden addressed the Democratic convention in Philadelphia on Wednesday, where he gave a personal account of Hillary Clinton while also attacking Donald J. Trump’s character.

headline: Yankees Fall to Astros, Blowing an Opportunity
abstract: With a chance to gain ground on their American League East rivals Baltimore, Toronto and Boston, all losers earlier in the day, the Yankees dropped a decision to Houston.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As hot as the Yankees have been in the last two weeks, they have not made up much ground in the American League East. So when they took the field Wednesday night with their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, on the mound, it was with the rare prospect of gaining on Baltimore, Toronto and Boston, all of whom had lost.

headline: Debt Collectors’ Abuses Prompt Consumer Agency to Propose New Rules
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau proposals aim to strengthen federal efforts to clamp down on collectors who hound people for debts they may not owe.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in nearly 40 years, federal regulators are preparing to significantly strengthen the rules that govern debt collection in an effort to clamp down on collectors who hound consumers for debts they may not even owe.

headline: Tim Kaine Goes on Attack While Appealing to Disaffected Republicans
abstract: The senator from Virginia, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, offered a little something for everyone in his convention speech.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In the early morning, he paid tribute to swing states, showering the Florida and Iowa delegations with love. By afternoon, he set off on an attempted Twitter tussle with Donald J. Trump.

headline: President Obama and the Long March
abstract: He took a long view in his convention speech, stressing Americans’ common bonds, consistent with the spirit that drove his historic presidency.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s speech before the Democratic convention in Philadelphia Wednesday night was, of course, an occasion to celebrate the candidacy of Hillary Clinton, his former secretary of state and the first woman to receive the presidential nomination of a major political party.

abstract: Hillary Clinton makes history on the final night of the Democratic National Convention. And Lollapalooza celebrates its 25th anniversary.
