The newest version, a limited-edition boyfriend tee, was just released online and at the brand’s East Hampton store. $95, atmcollection.com. — ALAINNA LEXIE BEDDIE

headline: Special Prosecutor Joins Philando Castile Shooting Case in Minnesota
abstract: The Ramsey County attorney in St. Paul said on Friday that he would not step aside, as Mr. Castile’s family had requested, but would seek help weighing the evidence.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The county attorney here said Friday that he would not step aside in the fatal police shooting of Philando Castile, despite requests from Mr. Castile’s family that a special prosecutor handle the case.

headline: Wild but Not Free
abstract: Viviana Peretti, an Italian photographer who lives in New York, spent three months in 2012 taking photographs at the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium.
lead_paragraph: Viviana Peretti, an Italian photographer who lives in New York, spent three months in 2012 taking photographs at the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium.

headline: Humans in the Wild, Animals in Captivity
abstract: Viviana Peretti, an Italian photographer who lives in New York, spent three months taking pictures every week in the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you are considering taking the children to the zoo for an entertaining and educational outing. The Italian photographer Viviana Peretti, who has lived in New York since 2010, would ask you to reconsider. Ms. Peretti, who had never been to a zoo before, spent three months in 2012 photographing every week at the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium. She always visited when admission was free or was a voluntary donation, so she would not be contributing to the operations. Her conclusion: Zoos are a great place to observe the exotic behaviors of human beings in the wild.

headline: The Playlist: AlunaGeorge Says No and Radiohead Says Goodnight
abstract: Our pop critics on the week’s 10 most notable new tracks, videos and mixes, from Nels Cline’s “The Bond” to RichPoSlim’s “Make You Mine.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: Hamilton, Burr and the Great Waterworks Ruse
abstract: A three-inch piece of wooden pipe is a reminder that five years before their fatal duel, Aaron Burr conned Alexander Hamilton into supporting a company that was a front for a bank.
lead_paragraph: The history of the Morris-Jumel Mansion is as complicated and sordid as you would expect of the oldest home in Manhattan. It is steeped in deceit, murder, ghosts and contemporary Broadway theater. And the artifact that untangles this convoluted history is an unassuming three-inch chunk of a hollowed-out pine tree.

headline: How Valeant Cashed In Twice on Higher Drug Prices
abstract: It wasn’t just soaring drug prices that helped Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ cash flow. A credit for inventories at those higher prices also plumped the figures.
lead_paragraph: The mania surrounding Valeant Pharmaceuticals International hit its peak a year ago. Strange as it may seem today after all that has happened, on Aug. 5, 2015 — two weeks after a dazzling second-quarter earnings report — the drug company’s stock closed at $262.52.

headline: Do Women Want to Have a Mimosa With Hillary?
abstract: Gail Collins replied to some of the thousand-plus comments she received on her article about the presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins responded to some of the thousand-plus comments she received on her Sunday Review cover story “Behind Hillary Clinton’s Mask.”

headline: Norway Considers a Birthday Gift for Finland: The Peak of an Arctic Mountain
abstract: A movement is afoot to turn over the summit of Mount Halti, already the highest mountain in Finland, to its neighbor.
lead_paragraph: Norway is pondering an unusual birthday gift for its neighbor Finland: an Arctic mountain peak.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Strikes Down North Carolina Voter ID Requirement
abstract: The decision on Friday upended voting procedures in a closely contested state about three months before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court decisively struck down North Carolina’s voter identification law on Friday, saying its provisions deliberately “target African-Americans with almost surgical precision” in an effort to depress black turnout at the polls.

headline: Navy Will Name Ship for Harvey Milk, Slain Gay Rights Leader
abstract: Mr. Milk, a San Francisco supervisor whose life and death have been the subject of books, movies and an opera, served in the Navy from 1951 to 1955.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of changing times for the American military, the Navy plans to name a ship for Harvey Milk, the gay rights leader and San Francisco supervisor who was assassinated in 1978.

headline: Summer Camp Memories
abstract: A reader describes her experience contrasted with that of young boys introduced to Jewish ritual slaughtering.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With the Conventions Behind Us, Our Takeaways From Both
abstract: The Republican and Democratic conventions offered important lessons about the two presidential nominees, and their parties, as they head into the November general election.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Democratic convention is over, and delegates streamed to airports and train stations on Friday morning to return home for the summer weekend. But the contrasting back-to-back political displays — Republicans met last week in Cleveland — offered important lessons about the two presidential nominees, and their parties, as they head into the November general election. Check out our takeaways:

headline: Dreaming Up a Summer Idyll for Frederic Edwin Church
abstract: Twenty-one architects come up with their own visions for a show at Olana, Church’s historic property overlooking the Hudson.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — The Hudson River School artist Frederic Edwin Church, who painted sweeping landscapes that turned him into one of the best-known American artists of the 19th century, wrote to a friend in May 1871 that he was as busy as “10,000 beavers.”

headline: 247 Victims of Terror
abstract: A reader writes that a New York Times project helps us see the “true losses.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Malaysia and the Trans-Pacific Partnership Trade Pact
abstract: Representative Louise Slaughter writes that the scandal in Malaysia is one reason among many that Congress should reject the trade agreement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hospitals in Syria Are Airstrike Targets
abstract: As government forces encircle rebel-held areas of Aleppo, Syria, the city’s few remaining hospitals have come under fire. Airstrikes and lack of supplies are a matter of life and death for patients, according to The New York Times's Beirut bureau chief, Anne Barnard.
lead_paragraph: As government forces encircle rebel-held areas of Aleppo, Syria, the city’s few remaining hospitals have come under fire. Airstrikes and lack of supplies are a matter of life and death for patients, according to The New York Times's Beirut bureau chief, Anne Barnard.

headline: The Pay Gap for Women
abstract: A psychology professor says, “We must rewrite the cultural scripts” that have produced stereotypes of women.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton, on the Grand Stage
abstract: The conventions over, readers reflect on a historic moment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Orangutan’s Mimicry Offers Clues to Language’s Origins
abstract: Rocky lives in the Indianapolis Zoo and can accurately copy the pitch and tone of human sounds, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Orangutan hear, orangutan do.

headline: How a Will Treating Children Differently Can Still Be Fair
abstract: Dividing an estate unevenly is likely to result in hurt feelings at the least. But honest discussions ahead of time can solve many problems.
lead_paragraph: CHILDREN crave equal attention from their parents. So when it comes to inheritance, which can seem like a final accounting of that love, anything but an equal split can be tough to grasp.

headline: Anton Coppola, a Maestro With Many Encores
abstract: Mr. Coppola, the patriarch of the creative Coppola clan, is 99 and still composing and conducting operatic music.
lead_paragraph: Francis Ford Coppola may have created the “Godfather” films, but these days, the real godfather of the Coppola clan is his uncle Anton Coppola.

headline: Is Hypnosis All in Your Head? Brain Scans Suggest Otherwise
abstract: A study at Stanford found that the “trance” people fall into is a neurophysiological state, not the result of a subject’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: You are getting sleepy. Very sleepy. You will forget everything you read in this article.

headline: How Lori Bodinizzo, a Bemelmans Bartender, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: For Ms. Bodinizzo, Sundays are about going outside, wearing comfortable clothing and spending quality time with her wife and friends.
lead_paragraph: Lori Bodinizzo has the distinction of being the only female bartender in the 69-year history of Bemelmans Bar at the Carlyle hotel. When she’s not mixing a Manhattan while surrounded by the whimsical murals of Ludwig Bemelmans, creator of the Madeline children’s book series, Ms. Bodinizzo, 49, spends Sundays in the sunshine with her wife, Nicole Riley, 39, dean at Edward A. Reynolds West Side High School. “I’ve been at the bar for the past three years. It’s beautiful, but sometimes it feels dark,” Ms. Bodinizzo said. “My shift is from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., so I lose most of the daylight. Sundays are about quality time with my wife and friends, and being outdoors.” The couple lives on the second floor of a walk-up on the Upper West Side.

headline: The Sports Editor, Jason Stallman: How I Do My Job
abstract: “Did you see the Norwich terrier’s ears?” The Times’s sports editor, Jason Stallman, explains why the sports section covers dog shows — and more.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, the sports editor, Jason Stallman, explains how he does his job.

headline: So, What Do You Think of Hillary Clinton Now?
abstract: What the historic nominee meant to a spectrum of people in Philadelphia this week.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — No matter what you think of Hillary Clinton, this week represented a historic moment in American politics. What does Mrs. Clinton’s presidential nomination mean to average voters, die-hard Democrats and Bernie or Busters? We asked a few here in Philadelphia.

headline: Bill Cosby Drops Lawsuit Against Accuser in Assault Case
abstract: His lawsuit sought to recover the money he gave in a confidential financial settlement to the accuser, Andrea Constand.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby has dropped a lawsuit that sought to recover the money he gave in a confidential financial settlement to the accuser in his criminal case who says he drugged and sexually assaulted her at his home in 2004, according to court documents filed Thursday.

headline: Clinton’s Portrayal of Trump as Dictator Aims at the Left and Right
abstract: Allies of Hillary Clinton, abandoning the standard Democratic game plan, are urging conservatives and liberals to band together against a singular threat.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Democrats marked a decisive turn in their campaign against Donald J. Trump this week, moving to recast the 2016 race not as a conventional battle between left and right but as a national emergency that requires voters of all stripes to band together against a singularly menacing candidate.

headline: The Democrats Nailed It. Does It Matter?
abstract: Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins chew over Hillary’s speech and the best Republican convention Democrats ever had.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: So, Arthur, what did you think of Hillary Clinton’s big speech? I admit she’s never going to stun the nation with her oratory, but I thought it was pretty good.

headline: Zelda Fichandler, a Matriarch of Regional Theater, Dies at 91
abstract: Ms. Fichandler was a founder of the Arena Stage in Washington in 1950, building it into a professional force that helped spur the growth of theater companies around the country.
lead_paragraph: Zelda Fichandler, a seminal figure in the regional theater movement who led Arena Stage in Washington for 41 years, producing more than 400 shows and directing more than 50 for a company that helped spur the growth of professional theater around the country and became its centerpiece in the nation’s capital, died on Friday at her home in Washington. She was 91.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Tilda Swinton
abstract: The actress shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Tilda Swinton, who shares her list with T.

headline: Witnessing History, Without Recording It
abstract: To fully experience Hillary Clinton’s nomination, I had to stop writing about it.
lead_paragraph: My physics teacher in high school used to tell us to put our pencils down when he was about to say something really important. If you’re taking notes, he said, you’re not really listening.

headline: A Pro-Immigrant Party Rises in the Netherlands
abstract: Denk, or Think, is intended to attract minorities and represent their views in Dutch politics, where a right-wing anti-immigrant movement has caught fire.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Europe has more than its share of angry anti-immigrant political parties these days. But one party has turned the politics of immigration on its head, positioning itself as perhaps the first in Europe with a pro-immigrant stance, run by people from immigrant backgrounds.

headline: What I Love | Victoria Clark
abstract: The Broadway star has a new husband, a new home in Hudson Heights, and a new role, directing.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway star has a new husband, a new home in Hudson Heights, and a new role, directing.

headline: Next Step in TXU Bankruptcy Is Up to the Courts and Regulators
abstract: The power producer NextEra Energy wants to buy the bankrupt company’s 80 percent stake in the power transmission group Oncor Electric Delivery.
lead_paragraph: The long, sad saga of TXU may finally be heading toward a conclusion. The power producer NextEra Energy is buying the bankrupt company’s 80 percent stake in the power transmission group Oncor Electric Delivery, valued at $18.4 billion.

headline: Review: In ‘The Winter’s Tale,’ the Silk Flows Better Than the Steps
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s adaptation of this Shakespearean romance, performed by the National Ballet of Canada, is part of the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: With dogged perseverance, Christopher Wheeldon has turned himself into a storyteller. For a choreographer who made his mark with nonnarrative ballets, like “Polyphonia,” that embraced form with a quietly effortless and eerie power, his current crop of narrative dances plants him firmly on the side of tradition. Yes, he won a Tony Award for “An American in Paris,” but over the past few years, I’ve found myself missing the Mr. Wheeldon whose imagination wasn’t bound by plot.

headline: A Broadway Star in Hudson Heights
abstract: Victoria Clark, a Tony winner, has a new husband, a new home and a new role, directing.
lead_paragraph: Here is how much Victoria Clark’s husband, Tom Reidy, loves her: On Sept. 30, 2014, he gave up a rent-regulated apartment in Brooklyn to throw in his lot with her.

headline: Overcoming Obstacles with Love
abstract: Kevin Hillery and Shannon Beydler faced many challenges together, which only proved to strengthen their bond. The couple were married on July 3 in Warrenton, Va.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Hillery and Shannon Beydler faced many challenges together, which only proved to strengthen their bond. The couple were married on July 3 in Warrenton, Va.

headline: After an Accident, Finding Love with a Marine
abstract: A Naval Academy graduate finds that obstacles are for conquering.
lead_paragraph: In a relationship that would be full of unusual challenges, Kevin Hillery faced an all-too-typical one just months after he and Shannon Beydler started dating.

headline: Photographs From the Democratic Convention
abstract: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

headline: What Women Owe Hillary Clinton
abstract: The first female presidential nominee was always going to face a difficult path. How difficult? We’re about to find out.
lead_paragraph: She put her hand over her heart when the crowd roared its raucous, loving welcome. When she mentioned the milestone she represents, as the first woman a major party has nominated for president, she wrapped it in “our nation’s march to a more perfect union.” She talked about “standing here as my mother’s daughter and my daughter’s mother.” And she went for it as a feminist, with one of the well-tested applause lines of the night: “We will help you balance family and work and you know what, if fighting for affordable health care and paid family leave is playing the woman card, then Deal. Me. In.” (“LadySwagger,” the writer Suzy Khimm tweeted.)

headline: Review: A Shark Storm in the Desert. And That’s Just for Starters.
abstract: The fourth “Sharknado” movie, on Syfy, is a cameo-choked mess.
lead_paragraph: For a third summer now, we find ourselves asking, “Did the world really need another ‘Sharknado’ movie?” In 2014, a disappointing “Sharknado 2” made the answer to that question “Perhaps not.” Yet in 2015, the gleefully outlandish “3” earned a “Sure, what the heck!”

headline: Appeals Court Ruling on North Carolina Voting Law
abstract: The court opinion on North Carolina's voting laws from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
lead_paragraph: The court opinion on North Carolina's voting laws from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

headline: Brooklyn Hospital’s Sale, Backed by de Blasio and Cuomo, Is Drawing Federal Scrutiny
abstract: Subpoenas have been received by the State University of New York, which owned Long Island College Hospital, and by a union that supported Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: Before Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo began their bitter public feud, the two men found themselves on the same side of tense negotiations over the future of Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Yahoo’s Sale to Verizon Leaves Shareholders With Little Say
abstract: The internet giant’s decision to sell its business is plagued with challenges that reveal how unusual deal structures can affect shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s $4.8 billion sale to Verizon is a complicated beast, showing how different acquisition structures can affect how shareholders are treated.

headline: ‘Stranger Things’ Is the Show of the Summer. Let’s Talk About It.
abstract: The Netflix throwback horror series has been steadily building buzz this month. Have you seen it?
lead_paragraph: There are homages, and there are homages so committed that they become practically indistinguishable from the original works.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jenna Wortham, Kim Severson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Emanuel Ax, the Emerson Quartet and Other Recitals With a View
abstract: A Little Night Music, the Mostly Mozart program at Lincoln Center’s Kaplan Penthouse, also features Paul Lewis and Martin Frost this week.
lead_paragraph: A Little Night Music, the series of intimate, hourlong programs at 10 p.m. in the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center, has become one of the most consistently popular offerings of the Mostly Mozart Festival. In that inviting space, with the city visible through dramatic, wall-spanning windows, audience members share small cocktail tables and enjoy complimentary wine. Four of this season’s seven Night Music programs take place this week, and each is enticing.

headline: Robert Streb Ties Jimmy Walker for P.G.A. Championship Lead
abstract: Walker faltered on the final two holes Friday and Streb tied him at nine under par. Jason Day tied Emiliano Grillo for third.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Everything was working for Jimmy Walker, playing a dream round on a sterling afternoon in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club on Friday.

headline: ‘Batman: The Killing Joke’ Finds Kevin Conroy Back Under the (Animated) Cowl
abstract: Forget Michael Keaton, George Clooney, Christian Bale. Mr. Conroy has played the Batman for almost 25 years.
lead_paragraph: As a rule, Batmen don’t age well. Screen portrayals tend to feel, in some way, like a response to an earlier actor’s take — Adam West followed by Michael Keaton, George Clooney followed by Christian Bale. There’s only one Bat actor whose performance feels timeless, partly because it’s all in his voice.

headline: A Sampler: A Batman Wrestling With Ghosts of the Past
abstract: Kevin Conroy’s run as the voice of the Caped Crusader includes some memorable episodes.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Conroy has spoken hundreds of thousands of lines of dialogue as Batman, but the following performances stand out.

headline: Review: In This Opera, You Can Depart, but You Can Never Leave
abstract: Thomas Adès has turned Luis Buñuel’s film “The Exterminating Angel” into an audacious three-act opera at the Salzburg Festival in Austria.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — It takes some daring for a composer to choose a classic film as a subject for an opera. Comparisons are inevitable. But not much intimidates the prodigious British composer Thomas Adès. On Thursday at the Salzburg Festival, Mr. Adès conducted the ORF Vienna Radio Symphony Orchestra and an outstanding cast in the premiere of “The Exterminating Angel,” based on the 1962 Luis Buñuel film.

headline: Sharon Jones, a Burst of Light, Even in Dark Times
abstract: The soul singer, the subject of a new documentary that chronicles her career and cancer struggles, tells of a hard new turn in her story.
lead_paragraph: On her emphatic new single, “I’m Still Here,” the soul singer Sharon Jones presents her life as a series of high hurdles she has cleared with grit and grace. The lyrics detail her birth in the Jim Crow South, her childhood in “the Bronx Is Burning” New York, the years she spent rejected by record companies for being “too short, too fat, too black and too old,” and, most recently, her well-publicized battles with cancer. “I didn’t know if I’d live to see another day,” the 60-year-old singer declares in the final verse. “But I’m still here!”

headline: Hillary Clinton, North Carolina, Zika: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Her Husband’s Death Motivates Sheryl Sandberg to Write Another Book
abstract: Ms. Sandberg, chief operating officer of Facebook, and a collaborator will focus on hardship and resilience.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer of Facebook, lost her husband last year, she wrote a moving post about her grief that prompted questions about whether she might write a book that would help people cope with their own losses.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Insult Comedy as Blood Sport: The Rise of the Roast Battle
abstract: Forget celebrity roasts. Inspired by rap throwdowns, standup comics are going head to head, and no subject is off limits.
lead_paragraph: When the comedian Jeff Ross started flinging insults at the Friars Club in the mid-1990s, the comedy roast was mostly seen as a relic. “It was like jousting or some lost art,” he said, recalling that comics poked fun at him for participating. “It was corny.”

headline: Andrew Sullivan on His Brief Return to the Online Political Fray
abstract: The commentator talks about his two-week foray into blogging about the two party conventions, after a long hiatus for meditation and work on a spiritual memoir.
lead_paragraph: Since Andrew Sullivan abruptly closed his blog, The Dish, in early 2015 after nearly 15 years and thousands of posts, he settled into a routine of reading, meditation and exercise along with work on a spiritual memoir about what it means to be a Christian in the 21st century.

headline: Computer Systems Used by Clinton Campaign Are Said to Be Hacked, Apparently by Russians
abstract: A federal law enforcement official said the intrusion appeared to have come from that country’s intelligence services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Computer systems used by Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign were hacked in an attack that appears to have come from Russia’s intelligence services, a federal law enforcement official said on Friday.

headline: Sumner Redstone’s Busy October: 3 Cases in 3 Courts in 3 States
abstract: The fight for Mr. Redstone’s media empire will culminate in October, with lawsuits over his mental competence and his move to replace five Viacom directors.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers in the bitter fight over Sumner M. Redstone’s $40 billion media empire could be awfully busy come October.

headline: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ Goes From Stage to Page on Saturday at the Witching Hour
abstract: Even though J.K. Rowling isn’t the author of this play, Scholastic’s midnight release of the script as a book is expected to draw thousands to stores this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The biggest book of the summer isn’t a blockbuster thriller or a splashy celebrity memoir. It’s a play about a middle-aged wizard.

headline: ‘We Still Have a Lot of People Dying’
abstract: More than a year after the death of Freddie Gray, we sit down with Brandon Scott, a Baltimore city councilman, to discuss the city’s next step forward.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — I first met Brandon Scott the day after Freddie Gray died.

headline: For Oracle, Money’s Not the Problem. It’s Coping With the Cloud.
abstract: The business software omnivore is playing catch-up in one of the hotter fields of tech. Its NetSuite purchase is its latest thrust in that direction.
lead_paragraph: REDWOOD SHORES, Calif. — It was not all that difficult for the Silicon Valley software giant Oracle to pay $9.3 billion for a company called NetSuite. But then writing big checks has rarely been a problem for Oracle, which over the last 11 years has acquired dozens of companies in its quest to find more and more customers.

headline: Stress Tests Find Some Big European Banks Wanting
abstract: Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena of Italy, the worst performer in the stress tests, announced that it would raise 5 billion euros in new capital.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European regulators announced on Friday that new stress tests found that a handful of the region’s biggest banks would struggle in a severe economic downturn or in the next financial crisis.

headline: Tesla Faults Brakes, but Not Autopilot, in Fatal Crash
abstract: The company told Senate staff members that the automatic braking system was “separate and distinct” from Autopilot, according to the staff members.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors has told Senate investigators that its crash-prevention system failed to work properly in a fatal crash, but said its Autopilot technology was not at fault, according to a Senate staff member.

headline: Robert Carswell, Treasury Negotiator in Iran Hostage Crisis, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Carswell was instrumental in choreographing the delicate financial talks that coaxed Tehran into freeing 52 American hostages in 1981.
lead_paragraph: Robert Carswell, a Treasury Department official who was instrumental in choreographing the delicate financial negotiations that coaxed Iran into releasing 52 American hostages in 1981, died on July 22 at his home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 87.

headline: Zika Cases in the United States
abstract: Mapping where Zika infections have been reported.
lead_paragraph: Mapping where Zika infections have been reported.

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega, Left of Center
abstract: Not quite what we saw in Philly, but maybe some relationship.
lead_paragraph: Music for the DNC that isn’t “Fight Song”? Anyway, I was actually at this performance.

headline: Lula, Brazil’s Ex-President, Will Face Trial on Obstruction Charges
abstract: The decision could complicate the political ambitions of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who is accused of obstructing the inquiry into the bribery scheme at Petrobras.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president who has been one of Brazil’s most towering political figures, will stand trial on charges of obstructing the investigation into the colossal bribery scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company, a federal judge said Friday.

headline: Study Proposes Steps to Better Ensure Police Officers’ Safety
abstract: Among the Justice Department recommendations were using body armor, waiting for backups on certain calls and giving responding officers better information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a time of rising concern over attacks on officers, a Justice Department study released Friday urged police departments to take a number of steps to ensure officers’ safety, such as using body armor, waiting for backups on dangerous calls and correcting “dangerous behaviors” that leave them at risk.

headline: Canada Judge Rules That Police Entrapped Couple in Bomb Plot
abstract: British Columbia court finds that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police manipulated a couple into planting what they thought were pressure-cooker bombs.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A Canadian couple who planted what they believed were pressure-cooker bombs outside British Columbia’s legislature in 2013 were freed on Friday after a judge ruled that they had been entrapped by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

headline: Robert Streb Shoots 63 at the P.G.A. Championship, Tying a Major Record
abstract: Streb is now tied for the tournament lead, at nine under, with Jimmy Walker.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — With a 21-foot putt on the par-3 ninth hole at Baltusrol Golf Club, Robert Streb tied the best round in a major championship with a seven-under-par 63. It was the 30th time a player has shot so low in a major.

headline: Fact Check: Hillary Clinton at the D.N.C.
abstract: The New York Times checks assertions by Hillary Clinton at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times checks assertions by Hillary Clinton at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Rules Delay at P.G.A. Championship Sinks Sport Into Quagmire Yet Again
abstract: A wayward drive by Jordan Spieth on the seventh hole led to a rules situation that lasted about 10 minutes to resolve.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Jordan Spieth was making a stirring, rousing run up the leaderboard Friday, finally bringing some sparkle and star power to a drowsy 2016 P.G.A. Championship, when golf’s pesky rule book once again elbowed its way into the competition.

headline: More Tuned in for Trump’s Speech, but Democrats Won Ratings Over All
abstract: The Nielsen ratings came in, and while more than 32 million people tuned in to watch Mr. Trump’s speech, the Democrats’ convention drew more viewers.
lead_paragraph: “The Nielsen ratings just came out,” Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, said with a smile on Friday in Colorado, hours after his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton, delivered her climactic convention speech. “We beat her by millions.”

headline: On English Tests, New York City Students Match Peers Across State
abstract: The latest results on standardized exams offer good news for the de Blasio administration as it struggles to fix faltering schools.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, New York City students caught up to their peers around the state in English, officials said on Friday in announcing the results for the standardized tests given to third through eighth graders this year.

headline: The Mets Celebrate a Memorable Mike Piazza Moment
abstract: The team, as part of a weekend celebrating Piazza’s induction into the Hall of Fame, displayed the jersey he wore when he hit a home run during the first major sporting event held in New York after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Mets quietly welcomed the return of a famed piece of team history, which earlier this year came perilously close to going astray.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, July 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Any trouble I get myself in now — even an honest mistake — will be a hundred times worse than if any normal person did it.”

headline: Presidential Convention Quiz
abstract: The nominations are complete. How well were you paying attention?
lead_paragraph: The nominations are complete. How well were you paying attention?

headline: In Pokémon Go, Lawmakers Fear Unexpected Entrance of the Sexual Predator
abstract: Two New York State senators who believe the game could endanger children are proposing legislation to prevent certain sex offenders from playing it.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction this month, the app known as Pokémon Go has sent millions of players chasing after imaginary creatures in parks, city streets and, occasionally, ditches and trees.

headline: Jason’s Still Kickin’
abstract: Performed by Matt Richtel (vocals, piano, lyrics, music), Susan Appe (backup vocals, guitar, drums, production), and Ben Lempert (lead guitar).
lead_paragraph: Performed by Matt Richtel (vocals, piano, lyrics, music), Susan Appe (backup vocals, guitar, drums, production), and Ben Lempert (lead guitar).

headline: The American Conventions, Full of the Unconventional
abstract: Declan Walsh, the Cairo bureau chief for The New York Times, is reporting on the presidential campaign for a global audience.
lead_paragraph: Declan Walsh, our bureau chief in Cairo, is reporting on the 2016 American presidential campaign for a global audience in much the same way he would cover an event overseas.

headline: Sitting on a Celestial Throne
abstract: Lily Silverstein makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we get to welcome Lily Silverstein as a new constructor. Ms. Silverstein makes her debut with a very accessible, fun Saturday grid, and it’s always a delight to see a female constructor join the themeless, late-week ranks.

headline: North Carolina’s Voting Restrictions Struck Down as Racist
abstract: The appeals court decision and others like it show the bitter struggle for basic fairness beyond the national spotlight of the nominating conventions.
lead_paragraph: The scurrilous attempt by North Carolina Republicans to suppress the rising power of black voters was struck down on Friday by a federal appeals court that concluded that the state’s voting strictures “target African-Americans with almost surgical precision.”

headline: Local Zika Cases in Florida Should Wake Up Congress
abstract: Too many people have been put at risk by the failure to appropriate emergency funds to fight the virus.
lead_paragraph: The Zika-carrying mosquitoes are here. Public health officials said on Friday that four people in the Miami area have become infected with the Zika virus. This is likely to be the first local transmission of the virus by mosquitoes in the continental United States. Perhaps this news will shock Congress and state and local governments into taking more forceful steps to fight this disease.

headline: Tell Consumers How Many Calories There are in Alcohol
abstract: With voluntary nutritional labeling standards for beer, wine and liquor ineffective, regulators may need to step in.
lead_paragraph: The average 12-ounce beer has 153 calories, slightly more than a can of Coca-Cola. But the typical beer drinker probably doesn’t know that, because regulators have long exempted alcohol producers from stamping their products with the kinds of nutritional labels that are required on other beverages and on food.

headline: Jets’ G.M. Is Wary of Guaranteeing a Playoff Berth
abstract: Mike Maccagnan, the general manager, also said it is conceivable the Jets will carry four quarterbacks on the roster after the re-signing of Ryan Fitzpatrick.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Mike Maccagnan and his wife, Betty, recently stole away for a trip to Europe, which would have been nice and relaxing had he been able to fully enjoy himself. But he spent much of the visit checking the internet, sending emails and making phone calls regarding the Jets’ negotiations with Muhammad Wilkerson and Ryan Fitzpatrick.

headline: Rays Rough Up Ivan Nova in What May Be His Final Start for the Yankees
abstract: Nova surrendered five runs on six innings before exiting in the fifth inning. He argued with plate umpire Laz Diaz on his way to the dugout.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — For all that the eternally easygoing Ivan Nova has encountered in his career — starting a playoff opener, undergoing Tommy John surgery, getting sent to the bullpen — he seems to greet it all the same way: with a shrug.

headline: Mets Lose Juan Lagares to Injury, Then Take the Field and Fall to the Rockies
abstract: A sputtering season hit more snags on Friday when Lagares, a Gold Glove-winning outfielder two seasons ago, landed on the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: Breaking standard practice, music played in the Mets’ clubhouse after Friday’s lackluster 6-1 loss to the Colorado Rockies at Citi Field. The defeats and head-scratching offense have piled up lately, but Manager Terry Collins spoke briefly to the team after the game and ordered music. So Bon Jovi and Silvestre Dangond blared from the speakers near Yoenis Cespedes’s locker.

headline: Trump’s Thunderbolts
abstract: The Republican presidential nominee responded to questions about the Democratic convention, including things said about him there.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is mad at me. He thinks I’ve treated him “very badly.” But he returned my call on Friday night on his way to a rally in Colorado and agreed to do a lightning round on the Democratic convention. He began, naturally, by bragging about his convention ratings and bounce, but then we got down to specifics.

headline: Russia’s Weight Lifters Are Barred From Rio
abstract: The International Weightlifting Federation said in Budapest that the integrity of the sport had been seriously damaged by the Russians.
lead_paragraph: All of Russia’s weight lifters were banned from the Rio Olympics on Friday for doping. The eight competition spots have been offered to other countries.

headline: Corrections: July 30, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, July 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Will Sanders Supporters Come Around?
abstract: The science of intergroup dynamics suggests they will.
lead_paragraph: Looming over the Democratic National Convention this week was the threat of party division. Will the rift between Hillary Clinton’s supporters and Bernie Sanders’s supporters be mended? Or will there be a failure to reconcile, imperiling the effort to defeat Donald J. Trump in the presidential election?

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Born to Be Blue’ and ‘The 33’
abstract: Ethan Hawke plays Chet Baker, the heroin-ravaged jazz trumpeter and singer, in “Born to Be Blue.” And Patricia Riggen recreates the Chilean mining disaster in “The 33.”
lead_paragraph: Ethan Hawke plays Chet Baker, the heroin-ravaged jazz trumpeter and singer whose mystique endures, in “Born to Be Blue.” Asif Kapadia chronicles the rise and fall of the singer Amy Winehouse in “Amy.” And Patricia Riggen recreates the Chilean mining disaster in “The 33.”

headline: Norway-Finland
abstract: Mount Halti is the highest mountain in Finland, but its 4,478-foot summit is in Norway.
lead_paragraph: Mount Halti is the highest mountain in Finland, but its 4,478-foot summit is in Norway.

headline: ‘I’m Resigned to Having a Terrible President’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss the Democratic convention, the acquittals in Freddie Gray’s death and Yahoo’s sale. And yes, Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Yahoo and the Online Universe According to Verizon
abstract: In amassing Yahoo, AOL and other online services, Verizon is preparing for the day when its most important clients are advertisers, not users.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications’ $4.83 billion acquisition of Yahoo has the technology cognoscenti scratching their heads. What does Verizon, the country’s biggest wireless company, see in an internet also-ran?

headline: Meet the New Owner of the Playboy Mansion
abstract: Who is Daren Metropoulos, and why did he just drop more than $100 million to buy the Playboy Mansion?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last month, when the 32-year-old co-owner of Hostess Brands plunked down $100 million for the Playboy Mansion, the snickering was instant: Hugh Hefner’s pleasure palace had sold to the maker of snack cakes like Twinkies and Ho Hos.

headline: The Disrupters: Making New York’s Cultural Boards More Diverse
abstract: The glass ceilings at elite cultural organizations are starting to crack after some pressure from the city.
lead_paragraph: One morning last September, the billionaires Ronald Perelman and Jerry Speyer strolled into Carnegie Hall, but not to hear Yo-Yo Ma play Bach or Deborah Voigt sing Strauss.

headline: Another Point of View
abstract: A walker in New York City can find an inexhaustible bounty of visual rewards, as the old proposition goes.
lead_paragraph: A walker in New York City can find an inexhaustible bounty of visual rewards, as the old proposition goes.

headline: New York, Through an iPhone’s Lens
abstract: Our reporter shares moments that made him stop, snap and tweet.
lead_paragraph: These scenes, photographed with a smartphone and posted to Twitter over the last month, are proof that an inexhaustible bounty of visual rewards is there to be reaped by a walker in the city.

headline: The Olympics Issue
abstract: The peerless swimmer Katie Ledecky; a photo essay of Olympians and their heroes; the sprinter Justin Gatlin’s comeback; how Boston’s citizens fought to reject their city’s bid; and 10 writers on their memories of Games past.
lead_paragraph: The peerless swimmer Katie Ledecky; a photo essay of Olympians and their heroes; the sprinter Justin Gatlin’s comeback; how Boston’s citizens fought to reject their city’s bid; and 10 writers on their memories of Games past.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia to the isle of Aero in Denmark.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia to the isle of Aero in Denmark.

headline: What Is Immunotherapy? The Basics on These Cancer Treatments
abstract: Some of the most promising advances in cancer involve these treatments. Here are answers to some basic questions about this rapidly evolving field.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most promising advances in cancer research in recent years involve treatments known as immunotherapy. These advances are spurring billions of dollars in investment by drug companies, and are leading to hundreds of clinical trials. Here are answers to some basic questions about this complex and rapidly evolving field.

headline: Have You Received Immunotherapy Treatment for Cancer?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from doctors and patients who have experience giving or receiving immunotherapy treatment for cancer.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from doctors and patients who have experience giving or receiving immunotherapy treatment for cancer.

headline: Harnessing the Immune System to Fight Cancer
abstract: New drugs and methods of altering a patient’s own immune cells are helping some cancer patients — but not all — even when standard treatments fail.
lead_paragraph: Steve Cara expected to sail through the routine medical tests required to increase his life insurance in October 2014. But the results were devastating. He had lung cancer, at age 53. It had begun to spread, and doctors told him it was inoperable.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Student Turnout, by Major
abstract: Did you vote, education major? How about you, engineer?
lead_paragraph: Did you vote, education major? How about you, engineer?

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Cautionary Tale of the Fall of Yahoo
abstract: Twitter, Facebook, Google and Amazon shared their second-quarter earnings reports, and Yahoo agreed to sell itself to Verizon for about $5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Disputes Over Sidewalk Gardens
abstract: Planting the tree pit in front of your house, an ex-husband’s name on a lease, and co-op inspections.
lead_paragraph: For decades, I have tended the pit garden — that little plot of soil surrounding the sidewalk tree — outside my townhouse, purchasing plants, mulch and soil. I even coordinated with the city to replace a tree. Many neighbors have complimented me on my work and expressed gratitude. But last fall, a spokesman for the block association (I did not even know we had one!) said he planned to landscape all the pit gardens on the block to give them a uniform look. This spring, he asked me to remove my plantings and garden elsewhere. He has already replanted one side of the street. My understanding is that the city owns the pit gardens, not the block association. I was doing urban beautification long before he was around. Should I continue as usual? What do you suggest?

headline: Hong Kong Bars Pro-Independence Candidate From Election
abstract: Officials said Saturday that the candidate’s support for independence from China made it impossible for him to uphold the legal duties of a lawmaker.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A political candidate in Hong Kong has been barred from running for office, after government officials said Saturday that his support for the territory’s independence from China made it impossible for him to uphold the legal duties of a lawmaker.

headline: At Sweetgreen, a Suitcase Full of Cash Won’t Buy You Lunch
abstract: Although America is far from being completely cashless, some restaurants are betting that customers will be comfortable forgoing cash for convenience.
lead_paragraph: Patrons of Sweetgreen are very particular about their salads. When the company recently removed bacon and sriracha from the menu, customers took to social media to complain. But after a handful of Sweetgreen restaurants stopped accepting cash in January, barely anyone noticed, according to the company’s owners.

headline: Back-Stabbing and Threats of a ‘Suicide Parachute’ at Hershey
abstract: A leaked memo reveals strife in the trust that controls the Hershey Company and the school for at-risk children started by its founder, Milton Hershey.
lead_paragraph: HERSHEY, Pa. — One toasty afternoon in mid-July, four 10-year-old boys gave a tour of their home at the Milton Hershey School, a boarding school for at-risk children and one of many gifts bequeathed by the chocolate magnate to the community that bears his name.

headline: Why Is the Stock Market So High? Ask the Bond Market
abstract: Bonds have risen sharply in value, and their yields have plummeted. That has made stock prices look cheap and dividends seem generous, driving up the market.
lead_paragraph: The American stock market has reached new highs this summer for some unsettling reasons.

headline: How to Deal With a Foreign Colleague Who Can’t Say No
abstract: In some countries, saying no is rude, so you may not be able to count on a co-worker’s “yes.” Communicating globally requires adapting to such differences.
lead_paragraph: When I worked as a global media coordinator for the United Nations several years ago, I organized biweekly conference calls, during which I would ask my colleagues around the world to provide information by particular deadlines. My colleagues almost always responded with a resounding yes, but all too often the deadlines came and went without the requested material, leaving me bewildered and upset.

headline: Lesson From a Doughnut Fryer Debacle: Let the eBay Seller Beware
abstract: When a buyer labels a doughnut fryer defective and eBay sides with her, the seller, who has evidence to the contrary, seeks help from the Haggler.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler wins so many showdowns that you might think he doesn’t know how to lose. The truth is more nuanced. The Haggler loses now and then. But when he loses, he keeps it to himself. So what you see in this space is carefully edited to minimize embarrassment. It’s like a list of Meryl Streep movies, minus “Mamma Mia!”

headline: Fender Benders on Water? (See: Expanded Panama Canal)
abstract: A section of the new, larger sea lane has troubled veteran ship pilots, and led to an accident involving a Chinese container ship.
lead_paragraph: It is a section of Panama’s newly expanded canal that has troubled veteran canal workers.

headline: A Fund-Raiser Planting Seeds to Improve Young Patients’ Lives
abstract: Rachel Wobschall builds relationships with donors to Gillette Children’s Specialty Healthcare to help fund treatment for children, teens and young adults.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Wobschall, 57, is senior major gift officer for Gillette Children’s Specialty Healthcare in St. Paul.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Joel Fagliano returns with Puns and Anagrams.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Joel Fagliano made his Puns and Anagrams debut at the end of last year and he returns with another knee-slapper/brain-twister today.

headline: Sharde Simpson and Ken Douglas: Finding an Apartment, and Much More
abstract: “Are you seriously looking for an apartment?” the real estate broker asked his future bride. “You look like you’re 12 years old.”
lead_paragraph: Sharde Simpson, the daughter of Sheila Williams of Newark, Del., was married July 30 to Ken Hollis Douglas, a son of Christine Thomas and Chesley Douglas of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Laurie S. Brockway, a minister ordained by the New Seminary for Interfaith Studies, officiated at Giando on the Water, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Dara Gordon and Chris McCoy: Casting a Comedy, Finding a Romantic Lead
abstract: A talent manager calls the director of a comedy called “Good Kids,” and love ensues.
lead_paragraph: Dara Lynn Gordon and Chris McCoy were married July 30 at the Foxfire Mountain House, an inn in Mount Tremper, N.Y. Robert J. Berson, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

headline: U.S. Wrestles With How to Fight Back Against Cyberattacks
abstract: The hacking into Democratic campaign computer systems is forcing the White House to confront a new question: whether, and if so how, to retaliate.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — It has been an open secret throughout the Obama presidency that world powers have escalated their use of cyberpower. But the recent revelations of hacking into Democratic campaign computer systems in an apparent attempt to manipulate the 2016 election is forcing the White House to confront a new question: whether, and if so how, to retaliate.

headline: Hot-Air Balloon Crash in Texas Kills 16, Officials Say
abstract: Officials said the craft caught fire in midair and plummeted to the ground in what appeared to be the worst balloon accident in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: LOCKHART, Tex. — A hot-air balloon carrying 16 people caught fire and crashed in Central Texas on Saturday, officials said, and the local authorities said no one had survived.

headline: Custom Wedges Offer Words of Confidence, or Crassness
abstract: Justin Thomas has a childhood nickname. Andrew Johnston has cuts of meat. No matter what a player has engraved on his wedges, they show he has made it.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Since he started engraving his wedges with funny quotes from his favorite movies two years ago, Robert Streb has envisioned the moment in which his puerile sense of humor might actually help him on the course.

headline: How to Counter the Putin Playbook
abstract: Undermining democracies is part of Russia’s plan to extend its influence. The U.S. must push back.
lead_paragraph: Palo Alto, Calif. — A quarter-century ago, at the end of the Cold War, it seemed that only democracies promoted their values abroad. Today, autocracies have entered the arena again, exporting their ideas and methods — even to the United States.

headline: Biggest Ads of the Campaign So Far: The Convention Videos
abstract: The biographical videos shown at the Republican and Democratic conventions amounted to some of the most important ads of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Carried live and uninterrupted on network television, the lengthy biographical videos broadcast on the final nights of the Republican and Democratic conventions, with their Hollywood narrations and slick packaging, amounted to some of the most important advertisements of the entire presidential campaign.

headline: A Glass Ceiling Now Broken, Is U.S. Ready for a Madam President?
abstract: With Hillary Clinton’s historic nomination, Americans are confronting the country’s poor record of putting women in positions of power.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — First a black president and now, just maybe, a woman. Karen Willis, an African-American delegate to this week’s Democratic convention here, was exhilarated by the historic possibilities of Hillary Clinton’s election run, viewing it as a natural succession to Barack Obama’s eight years in power. But when it comes to persuading voters, she noted, Mrs. Clinton’s gender milestone was the one thing her party was likely to play down.

headline: Tigers-Mets Deal Proves a Win-Win
abstract: A year ago at the trade deadline, Detroit dealt Yoenis Cespedes for two pitchers, including Michael Fulmer, who is 9-2 with a 2.50 E.R.A. this season.
lead_paragraph: When the nonwaiver trading deadline arrives Monday at 4 p.m., players across baseball will have a much better sense of their immediate futures. But they should not take the deadline as absolute.

headline: Chickens Uncaged
abstract: Readers respond to “Clearing the Cages but Maybe Not the Conscience” (July 17).

headline: Research and the Corporation
abstract: A reader responds to “They Promised Us Jet Packs” (July 24).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Quiet Protest Helped Tina Charles Find the Voice of Her Conscience
abstract: Charles has dominated the W.N.B.A. with her play and has found a platform to address social issues, particularly gun violence.
lead_paragraph: July has been a momentous month for Liberty center Tina Charles.

headline: Study Finds Chinese Students Excel in Critical Thinking. Until College.
abstract: As university enrollment surges in China, apathy and poor teaching are eating away at advantages seen in primary and secondary schools, research out of Stanford suggests.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese primary and secondary schools are often derided as grueling, test-driven institutions that churn out students who can recite basic facts but have little capacity for deep reasoning.

headline: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
abstract: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: I accompanied Iraq’s elite counterterrorism force and other units from the Iraqi military and the federal police into Falluja at the end of June, during the final days of their long battle to wrest back control of the city from the Islamic State.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Your Self-Driving-Car Manual
abstract: Sit back and let your new Golem Zombie act out for you.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations on the purchase of your 2017 Golem Zombie, the world’s most technologically advanced self-driving vehicle. This Quick Start manual will get you going to enjoy the best-in-class features that only the fully autonomous Golem Zombie provides, liberating you to enjoy the open road without the responsibilities of driving.

headline: Why Hillary Should Fear Optimism
abstract: In an anxious era, Democratic bromides won’t win over Americans deeply dissatisfied with their politicians.
lead_paragraph: If the last two weeks of our political life have seemed extra long, it is because we have gone through not two but four political conventions.

headline: A Few Simple Truths on Immigration
abstract: Careful examination of the facts undermines the claims of Donald Trump and his allies.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and his allies at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland peddled two falsehoods about America’s immigration problem. One was the vision presented by speaker after speaker of a nation overrun with foreigners crossing American borders and infiltrating communities to rob and kill. Another was the notion that most Americans are desperate for the kind of tough-guy response — including massive deportation and building a wall — that Mr. Trump offers as his solution.

headline: Virginia’s Century-Old Mentality on Race
abstract: A state court was wrong in ruling against Gov. Terry McAuliffe’s order restoring the voting rights of thousands of people with felony convictions.
lead_paragraph: The Virginia Supreme Court erred earlier this month when it ruled that Gov. Terry McAuliffe’s blanket executive order restoring the voting rights of more than 200,000 people who had been barred from voting for felony convictions violated the state Constitution.

headline: The Path to Prosperity Is Blue
abstract: States dominated by Democrats are generally better for your well-being.
lead_paragraph: HOW can America’s leaders foster broad prosperity? For most Republicans — including Donald J. Trump — the main answer is to “cut and extract”: Cut taxes and business regulations, including pesky restrictions on the extraction of natural resources, and the economy will boom.

headline: Thanks, Obama
abstract: The Audacity of Hope has downshifted to the Banality of Practicality.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — IT wasn’t easy for Barack Obama, a skinny newcomer to national politics with an exotic name and scant résumé, to overthrow the voracious Clinton machine.

headline: Liberalism’s Big Bet
abstract: Wooing anti-Trump Republicans with symbolism, swinging left on substance.
lead_paragraph: THE key pivot point in the Democratic convention arrived during President Obama’s speech on Wednesday, when he told the throng of Democrats that Donald Trump’s baleful convention rhetoric “wasn’t particularly Republican — and it sure wasn’t conservative.”

headline: Punishment That Doesn’t Fit the Crime
abstract: Thousands of youths, many guilty of nothing more than indecent exposure, are on sexual registries. The policy dooms many to lives of isolation.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — When Matthew Grottalio was 10 years old, he and his older brother initiated a touching “game” with their 8-year-old sister. “None of us knew what we were doing,” he said, and he soon forgot about the episode. But later that year, 1998, his sister’s teacher found out and notified the authorities. Just weeks after Matthew’s 11th birthday, police officers handcuffed him outside his fifth-grade classroom.

headline: What Babies Know About Physics and Foreign Languages
abstract: Our kids don’t need to be taught in order to learn.
lead_paragraph: Parents and policy makers have become obsessed with getting young children to learn more, faster. But the picture of early learning that drives them is exactly the opposite of the one that emerges from developmental science.

headline: A Woman-Child in Jamaica
abstract: You’re like us now, my mother and grandmother said. I wasn’t ready to be.
lead_paragraph: At 10 years old I was called into the living room by my mother and my grandmother. “Hurry up an’ sit, chile,” my grandmother said, her command like a hand pressed against my back, shoving me forward onto the plastic-covered sofa. After a moment of silence, my mother spoke. She told me she never again wanted to see me dancing and playing in public as I had been that morning. I was confused. I did not know that practicing my cartwheels and splits on the long veranda warranted such reprimand.

headline: The Trouble for Hillary
abstract: She’s the sunnier candidate, but these are stormier times.
lead_paragraph: Watching the Democrats’ smoothly staged, potently scripted convention last week, voters could easily think that Hillary Clinton has this election in the bag.

headline: Waters Most Foul at the Olympics
abstract: The woes facing the Rio Games pose a question: Why do cities court the extraordinary demands and expenses of the Olympics?
lead_paragraph: The report in The Times last week about the raw sewage in the waters off Rio de Janeiro, in which Olympic swimmers, sailors and windsurfers will be competing, shocked the senses. Marathon swimmers will be literally churning through human waste, said one physician; sailors have to keep their mouths closed when they are hit with spray, said a member of the Dutch sailing team.

headline: When Women Win, Men Win, Too
abstract: Research shows broad benefits of shattered glass ceilings.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a woman breaks a glass ceiling and becomes the presidential nominee of a major political party, what should men think?

headline: Quotes from Hillary Clinton’s Convention
abstract: Rounding up some of the notable things that were said at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: When someone is cruel or acts like a bully, you don’t stoop to their level. No, our motto is, when they go low, we go high.

headline: With a Million-Dollar Arm, a Softball League Makes Its Pitch
abstract: Monica Abbott signed a $1 million contract with the newest National Pro Fastpitch franchise in May, a sign that the league is ready to grow. But to do so, it may need corporate sponsors.
lead_paragraph: Monica Abbott was barely a year out of college when she won a silver medal with the United States softball team at the 2008 Summer Olympics. Now 31, she has not had a chance to win another.

headline: How Benjamin Netanyahu Is Crushing Israel’s Free Press
abstract: In the last year and a half, the prime minister has sought to turn Israeli media into his own private empire.
lead_paragraph: In its annual report released this spring, Freedom House, an American democracy advocacy organization, downgraded Israel’s freedom of the press ranking from “free” to “partly free.” To anyone following Israeli news media over the past year and a half, this was hardly surprising. Freedom House focused primarily on the “unchecked expansion” of paid content in editorial pages, as well as on the outsize influence of Israel Hayom (“Israel Today”), a free daily newspaper owned by the American casino magnate Sheldon Adelson and widely believed to promote the views of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Red in Beak and Claw
abstract: It’s nesting season, and there’s a blood bath near the birdbath.
lead_paragraph: Nashville — Two years ago, a day before the baby bluebirds were due to hatch, I checked the nest box just outside my office window and found a tiny hole in one of the eggs. Believing it must be the beginnings of a hatching, I resolved not to check again right away, though the itch to peek was nearly unbearable: I’d been waiting years for a family of bluebirds to take up residence, and finally an egg was about to shudder and pop open. Two days later, I realized I hadn’t seen either parent in some time, so I checked again and found all five eggs missing. The nest was undisturbed.

headline: Frans de Waal
abstract: A primatologist on the feelings of plants, watching fish and biking with abandon.
lead_paragraph: Frans de Waal is a Dutch-American primatologist who studies the parallels between human and ape social behavior, particularly relating to empathy, outrage, peacemaking, conflict and cooperation. His latest book is “Are We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are?”

headline: Common Core Regrets?
abstract: Readers differ on the value of educational standards.
lead_paragraph: Readers say progress has mostly been made under national education standards.

headline: The Next Derek Jeter? The Yankees Are Suddenly Full of Possibilities
abstract: Gleyber Torres, acquired from the Cubs in the Aroldis Chapman trade, is among a number of prospects at shortstop.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — To cut through the drudgery of batting practice on another steamy 96-degree day, the Yankees’ high Class-A affiliate in Tampa, Fla., turns the last round into a contest. For each swing a batter takes, the field is filled with imaginary position players who resemble the hitting coach Tom Slater, which is another of way of saying they do not cover much ground. The bases are filled with imaginary runners who all resemble Jorge Mateo, the team’s shortstop prospect, who runs the bases as if he has wings.

headline: John Kerr, Chronicler of Freud-Jung Rift, Is Dead at 66
abstract: Mr. Kerr wrote a book about the theorists’ feud, which became the basis for a play and a movie, and edited books written by psychologists.
lead_paragraph: John Kerr, an editor, literary muse and confidant for a generation of Freudian scholars and the author of “A Most Dangerous Method,” the book that became the basis for a play and a movie about the famous feud between Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, died on July 18 in Portland, Me. He was 66.

headline: Forest Hills Stadium, Cradle of the United States Open, Is Reborn
abstract: Six years after the West Side Tennis Club considered selling the stadium to developers, it will again host professional tennis.
lead_paragraph: Forest Hills Stadium was falling apart in 2012. Wooden benches were decaying, and weeds were growing beneath them. The old tennis court, so steeped in history, had cracks running throughout. Concrete fell from the passageways as a result of water damage.

headline: Russian News Group Walks Tightrope in Covering U.S. Election
abstract: RT, formerly known as Russia Today, has long been scrutinized for being a propaganda outlet of sorts for the Putin government, which oversees its finances.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The American news media is wildly overplaying Russia’s role in a major email leak. The Democratic National Convention was troubled by chaos and dissent. Donald J. Trump’s request for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to hack Democratic emails was a joke that American pundits simply did not get.

headline: Electoral Map Gives Donald Trump Few Places to Go
abstract: The Republican candidate intends to focus on three or four states his campaign believes he must sweep, but his path to election looks ever narrower.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, confronting a daunting electoral map and a significant financial disadvantage, is preparing to fall back from an expansive national campaign and concentrate the bulk of his time and money on just three or four states that his campaign believes he must sweep in order to win the presidency.

headline: Carson Wentz, the Eagles’ Future, Patiently Awaits His Turn
abstract: Wentz started at quarterback for just one season in high school and two in college. It may be another year before he sees the field as a pro.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As the Democratic convention took place on Thursday, the Eagles’ rookie quarterback Carson Wentz was just across the street participating in his first full-squad training camp practice. Security restricted access to the roads near the facility, and rain forced the Eagles to practice indoors. Only team personnel and members of the news media were there to watch Wentz, the second pick in April’s N.F.L. draft, begin his career in earnest.

headline: Doctors Are Improperly Billing Some on Medicare, U.S. Says
abstract: Federal officials have warned doctors that they may be subject to penalties if they persist in these practices and could be fined or excluded from Medicare.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Doctors are improperly billing poor people on Medicare for deductibles, co-payments and other costs from which they are supposed to be exempt, the Obama administration says.

headline: The Mets Are Clutchless, and Clueless Too
abstract: They are on pace to have the second-worst batting average with runners in scoring position in baseball history, and team officials do not know why.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Mets have prayed that one hit — a bloop, a squibbler, a ball just out of a defender’s reach — would spark a change in their offense. And the eighth inning of Friday night’s 6-1 loss to the Colorado Rockies seemed to provide such an opportunity. The first two batters, Alejandro De Aza and Curtis Granderson, reached on singles.

headline: Malaysia’s Leader, Dogged by a Billion-Dollar Scandal, Proves Untouchable
abstract: Over Najib Razak’s 40 years in public office, and through accusations of kickbacks, ties to a murder and more, he has been easy to underestimate.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The conspirators were confident. They planned to confront Malaysia’s prime minister, Najib Razak, at a cabinet meeting and demand his resignation. Prosecutors had collected evidence that Mr. Najib had deposited millions of dollars of public money into his personal bank account. Attorney General Abdul Gani Patail was ready to file criminal charges, according to Najib advisers and opposition leaders.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Donald Trump Criticizes Muslim Family of Slain U.S. Soldier, Drawing Ire
abstract: In an ABC interview, Mr. Trump implied that Ghazala Khan’s silence while her husband spoke about their soldier son’s death at the Democratic convention may have been because of her Muslim faith.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump belittled the parents of a slain Muslim soldier who had strongly denounced Mr. Trump during the Democratic National Convention, saying that the soldier’s father had delivered the entire speech because his mother was not “allowed” to speak.

headline: Texas Marks ’66 Sniper Attack as University Prepares for ‘Campus-Carry’ Law
abstract: The University of Texas will mark one of the bloodiest campus shootings in U.S. history on the day that a state law permitting concealed firearms on campus takes effect.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — On Aug. 1, 1966, Charles Whitman ascended the University of Texas clock tower here with a trunk full of weapons and unleashed 96 minutes of terror that effectively became a template for mass shootings and aroused in the public a new sensitivity to the threat of violence in public spaces.

headline: Make That a Double
abstract: Ruth Margolin returns with a puzzle that’s double the fun.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If there is one thing that trips me up when it comes to solving, it’s a rebus. If there’s two things that trip me up when it comes to solving, it’s a double rebus.

headline: Zika Cases in Puerto Rico Are Skyrocketing
abstract: Thousands of islanders — and up to 50 pregnant women — are getting infected every day with the mosquito-borne virus.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The Zika epidemic that has spread from Brazil to the rest of Latin America is now raging in Puerto Rico — and the island’s response is in chaos.

headline: Secrets, Denial, and, Decades Later, a Medal of Honor for a Vietnam Medic
abstract: Sgt. Gary Rose, a medic with an elite group of commandos in 1970, is to receive the first Medal of Honor acknowledging the heroics of a soldier on the ground in the Secret War in Laos.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — Unofficially, in the jungles of Laos in 1970, hundreds of North Vietnamese troops closed in on a small team of United States Army commandos. Unofficially, as men were shot down, a medic sprinted through a hail of bullets to help, hefting a man over his shoulder as he fired back with one hand. Unofficially, even when bloodied by a rocket, the medic kept going, not sleeping for days as he cared for 51 wounded soldiers.

headline: Nationals Trade for Mark Melancon, Who Led Majors in Saves Last Season
abstract: Keeping up with the rival Cubs, Washington bolsters the back of its bullpen. Each team acquired a pitcher who can be a free agent after the season.
lead_paragraph: Five days after another National League rival acquired a top closer, the Washington Nationals traded Saturday for Pittsburgh’s Mark Melancon, bolstering the back of their bullpen with a three-time All-Star.

headline: In Pennsylvania, Hillary Clinton Cites Economic Gains, and Challenges
abstract: On a bus tour that is also taking her to another crucial state, Ohio, Mrs. Clinton continued her balancing act on the economy.
lead_paragraph: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. — On the second day of a three-day bus tour through Pennsylvania and Ohio, Hillary Clinton continued a balancing act: painting a relatively rosy picture of national progress under President Obama — in contrast to Donald J. Trump’s grim appraisal of the country’s state — while insisting there is much more to be done.

headline: Rain Delays P.G.A. Championship, Bringing Scheduling Under Fire
abstract: A forecast of continued rain for the area around Baltusrol could delay the tournament through Monday or Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, N.J. — Thunderstorms and steady rain interrupted the third round of the 2016 P.G.A. Championship on Saturday afternoon, and after a nearly four-hour delay, play was suspended until Sunday morning.

headline: HBO Gives ‘Game of Thrones’ an End Date
abstract: While discussing the demise of “Vinyl” and the coming show “Westworld,” a network executive also responded to criticism of HBO’s depiction of sexual violence against women.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “Vinyl” wasn’t worth it anymore, “Game of Thrones” will run for two more seasons, and “Curb Your Enthusiasm” will be back next year.

headline: Even With Alex Rodriguez in Lineup, Yankees’ Offense Struggles
abstract: Rodriguez, in the role of cleanup hitter, struck out in all four of his at-bats as the Yankees fell to the Tampa Bay Rays on the road.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez arrived at the ballpark Saturday afternoon to find his name penciled into the lineup for the first time in eight days. When the Yankees had faced the Astros left-hander Dallas Keuchel, Rodriguez was on the bench. When he had celebrated his 41st birthday, Rodriguez was on the bench.

headline: The Mets Welcome Mike Piazza Home and Give His Jersey a Spot in History
abstract: Before Saturday’s game against the Rockies, the Mets honored the former catcher Mike Piazza, who was inducted into the Hall of Fame last week, with a jersey retirement ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Mike Piazza paused, wiped his left eye and thanked the roaring Citi Field crowd. Piazza, the Mets’ former star catcher, was looking for an opening in the applause to begin his speech before Saturday’s pregame ceremony in which the team retired his jersey number.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, July 31, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Because we were where we weren’t supposed to be, a lot of men never got what they deserved. Rose is one of them.”

headline: Skydiver Survives Jump From 25,000 Feet, and Without a Parachute
abstract: With a live television audience watching, Luke Aikins, a veteran jumper, drops into a net less than half the size of a football field in the California desert.
lead_paragraph: If you think skydiving is scary, try doing it from twice the usual height and without a parachute. After two minutes of free-fall, you must position yourself to land on a net less than half the size of a football field, spread out 200 feet above the earth.

headline: Jennifer Burlenski, Steven Lorch
abstract: A museum administrator and a tax lawyer were introduced in Manhattan in 2013 through mutual friends.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lynn Burlenski and Steven James Lorch were married July 30 in New Haven. The Rev. Marek P. Zabriskie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church.

headline: Heather Levin, Joshua Polsky
abstract: The couple, who met through Tinder, were married in East Meadow, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Heather Ilyssa Levin and Joshua Samuel Polsky were married July 30 at the Carltun in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Nacht officiated.

headline: Caitlin Cassidy, Sanjay Nair
abstract: The bride and groom, who met at Holy Trinity High School in Hicksville, N.Y, were married in Smithtown, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Margaret Cassidy, the daughter of Kathleen T. Cassidy and John E. Cassidy of Westbury, N.Y., was married July 30 to Sanjay Vijayan Nair, the son of Dr. Suja Vijayan and Vijay Nair of Mansfield, Tex. Pandit Mahesh Shastriji, a Hindu priest, officiated the Hindu ceremony at the Watermill, an event space in Smithtown, N.Y.

headline: Jean Taylor Ellis, James Tedesco
abstract: The bride, a geography professor, and the groom, a firefighter, were married in Middletown, R.I.
lead_paragraph: Jean Taylor Ellis and James Joseph Tedesco IV were married July 26 at Sachuest Beach in Middletown, R.I. The Rev. Donald Beach, who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: Irena Ajic, Matthew Jacobs
abstract: The bride and groom, who met at a rock-climbing gym, were married in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Irena Lana Ajic, the daughter of Vesna Ajic and Louie Ajic, both of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married July 27 to Matthew Leonard Jacobs, a son of Lisa M. Jacobs and Steven H. Jacobs of Sarasota, Fla. Matt Amar, a Universal Life minister who is a friend of the couple, officiated at the couple’s apartment in Los Angeles.

headline: Mary Wright, David Cavicke
abstract: The bride and groom met through eHarmony in 2014.
